title: Talbot leaders, community remember 9/11 on Patriots Day
content:
Talbot leaders, community remember 9/11 on Patriots Day

 September 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A1 | Section: News 
 
 780
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Local leaders and community members joined together at the corner of West and Dover streets Monday morning to honor the many heroic sacrifices made by Americans on Sept. 11, 2001.The 9/11 Day of Remembrance ceremony, held at Easton's Service Memorial, was originally slated to start at 8:30 a.m., but began slightly later due to a brief but sudden downpour.The commemorative event featured remarks from local elected officials, a presentation of flags by local law enforcement officers, patriotic music from the Easton Middle School band and prayers from community faith leaders."Never forget the strength of our community. Never forget all that we have accomplished and will accomplish by working together," Easton Mayor Megan Cook said. "Never forget that every day our lives are in each other's hands, and never forget that when the chips are down, our humanity shines brightest." The crowd also observed a moment of silence and the tolling of bells to remember the heroes of that day.Pete Lesher, vice president of the Talbot County Council, served as the event's keynote speaker."We look back to those days after Sept. 11, 2001, remembering how we came together as one. How we - as a community support our community," he said."We have risen to the challenge when we have heard the call in the past, and we will most assuredly have to do so again sometime in the future." "And when we face that outside challenge, we will remember that, after all, we are truly one," Lesher said. "We are a community that supports our community." The ceremony was followed by an art show at the Talbot County Free Library, which featured artwork created by community members this summer. The show also included the unveiling of "Community," a public art installation.Throughout the summer, local volunteers worked together to help strengthen relationships between members of the community by supporting projects that exemplified the theme, "We Are One: Community Supporting Community." The project is one of many across the country that pays tribute to the individuals lost and injured on 9/11 and honors the first responders and many others who have risen to service in a crisis.The purpose of the awareness effort is to empower the general public to be caring, responsive community members should their fellow citizens need their support, and to be mindful of the work of first responders in their community.The Easton Economic Development Corporation, along with the Talbot County Department of Emergency Services and the Talbot County Chamber of Commerce Young Professionals, were awarded a $10,000 grant from The Arc of the United States in collaboration with the Ameri-Corps/September 11 Day of Service and Remembrance Project for the collaborative community educational event series.Another local effort to commemorate the 22nd anniversary of 9/11 came in the form of a short film.EEDC, in coordination with the Talbot County government, released the film Monday to provide a snapshot of resiliency within the community.Funded through the nationwide grant program from AmeriCorps, the film asks Talbot County leaders to reflect on the history and aftermath of 9/11, but also challenges them to look to the future.Deena Kilmon, the director of strategic initiatives at EEDC, said the organization's goal with the film is to share how the Talbot County community is prepared for a crisis or emergency."Most importantly, we hope to encourage our residents of all ages to answer that call to help others, and empower our youth to understand that they too have the power to effect change and improve the outcome of a crisis event," she said.TheTown of Easton, Talbot County government, the Talbot County Department of Emergency Services, and Talbot Young Professionals all served as partners on the yearlong grant.Local officials from town, county and state government participated in the film, along with community leaders."We have to take time to capture the history of 9/11 with interviews from those who still remember it firsthand," said Talbot County Manager Clay Stamp. "That is how we learn from our past and ensure that we are prepared for the future." The 10-minute film was filmed and edited by Mid-Shore Community Television.The video can be viewed on social media and the Talbot County website.

title: '25 kids should not take this whole city down' - Cambridge council grapples with youth crime in city
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
'25 kids should not take this whole city down' - Cambridge council grapples with youth crime in city

 September 14, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 610
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - Youth issues were the overwhelming theme for the third Cambridge City Council meeting in a row.At the Sept. 12 meeting, residents and commissioners alike made comments about juvenile crime.Lance Cephas, who is the father of Commission President Lajan Cephas and Commissioner Sputty Cephas, said crime is affecting everyone, including the children and families who aren't part of the problem.He further noted the children who aren't contributing to juvenile crime are being punished for the actions of about 25 children, "25 kids should not take this whole city down," he said.Lance Cephas stressed the importance of educating the kids that are caught doing things they shouldn't be."Because if you send them back home to that same environment, ain't nothing going to happen," he said. "A lot of police officers, they'll pick them up, they'll let them go, and soon as they're around the corner, they've done something else to somebody else. So you've got to get them and educate them." He said he understood both his children's, Lajan and Sputty, and Mayor Stephen Rideout's points of view regarding the juvenile curfew but said the council shouldn't be "at each other's throats" and "controlled by 25 kids." "We've all got to come together," he said.In late August, Rideout vetoed a juvenile curfew ordinance which commissioners had passed Aug. 14.Before that, in July, Rideout had proposed an alternative curfew ordinance which had additions and changes from the original curfew ordinance. These included adding definitions and altering language on enforcement procedures and penalties.Since Rideout vetoed the original curfew ordinance, Sputty Cephas has made amendments to Rideout's alternative ordinance in an effort to compromise and "find middle ground." According to council meeting documents, Cephas plans to recommend these amendments Sept. 25 when Rideout's proposed ordinance will be read for a second time.During the meeting, Sputty Cephas talked about finding that middle ground."Commissioner Atkiss made a point to say that $100 is a lot of money for a struggling parent," he said."My day job is in banking, so I understand that struggle as well." Sputty Cephas said he would like to keep fines as part of the penalty for not following the curfew, but said he cut them in half in his amendment. Instead of a $100 fine, it would be $50.At the end of the meeting, Rideout suggested to Sputty Cephas that the two of them get together to talk about the proposed amendments to the alternative ordinance. Sputty Cephas agreed to meet.Two presentations were given during Monday's meeting, as well. One presentation was given by Pam Gregory, president and CEO of United Way of the Lower Eastern Shore, and one by Lisa Molock, chief executive director at Let's Thrive Baltimore and an organizer for Moms Demand Action for Gun Sense in America.Molock talked about the work she has been doing in Baltimore, and Gregory talked about the economic issues that many Marylanders face. She shared data from a report that focused on asset limited, income constrained and employed (or ALICE) Marylanders and shared data on Dorchester County residents specifically. Gregory said that in Dorchester County, 45% of residents are below the ALICE threshold.During public comment, Theresa Stafford said poverty is a "lead driver" for many other issues in Cambridge."We need to get serious about fixing the problem of poverty," Stafford said."Bringing in industries or businesses that will pay good wages, and of course, supporting getting kids educated because that's the other key driver that keeps driving up the crime."

title: It's time to confront ongoing youth violence
author: Armstrong Williams
content:
It's time to confront ongoing youth violence

 September 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Armstrong Williams | Page: 7 | Section: News 
 
 689
 Words 

 Read News Document

 If you go to Google and type "heinous crimes up with young people," you'll see over 2 billion results.It's a stark reminder that the alarming trend of young people committing gruesome acts isn't a new phenomenon, but the sheer proliferation and frequency of these acts most certainly is. Our society is grappling with a disconcerting reality - a reality born out of the convergence of various factors.From the messages embedded in our music to the desensitizing violence prevalent in our culture, and even the erosion of moral and ethical values, each contributes to the emergence of a more violent society.It's a society where individuals no longer temper their darkest impulses, and regrettably, it's our youth who often find themselves on the frontline, manifesting behaviors at an unacceptable rate. This is a phenomenon that should deeply trouble us all and lead us to pause in concern for the direction in which our society is headed.These young individuals, driven by a cocktail of influences, often react impulsively or, in the gravest of cases, meticulously plan calculated crimes that result in the loss of innocent lives. We've witnessed stories like that of Mackenzie Shirilla, a name etched into the annals of a society grappling with the aftermath of senseless violence.Shirilla was recently found guilty of the murder of her boyfriend, Dominic Russo, and her friend, Davion Flanagan. Their tragic deaths underscore the gravity of the situation we're facing - a situation where young people are becoming entangled in webs of aggression and desperation. In Shirilla's case, she purposely sped up her car to 100 mph and drove straight into a wall, instantly killing her boyfriend and friend.The breakdown of morality in our society is contributing to this disturbing trend. Traditional values that once served as guiding principles seem to be waning, leaving a moral vacuum in which right and wrong are increasingly ambiguous. The erosion of moral foundations means that young people are less equipped to distinguish between ethical choices and destructive actions.The deterioration of ethics further compounds the issue. Ethical conduct is the cornerstone of a civilized society, fostering a sense of responsibility and accountability. Yet, as we witness these disturbing trends among our youth, it becomes evident that the concept of ethics is losing its grip. The pursuit of personal gain, even at the expense of others, has become alarmingly normalized.As we reflect on these developments, the implications for our future are profoundly concerning. A society that permits the erosion of morality and ethics in its younger generation is sowing the seeds of its own demise. The actions of today's youth foreshadow the trajectory of tomorrow's adults. If we fail to address these concerning trends, we risk a future marked by increased violence, social fragmentation and a dearth of empathy.It's time for us to confront these unsettling truths and take meaningful action. By reemphasizing morality and ethics in our families, communities and institutions, we can recalibrate the moral compass of our youth. This requires an unwavering commitment to fostering values that prioritize human dignity, compassion and respect for one another. Only through concerted efforts to restore these foundational principles can we hope to guide our society toward a more harmonious and promising future.This alarming trend of young people exhibiting violence and aggression should serve as an urgent wake-up call for our educational institutions. We must prioritize emotional education alongside academic excellence. By equipping our youth with the tools to manage their emotions, resolve conflicts constructively and communicate effectively, we can help curb the escalation of anger and violence.It's imperative that our schools become places not only of intellectual growth but also of emotional well-being and character development.The rising wave of heinous acts committed by young people underscores the pressing need for a comprehensive societal response. We must address the erosion of morality and ethics, and we must prioritize emotional education within our education system. This is a challenge that requires the collective effort of families, communities, educators and cultural influencers. By refocusing on our shared values, investing in the emotional well-being of our youth and fostering a renewed sense of empathy, we can shape a society that rejects violence and paves the way for a brighter and more harmonious future.COPYRIGHT 2023 CREATORS.COM

title: Cambridge OKs revised curfew for youth in city - New ordinance applies to juveniles under 16
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Cambridge OKs revised curfew for youth in city - New ordinance applies to juveniles under 16

 September 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 621

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - Nearly three months after Cambridge's temporary juvenile curfew ended, the city council has passed a new curfew ordinance.The curfew will last 12 months, beginning Oct. 1.It will end Sept. 30, 2024, unless it is extended or approved as part of the city code.The curfew will make it so that juveniles under 16 cannot be in a public place within the city between the hours of 10 p.m. and 5 a.m. on Sundays through Thursdays and 11 p.m. through 5 a.m. on Fridays and Saturdays. There are exceptions to this, however, including when the juvenile is with a parent or when the juvenile is on the way home from work or a school activity.The curfew passed in a four to one vote Monday evening. All city commissioners voted in favor of reinstating the curfew except for Ward 3 Commissioner Jameson Harrington.This vote comes more than a month after Mayor Stephen Rideout vetoed another version of a curfew that commissioners had passed at an Aug. 14 meeting.The failed ordinance used the same language as the temporary curfew that was in place from February through June.The newly passed ordinance, which was drafted based on proposed amendments from Rideout, passed with a number of amendments.Rideout's drafted ordinance included the addition of definitions and alterations to language on enforcement procedures and penalties. It eliminated language that allowed parents to be fined for a child's actions.It also implemented the Children in Need of Supervision process in the event the family refuses to participate in services requested by the Local Care Team, a collaborative group of local agencies serving families. In this process, the Department of Juvenile Services would have the authority to refer the youth to appropriate services, employ a precourt supervision agreement where the youth and family agree to certain conditions like participating in services, or file a petition with the juvenile court.In September, Ward 4 Commissioner Sputty Cephas proposed amendments to Rideout's drafted curfew ordinance.Cephas' version adds a penalties section which penalizes parents if their child is given a curfew violation following an initial written warning. The penalty would be $50 for a first offense and $100 for a second offense. Three or more violations of the ordinance would be forwarded to the Dorchester County State's Attorney's Office for review and could result in "additional crime charges against the parent."During the council meeting Monday, the mayor and commissioners went through Cephas' amendments line by line and voted on each one before voting on the entire amended curfew ordinance. In this process, the council voted to include Cephas' addition of a penalties section to the ordinance, including fining families for juvenile offenses. Harrington and Ward 1 Commissioner Laurel Atkiss voted against amending the ordinance to include fines. However, the amendment still passed.The council voted to include wording so that, unless the child has previously violated the ordinance, the Cambridge police chief cannot proceed with further action.After this amendment passed, Rideout clarified with the police chief, "The fact that a child is uncooperative cannot give you any advance to do anything more about that particular case if it's a first-time offense."Before any action was taken on the ordinance, three residents spoke about the curfew.Jose J. Rodriguez said that a curfew needs to be in place."Responsibility starts with us, not with them," Rodriguez said about Cambridge's youth.At the end of the meeting, Atkiss thanked everyone for coming together to compromise and pass a curfew."I also want to be sure to remind everyone that the curfew is not the solution," she said. "It's just a tool in our toolbox. We still need to address our children and our education and our housing."

 HUNTINGTOWN, Md.- Four Caroline County heroes were honored Sept. 21 at an awards ceremony celebrating "a year of hard work, dedication to the profession, (and) a job well done for handling the numerous incidents that occur each day throughout the state."The Caroline County Department of Emergency Services recognized Lt.Cody Bennett, 911 specialist Marie Starkey, 911 specialist Erin Reibly and 911 specialist Tyler Edgar for their efforts during a Jan. 4 motor vehicle collision that claimed the lives of five people. 911 specialists from across Maryland gathered at the Huntingtown Volunteer Fire Department in Calvert County for the 911 Day of Celebration and Annual Awards Ceremony sponsored by the Maryland Emergency Numbers Association and the Maryland 9-1-1 Board.Emergency dispatch personnel from nine of Maryland's Public Safety Answering Points (911 Centers) took part in a brief training session provided by the 911 Training Institute's Jason Scott, a keynote speech by Russell Strickland, secretary of the Maryland Department of Emergency Management, lunch and an awards ceremony.Caroline County EMS recounted the efforts of the four responders on its Facebook page.At about 8:25 a.m.Wednesday, Jan. 4, the Caroline County Emergency Communications Center began receiving numerous 911 calls about a serious motor vehicle collision on Shore Highway in the area of Bullock Road.Those calls reported multiple people were trapped or ejected, the vehicle was on fire, and there were fatalities.The four members of the dispatch team processed the calls and dispatched resources."Upon arrival of the first EMS unit, the (responding) crew confirmed all the reports and went to work triaging the patients," Caroline County EMS posted."Numerous requests from EMS and law enforcement on the scene prior to Command being established were handled flawlessly with multiple updates being provided to responding fire units.Multiple aviation units were utilized as well as additional EMS units for ground transport.Firefighters arriving shortly thereafter handled the extrication and fire and assisted with patient packaging."All-in-all, the dispatch team maintained composure and acted with the utmost professionalism during a very trying incident," the Facebook post continued."They handled a multitude of requests from all responding agencies to provide the resources necessary. In the end, the incident would involve five fatalities among the seven people involved, with the additional two being transported to nearby medical facilities."Three fire departments, four paramedic units, two BLS (basic life support) units, three aviation units and numerous law enforcement personnel, along with the dispatch team did a hell of a job to provide for the best outcome possible. We are proud of their commitment and dedication to our citizens," the post continued."Now, some will say, so they did their job. Why yes, while they did their job, they did it with poise and compassion while managing other incidents to keep the county protected.  EASTON - An Easton teenager was arrested Thursday, Sept. 21 and charged as an adult after allegedly striking a woman in the head with a rock.Police said Denilson E. title: Ophelia a bust but still causes flooding
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Ophelia a bust but still causes flooding

 September 28, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 480
 Words 

 Read News Document

 HOOPERS ISLAND - Tropical Storm Ophelia caused flooding in parts of Dorchester County this past weekend."Luckily we didn't make out too badly with the storm," Dorchester County Emergency Management Planner Jimmy Windsor said.According to the National Hurricane Center, the storm made landfall near Emerald Isle in North Carolina Saturday.On Sunday, the center warned of continued coastal flooding "along portions of the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal rivers" for the rest of the day.Cambridge received 2.61 inches of rain between Friday, Sept. 22, and Sunday, Sept.24, according to the National Weather Service.The storm resulted in "moderate to borderline-major tidal flooding" in the county, particularly in its southern and far western areas, Windsor said. He added the areas most affected were the Hoopers Island area, Taylor's Island and the Wingate, Toddville and Bishops Head areas.Dorchester County Council member Rob Kramer monitored how the storm affected the county over the weekend.He said the road past the Hoopers Island Causeway "took a little bit of a beating." While the causeway had been closed Saturday, it has since been reopened.Windsor said Water Street in Cambridge also shut down temporarily due to the storm.Over the weekend, the Sheriff's Office was trying to limit traffic through Worlds End Turn as well, he said.The county's Department of Emergency Services had few, if any, flood-related calls over the weekend, Windsor said."I know the [Hoopers Island Volunteer Fire Company] assisted some people with getting back to their residences from places they were at on the island after it had started to flood," he said.As part of the county's contingency plan, the National Guard was brought into the county. Kramer said the county received the guards once Gov.Wes Moore declared a state of emergency in response to Tropical Storm Ophelia on Friday."They had brought a couple Humvees with them," Kramer said. "They were just a contingent plan in case we needed them." Windsor said while the county didn't end up needing assistance from the National Guard, it did some pre-deployment area reconnaissance "just to make sure they knew where they were going if they had to go anywhere." As of Wednesday, Windsor said most of the flood water has receded."There is still some high water areas in the lower part of the county, which is not being helped by the fact that we currently have a higher than usual tide cycle," he said. "But everything is back open." Windsor asked that the public use caution when traveling in those lower parts of the county in case the water has made it difficult to navigate the roads."In the grand scheme of things, this was minor compared to some of the storms we've had in the past," Kramer said.

title: Guilty but not held criminally responsible - 'I love you,' dad says to son who tried to kill him
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Guilty but not held criminally responsible - 'I love you,' dad says to son who tried to kill him

 September 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 997
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - The Ridgely man who struck his own father with a car in Cordova last December was found guilty, but not criminally responsible, of assault and related charges.Frank Justin Ashe Jr., 20, who goes by Justin, entered pleas to first-degree assault, use of a firearm in the commission of a violent crime and reckless endangerment, but maintained that he was not criminally responsible by reason of insanity - an argument that Talbot County Circuit Judge Stephen H. Kehoe later agreed with.The case against Justin stemmed from a reported assault in the 11000 block of Three Bridge Branch Road in Cordova around 3:30 p.m. on Dec. 4, 2022.In the roughly 90-minute hearing Thursday, the prosecution and defense shared two sides of the same story, providing joint insight on the day's events and Justin's mental state at the time.According to Frank J. Ashe Sr., Justin's father, his son wasn't acting like himself that morning, said Talbot County State's Attorney Joseph Coale. And to defense attorney Kisha Petticolas, Justin's unusual behavior had started some time before then.By all accounts, Justin was a normal kid who had never had problems, Petticolas said. But at some point in his teen years, he became fixated on Freemasonry, going down a social media rabbit hole that led to him seeing symbols and signs of the organization.Justin believed he knew too much and people wanted him eliminated because he knew their secrets, Pettico-las said. The night before, his mother had considered taking him to the hospital. And that day, he woke up "completely and positively sure" that someone was going to kill him.According to Coale, Justin, then 19, was in an outbuilding the afternoon of Dec. 4 when his father came to check on him. When Ashe Sr. entered, he found his son standing by the windows, holding a firearm and saying that someone was coming to get him, Coale said.Justin believed that the man who looked like his father was a clone who came to kill him, and the teen had armed himself for protection, Petti-colas said.Ashe Sr. told Justin to put the gun down, but Justin aimed it at his father.Ashe Sr. knew he needed to get the gun out of his son's hands and attempted to distract Justin. Ashe Sr. grabbed the gun, fighting to pull it away from Justin. But as the two wrestled, the gun went off, firing a bullet through a wall, Coale said.Justin ran out the back door of the outbuilding while Ashe Sr. went out the front door. He saw Justin get into a car and begin driving away, Coale said.But Justin turned the car around and accelerated toward his father, striking him and knocking him unconscious for several minutes.The family's security camera footage, which both father and son declined to view in court Thursday, captured the strike and the moments after. According to Coale, the video showed Justin approaching his father, taking the gun and stepping on his father's stomach and checking it for an old scar before getting back in the car.After regaining consciousness, Ashe Sr. was able to get up and enter his home, Coale said.Ashe Sr. suffered a broken back, brain bleeds and other smaller injuries from being struck with the car, Coale said. He was flown to the University of Maryland Shock Trauma in Baltimore for treatment.Justin's grandfather, who was inside the house, heard the earlier argument between the two men. By now, Justin had walked back into the house and was tackled by his grandfather, who was trying to secure the gun. A second shot was fired accidentally during the scuffle, according to the grandfather, Coale said.Justin drove off after the scuffle. Coale said he was apprehended by police on Interstate 95 near Rocky Mount, North Carolina, around 11 p.m. that night.Petticolas said while Justin's memory of the day didn't match what Coale presented, she acknowledged that the prosecution would have been able to produce those facts had the case gone to trial.Prior to rendering a verdict and final decision on the case, the court heard additional information to determine Justin's criminal responsibility.In a report from the Maryland Department of Health, a doctor diagnosed the 20-year-old with schizoaffective disorder, bipolar type. The diagnosis, along with Justin's behavior, paranoia and delusions, led to identical recommendations from the prosecution and defense - both asked the judge to find Justin not criminally responsible and commit him to the department.Justin's father provided tearful testimony in support of the best outcome for his son.Choked up with emotion, Ashe Sr. said he couldn't ask for a better son. He knew the teen wasn't trying to kill him, he said."What happened that day (was) just not my son," he said, later adding: "I didn't raise my son that way.""I love you, son," Ashe Sr. said, stepping off the witness stand. Across the courtroom, Justin replied: "I love you."To Petticolas, Justin's not criminally responsible plea was the clearest cut case she'd seen, and one in which justice could be found through the commitment to the Maryland Department of Health. The prosecution not arguing differently "speaks volumes," she said.And the Ashe family is "irreparably scarred," and they too need to heal, she said.After listening to the volume of testimony, Kehoe determined that Justin's actions directly stemmed from the delusions."(It's) clear to me beyond any question that he is not criminally responsible for what he did that day," he said.While Justin was found guilty, the lack of criminal responsibility finding in the case means that he will be committed to a state health department psychiatric hospital indefinitely until it's determined that he is not a danger.Not criminally responsible pleas are "fairly uncommon," according to Coale.After the hearing, Petticolas reflected on the the collegial practice within the smaller jurisdiction, which allowed the prosecution and defense to come up with results that served the public good, she said."I think justice was served today," she said.

title: Two arrested in shooting death at Easton bar
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Two arrested in shooting death at Easton bar

 October 4, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 546

 EASTON - Police arrested two people in connection with the Saturday, Sept. 30, shooting death ofa 23-year-old man in the parking lot of an Easton bar. Both were ordered to remain held without bond following bail reviews Monday afternoon.With assistance from the Cambridge Police Department, detectives from the Easton Police Department arrested Kevron Chase, 34, ofCambridge and Chadnee Harris, 32, ofHurlock on Saturday.Chase is charged with first-and second-degree murder, first-and second-degree assault, reckless endangerment, using a firearm in a felony crime and illegal possession of a regulated firearm.Harris is charged with acting as an accessory after the fact offirst-and second-degree murder and acting as an accessory after a felony.The charges against the two stemmed from the early morning shooting at the Sidetracked Saloon. Police responded to the bar just before 2 a.m. Saturday morning for a report of shots fired.Officers found a large crowd in the parking lot and a man, later identified as Antonio L. Smith, suffering from a gunshot wound to the head.Two shell casings were found in the parking lot, according to charging documents.Officers initiated lifesaving efforts until Talbot County paramedics arrived and transported Smith to the University ofMaryland Shore Medical Center at Easton, where he was pronounced dead.In charging documents, police said multiple witnesses were interviewed. Multiple people identified Chase as the shooter.Police reviewed the bar's security camera footage, which showed Chase and Harris entering the bar shortly after midnight and exiting to the parking just before 1 a.m., according to charging documents.Further review of the video footage reportedly showed Chase and Harris standing between two cars near the entrance of the bar and Smith approaching the two.The officer reviewing the footage wrote in charging documents that Chase pulled a handgun from his waistband area and pointed the handgun at Smith. Chase put the handgun back toward his waistband area and then appeared to hand the gun to Harris, police said.Smith and Chase began physically fighting in the parking lot, drawing a crowd.Charging documents said Harris walked toward the two men fighting near Chase and that the crowd quickly dispersed. Smith appeared to duck behind a car and Chase walked toward Smith, pointing a handgun at him.The officer who reviewed the footage wrote in charging documents that they saw a muzzle flash from the gun and Smith collapse in between two cars.Security camera footage captured the license plate number on Chase's car, police said. Police shared information with surrounding law enforcement agencies and obtained location data on Chase, who was found in the car with Harris during a traffic stop on Race Street in Cambridge. Both were detained by police.In interviews with Cambridge police, Chase told officers that the physical fight began over Smith trying to rob him several months before, according to charging documents. Chase told police that Smith's friends shot at him, and he fired a single shot back toward their area, but Chase denied shooting Smith.Talbot District Court Judge Karen Ketterman ordered that Chase and Harris remain held without bond during bail reviews Monday afternoon, citing concerns about public safety.Chase and Harris are scheduled to appear for preliminary hearings in the county district court on Oct. 30.

title: Day of hope and healing - Moms Demand Action group urge end to gun violence
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Day of hope and healing - Moms Demand Action group urge end to gun violence

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News

 CAMBRIDGE - People of all ages, from near and far, packed a large room of the Cambridge Empowerment Center Saturday afternoon for a Day of Hope and Healing, which was put on by Moms Demand Action.During the event, people from Cambridge and other parts of the region, including Baltimore and Alexandria, Virginia, spoke about their experiences losing loved ones to gun violence.After each survivor spoke, the names of their loved one echoed throughout the room."My mission is to get everyone to keep saying his name,"Jeanne Elliott said about her son Roderick Russ Jr., who was killed in Cambridge in October 2020."I'm going to keep saying his name. I'm going to live his legacy, and I'm going to live a legacy for myself as well."Carla Young said she is still trying to figure out who she is since losing her son A'Corie Young, who was killed in Cambridge in April 2022."My whole life changed," Young said. "I never knew I could feel the way I felt since his passing."Young said her faith has helped her."I hope nobody has to stand where I'm standing," she said. "But it's just something we have got to walk together. We've got to stand together and do all that we can to make a difference."Young's daughter, Meisha Woolford spoke about the need for more millennials to get involved.A 2003 graduate of Cambridge-South Dorchester High School, Woolford said students were taught to "go to college and leave and never look back.""But there's a problem with that," she said. "All of the good people are not here. So if all of the good, influential millennials are not here, what's happening to this generation?"Woolford said it's time for those millennials to get involved "and realize we've all got work to do to make this a better and safer place for our youth."Tyreese McAllister and her husband, Anthony McAllister, traveled from Alexandria, Virginia, for the event. Since losing their daughter, Ayana, to gun violence, the McAllisters have started the Ayana J. McAllister Foundation. According to its website, the foundation's mission is to use advocacy and education strategies to engage minority communities that have been disproportionately affected by gun violence.On Saturday, Tyreese McAllister spoke about the importance of having hope."Hope is not just a fleeting emotion," she said. "It is a driving force that propels us forward. It is the belief that we can make a difference, that our actions matter and that change is possible."Tyreese McAllister said it will take more than gun laws to solve the problem of gun violence in America."We need boots on the ground," she said. "We need people in the communities to make this change."Cambridge Mayor Stephen Rideout called the event-which also included speeches from faith leaders, musical performances, food and activities - powerful."In a town of our size, a community that is engaged, as I felt it was Saturday, with the help of groups such as Moms Demand Action and our police department, we're going to be able to do a lot to start addressing this problem," Rideout said in an interview.Rideout said it will take more than "a couple meetings" to solve this problem. He mentioned things the city is doing to address gun violence, including Police Chief Justin Todd's efforts with community policing and the juvenile curfew that went into effect Sunday.Rideout said he sees the curfew as tool to help identify families that may need help or benefit from local services.Rideout talked about his own efforts to address gun violence and juvenile crime. He said he has a meeting scheduled with a representative from the governor's office to discuss juvenile justice concerns and has reached out to delegates about possible legislation he thinks could help bring cases to the court "in a more effective way.""To me, the gun is the symptom," Rideout said. "My view, from my experience in Virginia [as a judge] on the bench, is that we can get help get family services to kids in a way that will get them back on the right track and not be engaged in fights and violent action. Those I think are as important as the gun legislation itself."

title: State on pace for record traffic deaths
author: Lucy Hubbard; Capital News Service
content:
State on pace for record traffic deaths

 October 5, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lucy Hubbard; Capital News Service | Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 995
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS - Maryland is on track to see the highest number of roadway fatalities since 2007, according to Motor Vehicle Administrator Christine Nizer, with Prince George's County leading the state in fatal crashes.As of Oct. 4, Maryland has seen 456 roadway fatalities this year, according to Maryland Department of Transportation's Crash Data Dashboard. Last year, 564 people died on Maryland roadways, while in 2007, 615 people were killed on state roads."We are on track at this point, if the numbers stay consistent, to go over 600 fatalities," Nizer said during the Transportation Revenue and Infrastructure Needs meeting last month. "We have not seen that kind of numbers since 2007 and so we are sounding the alarm." More traffic around the fall and winter holidays often increases the toll."We see a lot of fatal crashes during holiday weekends and especially during those highly traveled holidays," Elena Russo, a spokesperson for the Maryland State Police, said. "We see a higher volume of traffic and with a higher volume of traffic, as you can guess, we see a lot more violations of the rules of the road." The number of roadway fatalities in Maryland rose in 2020. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic decreasing travel across the state, Maryland saw 574 roadway fatalities in 2020, 39 more deaths than the year prior. Traffic deaths continued higher than typical pre-pandemic numbers into this year.On Sept. 12, Gov. Wes Moore announced more than $11.5 million in funding for 85 organizations, agencies and programs working to improve roadway safety in Maryland. The money is destined for measures such as overtime traffic enforcement, to prevent distracted or impaired driving and to promote use of seat belts and child seats.Changes in driving behaviors since 2020 are at least partly responsible for the increase in roadway fatalities, said Ragina Ali, public and government affairs manager for the American Automobile Association - Mid Atlantic."We know there were less people on the roadways, at least in our area and across most of the country, but it seemed like those who were driving were engaging in more dangerous and risky behaviors," Ali said. "That they kind of thought the roadways were open and raceways and we did definitely see an alarming increase in dangerous driving behaviors." The unsafe and reckless driving habits that proliferated during 2020 have continued into 2023, she said."Any increase in the fatalities on our highways is alarming," said Russo. "And when we see our numbers increasing, it should be a wake-up call to motorists to sort of revisit the rules of the road." The leading causes of roadway fatalities have been consistent in the years since 2020. Over the last four years, distracted driving has been involved in the most crashes, followed by speed. Often, though, several things contribute to a crash."In some instances, a crash may have multiple factors," Ali said. "In other words, somebody may be impaired and be distracted.They may be distracted and speeding." According to John Seng, founder of the Maryland Coalition for Roadway Safety, a shortage of police officers monitoring roadways and, ironically, an increase in speed cameras encourages speeding."(When) you get to drive 11 to 12 miles over the speed limit and still not get a ticket for speeding through electronic speed enforcement," Seng said, "you are tacitly saying, 'It's OK if you speed eight miles over the speed limit.'" According to Russo, law enforcement agencies across the country have faced difficulties recruiting officers."Like every law enforcement agency in this nation right now, we're having a tough time recruiting individuals who are qualified for the job," Russo said. "One of the primary reasons may be public perception at this time of law enforcement.In the media, you've seen a lot of high-profile incidents that include police misconduct and therefore our citizens may have lost trust in their law enforcement agency." While the number of crashes has decreased every year since 2018, the number of fatal crashes continues to rise, according to MDOT. In 2018, one in every 243 crashes was fatal. Comparatively, in 2022, one in every 203 crashes was fatal.Prince George's County has led the state every year at least since 2016 with more fatal crashes than any other county, according to MDOT's Crash Data Dashboard. In 2022, 121 roadway fatalities were reported in Prince George's County, 21% of the statewide total.Just a few days ago, on Sept. 29, four people died in a crash in Prince George's County after their car ran into a tree on Woodmore Road.Commuters' reliance on Prince George's roadways is one reason the county sees higher rates of fatal accidents than any other county in Maryland, according to Ron Weiss, a member of the MD Route 210 Traffic Safety Committee."A lot of people travel through Prince George's County to get to the District to work," Weiss said."A lot of the traffic on our roads is commuting back and forth from the Beltway and I think that plays a part (in) it." One area of concern for drivers in Prince George's County is Maryland Route 210, known colloquially as Indian Head Highway.According to Rev. Robert L. Screen, founder of MD Route 210 Traffic Safety Committee, in 2022 10 people died on the 14-mile segment of MD 210 in Prince George's County."People are scared, they're nervous, they're anxious," Screen said. "I can't tell you the number of people that avoid 210, they go on other roads to avoid going on Indian Head Highway. The reputation precedes itself in the mindset of a lot of people that live in this community." According to Screen, Route 210, sees higher volumes of traffic than other highways because it offers access to Washington, D.C., which when combined with increasing populations in Charles County and St.Mary's County from infrastructure improvements has meant more wrecks."It's got a reputation in the area and it's not a good reputation," Weiss said. "It reflects not just on Fort Washington or Accokeek or Oxon Hill; it reflects poorly on all of Prince George's County and Maryland."

title: Few show for police town hall meeting
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Few show for police town hall meeting

 October 5, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 870
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - Few residents showed up to a town hall meeting, hosted by the Cambridge Police Department Tuesday evening, to hear about the department's community policing efforts and its goals for the future.Toward the end of the meeting, which was held at the Empowerment Center in Cambridge, Police Chief Justin Todd asked the five residents in attendance to share information from the meeting with other residents."All I ask of you, is that you take this tonight and make sure that the information - whether it's good information or bad, if you agree or disagree - and you put it out there to the public that we, the police department, want to work with our community to better the situation out on the street," Todd said.While the department used to only have two or three officers in a community policing division, Capt.Shane Hinson explained that every officer in the department is now a community-oriented police officer."It's all of our jobs to go out and make meaningful connections with the community," Hinson said, adding that every officer has been through a training course on community-oriented policing.Todd said community-oriented policing is what the department "is and will be built off of." Along with Todd and Hinson, Capt. Antoine Patton and Lt. Greg McCray spoke at the town hall.Patton spoke about some of the things the department does to increase positive interactions with the community."If you look on the news, it would have you to believe sometimes that police officers are only there when bad things happen," he said. "But we want our community to know that we love them, and we're here to work together." Patton mentioned how the department takes children and senior citizens Christmas shopping every year. This year, he said he had the idea for "12 Days of Christmas" where the department will take children and senior citizens out shopping from Dec. 12 through Dec. 24.Patton talked about a Thanksgiving dinner the department hosted last year and plans to host again this year."In five to 10 years these children will be teenagers and these teenagers will remember the things that we did," he said.Todd shared some of the city's crime data at the meeting as well.Since 2019, the Cambridge Police Department has taken 114 illegal guns off the streets, he said.Compared the the record number of seven homicides in Cambridge last year, Todd said there have been two homicides so far in 2023."I don't call that success by any means," he said. "The day we have zero is the day we've been successful. [[---]] But it's progress. And that's what we have to keep banking on as we keep getting better as a community and a city." Todd said the number of juvenile crimes (committed by those under 18) is "continuously getting worse." "Out of the 300-and-some assaults that we've had this year, 127 have been committed by juveniles," he said.Todd brought up the juvenile justice reform bill, passed in 2022, which stops youth, under the age of 13, from facing criminal charges like assault and weapons violations.He said something needs to be done to fix this reform."And the juveniles know it," he said. "We have 12-year-old kids telling us, 'What are you going to do to me?'" With the juvenile curfew in Cambridge, which went into effect Oct. 1, Todd said the last thing he wants to do is fine a parent."But at the end of the day, if we can help one child or one family, one parent to better parent their child, and get them out of the streets, then we've done something right as a community and it's a start," he said about the curfew.In 2010, Todd said the department had 52 officers. When he entered the role of police chief, there were 29 total officers with two in the police academy."At that time, we had a department that was depleted," he said.The department is building itself back up. Todd said there are 39 total officers in the department right now, with four in the police academy."So we'll get those out of the police academy in December, and we'll keep building our Criminal Investigations Division," he said.Todd said he hopes to increase the diversity of the department. He said that 67.5% of both civilian employees and sworn officers in the department are white. Black employees make up 22.5%. Hispanic employees and Asian employees each make up 5%."We want to mirror our community," Todd said, acknowledging that this is no easy feat."But I just want the public to know we're working hard to get there," he added.After the meeting, Gary Gordy, one of the residents in attendance, said that he thinks more policing is needed in Cambridge and thinks it's good the department is hiring more officers. He said that when it comes to crime, Cambridge needs cameras.Gordy added that some of the problems the city is facing with crime could have been prevented if the city had acted earlier."We wait for years to get things done," he said.

title: Police charge woman with being accessory in killing
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Police charge woman with being accessory in killing

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 2 | Section: News

 EASTON - An Easton woman is charged with acting as an accessory after the fact to second-degree murder and related charges in connection to the shooting death of a 55-year-old man in August.Detectives from the Easton Police Department arrested Dana L. Wilson, 59, on Thursday, police announced.The charges, which include acting as an accessory, altering physical evidence and obstructing and hindering a police officer, stem from Wilson's alleged involvement after the shooting death of Easton resident Ty A. Brooks in early August.Police responded to the area of 104 Blake Street around 7 p.m. Aug. 7 for a report of a person who had been shot and was laying in the grass.Officers arriving on scene rendered aid to the man, later identified as Brooks, until paramedics arrived. Brooks died from his injuries at the scene, police said. He was transported to the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner in Baltimore for an autopsy.Police said earlier in the day, Brooks argued with individuals that were near and operating a 2018 Land Rover Range Rover, which was parked in the 100 block of Blake Street.Brooks left the area and returned later, operating an ATV. Brooks confronted the same individuals with a shotgun, police said.Police said after the group exchanged words, a man seated in the driver's seat of the Range Rover fired shots through the front passenger seat window and struck Brooks' side.The man in the driver's seat was identified by police as Daseir Cornish, 22, of Denton. Cornish is charged with second-degree murder, assault, manslaughter and related charges in connection to Brooks' death.After Brooks was shot, he fell off of the ATV, police said. The Range Rover fled the scene accompanied by a gray Hyundai sedan.Police said Thursday that when officers were attempting to secure the crime scene and render aid, Wilson walked to the area where Cornish allegedly shot Brooks and retrieved his cell phone, which was dropped by Cornish. Wilson left the area with the phone, police said.Wilson was released on a $25,000 unsecured bond, according to online court records.

 TAYLORS ISLAND - A Maryland State Police aviation crew helped rescue a 22-yearold man early Thursday morning after the boat he was operating ran aground, stranding him on a small island in Dorchester County.MSP's Trooper 7, which is based at St. Mary's Airport, was dispatched to the area of Taylors Island around 12:40 a.m. Thursday for a report of a missing boater.The request came from the Dorchester County Fire and EMS Department after they had exhausted efforts searching for the subject by boat.Shortly after Trooper 7 arrived in the area, they located the victim in his boat that had run aground in a marshy area. Trooper 7 guided ground rescue crews to the victim location, but conditions proved to be inaccessible by foot or boat.MSP's Trooper 2, which is based at Joint Base Andrews, was dispatched at about 1:20 a.m. to assist with a hoist extraction and take over rescue operations.Once overhead, the pilots on Trooper 2 hovered the Leonardo AW-139 helicopter approximately 50 feet above the marshy terrain while a trooper/paramedic was lowered below to assess the victim.The victim was extracted utilizing the air-lift rescue vest. The trooper/paramedic and victim were hoisted back into the aircraft.Trooper 2 then landed at a landing zone established by the Dorchester County Fire and EMS Department, where the victim was transferred to ground paramedics for a secondary evaluation.The victim ultimately did not require treatment or transport.The Maryland State Police Aviation Command has served Maryland citizens since 1970 and operates a fleet of 10 AW-139 helicopters from seven bases throughout the State. author: Isabella Loy; Stanwood Camano News
content:
Butters makes it back home - Missing cat returns to owners 12 years after being lost

 Author/Byline: Isabella Loy; Stanwood Camano News | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 471

 All was calm and it seemed like an average day for Angelo and Shelley Castellino as they recently drove to their Stanwood, Washington, home on their 29th wedding anniversary.They had no idea that a phone call would soon give them the shock of their lives.Shelley Castellino received the mysterious call from an unknown number, and at first, she declined it."We figured was a scam call," Angelo Castellino said.Soon enough, the number called again. This time, they decided to answer."The gentleman said, 'I'm from animal control, and I have your cat, Butters,'" Angelo Castellino said."I go, 'Is this some sort of punk call?'" The Castellinos soon discovered it was not a scam - it was Riverside County Animal Control Officer Dalton Churchwell in California, who had found Butters in his yard late at night on Sunday, Oct. 3, and scanned him for a microchip.The couple had been living in San Diego and reported Butters missing 12 years ago in 2011. They had since moved to Stanwood in 2014 and lost hope of ever seeing the cat again.Luckily, the phone number attached to the microchip is the same one Shelley Castellino has today."I was astonished, it was kind of unbelievable," Angelo Castellino said."We figured that he was a meal for some coyotes." Angelo Castellino said he's unsure how Butters traveled so far, but that he was always trying to explore. The couple had adopted Butters and his brother, Barnacles, from a shelter in San Diego as kittens.After the news was shared, the Castellinos knew they wanted to bring Butters to their new home in Stanwood, but the expenses and logistics of flying a cat from California to Washington made for a tricky situation.The Animal Solutions Konnection Foundation, a California non-profit organization supporting the Department of Animal Services, soon heard the story.The organization decided to fund the cost of a flight to Seattle to see Butters safely return to his family."We were thrilled to work with the Department of Animal Services to make this reunion possible," said Carolyn Badger, president of the ASK Foundation, in a news release from Riverside County Animal Control."It was such a wonderful story, and we are very happy to know that Butters is home and safe with his family," she said.Butters' unlikely reunion finally happened Oct. 7, when Riverside County Department of Animal Services' longtime volunteer Larry Rudolph delivered Butters to the Castellanos in Seattle.Butters is now settled in his Stanwood home, and lives happily beside his brother, Barnacles, and the Castellinos' two dogs, Roscoe and Alita.Riverside Animal Services said Butters' defying of the odds was a testament to dedication and teamwork - but also a reminder to microchip pets to ensure reunification.

title: Strained blue lines - Police battle mental health challenges along with crime
author: Mike Sunnucks; Apg National Enterprise Editor
content:
Strained blue lines - Police battle mental health challenges along with crime

 October 17, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks; Apg National Enterprise Editor | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 1287
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Police officers, corrections guards and staff at jails and prisons and other law enforcement personnel are in stressful and dangerous vocations.They are one of the emerging frontline populations in America's current mental health crisis that saw record numbers of suicides last year and increased levels of anxiety and depression.There have been 87 officers killed in the line of duty so far this year and more than 1,400 officers have died due to on-the-job events and causes between 2020 and 2022 (including 863 attributed to COVID), according to the Officer Down Memorial Page.Another 1,172 police officers, corrections staff and emergency dispatchers have taken their own lives since 2017 (including 69 so far this year), according to Blue H.E.L.P, a Massachusetts-based nonprofit group. The FBI is asking local police to start reporting officer suicides in their crime reporting.Law enforcement officers have a 54% greater suicide risk than the general U.S. population, according to a 2021 analysis by researchers from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and the State University of New York Buffalo.A record 49,449 Americans died by suicide last year - 79% of them men, according to the CDC.The suicide numbers and mental health stressors among the rank-and-file are not lost on police chiefs, county sheriffs and other law enforcement advocates across country in a vocation where there have been historical stigmas and cultural hesitancies to talk about mental health.PEER SUPPORTA number of departments across the country are turning to peer support programs to overcome those past and current stigmas and hesitations and to tell officers it's OK to seek assistance.In Florida, Capt. Kenneth Rainey with the Sarasota Police Department said his law enforcement agency is restarting a peer support program that fell by the wayside a decade ago."It never got the attention it deserved," Rainey said of past efforts.That's changing.Rainey, who leads SPD's professional standards operations, said a new coordinator will be hired to lead the peer support efforts along with six initial officers who will stand ready to talk to their cohorts about on the job stressors.He said the program will rollout in early 2024 with hopes for growth."Nobody knows officers better than their coworkers and fellow employees. We're really trying to eliminate the stigmas associated with mental health saying that its OK to ask for help," Rainey said.Sarasota, on Florida's west coast, has 185 officers and staff.The U.S. Department of Justice is working with law enforcement agencies on establishing peer support programs related to officers' mental wellness. That includes training sessions and publications focused on best practices for such efforts.In addition to police, the peer path is increasingly being followed by a number of colleges, high schools and middle schools to help overcome hesitations to talk about mental and behavioral health issues with employers, teachers, doctors as well as family members.STAFFING STRESSESIn Wyoming, Laramie County Sheriff Brian Kozak said staffing shortages and turnover rates have been challenging his agency and other law enforcement departments across the country. That takes a toll on existing personnel's morale and mental health if they are working short-handed with mandatory overtime shifts."The pressures of the job from working so many hours are catching up to them," said Kozak.Police agencies across the country have been beset by officer shortages and high numbers of retirements with an aging workforce and stresses of the job.Kozak was elected sheriff in 2022 and was previously police chief in Cheyenne. He said when he became sheriff there were 70 openings. Now, that number is down to 20 with a staff of 220.Like other police agencies, Kozak said his department is looking to grow a peer support system to help patrol and corrections officers who deal with violence against and abuse of children, suicide attempts and those suffering from chronic mental illness."Just a few weeks ago, we had a deputy who was stabbed," the Wyoming sheriff said.Kozak said his agency works with a psychiatrist who specializes in working with law enforcement and is part of required debriefing sessions after officer-involved shootings and other traumatic calls.The Laramie County Sheriff's Office keeps employees' visits to counselors and therapists anonymous.The agency currently has eight staff members and officers as part of the peer support efforts that also include the county fire department."We're looking to expand that," Kozak said.NEW CULTURESA number of departments are seeing more officers able to reach out on the mental health front thanks to employee assistance programs that went and have stayed more virtual during the pandemic.That has helped officers with privacy concerns and the ability to get appointments with counselors who might be more available online."It's all about affecting a new culture within an organization that it is OK to say you are not ok," Rainey said.In Wisconsin, the Eau Claire Community Foundation launched a new effort in April raising money funds from businesses and the public to reimburse local law enforcement officers and staff with costs associated with seeking mental health help."The fund was recently established to reimburse local law enforcement personnel for mental health expenses not covered by their health insurance; grants will be paid directly to the Eau Claire County Sheriff's Department (since we can't make grants to individuals) and applied to their requests for reimbursement," said Rebecca White Body, program coordinator for the Wisconsin effort.Kozak said a key to those efforts is finding counselors and programs that officers and staff will trust.'FREQUENT REMINDERS'That can be a challenge with some old school cops.Capt. John Bollinger, administrative commander for the Talbot County Sheriff's Office on Maryland's Eastern Shore, said there needs to be "frequent reminders that seeking help is not a sign of weakness." "I am old school, 43 years on the job, so this was difficult for me to learn, but being in a command position changes your perspective when looking out for the welfare of your people," he said.Bollinger said negative views of police - are part of the challenging equation.Unfavorable views of law enforcement were magnified after the death of George Floyd at the hands of a Minneapolis police officer in 2020 and other high profile shootings, but also stem from institutional inequities in the broader criminal justice system that disfavor poor people and people of color.The U.S. prison population (including in local jails and those being held in custody before trials) totals more than 1.76 million people (the most of any country), according to the World Prison Brief research group.The U.S. has the highest per capita incarceration rate among industrialized countries and one of the highest rates in the world.Bollinger said unfavorable views of the police (whether they come from politicians, the news media or general public) take a toll on officers' morale and wellness."Too many citizens nationwide believe police officers are generally bad people," Bollinger said, pointing to news stories that emphasize the "bad actions of a few police officers." Rainey agrees and sees its impact on officers."It's challenging to put on a police uniform and feel or just assume there is just disdain for you just as a result of your profession," he said."Individuals know in their own hearts that the great majority of police get involved because they want to help people."

KENNY HOLSTON SSGT USAF/WIKIMEDIA COMMONS

title: CASA of Caroline celebrates 20 years
author: Tom Mccall; tmccall@chespub.com
content:
CASA of Caroline celebrates 20 years

 October 18, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom Mccall; tmccall@chespub.com | Page: A1 | Section: News 
 
 640

 DENTON - CASA of Caroline celebrated a legacy of caring on Oct. 12, when they marked 20 years of advocacy for children who would otherwise be alone in navigating the legal system.Lots of members of the legal community gathered at Caroline's Table in Denton to mark the occasion, including several former judges.The event's keynote speaker, Lisa Spicknall, said she could speak to CASA's mission from personal experience."I started in advocacy after my children were murdered in 1999," she told those gathered. "They were murdered here on the Eastern Shore by my ex husband. That sent me down the road of advocacy." "My children didn't have the opportunity to have their rights and needs met," said Spicknall. "We need to make sure that any victim that is out there, that their needs are met while they are going through the judicial process." The CASA, or Court Appointed Social Advocate, program provides trained volunteers to act as advocates on behalf of the needs of children currently under the protection of the courts.These advocates are appointed by judges overseeing cases involving charges of child abuse or neglect.One of the earliest CASA supporters in Caroline County was retired Circuit Court Judge J. Owen Wise."Let's just say I transported the national idea to Caroline County," he said. "After I retired as (a) judge I said 'we need this here.' The idea was started by a judge in Washington State." Wise said that he saw a need for the program from the bench. For him, all you had to do was ask one simple question - how are you doing?"You have a kid under the court's supervision and you ask, 'What do you need?' I will never forget one kid was shocked that I asked him," he said."He said he just wanted to see his sister.They were our charges. They were our wards. I wanted to make sure that every kid had the best that we have to offer." Wise credited the workers at CASA, who do all the day to day work of advocacy for the program's decades-long legacy in Caroline County.According to those in attendance Thursday night, advocacy can come in lots of different forms."We had a young intern come into my shop. He is part of one of the advocacy groups from around here, said Jason Lee, owner of Jason's Computers in Easton."He wanted an internship in technology and he really couldn't get an opportunity anywhere else. So we brought him in. He turned out to be one of the best interns we have ever had. He is a great young man from a broken home. It is not his fault." Organizers set an ambitious fundraising goal for the anniversary event, attempting to bring in $20,000 to celebrate 20 years. Each attendee paid $150 for admission."This year we are celebrating 20 years of child advocacy here in Caroline County," said Amy Horne, executive director of CASA of Caroline."We have served over 100 children in the last 20 years.We have trained more than 75 volunteers to advocate on behalf of abused and neglected children. This is kicking off our twenty for twenty campaign that we are going to carry through the holiday giving season."

title: Young driver fatality rates fall sharply in the US
author: Assoclated Press
content:
Young driver fatality rates fall sharply in the US

 October 19, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Assoclated Press | Page: A2 | Section: News 
 
 286
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Crash and fatality rates among drivers under 21 have fallen dramatically in the U.S. during the past 20 years, a new report says, while noting young drivers are still the riskiest group behind the wheel.Using data from 2002-2021, a non-profit group of state highway safety offices says in the report made public Wednesday that fatal crashes involving a young driver fell by 38%, while deaths ofyoung drivers dropped even more, by about 45%. For drivers 21 and older, fatal crashes rose 8% and deaths rose 11%.The report from the Governors Highway Safety Association acknowledges that young people are driving less than they were 20 years ago, but highlights several other reasons for the improvement, while offering recommendations for building on them.State programs that phase in driving privileges were at the top ofthe list. These programs, called graduated drivers license laws, often restrict or ban certain activities, such as driving at night or with peers, for teens. The GHSA suggests strengthening those programs and even expanding them to cover drivers 18 to 20 years old, like Maryland and New Jersey do.Other recommendations include bolstering adult and parent participation in their child's driving education, more peer-to-peer education programs and making driver training accessible to all."Young drivers are the riskiest age group on the road, and the reasons are straightforward- immaturity and inexperience," said Pam Shadel Fischer, author ofthe GHSA report. "Many young drivers simply don't have the behind-the-wheel experience to recognize risk and take the appropriate corrective action to prevent a crash."According to the National HighwayTraffic Safety Commission, overall traffic fatalities dropped 3.3% in the first halfofthe year compared with the prior-year period and have now fallen in five straight quarters after a pandemic surge.

title: Youth not facing consequences for breaking laws
author: Thomas R. Hurley; Fraternal Order Of Police
content:
Youth not facing consequences for breaking laws

 October 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Thomas R. Hurley; Fraternal Order Of Police | Page: 7 | Section: Opinions 
 
 1208
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Law Enforcement across the State of Maryland is now having to deal with the Insanity that has been caused by many of our anti-police and soft on crime lawmakers out of Annapolis.The state of Maryland has now joined the other insane places like New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, Seattle, Portland and even Washington, D.C.Many of you may not know what they have done, not only to our officers but also to the laws they enforced to keep you and your property safe.Prior to Oct. 1, a juvenile under the age of 7 could not be arrested or charged for a crime in the state of Maryland. Juveniles 7 and older could be. If they committed a serious crime, it was up to the local state's attorney if they were tried as an adult. Those cases most of the time involved older juveniles, 13 and above, for things like murder, rape and robbery.Less serious crimes went to Juvenile Court if Juvenile Services and the state's attorney agreed. Juveniles found guilty or delinquent in Juvenile Circuit Court could receive sentences from probation, home detention, detention in a juvenile facility and other things like community service and counseling.If there were any damages or restitution the court could require the parents to pay that or face jail time themselves.Really only the serious crimes and repeat offenders saw the inside of a court room, most of the time the juvenile was seen by a juvenile services officer and were counseled and warned not to commit any further acts or they could face a court hearing.Well, the wisdom of the Annapolis lawmakers has blown all of that to hell. The age now for a juvenile to "not be charged with any crime is under 10 years old." Furthermore, any juvenile under the age of 13 cannot be charged with a crime also unless it is a crime of violence.That means crimes like theft, car theft, burglary, vandalism, arson, drug dealing, having a handgun or other deadly weapon, trespassing, disorderly conduct, failure to obey a police officer, and even crimes that are a non-violent felony, and the list goes on and on.If you can think of a crime, and it is not a crime of violence then they cannot be charged period.This also includes simple assault since the lawmakers do not think that is even a crime of violence. The police will just turn the juvenile over to the parents, and there are no consequences for their criminal behavior. If your property is lost, damaged or destroyed you will have to sue their parents since there will now be no court hearing for the parents to be ordered to give you restitution.This will make you a victim a second time, cost you money and make your insurance go up if you have coverage on the property stolen or damaged. The very worst case is where a juvenile under the age of 10 murders or kills someone, and they cannot be charged.These new laws are already seeing crime out of control within just a few weeks that it has been law. I am aware of a juvenile in Dorchester County that stole 11 motor vehicles and was released without charges. Another with a loaded hand gun released without charges. In Wicomico County, a teacher was assaulted by a 12-yearold at school and since it was simple assault the juvenile was not charged.There will be more and more horror stories in the weeks and months ahead. What we are seeing is that gangs and adult criminals are recruiting these juveniles to do crimes on their behalf and training them not to say anything because nothing can be done to them. They will be used to help with drug dealing, theft rings and even carrying the guns and drugs of the adult criminals because nothing will happen to them if they are caught. They may even put them up to doing murders.Part of the new law also is that the police cannot question any juvenile under the age of 18 anymore without an attorney being present there for them. The juvenile's parents cannot waive that right either, so they cannot make their child talk to or help the police.Even if they tell the police who they were carrying the drugs or guns for it may not be able to be used in court against the adult if the juvenile did not have an attorney present there for them.What is happening is that we are now raising children to be "career criminals" because they will learn that nothing will happen to them and even into their adulthood and that is when they will most likely run into the criminal justice system because that will be all that they know and it will be too late for them.These new laws have tied the hands of your police officers into doing nothing for you but giving you the bad news that nothing can be done. The politician that introduced this law and got it passed has stated that the police can still do something the police can do a referral to Social Services to get the juvenile counseling. That is right, if a 9-year-old commits murder they get counseling.You may ask what can be done about this.Well, we all must make Annapolis reverse what it has done and see that we are causing our children to grow up without any morals.Call, write or email your local state delegates or senators. Talk to your local city councils and county councils and let them know that you are upset about these new laws and most of all support your police, deputies and troopers. Talk to your friends and family and get them involved also.Many of these lawmakers in Annapolis are already beginning to hear and feel what they did is wrong. They also are hearing from almost all the local state's attorneys and your law enforcement leaders that these changes are wrong and have and will increase crime and that children will be used by criminals.The sad part is the next legislative session is not until January 2024; therefore, this might not be undone until the middle of next year.The Fraternal Order of Police, Maryland State Lodge, and many of the nearly 80 local F.O.P. lodges across the state of Maryland are fighting many of these stupid laws and rules that have been imposed upon our citizens and our law enforcement by those in Annapolis.We hope you will support us in this fight because we care about it and you. Contact your local FOP Lodge and offer your support. Your voice counts and should be heard and now is the time to speak up because the world is going insane, and we must stop it if we can.I never thought that we would see this on the Eastern Shore of Maryland, but it has come here now and found us and now is not the time to be silent. I hope that we can count on your help to change this because we need it, and it's only going to get worse if we do nothing.Thomas R. Hurley is the local lodge president of the Fraternal Order of Police, Cambridge-Dorchester Lodge No. 27. He is a retired sergeant from the Cambridge Police Department.

title: Trial begins for Cambridge man charged in 2022 shooting
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Trial begins for Cambridge man charged in 2022 shooting

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 493
