 CAMBRIDGE - The sunny, warm afternoon of Sept. 20, 2022, was a perfect day for a family birthday barbecue in Cambridge. Around 3 p.m., everything changed.Numerous officers from the Cambridge Police Department responded to the area of Rigby Avenue and Fairmount Avenue for a report of shots fired around 3:05 p.m. Police spread out, canvassing the area nearby for any witnesses.Minutes later, officers found the body of20 year-old Kevin Raeford laying in a wooded area near the 600 block of Edgewood Avenue. Police officers would later testify that Raeford's body was covered by a blanket.About 20 minutes after police were dispatched, Raeford was pronounced dead by medics. A medical examiner ruled his death a homicide by gunshot wound.Only one person is responsible for Raeford's death, and it wasn't a random shooter - it was Raeford's cousin, Geett Cornish, said Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard, pointing toward Cornish across the courtroom at the outset of his trial Tuesday.Cornish, 31, of Cambridge, faces first-and second-degree murder, assault, reckless endangerment and handgun charges in connection to the shooting that left Raeford dead.Family members who were present that day would be called to testify against Cornish, sharing emotions they'd struggled with for the past year, Leonard said. The family would provide the 'who' of the case, while others, including law enforcement, would fill in the 'what' and the 'where' of the shooting.But to Baltimore-based defense attorney Brad MacFee, testimony from three other civilian witnesses, along with Raeford's affiliation with a local gang, would be key for the jurors deciding the case.In his opening statement, MacFee asserted that Cambridge has a gang problem - a "significant, substantial" one. Raeford was a member of a more prominent local gang, and gangs and violence go together like peanut butter and jelly, he said.Two of MacFee's three three highlighted witnesses were possibly affiliated with gangs, and all three had varying motives to lie about what happened that day, including concerns about gang reprisal and fear of going back to jail, he said."My client's fate relies on whether or not you believe these three guys. That's it," he said.By lunchtime Tuesday, five witnesses had testified, including Raeford's mother, his girlfriend and three Cambridge Police officers.Testimony from police established the discovery of two separate crime scenes. The first, located at Fairmount Avenue and Rigby Avenue, was where officers found spent casings and blood spatter.The second scene, the wooded area near Edgewood Avenue, was where Raeford's body was found.MacFee asked three of the five witnesses about gang violence in the city, echoing his assertions from the opening statements.Testimony from a Maryland State Police crime scene technician, a ballistics expert and a medical examiner were expected Tuesday afternoon.Additional witnesses are expected to testify Wednesday and Thursday. A verdict is anticipated Friday.

 ANNAPOLIS - Maryland's Department ofJuvenile Services will relocate girls awaiting court hearings or long-term placement this month from a single unit of the Cheltenham Youth Detention Center, a facility that previously housed only boys, to a center the agency says will house all girls in the agency's residential care.The move is designed to correct problems highlighted in a series of reports by the Juvenile Justice Monitoring Unit in the state Office of the Attorney General.The reports revealed that four moves of detained girls and one move ofgirls in long-term placement over seven months in 2022 disrupted school, led to longer and more frequent periods of confinement and isolation, delayed medical services and exposed girls to sexual harassment.But it's unclear whether the change to an all-girl facility will impact the inequities experienced by girls in Maryland's youth detention system."They just treat these girls like chattel, moving them constantly from one place to another without thinking of how it will impact them," a staffer told a JJMU investigator in early 2023."They are just replicating the streets here, it's like survival every day," said a mental health therapist to an investigator during the same period. While all DJS long-term placement facilities are meant to offer treatment, the therapist told the investigator that the facility was too "short-handed" to do so.A 19-year-old at the facility, the Victor Cullen Center in rural northern Frederick County, said to an investigator, "There is nothing treatment-oriented about this program."DJS has housed detained girls from most of the state at Cheltenham and all girls in long-term committed placement at Cullen since October 2022. The department said that after girls at Cheltenham are moved to the Western Maryland Children's Center in Hagerstown later this month, girls committed by the courts to DJS care will join them "at a later date."Boys currently detained at WMCC will be moved to DJS residential facilities closest to their home communities, the department said. The department also indicated that WMCC staff are receiving training in "gender-responsive programming and trauma-informed care."Girls and young women comprise a small portion ofyouth confined in DJS detention and treatment centers. For fiscal year 2022, DJS reported average daily populations of 10 girls in detention and 12 in court-ordered committed placement. The number of girls sent to detention from juvenile court in the course of a given year is much higher, though it has decreased each year since 2018, from 437 to 91 in 2022.The department's repeated moves of detained and committed girls in 2022 followed over a decade of debate and activism about how DJS should serve girls in its custody.In March 2022, DJS closed the Thomas J.S. Waxter Children's Center in Laurel and moved detained girls to the Alfred D. Noyes Children's Center in Rockville, which the department had refurbished to serve as a girls' facility. The monitoring unit had been calling for Waxter's closure since 2007, stating that it was "virtually impossible to improve the physical plant sufficiently to make it suitable for a secure detention program." A 2010 bill in the House of Delegates that would have closed Waxter died in committee.The Juvenile Services secretary at the time, Donald DeVore, told CNS he couldn't close Waxter because it would mean placing girls in a facility with boys."If I close Waxter, the other facilities I have are for boys. Where do I put the girls? I would hate to stuff them in two wings (in a facility) where I have boys," DeVore told CNS in 2010.Just one month after the move to Noyes, the girls were moved again, this time into a 12-cell unit at Cheltenham after an air handler unit caught fire. The girls returned to Noyes in late May but were moved back to Cheltenham in October, this time to address a staffing shortage that had reached a crisis level. Cheltenham staff had been working back-to-back double shifts to reach the level of coverage required by departmental policy.Girls at Cheltenham awaiting court-ordered secure placement were sent to Cullen, the center in Frederick County.Keeping girls and boys separated at Cheltenham created new problems:■Delayed medical care:Girls at Cheltenham did not have access to the facility infirmary because boys are housed there. A girl experiencing withdrawal symptoms in early 2023 was transported from Cheltenham to WMCC in Hagerstown, almost 100 miles away, because her condition required monitoring.■Disrupted school:Persistent staff shortages at Cheltenham led to shortened or canceled school days. A special education teacher who had taught at Noyes quit in late 2022 after several years of service, partly due to her increased commute to Cheltenham with no definite end date, according to JJMU.■Increased isolation and confinement:During a COVID-19 outbreak in late 2022, a lack of space to quarantine girls meant that girls who tested positive isolated in their cells for 23 hours a day for five to seven days, according to the monitoring unit. After seven days isolating in her cell, one girl "destroyed her room." Staff asked another youth to comfort the girl from the hallway.■Heightened conflict between girls:Staff separated girls into groups that took turns in a dayroom and small TV room, as well as going to school, to manage tensions. One girl told a JJMU investigator that all the noise made her feel anxious. She said, "It's so crazy here. It's so hard to concentrate in school because it is so loud, and loud noises are my trigger." A pregnant girl who was assaulted twice indicated, "Me and my child feel threatened."■ Exposed girls to sexual harassment:Two girls reported in early 2023 that a boy made repeated lewd comments and gestures when they were all in school. The boy moved his hand over his crotch and told the girls to perform a sexual favor and referred to the girls pleasuring themselves with tampons.In its report on the first quarter of 2023, JJMU wrote, "Relegating detained girls and young women to a single unit in a secure detention facility set up to serve boys and young men indicates a lack of appropriate planning and dedication of resources and arguably demonstrates a casual disregard for the well-being of girls in DJS custody."At Cullen, shortages and lack of continuity of staff interfered in girls' mental health care, according to JJMU's report for the second quarter of2023. The report described how one girl who experienced suicidal ideation was "ejected" from the program at Cullen and sent to a secure detention center for a month to "stabilize her."The girl had told staff that she thought no one loved her and that she had nowhere to go after Cullen.DJS, Moroney and other advocates of girls in the youth legal system agree that a new facility for girls is not the way to provide genuine treatment.DJS acknowledged in its response to JJMU's first quarter 2023 report - the first of the new administration - that girls' needs were not being met at Cheltenham or Cullen, but said that the number of girls in its residential facilities - 13 in secure detention and 4 in commitment on June 1,2023 - was too small "to invest a large amount of resources into correctional facilities dedicated to girls." "The answer is not simply to provide dedicated space and gender specific treatment, although those things are important," DJS wrote in its response. "It is the institutional model itself that is failing these young women."In the Maryland House Judiciary Committee meeting in September, DJS Secretary Vincent Schiraldi voiced the aim of expanding Maryland's range of services for youth, which he told lawmakers has deteriorated over the past eight years.But justice reform advocates differ on whether the department is equipped to divert girls to community-based services and treatment.Schiraldi told lawmakers that DJS has adequate resources to develop Maryland's community-based offerings.But JJMU indicated in its first quarter 2023 report that there is "a shortage and lack of variety and specialization" in Maryland's community-based programming for girls.Moroney said that although relocating incarcerated girls to their own facility is a positive step, corrections-oriented facilities are not suitable spaces for young people to receive treatment."We would prefer that the girls not be incarcerated in the first place," Moroney said. "But I guess if courts and the police cause kids to go to a jail-like situation, then having their own place is a better situation than being shoehorned into a boys' place."

title: Fire engulfs downtown Easton duplex
author: Wendy Weitzel; wweitzel@chespub.com
content:
Fire engulfs downtown Easton duplex

 October 26, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Wendy Weitzel; wweitzel@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 411
 Words

 EASTON - The card game at American Legion Post 77 ended abruptly on Wednesday evening when a duplex located next door caught fire shortly after 5:30 p.m., pulling players from the table and into the action."We were in there playing cards together, and my father said, 'Come outside and see the smoke.' He said, 'Is that my vehicle on fire?'" said Anthony Wilson, a member of the lodge, who stood across the street as firefighters extinguished dwindling embers. (Some members) ran around here and saw the smoke and said there was a fire Then all of us came out and came over here." "(There were) no injuries. Nothing but the dog. Everybody else was gone, except for the guy upstairs. We kicked the door pretty hard, and he finally came out, luckily. Everyone else was out after that, and it was just a matter of time waiting for the fire company."Dispatchers alerted local fire departments about the blaze at 5:46 p.m. About 60 first responders reported to the scene, according to emergency officials at the scene.An official from the St. Michaels Volunteer Fire Department, who was on the scene, confirmed that there were no injuries reported in the incident and that the fire was contained to a single structure, located at 21 South West St. in Easton.Due to the structure's age, he said, safeguards had not been included in its construction, making the duplex susceptible to the quick-spreading fire.Neighbors who gathered at the scene reported that the duplex, which consists of an upstairs and a downstairs unit, had been engulfed in flames at one point in the evening, with fire visible from both upstairs and downstairs windows.Firefighters on the scene included the Easton Volunteer Fire Department, the Oxford Fire Company, the Trappe Volunteer Fire Company, the St. Michaels Fire Department and the Cordova Volunteer Fire Company. EMS and law enforcement personnel were on site to assist.As firefighters began to extinguish the last remaining flames shortly before 7 p.m., a fire marshal arrived to begin conducting an investigation into the fire's cause. Findings from this investigation will be released at a later date.A GoFundMe has been established to benefit a resident of one of the two affected units. More details can be found at https://www.gofundme.com/f/7u4cy-my-grandma.Star Democrat reporter Natalie Jones contributed to this report.

 The Friends of the Easton Volunteer Fire Department recently received a $300,000 gift from the Preston Automotive Group for its Emergency Services Training Campus in Easton."Preston Automotive Group is proud to support an amazing project that will benefit the first responders in our local counties firsthand," said David Wilson Jr., president of Preston Automotive Group."We are grateful to have so many brave men and women putting their lives on the line daily to make sure we are all safe. Law enforcement training will include hostage rescue, physical training/testing, traffic training, Homeland Security and K-9. Emergency Medical Services can use classroom facilities for training."We train together because we answer the call together," said Brett Whitehead, co-chairman of the Public Safety Capital Campaign, which benefits the new training facility, and president of the Friends of EVFD."The donation from the Preston Automotive Group is an essential first step toward ensuring training available for all emergency services in Talbot County, including our volunteer firefighters, our law enforcement and our emergency services personnel and paramedics. The demand for these services continues to grow on the Mid-Shore and this training campus will help meet this critical need."For further information or to donate to the Friends of the EVFD Public Safety Capital Campaign for its Emergency Services Training Campus in Easton, Maryland, contact Brett Whitehead at (302) 236-6249 or whitenj20@gmail.com.

title: Trial set for man charged with arson of own house
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Trial set for man charged with arson of own house

 October 26, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 354
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON-A man charged with arson after fire officials determined he set his own home on fire last November will go to trial in March next year, according to court records.Fred "Trey" Rider III, 42, is set to appear for a jury trial in Talbot County Circuit Court from March 4 through March 8.A pretrial conference is set for Jan. 19.Rider faces first-and second-degree arson, first-degree malicious burning and two counts ofthreatening arson after state fire officials determined he was responsible for the fire that caused roughly $800,000 in damage to his home's structure and belongings.Over 45 firefighters responded to the fire in the two-story, single-family home at 27930 Peach Orchard Road in Easton just after 8 p.m. Thursday, Nov.24,2022.According to charging documents, heavy fire was observed on a corner and two sides ofthe home. The fire had also penetrated the roof and partially collapsed the roof on the front left side.It took over 30 minutes to control the fire with a tanker task force.Through investigation, officials determined that the fire originated in a living room on the left front side of the home. The room reached a flashover - a thermally-driven event in which all combustible surfaces exposed to thermal radiation in an enclosed space rapidly and simultaneously ignite, according to the U.S. Fire Administration.The living room was a complete burn with a partial structural collapse and roof collapse, and all combustible materials in the room were a complete burn, according to charging documents. The investigation also revealed there were no other ignition sources available in the area of origin other than human behavior.The fire was identified as an act of human intervention with an open flame, classifying the cause of fire as incendiary.Rider's reckless conduct in igniting the house on fire "clearly" put emergency services personnel, specifically firefighters, in danger as they suppressed the fire, according to court papers.Rider was arrested in February and released on a $20,000 unsecured bond. In April, Rider entered a plea ofnot criminally responsible by reason ofinsan-ity, according to documents filed in court.

title: CASA seeks new faces for volunteer training class
author: Contributed
content:
CASA seeks new faces for volunteer training class

 October 26, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 485
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CASA of the MidShore is looking for more volunteers.The organization serves children under the protection of the circuit courts in Talbot, Dorchester, Queen Anne's and Kent Counties.The children have been abused or neglected and need a consistent, trusted advocate to stand by their side. Court Appointed Special Advocate (CASA) volunteers use a one-to-one model in speaking up for local children's needs, safety and permanence."CASA is not a typical volunteer role, which is one of the unique aspects of volunteering with our program," said Executive Director Robin Davenport. "It's also not for everyone.""CASAs are adult volunteers working to ensure the individual needs of children under court protection remain a priority in a complex child welfare system. Most importantly, each CASA volunteer gets to know his or her appointed child and frequently becomes one of the most consistent adults in the child's life. We want to grow our pool of CASA volunteers in order to serve more children in our four-county service region."Interested individuals are asked to complete an application and screening process. Following screening, the volunteer experience starts as a learning opportunity through pre-service training. The CASA staff creates a supportive learning environment to build skills and knowledge in child welfare policy, communication, cultural humility, core values and best-interest advocacy.Training is intended to prepare volunteers to carry out best-interest advocacy for their assigned children.Case studies bring the learning to life, as trainees work together to solve problems and offer solutions to situations that simulate real-world dilemmas."The value of the CASA Volunteer Panel cannot be overstated," the organization said in a press release. "Volunteers-in-training are given the opportunity to observe and be inspired by the level of commitment, compassion, creativity and caring brought to CASA of the Mid-Shore by current CASA volunteers."After successfully completing the training, new CASA volunteers are sworn in as officers of the court.Upon appointment to a child's case, CASA volunteers work closely with CASA supervisors in developing an advocacy plan. By getting to know their appointed child's wishes and needs, the CASA is able to advocate for services to meet those needs as quickly as possible.Studies show that children with CASA volunteers have their needs identified sooner, and services to meet those needs are put into place sooner than for those foster children without CASAs. Studies also confirm that children with CASAs feel more hopeful about their futures.CASA volunteers bring a myriad of life experiences to their advocacy work. CASA volunteers come from diverse walks of life, have varied experiences and professions, and are at least 21 years of age. CASA welcomes volunteers from all cultures, ethnicities and backgrounds.To learn more about becoming a Court Appointed Special Advocate, visit casamidshore.org or email jc@casamid-shore.org.

title: 'Just grateful no one was home' - Resident reflects on Wednesday evening house fire
author: Tom Mccall; tmccall@chespub.com
content:
'Just grateful no one was home' - Resident reflects on Wednesday evening house fire

 October 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom Mccall; tmccall@chespub.com | Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 516
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Clara Dorsey was sitting in a red beach chair with neighbors, family and friends on the curb in front of the melted yellow siding and charred timbers of her home on Thursday, Oct. 26.Red caution tape blew in the breeze and even the metal house number, 21, is seared.The evening before, a structure fire tore through the duplex where Dorsey has rented her apartment for 20 years."I am just glad it wasn't in the night time," she said."We were sitting on the porch, and I left for a few minutes. When I came back it was all on fire." According to the fire marshal, there were no injuries or fatalities reported in the blaze, but all of the residents' belongings were lost.Dorsey's beloved terrier, Peanut, has been missing since the event. She said she thought about looking for the remains in the charred rubble, but she is pretty sure there is nothing left.The fire, which broke out at 21 South West Street in Easton shortly after 5:30 p.m. on Wednesday, drew the attention of passersby, who alerted emergency officials to the blaze."It was some of them from the American Legion (which is next door) that were sitting there playing cards. They looked out the window," Dorsey said.The fire marshal estimates that $50,000 worth of damage was done to the building.They could not determine the smoke alarm status, and there was no sprinkler action."The building consisted of two apartments with the fire originating in the kitchen area of the downstairs apartment," the fire marshal wrote in a report about the incident."The families in both apartments were displaced due to the fire." Investigations into the preliminary cause of the blaze are still ongoing.Dorsey said her next step is to find a new place to live.She said she is being taken care of and has a place to sleep in the meantime."If everybody could say a prayer and thanks to everybody.This is different than yesterday when it happened.It was chaotic," Dorsey said.60 emergency personnel responded to the fire, according to the fire marshal's report, representing five volunteer fire departments, along with law enforcement and EMS personnel.Dorsey said in the aftermath of the event, she leans on gratitude that no one was hurt. She is also grateful she had renter's insurance."I've got to wait for the insurance adjuster to call me.They want to come and take pictures," she said.A GoFundMe has been established by Dorsey's grandson, De'Andre Dorsey.In the description on the page, De'Andre wrote "Unfortunately my grandma's house caught on fire today (10/25), and she lost everything. Her dog, Peanut, who was by her side for 14 years, clothes, family photos, important letters and documents, several sentimental items, and, unfortunately, her savings were in her house." He continued, "My grandmother has given her heart to the community of Easton, and today she is in desperate need of yours." More details can be found at https://www.gofundme.com/f/7u4cy-my-grandma.

 EASTON - Eleven patients were transported to the hospital following a crash between a SUV and a Caroline County school bus near the intersection of Matthewstown Road and Three Bridge Branch Road just before 8 a.m.Monday morning.According to a preliminary investigation by Maryland State Police, a Kia Sportage failed to stop at a stop sign at a four-way intersection and crashed into the side of the bus.The school bus rolled over.According to a statement from Caroline County Public Schools, the bus was transporting high school students involved in the Navy Junior Reserve Officers Training Corps program to Easton High School. title: Preston man pleads guilty to attempted murder - CRIME
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Preston man pleads guilty to attempted murder - CRIME

 November 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 2A | Section: News 
 
 405
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - A Preston man pleaded guilty Monday to attempted murder in connection to the February 2022 stabbing of a young woman.After waiving his right to a jury trial two weeks ago, Mark William Thompkins, 25, pleaded guilty to attempted second-degree murder during a hearing in Caroline County Circuit Court.The plea reached Monday comes over a year and a half after the stabbing of a then 25-year-old woman near Holly Park Drive and Gilpin Point Road in Preston shortly before 3 p.m. on Feb. 17, 2022.According to Caroline County State's Attorney Sloane Franklin, trash collection workers near the scene first saw the woman sitting in the driver's seat of her vehicle with a man, later identified as Thompkins, seated behind her. Thompkins began striking the woman with his fists, then brandished a knife to stab her neck.The woman ran from her vehicle and collapsed in the front yard of a nearby house. Thompkins cradled her while holding the knife to his own throat, Franklin said.A witness attempted to help the victim but Thompkins threatened them, pointing the knife at them and yelling for them to get back.Multiple law enforcement agencies, including the Caroline County Sheriff's Office, Maryland State Police and Maryland Natural Resources Police, responded to the stabbing.Franklin said Thompkins punctured his own neck with a knife while running to the woods, evading officers.After 15 minutes and the use of multiple non-lethal methods, including a taser, to diffuse the situation, a state trooper was able to knock the knife out of Thompkins' hand to detain him, police said.Both Thompkins and the woman were flown to the University of Maryland Shock Trauma Center in Baltimore for treatment of their injuries.Following his arrest, a judge found Thompkins incompetent to stand trial in April 2022.He was committed to the Maryland Department of Health until August of this year, then transferred back to a local detention center upon being found competent, according to court filings.In court Monday, Franklin said he will recommend a 30-year sentence with all but 15 years of active incarceration suspended, followed by five years of supervised probation and special mental health conditions.State sentencing guidelines recommend five to 10 years, said Jesse Hicks, Thompkins' attorney. The plea is not binding, meaning a judge has the ability to impose a higher or lower sentence than what is recommended.Sentencing will be deferred until Feb. 1, 2024.

title: 'We made a big impact' - Greensboro PD's Trams promoted, Chief Paugh joins Sheriff's Office
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
'We made a big impact' - Greensboro PD's Trams promoted, Chief Paugh joins Sheriff's Office

 November 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 3B | Section: News 
 
 519
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO - While one Greensboro police officer was promoted Monday morning, Oct. 30, the chief announced his departure to join the Caroline County Sheriff's Office.But the focus was on Greensboro Police Chief George Paugh's promotion of Officer Lenox Trams to the rank of lieutenant, pinning his bars on his collar during an informal ceremony at the Town Meeting Hall on Main Street."Well, I'm very humbled," Trams said. "I was recruited here to make a difference and reinstate the love for law enforcement, so I've been trying to do that for seven months, and I'm going to continue to do that. It's a great little town." "I'm going to stay and watch this thing grow, and continue to give excellent service to the citizens and the town," Trams said."We're very proud to have you, and you're doing a fantastic job," Town manager Tammy Kelledes said.Several town employees attended the ceremony. Paugh thanked them and said, "I want to thank you guys for taking your time out of your busy Monday to join Lenox on his special day. It's been a long time coming." "Even though it's been a short period of time in Greensboro, you definitely made an impact in the community," he told Trams."I'm always stopped and told about how well you're doing and how you interact with the community, and that's huge. And that's who you are. You're Mr. Community Policeman," Paugh said."You've done some amazing things, and you're worthy of the rank." Trams joined the Greensboro Police Department with Paugh seven months ago.Most of their law enforcement careers were spent with the Easton Police Department.Trams, 48, was a police officer in Easton for 22 years, completing his career there as a school resource officer at Easton Middle School.Paugh, 50, a 26-year veteran of the Easton Police Department, is leaving soon to join the Caroline County Sheriff's Office as commander of criminal investigations and a lieutenant, the same rank he attained with the EPD.In only seven months, Paugh said, "We made a big impact." "We completely redid all the cars - the technology in them. Everything is up to date," he said. "We got a new CAD (computer-aided dispatch) system, new body cameras, new in-car cameras, all new computer systems" - all updates the department "very, very much" needed. 
 
 Caption: CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Greensboro Police Chief George Paugh, right, pins lieutenant bars on uniform of Lt. Lenox Trams Monday morning, Oct. 30.

title: Jury finds Tilghman man guilty of child sexual abuse
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Jury finds Tilghman man guilty of child sexual abuse

 November 3, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 732
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - After roughly five hours of deliberation Thursday, a Talbot County jury found a Tilghman man guilty on all but one count relating to the sexual abuse of a child earlier this year.The jury found Eric L. Werner guilty of 16 counts, including sexual abuse of a minor, third-and fourth-degree sex offenses, second-degree assault and displaying obscene matter to a minor.However, the jury did not convict Werner on one count of sexual abuse of a minor.The verdict comes after a four-day jury trial in Talbot County Circuit Court.The child's mother, whom the Star Democrat is not naming to protect the victim's privacy, expressed gratitude for the guilty verdict."Justice has been served today," she said in an email. "We can't thank the Talbot County Sheriff's (Office), and the Talbot County State's Attorney's Office enough for their dedication to this case and the support that they've given my daughter and our family these past 8 months." She continued: "I'd also like to express how important it is that parents, and guardians educate themselves and their children on the statistics and signs of sexual abuse and grooming. Empower your kids to speak up if someone is hurting them, being inappropriate with them, or making them feel uncomfortable. If your child discloses abuse to you, believe them, support them, and report the abuse to authorities or a mandatory reporter." "What happened to my daughter was horrible, but it could have been a lot worse if she had not spoken up when she did.She will carry this trauma with her for the rest of her life, but we all hope that because she spoke up, it will help encourage another child to do the same and stop their abuse." Defense attorney Philip Cronan said he was disappointed in the verdict, but would see what comes next with sentencing, which is yet to be scheduled.Detectives from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office began investigating Werner, 61, in February after learning of multiple child sexual abuse incidents that occurred at a home in Tilghman that month.Police investigation revealed that Werner sexually assaulted a preteen girl through inappropriately touching her on three different occasions in February.Werner showed the child pornographic videos, which the child remembered in detail during the trial. Police testified to a specific adult website appearing in Werner's phone's search history.In closing arguments Thursday, Talbot County Deputy State's Attorney Chelsea Endzel highlighted the testimony and evidence presented during the trial as concrete proof that Werner established an inappropriate relationship with the child, grooming her, she said.Numerous text messages between the two, plus the child testifying to Werner initiating sexual conversations with her, further illustrated the inappropriate relationship, Endzel said.Later, Werner, asking the child to delete messages, indicated that he continued to coax the child into becoming comfortable with sexual contact, she added.Endzel also pointed to recordings of calls Werner made to his wife while in the county jail as additional corroboration for his guilt. During one call, Werner said the truth would get him "into some trouble." And during another, he attempted to discredit her, telling his wife they needed to give a reason why she would lie, Endzel said.Countering the prosecution, Cronan acknowledged that the allegations against Werner would bother any juror, but questioned what the prosecution presented as facts.A point of contention between both attorneys Thursday morning was whether or not Werner had permanent or temporary care or custody or responsibility for the supervision of the child - criteria that needed to be met to move forward with the sexual abuse of a minor charges.Though Talbot Circuit Judge Stephen H. Kehoe ruled that the prosecution had provided evidence demonstrating that Werner had temporary responsibility for the child during the incidents, Cronan still questioned if there was a change in responsibility between adults during his closing arguments.Cronan also questioned the consistency of the child's statements made to police compared to what she testified to on the witness stand, urging the jurors to find Werner not guilty if they only thought he "probably" or "maybe" touched the child inappropriately.In her final remarks to the jurors, Endzel said the child had no incentive to lie. She turned attention back to Werner, again highlighting his request for the child to delete text messages and pointing to the jail calls attempting to discredit her story."If that's not consciousness of guilt, I don't know what is," she said.

title: Cambridge man sentenced to five years for reckless endangerment
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com

Cambridge man sentenced to five years for reckless endangerment

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 3 | Section: News

 CAMBRIDGE - A Cambridge man was sentenced Monday to five years in prison for reckless endangerment and illegal possession of a firearm in connection to last year's fatal Fourth of July shooting in the town.Emphasizing the tragic nature of the shooting, Circuit Judge Karen Dean handed down a sentence consistent with the prosecutor's recommendation to Dominic Savage, 34: five years of incarceration for illegal possession of a regulated firearm and five years, all suspended, for reckless endangerment."The level of gun violence in this town is astonishing," said Dean, who splits time between courts in Dorchester and Wicomico counties.Officers from the Cambridge Police Department responded to the 1000 block of Cosby Avenue just before 9 p.m. on July 4, 2022, for a reported shooting. There, police found 24-year-old Tyuane Johnson of Cambridge with a gunshot wound to the right side of his head.Over 30 spent shell casings were observed by police in various areas around the scene.Police attempted lifesaving measures while waiting for paramedics.Johnson was transported to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Dorchester, where he was pronounced dead.Autopsy results from the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner ruled Johnson's death a homicide from a gunshot wound.According to Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard, police identified Savage in surveillance video of the shooting.L eonard said Savage fired a gun in the area, then fled toward a home on Greenwood Avenue.Savage was already prohibited from owning a firearm due to a previous conviction.During the shooting, Savage also sustained a gunshot wound to his left foot and left a trail of blood from the scene to Greenwood Avenue.In recommending the maximum penalty on the firearm charge, Leonard said Johnson's family was still not satisfied.In the months after the shooting, nearly a dozen men were arrested and charged in connection to Johnson's death and the chaotic scene that unfolded that night, including Savage.Charges against two of the men were eventually dismissed; others received time served sentences after pleading guilty to lesser charges. Three men were handed sentences ranging from 18 months to five years, to be served in state prisons.In September, Deondray Stanford, 23, of Cambridge, was sentenced to 10 years in prison for manslaughter, the most significant punishment in the case.But to the family, no plea would ever fill the hole left by Johnson's death, Leonard said.Defense attorney Andrea Jaskulsky agreed that Johnson's death was a tragedy, but asserted that Savage was the intended target of the fatal shooting. Other men charged in connection to the shooting were upset with Savage for not intimidating a witness in a different court case, she said.It was "impossible" to tell what was going on from the surveillance video, Jaskulsky added.Savage spoke briefly, saying that he was only walking out of his front door and didn't intend to hurt anyone.Both Savage and Jaskulsky asked the judge for consideration for a work-release program, which was opposed by Leonard and denied by Dean, though Dean said she would recommend work programs for him.Savage will receive credit for the 16 months already served in the county jail since his arrest last July.He will also be required to submit to mental health and substance abuse evaluations.

title: Anton Black's family settles with state medical examiner
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Anton Black's family settles with state medical examiner

 November 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 773
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS - A $235,000 settlement approved by the Board of Public Works resolved all claims in a federal lawsuit brought against the state medical examiner by the family of 19-year-old Anton Black, who died in Greensboro in 2018 after being restrained by police.The settlement, which includes a $100,000 payment to Black's family and $135,000 toward attorneys' fees, was approved without discussion during Wednesday's Board of Public Works meeting.The settlement also "makes necessary changes to the Maryland Office of the Chief Medical Examiner's process for autopsies conducted on people killed in law enforcement custody and requires notification to families about the results and their rights to challenge the results," according to a news release from the American Civil Liberties Union.Reforms to the state medical examiner's office include the adoption of a policy addressing how medical examiners handle deaths in custody, which includes those involving law enforcement restraint, according to the ACLU.The policy also incorporates and models guidelines from the National Association of Medical Examiners for determining how such deaths are investigated and how examiners determine causation.The ACLU said the reforms will instill more transparency, impartiality and "independence from improper law enforcement influence." The Office of the Chief Medical Examiner must also provide families with information on their rights to seek correction of an autopsy report and the procedures to seek that correction.In a statement, Richard Potter, the founder of the Coalition for Justice for Anton Black, called the settlement an "excellent first step," adding that community members must stay vigilant to ensure it's effective and increases accountability from within."I hope that with this settlement agencies will begin to recognize their own wrongdoings, catch them and change them before they cause harm," he said in the statement. "What is needed is a sense of shared ownership that can only come through trust and mutual accountability, with police confronting their own biases about mental illness, committing to de-escalation, and truly serving a diverse community." Black died on his mother's front steps on Sept. 15, 2018, after being chased, tased and restrained by three white police officers and a white civilian.That day, Black and a 12-year-old family friend were walking around Greensboro together when Black began pulling and dragging the child, who was calling out for help, garnering attention from onlookers that led to a call to police.The chase ended outside Black's home, where Greensboro Police Officer Thomas Webster IV, offduty Ridgely Police Chief Gary Manos, Centreville Police Officer Dennis Lannon and a civilian attempted to restrain Black, pressing his body against a wooden handicap ramp for six minutes while attempting to handcuff and shackle him.Black later became unresponsive, but continued breathing and had a pulse.Officers rolled Black on his side, then shifted him to a sitting position.After no further response, officers removed the handcuffs and began CPR. Black was later transported to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center in Easton, where he was pronounced dead that evening.The medical examiner ruled that Black's death was an accident caused by a heart condition, with bipolar disorder as a contributing cause.Unanswered questions surrounding Black's death and excessive use of force spurred the litigation. The family filed a wrongful death lawsuit against multiple police officers, towns and the state medical examiner involved in the case in December 2020.No one was charged in connection to Black's death.In August 2022, the family and coalition reached a settlement that required police departments in Greensboro, Ridgely and Centreville to overhaul use of force policies and the enhancement of resources for police confronting mental health emergencies; officer training in de-escalation, intervention and implicit bias; hiring transparency; and public complaint reporting.The settlement also included a $5 million payment to Black's family from the police and municipal defendants.Black's death caused his family and the coalition to become deeply involved in Maryland's campaign for police reform and accountability.Efforts by the family and the Coalition led to the passage of Anton's Law in 2021, which makes police discipline records available to the community under Maryland's Public Information Act.Sonia Kumar, a senior staff attorney with the ACLU of Maryland, said the "hardfought" settlement is about ensuring the medical examiner is truthful about what happens when people, particularly Black people, are killed by police or corrections officials."We can't prevent such deaths if we aren't honest about what caused them, and this settlement is a crucial step towards that goal in future cases," she said in a statement. "We hope this settlement will make a real, positive impact, but it is truly just the beginning of the reckoning needed to address decades of misrepresentations so we can bring justice to families still waiting for the government to tell the truth." 
 
 Caption: ANTON BLACK

 The first 24-hour publicly accessible automatic external defibrillator (AED) for downtown Easton is now operational, thanks to the collaboration of Talbot CARES and Bluepoint Hospitality.Talbot CARES, a program spearheaded by Talbot Paramedic Foundation, Team Trace and Talbot Emergency Services (DES), aims to provide publicly accessible defibrillators and additional emergency equipment around the county.Located on Washington Street adjacent to Doc's Downtown Grille, the newly placed station will ensure citizens have access to potentially life-saving equipment in case of an emergency, no matter what time it is.The station contains an AED device and other medical supplies, including a Stop the Bleed tourniquet kit and opioid overdose kits."We are incredibly proud of this station.It's the first time we've been able to place a station that is accessible 24 hours a day, outside of a public park or recreation area," said Rachael Cox, special programs paramedic for DES."By placing it in a prominent location downtown, we are hoping that this important resource will be utilized in emergencies by the surrounding community." "As part of this initiative, many Bluepoint staffers were certified in CPR, First Aid, AED and Stop the Bleed this year. We hope other downtown businesses join in on the efforts. The more staff that is certified, the better we can serve individuals with life-saving techniques before the professionals arrive." A nationally recognized model for placing public access AEDs, Talbot CARES has placed over 200 automatic external defibrillators (AEDs) in businesses, recreation facilities and parks, government buildings and more in Talbot County.To learn more about the program, contact Talbot Paramedic Foundation at talbotparamedic.org. Easton veteran celebrates a family lineage of service

 EASTON - Eric Saulsbury comes from a lineage of service.Born and raised in Easton, he is a third generation veteran, having served as an Army paratrooper with the 82 Airborne Division before he retired as a lieutenant colonel."My grandfather fought in the Korean war," he said. "My father did three tours of Vietnam. I served in the Army. My brother Kevin served in the Army. My brother Brian served in the Marines. As far as I know, I am a third generation to serve." Saulsbury's son is taking a little time, but then he also has plans to enlist.Saulsbury enlisted in 1993 and retired in 2023 - a 30-year military career."I lead a battalion of 350 and ran a brigade of 3,500 as a brigade XO - chief of staff. I was second in charge. I took a battery out of country in 2006 of 140 soldiers to Iraq and back," he said. "We did route clearance, and I also shot artillery in combat. I got deployed five times. Three times to Iraq and twice to Afghanistan. I have also been deployed to Haiti. It was a response force." Having experienced both service work in Haiti and combat in the Middle East, Saulsbury said he preferred combat."In combat you were at least helping the people of Iraq and Afghanistan.It was more rewarding to get rid of the Taliban in Afghanistan, and Al Qaeda in Iraq, and Al Qaeda and Isis in Iraq," he said.After jumping out of airplanes and being in combat situations, Saulsbury said he has learned an important lesson - "to live life every day to its fullest." "When you have had that significant emotional event in combat, then you realize that life is short," he said.Saulsbury celebrated his retirement in September, which was attended by friends made throughout his decades-long career.Saulsbury looks at the numbers of his time in service. He brought all 140 soldiers back from Iraq. He gave out ten purple hearts."There were 67 IED attacks.We had humvees and different kinds of gun trucks. We did route clearance and escort and we shot artillery. Cannons with howitzers - 155mm. I did 110 jumps.I feel all 110 now. I got a metal hip from years of wear and tear," he said.And as the life out of the service comes he is pretty clear about what he wants from his community and the Army."The one thing I can say is when you see a service member, it is not the 'Thank you for your service' comment. It is really just have an appreciation for what they do. Only 1% serves in the military," he said.

Medical center, juvenile justice top priorities for Shore lawmakers

 EASTON - Securing funding for the new regional medical center and addressing local impacts of last year's juvenile justice reform laws are priorities for Mid-Shore lawmakers heading into the 2024 General Assembly in January.During a Tuesday meeting with the Talbot County Council and local stakeholders, the three Mid-Shore legislators, Sen. Johnny Mautz and Reps. Chris Adams and Tom Hutchinson, tackled a number of issues affecting the district, discussing ways to advance their progress in the upcoming legislative session.REGIONAL MEDICAL CENTERSecuring financial support for the University of Maryland Shore Regional Health's new regional medical center has long been a top priority for local legislators.The proposed 147-bed hospital and medical office building are slated to occupy just over 235 acres off of Longwoods Road near U.S.Route 50 in Easton.The start of construction is dependent on the project receiving a Certificate of Need from the Maryland Health Care Commission.The hospital system filed the CON application in January and anticipates a response in December or January, said Ken Kozel, president and CEO of UM Shore Regional Health.In a separate process, the hospital system is working with the Health Services Cost Review Commission, the state's rate-setting authority, to see if rate relief can be obtained to offset the cost of interest and depreciation for the project.However, MHCC will first need to hear from HSCRC to determine if the project is financially viable before making a decision on the application. Uncertainty lies in how much the HSCRC decision will weigh on the health care commission's answer, Kozel said.That relief, along with government funding, is key to moving forward with the regional medical center.Former Gov. Larry Hogan earmarked $100 million last December for the project in the state's fiscal year 2024 budget.During this year's legislative session, lawmakers secured $10 million in the budget for the new medical center, which the hospital system must spend by June 30, 2024, Kozel said.There's also a pledge for $20 million in fiscal year 2025, though it's subject to change, so the hospital system is asking Gov. Wes Moore to solidify that allocation, along with the remaining $70 million, he added.The county council and lawmakers can write letters of support to help ensure the governor is aware of the project, Kozel said.Del. Chris Adams (R-37B) expressed his vote of confidence and support."We want this project to happen as much as you do and as much as every elected official does," he said, "And most importantly, as much as every citizen that will stand to benefit from the delivery of the services that are possible in a brand new facility and the quality that you get from your organization."JUVENILE JUSTICETalbot County Sheriff's Office Capt. John Bollinger and Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey raised concerns about the significant impacts resulting from the passage of juvenile justice reform measures last year.Bollinger said the legislature was "wrong" for passing the laws last year, highlighting a 42% increase in youth crime in schools and two provisions of the laws that have been particularly burdensome for local law enforcement.One provision bars police from being able to charge a child under 13 years old with a crime unless it's a violent crime, such as murder, attempted murder or rape."The worst part is that these kids know that, and the criminals know that," Bollinger said, suggesting that 12-year-olds could be implicated in illegal activities and not be punished for their involvement."They can do it in front of our face, and we can't do anything other than tell them, 'That's bad, you shouldn't do that,'" he said.Under another law, police are not allowed to interview a child after they're arrested until the child has an attorney to represent them, even if it's to get more information or to find out if others are involved."I'm here to tell you that there's not a lawyer anywhere that's going to say, 'Sure, tell the police everything,' - they're going to shut them down on the phone without even meeting them, knowing nothing about the case, and then our hands are tied," Bollinger said.The increase in crime in schools is mainly from the county's middle and high schools, and the majority of the crimes are assaults, he said. And out of 114 reported assaults in the schools in the last year, 40 of them involved children under 13.However, Talbot County is experiencing less youth crime than some other Shore jurisdictions. In Dorchester and Wicomico counties, the number of assaults on both students and staff are "dramatically higher" than previous years, said Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-37B)."The good newsis every county is now talking about it," he said. "The county executives on the western shore are talking about it, butis anybody going to want to make a change?"COUNTY INITIATIVESWhile there are no specific Talbot County bills being proposed for consideration by the state legislature so far, the county is supporting the Maryland Association of Counties' 2024 legislative initiatives.Those initiatives include launching forward-thinking firefighter and emergency medical services incentives, providing transparency in education spending, modernizing local revenue structures and advancing comprehensive housing solutions.

title: Serving, protecting for 250 years - The Caroline County Sheriff's Office celebrates its sesquicentennial
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
Serving, protecting for 250 years - The Caroline County Sheriff's Office celebrates its sesquicentennial

 November 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 1A | Section: News 
 
 979
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - To mark the 250th anniversary of the Caroline County Sheriff's Office, a new badge has been struck, containing symbols of its history dating to colonial Maryland.But the badge itself is a symbol of the long line of sheriffs who have held the office since 1773, when Thomas Hughlett of Greensboro was appointed by the British governor after the county was formed from parts of Dorchester and Queen Anne's counties.Bookending the long blue line is Sheriff Donnie Baker, who, like Hughlett, is also a Greensboro native. He's the county's 77th sheriff.Caroline County Deputy Lt. Jacob Andrew is the unofficial historian of the sheriff's office. And because he's the fifth generation of the Andrew family to serve the office during the past century, he's well-qualified for the job."Jake was just teaching me something," Baker said. "I didn't know that the first sheriff was buried up there (in Greensboro)." According to Andrew's research, Hughlett was a plantation owner appointed to a one-year term by the governor to be in charge of weights and scales because he was deemed trustworthy.Ironically, the next year he became captain of the Caroline County Militia Fifth Company, which encompassed Greensboro, Goldsboro and Bridgetown during the American Revolution.Hughlett later became a judge. He is buried in a crypt in a tiny, privately-owned graveyard in a Greensboro subdivision, the site of the Hughlett family farm.During the Civil War, John Wilson Saulsbury served a two-year term from 1861 to 1863 and was required to swear allegiance to the Union.Andrew said Sheriff James Temple, who served from 1923 to 1926 "was actually a pretty cool guy." A veteran of the Spanish-American War, Temple was known as the walking sheriff."He had the first Buick in Caroline County. He always told everybody that," Andrew said. However, "he hated driving it.So, if he had to go serve a warrant on somebody, he'd walk from Denton to Ridgely, lock them up and walk them back." "The original sheriff's office was pretty much a shed on the courthouse green, and it was very easy to break out of," Andrew said. The lynching on the green of Federalsburg blacksmith Marshall Price following accusations of murder in 1895 prompted the government to build a new jail across Gay Street on the Choptank River, where it stands today.In 1921, William Curtis Andrew, Jacob Andrew's great-great grandfather, became sheriff and served a two-year term. His son, William E. Andrew served from 1938 to 1946 and, following a four-year term by Saulsbury Sparks, served again from 1950 to 1961, dying of a heart attack in his office.William's son Louis C. Andrew served from 1961 to 1994, retiring when he was 70. His son, then-Deputy Charles Andrew, served as acting sheriff until Phil Brown was elected sheriff the following year.Back then, the sheriff and his family lived in the center section of what is now the Caroline County jail. Two wings were added to the large brick structure, but Charles Andrew remembers when the original section was home."I got to know a lot of inmates," he said.He recalls the night his "mother had a fit" when a naked woman was brought in by the state police."They had to come in the front door and walk down the hall which separated the living room and dining room directly back to that one-room office" at the back of the house, he said."I would have been seven or eight" years old, Charles Andrew said. "So, she made my father go to the commissioners, and that's when they put stairs on the side of the building to come in the outside door." "Back then, when my father started, he was only making $2,600 a year," he said. "They had to supply their own vehicle. The only thing the county gave them was a radio that went into their own private car." That center section of the current jail is called the Andrew Building today.Until 1994, both the sheriff's office and jail were under the jurisdiction of the sheriff, according to Charles Andrew. When Brown became sheriff, the county Department of Corrections was formed as a separate agency, and Charles Andrew served as the superintendent for 13 years, after serving in the sheriff's office for 20 years.Charles's son Jacob, now the fifth generation to serve in the sheriff's office, serves the county with almost 50 fellow deputies. After serving in the Air Force, Jacob Andrew joined the sheriff's office and has been on the job for 19 years. "I love it. I love my job," he said.The commemorative badge symbolizes not only his family's history of serving county citizens in the sheriff's office, but a long legacy of the office's commitment to public safety stretching back to the nation's founding.At the five points of the badge's star are a Revolutionary War soldier, the Caroline County Circuit Court building, the original courthouse before the renovations, the original sheriff's office on Gay Street, and the current office, completed in 2021 on Double Hills Road."One of the things that former Sheriff Randy Bounds wanted to do was have a wall of sheriff's (pictures)," Baker said."So I told him that Jake is going to fulfill that dream of his." The sheriff's office is seeking memorabilia from the public for a future museum or showcase. If you have any artifacts, photos or clippings you'd like to share, contact Lt. Jacob Andrew at 410-479-4124 or jandrew@carolinemd.org.

title: Republicans pledge to 'restore balance' with public safety agenda
author: Steph Quinn; Capital News Service
content:
Republicans pledge to 'restore balance' with public safety agenda

 November 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Steph Quinn; Capital News Service | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 642
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS - Senate and House Republicans vowed Tuesday to redress what House Minority Leader Jason Buckel (R-Allegany) called Maryland's "soft on crime policies" with a 2024 public safety agenda that would intensify punishment for adults accused of gun-related and violent crimes and reverse reforms to the youth legal system passed by the General Assembly in 2022."The crime we're seeing in our communities is not anecdotal, nor media manufactured," said Senate Minority Leader Stephen Hershey (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil and Caroline). "It is real. The violence is real. And we are pleading with our Democrat colleagues to join us in making it their priority as well." The package would increase penalties for gun theft and violent firearms offenses, authorize law enforcement to search vehicles based on the smell of cannabis alone and limit eligibility for bail or reduced sentences for those charged with or convicted of violent crimes.One proposal would make theft of a firearm a felony - a measure Republicans have sponsored without success since 2018.Another would increase prison time and maximum fines for crimes committed with illegal firearms and would remove the "drug dealer loophole" whereby drug dealers receive a lighter sentence for possessing weapons than others committing similarly weighted offenses.A measure would eliminate reduced prison time for good behavior for those convicted of first-or second-degree murder, cap such reductions for other crimes of violence and prohibit bail for those accused of a crime of violence while facing pending violent crime charges.House and Senate Democratic leaders could not be reached to comment on the likelihood that the proposals in the package will clear Democratic majorities in both chambers.The youth justice proposal would require under-13 youth to appear before a juvenile court upon arrest for crimes involving firearms and broaden the juvenile court's jurisdiction to include youth on their third arrest for nonviolent crimes, including auto thefts. It would also allow police to interrogate youth with parental consent alone, rather than requiring that a young person first consult with an attorney.The proposal would allow law enforcement to skirt the Child in Need of Supervision process, which provides a pathway for police or citizens to enlist help from the Department of Juvenile Services in connecting youth of any age with services.Del. Jesse Pippy (R-Frederick) said current law, including the CINS process, has neither held "offenders that happen to be juveniles" accountable nor connected them with services."The argument we're hearing from on the street is (that) law enforcement doesn't know what to do with these kids," Pippy said."So they're not going anywhere.They're not getting any services. No one's talking with them. No one's following up with them." DJS data shows that most CINS cases end in referrals to services rather than in court, but also that law enforcement are using the process infrequently in much of the state.Though Pippy said he's open to programs to educate police officers on the CINS process, which dates to 1969 in Maryland law, he and others said that CINS is not sufficient.Buckel said youth involved in escalating and violent crimes "need more than what theChild In Need of Supervision system can provide." Pointing to closures of DJS residential facilities in western Maryland, Buckel suggested committed placement in DJS residential facilities could give youth "opportunities to succeed." "They're not draconian prisons," he said. "They're getting classes.They're getting education." But advocates of youth legal reform have pointed to research showing that youth incarceration increases the likelihood of recidivism and called for long-term investment in resource-starved communities.Senate Minority Whip Justin Ready (R-Frederick and Carroll) stressed a need for balance in comments after the press conference, saying, "I think we need to provide more accountability and more services that are truly effective."

title: Caroline CASA honors armed forces veterans
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
Caroline CASA honors armed forces veterans

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 1A | Section: News

 DENTON - CASA of Caroline welcomed veterans of the armed forces to its annual Veterans Day Heroes Breakfast Friday, Nov. 10, at the Denton Diner.From a former corporal to a retired lieutenant colonel, local veterans enjoyed the free breakfast hosted by the nonprofit organization that "advocates for the best interest of all abused and neglected children who are in the Caroline County court system through no fault of their own," according to carolinecasa.org.Executive Director Amy Horne welcomed about two dozen veterans. "Anybody who has had the courage to put on the uniform is a hero in my mind," she said.The 7:30 a.m. gathering began with a prayer led by Pastor Don Reynolds of Calvary Baptist Church in Denton. He is also a retired lieutenant colonel with the Maryland Army National Guard.Horne read a lengthy statement from U.S. Sen.Ben Cardin, who expressed his "profound admiration for the unwavering service and sacrifices of our veterans," particularly recognizing Maryland veterans who have served in every armed conflict since the Revolutionary War.Following a moving short video that depicted a military veteran, who is a court-appointed special advocate (CASA) volunteer, helping a young child. A few veterans wiped tears from their eyes."At CASA, we really want to honor and recognize our veterans because veterans are people who protect our freedoms, just like our advocates are the people who protect the rights of the children we serve," Horne said.She said her late father, Talbot County Circuit Court Judge William S.Horne, who was an Army veteran, helped bring the CASA program to the Eastern Shore in 1990.Denton Town Councilman and former Marine Keith Johnson is also president of CASA of Caroline.After some good-natured ribbing of the other service branches, Johnson asked veterans to consider becoming CASA volunteers."Why is CASA, a child advocacy group, hosting a Veterans Day (event)?" he asked, answering the question by listing traits that correlate between veterans and CASA volunteers."Discipline, fighting spirit, leadership, resiliency. We see our veterans as difference-makers in the world.They're mission-ready," said Johnson, whose wife is CASA volunteer Stephanie Johnson."Being married to an advocate, I know that those traits overlap," he said. "Our advocates make a difference every day, our staff makes a difference every day." "As a (Maryland State) trooper, I served about three years as the primary investigator for Caroline County for the Maryland State Police, dealing with child abuse, child neglect," Johnson said. "There's a need in our county for advocates because our children are underserved and our children live as victims of abuse and victims of neglect every day." Johnson appealed to the gathered veterans to consider becoming a CASA volunteer."If you're not an advocate, think about what you can do different this year," he said. "The military focuses on protecting our country, while at CASA we want to protect tomorrow's future - our children."

title: Oxford to install three-way stop on Tilghman Street - Town considering traffic study to address speeding concerns
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Oxford to install three-way stop on Tilghman Street - Town considering traffic study to address speeding concerns

 November 17, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 2 | Section: News 
 
 545
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD - The Town of Oxford is taking steps to address traffic concerns on Tilghman Street.Resident Will Cawley brought his concerns to the Commissioners of Oxford at a town meeting Tuesday evening. Cawley spoke about the safety issue of cars driving too fast down Tilghman Street.To address these concerns, the town will be putting in stop signs at the intersection ofTilghman Street and Bank Street. On Thursday, Town Manager Cheryl Lewis said in a text that the stop signs will be installed in the next few weeks."I think the first step really is to put up a stop sign at Tilghman and Bank," Commission President Tom Costigan said at the meeting on Tuesday. "A three-way stop. Let's see if that works."Cawley came to the commissioners with speed data collected over a 13-day period in August as well as a proposal for a speed study from Traffic Concepts Inc. He said that in doing research, he found that the first step in getting the speed lowered from 25 miles per hour on Til-ghman Street would be to have a speed study done."Once the speed study is done, then we can reevaluate what the recommendations are and see if we can make some changes to get the speed lowered," he said.Cawley asked that, in the meantime, the town get speed feedback signs installed on the street.According to the speed data collected by the Oxford Police Department in August, of the 3,225 total vehicles counted, there were 73 speed violations. The max speed recorded was 36 miles per hour.During the meeting, Cawley pointed out that Tilghman Street is 17-feet wide without any shoulders or a continuous sidewalk.Oxford Police Chief Eric Kellner said that sidewalks would be a benefit, considering all the pedestrians walking down Tilghman street in the summer."People walk up and down that road, tourists and locals alike," he said. "Sidewalks would be a great thing to look at. But I also know that putting in sidewalks is not as easy as saying, 'We want a sidewalk.'"The speed study proposed by Traffic Concepts Inc. would cost the town $3,100. From it, the town would receive the speed study results, the engineering firm's observations and a report "that details the steps and reasoning used to establish the recommended speed limits."Costigan and Cawley agreed that if town opts to do the speed study, it should be done in the summer, when traffic is at its peak.Costigan said that while he didn't disagree with doing a speed study, putting up stop signs is a good first step."It's not an easy process," Costigan said about getting the speed lowered. "But it's one we can certainly look into and try."Kellner said that once the stop signs are up, there will be a "period of education" for people to get used to the change before they begin ticketing people for failing to stop.Costigan said getting the stop signs installed now, rather than in June or July, is better because it will give drivers time to get used to the stop before the busy summer months."And who knows," he said. "They may even like it."

title: CASA of the Mid-Shore is thankful for dedicated volunteers
author: Casa Of The Mid Shore
content:
CASA of the Mid-Shore is thankful for dedicated volunteers

 November 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Casa Of The Mid Shore | Page: 9 | Section: News 
 
 391
 Words

 CASA of the Mid-Shore, a private, nonprofit organization, advocates for children under the protection of the Talbot, Dorchester, Queen Anne's or Kent Circuit Courts because of abuse, neglect or abandonment to ensure the children's right to thrive in safe, permanent homes.A CASA volunteer's role is unique. As a caring and consistent adult, CASA volunteers attempt to identify the specific needs of each child, advocate in court and with agency partners for services to meet those needs and assist in seeking a permanent resolution for each child's life as quickly and safely as possible.Most importantly, the CASA gets to know their appointed children, often becoming one of the most consistent adults in children's lives.This is especially poignant during the holiday season, when all children need to know that someone cares and is looking out for them.For many children, the holidays are a time for building happy memories with family.However, holidays can be very difficult for children who have been removed from their homes and placed in foster care.Rather than enjoying the magic of the season, these children may be adjusting to new foster homes and transitioning to new schools. That can be a heavy burden, and CASA volunteers can help by being present for the children.CASA's involvement can lead to children's hope for a better tomorrow.Studies support the fact that children and youth with CASA volunteers have higher levels of hope than foster children who do not have CASA in their lives.Greater hope can lead to children being more likely to succeed in school, having greater self-control, increased optimism and a healthier sense of well-being."Speaking up for children is our proverbial North Star. It guides us in the certainty that a better future is a real possibility for each child we serve," said Robin Davenport, CASA's executive director. "As we enter the holiday season, we are filled with gratitude for our CASA volunteers. Their compassionate dedication to vulnerable children is a treasure in our service region." CASA volunteers come from all walks of life, varied experiences and professions, and are at least 21 years of age. After completing the application and screening process, individuals participate in pre-service training before being sworn in as an officer of the court.CASA welcomes volunteers from all cultures, ethnicities and backgrounds.To learn more about becoming a Court Appointed Special Advocate, visit casamidshore.org or email jc@casamidshore.org.

title: Juvenile crime, reform are top issues for Talbot County police
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Juvenile crime, reform are top issues for Talbot County police

 November 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 615
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Talbot County is seeing increases in juvenile crime, along with upticks in petty thefts and some violent crimes, according to the county's top law enforcement officials.Updates on local crime trends from each law enforcement agency in the county dominated discussion at Talbot County's latest Police Accountability Board meeting on Tuesday, Nov. 14.Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble reported a 19% increase in calls for service and a 13% increase in reported crime handled by the sheriff's office, including some small increases in assaults and drug charges. Crimes relating to fraud of older residents are likely the biggest financial loss in the county, he added.Gamble identified juvenile crimes in schools as a particular issue for the sheriff's office, which has uniformed officers serving in most of the public schools.Recently implemented state juvenile justice reform laws have barred police from charging anyone under 13 with most crimes.Gamble said Easton High School and Easton Middle School are where police see most of the incidents involving children, and over 30% of this year's reported incidents involve children under 13."We have 12-year-olds that are punching other kids in the face time and time again in the schools, or assaulting other kids, and there's no services for them," he said.Police Accountability Board members acknowledged the concerns, asking what officers can do to better handle issues with youth under 13 and if police can work with the schools.Gamble said the school system doesn't have leverage to handle discipline other than resorting to suspensions.Looking forward, Gamble hopes to see movement within state leadership in Annapolis during the upcoming General Assembly session to push legislation to tackle issues with the juvenile reform laws.Outside of juvenile crime, those at the meeting discussed several recent local incidents.In Easton, two homicides occurred within town limits in the last few months - one on Blake Street in early August and a second at the Sidetracked Saloon in late September.Several thefts and robberies have also occurred in town, said Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey. Those include a series of burglaries at vape stores where individuals are seeking Delta-8 THC cartridges, a non-regulated and legal psychoactive substance with effects similar to recreational cannabis.Another issue of great concern to Easton residents is crime on the Rails to Trails pathways throughout town, Lowrey said, citing a serious assault on the trails in the summer.To alleviate those concerns, the town's police department is increasing patrols on the trails and issuing more citations, Lowrey said. Those efforts include repopulating the department's bike unit, which is down due to lower staffing levels.In St. Michaels, Police Chief Jeffrey Oswald didn't note any specific crime trends, though he did mention two car thefts, which are "extremely unusual" for the town, he said. The town's tourist season is coming to a close, which means St. Michaels will have a lower population and more shops closed up for the winter.The small St. Michaels Police Department is down a few officers, though two new officers are starting soon, Oswald said. The department was also able to secure higher starting salaries and increases for current officers."Things are looking up. It's just going to be a little while," he said.Oxford Police Chief Eric Kellner did not report any major issues, adding that Oxford is a "very safe little town." The town's three-member police department was fully staffed until a few weeks ago, but Oxford's town commissioners recently agreed to increase the department to four full-time officers, Kellner said. The town is now looking to hire one additional officer.
