title: Felony Charges Upheld Against Unionville Shooting Suspect
author: Natalie Jones; Njones@Chespub. Com
content:
Felony Charges Upheld Against Unionville Shooting Suspect

 November 24, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; Njones@Chespub. Com | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 510
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - A Talbot County judge upheld felony charges against the Prince George's County man arrested in connection to an August shooting in Unionville.During a preliminary hearing Tuesday, Talbot District Court Judge Karen Ketterman determined there was sufficient probable cause to forward multiple felony charges against Stewart Orlando Ray to the county's circuit court.Ray, 37, was extradited from Washington, D.C. to Talbot County in late October on warrants charging him with attempted murder, assault, reckless endangerment and firearm offenses related to the Aug. 6 shooting of a 39-year-old man.Deputies from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office responded to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Easton around 9 p.m. Aug. 6 for a report of a shooting victim.The man told police he was driving near Unionville when he noticed another car following him at a high rate of speed. The car, which the victim identified as belonging to Ray, passed him and pulled off to the side of the road near a stop sign, police said.As the victim passed Ray's vehicle, a man shot at him multiple times, striking both the victim and his car, the victim told police. The victim was struck in the hand and drove himself to the hospital for treatment, police said.The victim's girlfriend, who was previously with Ray, said Ray had previously made threats against the victim's life, a detective from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office said Tuesday.Police said Ray fled the area in his car, failed to stop for a stop sign at the intersection of Unionville Road and Bruffs Island Road, left the roadway and struck a parked vehicle, disabling his own car.In court, the detective testified that Ray's phone was plotting in the area of the shooting that night.Ray then fled on foot into the nearby woods, prompting a 24-hour manhunt beginning in the early morning hours. Police later learned that Ray's girlfriend picked him up in the area several hours later.The detective testified to Ray's girlfriend, telling police Ray admitted to the shooting and that Ray had a handgun with him when she picked him up.A U.S. Marshals task force located Ray in Alexandria, Virginia on Aug. 8. Police said Ray was shot when the task force attempted to apprehend him.He was taken to a local hospital with life-threatening injuries.A .40 caliber handgun was recovered in the car Ray was using in Alexandria, the detective said. While ballistics testing is still in progress, several .40 caliber casings were recovered from the shooting site in Talbot County.The detective also said Ray texted the victim's girlfriend, whom Ray has a daughter with, to tell his daughter that he was sorry and he loved her.Prosecutor Joyce Jones pointed to the threats and the victim saying a man parked and waited to shoot at him and his vehicle as substantial steps to attempt to murder the victim.Defense attorney Kisha Petticolas said it was "curious" that no one identified Ray as the man who shot at the victim, saying that without an identification, all other evidence was circumstantial.Ray will remain held without bond pending further court hearings.

title: Easton woman gets probation for evidence tampering in shooting case
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Easton woman gets probation for evidence tampering in shooting case

 November 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 488
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - An Easton woman was given two years of unsupervised probation Wednesday, Nov. 22, after she was found guilty of tampering with evidence related to a fatal shooting in Easton.During a trial last week in Talbot County District Court, presiding District Judge Joseph Riley found Dana L. Wilson, 59, guilty of tampering with evidence connected to the man charged with murder in the shooting. She was given a one-year sentence, all of which was suspended, according to court documents.The charges against Wilson stemmed from her actions in the minutes following the fatal Aug. 7 shooting.Police responded to the area of 104 Blake Street around 7 p.m. that day for a report of a person who had been shot and was laying in the grass.Officers arriving on scene rendered aid to the man, later identified as 55-year-old Ty A. Brooks, until paramedics arrived. Brooks died from his injuries at the scene, police said.Police said earlier on Aug. 7, Brooks argued with individuals who were near and operating a Range Rover, which was parked in the 100 block of Blake Street.Brooks left the area and returned later, operating an ATV.Brooks confronted the same individuals with a shotgun, police said.Police said after the group exchanged words, a man seated in the driver's seat of the Range Rover fired shots through the front passenger seat window and struck Brooks' side, causing him to fall from the ATV.The man in the driver's seat was identified by police as Daseir Cornish, 22, of Denton. Cornish is charged with second-degree murder, assault, manslaughter and related charges in connection to Brooks' death.According to charging documents filed in Wilson's case, surveillance footage showed Cornish exiting the car after the shooting and dropping an object from his lap onto the sidewalk on Blake Street, police wrote.Six minutes later, the footage showed a woman, later identified as Wilson, emerging from the tree line between Blake Street and Glenwood Avenue. Wilson bent down to pick up an item on the sidewalk, which appeared to be the same item Cornish dropped, police said.During an interview with police, Wilson said she received a call from Cornish - her grandson - asking her to pick up the cell phone he dropped on Blake Street.The number Cornish called Wilson from was later identified as a number belonging to Raheem Green, 28, of Cambridge, police said. Green is charged with acting as an accessory after the fact of murder for allegedly helping Cornish flee from the scene and discard evidence.Wilson said she placed Cornish's phone in a bag on a bench behind a home on Glenwood Avenue.One of Cornish's friends picked up the phone, Wilson told police.In charging documents, police asserted Cornish's phone would have been evidence in the homicide investigation.The cases against Cornish and Green are still pending. Cornish is scheduled for a trial Feb. 26 to March 1. Green is set for a trial March 11 to March 15, according to online court records.

title: Talbot Police Accountability Board gears up for first annual report
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Talbot Police Accountability Board gears up for first annual report

 November 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 346
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - As the year draws to a close, the Talbot County Police Accountability Board is preparing to compose its first annual report.The Board, which receives complaints of police misconduct, meets with law enforcement officials and reviews outcomes of disciplinary matters, will be required to submit the annual report to the Talbot County Council by Dec. 31.The report is intended to identify trends in police disciplinary processes and recommend policy changes that would improve police accountability in Talbot County.It will also include the number of complaints submitted by members of the public.The Administrative Charging Committee which reviews findings of a law enforcement agency's investigation of a complaint, determines if an officer should be administratively charged and recommends appropriate discipline, has received 14 complaints between January and August, according to the Talbot County Office of Law.While the Board will meet on Tuesday, Dec. 19, to discuss the draft annual report, top law enforcement officials weighed in on some items they want to see included in the document at the Board's Nov.14 meeting.Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble asked the Board to include details on the amount of time local law enforcement agencies are spending on handling complaints, adding that it's an added workload for his office.Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey said he appreciated how the Administrative Charging Committee's opinions were reasoned out, though he believed some things were mischaracterized.Lowrey also said the "year and a day" issue needed to be addressed.State law requires that a determination on whether or not an officer should be administratively charged be made within a year and a day of a complaint being made. Talbot County law enforcement officials raised concerns about the rule in the context of parallel criminal investigations, according to minutes from the Board's August meeting.Police Accountability Board Chair Mitch Ettinger agreed to address the issue in the report.Further discussion will take place at the December meeting.

title: Man found guilty in death of infant son - Baltimore man sentenced to 35 years by Caroline County judge
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Man found guilty in death of infant son - Baltimore man sentenced to 35 years by Caroline County judge

 November 30, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 465
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - A Baltimore man was sentenced Wednesday to 35 years in prison after a judge found him guilty of murder in the death of his infant son.Agreeing with joint recommendations from the prosecution and the defense, Caroline Circuit Judge Heather Price handed Sean Casey Pierce the lengthy sentence: 40 years, with all but 25 years suspended, for a second-degree murder charge and 25 years, with all but 10 years suspended, for first-degree assault.The sentences will be served consecutively.Pierce, 50, entered Alford pleas to the two felony charges during Wednesday's court hearing.An Alford plea does not require a defendant to admit guilt, but acknowledges that there was enough evidence for a conviction had the case gone to trial.The sentence comes nearly 18 months after the death of 8-week-old Chance Pierce on May 30, 2022.The case against Pierce stemmed from a 911 call reporting an infant experiencing a medical emergency.Officers from the Federalsburg Police Department responded to a camper on Buena Vista Avenue with emergency medical services personnel for the report.Police said the infant had a weak pulse and was cool to the touch upon their arrival.The child was taken to Nanticoke Memorial Hospital in Seaford before being transported to Nemours Children's Hospital in Wilmington, where he was declared deceased.Pierce told police that he was sleeping in a trailer with Chance and his other young son when he was awoken by the infant choking and vomiting.Pierce and another adult male on the property thought the child was suffering from heat stroke and attempted to cool him off using water and ice pops.However, a medical examiner ruled the child's cause of death as closedhead trauma caused by a blunt force injury.The medical examiner also found the child had several partially healed rib fractures, indicating prior abuse, said Caroline County State's Attorney Sloane Franklin.Pierce was unable to explain his son's injuries, Franklin added. The child's mother said Chance was healthy and had no prior issues.The child's mother was not present in court Wednesday and did not wish to be there, Franklin said."This has been a nightmare for her," he said, adding that he didn't want the child's mother to relive the death of her son.Defense attorney Dana Boston agreed with the prosecution's recommended sentence, calling it and the plea agreement fair."Thirty-five years in prison for a 50-year-old man is not a slap on the wrist," he said.Pierce spoke briefly in court Wednesday, acknowledging the difficulty of the case and some guilt he held, but he ultimately denied criminal involvement in his son's death."I didn't murder my son," he said.As part of the plea agreement, Pierce is not allowed to contact the child's mother.When released from prison, Pierce will be placed on five years of supervised probation.

 CAMBRIDGE - The Cambridge Police Department is adding a civilian position to its ranks.Lamont Goodson was announced as CPD's PROTECT coordinator, a new role that will be funded by the Governor's Office of Crime Control and Prevention.At a Cambridge City Council meeting on Monday, CPD Police Chief Justin Todd said PROTECT stands for Public Resources Organizing to End Crime Together.According to City Council meeting documents, Goodson's tasks will include ensuring the department is using all existing crime prevention programs, working with CPD on grants offered through the state, coordinating community and youth programs and coordinating engagement with CPD in the high-crime area micro-zones.The state PROTECT program was established to maximize resources to "combat neighborhood decline throughout the state" and to "support comprehensive strategies to reduce crime and fear" in communities experiencing high crime.Todd said Cambridge was one of 10 cities that the Governor's office recognized as a high-crime microzone for violent crimes. He said securing a PROTECT coordinator has been a "trying process.""This has been going on for quite some time," Todd said. After 21 years with the FBI, Goodson has retired to Cambridge.Todd said CPD is looking forward to seeing the positive outcomes that come out of the creation of this position. title: Cambridge man found not guilty of assault, mistrial on one charge
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Cambridge man found not guilty of assault, mistrial on one charge

 December 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 489
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - After more than three hours of deliberation, a jury found Jonathan Diaz-Santiago, 36, of Cambridge, not guilty of first-and second-degree assault. The jury could not come to an agreement on a reckless endangerment charge, resulting in a mistrial on that count.Thursday, Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard said the state had not yet made a decision on whether they will retry the reckless endangerment charge.The charges stemmed from a report made by two of Diaz-Santiago's family members that Santiago attempted to hit, choke and stab his stepfather, Jose Sierra, during an argument on Decoursey Bridge Road in Cambridge on May 6.Diaz-Santiago was originally charged with attempted first-and second-degree murder, as well.Leonard said it was a prosecutorial choice, based on the evidence in the case, to drop those charges before the trial.During opening statements of the trial, Leonard said that a family fishing expedition on May 6 ended in violence and bloodshed. She said Sierra was "battered, bruised and in need of medical treatment," following the altercation.Worse than the physical injuries, Leonard said, are the long term effects Sierra is facing from the incident.Defense Attorney Michelle Moodispaw, from the Dorchester County Public Defender's Office, said that the state's case was based around the victim's claims."Because he said so," Moodispaw said in her opening statement, adding that law enforcement didn't talk with others in the area in which the fight took place.Moodispaw said that the case was not simple and straightforward, and said the jury would have just as many questions at the end of the trial as they did at the beginning of the trial.Moodispaw said Sierra was drinking that day, angry with Diaz-Santiago, and said Sierra hit Diaz-Santiago with a liquor bottle "several times."According to police, following the incident, Sierra reported that Diaz-Santiago grabbed his throat, attempting to choke him, while on the fishing trip. Diaz-Santiago then allegedly attempted to hit Sierra in the head with a tire iron, but Sierra was able to block the hit, police said.The two men then got into their vehicle, with Sierra seated in the driver's seat and Diaz-Santiago in the backseat. According to charging documents, the victim told police that Diaz-Santiago put a knife to his throat and verbally threatened him.Sierra told police he exited the car and was followed by Diaz-Santiago, who then attempted to stab him in the upper chest area. Sierra was able to block the attack, but was cut on his left wrist, police said.The officer who took the report observed multiple signs of injury on Sierra, including bruise marks around his neck and shoulder, blood coming out of his right ear and bruises and cuts on his arms.Leonard said she could not give any comment on the trial due to pending litigation.As of Thursday afternoon, Diaz-Santiago is being held without bond. A status conference is set for Friday morning.

 CAMBRIDGE - A Glen Burnie man was arrested Tuesday in connection with a shooting that allowed a patient to escape from the Eastern Shore Hospital Center via a broken window in August.Following a joint investigation with the Cambridge Police Department and the Rockville Police Department, officers arrested Israel Labastida, Jr., 19, and searched his Glen Burnie home Tuesday. Several items were seized from Labastida's home, including a loaded 9mm handgun, police said.Labastida is charged with conspiracy to escape, numerous counts of first-and second-degree assault, reckless endangerment, firearm charges and malicious destruction of property over $1,000.Charges are still pending in Rockville for items seized from Labastida's residence, police said.The charges against Labastida stem from his alleged involvement with the patient's escape from the psychiatric facility.Officers from the Cambridge Police Department responded to the facility in the 5200 block of Woods Road just after 5:30 p.m. Aug. 1 for a shooting incident.Security officers on scene at the hospital told police that an unknown person in a black vehicle approached the building and shot several times into a glass window. The unknown person then kicked the broken window out, which allowed a hospital patient to escape with the unknown person in the black vehicle, police said.Police said no injuries were reported at the scene.Detectives from CPD's criminal investigation also responded to the scene and recovered several spent shell casings, police said.The patient who escaped was identified as Darrin Lee Jeter, 19, of Rockville.Police said Jeter had been committed to the hospital center for assault on law enforcement officers in Montgomery County.Detectives continued the investigation through contacting law enforcement in Montgomery County, where Jeter was later located.Jeter was charged with first-degree escape and is being held without bond. title: 'Being Proactive, Not Reactive' - Caroline County Problem-Solving Court Awarded $200K To Improve, Continue Work
author: Connie Connolly; Cconnolly@Chespub. Com
content:
'Being Proactive, Not Reactive' - Caroline County Problem-Solving Court Awarded $200K To Improve, Continue Work

 December 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; Cconnolly@Chespub. Com | Page: 13 | Section: News 
 
 729
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - The Caroline County Problem-Solving Court recently was awarded more than $200,000 to continue its mission to help individuals who are in the criminal justice system to overcome their addictions, reunite with their families and make positive contributions to their communities.The grant, funded from the Federal Bureau of Justice Assistance through the Maryland Office of Problem-Solving Courts, funds a two-year pilot program that became effective Oct. 1.Caroline County Circuit Court Judge Heather Price explained the problem-solving court to the Caroline County Commissioners Oct. 10.Calling it "a really amazing program to be a part of," Price also explained the purpose of the $206,138 grant.Problem-solving courts, sometimes called adult treatment or adult drug courts, use a team approach, calling on professionals in the community - the state's attorney, mental health professionals, parole and probation and corrections, law enforcement, among others - to help people who are already in the criminal justice system.Problem-solving courts are in 23 of 24 jurisdictions in Maryland.The crimes committed by those involved are mostly nonviolent and primarily driven by substance use disorders, Price said."If you have crime and an addiction, it affects first responders, it affects EMA (and) police, it affects the health department it affects the justice system, it affects corrections," the person's family and children in school, Price said. "There's not an angle in this county that it doesn't affect, and most importantly, it affects the community as a whole."The team approach begins when the decision is made to accept a person in the problem-solving court, which then becomes a "post-conviction, post-sentencing part of (their) probation," Price said."You have to successfully enroll in and complete problem-solving court, which is no easy task," she said. "It takes at least a year, oftentimes longer, and it involves a multidisciplinary approach, so it's not just treatment for substance use disorder. It's required mental health treatment, and it's all these other factors." Four participants graduated in November 2022 and two in January 2023."I'm passionate about it because you can actually see when somebody gets it, and it's remarkable the impact it has on a community," she said. Seven participants currently are enrolled in the program.Commission Vice President Larry Porter said he's attended a graduation ceremony of those who successfully completed the program. "I think it's a great program. I've seen it work," he said. Price encouraged the commissioners and interested people to attend the graduation ceremonies.Statistics supplied to the commissioners by Michelle Bethke, Problem-Solving Court Coordinator for the Caroline County Circuit Court, document the success of the program in Maryland.Adult Treatment Courts statewide demonstrated a "9% reduction in rearrests over two years compared to individuals going through business-as-usual court processing," according to research commissioned by the Maryland Judiciary. Individuals spent 23 fewer days in jail. Two-thirds of ATCs showed improvements in rearrests over time.The Caroline County team is improving its performance, Bethke said. Compliance with best practices has increased from 60% to 89% during the past 18 months the team has revamped the program. "We still have a lot on our to-do list to make more improvements," she said."It costs money to run the program," Price said. However, "it saves money in the long run to the community without a question, and seeing people that go on and have jobs and reunite with families, mothers that haven't seen children in years, it's a really amazing program to be a part of."According to a December 2022 report issued by NPC Research to the Maryland Administrative Office of the Courts, the "average statewide cost to administer an ATC was $27,134 per participant, and the largest spending category was substance use disorder treatment." Maryland saved an average of $14,352 per participant in reduced criminal justice and societal cost outcomes over two years.Price said Caroline County's PSC is one of four in the state that received the grant to implement a universal risk screening pilot program with high-risk, high-need individuals, and "increase the diversity, expand the program, decrease the time of when a person is charged to when they are admitted into the program and, of course, connect individuals to community resources sooner," Bethke said."I think it's just great," Commissioner Frank Bartz said. "I mean, you guys are being proactive, not reactive here, and (the program) is data-driven." 
 
 Caption: CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Caroline County Circuit Court Judge Heather Price explains the mission of the Problem Solv-ing Court to the Caroline County Commissioners Oct. 10.

title: Emergency Services launches 'Season's Safety' campaign
content:
Emergency Services launches 'Season's Safety' campaign

 December 7, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 7 | Section: News 
 
 487
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Talbot County Department of Emergency Services launched a new public awareness campaign coined "Season's Safety." The initiative aims at enhancing public awareness of winter hazards and safety measures, especially around the season of giving."The holidays are a wonderful time to get together with friends and family, but with colder weather and holiday specific activities, there are several hazards to be aware of that may cause injuries, and potentially (loss of) lives each year," said Brian LeCates, director of Emergency Services. "We hope that this campaign will help keep safety on people's minds throughout their holiday celebrations."From home decorating and hot cocoa by the fire, to shopping for gifts and baking cookies, Emergency Services would like to remind citizens of the following safety tips: DECORATE SAFELYKeep potentially poisonous plants, like mistletoe, holly berries and amaryllis, away from pets and children.Avoid placing breakable ornaments or ones with small detachable parts within the reach of small children.Use only indoor lights indoors and outside lights outdoors, and choose the right ladder for the task of hanging lights.For a full list of holiday decoration tips, visit the U.S.Consumer Product Safety Commission publication at cpsc.gov/s3fs-public/611.pdf.WATCH OUT FOR FIRE-STARTERSPick decorations that are flame resistant or flame retardant.Keep lit candles away from children, pets and other decorations.Replace string lights that show signs of wear or have broken cords or bulbs; never tack wiring directly.Place trees at least three feet away from fireplaces, radiators, and other sources of heat and water live trees regularly so they don't dry out.Place a screen in front of your fireplace Blow out candles and turn off electronic decorations before you go to bed.For more information on winter holiday fire tips, visit the National Protection Association at nfpa.org/Education-and-Research/Home-Fire-Safety/Winter-holidays.SHOP SAFELY ONLINEWhen shopping online, have a general idea of how much an item should cost.Sometimes prices are too good to be true.Don't access bank records or online shop when on public wifi. Instead, use a VPN or mobile hotspot.Only buy items from vendors you can verify.Keep an eye on your bank statements and flag any suspicious activity.For the full shopping online toolkit, visit the National Cybersecurity Alliance tips at staysafeonline.org/resources/safe-online-holiday-shopping/.SAY NO TO RAW DOUGHBaking is a great way to celebrate special occasions.When making cookies, brownies, cakes or bread, you might be tempted to taste a bite before it's fully baked. But you can get sick after eating or tasting raw (unbaked) dough or batter.Don't let children handle raw dough, including play clay and dough for crafts.Wash your hands, bowls, utensils, and countertops after handling raw flour, eggs or dough.For more food safety tips, visit cdc.gov/foodsafety/communication/holidays.html.The "Season's Safety" Campaign will run on Talbot County Emergency Services Facebook page during the month of December.The campaign also includes tips on porch pirate prevention, winter weather safety for pets, fireplace safety and more. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Santa On The Shore: St. Nick, Mrs. Claus Visit Local Firehouse
author: Laura Tayman; Ltayman@Chespub. Com
content:
Santa On The Shore: St. Nick, Mrs. Claus Visit Local Firehouse

 December 11, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Laura Tayman; Ltayman@Chespub. Com | Page: 4 | Section: News

 Once they entered the firehouse door, the lucky local children who attended this year's Lunch with Santa on Dec. 3, were mesmerized by only one thing in the room. There, sitting in his big chair, was Santa.And it wasn't just any Santa, it was the real Santa.
Even parents were loving the magic.
"I am very happy I got to come to Chestertown today," Santa said. "We've been so busy at the North Pole. And then we had this fog- lucky thing I had Rudolph to guide the way." This year for the first time the fire company was able to welcome Mrs. Claus as well.
"I am usually so busy monitoring the elves who are getting ready for Christmas," she explained.
"But I managed to get away this afternoon." This family-friendly annual event is sponsored by the Chestertown Volunteer Fire Company, whose members are committed to making the holiday memorable for local families.
Along with the choice of pizza or hot dogs, families were offered an enormous display of a variety of cookies, lovingly prepared by company members.
The most popular? "Definitely the s'mores," longtime fire company family member Megan Darling said, "but chocolate chip is a close second." Numerous tables were set up in the firehall, with different crafts at each.
Kids were busily traveling to new spots, making ornaments and snowmen throughout the day.
But the purpose of their visit was to meet Santa and let him know what they were looking for on Christmas morning.
A Barbie Dreamhouse and her pink corvette was one of the most popular requests.
"Do you know that the elves made one for themselves?" Santa asked a little one. "They have the best time driving it around in the snow." Ken Young, a member of the company and professional photographer, was there to catch the moment when children shared some time with Old St. Nick.
"This is my third year doing it," said Young. "I bring my special equipment, including a printer where I can print the photo out for the parents before they leave." Cindy Morris, who organizes the event, said the day wasn't about the funds raised. "This is us supporting our community."

title: Trial Begins For Cambridge Man Charged In Fatal Shooting
author: Natalie Jones; Njones@Chespub.Com
content:
Trial Begins For Cambridge Man Charged In Fatal Shooting

 December 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; Njones@Chespub.Com | Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 528
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - Testimony began Tuesday in the jury trial for a Cambridge man charged in the shooting death of a 24-year-old man last December.Tramelle Williams, 23, is charged with firstand second-degree murder, armed robbery and firearms offenses in the fatal shooting of Taijay Brian Daniels on Pleasant Street just after 7 p.m.
Dec. 8, 2022.
Wearing a Space Jam jacket and walking down Race Street that night, Daniels was just a normal 24-year-old. He had no idea he was about to be killed "execution-style," said Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard, who is prosecuting the case with Senior Assistant State's Attorney Ella Disharoon.
Williams, wearing a mask, approached Daniels with a gun, shooting him in the back. Then, he shot again, striking Daniels in the head twice before taking Daniels' belongings and leaving.
Although a Cambridge resident on his way home that night found Daniels' body lying facedown on Pleasant Street within minutes of the shooting, and police and emergency medical services personnel performed CPR, Daniels was pronounced deceased at the scene.
Daniels' death was ruled a homicide by multiple gunshot wounds, two of which were "rapidly fatal," a state medical examiner testified Tuesday afternoon.
"He didn't stand a chance," Leonard said during her opening statement.
However, Williams didn't count on surveillance cameras from local businesses capturing the shooting, she said.
Williams also didn't count on police arresting him while he was wearing the same backpack from the night of the shooting, or police finding Daniels' phone in his pocket, Leonard added.
Williams was arrested the next evening following a foot pursuit on Lincoln Terrace. After he attempted to flee, a Cambridge police officer fired, shooting Williams in the leg.
But to defense attorneys Michelle Moodispaw and Stephanie DeLang, evidence shown by prosecutors would not prove Williams guilty.
Video surveillance and forensics presented by prosecutors have limited value, Moodispaw said, urging the jury to consider evidence that wasn't being shown.
The only thing to be presented was "maybes and possibilities," she said.
By the end of the day Tuesday, seven witnesses had testified, including Daniels' mother, police officers, crime scene technicians and the medical examiner.
Additional law enforcement witnesses and forensic analysts are expected to testify Wednesday. A verdict is anticipated Friday.
This week's trial is not the only pending case against Williams.
Williams is also accused in a second fatal shooting in Cambridge, which occurred roughly three hours after Daniels was shot.
Around 10 p.m. Dec. 8, 2022, police responded to the 700 block of High Street for a second gunshot victim, who was identified as Lory Eugene Fields, 69, of Cambridge.
Fields was found lying in a yard with a gunshot wound to his head. He was declared deceased at the scene.
Williams is facing additional murder and robbery charges in connection to Fields' death.
Though the shootings happened within hours of each other and all charges appear to be grouped together in Maryland Judiciary court records, Williams is set to stand for a second trial related to Fields' death in mid-January.

title: Police Team With Talbot Optimist Club For Shop With A Cop
author: Contributed
content:
Police Team With Talbot Optimist Club For Shop With A Cop

 December 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 2 | Section: News 
 
 523
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - The Easton Police Department, the Oxford Police Department and the Talbot County Sheriff 's Office came together Saturday, Dec. 9, for the Talbot Optimist Club's Shop with a Cop event.The event sees police officers pairing with local youths to assist them on a shopping spree to provide holiday gifts for the youths and their families.
Debbie Henckel, event organizer and member of the Talbot Optimist Club, has been working the event for over a decade.
"It's all about the kids, the smiles on their faces, and them being able to have something to give to their families," Henckel said.
The children participating came to the Elks Lodge off Dutchmans Lane, where they were greeted and paired with their chaperoning officers.
After they were welcomed by the officers, the children ventured out to the squad cars to head over to the Easton Walmart.
The squad cars left the Elks Lodge in an impressive fashion, lined up and utilizing lights and sirens similar to a parade procession.
Once they were at Walmart, officers helped the children use their budget and shopping lists to acquire presents for their families. Many of the children involved utilized their entire budget to purchase gifts for their families instead of themselves.
Fortunately, their kindness did not go unnoticed and was rewarded. The chaperoning officers found it in their hearts to give them a little extra so everyone left with a gift of their own.
In addition to the officers chipping in, there were a few shoppers passing by who also donated their own funds to the cause.
"This is a good place we live in," Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey said. "I've seen these kids looking out for their families instead of themselves, our officers reaching into their own wallets to make sure no one is left out, and even just some local townspeople going out of their way to do the same. It is really moving, and I'm proud to see it all." After the shopping was completed, the group returned to the Elks Lodge to get wrapping.
Tape, wrapping paper, bags and scissors were all deployed simultaneously as the officers, and their companions took all the gifts and did their best to make everything look beautiful enough to go under the tree.
Once completed, the officers and children enjoyed pizza and snacks together, before wrapping up the day by playing a spirited soccer match on the lawn outside.
In all her years organizing the event, Henckel said she always sees familiar faces among the officers.
"You see a lot of returning officers and you know that's because they care. It's nice to see their eagerness to be here with the kids," she said in a news release. "They really make a difference to these kids, and around our community."
Henckel thanked the Elks Lodge for donating the space, the Easton Walmart for making the event possible and the three police departments for joining forces.
" To have their support over the years means more than you know," she said.

Helmer Sworn In As Chief Deputy

 December 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; Cconnolly@Chespub.Com | Page: 15 | Section: News

 DENTON - Capt. Rodney "R.J." Helmer was sworn in as chief deputy of the Caroline County Sheriff 's Office Friday, Dec. 8.Clerk of Court Terry Lord administered the oath of office at 1 p.m. at the Caroline County Circuit Court.
A reception followed at the Sheriff 's Office on Double Hills Road in Denton.
"R.J. has been with me through thick and thin at the sheriff 's office," Sheriff Donnie Baker said. "He is true blue, and I really appreciate that, So it wasn't really a hard choice for me."
About 40 people attended the ceremony, including Caroline County Commission Vice President Larry Porter, Commissioner Frank Bartz, retired Sheriff Randy Bounds, Judge Heather Price, Register of Wills Jim Phelps, Deputy County Administrator Dan Fox, members of Helmer's family, deputies and county staff. Attendees greeted Helmer's promotion with a standing ovation.
"I thank Sheriff Baker for the opportunity, and I wouldn't have this opportunity if it weren't for Sheriff Bounds," Helmer said.
"It's a pleasure to work with each and every one of you, and I look forward to doing everything to the best of my ability."
Helmer, 38, began his career in law enforcement in July 2008 with the Cambridge Police Department and joined the Sheriff's Office as a deputy first class on August 19, 2013. He and his family live in Hurlock where Helmer served as chief of the Hurlock Volunteer Fire Company until Dec. 18.
"R.J. is an outstanding police officer, a wonderful human being and one of the hardest working people that I've ever had the pleasure of working with," Bounds said.
"It was an honor to hire him, and I've never regretted that one second. He's knowledgable, energetic, and most supremely of all, he cares about those with whom he interacts."
"You will never, ever have to worry about his dedication and loyalty," Bounds said.
"He will serve the citizens of Caroline County well."
"He is an absolutely hardworking individual and a very capable individual to be my chief deputy and to lead this agency to the next level," Baker said.
Helmer formerly was the lieutenant of the criminal investigation division. Baker appointed Lt. George Paugh, former chief of the Greensboro Police Department, to that position Nov. 1.
Former Caroline County Chief Deputy Sheriff Maj.
James Henning retired in September after more than 26 years of service to the Sheriff's Office.

Dorchester County Circuit Court Welcomes New Casa Volunteers

 December 14, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 New Court Appointed Special Advocates for CASA of the Mid-Shore were sworn in by Clerk of the Court Amy Craig at a ceremony in Dorchester County Circuit Court on December 6.CASA staff and board members were present as the new advocates took an oath promising to advocate for the best interest of children who are under court protection because of maltreatment.
Court Appointed Special Advocates are officers of the court and, as such, are provide assessments and recommendations to judges regarding the best interest of the children to whom they are appointed.
Presiding over the swearing-in ceremony in Dorchester County Circuit Court were the Honorable William H. Jones and the Honorable Mary O'Donnell.
The judge and magistrate thanked the new CASA volunteers for their time and talents on behalf of children and commended the organization for the important information contained in their insightful reports to the court.
"Our program strives to ensure that all children under court protection due to maltreatment receive needed services and a safe, permanent home. We could not accomplish our work without the dedication and commitment of our amazing staff and volunteers.
They work passionately to help improve the lives of maltreated children to assist them in growing to their full potential and giving them hope," said Robin Davenport, executive director of the CASA of the Mid-Shore.
CASA of the Mid-Shore is a private nonprofit created to advocate for every child who is under the protection of the circuit court because of abuse, neglect or abandonment.
CASAs attempt to identify specific needs of each child for the court, advocate for service provision to meet those needs and assist in seeking a permanent resolution for each child's life as quickly and safely as possible.
Most importantly, the CASAs get to know the child and frequently become one of the most consistent adults in the child's life.
CASA of the Mid-Shore is currently accepting applications from adults from Talbot, Dorchester, Queen Anne's and Kent Counties who are interested in becoming CASA volunteers. An organization valuing diversity and equity, CASA seeks volunteers from all walks of life, varied experiences, backgrounds and professions, and who are at least 21 years of age. After completing the application and screening process, prospective volunteers participate in pre-service training before being sworn in as officers of the court.
To learn more about becoming a Court Appointed Special Advocate visit casamidshore.org

title: Easton Man Gets 18 Years For Enticing Child For Sexual Activity
content:
Easton Man Gets 18 Years For Enticing Child For Sexual Activity

 December 14, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: B2 | Section: News 
 
 553
 Words 

 Read News Document

 BALTIMORE - An Easton man was sentenced Wednesday to 18 years in federal prison for attempted coercion and enticement of a minor to engage in illicit sexual activity.U.S. District Judge George L. Russell III handed down the prison term to Samuel Charles Hardeman, 55. His prison term will be followed by lifetime supervised release.
Hardeman had a previous federal conviction in a 2002 case in the Northern District of Georgia for use of a computer to entice a child to engage in sexual activity, for which he was sentenced to 174 months in prison.
Upon his release from prison, Hardeman must continue to register as a sex offender in the places where he resides, where he is an employee and where he is a student, under the Sex Offender Registration and Notification Act, per the judge's order.
The sentence was announced by United States Attorney for the District of Maryland Erek L. Barron, Acting Special Agent in Charge R. Joseph Rothrock of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Baltimore Field Office and Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble.
According to the guilty plea, from Dec. 11, 2022, through Dec. 26, 2022, Hardeman engaged in conversations with an undercover law enforcement officer who purported to have a 10-year-old daughter.
During the conversations, Hardeman expressed how he wanted to have sex with the 10-year-old, sent a video containing child pornography to the undercover officer and made plans to drive to New York, where the undercover officer purportedly lived, to have sex with the 10-year-old.
Hardeman communicated with the undercover officer by phone via video call, text and through the use of encrypted messaging platforms.
The Maryland U.S.
Attorney's Office said the conversations occurred while Hardeman was on the sex offender registration for a previous federal sex offense conviction.
During a call on Dec. 26, 2022, Hardeman expressed hesitation about traveling to New York to visit the undercover officer and her daughter. The officer did not hear from Hardeman after that time.
On March 14, 2023, a federal search warrant was executed at Hardeman's residence, where several electronic devices were seized.
A forensic examination of one of the phones revealed the encrypted messaging account which Hardeman used to communicate with the undercover officer, a text message thread between Hardeman and the officer, photos sent to Hardeman by the officer at Hardeman's request, the photos and videos that Hardeman sent to the officer and dozens of images and videos depicting minors engaged in sexually explicit conduct.
Forensic examinations of several other devices and Hardeman's cloud storage account recovered additional images of child sex abuse material, including bestiality.
This case was brought as part of Project Safe Childhood, a nationwide initiative launched in May 2006 by the Department of Justice to combat the growing epidemic of child sexual exploitation and abuse.
Led by the United States Attorney's Offices and the Criminal Division's Child Exploitation and Obscenity Section, Project Safe Childhood marshals federal, state, and local resources to locate, apprehend, and prosecute individuals who sexually exploit children and to identify and rescue victims.
For more information about Project Safe Childhood, visit justice.gov/psc. For more information about Internet safety education, visit justice. gov/psc and click on the "Resources" tab on the left of the page.
Barron commended the FBI and the Talbot County Sheriff 's Office for their work in the investigation.
Barron thanked Assistant U.S. Attorneys Spencer Todd and Paul E. Budlow, who prosecuted the federal case.

title: Shop with a Cop brings smiles, connections
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Shop with a Cop brings smiles, connections

 December 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 450
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - Jurnee Cannon, 8, led the way down the narrow toy isles of the Cambridge Walmart on Dec. 14 with Officer Malik Shirley following close behind."You drive better than I do," Shirley said to Cannon as she turned into another aisle and gazed up at the bright display of different dolls.
A moment before, Shirley had taken a toy off the top shelf for Cannon to put in her cart. It was a moment she remembered on the ride back to her house later that evening.
"He helped me get my doll that was on the top shelf," she said to explain why she liked Shirley.
At 4 p.m. that Thursday, Cannon's name was the first of two that was pulled from a red bucket at the Cambridge Police Department on Washington Street. Cannon and Nevaeh Moran, 6, were the two lucky children of the day to get the opportunity to "Shop with a Cop." For five years now, the department has been taking children out to Walmart to purchase items for themselves or for family members for the holidays.
"We normally partner up with the Dorchester County Board of Education and they pick the names," Captain Antoine Patton, who started the program, said.
"However, we realized that we were leaving a lot of our community out, so we decided to open it up to the entire community." This year, CPD is drawing two names every evening for 12 days, concluding on Christmas Eve.
Paul Davis Restoration is sponsoring the entire program this year.
"There may or may not be some special kids added toward the end," Patton said. "Wink, wink." Each drawing is broadcasted on Facebook Live. After names are picked, Patton calls the families to let them know their child has won. Then, a small group leaves the station to pick the children up from their homes and take them to Walmart. Each child then gets to spend $100 on "anything of their choosing." The program helps strengthen the department's relationship with the community, particularly with children in the community, Patton said.
"It gives us an opportunity to interact with children and families," he said. "Letting them know that we do a lot of positive things and give them a positive interaction with the police department instead of coming to the house when something's wrong." Patton remembers one night where they pulled up and a little girl "was smiling from ear to ear." "She was like, 'Yes! The police are here!'" Patton said. "She knew we were coming to take her Christmas shopping."

title: Seaford woman found guilty of embezzlement
content:
Seaford woman found guilty of embezzlement

 December 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A2 | Section: News 
 
 291
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - After two days of a three-day jury trial, Karen Knauer, 55, of Seaford, Delaware, entered an Alford plea Oct. 12 to one count of embezzling $36,245.30 from Bell Creek Equipment LLC, of Preston, Maryland, State's Attorney Sloane R. Franklin announced.An Alford plea allows a person to maintain their innocence but acknowledge the State had enough evidence to obtain a conviction.
Knauer was employed by Bell Creek Equipment as a bookkeeper and was responsible for accounts payable, receivable and depositing monies received.
Between Feb. 2017 and May 2018, Knauer failed to make a number of cash and check deposits.
She also wrote checks to herself from the business and changed the business checking account registry to hide her embezzlement.
"Knauer was in a position of trust, and she broke that trust and almost bankrupted a local family business for her own personal gain," Franklin said.
"I want to thank Salisbury University for the use of its resources.
I want to personally thank Professor David Weber, and his students, Micah J. Weber (SU '23; UB School of Law '26), Kaylynn Boswell (SU '23; U.S. Department of the Navy), Camryn Pepper (SU '24), Selena Sandbank (SU '24), and Mitchell Adams (SU '24) for conducting a through forensic accounting of Bell Creek Equipment's accounting records to help discover the embezzlement by Knauer." "Financial crimes are difficult to prosecute, but having the resources that Salisbury University provided and people like Professor Weber and his students, contributed greatly to the outcome of the case," Franklin said.
On Dec. 13, Judge Heather L. Price, sentenced Knauer to three years, suspended all but six months, ordered restitution in the amount of $36,245.30, and placed her on probation for three years.
The case was prosecuted by Franklin on behalf of the citizens of Caroline County.

 QUEEN ANNE - A Queen Anne man is facing multiple charges in connection to two assaults earlier this year, police said.Travis N. Lynch, 33, is charged with first-and second-degree assault and reckless endangerment stemming from incidents in September and October.
He also is charged with illegal possession of a firearm and handgun offenses following the execution of a search warrant, police said.
Investigators with the Talbot County Sheriff's Office responded to the University of Maryland Shore Emergency Center at Queenstown on Friday, Dec. 22, and interviewed a woman who said she was the victim of two separate assaults in the 13000 block of Cannery Road in Queen Anne.
The investigators learned the first incident occurred in September or October. Lynch grabbed the victim after she caught him performing a sex act while watching her in the bathroom, police said.
A second incident occurred in October. The victim told police they were sitting in a vehicle parked in the driveway with another person. Lynch accosted them with a pistol while they were sitting in the driveway, police said.
Investigators obtained an arrest warrant for Lynch on Dec. 22. Police surveilled the Cannery Road address and saw a vehicle believed to be owned by Lynch leave the home.
Deputies with the Talbot County Sheriff's Office pulled the vehicle over for a traffic stop and identified Lynch as the front seat passenger. Police arrested Lynch and took him to Talbot County's central booking facility, where he was ordered held without bond during an initial appearance with a district court commissioner.
Lynch was ordered to remain held without bond during a Dec. 26 bail review, according to online court records.
The investigation continued after Lynch was arrested, police said.
Detectives searched the Cannery Road home and recovered pistol ammunition in a bag connected to Lynch, police said.
Police said detectives searched the vehicle Lynch was in when he was arrested and located a loaded pistol secreted under a trim panel in the front seat passenger area.
The Talbot County Sheriff's Office was assisted by the Easton Police Department's Crisis Response Unit, the Talbot County Drug Task Force and the Maryland State Police Gun Center.

title: Kyleigh remembered - Community rallies around family of girl killed in Christmas morning fire
author: Carl Hamilton; cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Kyleigh remembered - Community rallies around family of girl killed in Christmas morning fire

 January 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton; cahamilton@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 1547
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ELKTON - Tom and Nancy Minor stood in front of the charred remains of a townhouse at 317 Willow Drive in Winding Brook Village near Elkton on Wednesday and remembered 10-year-old Kyleigh Nicole Treadway."Kyleigh was so sweet. She was a most vivacious girl, always smiling.
She loved to give hugs and loved animals. She loved our cats and always asked about them whenever she saw us," Nancy, 67, rattled off, needing little time to gather her thoughts to describe Kyleigh when asked about her.
Her 66-year-old husband, Tom, interjected, "Nothing seemed to faze her. Kyleigh always seemed to be upbeat, like nothing was impossible." Nancy started to speak again, but paused for a few seconds before recalling the last time she saw and interacted with Kyleigh - on a morning maybe a week or so earlier.
Chaperoned by her grandmother, Kyleigh was waiting for the school bus to arrive and take her to Cecil Manor Elementary School.
Nancy, who lives three doors down from 317 Willow Drive, happened to be outside.
"It was right before school was out for Christmas break. She was telling me about all of her animals," Nancy said. (The list of beloved pets in Kyleigh's home included two dogs, a cat, three ferrets and two rats, according to a family friend.)
When the school bus arrived, Kyleigh said her goodbyes - in a way that beautifully reflected her bubbly personality - and then she boarded.
"She said, 'I love you' and hugged her grandmom. Then she hugged me, too, and said, 'I love you'," Nancy said, prompting Tom to marvel, "I don't think she encountered anyone she didn't love." On Christmas morning, in stark and sobering contrast to the wonder and joy that the holiday holds for children, Kyleigh died in a swift-moving blaze that ripped through her family's two-story townhouse at 317 Willow Drive.
Singerly Volunteer Fire Company of Elkton and other area volunteer fire companies rushed to that neighborhood, northeast of Elkton, at approximately 7:30 a.m. Monday after receiving a dispatch regarding a dwelling fire at 317 Willow Drive, reported Master Deputy State Fire Marshal Oliver J. Alkire, an agency detective and spokesman.
"Upon arrival, firefighters found the family standing outside their home, stating a young girl was still inside. Firefighters heroically entered the home and located the child. However, she was later pronounced deceased on the scene," Alkire said, before emphasizing on Wednesday, "Investigators later learned that after family discovered the fire, they made several attempts to save Kyleigh during the fast-moving fire; however, they were unable to due to thick smoke and intense heat." The medical examiner attributed Kyleigh's death to "thermal injuries and smoke inhalation," Alkire reported.
The spokesman updated, "Deputy state fire marshals continue investigating the exact origin and cause (of the fire). While the fire remains under investigation, they have not recovered evidence that it was an intentionally set fire, nor do they believe or suspect that this was an intentionally set fire, and continue to explore all possible accidental causes." In addition to killing Kyleigh - despite heroic efforts by fire responders to rescue the girl - the blaze displaced 17 residents, including her five surviving family members, fire officials said.
The other 12 displaced residents lived in adjacent townhouses, fire officials added. Most of the pets at 317 Willow Drive, where Kyleigh lived, reportedly were lost in the blaze.
The fire displaced three adults and three children who lived at 319 Willow Drive, fire officials said. In addition, the fire displaced two adults and four children at 315 Willow Drive, fire officials added. The American Red Cross is assisting the 17 displaced residents, including Kyleigh's surviving relatives, the spokesman reported.
News of the fatal Christmas morning fire sparked an outpouring of community support for Kyleigh's survivors.
As Tom and Nancy - a retired couple that has owned and lived in their Willow Drive townhouse since 1993 - were speaking with the Cecil Whig on Wednesday afternoon, a woman pulled up in a sport utility vehicle and parked it.
The woman got out of the vehicle and purposefully walked over to a small patch of grass in front of the gutted remains of 317 Willow Drive, where a few people already had placed decorations and stuffed animals to show support, including at least one teddy bear. A strand of yellow "Do Not Cross" emergency scene tape was lying on the ground directly behind a teddy bear. Also nearby were two small, wooden crosses, one of which read, "Grow in grace." There were three candles in tall, slim glasses - similar to ones that might be found inside a church - on the nearby sidewalk. Only one candle was burning, however, the purple one. The blue and orange candles had burned out. The woman who had arrived in the SUV unsuccessfully attempted to relight the other two candles amid a steady rain.
"I did not know Kyleigh and I do not know her family, but I just wanted to come here today," said the woman, a Rising Sun resident who identified herself only as Kathi.
Teary-eyed, Kathi explained that she was experiencing sorrow after learning about the devastating blaze that killed Kyleigh and that she felt compelled to come to the place where it happened.
She placed a small teddy bear, one clad in a soldier uniform reminiscent of "The Nutcracker," in the lap of a bigger teddy bear already on the ground in front of the burnt shell of a townhouse. The woman also left a snowman decoration.
The tragedy spurred Cecil County resident Theresa Retz into action, too.
On Tuesday, one day after the fatal fire, she started a GoFundMe page to benefit Kyleigh's surviving family, which does not have insurance, and she did so with the permission of Kyleigh's mother - Theresa Moats - according to Retz, who works with Moats at Terumo Medical Corporation in Elkton.
"We work together, but we are also good friends," Retz explained.
"I only met Kyleigh a couple of times. But I can say Kyleigh made everyone smile. Her personality brightened a room, and she was the life of the party." On Monday, a few hours after losing Kyleigh in the house fire, Moats reached out to Retz from an area hospital, where medical staff was observing her and the other surviving family members.
"I found out late that morning. She messaged me from a friend's Facebook account because her laptop had burned up along with everything else inside the house. She told me her house burned down and Kyleigh did not make it," Retz said, noting that she sensed Moats was emotionally discombobulated.
"She wanted to know how to get up with the (Terumo) supervisor to let the company know that her badge and scrubs burned in the fire.
That's how I knew her head was nowhere in the right place. I let her know that it's OK and don't worry about that right now." They communicated electronically with each other throughout the day, after Moats and the surviving family members had moved from the hospital to an area hotel that American Red Cross volunteers had arranged for their lodging, at least for the next few days, according to Retz.
The friends had their emotional first face-toface meeting on Tuesday, one day after the fire, when Retz went to the hotel serving as temporary lodging for Kyleigh's surviving family members.
"There was a lot of crying," Retz said.
That day, Retz set up the GoFundMe page to benefit Moats; her fiance, Kevin; Moats' 13-yearold son, Ethan; her 20-year-old son, Jordan; and Moats' mother - the grandmother whom Kyleigh hugged at the bus stop on that morning earlier this month, a heartwarming scene witnessed by neighbor Nancy Minor, who also was embraced by the girl before she departed.
"Anyone who ever interacted with Kyleigh would have a hard time forgetting her," Minor said, after recalling that scene at the bus stop.
As of Thursday afternoon, the GoFundMe page had generated $17,414 in donations for Kyleigh's surviving family members. Also helping with the donations collection is Beth Edwards.
A section on the GoFundMe page reads, "Theresa Moats and her family are wonderful people who have suffered a devastating loss on Christmas Day Funds will be used for Kyleigh's funeral, supporting the family, paying for their current hotel room, as well as helping to secure permanent housing. The family did not have insurance." "People have been awesome.
In addition to (monetary) donations, there has been an avalanche of donated clothing," Retz said.
The list of items needed the most, aside from money, includes cell phones with chargers (T-Mobile network); restaurant gift cards; gasoline gift cards; Walmart and grocery store gift cards; and "any type of special Christmas gift." When asked about Moats' emotional condition, Retz explained, "She's holding up the best she can. She has to be strong, particularly for Ethan, who is now her youngest child."

 PRESTON - A car crashed into a Preston home Sunday morning, sending a 4-month-old baby who was inside the home to the hospital.Troopers from the Maryland State Police Barrack in Easton responded to the 200 block of Main Street in Preston shortly after 9:30 a.m. Sunday for a report of a vehicle that crashed into a residence.

The Maryland State Police Crash Team is leading the investigation. Once their investigation is complete, the team's findings will be submitted to the Caroline County State's Attorney's Office, which will decide whether charges will be filed in the case.

title: Cambridge, Queen Anne's County receive MDOT grants
content:
Cambridge, Queen Anne's County receive MDOT grants

 January 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 3 | Section: News

 HANOVER - The Maryland Department of Transportation congratulated 17 counties and municipalities in Maryland for their selection to receive more than $28 million in Fiscal Year 2023 Safe Streets and Roads for All grants.Awarded by the U.S. Department of Transportation, these grants are an important step toward meeting Maryland's goal of Vision Zero - the elimination of all traffic fatalities and severe injuries on Maryland roadways by 2030.
"In order to create the transportation system that Marylanders deserve, we must work with our citizens, our local officials and our Congressional delegation with unity and focus to deliver safe, equitable access across the state for everyone, whether they drive, ride, or walk," Gov.
Wes Moore said. "These grants help us achieve that goal and help fulfill our mission to lift every community."
The grants will be used for implementation, planning and demonstration projects to improve safety and help prevent deaths and serious injuries on the region's roadways.
MDOT worked in collaboration with local municipalities to advocate for the grant funding.
"The Maryland Department of Transportation is proud to have worked closely with our federal delegation to support our local partners' efforts to receive more than $28 million in funding to boost safety for those who bike, walk and drive on our roads," Maryland Transportation Secretary Paul Wiedefeld said. " The Maryland Department of Transportation looks forward to working with local leaders throughout the state to put this money to use to reduce roadway fatalities and ensure our streets are safer for all Marylanders."
The City of Mount Rainier is the largest implementation grant recipient in the state, receiving more than $9.7 million. Funds will be used for traffic calming measures, bicycle network improvements, sidewalk enhancements and pedestrian safety measures near Mount Rainier Elementary School.
The Town of Brentwood received $160,000 to develop a Vision Zero Action Plan.
"As a historically disadvantaged community, we're grateful for this federal investment and support of our county and state partners so that we can deliver safety for our residents, businesses and visitors," Brentwood Mayor Rocio Treminio-Lopez said. "While a small town, we have urban issues that need collaborative approaches to solve."
Baltimore County received $3.5 million to put toward developing a Vision Zero Action Plan.
"Investing in our roadways not only improves vital infrastructure, but prioritizes the safety and wellbeing of our residents and communities," Baltimore County Executive Johnny Olszewski said. "We are grateful to our federal and state partners for their help with the critical planning projects supported with this grant - and for helping to ensure Baltimore County's roads are safe for years to come."
Queen Anne's County received a grant of $280,000 to develop a comprehensive multimodal safety plan.
"This federal grant will help our local, state and federal partners combine knowledge and resources to create a comprehensive highway safety plan that will improve safety for our citizens and everyone traveling though Queen Anne's county," Queen Anne's County Commissioner Jim Moran said.
The City of Cambridge received a grant of $320,000 for research on ways to reorganize its streets to make them safer and more pedestrian-friendly.
"We have a number of streets and intersections that are really quite dangerous, especially to pedestrians," Cambridge Mayor Stephen Rideout said. "We're grateful for the funding. It's the kind of thing small communities need."

title: A worthy New Year's resolution - Provide support to an abused or neglected child
author: Casa Of The Mid Shore
content:
A worthy New Year's resolution - Provide support to an abused or neglected child

 January 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 It's the first week of 2024, and many of us are excited to pursue new goals.We may have a renewed sense of purpose that beginnings can bring. While New Year's resolutions often focus on self-improvement, a sense of purpose can also involve helping others.
This year, why not resolve to help improve the life of a local child who is under court protection because of abuse or neglect?
You can bring this resolution to life by becoming a volunteer Court Appointed Special Advocate. Or you can help by making a financial contribution to CASA of the Mid-Shore.
CASA of the Mid-Shore is a nonprofit organization whose mission is to provide volunteer Court Appointed Special Advocates to all children under court protection in Talbot, Dorchester, Queen Anne's or Kent Counties due to maltreatment.
CASA volunteers receive in-depth training, enabling them to advocate in court and in the community for the needs and rights of children in foster care. CASA volunteers come from all walks of life and professions and share a common mission: they care about the future of vulnerable children in our communities.
"Volunteers fulfill their responsibilities by spending time with the child, as well as talking with everyone involved in the child's life. This might include parents and relatives, foster parents, teachers, medical professionals, attorneys, case workers and others. They use the information they gather to assist judges and other professionals in making important decisions to meet each child's needs, with the goal of obtaining a safe, permanent home for these children," said Robin Davenport, executive director of CASA of the Mid-Shore.
Start this New Year with a resolution to learn about how you can make a positive difference in the life of a local abused or neglected child.
CASA of the Mid-Shore is accepting applications for Spring Pre-Service Training.
Learn more about becoming a CASA volunteer by calling 410-822-2688 ext. 6 or visit casamidshore.org.

 GREENSBORO — Mayor David Spencer administered the oath of office to new Greensboro Police Chief Lenox Trams shortly after 6 p.m. Thursday, Jan. 4, at the Greensboro Community Center and Fire Hall.Trams was named chief on Dec. 11. Also taking the oath of office was Greensboro Police Sgt. Jake Smith. The ceremony and meet and greet preceded the town's first meeting of 2024.
Trams, 48, has a 25-year career in law enforcement. He joined the GPD in March 2023. "(Chief Paugh) did a lot of work to get us up to standards," Trams told attendees, adding he would continue that trend.
Trams said he wants to fill out the department with three more officers. "We want the best officers who can do the job that the town deserves," he said.

George Paugh, who hired Trams to the GPD and moved on in November 2023 to become commander of the criminal investigation division in the Caroline County Sheriff's Office.
Several of Trams' family members attended, and Trams' law enforcement colleagues shared their thoughts.
Upon joining the EPD, Sgt. Al Orrison said Trams offered him his trademark strong handshake and "took me under his wing. My kids actually call him Uncle Lenox. I love this man."
Orrison said Trams had not become cynical after so many years in law enforcement.
"When you get to that 15-, 20-year mark, you become very cynical, and it's hard to have compassion all the time," he said. "But Lenox Trams always has compassion for everyone. He treats everybody fairly, and he's just an incredible human being."
EPD Sgt. David Trevino said Trams has "endless energy" and "never stops giving to people" through mentoring and volunteer work.
"The town of Greensboro is very fortunate," he said.

title: Talbot Police Accountability Board releases inaugural report
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Talbot Police Accountability Board releases inaugural report

 January 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Crime 
 
 749
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Police Accountability Board's first year was marked by challenges in adjusting to citizen oversight in policing, but "reluctant confidence" from law enforcement is believed to be growing, the board said in its inaugural report.The annual report, submitted to the Talbot County Council on Dec. 20, 2023, outlined the board's yearlong struggle in establishing a rapport with the county's four law enforcement agencies, which voiced concerns with the state-mandated legislation that created the board and a committee to review complaints of police misconduct.
Trends in call volume, arrests, struggles with recruitment and retention, use of force and police-community relations within each of the county's law enforcement agencies were analyzed in the report.
The board also asked the County Council to consider a number of recommendations to improve police accountability in Talbot County.
However, the board said most of the concerns from local police agencies centered on the Administrative Charging Committee, which is tasked with determining if officers should face administrative charges following a police agency's own investigation into the allegations. The committee also recommends appropriate discipline.
The committee is composed of five county residents and is helmed by Mitchell Ettinger, who also serves as the chairman of the Police Accountability Board.
Gaining the confidence of the county's law enforcement agencies proved to be the Administrative Charging Committee's great challenge last year, the report said.
Police questioned the wisdom of citizen oversight, the breadth of the committee's role and a lack of experience in law enforcement, which could translate to a gap in understanding the tasks and competing interests police officers face daily, according to the report.
In 2023, 15 complaints were submitted to the Administrative Charging Committee for review: 10 from the Sheriff's Office and five from the Easton Police Department.
Twelve complaints resulted in officer exonerations or were ruled as unfounded charges. Three complaints ended with varying disciplinary actions — two of which involved disagreements on recommended dispositions between the Administrative Charging Committee and the officers' respective agencies, the report said.
In one case, a Sheriff's Office deputy was administratively charged for undue use of force. According to the report, the deputy deployed pepper spray in an attempt to stop a juvenile who was improperly operating a mini-bike on the road.
The Administrative Charging Committee found it was unreasonable for the deputy to do so and imposed charges. The committee recommended two days' loss of pay, which the deputy accepted, according to the report.
The Sheriff's Office also revised its policy to clarify that deploying pepper spray on a moving motorist is inappropriate.
Use of force reports were a particular focus of the Police Accountability Board in 2023, according to its report. Law enforcement agencies now submit those reports quarterly.
The board's report said given the extensive interaction between police and the public, it was "remarkable" that officers only resorted to use of force on 10 occasions — six times by the sheriff's office, three times by the Easton Police Department and once by the St. Michaels Police Department.
Another case was heard against an Easton officer for unbecoming conduct off-duty, along with administrative failures to report conduct and a subpoena to testify. The allegations in that case were sustained, with the committee recommending two days' loss of pay or leave and a letter of reprimand.
The committee heard a third complaint against a sheriff's office deputy for speeding, which the deputy acknowledged. The deputy received a letter of reprimand.
Despite a year of building relationships, some distrust still lingers between the Administrative Charging Committee and local law enforcement.
"...The LEAs most certainly will maintain that they did not (and do not) need citizen oversight to exercise proper review and disposition of citizen complaints," the report said.
Though work remains to be done, the board believes the Administrative Charging Committee has established credibility with police through its "well-reasoned and supported" opinions on each of the complaints.
Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey acknowledged the lack of consensus between law enforcement and the committee on some case dispositions, but he said there was space for those disagreements.
"I think that we all want to be going in the same direction, and that is to have professional law enforcement in Talbot County," he said. "I've never gotten a sense from either entity, the PAB or the ACC, that they're looking to do in law enforcement like has been the narrative nationally for a few years of some groups — not all groups."
"We understand that it's important to have a rule of law in our community, and we just want it to be done well," Lowrey continued.
