title: After-school activities canceled, some Wednesday delays in place due to strong storm
author: Natalie Jones
content:
After-school activities canceled, some Wednesday delays in place due to strong storm

 January 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Local News 
 
 574
 Words 

 Read News Document

 UPDATE 1:30 p.m. Tuesday: Impending heavy rains, gusty winds and flooding from the powerful storm system moving across the region have prompted local school districts to cancel after-school activities Tuesday, with delays and closures possible Wednesday.Dorchester County Public Schools are operating on a half-day dismissal schedule Tuesday, with all after-school activities canceled. All of the county's schools will be operating on a two-hour delay schedule Wednesday, Jan. 10, for evaluation of overnight flooding and storm damage, according to the school system.
Queen Anne's County Public Schools were also dismissed early Tuesday due to the storm. As of Tuesday afternoon, all of the county's schools are set to run on a 90-minute delayed opening Wednesday, with reevaluation and modifications possible in the morning.
Schools in Talbot and Caroline counties canceled all after-school activities Tuesday. Both districts are monitoring conditions to determine if delays or closures will be necessary Wednesday.
The Caroline County Board of Education meeting will be held as scheduled at 6 p.m. Tuesday.
Gov. Wes Moore enacted a State of Preparedness declaration Tuesday morning, directing the state's department of emergency management to coordinate responses to the storm's impacts.
Rainfall of 1 to 3 inches is possible across the region Tuesday, with the heaviest rain expected Tuesday night before tapering off Wednesday morning, according to the National Weather Service.
The main concern is the potential for coastal flooding in Talbot and Queen Anne's counties, said Mike Lee, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service's Philadelphia/Mount Holly office. Dorchester County is also expected to experience significant flooding.
A coastal flood warning is in effect from 7 p.m. Tuesday to 7 p.m. Wednesday for areas along the lower Chesapeake Bay, including Cambridge, which will see major impact from flooding early Wednesday morning, according to the Weather Service. Water is expected be two to three feet above ground level in some low-lying areas.
A coastal flood warning and a flood watch are in effect for Talbot, Caroline, Queen Anne's and Kent counties from Tuesday afternoon through Wednesday morning.
Moderate coastal flooding is possible Tuesday with the high tide cycle. Water levels are expected to continue rising Tuesday night from strong southerly winds. The rising water levels could lead to potentially significant flooding.
The highest tides will be early Wednesday morning and again in the afternoon.
Widespread roadway flooding is expected across the region's bayside communities and along tidal waterways. Dorchester County could see road closures.
Strong, gusty winds are also expected to build across the region throughout the day Tuesday.
Dorchester County is under a high wind warning from 4 p.m. Tuesday to 4 a.m. Wednesday, with south to southeast winds of 30 to 40 mph with gusts up to 60 mph possible. Fallen trees, downed power lines and widespread power outages are expected.
Talbot, Caroline, Kent and Queen Anne's counties are under a wind advisory from 5 p.m. Tuesday to 3 a.m. Wednesday. Sustained winds of 25 to 35 mph are expected, with gusts up to 55 mph.
The already-saturated ground in the region has also made trees more vulnerable to becoming uprooted with strong winds.
The Talbot County Department of Emergency Services urged residents to make sure loose items are secured ahead of time and reminded residents to not drive through or stand in flooded roadways.
The region will dry out some on Thursday, but a second storm is likely to roll through the region again Friday night into Saturday, the Weather Service said.

Police Chief Robert Hobbs confirmed the suspect and victim were related. The victim, an adult male, sustained only superficial injuries from the incident. He was taken to the hospital and released the same evening, Hobbs said.
The man charged is being held pending trial. His name is not yet being released as investigation surrounding this incident continues.
Members of the Maryland State Police, Centreville Police Department, Queen Anne's County Office of the Sheriff, US Marshals Service, Queen Anne's County Narcotics Task Force, Maryland State Police Crime Lab as well as the Queen Anne's County State's Attorney's Office are continuing the investigation.

title: Eastern Shore legislators prioritizing health care, public safety this session
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Eastern Shore legislators prioritizing health care, public safety this session

 January 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: General Assembly 
 
 909
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — As the 446th session of the Maryland General Assembly kicks off, Eastern Shore legislators are focused on health care, public safety and the implications of the budget shortfall.Sen. Johnny Mautz, Sen. Stephen Hershey and Del. Tom Hutchinson all said the University of Maryland Shore Regional Health's new regional medical center in Easton is a top priority for Eastern Shore legislators this session.
"Making sure all the pieces are in place for that project to move forward," Mautz said. "It's long overdue to be replaced and upgraded."
Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said there are multiple hurdles to achieving this, including state regulatory approvals and other "loose ends." He said the University of Maryland Medical System has made it clear that a new medical center in Easton is also their top priority.
"Which is a huge help," Mautz said. "However, making sure that everything else is in place ... it's a huge undertaking."
Hershey (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, and Caroline) said that in creating an Aging & Wellness Center in Kent County and a freestanding medical facility in Dorchester County, the "spokes" are being put in place when it comes to health care on the Eastern Shore.
"But now we need the hub," he said. "And so what we are advocating for down here in Annapolis — and I've spoken with the governor about it — is we need to finalize that final piece on how we deliver health care services in the Mid-Shore region."
Hutchinson (R-Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico), who is on the Maryland House Health and Government Operations Committee, said he is sponsoring a number of bills that will make sure health care facilities have additional resources. He said he also plans to support bills related to better access to mental health care on the Shore.
Del. Chris Adams (R-Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico), who is the chair of the Eastern Shore Delegation, called public safety a "top-line issue" for this session.
On the Eastern Shore, Adams said that it has become more difficult to hire and retain law enforcement officers.
"I think it's because we've made this career path so difficult and so unclear about what the role is and what the responsibilities are," he said, adding that the job of law enforcers are to serve and protect.
In 2022, state legislators passed bills to limit what charges children under the age of 13 face. Adams said this legislation is a piece of this public safety issue.
"(Juvenile justice) has been an incremental step that has been, shall I say, just anti-police," he said.
Mautz said there are different approaches to amending the juvenile justice legislation. He said one approach is to look at enforcement and another is to look at services that can prevent children from engaging in criminal activity.
"You can have all the services in the world, but if you don't have the deterring enforcement, the services aren't going to do any good," he said. "You've got to have both, and you really need to start with enforcement. I mean there's got to be a rule of law."
Hutchinson, who said he thinks the existing juvenile reform laws need to be modified, has spearheaded a group of different stakeholders in Dorchester and Wicomico counties to discuss the the juvenile reform laws and its effects.
"I got to the point that I invited the Secretary of Juvenile Services to come, where we could express our frustrations," he said.
Hutchinson said it will be interesting to see what the pushback will be on these laws. He said that some members of the General Assembly feel that the laws haven't been in place for long enough to amend them.
"Me, along with many, many other members of the delegation, completely disagree with that," he said. "We need to address it now."
When it comes to finances, the state is facing a projected $761 million budget shortfall for FY2025.
Adams said he fears that tax increases are coming. He said that in his nearly 10 years as a legislator, this might be the first year he votes against the budget.
Hershey said dealing with the budget is a priority this session.
"We're going to have to find some ways that we can cut spending and pass a budget that doesn't include increasing taxes," he said.
Del. Jay Jacobs (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, and Caroline) said the legislature needs to be careful how it spends money.
"I like to prioritize the necessities first," he said. "If you've got extra money after your primary duties are taken care of, then you can address some of that."
Jacobs said he has concerns with funding for the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, a statewide plan to increase public education funding, improve student outcomes and improve the quality of public education.
He said meeting the Blueprint requirements will be especially hard on his home county, Kent County, adding that a one-size-fits-all approach is not going to work.
"I am not at all in favor of one-size-fits-all anything," he said. "Because we are so diverse in this state."
Jacobs said that counties should not have to face raising taxes "to a ridiculous level" or cutting services in order to fund the Blueprint.
"And some of that is potentially on the line right now," he said. "That's what's very concerning."
Del. Sheree Sample-Hughes (D-Dorchester, Wicomico) said she understands that some jurisdictions are struggling to fund the Blueprint.
"I know what that looks like," she said. "Because they can't get any more property taxes out of the citizens, because in areas such as Crisfield, they don't have anymore property to sell. It's flooded. So, it's a struggle."

title: Number of Cambridge homicides down in 2023
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Number of Cambridge homicides down in 2023

 January 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 743
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — There were less than half as many homicides in Cambridge in 2023 compared to the year before.In 2022, Cambridge saw seven homicides. In 2023, it saw three.
Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd, who was sworn in as chief in January of 2023, called the difference progress. He credits the decrease in homicides to a few different things — namely, how the department polices and its partnerships with other agencies.
One of the police department's top priorities last year was community-oriented policing. For Todd, that meant being a part of the community that the department services.
He said getting out into neighborhoods and creating programs like neighborhood watches can help build relationships and trust in communities and, hopefully, reduce crime.
Along with prioritizing community policing, Todd said that the department has tried to be proactive in addressing gun violence and aggressive assaults. He said CPD is now taking an average of one gun off the street each week, "well more than double" the average in 2022.
Todd also stressed the importance of working with other agencies and working with the community. He said that being a part of the Dorchester County Task Force, getting support from Cambridge City Council and focusing on community-oriented policing has all made a difference.
"I think a lot of people have come to the table in the last year," he said.
Cambridge Mayor Stephen Rideout said this decrease in the number of homicides in Cambridge is a significant one.
"Every shooting that we can stop is a step in the right direction," he said.
Rideout said he thinks CPD's community policing efforts are part of the reason for that success.
"It's just started, but I think they're building a trust within the community that just did not exist before now," he said.
Lieutenant Kyle Clark with Maryland State Police's Homicide Unit said that although he can't say for certain why the number of homicides has gone down in Cambridge, he can say that there has been a focus on collaboration between agencies.
"We do concentrate on a lot of collaborative efforts with other units within the State Police and also allied agencies," he said, specifying the use of task forces, gang units and gun units. "And those are all tools that we use to combat the crime in any city."
Clark said that he would estimate about 50% of the homicides in the last two years in Cambridge have been gang-related. He said that in addressing gang violence, MSP, along with other agencies at all levels, do "everything and anything" to combat the gang violence.
Todd said CPD is working to identify gang members and groups that are "constantly harassing" residents in different Cambridge neighborhoods. He said they have worked with the different agencies within the Dorchester County Task Force as well as federal agencies to identify who is bringing in handguns and where they are coming from.
"The partnership's been great with the Task Force and Maryland State Police," he said. "The Homicide Unit with Maryland State Police — they handle all of our homicides. So we work hand in hand together. And that's what it's going to take."
Todd said he has noticed gun violence and homicide rates begin to fall throughout the country.
Specific data on other crime rates in Cambridge should be released to the public in the next couple of weeks, Todd said.
Rideout said early intervention is important when it comes to crime prevention. Rideout was recently at a meeting about a flag football initiative by CPD and the Maryland Department of Juvenile Services.
"It was really an exciting possibility of where we can really start focusing, not only on the crime itself, but on the prevention and early intervention," he said.
Rideout added that engaging children in education and outside activities, such as programming at the YMCA or Boys and Girls Club, can have a positive effect.
Going into 2024, CPD's goals include continuing to build its manpower, focusing on data-driven technology and "patrolling with a purpose."
Todd said "patrolling with a purpose" means putting officers in the areas where crimes are occurring on the specific days and at the specific times they have been occurring.
He said that residents can also expect to see more data from CPD in the new year, including heat maps of where crimes are occurring.
Regarding homicides, Rideout said the downward trend is good, but added that the work doesn't stop here.
"What we have to do is continue working on it and engage the community in working on it to hopefully keep these numbers down," he said.

title: Second trial begins for Cambridge man charged in fatal shooting
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Second trial begins for Cambridge man charged in fatal shooting

 January 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Crime 
 
 492
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Dec. 8, 2022, was a routine night for Lory Eugene Fields. Heading out of his home on High Street in Cambridge, he was only set to be gone for a few hours before returning.But that night, what was a consistent routine for Fields was permanently disrupted, said Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard, who is prosecuting a case involving Fields' death with Senior Assistant State's Attorney Ella Disharoon.
Around 10 p.m., officers from the Cambridge Police Department found Fields, 69, laying in the front yard of his own home. He had been shot once in the head at close range and robbed of the keys to his Chrysler 300, Leonard said.
Though the keys were missing, the car wasn't; it remained parked in front of the home at 718 High Street. And 24 hours later, police found the person believed to be responsible for Fields' death sitting right in the driver's seat.
That return to the scene was how police caught Tramelle Williams, Leonard said.
Williams, 23, was arrested that evening following a foot pursuit on nearby Lincoln Terrace. After he attempted to flee, a Cambridge police officer fired, shooting Williams in the leg.
After being taken to a hospital for treatment of his injuries, Williams was charged with first- and second-degree murder, assault, armed robbery and a firearms offense in connection to Fields' death.
To Leonard, testimony from Maryland State Police homicide investigators, officers involved in Williams' arrest, a medical examiner and crime scene and ballistics analysts would put the picture together, rendering a guilty verdict from the jury.
But to defense attorneys Michelle Moodispaw and Stephanie DeLang, a lack of witnesses, coupled with the limitations of DNA and ballistic evidence, would paint a different image — one in which Williams would be found not guilty.
In her opening statement to the jury Tuesday, Moodispaw emphasized the lack of testimony from witnesses.
No one saw the shooting. There was no video surveillance that captured the shooting either, only audio that seemed to be consistent gunfire from a city camera on a different street, police would testify.
And although a 9mm gun was found by Williams when he fell, crime scene processing of the gun and Fields' car keys only showed that Williams couldn't be excluded as a contributor to the DNA evidence, she said.
"The question about what happened on Dec. 8, 2022, will remain unanswered," Moodispaw said.
The shooting on High Street wasn't the only one police responded to that night. Just three hours earlier, 24-year-old Taijay Brian Daniels was found dead from multiple gunshot wounds on Pleasant Street.
Williams was also charged in connection to Daniels' death. In December, a jury found Williams guilty of first- and second-degree murder, assault, armed robbery and multiple firearms offenses in the fatal shooting.
Multiple witnesses testified at the outset of Williams' trial Tuesday, including Fields' daughter and significant other and law enforcement officers who responded to the scene.
Additional law enforcement witnesses and forensic analysts are expected to testify. A verdict is anticipated Friday.

title: Oxford police chief steps down
author: Maggie Trovato

Oxford police chief steps down

 January 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News

 OXFORD — Oxford Police Chief Eric Kellner is stepping down from his position, but he will be staying with the Oxford Police Department.At a Commissioners of Oxford meeting Thursday, Town Manager Cheryl Lewis said Kellner would be stepping down for "personal and professional reasons," but that he would stay on with the police department as an officer.
Kellner was not present at the meeting.
In an interview Friday, Kellner said he was grateful for the opportunity the commissioners gave him.
"This decision is both for personal and professional reasons and (is) in the best interest of the Town of Oxford and myself," he said. "But I look forward to continuing to serve the Town of Oxford in my new capacity as patrol officer."
Kellner, who took the position in April, said that being the police chief for Oxford was challenging and rewarding.
Regarding his new rank in the department, Kellner said he didn't think anything had been finalized and wouldn't be finalized until a permanent chief is appointed.
Until the town finds a permanent chief, Oxford Police Department's Lieutenant Chris Phillips will fill the role of interim chief. At the meeting Thursday, Lewis said the town will be posting a request for applications for a new chief, per employee hiring policy, "in the near future."
In an interview Friday, Lewis called Kellner a "phenomenal" officer and said she was happy he would be staying with the department.
"I'm happy to have three wonderful officers in our department," she said.
This change in leadership in the Oxford Police Department is the second change in about a year. In mid-February, the previous police chief, Patrick Maxwell, retired abruptly, leaving the department with just one officer. Maxwell had served in the town's police department for 34 years, spending 12 of those years as chief. The town did not provide a reason for his retirement.
In an interview, Phillips, who has been with the department for about five years now, said taking on the role of interim chief will be a challenge, but it is one he is looking forward to.
"I've been in the profession now for about 10 years, and it's something that I've strived towards," he said.
The challenge of the role, Phillips said, is something that comes with the territory of being in a leadership position.
"It's not something that I think should be taken lightly," he said.
As interim chief, Phillips' number one priority is consistency.
"Once the town is satisfied with finding the appropriate chief for the position, whether it be me or somebody else, then you can look towards more long term goals," he said. "But right now, it's just about public safety."
Reporter Natalie Jones contributed to this article.

title: Moore calls for accountability, rehabilitation
author: KIERSTEN HACKER Capital News Service
content:
Moore calls for accountability, rehabilitation

 January 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KIERSTEN HACKER Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 487
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Gov. Wes Moore said he expects "robust debates" about juvenile justice in coming weeks — and that his administration will be an "active participant" trying to balance rehabilitation with cracking down on crime."The hallmark of what I hope to see in any juvenile justice legislation that's going to make it to my desk can be summarized in one word: accountability," the governor said. "I believe in rehabilitation, but I will not tolerate lawlessness."
Moore's comments came Tuesday, a day before the opening of the 2024 Maryland General Assembly, in a press conference devoted to his legislative priorities regarding public safety. He said he plans to press for three measures aimed at promoting victim's compensation, expanding apprenticeships in law enforcement jobs and preventing firearm violence.
But he also mused aloud on the issue of juvenile justice, at a time when state Republican officials are calling for passage of tougher crime policies — and specifically for reversing recent reforms to the youth legal system. House Republican Leader Jason Buckel, R-Allegany, recently vowed to toughen up what he called Maryland's "soft-on-crime policies."
Moore said Tuesday he will demand accountability for young offenders who are repeatedly violating the law, or who use a handgun to threaten the safety of others.
While Moore acknowledged the coming debate over juvenile crime this session, he stressed the importance of supporting communities and the advocates working at the grassroots level to prevent violence.
He said he supports lengthening probation for juveniles found guilty of certain crimes to allow for more time for rehabilitation programs. He also backs moving more crimes related to illegal guns from misdemeanors to felonies.
"It takes a village to raise a child, and it will take a village to build safer communities," Moore said.
The legislative criminal justice proposals Moore announced do not address the treatment of juveniles, but rather focus on other things.
He proposed establishing a firearm prevention center based on recommendations from the Safer States Initiative launched by Vice President Kamala Harris.
The statewide office would work in partnership with the White House, taking an "all of government" approach to effective prevention and intervention policies or programs, according to Rob Wilcox, deputy director of Biden's Office of Gun Violence Prevention. Maryland would be the first state to establish such a center, said Wilcox, who spoke at Moore's press conference.
"It's a critical step to focus investments and drive the strategies that we know will save lives," Wilcox said.
According to Moore, 75% of homicides in Maryland are committed with a gun. He said he considers it not only a public safety issue but a public health issue. He pledged to get illegal guns "off of our streets."
To help wage that fight, Moore hopes to recruit more people into law enforcement and public safety with a bill to promote apprenticeships.
"We need officers who reflect the diversity of our great state," Secretary of Labor Portia Wu said, "and we need them to come from the neighborhoods they serve."

author: CARL HAMILTON cahamilton@chespub.com

Former Cecil County deputy gets one year in misconduct case

 CECIL COUNTY — A former Cecil County Sheriff's Office deputy who took and sent sexually explicit photos and videos of himself and two women, including one picture that he took of his genitals — while on duty, in uniform and inside agency headquarters — received a one-year jail term on Wednesday, according to the Maryland Office of the State Prosecutor.Visiting Retired Kent County Circuit Court Judge Paul M. Bowman imposed a five-year sentence on the defendant — Elkton resident Kyle Logan Thomas, 28 — for misconduct in office and then suspended four years of the penalty, prosecutors said. Bowman also imposed a suspended one-year sentence on Thomas for visual surveillance with prurient intent, prosecutors added.
In addition, the judge ordered Thomas to serve three years of supervised probation after completing his one-year jail term, prosecutors reported.
"The defendant's conduct is best described as depraved, sadistic, and vicious," Bowman reportedly remarked from the bench while sentencing Thomas.
The sentence imposed by Bowman matched a recommendation made by Assistant State Prosecutor Abigail E. Ticse, who handled the criminal case with Deputy State Prosecutor Sarah R. David.
After Wednesday's sentencing, Maryland State Prosecutor Charlton T. Howard III said, "I am proud of our office's efforts to build a strong case against a law enforcement officer who was sworn to protect and serve, not to abuse and traumatize, the residents of Cecil County. We appreciate the Court's sentence and believe that it demonstrates to the residents of Cecil County and the entire State of Maryland that real consequences await people who commit crimes such as these, especially by those that hold positions of public trust."
Thomas had pleaded guilty to those two charges in October, as part of a plea deal in which prosecutors agreed to dismiss nine related charges against him, according to court records and Cecil Whig archives.
In August, two months earlier, Thomas was charged with misconduct in office, witness retaliation, visual surveillance with prurient intent, revenge porn, and distribution of obscene material. Thomas was not arrested, but rather was served charging papers.
Thomas had worked as a sworn Cecil County deputy for approximately two and a half years — from February 2021 until July 18, 2023 when the agency "separated Deputy Kyle Thomas from employment" amid an internal investigation into the allegations made against him, according to Capt. Michael Holmes, a CCSO spokesman. Thomas had been on suspension, per protocol, during his last nine months with the sheriff's office after the agency received a citizen complaint on Oct. 28, 2022 regarding his purported off-duty and on-duty misconduct, he noted.
As part of an overview in the charging document, prosecutors explained, "Thomas, who was married, frequently utilized Snapchat to communicate and exchange photos and videos with other users because the communications or other exchanges typically disappear."
Thomas had a romantic relationship with a woman, who ended that relationship in August 2021, prosecutors reported.
"Throughout their relationship, Thomas shared photographs and videos with Victim I, primarily via Snapchat, depicting Thomas engaged in sexual acts," according to prosecutors.
At approximately 12:20 p.m. on June 16, 2021 — while on duty amid a shift that went from 7:45 a.m. to 7 p.m. that day — Thomas shared a video with VICTIM I using the "My Eyes Only" album on Snapchat and the image "depicted Thomas in his CCSO uniform, in the CCSO building, holding, touching his exposed penis," prosecutors reported.
The woman attempted to end her relationship with Thomas several times and, in response, according to court records, Thomas "made verbal threats" to her.
In August 2021, VICTIM I attempted to cease all contact with Thomas, prosecutors reported. After an interaction between VICTIM 1 and Thomas in October 2022, VICTIM I and others made complaints about Thomas to the CCSO, which spurred the internal investigation that resulted in agency officials suspending Thomas, according to prosecutors.
In late October 2022, Thomas learned that CCSO was investigating him and that VICTIM I had been interviewed by agency investigators and that "a copy of the video that he shared with VICTIM I on Snapchat had been provided to the CCSO," according to prosecutors.
In response, Thomas contacted VICTIM I several times at her place of employment — a doctor's office — on two days in November 2022 and requested to make a complaint against her, prompting her to obtain a final peace order against him, prosecutors said.
Prosecutors reported that Thomas went to a Cecil County District Court commissioner and requested that VICTIM 1 be charged with sharing the "video of Thomas in his uniform exposing his penis to her husband and Thomas' employer, the CCSO." VICTIM I had provided that video to CCSO in October 2022 while making her formal complaint against Thomas.
The Cecil County State's Attorney's Office, however, dismissed the charges that Thomas had filed against VICTIM I, prosecutors reported. The MOSP criminal information filed against Thomas accused Thomas of taking retaliatory action against VICTIM I.
Prosecutors reported that Thomas became "engaged in a sexual relationship" with a second woman in 2019 and that she ended their relationship in May, some four years later.
They further reported that, throughout their relationship, Thomas took videos and photos of himself and the woman engaged in sexual acts and that he took those images without her consent.
The woman tried to end their relationship several times and, in response, Thomas sent videos of himself and the woman engaged in sexual acts to her, prosecutors said. Thomas also threatened to send videos of the woman engaged in sexual acts to other individuals or post the videos online, prosecutors added.
In July 2022, VICTIM 2 told Thomas to delete the photos and videos that he had on his phone, according to prosecutors. But Thomas told VICTIM 2 that he couldn't because he was anxious to post them on social media someday "maybe when you get pregnant or married," prosecutors reported.
From April 2022 through January, Thomas sent dozens of videos of himself and VICTIM 2 engaged in sexual acts to other Snapchat users without VICTIM 2's consent or knowledge, according to prosecutors. Thomas asked random Snapchat users to watch the videos, prosecutors said. Thomas also paid several Snapchat users to watch the videos," prosecutors added.
When the Cecil County Sheriff's Office suspended Thomas on Oct. 28, 2022, agency officials served him a non-contact order forbidding Thomas from interacting with several specified people involved in the administrative investigation, including the second woman, prosecutors reported. Thomas refused to sign the non-contact order, according to prosecutors.

title: Cambridge man found guilty of murder in second fatal shooting
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Cambridge man found guilty of murder in second fatal shooting

 January 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Crime 
 
 417
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A Dorchester County jury found a Cambridge man guilty Thursday of all counts in a fatal December 2022 shooting, marking the second killing the man was convicted of in the last month.The jury found Tramelle Williams, 23, guilty of first- and second-degree murder, assault, armed robbery and a firearms offense in connection to the death of Lory Fields.
Fields, 69, left his home on High Street on the evening of Dec. 8, 2022, heading out for a few hours before returning.
But what was a routine evening for Fields turned into tragedy.
Around 10 p.m., officers from the Cambridge Police Department found Fields laying in the front yard of his own home. He had been shot once in the head at close range and robbed of the keys to his Chrysler 300, Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard said at the outset of the trial Tuesday.
Though the keys were missing, the car wasn't. It remained parked in front of the home at 718 High Street.
The shooting on High Street wasn't the only one police responded to that night. Just three hours earlier, 24-year-old Taijay Brian Daniels was found dead from multiple gunshot wounds on Pleasant Street, one of which was fired at close range.
Twenty-four hours later, police saw the person believed to be responsible for the shooting around Fields' car.
Police approached Williams, but he attempted to flee.
A foot pursuit ensued on nearby Lincoln Terrace. Williams reportedly brandished a handgun, police said.
After he attempted to flee, a Cambridge police officer fired, shooting Williams in the leg. A handgun was found by Williams where he fell.
Fields' car keys and Daniels' phone were also recovered from Williams that night, police testified.
Williams was transported to TidalHealth Peninsula Regional in Salisbury for treatment of non-life-threatening injuries.
He was charged with first-degree murder in connection to both fatal shootings. In December, a jury convicted Williams of all counts related to Daniels' death.
Surveillance footage and forensic evidence linked Williams to the two killings.
A presentence investigation was ordered by Dorchester Circuit Judge William Jones, who presided over both trials. No sentencing date has been set yet.
Williams faces a maximum of life in prison without the possibility of parole for each first-degree murder conviction.
In a press release posted to Facebook, Leonard thanked the juries for their time and deliberations in the cases.
"While the senseless killings ... cannot be undone, it is the State's hope that these verdicts will give the families and loved ones of the victims a small sense of peace moving forward," the post stated.

title: Worried by spikes in youth crime, Maryland lawmakers close in on new fixes to the system
author: STEPH QUINN Capital News Service
content:
Worried by spikes in youth crime, Maryland lawmakers close in on new fixes to the system

 January 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEPH QUINN Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 602
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Almost two years after passing landmark youth justice reform, Maryland lawmakers are scrutinizing its impact on young offenders — and questioning whether they've done enough to make things better.The 2022 reforms were meant to help more young offenders avoid incarceration and get on the path to rehabilitation. But with spikes in auto thefts, carjackings and handgun violations by youth around the state, lawmakers on both sides of the political aisle are thinking about refining and updating the reforms this year.
Senate President Bill Ferguson (D-Baltimore City) said there is an agreement taking shape among lawmakers who want to smooth the process for referring young people for rehabilitative services. State agencies have the resources to help kids and families, Ferguson said, but a lack of cooperation sometimes gets in the way.
He said one thing in need of improvement is the Child in Need of Supervision process, which lets law enforcement refer young people to Juvenile Services for assessment and programs when they get into trouble.
"What happened over the last few years is that the CINS process never led to actual conversations (or) collaborations amongst agencies that have various resources to surround the child with those supports," Ferguson said this week.
In their quest to change the law, lawmakers are motivated both by complaints from constituents and by a sense that youth crime is on the rise. While youth violent crime arrests fell 16.5% overall between fiscal years 2022 and 2023, according to a Juvenile Services report last year, carjackings increased by 85.4% and handgun violations rose almost 220%. Auto theft grew 64.6%, doubling between 2022 and 2023.
Some Republicans blame the reform itself, and some prosecutors are joining them in raising concerns about the law. Among other changes, the 2022 reforms set 13 as the minimum age for a young person to be sent to juvenile court — except in cases of violent crime, where the minimum age is 10 — and prohibited police from interrogating youth without letting the child consult an attorney.
But Democrats are more interested in refining the system, and they're engaged in discussions that could produce a more sweeping set of improvements in the coming days.
Gov. Wes Moore's office is also involved in talks and expects that like-minded lawmakers may introduce legislation aimed at making improvements to the current law.
Sen. Jill Carter (D-Baltimore City), one of several lawmakers concerned about juvenile justice this session, said she wants to see police and prosecutors work together to use the tools the legislature has already given them.
"I think that the most effective thing that could happen is that law enforcement and prosecutors could work within the law, stop resisting it and work more collaboratively, and if they come up with suggestions, they should be data-driven," Carter said.
Several lawmakers defended the 2022 reforms in a press conference with the Maryland Youth Justice Coalition this week, and urged law enforcement and state's attorneys to use the tools it set up.
Del. Charlotte Crutchfield (D-Montgomery) said that the reform legislation is "still in its infancy."
"We know that there are things that need to be put in place to ensure that it continues and that our youth are well taken care of under this legislation," Crutchfield said.
Prosecutors say it's not that simple. Juvenile Services officers sometimes see six or seven complaints regarding the same young person before prosecutors are notified, Montgomery County State's Attorney John McCarthy said during a recent Senate Judicial Proceedings Committee.
"Let us, as state's attorneys, have what we had before," McCarthy said, "the ability to have those matters referred to us so that we may put a second additional set of eyes on it."

title: Democrats say no big changes to cannabis law
author: ANGELIQUE GINGRAS Capital News Service
content:
Democrats say no big changes to cannabis law

 January 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANGELIQUE GINGRAS Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 445
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Republicans are pushing to repeal a controversial Maryland law that prohibits police from pulling over and searching drivers simply because they smell of marijuana, but Democratic leaders say they aren't interested in dramatic changes to the state's cannabis legislation this year.Senate President Bill Ferguson (D-Baltimore City) says Democrats are only considering what they refer to as "improvements" to Maryland's cannabis law, following its legalization for adult use last year.
"I think we're going to have a cannabis bill this year that sort of does some — I don't want to call it cleanup — but adjustments to the system that we passed last year," Ferguson said. "I don't think you'll see major changes to the program, but implementation adjustments."
In 2023, the Maryland General Assembly passed the new "odor" law hoping to prevent unwarranted search and seizure against people of color, according to members of Maryland's Legislative Black Caucus, who were proponents of the bill. With Democrats controlling both chambers of the General Assembly, their opposition to repeal makes it unlikely.
But critics of the law — Republicans in particular — say the law is making it harder for police to do their jobs.
"The irony is, if we see someone chugging a beer, police can pull them over," said Sen. William Folden (R-Frederick), a police officer who serves in the legislature. He says the law potentially takes away probable cause for police when "there is a crime occurring, just because you're saying, well, you're not allowed to use your nose anymore."
After voters approved a ballot referendum legalizing cannabis for adult use, the General Assembly passed legislation in 2023 setting up licensing and taxation as well as other rules.
Those laws were meant to address "the harms of the past when it comes to criminalization of cannabis," Del. Jheanelle Wilkins (D-Montgomery), chair of the Black Caucus and sponsor of the odor law, told Capital News Service.
Maryland's odor law isn't uncommon. In fact, several states that have legalized cannabis have said its smell doesn't warrant a police search of a vehicle, or they're considering such a provision.
"The public clearly wanted marijuana legalized, fine," said Sen. Jack Bailey (R-Calvert, St. Mary's), "but we shouldn't do away with the requirements."
But top Democrats said they are only considering small alterations, including adjustments to the duties and makeup of the Maryland Cannabis Administration and related authorities.
"It was hugely complicated, lots of moving pieces for the cannabis bill last year," Ferguson said. "And as we've been implementing, there's little things that have to be worked through."
Wilkins says the goal of Democrats and the Black Caucus is "working closely with the administration to make sure that our intentions of the bill are carried out."

 ANNAPOLIS — A multi-vehicle incident on the westbound span of the Chesapeake Bay Bridge had travel shut down for several hours Saturday morning. Numerous patients were transported, some with serious injuries. No fatalities were reported.Although yet to be determined, heavy fog is believed to be a factor in the mass casualty incident. Maryland Transportation Police dispatch received initial calls at 8 a.m. Saturday morning.

Two-way traffic on the eastbound span was suspended and officials directed alternating eastbound and westbound traffic every 20-30 minutes until conditions improve. All lanes were reopened at 2 p.m. Saturday afternoon, with delays still expected from the earlier closure.

 CONOWINGO — A Conowingo woman was shot and killed by an arrow fired from a crossbow on Wednesday.Investigators said 45-year-old Judy Elizabeth Gee died in the Conowingo residence where the fatal incident occurred, according to the Cecil County Sheriff's Office.
Also in the update released by the agency on Friday morning, Lt. Michael Zack, a sheriff's spokesman, reported, "This matter is still being investigated by detectives with the Cecil County Sheriff's Office, in conjunction with the State's Attorney's Office for Cecil County. An autopsy is currently being performed in Pennsylvania, where the victim was pronounced dead."
In addition, Zack said that no arrests had been made as of Friday in the ongoing homicide investigation, before adding, "However, all interested parties have been identified."
Sheriff's deputies and paramedics rushed to the scene in the 700 block of Bell Manor Road at approximately 4:40 p.m. Wednesday, after receiving a dispatch regarding a woman who had been struck in the back with an arrow, police said. Deputies and paramedics rendered medical aid at the scene, before an ambulance crew drove Gee to Lancaster General Hospital in Lancaster, Pa., where she died from her wound despite "life-saving measures attempted by medical staff," police added.
"The arrow was fired from a crossbow, which belonged to an occupant of the residence. The individual who fired the weapon was located at the residence and (was) transported to the Cecil County Sheriff's Office for further investigative efforts," said Zack, who declined to release the name of the person who purportedly shot the arrow that killed Gee because of the ongoing homicide investigation.
Detectives have been consulting with the Cecil County States Attorney's Office about the crossbow incident that resulted in Gee's death and, as of Friday, the homicide investigation remained active, Zack reported.

 EASTON — Following a three-day trial ending Friday, Jan. 19, a Talbot County jury found a McDaniel man not guilty of a sex offense. However, jurors were unable to reach a verdict on a related assault charge, resulting in a mistrial on that count.Six witnesses testified in the trial for Charles M. Kling, 53, who was facing two charges — a fourth-degree sex offense and second-degree assault — in connection to an alleged incident involving a female employee at a business in St. Michaels on June 19, 2023.
According to police, Kling was charged after he allegedly entered the business where the woman was employed, lured her away and touched her inappropriately.
Jurors deliberated for over three hours on Jan. 19 before returning a unanimous acquittal on the sex offense charge, according to Christine DuFour, one of Kling's attorneys.
The jury foreman told Talbot County Circuit Judge Stephen Kehoe, who presided over the case, that the jurors were deadlocked 11-1 on the assault charge, DuFour said.
According to one juror, who spoke to DuFour in the presence of other attorneys and a bailiff, the majority was in favor of a not guilty finding on the assault charge, she added.
Though a mistrial was declared, the prosecution does have the option to retry Kling for the assault charge.
Deputy State's Attorney Chelsea Endzel, who prosecuted the case, was unable to comment.
Andrew Jezic, one of Kling's attorneys, said if the state chooses to retry the case, he expects a full acquittal.
Police previously noted that Kling was a Tier III sex offender — a lifetime registry in Maryland.
The registration followed Kling's release from prison after serving time for a first-degree rape conviction in Anne Arundel County in 2004, according to court records.
Kling was sentenced to 25 years of active incarceration in that case, though he was released in spring 2020 and placed on supervised probation due to housing issues stemming from the pandemic.
If the prosecution does retry the case for the assault charge, the jury will not be able to consider Kling's prior conviction due to the acquittal on the sex offense, Jezic said.
Though Kling was released from custody in Talbot County following the acquittal, he remains held in Anne Arundel County due to a pending violation of probation in the 2004 case.
In a bail review Tuesday, an Anne Arundel judge approved Kling's release to house arrest, DuFour said, but he has not yet been released.
He is set to appear in court for a status conference in Talbot County on Feb. 16 and violation of probation hearing in Anne Arundel County in March.

Pennsylvania man arrested for indecent exposure in Ridgely

 January 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 RIDGELY — A Pennsylvania man was arrested Wednesday, Jan. 24, for allegedly indecently exposing himself to a mother and her 6-year-old daughter.Lane J. title: Trappe woman found guilty of criminally negligent manslaughter by vehicle
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Trappe woman found guilty of criminally negligent manslaughter by vehicle

 January 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Crime 
 
 787
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A Trappe woman who fatally injured an 84-year-old woman in a crash at the intersection of U.S. Route 50 and the southern end of the Easton Parkway nearly three years ago was sentenced Monday to 45 days in jail.Brittnee Ewing, 24, pleaded guilty to one count of criminally negligent manslaughter by vehicle — a misdemeanor charge — in connection to the fatal Easton crash, which occurred in the afternoon hours of April 8, 2021.
"These are the hearings where I feel the most powerless," said Talbot County Circuit Judge Stephen Kehoe, who presided in court Monday.
Though no specific disposition was recommended by prosecutor Jennifer Wilson and defense attorney Stephanie Shipley advocated for a probation before judgment and no active incarceration, Kehoe handed Ewing a three-year sentence, suspending all but 45 days.
The case against Ewing stemmed from a multi-agency investigation into the crash.
Ewing, the driver of a Ford Escape, was traveling eastbound on Route 50 toward its intersection with the parkway at a high rate of speed — 85 mph prior to the crash, 79 mph at the time of the collision, Wilson said.
Vicki Harvey, 63, of Easton, was driving a Ford C-Max Hybrid that day. Jo Ann Wright, 84, of Easton, was her passenger.
Harvey and Wright were crossing over eastbound Route 50 from westbound Route 50 at the light to turn onto the parkway, traveling roughly 25 mph heading toward the parkway, when they were struck by Ewing's car.
Wright was seriously injured in the crash, Wilson said. She was flown to the University of Maryland Shock Trauma Center in Baltimore. Harvey was taken to the hospital in Easton with minor injuries.
Wright suffered "devastating trauma" to her head, along with multiple fractures and bruises all over her body, Wilson said. She died at the trauma center on April 9, 2021.
Wilson said Ewing's car was "completely destroyed" in the crash. Ewing, who was also seriously injured in the crash, was flown with her 1-year-old son to Johns Hopkins in Baltimore for treatment.
A witness who was driving westbound on Route 50 at the time of the crash told police that the C-Max Hybrid had a green light. According to the witness, Ewing did not slow or brake, Wilson said.
In a later interview with police, Ewing said she remembered picking up her son before the crash, though she said she wasn't in a hurry, Wilson said. She did not remember the crash.
Speaking in court, Wright's daughters, Julia George and Janine Conway, recounted the painful memories surrounding their mother's death.
Both women said Wright was internally decapitated, meaning her spinal cord separated from her skull. The family decided to remove her from life support.
George recalled how her mother would outstretch her arms when scared, voicing a fearful suspicion that her mother's broken wrists from the crash were from that movement.
"Her death was one of pain," George said, remembering Wright gasping for breath. A tear rolled down the side of her face around the time of her death.
Conway remembered rounding up her family together to take a photo with Wright on Easter, just days before the crash. She recalled urging her brother to get up for the photo, saying they wouldn't know if it would be the last picture they took with Wright.
"And it was," she said, her voice catching.
Conway and George asked the judge to hold Ewing responsible for her actions that day.
"The accident didn't kill my mother, the choices Ms. Ewing made killed my mother," Conway said.
Shipley acknowledged the family's pain and desire to hold Ewing responsible, saying Ewing did suffer physically and mentally from her split-second decision at that yellow light.
Ewing had undergone multiple surgeries following the crash, she said. The 24-year-old mother of one was unable to walk for months afterward.
The crash was out of character for Ewing, Shipley said — she had never even been pulled over before. Her life was one of service and hard work, she added.
"She lives with, every day, the thought that she killed someone else," Shipley said.
With tears in her eyes, Ewing apologized multiple times for her actions that day, saying she took full responsibility for the tragedy.
"I will carry this with me for the rest of my life, as I should," she said, looking back toward Wright's family members seated in the courtroom. "I am so sorry."
Kehoe said he truly believed her, but given what happened, consequences were still needed.
Despite Shipley's pleas for a delay in Ewing reporting to the county detention center to serve her term, Kehoe denied the requests. Ewing was taken into custody after the hearing.
Court records indicate Shipley filed a motion Tuesday afternoon requesting the court grant Ewing emergency release or home detention due to potentially life-threatening health issues. No decision was made as of press time.

title: Democratic lawmakers plan to crack down on youth crime in the coming weeks
author: STEPH QUINN Capital News Service
content:
Democratic lawmakers plan to crack down on youth crime in the coming weeks

 February 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEPH QUINN Capital News Service | Section: General Assembly 
 
 587
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Children as young as 10 could potentially go to court for auto thefts and handgun violations, under one proposal key Democratic lawmakers detailed on Wednesday and plan to push for in the legislature in coming weeks.The lawmakers propose giving Juvenile Services officers the option to route a young person's case to court if the child is 10 to 13 years of age and accused of these or other crimes — adding them to the list of serious offenses that already can land a young person before a judge.
The proposals are meant to promote collaboration and make the system work more smoothly, Democratic officials said, but youth advocates worry that they will lead to higher incarceration rates, especially of youth of color.
"Right now, juvenile offenders and the services and accountability they need are separated by an abundance of confusion," said House Speaker Adrienne Jones, D-Baltimore County. "Egos, political agendas and arguments over process have filled the gaps."
There must be "accountability for adults in the system, who are charged with administering the system," said Senate President Bill Ferguson, D-Baltimore City. "We must ensure that all parts are working to their highest potential."
Jones and Ferguson joined Democratic Gov. Wes Moore on Wednesday for a public announcement of the proposals, alongside the lawmakers who crafted them.
The raft of changes, if enacted, would toughen a reform law the state legislature passed in 2022. Among other things, that reform barred police from charging young people under 13 except when they are accused of the most serious crimes.
The newly unveiled legislative package would expand that list of serious crimes and lengthen the maximum probation period that can be ordered by a judge. It would also expand the reporting responsibilities of a state agency charged with oversight of the youth justice system.
The announcement on Wednesday gave shape to Democrats' response to pleas for accountability amid spikes in certain youth offenses in recent years. While youth violent crime arrests fell 16.5% overall between fiscal years 2020 and 2023, according to a Juvenile Services report last year, carjackings increased by 85.4% and handgun violations rose almost 220%.
After weeks of talks with law enforcement and advocates, the set of proposals represents a general agreement among Democrats, who control both chambers of the legislature and also hold the governor's office.
But advocates in the Maryland Youth Justice Coalition predicted in a written statement that the "legislation introduced today will see thousands more kids incarcerated every year, particularly Black and brown children, and (exacerbate) the already serious racial disparities in Maryland's juvenile justice system."
As the minority party, Republicans have said in recent months that the reform law leaves Marylanders less safe and also prevents young people from getting the services they need. GOP lawmakers in Annapolis have their own ideas for change, including a measure that would prohibit young people who have committed sexual offenses from attending school in person.
But one key Republican on Wednesday said the Democrats' plan shows they are taking "first steps" in addressing flaws in the youth justice system. House Minority Leader Jason Buckel, R-Allegany, said he appreciates that Moore has put his weight behind the issue of youth crime.
"For him to be able to step in and say, 'Hey, I'm a Democrat. I'm from Baltimore City, but I'm going to step up and say too much is too much and this is a reasonable way to deal with this' — it's incredibly helpful," Buckel said.
Buckel said he also hopes Moore will be able to persuade fellow Democrats to consider other tough ideas, too.

title: CPD annual report shows reduction in some major offenses
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
CPD annual report shows reduction in some major offenses

 February 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Crime 
 
 540
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — There were fewer burglaries, homicides and assaults in Cambridge in 2023 compared to 2022.According to the Cambridge Police Department's 2023 year-end report, robberies and rape offenses were the two major offenses that Cambridge saw more of in 2023 than the year before it, increasing around 30% each.
The report states that homicides were down from seven in 2022 to two in 2023. Although there were three total homicides in 2023, Police Chief Justin Todd said the Dec. 18 fatal shooting of Taron Jones has been ruled justified, meaning that the person that shot Jones is not considered criminally liable and will not be charged with the murder.
Burglaries were down 42%. Aggravated assaults were down 8.8%. Simple assaults were down 10%.
"The overwhelming amount of support that the Cambridge Police Department has received, along with the countless number of community leaders that have dedicated their time to assist in community engagement, shows that working together, we can flourish and continue to improve," the report says.
CPD seized 53 illegally-possessed guns in 2023, according to the report. The majority of them, or 38, were pistols. Seven revolvers, six shotguns and two rifles were also seized.
When it came to shots fired in 2023, CPD reported that it received 256 ShotSpotter alerts as well as 74 shots fired calls. ShotSpotter is a gunshot detection system that has sensors that can detect and locate illegal gunfire incidents and alert law enforcement.
According to the report, the Criminal Investigations Division, which is made up of three detectives and an evidence technician, cleared 163 of its assigned 214 cases, or 76.2%.
In 2023, the department swore in eight new officers, making the total number of sworn officers 34, with two additional officers in the academy.
Although this is two officers more than 2022's staffing rate, CPD still has fewer officers than it had in 2018, when there were 44 sworn officers on the force.
The department had one more civilian employee in 2023 than in 2022. This year, that number has increased one more, making the total number of civilian employees six.
In the summer, the department established the Office of Professional Standards. This new unit has been tasked with managing department policies and procedures, collecting data that can be used for better staffing officers and increasing transparency to the community.
At the end of 2023, the unit conducted a staffing survey to be completed in 2024. The results of this project will include a recommendation to Todd and City Manager Tom Carroll for approval.
Community-oriented policing was a focus for the department in 2023. According to the report, CPD's Community Policing Unit hosted over 50 events over the year, including National Night Out and Shop with a Cop.
Going into 2024, community policing will stay a focus. According to the report, the goal of the department in 2024 is to continue to reduce crimes while increasing residents' quality of life.
The department has several specific initiatives it plans to implement this year, including "Patrolling with a Purpose" and initiating a Proactive Criminal Enforcement Unit in order to address areas identified as "problem areas" in Cambridge.
The department also plans to implement a drone program that can be used in missing persons, active shooters and barricaded suspects cases; increase cooperation with allied agencies and continue recruiting officers.

 QUEENSTOWN — Saturday evening, Jan. 27, the Grasonville Volunteer Fire Department hosted their 65th annual Installation of Officers and Awards for 2023 to its members. The program took place at the Bay Country Moose Lodge in Queenstown.Fire department President Matt Coursey welcomed everyone, firefighter J.T. Clarke provided the opening prayer for the event. Major service awards were then presented. For years of service, Cory Holm was awarded his 10-year pin. Keith Thomas received his Life Membership recognition, receiving a plaque, his 20-year pin, and his 20-year membership card. "Skippy" Haddaway received a special commendation from Governor Wes Moore, presented by Queen Anne's Commissioner Phil Dumenil, for his 45-years of active service to the fire department.
Topping the years of service awards, former longtime Fire Chief Pete Risley also received a commendation from the governor for his 55-years of active membership. Both Haddaway and Risley were presented unique plaques for their fire department service, and standing ovations from those who were attending.
The Rookie of the Year award was presented to four young firefighters who are recent graduates of the fire department's Cadet program, Jason Anthony, Jr., Caleb Bargerstock, Colby Bargerstock, and L.T. Blake, Jr.
EMS Provider of the Year Denise Ornduff, who was also to Top EMS Responder, responded to 211 emergency calls in 2023. Firefighter of the Year was presented to Dave Bell, Chief's Award to Mike Mattison and President's Award to Skippy Haddaway.
The Top Five Fire Suppression Responders for 2023 were: Jimmy Hurlock, Jr. (311 calls), Pete Risley (292 calls), Steve McCombs (275 calls), Dave Bell (266) and Jason Anthony, Sr. (265).
Six members of the fire department received "Medals of Honor" for their roles in saving the life of a heart attack victim in March, 2023. Those members were Captain Matt Coursey and firefighters Pete Risley, Skippy Haddaway, Tom Sheahan, Michael Balsoma and Cory Holm.

title: Preston man sentenced to 15 years for stabbing
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Preston man sentenced to 15 years for stabbing

 February 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Crime 
 
 415
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — A Preston man was sentenced Thursday to 15 years in prison for the February 2022 stabbing of a then 25-year-old woman.Agreeing with a recommendation from the prosecution, Caroline County Circuit Judge Heather Price handed Mark William Thompkins a 30-year sentence with all but 15 years suspended. He will receive credit for 714 days, or nearly two years, already served, according to court records.
Thompkins, 26, pleaded guilty last October to one count of attempted second-degree murder.
Price also referred Thompkins to the Patuxent Institution, a treatment-oriented, maximum security correctional facility.
"I believe that it was an appropriate sentence," said Caroline County State's Attorney Sloane Franklin, who prosecuted the case. "Unfortunately, the mental health system is broken and failed both the victim and Mr. Thompkins."
Thompkins' defense attorney, Jesse Hicks, could not be reached for comment.
Thursday's sentence comes nearly two years after the young woman was stabbed near Holly Park Drive and Gilpin Point Road in Preston shortly before 3 p.m. on Feb. 17, 2022.
During the Oct. 30 plea hearing, Franklin said trash collection workers near the scene first saw the woman sitting in the driver's seat of her vehicle with a man, later identified as Thompkins, seated behind her.
Thompkins began striking the woman with his fists, then brandished a knife to stab her neck.
The woman ran from her vehicle and collapsed in the front yard of a nearby house. Thompkins cradled her while holding the knife to his own throat, Franklin said.
A witness attempted to help the victim, but Thompkins threatened them, pointing the knife at them and yelling for them to get back.
Multiple law enforcement agencies, including the Caroline County Sheriff's Office, Maryland State Police and Maryland Natural Resources Police, responded to the stabbing.
Franklin said Thompkins punctured his own neck with a knife while running to the woods to evade officers.
After 15 minutes and the use of multiple non-lethal methods, including a taser, a state trooper was able to knock the knife out of Thompkins' hand to detain him, police said.
Both Thompkins and the woman were flown to the University of Maryland Shock Trauma Center in Baltimore for treatment of their injuries.
After his arrest, a judge found Thompkins incompetent to stand trial in April 2022. He was committed to the Maryland Department of Health until August 2023, then transferred back to a local detention center upon being found competent, according to court filings.
Following his release, Thompkins will be placed on five years of supervised probation. He will also be required to complete mental health treatment.

title: Violent Firearms Offender Act back before lawmakers a fifth time
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Violent Firearms Offender Act back before lawmakers a fifth time

 February 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Crime 
 
 872
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — For the fifth legislative session in a row, the proposed Violent Firearms Offender Act is back in front of Maryland lawmakers for consideration and hopes of passage through both chambers.Senate Bill 28 and Senate Bill 179, two separate bills both known as the Violent Firearms Offender Act of 2024, are being brought forward in an effort to address gun violence across the state.
Both bills include the same provisions, including altering a number of firearms-related offenses, expanding the definition of a crime of violence and specifying that a violation of parole or probation involving a firearm is not a technical offense.
It would also require the state Commissioner of Correction to provide incarcerated individuals with a reentry kit prior to their release.
More specifically, the bill would make the use of a firearm in the commission of a violent crime a felony — a crime that's currently a misdemeanor. The bill would also make the use of an assault weapon, machine gun or magazine with a capacity of more than 10 rounds a felony.
Current state law also does not classify the use of a firearm while possessing drugs with the intent to distribute them as a crime of violence. If passed, the bill would remove that exception.
Additionally, current law says if a person who is prohibited from having a firearm due to previous felony convictions, for example, is caught with one, that person can be charged with illegal possession of a firearm — a misdemeanor crime with a maximum sentence of five years.
The bill would increase the maximum penalty from five years to 10 years in prison for a second offense.
State lawmakers have previously heard and voted in favor of similar versions of the Violent Firearms Offenders Act, though it hasn't been able to move forward to becoming law.
In the 2020 and 2021 General Assembly sessions, the legislation passed the Senate, but failed to advance further in the House of Delegates. And in 2022 and 2023, the legislation failed to advance past the Senate Judicial Proceedings Committee.
However, SB 28, the Senate Republican Caucus version of the bill introduced this session by Sen. William Folden (R-Frederick), adds a new provision: imposing a penalty on a person who sells or loans a regulated firearm to someone else knowing that the firearm would be used to commit a crime or cause harm.
If the bill with that provision is approved, a person who violates that law would be guilty of a felony and could face a maximum of 10 years in prison.
At a Jan. 25 Senate Judicial Proceedings Committee hearing, Folden and SB 179 sponsor Sen. Ron Watson (D-Prince George's) testified to the need to finally pass the legislation.
Watson, who's served in the Senate since summer 2021, focused on the fact that the bill has been presented multiple times without passage, and to the committee, the legislation wasn't new.
"But I have to ask the committee, are we ready now to take action?" Watson asked. "Because the state of Maryland is watching, and everything we've done over the last several years with respect to guns and trying to hold folks accountable, it is clear that crime is continuing to rise, particularly among our juveniles and the gun use."
Folden, acknowledging that the two bills have "the exact same posture," asked if Watson would support his bill's new provision adding punishment to selling or transferring a firearm to someone who commits a crime.
Watson said in talking with attorneys about trying to punish the person who sold a firearm, it would be difficult to prove what the intent of a purchaser would be.
Folden countered, saying it would be difficult, but not impossible, considering the number of people who communicate via digital platforms.
"Because if there's ever been a time (when) the opportunity exists to prove that there was the intent, it's now, with the environment we live in with the electronic devices," he said.
Watson said he would be amenable to the provision if the committee agreed.
"But we have to do something," he said, with Folden agreeing. "Standing still is not an option."
The currently proposed Violent Firearms Offender Act has the support of Shore lawmakers, too.
Sen. Steve Hershey (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline), a co-sponsor of SB 28 who has supported similar versions of the legislation since 2020, noted the emphasis that's being placed on public safety this session by Republicans, Democrats and Gov. Wes Moore.
"The feeling in Annapolis is that we need to do something about public safety and violent crime," he said, also pointing to the spread of crime across the state.
Though he's not on the Judicial Proceeding Committee that determines which version of the bill, if either, will move forward, Hershey said the Senate Republican Caucus would be "pleased" to see either bill moved out of the committee and on to the Senate and House floors.
The Violent Firearms Offender Act is one of five pieces of legislation the Joint Republican Caucus is proposing this session as part of its public safety agenda.
Other bills proposed as part of the agenda include the Gun Theft Felony Act of 2024 (SB 39/HB 304), the Safe Communities Act of 2024 (SB 44/HB 310), the Drug-Free Roadways Act of 2024 (SB 396/HB 320) and the Juvenile Justice Restoration Act of 2024 (SB 52/HB 319).

 QUEENSTOWN — Saturday evening, Jan. 27, the Grasonville Volunteer Fire Department hosted their 65th annual Installation of Officers and Awards for 2023 to its members. The program took place at the Bay Country Moose Lodge in Queenstown.Fire department President Matt Coursey welcomed everyone, firefighter J.T. Clarke provided the opening prayer for the event. Twenty-five different local businesses and organizations were recognized for their contributions and support to GVFD in 2023.
One of those, the Kent Island American Legion, Post 278, in Stevensville, presented checks totaling $9,500 to the fire department at the banquet.
Fire Chief Jason Anthony, Sr., gave a summary report of events for the fire department for 2023. A few of the highlights included three major donations of $10,000 each from the Didonato family, the Narrows Restaurant (the Hardesty family), and the Rob and Fran Marsh family to the building fund towards the new fire house to be built.
Anthony added, "The fire department responded to 834 emergency calls in 2023. August was the busiest month with 103 calls."
In June, the Queen Anne's County Planning and Zoning approved the plans for the new fire house. In October, Fire Prevention Month activities were held at Grasonville Elementary, Little Lambs Schools and Grasonville Head Start, to impress upon young children the importance of fire safety.
Major service awards were then presented. For years of service, Cory Holm was awarded his 10-year pin. Keith Thomas received his Life Membership recognition, receiving a plaque, his 20-year pin, and his 20-year membership card. "Skippy" Haddaway received a special commendation from Governor Wes Moore, presented by Queen Anne's Commissioner Phil Dumenil, for his 45-years of active service to the fire department.
Topping the years of service awards, former longtime Fire Chief Pete Risley also received a commendation from the governor for his 55-years of active membership. Both Haddaway and Risley were presented unique plaques for their fire department service, and standing ovations from those who were attending.
The Rookie of the Year award was presented to four young firefighters who are recent graduates of the fire department's Cadet program, Jason Anthony, Jr., Caleb Bargerstock, Colby Bargerstock, and L.T. Blake, Jr.
EMS Provider of the Year Denise Ornduff, who was also to Top EMS Responder, responded to 211 emergency calls in 2023. Firefighter of the Year was presented to Dave Bell, Chief's Award to Mike Mattison and President's Award to Skippy Haddaway.
The Top Five Fire Suppression Responders for 2023 were: Jimmy Hurlock, Jr. (311 calls), Pete Risley (292 calls), Steve McCombs (275 calls), Dave Bell (266) and Jason Anthony, Sr. (265).
Six members of the fire department received "Medals of Honor" for their roles in saving the life of a heart attack victim in March, 2023. Those members were Captain Matt Coursey and firefighters Pete Risley, Skippy Haddaway, Tom Sheahan, Michael Balsoma and Cory Holm.

title: Education needed on the juvenile crime law
author: STEPEHN RIDEOUT
content:
Education needed on the juvenile crime law

 February 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEPEHN RIDEOUT | Section: Columns 
 
 732
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Maryland Juvenile Interrogation Protection Act that passed under the Hogan Administration has raised some concerns. While it appears that this law was carefully written and training materials were provided, the complaints seen in the news seem to indicate that insufficient training was provided to the police or the states' attorneys about its implementation.From my experience in Virginia, I know that when new legislation passes that makes significant changes to laws involving children, training on that legislation, before it goes into effect, is an important part of making a smooth transition to the new law. It appears that the time between the passage of this law and its implementation was sufficient to provide that training but may not have been done. At the same time, taking a second look at new laws to make minor changes is not unusual or out of the ordinary.
As I have thought about this law, one thing that is not being discussed with regard to concerns is how there is a significant difference between how children should be advised of their rights and questioned and how adults are advised of their rights. They are not the same. Children are not simply small adults.
Soon after becoming a juvenile court judge, I received training in a number of areas relating to children. One of them related to child development. Others were about ages when children are able to understand certain concepts and how to question children in a way that is age appropriate. The "Handbook on Questioning Children: A Linguistic Perspective" by Anne Grantham Walker was our guidebook as new judges.
It helped us understand what concepts children could understand at different developmental stages and ages in their lives and how to ask questions of them in a way that they understood so they could give truthful answers. When they were called to testify and take the oath to "tell the truth," I often had to ask them simple questions so that they understood what "telling the truth" meant. During trials, it was interesting to hear how police officers and lawyers would ask questions and get answers that seemed to mean one thing to them and mean something different to me.
As part of my responsibilities with newly charged youth in delinquency cases, I would advise the children of their rights to a lawyer and to remain silent. The police had done it and our Court Service Unit, similar to Maryland DJS, had done it.
I would not just go though the routine questions about their right to a lawyer and right to remain silent, as I knew that many if not most did not or could not understand those words. They might be too young or they might not have done well enough in school to be able to understand the advisement of rights form that we prepared for them.
So I would ask the question and then, after a response or no response, would ask them what that meant to them. My best guess is that close to 90-95% of those youth did not understand their rights before they came to court and few even understood them after I talked with them.
Their concerns and fears about being charged and in court and the possibility of their being locked up were what they were thinking about and not the questions from me or our conversation.
So the General Assembly was reasonably concerned about the whole issue of advisement of rights. An additional concern should be about how the police advise them of their rights. If it is a pro-forma reading as they do with adults, in my view, that is meaningless. So having a video or audio (preferably video) of the advisement is critical for the judge to be able to watch. In addition, how the public defender, under the current law, advises them is also important. Unless the lawyer uses language and understands the age and developmental age of the children he or she are speaking with, what they tell the youth may not help much, if at all.
While I have suggestions for some modifications to the law that I have shared with some of the members of the General Assembly, the most important suggestion would be to be sure that all of the police and lawyers who speak with or advise youth in these matters be trained on how to properly communicate with children.
Stephen Rideout is the mayor in Cambridge.
