title: Residents displaced in 2-house fire
author: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com
content:
Residents displaced in 2-house fire

 February 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 346
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Of all the things in her home that Leona Demdy, 87, lost to a fire Saturday afternoon, she said her photographs are what she will miss the most.A lifelong resident of Easton, Demdy had collected photos of friends, family and neighbors. She said the snapshots were proudly displayed on her walls.
"I cried, cried, cried," Demdy said as she watched firefighters extinguish the last remaining embers at 17 South Locust Lane, many of her belongings strewn across the front yard of the early 20th century house. "I had everybody's picture on the wall. My walls were just full of pictures."
Demdy's home of 27 years was one of two houses that caught fire a little before 3 p.m. Saturday. It was the second house fire that Demdy had experienced in her life. Her home a few streets over had been lost to a fire three decades prior.
Firefighters were dispatched to the blaze at 3:07 p.m., by which time, neighbors said, flames were spreading quickly between the two structures.
Both Demby, who lived alone, and the family who lived next door were able to make it out of the houses, and emergency officials on the scene said that no serious injuries were reported.
It took firefighters a little more than two hours to control the blaze. Responding fire departments began to gather their equipment and leave the scene a little before 5:30 p.m.
Seven local fire departments responded to the fire — the Easton Volunteer Fire Department, the Cordova Volunteer Fire Company, the St. Michaels Fire Department, the Preston Volunteer Fire Company, the Oxford Fire Company, the Queen Anne-Hillsboro Volunteer Fire Company and the Trappe Volunteer Fire Company, along with local EMS and law enforcement personnel.
The state fire marshal is conducting an investigation into the fire and its causes, the results of which will be available at a later date.
Though exact damages are yet to be determined by the fire marshal, both houses sustained significant damage, and all residents of the structures were displaced.
Demdy said she would be staying with a relative near Salisbury, and arrangements were made for her neighbors.

 DENTON — A 26-year-old Ridgely man was indicted Jan. 18 in Caroline County in connection to an alleged sexual assault in 2012.Rhett Ritter is facing second-degree rape; second-, third- and fourth-degree sex offenses and second-degree assault charges related to the incident.

title: Officer fights to deter drivers like one who harmed him
author: LYDIA HURLEY Capital News Service
content:
Officer fights to deter drivers like one who harmed him

 February 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LYDIA HURLEY Capital News Service | Section: General Assembly 
 
 740
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Less than four months after losing his legs in an attempt to stop a reckless highway driver, a Montgomery County police officer is at the forefront of a movement to crack down on negligent driving in Maryland.Sgt. Patrick Kepp plans to testify on two bills in the state capital of Annapolis this session — traveling from Walter Reed National Military Medical Center in Bethesda, where he is still in active recovery from last October's incident.
"When I was brought into the conversation about new laws being created, right away, I knew it was something I wanted to do," Kepp said.
Rehabilitation is his first priority, he said, but treatment won't get in the way of his new mission. "I will be there in Annapolis to make sure these bills happen," Kepp said.
Kepp announced his plans this week in a press briefing alongside Montgomery County Executive Marc Elrich and Montgomery County lawmakers who are taking up the cause with him. Kepp's story has inspired them to craft new legislation that would punish repeat offenders of reckless driving.
"I'm going to call it the Sergeant Pat Kepp Bill on Reckless Driving," said Delegate Greg Wims (D-Montgomery), calling Kepp a "hero."
Reckless driving isn't a new phenomenon in Maryland. Outraged by stories of dangerous driving on the Beltway or the Ocean City Expressway, Maryland lawmakers in years past have proposed legislation meant to stop these behaviors. This session, two other bills, separate from Kepp's, are making their way through the legislature, specifically aimed at ending the deadly game of drag racing or "exhibition driving."
But Kepp's bill is a personal one, inspired by an officer who patrolled the sponsoring lawmakers' home district. Elrich visited Kepp while he was in recovery to propose the idea of working together on this set of bills, the officer said.
The two bills have not been filed, but the sponsors say they share common goals. The bills would change existing criminal law to widen the definition of what constitutes reckless and negligent driving and increase penalties for those crimes, the sponsors said.
One penalty they will propose is requiring offenders to appear in court for their offenses. "It's way too easy for a driver to just pay a fine and get back on the road and do what they were doing before," Elrich explained.
Sgt. Kepp, who worked as an officer in the alcohol initiative unit, says these bills will "give a little more teeth to some of our laws." Additionally, he hopes the law will address the "overall frustration" with the difficulty enforcing existing reckless driving laws. The penalties aren't tough enough, he said, and the fines aren't a good enough deterrent.
In the early morning hours of last Oct. 18, Kepp had just finished his shift when he heard a radio report of a speeding driver on Interstate 270. He joined other officers in an attempt to stop the driver. While Kepp was standing outside of his car, the driver struck him and left him critically injured, as Elrich recounted in the press briefing.
The Montgomery County Police officers on duty that night knew the driver "had a history of speeding and taunting police into chasing him," Elrich said. Police say the driver targeted and intentionally hit Kepp, Elrich said, and he is now being charged.
Both of Kepp's legs were amputated due to the injuries he sustained that night. Now he said he spends every day — from 9:45 a.m. to 2:15 p.m. — at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center undergoing rehabilitation. He joined the Zoom call for Elrich's press briefing from the medical center, wearing a blue dry-fit shirt and a short military-style haircut.
It has been four months since the accident, and Kepp said he has had a dozen surgeries since.
Still, he wants to speak on behalf of legislation that "will strengthen our laws and make our roadways safer," Kepp said.
The aim of the bills is "not for everybody to be thrown in jail, have huge fines, or lose their licenses," Kepp said, but rather to end reckless driving, especially by repeat offenders.
Elrich said he hopes the law will stop people from "ignoring lights and sirens from law enforcement, breaking the rules of the road … and performing car tricks like drifting, peeling out, and doing donuts in the middle of a road."
"All it takes is a moment's loss of control over that vehicle," Elrich said. "Instead of being entertaining, it would take little to transform it into a deadly incident."

title: Caroline Police Accountability Board reports progress
author: Connie Connolly
content:
Caroline Police Accountability Board reports progress

 February 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly | Section: Local News 
 
 1030
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — The Caroline County Police Accountability Board shared its second annual report with the County Commissioners at their Feb. 6 meeting.The bottom line: Of the thousands of contacts people had with county and town law enforcement officers, a handful of complaints were made, and a fraction of those resulted in disciplinary action.
Presenting the report were Police Accountability Board Chairman John Bartlett and Board Administrator Kimberly Raeder.
Bartlett said he wanted to make one "very important" point: The Caroline County Sheriff's Office had over 26,000 calls for service in 2023, which generated only six complaints, he said.
"Five of those six were exonerated, meaning unfounded, and one was a very minor infraction, which led to a written reprimand," he said. "I think that speaks volumes with law enforcement here in Caroline County."
A state mandate
Raeder explained the purpose and scope of the three police oversight boards mandated by the Maryland Police Accountability Act of 2021, which became effective July 1, 2022.
The role of the county's Police Accountability Board "is to receive police complaints, recommend policy changes and identify any trends," Raeder said.
"The second board is the five-member Administrative Charging Committee, and their role is to look over and review completed complaint investigations and recommend discipline," she said. If the Charging Committee decides to administratively charge, they use the statewide police disciplinary matrix to "decide what kind of discipline would be necessary based on the complaint."
The five members of the Charging Committee were appointed and trained in April 2023 at the Fretterd Center by the Maryland Police Training and Standards Commission.
The third board is the Trial Board comprised of retired Maryland Circuit Court Judge Owen Wise, a citizen and a police officer of the same rank, Raeder said. No complaints have been referred to this board.
"I'm proud to say that Caroline County is leading the way for other counties on the Eastern Shore who have reached out to us regarding using Judge Wise, if they need a judge for a trial board," she said.
Few complaints filed
Among the county's municipalities, 15 complaints were filed, including a pending complaint related to an April 7, 2023, incident in Denton that prompted millions of views on YouTube, Bartlett said.
A video of the incident shows Christopher Morgan threatening the residents and breaking the window of the storm door of a home while two Denton Police officers stand on the sidewalk watching.
The way the officers handled the call for service prompted Denton Police Chief George Bacorn to request the Talbot County Sheriff's Office to investigate the handling of the incident. Their findings were turned over to the Administrative Charging Committee.
There were no complaints from Ridgely or Greensboro. One was brought to the Police Accountability Board from Federalsburg, which was exonerated, Bartlett said.
The report breaks down the 15 complaints by percentages; numerically, four complaints are pending investigation, three were administratively charged, two were withdrawn by the complainant, four were exonerated and two were "not in the purview of the ACC (Administrative Charging Committee)."
The Accountability Board identified trends in the disciplinary process and didn't "recommend any changes at this time."
"A common identified trend, however, has been the lack of activation of body cameras when officers interact with the public," the report stated. "The ACC discovered this trend when reviewing completed complaint investigations which had no body camera footage for the ACC to review. The Board advised the municipal Police Departments and the Sheriff's Office to remind Officers to adhere to department policy and activate their cameras when encountering the public. The policy protects both the Officer and the Citizen if a complaint were to arise from the interaction."
Cost to the county
Bartlett thanked the commissioners for their "financial support of the committee for legal decisions when needed."
The boards' complying with the state mandates has incurred expenses for the county, although some have been covered by the Police Accountability, Community, and Transparency Grant program.
Of the $105,272 in grant funds received, the Accountability Board has spent $49,545, which includes the purchase of IAPro software for filing complaints, annual computer licensing for all board members, and pay for the Board's administrator.
The Police Accountability Board is asking the state to continue offering these grants, as well as other police-oriented grant programs for local police departments to be able to purchase "the required technology, resources, and tools to comply with the law," including software and a change in the vendor for body cameras, so that every law enforcement agency in the county has the same system.
Other costs included outside legal counsel, with expenses the County Commissioners agreed to fund to the tune of nearly $8,000.
Questions arose requiring legal clarification for both the Police Accountability Board and Administrative Charging Committee, and the county commissioners "agreed to bear the expense of hiring outside legal counsel" to represent both. "Legal Counsel attends each quarterly meeting and provides interpretation of the Maryland Police Accountability Act of 2021 as needed," the report stated.
The legal expenses for the Police Accountability Board were $3,650, while those of the Administrative Charging Committee amounted to $4,300.
PAB recommendations
The Accountability Board recommends "changing ACC training from all in-person training to online meeting based or pre-recorded online training. With one member of our ACC board resigning this past July, we have firsthand knowledge of the burden imposed on the newly appointed volunteer Board member. As terms end or resignations occur, the pool of applicants will continue to shrink when advised that members must undergo uncompensated training prior to serving."
Another unanticipated result of the law has been the withdrawing of multiple complaints, which created a legal conundrum for the Accountability Board and is currently being resolved with the Office of the Attorney General.
The report also suggested amending the law by mandating only complaints of "matters of public concern," that is, "police misconduct, such as abuse of power, false arrest, police brutality, or criminal activity" be referred to the Charging Committee, thus alleviating pressure on municipal police departments. "Rude and discourteous" behavior towards a citizen would be handled at the department or agency level, as suggested by the Accountability Board.
To read the full report, which includes rosters of members of the PAB and ACC boards, visit carolinemd.org/DocumentCenter/View/8606/2023-Annual-Report-PAB?bidId=. The last page provides links to other documents and resources provided by the PAB.

title: ‘Hang up immediately’: Scam artists impersonating police, targeting nonprofits with big, bogus donations
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS Belgrade News

‘Hang up immediately’: Scam artists impersonating police, targeting nonprofits with big, bogus donations

 Consumers lost a record $10 billion to fraudsters last year across the U.S. and there are fresh scam warnings from local police as well a scheme targeting Montana nonprofits.The Gallatin County Sheriff's Office is warning local residents of telephone scams involving fraudsters impersonating law enforcement officers.
On Monday, Feb. 12, the Sheriff's Office issued a scam alert saying it "has dozens of reports in recent weeks of a jury duty phone scam making the rounds."
"The caller claims that the person missed jury duty and that there is a warrant for their arrest, but they can post a fine or bail to take care of it," GCSO said in its announcement.
The law enforcement agency tells residents to "hang up immediately" and to not send any payments.
Like with other police-related scams across the state and country, the Sheriff's Office said it would not request monetary payments over the phone.
The latest alert follows one issued by GCSO on Jan. 26.
This scam also involves someone impersonating law enforcement and telling residents they missed jury duty, a court date or have unpaid parking tickets or criminal warrants.
"They will tell you to get gift cards and/or money to send over the phone in order to avoid arrest. Please know that while we may contact you to serve you various documents, we will never request money or gift cards. Any payments related to law enforcement or the jail are processed through the courts, never our office," GCSO said.
The scam artists might also use cloned police telephone numbers and actual deputy names. Again, police recommend hanging up immediately on the bogus callers.
"Scammers will be insistent that you stay on the line, which prevents you from thinking through their demands or calling someone else," GCSO said.
Other police agencies across the state and country have also seen imposters posing as officers as part of various phone scams.
NONPROFITS TARGETED
The Montana Nonprofit Association is also warning organizations of donation schemes that have so far targeted 19 groups statewide.
MNA said a nonprofit will receive " an unexpected donation of around $200,000 to honor someone's late mother."
"Multiple (organizations) have said the amount they received was $191,250, and that the email came from Alphonso Blye. The cashier's check looks legitimate so they cash it, " the Helena-based group said in an announcement Monday.
A few days later the same donor will contact the nonprofit and tell them the check should have been for $100,000 and request a refund of the remaining amount.
The check is bogus to begin and will bounce but scam rings hope to bilk groups out of $91,250 in the meantime.
"So far, everyone who has contacted us has managed to catch the scam before falling victim, but with this amount of money, the scammer only needs to convince one," MPA said.
The statewide association recommends confirming the identity of donors before accepting money and asking them to wait 30 days before issuing any refunds.
Major banks statewide and the Montana Bankers Association have also been alerted to the fraud scheme.
RECORD FRAUD LEVELS
The Federal Trade Commission reported Feb. 9 that U.S. consumers lost a record $10 billion to fraud schemes in 2023.
That is a 14% increase from 2022. Some of that jump stems from crypto currency fraud.
"Consumers reported losing more money to investment scams—more than $4.6 billion—than any other category in 2023. That amount represents a 21% increase over 2022. The second highest reported loss amount came from imposter scams, with losses of nearly $2.7 billion reported. In 2023, consumers reported losing more money to bank transfers and cryptocurrency than all other methods combined," FTC which received 2.6 million consumer complaints last year.
The U.S agency received 2.5 million complaints in 2022. The FTC said last year saw an increase in consumer calls involving fraud rings impersonating government officials (including police) as well as businesses.
The FTC received fraud reports from 2.6 million consumers last year, nearly the same amount as 2022. The most commonly reported scam category was imposter scams, which saw significant increases in reports of both business and government impersonators.

title: House of Delegates hears testimonies for Jamari's Law
author: Sarah Meador somdnewsintern@chespub.com
content:
House of Delegates hears testimonies for Jamari's Law

 February 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Sarah Meador somdnewsintern@chespub.com | Section: State News 
 
 520
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Maryland residents on Feb. 7 testified before the state House of Delegates in support of Jamari's Law, which would increase the maximum penalty of manslaughter by vehicle.Jamari Tyrese Duckett, the bill's namesake, was a recent graduate of Great Mills High School and registered for college with plans to study mechanical engineering when a drunk driver killed him on July 9, 2022, in St. Mary's County.
Matthew Mark Mazza was sentenced in October 2023 to the maximum sentence of 10 years in prison. Mazza, 28, of Lexington Park will be eligible for parole after serving only 2 1/2 years, as vehicular manslaughter is considered a non-violent crime in Maryland.
Mazza's braking speed at the time of the collision was between 76 mph and 91 mph in a 40 mph zone at the time of the crash, according to the St. Mary's sheriff's office.
Jamari's Law proposes to increase the maximum penalty for manslaughter by vehicle to 20 years and 15 to 30 years for any subsequent convictions.
"This is reckless and a disregard for life when you get behind the wheel, drunk, driving over the speed limit. That could have been you, me, your kids, parents or grandparents in that car, and to only get 10 years and out a few years later on probation, is a slap to all families that have lost someone to a drunk driver," Shownda Greenwell, Duckett's mother, said at the hearing.
Other families affected by drunk driving testified at the hearing both in person and over Zoom, urging the House Judiciary Committee to increase the maximum penalty to bring justice to their loved ones.
Del. Brian Crosby (D-St. Mary's) is sponsoring House Bill 264, which is cross-filed with Senate Bill 26 sponsored by Sen. Jack Bailey (R-St. Mary's, Calvert). The Senate hearing for the bill occurred on Jan. 24.
"It was very painful for them, but it was very important that the legislators understand what is happening as a result of such a serious crime," Bailey said of the many families who testified at both hearings.
The bill does not propose a minimum sentence, but gives judges further discretion in their sentencing of those who are found guilty of the crime of manslaughter by vehicle, Bailey said.
St. Mary's County State's Attorney Jaymi Sterling (R) also urged both the House and Senate to increase the maximum penalty, stating that the lives lost to vehicular manslaughter are worth more than the 10-year criminal penalty equivalent to passing a bad check.
"We need your help," Sterling said at the Senate hearing last month. "Please consider raising the penalties so that we have more to work with, so that we can rehabilitate, so that we can provide deterrence, but so there is also punishment."
Both the House and Senate bills were referred to the state legislature's committees.
"They're still seeking justice and trying to make sure that no other family should have to endure the same amount of pain that they did and not receive fair justice under the law," Crosby said.
He cited the bravery of all families who testified to bring justice to lives lost to vehicular manslaughter.
If the bill passes, the law would become effective Oct. 1.

title: Chamber of Commerce partners with Sheriff in fight against opioid overdoses
author: ERIC SYLVIA Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Chamber of Commerce partners with Sheriff in fight against opioid overdoses

 February 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ERIC SYLVIA Special to the Star Democrat | Section: News 
 
 544
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTER — On Monday, Sheriff Gary Hofmann joined Queen Anne's County Chamber of Commerce President Linda Friday to distribute ONEboxes, reverse overdose kits, at no charge to 11 local businesses.An emergency opioid overdose reversal kit designed to promote safety by assuring that individuals have life-saving, on-demand training when and where they need it, Hofmann said these kits are analogous to the AEDs which are showing up in more Queen Anne's County establishments than ever before.
"(AEDs) save lives," Hofmann said, "and these kits will too."
Opioid overdoses are not just contained to those with an addiction, Hofmann said, but can happen to anyone who may not realize they are taking more prescription pain medicine than is safe.
What is important about the ONEbox kit is it is a fully contained solution — it not only contains the Narcan (naloxone hydrochloride) doses, but multiple personal protection kits for those who will administer the life-saving doses, as well as a self playing video in both English and Spanish to assist those giving aid.
In the relentless battle against opioid overdose deaths plaguing communities across the nation, Narcan has emerged as a beacon of hope.
Developed as a nasal spray or injectable medication, Narcan acts swiftly to reverse the effects of opioid overdose, effectively restoring breathing and consciousness to individuals on the brink of death.
Statistics paint a compelling picture of Narcan's efficacy in saving lives. According to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the administration of naloxone reversed over 27,000 opioid overdoses in 2019 alone. This figure represents not just numbers on a chart but stories of individuals given a second chance at life, families spared the agony of loss and communities buoyed by the promise of redemption.
In Queen Anne's County, when emergency services respond to an overdose patient, they are transported to the hospital, and a peer specialist meets them there to offer services.
With support from surrounding counties, Queen Anne's commissioners and health officers have stepped up funding to the Whitsitt Center in Chestertertown for crisis beds and drug treatment.
In Queen Anne's, schools have Narcan in each school available to be administered by school nurses.
Since January of last year, 1,488 doses have been made available with training at no cost.
From the Coalition's viewpoint, making Narcan available to anyone, and offering training all over the county has been huge. According to program coordinator Rebecca Groff with the Chamber of Commerce, "The goal is to distribute these kits to businesses throughout the county, regardless of their size."
Friday said, "QAC businesses give all the time to worthwhile community causes." Her goal is to give something back to them that could be life saving.
Thanks to the joint effort of the Chamber of Commerce, County Commissioners, Drug Free Coalition, Health Department and Sheriff's Department these kits are now being distributed to area businesses at no cost. Prevention Specialist at the Health Department, Anna Ashley is in charge of distribution.
And Hoffman is providing his network to encourage local businesses to get the boxes while they last. Wright concluded, "This is a great example of the community coming together — everyone working together makes tasks easier."
For local businesses looking to join the fight, contact Becky Groff at Queen Anne's County Chamber of Commerce, 1561 Postal Road in Chester, at 410- 643-8530 or at rgroff@qacchamber.com.

title: Tilghman man sentenced to five years for sexual abuse of a child
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Tilghman man sentenced to five years for sexual abuse of a child

 February 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Crime 
 
 680
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A Tilghman man was sentenced Friday to five years in prison for sexually abusing a child last February.After nearly an hour-long recess following statements from the child's family and the defense, Talbot County Circuit Judge Stephen Kehoe sentenced Eric Werner, 62, to five years of active incarceration.
"This is a very awful situation," Kehoe said prior to handing down the term.
Werner received nearly a year of credit for time already served. He will be required to serve at least half of his sentence before being eligible for parole.
State sentencing guidelines for the case recommended 15 to 30 years, according to Deputy State's Attorney Chelsea Endzel, who prosecuted the case and recommended 30 years of active prison time.
The sentence comes over three months after a jury found Werner guilty of 16 counts, including sexual abuse of a minor, third- and fourth-degree sex offenses, second-degree assault and displaying obscene matter to a minor.
Detectives from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office began investigating Werner last February after learning of multiple child sexual abuse incidents that occurred at a home in Tilghman that month.
Police investigation revealed that Werner sexually assaulted a preteen girl through inappropriately touching her on three different occasions that February.
Werner also showed the child pornographic videos, which the child remembered in detail during the trial.
At Friday's sentencing, Endzel emphasized Werner's "calculated effort to groom and abuse the child" over several months.
Werner inserted himself into the child's life as a "pseudo family member," learning what made her especially vulnerable, she said. And once the girl felt comfortable spending time with him, he began making sexual comments, increasing her self-consciousness, Endzel added.
Things escalated further when Werner inappropriately touched the child.
Werner always told the child not to tell anyone else about his actions, threatening the possibility of her going to jail, Endzel said, but in a show of "astonishing strength and courage," the girl told a friend.
For the child's mother, whom the Star Democrat is not naming to protect the victim's privacy, it was difficult to see her child referred to as a victim and just as hard to put the impact into words.
"I have no way to measure what this has cost my daughter and … my family," she said.
The impacts were wide-ranging, she explained. Invoices added up with homeschooling and therapy. Hours of sleep were lost and anxiety built up. The child struggled "every hour of every day."
"She — the victim, my daughter, my child — will never be the same," the child's mother said.
Defense attorney Philip Cronan said it was easy for the prosecution to suspect "nefarious intent" with Werner's community activities involving direct contact with children, but Werner had never displayed similar behaviors, he said.
Psychiatric evaluations deemed Werner to be a low risk for repeating similar crimes and determined he would have a high chance of success in returning to the community, he added.
Though Cronan did not make a specific sentencing recommendation, he argued that Endzel had effectively asked for a life sentence, given Werner's age.
When given a chance to speak, Werner acknowledged his actions as wrong, saying he lost his "moral compass."
"I have no excuses and no explanations," he said.
When released, Werner will be required to register as a Tier III sex offender — a lifetime registry in Maryland.
He will be under supervised probation for five years, is barred from contacting the child and must stay away from the child's home. He will also be required to complete mental health treatment.
Cronan did not give a comment following the sentencing.
Endzel highlighted the "huge team effort" with the Talbot County Sheriff's Office in investigating and prosecuting the case, along with providing support to the family.
But above all, she commended the child for her "bravery and strength" throughout the process.
"The child victim stood up to her abuser in front of a courtroom full of strangers and found the courage to recount her abuse and withstand a grueling cross-examination," she said. "This showing of tenacity and strength gives me hope that this remarkable child will one day recover from the abuse inflicted upon her and will find a way to move forward."

title: Officer fights to deter drivers like one who injured him
author: LYDIA HURLEY Capital News Service
content:
Officer fights to deter drivers like one who injured him

 February 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LYDIA HURLEY Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 739
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Less than four months after losing his legs in an attempt to stop a reckless highway driver, a Montgomery County police officer is at the forefront of a movement to crack down on negligent driving in Maryland.Sgt. Patrick Kepp plans to testify on two bills in the state capital of Annapolis this session — traveling from Walter Reed National Military Medical Center in Bethesda, where he is still in active recovery from last October's incident.
"When I was brought into the conversation about new laws being created, right away, I knew it was something I wanted to do," Kepp said.
Rehabilitation is his first priority, he said, but treatment won't get in the way of his new mission. "I will be there in Annapolis to make sure these bills happen," Kepp said.
Kepp announced his plans this week in a press briefing alongside Montgomery County Executive Marc Elrich (D) and Montgomery County lawmakers who are taking up the cause with him. Kepp's story has inspired them to craft new legislation that would punish repeat offenders of reckless driving.
"I'm going to call it the Sgt. Pat Kepp Bill on Reckless Driving," Del. Greg Wims (D-Montgomery) said, calling Kepp a "hero."
Reckless driving isn't a new phenomenon in Maryland. Outraged by stories of dangerous driving on the Beltway or the Ocean City Expressway, Maryland lawmakers have in years past have proposed legislation meant to stop these behaviors. This session, two other bills, separate from Kepp's, are making their way through the legislature, specifically aimed at ending the deadly game of drag racing or "exhibition driving."
But Kepp's bill is a personal one, inspired by an officer who patrolled the sponsoring lawmakers' home district. Elrich visited Kepp while he was in recovery to propose the idea of working together on this set of bills, the officer said.
The two bills have not been filed, but the sponsors say they share common goals. The bills would change existing criminal law to widen the definition of what constitutes reckless and negligent driving and increase penalties for those crimes, the sponsors said.
One penalty they will propose is requiring offenders to appear in court for their offenses. "It's way too easy for a driver to just pay a fine and get back on the road and do what they were doing before," Elrich explained.
Kepp, who worked as an officer in the alcohol initiative unit, says these bills will "give a little more teeth to some of our laws." Additionally, he hopes the law will address the "overall frustration" with the difficulty enforcing existing reckless driving laws. The penalties aren't tough enough, he said, and the fines aren't a good enough deterrent.
In the early morning hours of last Oct. 18, Kepp had just finished his shift when he heard a radio report of a speeding driver on Interstate 270. He joined other officers in an attempt to stop the driver. While Kepp was standing outside of his car, the driver struck him and left him critically injured, as Elrich recounted in the press briefing.
The Montgomery County Police officers on duty that night knew the driver "had a history of speeding and taunting police into chasing him," Elrich said. Police say the driver targeted and intentionally hit Kepp, Elrich said, and he is now being charged.
Both of Kepp's legs were amputated due to the injuries he sustained that night. Now he said he spends every day — from 9:45 a.m. to 2:15 p.m. — at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center undergoing rehabilitation. He joined the Zoom call for Elrich's press briefing from the medical center, wearing a blue dry-fit shirt and a short military-style haircut.
It has been four months since the accident, and Kepp said he has had a dozen surgeries since.
Still, he wants to speak on behalf of legislation that "will strengthen our laws and make our roadways safer," Kepp said.
The aim of the bills is "not for everybody to be thrown in jail, have huge fines, or lose their licenses," Kepp said, but rather to end reckless driving, especially by repeat offenders.
Elrich said he hopes the law will stop people from "ignoring lights and sirens from law enforcement, breaking the rules of the road … and performing car tricks like drifting, peeling out, and doing donuts in the middle of a road."
"All it takes is a moment's loss of control over that vehicle," Elrich said. "Instead of being entertaining, it would take little to transform it into a deadly incident."

title: Bikers try (and try) to gut a state helmet law
author: SAPNA BANSIL Capital News Service
content:
Bikers try (and try) to gut a state helmet law

 February 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SAPNA BANSIL Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 955
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — A group of bikers in leather vests and wispy beards greets lawmakers here each Monday of the legislative session, hoping this is the year they'll succeed in their galvanizing cause: gutting a Maryland law that requires them to wear helmets.The group, which calls itself A Brotherhood Against Totalitarian Enactments, has experienced decades of setbacks on the helmet issue. Its vociferous critics say ABATE's position is at a minimum, eccentric and at worst, dangerous.
But driven by a burning belief in personal freedom and a joy for riding, ABATE has used persistent, grassroots activism to keep the helmet issue alive in Maryland. It's why in nearly every legislative session since the state's mandatory helmet law took effect in 1992, the Maryland General Assembly has at least considered a bill that would make wearing a helmet optional for most riders.
"It's been 32 years this year to no avail," said Bob Spanburgh, Maryland ABATE's board chairman. "But we keep introducing it. We have some pretty ardent supporters. We have a lot of people who think we're nuts, probably."
Like many of its previous incarnations over the last three decades, this year's bill would make wearing a helmet optional if a motorcyclist is at least 21 years old, has been licensed for a minimum of two years and has completed a safety course. It is named in honor of Gary "Pappy" Boward, a former ABATE executive director and motorcycle rights advocate who died in 2020 of health issues.
ABATE and other supporters insist that they aren't opposed to riders wearing helmets if they so choose. But they feel the current mandate abridges freedom of choice and represents government overreach.
"I firmly believe that we as government do better when we educate people, (rather) than legislating something," said Sen. Mike McKay (R-Allegany, Garrett and Washington), the bill's primary Senate sponsor and a friend of Boward's. "There are people that would like to have the choice (to not wear a helmet). And I tend to believe that we should give people the choice but 100% support educating them about it."
Established in 1974, ABATE will mark 50 years of advocacy for motorcyclists' rights this June. Its animating issue has been eroding Maryland's helmet law, different iterations of which have been in place since 1968. Today, Maryland joins 16 other states and the District of Columbia in requiring all riders to wear protective headgear.
Spanburgh, a 66-year-old retired carpenter, only casually followed politics when he joined ABATE in the mid-1980s. Initially, he saw the group as a community of like-minded individuals, who shared his enthusiasm for bikes, firearms, the outdoors and rock and roll. But right away, ABATE turned Spanburgh into an unlikely activist.
"At the first meeting I went to, the thing they told me (was), 'You got to register to vote. It's very important in this organization,'" Spanburgh recalled. "That was actually the first time I ever registered to vote in my life. I was 27 at the time."
Each legislative session, the helmet bill faces cockeyed glances and prodigious odds. Contending with a wealth of scientific evidence, which shows crashes involving non-helmeted motorcyclists are much more likely to result in severe head trauma and death, the measure almost always dies in committee.
But ABATE ensures the issue is revived and relitigated, year after year, by finding ways to get in front of elected officials, despite limited financial resources and dwindling numbers. In the past, the group used a tactic it called "piss house politics," which involved following lawmakers into the bathroom to gain an audience and get its message heard.
"They're diehards for what they believe in," said Del. Jay Jacobs (R-Caroline, Cecil, Kent and Queen Anne's). "Thank God they do. They don't let go of this stuff. It's a tough fight over here to get that kind of legislation passed."
While Republicans are the most likely to sympathize with ABATE's cause, the group engages lawmakers on both sides of the aisle. This year's bill, cross-filed as HB639 and SB503, has bipartisan sponsors in both chambers.
"I don't agree with them that they shouldn't wear a helmet, but I do agree about the civil liberty issue," said Sen. Jill Carter (D-Baltimore City), one of the bill's Senate co-sponsors.
"They are adamant as dedicated motorcyclists that this is not something they want mandated to them," she added.
In a recent hearing of the House Environment and Transportation Committee, opponents included highway safety groups, medical associations and public health officials. They argued that a weaker helmet law would increase motorcyclists' risk of injury and death, impose an avoidable burden on taxpayers and encumber the healthcare system.
"A lot of people might say, 'Well, it's my free will to do whatever I want to do, no matter how stupid it is,'" Gene Ransom, CEO of MedChi, the Maryland State Medical Society, said in an interview. "The problem is, when it comes to healthcare … your decision then ends up costing the entire system a whole lot of money.
"Not only is it the right thing to do and the smart thing to do — logical people wear helmets when they ride a motorcycle or a bike or other things — it also is appropriate from a common good and cost point of view," Ransom added.
The bill is scheduled for a hearing before the Senate Judicial Proceedings Committee later this week. Spanburgh hopes to see the measure make it out of committee and get a vote on the House or Senate floor. If unsuccessful, proponents vow they won't stop trying.
"If I don't do it, who else is going to do it?" said Ken Eaton, Maryland ABATE's executive director. "We try to get other people to help us as much as possible. But if I don't do it, how can I convince other people to do it?"

title: 'End of Watch'
author: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Bay Times Record Observer
content:
'End of Watch'

 February 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Bay Times Record Observer | Section: End Of Watch 
 
 649
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE— As evening fell, the American flag proudly waved high up between ladder trucks welcoming the community to come, honor, and remember their fallen heroes.A date remembered and honored by many in Queen Anne's County for the last 22 years the Fallen Heroes Memorial continues to be observed Feb. 13. Hosted by Fraternal Order of Police Lodge 108, the event's location has varied through the years. It was held this year at the Centreville United Methodist Church.
The event began with the Pledge of Allegiance and a moment of silence led by Sheriff Gary Hoffman. Senior Pastor Rev. Karen Handy of Centreville Methodist Church welcomed and addressed families, friends and community members.
Chase Armington, past president of Lodge 108 and current Queen Anne's County deputy began, "Tonight, we gather to honor our fallen heroes. It is our duty to never forget them, for they have paved the path forward with their lives. The path leading us here tonight was born from tragedy. Incredible losses. Unbearable pain for our families, friends, and the community. These honored in front of you served our community with pride, dignity, and honor. Knowing their lives could, at any moment be taken, so that we may live. So that we may continue on the path they have now paved."
Sue Nickerson, who lost her son, Centreville Police Officer Michael Nickerson, in 2001 explains, "The FOP from QAC started (this event) and they will always have it on February 13, the night that Michael (Nickerson) and Jason (Schwenz, Queen Anne's County deputy) were killed. But, it's to honor all emergency people who have passed away in the line of duty from Queen Anne's County."
As a mother who lost her son, this event is near to her heart. Nickerson said, "It means a lot. It really does. QAC is willing to step up, and support the families, and acknowledge the jobs that our law enforcement, our firefighters and our EMTs have done. It is very much appreciated."
First responders marched in for the Presentation of Colors, holding flags to honor those lost in the line of duty.
Queen Anne's County State's Attorney Lance Richardson spoke about stoicism and how it applies here. "The heroes we celebrate tonight were tragically taken from us. We don't have any control over that. But what we do have control over is how we respond to it, how we react, how we pick up the pieces and go on. Stoicism also places an emphasis on appreciating the unity and precious gift of life."
During this powerful remembrance, family members came, first responder representatives saluted and all placed long-stemmed red roses by the framed photographs.
The names of the fallen heroes were read along with the date of their End of Watch.
Ten Queen Anne's County residents and fallen heroes' pictures filled the front table: Queen Anne's-Hillsboro Volunteer Fire Company's Daniel Lister, Sudlersville Volunteer Fire Company's "Buck" Clough, Kent Island Volunteer Fire Department's "Dougie" Thomas, United Community Volunteer Fire Department's David Brinkley, Centreville Police Department's Michael Nickerson, QA Sheriff's Deputy Jason Schwenz, DNR Warden Charles Rider, and Maryland State Police troopers Thomas Noyle, Philip Russ and Wallace Mowbray.
Radio transmission echoed for all to hear to mark the ultimate sacrifice given on that fateful Feb. 13, 2001, "Today we honor the memory and pay tribute to those who greatly served and protected QAC and the State of Maryland. May their dedication and sacrifice never be forgotten and may they rest in eternal peace." Bagpipes played 'Amazing Grace' from the balcony overhead. Silence filled every space of the church.
Handy closed, "Lord, you gave them the gift of courage of serving others. Lord, mend those hearts that are broken in the loss of these loved ones. Lord, we pray that this memorial tonight has brought a bit of peace. Lord, we lift up and thank you for each of these persons. We thank you and pray for those that they have left behind."

title: Cambridge man charged with kidnapping in connection to missing woman
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Cambridge man charged with kidnapping in connection to missing woman

 February 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Crime 
 
 1018
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A Cambridge man was arrested Monday in the alleged kidnapping of a 31-year-old woman who was reported missing over a week ago. The woman has yet to be located.Kenneth Stefan Bradley, 41, is charged with kidnapping, assault and related charges in connection to Tiyavauna Britt's disappearance.
An arrest warrant indicated Bradley was arrested in Anne Arundel County on Monday, Feb. 19. He was ordered held without bond during a bail review in Glen Burnie District Court that day, according to court records.
Britt, who was first reported missing to the Easton Police Department on Tuesday, Feb. 13, remains "critically missing," according to charging documents authored by a Maryland State Police sergeant.
According to charging documents, Britt's mother told police she had attempted to contact her daughter several times between Jan. 31 and Feb. 13, but had not been able to reach her. Several other family members were unable to make contact with Britt, her mother told police.
Britt's mother also told police that the car typically driven by Britt was found unoccupied in the Dollar Tree parking lot in Easton.
The car was found unlocked with Britt's belongings inside, including her phone and wallet.
Britt's mother said she found a note in the driver's side door of the car that appeared to be "a list of couple goals," according to charging documents. Police wrote that the end of the letter said "No phones, no kids, just us."
It was not clear who authored the note.
According to charging documents, Britt's mother believed her daughter was with her ex-boyfriend, identified as Bradley. The mother feared for her daughter's safety, citing previous domestic violence history between the two.
Bradley is currently on probation for a previous assault conviction related to Britt in Talbot County.
In early September 2021, police responded to an alleyway in Easton, where they found Britt crying. According to charging documents in that case, Britt told police Bradley was chasing her in his truck after the two got into an argument.
Britt told police that Bradley pulled her hair, grabbed her by the throat and choked her. He also reportedly held a pillow over her face and mouth, threatening to kill her, and told her not to leave.
Britt was found to have abrasions on her neck consistent with being choked, along with abrasions on her wrist and redness to the back of her neck at her hairline, police wrote.
While that case was still pending, police were called to an apartment in Hurlock in April 2022 for another altercation between Bradley and Britt, though that case was later placed on the stet, or inactive, docket.
Bradley was convicted of second-degree assault in Talbot County Circuit Court in June 2022 and was sentenced to 10 years, with all but time already served suspended.
He was placed on three years of supervised probation and ordered to complete an abusers' intervention program, though a violation of probation report filed on Feb. 16 indicated he had not provided verification of completing the course.
In further investigating Britt's disappearance, police spoke with three other people who knew her, all of whom said they had last heard from or seen Britt on Wednesday, Feb. 7.
Britt's employer told police she was seen leaving work in Delaware around 3 p.m. Surveillance footage from her employer showed Britt wearing a black coat and black sweatpants, police said.
A woman who identified herself as Britt's cousin told police she was with Britt that afternoon and heard her and Bradley having a verbal argument on the phone before the couple planned to go to dinner at Portside in Cambridge.
The cousin told police Britt dropped her off in Hurlock around 6 p.m., according to charging documents. The two spoke on the phone for several minutes afterward.
Police said a man who identified himself as an acquaintance of Britt said he received a phone call from her shortly after 7:30 p.m. The man told police he briefly spoke with Britt before hearing a male voice, adding that he believed the man with her "started to assault" her before the call suddenly ended.
Detectives obtained cell tower records for Britt's phone, giving police a timeline of events leading to the last time her phone was active, according to charging documents. Police wrote that Britt was in downtown Cambridge and Great Marsh Park that evening.
The last known cell tower location placed Britt's phone at Great Marsh Park shortly before 8:30 p.m. Feb. 7, police wrote.
Police also obtained cell tower data for Bradley's phone number, which placed him in the same area and locations as Britt during that time frame.
Officers from the Cambridge Police Department reviewed surveillance footage between Portside and Great Marsh Park, which showed a dark-colored Chevrolet Suburban pulling into the park shortly before 7:30 p.m.
According to charging documents, a Black male was seen exiting the vehicle with a woman who appeared to have her hands bound. The man walked the woman to the rear of the vehicle, opening and closing the hatch, and walked her to the front of the vehicle — out of view of the camera, police noted.
Further review of the camera footage revealed audio of male and female voices. Police wrote that "sounds of loud thuds" also were heard, which "appear to be consistent with forceful strikes."
Police interviewed a man connected to Britt on Feb. 16, who identified the voices as Britt and Bradley.
Charging documents said a "dark object" was seen lying on the ground in front of the vehicle as it drove away shortly before 8 p.m. The same vehicle was seen returning about 25 minutes later.
Police wrote that the footage showed a male driver leaving the vehicle and walking toward the object. Within minutes, the man was seen "carrying and dragging" what appeared to be a "small statured, light skinned female" consistent with the woman observed in the videos.
The man later carried the woman's "limp body" to the rear cargo area of the vehicle, placing other unknown items there before leaving at 8:30 p.m.
Police have not shared further information on Britt. Anyone with knowledge of her whereabouts is asked to contact Maryland State Police.
Bradley is set to appear for a preliminary hearing in Dorchester County District Court on March 12.

title: New commander joins Maryland State Police barrack in Easton
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
New commander joins Maryland State Police barrack in Easton

 February 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 443
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Lt. Stacey J. Gappert is the new Maryland State Police Barrack Commander in Easton.She has decades of law enforcement experience, having gone right into cadet training when she graduated from Queen Anne's County High School in 1998.
"You start out as a new trooper and then you make TFC (trooper first class). Then you make corporal, then sergeant, the first sergeant and then lieutenant. There are 23 barrack commanders in the state," she said.
"One day I had an epiphany. I knew I didn't want to go to college. I really wanted to go to work. I had no law enforcement in my family at all. None. I am still here," she said.
She has been a lieutenant for six years, working at the JFK Highway Barrack before recently being moved back to the Eastern Shore. She was a commander there for those six years.
Her experience has helped her understand the requirements of the barrack commander job.
"My main responsibilities are oversight of all barrack operations. I now have three assistant commanders. The administrative staff falls under me — not just troopers, but dispatchers as well. It is a good amount. You need to know your people and what is going to motivate them," she said.
Fred Stanco, assistant barrack commander, said, "(Gappert) is the captain of the ship. She is the beginning and the end of the installation. So everything is hers."
Gappert's jurisdiction is three counties — Dorchester, Talbot and Caroline.
"I love working at this barrack because we have three good sheriffs. The municipality chiefs are great. I have only been back a few weeks, but the troopers and the officers get along great. We all work together," she said.
"I think what I am looking for the most would be the relationships with the sheriffs' departments and the municipalities. We do monthly chief's meetings. So community relationships and relationships with our allied partners are important," she said.
One of the struggles she will need to work to overcome is recruitment, Gappert said. The Maryland State Police are recruiting for cadets at the end of April.
"It has always been a concern not having enough troopers. We are doing the best we can for right now," she said.
"The climate of getting people to want to be cops and troopers, it is exhausting trying to get people on board to do the job," she said.
They have a full time recruiter to try and get people to join.
"We do job fairs. We go out of state. We go to schools. The philosophy is to get them when they are young and have them go into the cadet program and then from there get them in the academy," she said.

title: Why we cannot solve America's gun problem
author: LARRY PIFER
content:
Why we cannot solve America's gun problem

 February 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LARRY PIFER | Section: Columns 
 
 614
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On Feb. 14 the shooting of at least 23 people in Kansas City abruptly halted the celebration of the Super Bowl win by the Kansas City Chiefs. At least one person is dead. At least half of the victims were under the age of 16 (one only 6). The state of Missouri has some of the most permissive gun safety laws in the country. There are no background checks required, no permit to carry a concealed gun, no restrictions on gun ownership by violent offenders, no requirement to lock up firearms and no restrictions on assault weapons. Two juveniles are charged for this slaughter.The United States has more guns than people. We have mass shootings on a weekly basis. Our laws regulating gun sales, ownership and use are some of the most lax in the world. The United States has a gun homicide rate 26 times that of other high-income countries. The second leading cause of death for children under 18 years-old is gun homicide (second only to automobile deaths). This is our shameful problem.
Most everyone wants to fix it. Polls show that as many as 97% of us support a universal criminal background check on all gun purchases. Much of the senseless killing and mass shooting is by assault style weapons developed for use in war. The Second Amendment to the Constitution grants us the right to bear arms, but not for the unconstrained use of weapons of war to murder our fellow citizens and children.
A large majority of us want to ban these weapons. So what prevents us from altering what we have done to ourselves? Why can't we do better in saving our children from gun violence?
Is the latest tragedy in Kansas City a possible turning point in this terrible tale? Could the gun protectors suddenly perceive an economic impact if families cannot safely attend large gatherings and so they think twice about attending sporting events, the Easter parade or other American celebrations? Gun protectors seem unmoved by school, church or grocery store shootings, but perhaps families and individuals who value their safety above their support for guns might shy away from attending large events, costing event-organizers real money.
People might be less willing to spend large sums to attend a football game with their family if they fear that others with concealed weapons might also attend.
I truly believe that the issue lies with one party of lawmakers and politicians who have made their pact with the National Rifle Association. The elected members in one party in both the Senate and the House have consistently fought against laws that would help solve this problem. They oppose universal background checks, a ban on assault-style weapons and red flag laws that identify people who should not have guns.
They have successfully subverted what the citizens in the United States want. I believe that the lawmakers in one party have done this as a political weapon and message. I think they believe they must run on this stance for political gain. What a horrible, horrible thing to do. But until this stance changes, or such lawmakers are defeated, this is what we citizens, the next victims, must live with. And the framers of our Constitution did not intend for us to arm ourselves with weapons of war to defend ourselves at a celebratory parade.
I appeal to all of you, for the sake of our children, our fellow citizens and ourselves — do not vote for any candidate who opposes an assault weapons ban, red flag laws or universal background checks on gun sales and ownership.
Our future and our lives depend on it.
Larry Pifer lives in Easton and is a member of the Talbot Democratic Forum.

title: 'End of Watch'
author: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Star Democrat
content:
'End of Watch'

 February 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Local News 
 
 786
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE— As evening fell, the American flag proudly waved high up between ladder trucks welcoming the community to come, honor, and remember their fallen heroes. A date remembered and honored by many in Queen Anne's County for the last 22 years the Fallen Heroes Memorial continues to be observed Feb. 13. Hosted by Fraternal Order of Police Lodge 108, the location has varied through the years but was held this year at the Centreville United Methodist Church.The event began with the Pledge of Allegiance and a moment of silence led by Sheriff Gary Hoffman. Senior Pastor Rev. Karen Handy of Centreville Methodist Church welcomed and addressed families, friends, and community members.
Chase Armington, past president of Lodge 108 and current Queen Anne's County deputy, began, "Tonight, we gather to honor our fallen heroes. It is our duty to never forget them, for they have paved the path forward with their lives. The path leading us here tonight was born from tragedy. Incredible losses. Unbearable pain for our families, friends, and the community. These honored in front of you served our community with pride, dignity, and honor. Knowing their lives could, at any moment be taken, so that we may live. So that we may continue on the path they have now paved."
The event started from tragedy, continues years later as a way to honor and remember those who have unselfishly given their lives for others. Sue Nickerson, who lost her son, Centreville Police Officer Michael Nickerson, in 2001 explains, "The FOP from QAC started [this event] and they will always have it on February 13th, the night that Michael [Nickerson] and Jason [Schwenz, Queen Anne's County deputy] were killed. But, it's to honor all emergency people who have passed away in the line of duty from Queen Anne's County."
Nickerson is the Maryland Concerns of Police Survivors (COPS) Director.
As a mother who lost her son, this event is near to her heart. Nickerson said, "It means a lot. It really does. QAC is willing to step up, and support the families, and acknowledge the jobs that our law enforcement, our firefighters, and our EMTs have done. It is very much appreciated."
First responders marched in for the Presentation of Colors, holding flags to honor those lost in the line of duty. Queen Anne's County State's Attorney, Lance Richardson, spoke about stoicism and how it applies here. "The heroes we celebrate tonight were tragically taken from us. We don't have any control over that. But what we do have control over is how we respond to it, how we react, how we pick up the pieces and go on. Stoicism also places an emphasis on appreciating the unity and precious gift of life."
Richardson went on to quote the Roman Emperor Marcus Aurelius, "When you arise in the morning, think of what a precious privilege it is to be alive — to breathe, to think, to enjoy, to love." Applying this quote, Richardson said, "So, tonight, we honor those who gave the ultimate sacrifice, their lives, so we could go on living our lives in peace and safety." He ended by encouraging all to 'earn this.' "We must continue to honor these brothers and sisters, live a life that would be a testament to their memory, and continue to do God's will and God's work."
During this powerful remembrance, family members came, first responder representatives saluted, and all placed long-stemmed red roses by the framed photographs. The names of the fallen heroes were read along with the date of their End of Watch. Ten Queen Anne's County residents and fallen heroes' pictures filled the front table: Queen Anne's-Hillsboro Volunteer Fire Company's Daniel Lister, Sudlersville Volunteer Fire Company''s "Buck" Clough, Kent Island Volunteer Fire Department's "Dougie" Thomas, United Community Volunteer Fire Department''s David Brinkley, Centreville Police Department's Michael Nickerson, QA Sheriff's Deputy Jason Schwenz, DNR Warden Charles Rider, and Maryland State Police troopers Thomas Noyle, Philip Russ, and Wallace Mowbray.
Radio transmission echoed for all to hear to mark the ultimate sacrifice given on that fateful Feb. 13, 2001, "Today we honor the memory and pay tribute to those who greatly served and protected QAC and the State of Maryland. May their dedication and sacrifice never be forgotten and may they rest in eternal peace." Bagpipes played 'Amazing Grace' from the balcony overhead. Silence filled every space of the church.
Handy closed, "Lord, you gave them the gift of courage of serving others. Lord, mend those hearts that are broken in the loss of these loved ones. Lord, we pray that this memorial tonight has brought a bit of peace. Lord, we lift up and thank you for each of these persons. We thank you and pray for those that they have left behind."

title: State lawmakers hope to protect judges’ privacy
author: TYRAH BURRIS Capital News Service
content:
State lawmakers hope to protect judges’ privacy

 February 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TYRAH BURRIS Capital News Service | Section: General Assembly 
 
 629
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Just a few months after a Maryland judge was killed in front of his home, state lawmakers are considering a measure that would remove personal information from the internet to provide more safety for judges.The Judge Andrew F. Wilkinson Judicial Security Act is named after the judge, who was shot and killed in his driveway in October 2023 by a man he'd ruled against in a custody dispute.
Sponsors hope the proposed change would provide more safety to judges and their families.
"The threats that happen to the members of the judiciary, they happen all the time," said Del. Luke Clippinger (D-Baltimore City), House sponsor. "It's a very challenging job to begin with, but a particularly challenging job when you add on the threats that they face and their families face."
Wilkinson isn't the only judge whose life was put in danger. All cross the country, state legislatures are looking to beef up protections for judges. In 2022, Congress passed the Daniel Anderl Judicial Security and Privacy Act, in honor of the son of New Jersey Federal judge Esther Salas. Salas was targeted by a lawyer who found her address and personal information online. Her son was gunned down in their family home. That law allows federal judges to remove personal information from federal government websites, according to a statement on the United States Courts website.
During the 2024 legislative session, the Maryland General Assembly is trying to do something similar. The bill would protect the privacy of judges by removing or prohibiting personal information from being published on the internet or any form of social media. The bill passed in the Senate and now moves on to the House.
Watchdog and advocacy groups in other states that have considered similar legislation have raised concerns about the possibility of withholding too much information about elected and appointed officials, who ultimately answer to the public. In a committee hearing, Sen. Charles Sydnor III (D-Baltimore) expressed concerns that the effort could be too broad.
"While I understand there was a specific concern about people posting and immediately wanting to be able to act, that was just one circumstance, and I just thought it was too broad," Sydnor said in an interview with Capital News Service.
After Wilkinson was killed, Jason DeLoach, the president of the Maryland State Bar Association, said he began working with others to put the bill together.
"When Judge Wilkinson was tragically murdered, I looked his wife in the eye at his service and I told her that the MSBA would be actively involved in making sure that we improve judicial security and doing everything we can to prevent this type of thing from happening again," he said during an interview with CNS.
As an attorney, DeLoach said he thinks that it's important to trust that a case will be resolved based on the facts and evidence of the case.
"We don't want the judge to have to think about anything other than the facts and the evidence," he said. "When judges are being threatened, or there's a potential for violence, that may persuade them on how they're going to rule."
Shortly before he died, Wilkinson ruled against his shooter in a divorce case granting the man's ex-wife custody of their children. Police suspect that was the motive for the shooting later that night.
Stephanie Wilkinson, the wife of Judge Wilkinson, said in her testimony before lawmakers that the gunman ambushed Wilkinson while he stepped outside to take a walk.
"I am devastated that I lost my husband, but my heart is beyond repair that my children have lost their father," she said. "Please help make things right by supporting this bill. By doing so you will assure my children, and the children Drew saved that day in this domestic case, that he did not die in vain."

title: Maryland Democrats close in on refined juvenile justice bill
author: STEPH QUINN Capital News Service
content:
Maryland Democrats close in on refined juvenile justice bill

 February 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEPH QUINN Capital News Service | Section: General Assembly 
 
 789
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Democratic leaders are "very close" to agreement on adjustments to their controversial juvenile justice bill, including changes to the list of crimes that should qualify children ages 10 through 12 for delinquency jurisdiction, a key lawmaker said Thursday.Sen. Will Smith (D-Montgomery) said discussions on the bill are "still an iterative process," but that the bill's architects plan to limit under-13 jurisdiction to regulated firearms violations and third-degree sex offenses. An earlier version of the bill included auto thefts, among other crimes.
In addition, Smith said, leaders are also looking at changes to improve the process for referring young people to rehabilitation services, through what is known as the "Child in Need of Supervision" petition.
"It's to hold the entire system accountable and to ensure that youth get the support and the treatment that they need," Smith told Capital News Service in an interview Thursday afternoon.
Democratic leaders have been negotiating behind the scenes as they try to reconcile their initial proposal, introduced in January, with testimony and data pouring in from prosecutors, public defenders, victims and youth advocates.
Now, after months of briefings and hours of testimony in House and Senate committees, they are closing in on an amended bill that will present their refined plan for holding young people, as well as adults in government, accountable for youth rehabilitation.
Whatever they may ultimately pass will be an update to the Juvenile Justice Reform Act, approved by Maryland lawmakers in 2022 to protect the rights of children and improve their chances at turning their lives around.
Currently, lawmakers are negotiating a "more prescriptive and clear" Child in Need of Supervision process, which would unfold in court and create a paper trail rather than being handled informally by the Juvenile Services department.
"We're trying to make sure that there's an actual more formalized, universal application of CINS across the state," Smith said.
Another change they are considering has to do with what happens when a young person fails to show up for two or more rehabilitation treatment appointments.
"You can have probation extended if you miss treatment," Smith said, "but you cannot be incarcerated."
In addition, he said, public defenders pointed out that many young people under 13 aren't competent to stand trial, and they aren't getting rehabilitation services during the time when they are working to gain that competency.
"There are no services provided while that process is happening," he said. "And this whole thing is about getting kids and families services and supports."
The lawmakers have also been looking at data in their deliberations, especially about which crimes have spiked among young offenders, Smith said. That data is guiding decisions about expanded jurisdiction and other matters.
In addition to data, hearings in February brought emotional testimony into the spotlight.
Some lawmakers questioned whether the January proposal went too far to reverse the reform measures — and whether it was overly influenced by media accounts and public perception that youth crime is out of control.
"During the hearing, I kept asking, where's the data?" said Sen. Charles Sydnor (D-Baltimore County). "At times, we've allowed the media to drive our policy, and we're supposed to be data-driven. So show me the data."
Children under 13 accounted for less than 3.5% of all Juvenile Services intakes during the latest fiscal year for offenses the January proposal wanted to add, including deadly weapon, handgun, motor vehicle theft and misdemeanor sex offenses. That's down from 6.5% the year before reforms went into effect, according to a racial equity impact note released Tuesday by the Department of Legislative Services.
"Everyone agrees that auto thefts are up for adults and juveniles," said Sen. Jill Carter (D-Baltimore City). "But the issue is that kids 12 and under doing it is miniscule."
Amid assertions that the bill would worsen racial inequality in Maryland's juvenile justice system, some witnesses speaking in support of the January bill have pointed out that youth crime also victimizes communities of color.
Baltimore Deputy District Public Defender Alycia Capozello said in one recent hearing that the original proposal would disproportionately punish "little boys of color who historically have been adultified."
Gordon Pack, who spent almost 43 years in prison after being tried as an adult when he was 15, said he thinks lawmakers should build up the state's offerings of rehabilitative services and treatments before putting more kids into formal involvement with the juvenile justice system.
"All they're trying to do is equip law enforcement with another tool to address things, and they want to think that law enforcement will take the best tool in that situation," Pack said. "And this is how we're supposed to think. If you're a legislator, you're supposed to think like that."
Still, Pack said he thought lawmakers were moving too fast with the initial version of the bill.
"I think," he said, "they've got to be cautious."

title: CPR training for 911 calls could expand statewide
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content:
CPR training for 911 calls could expand statewide

 February 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 367
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Tony Rose, the chief of 911 for Charles County, was given unanimous permission from the Charles County commissioners on Feb. 28 to go to Annapolis and testify on behalf of House Bill 1092.House Bill 1092 would require the Maryland 911 Board to establish training standards for public safety answering point personnel concerning telecommunications CPR and alter the purposes of the 911 Trust Fund to include funding the costs of certain telecommunications CPR training.
"When an out-of-hospital cardiac emergency occurs, you have about 600 seconds —10 minutes — to make a difference to save a life before irreversible brain death occurs," Rose said.
In 2019, Rose learned of a new program to help change the way education is delivered to 911 call center operators.
Rose jumped on the opportunity and immediately brought in a specialist to evaluate current telecommunications personnel.
"It was all over the board," Rose said referring to answers about the last time 911 operators had given over-the-phone CPR. "Some had it done it yesterday, some had never done it."
The new program requires a virtual training scenario every three months, according to Rose. During the training, operators are subject to challenging scenarios to help provide CPR instructions more proficiently.
"The results have been phenomenal," Rose said. "We have doubled, and in some cases tripled, the number of survivors of out-of-hospital cardiac arrest in Charles County. They're walking out of a hospital after they've stopped breathing."
"We also reported that we had improved the application of bystander CPR from 27% to 43%, improved bystander application of an AED from 23.5% to 28.6% and saw the number of survivors that were discharged from the hospital increase from five to eleven," a written testimony Rose provided to the board said.
"It reminds me of an incident when I used to coach soccer," Commissioner Ralph E. Patterson II (D) said. "We had a cardiac arrest incident."
Patterson recalled how the operator he talked to was calm and helped guide those present through the situation, underscoring the importance of legislation like House Bill 1092.
"Currently, Charles County is the only jurisdiction that participates in this program," Rose said. "This bill would make it mandatory for 911 centers to provide, not necessarily this particular program, but one similar to it."

Cornish's family described Cornish as a kind, shy, loving, but, most importantly, a protective young man to the people around him and the animals he loved.
