title: Demands for safety, security: Cambridge's Bradford House management keeps changing but problems persist
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Demands for safety, security: Cambridge's Bradford House management keeps changing but problems persist

 May 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 2336
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — When Linda Johnson moved to the Bradford House Apartments in May 2000, things were different."It was lovely," she said. "I mean, it was respectful. Everybody was mindful."
But as the years went by, Johnson said she started to notice a change. Work orders wouldn't get filled. In 2020, Johnson and other residents organized a protest in front of the building.
"Bradford House matters," she remembers chanting. "We were all out front. The horns were honking."
At that time, Preservation Management was managing the apartment complex.
Four years later, problems have bubbled to the surface again.
"Same thing, new name," Johnson said. "Millennia."
Millennia Housing Management, a Cleveland-based company with properties across the nation, manages the 122-unit building located at 701 Race St.
The company is in the process of selling the majority of its affordable multifamily housing properties, which Millennia said will likely include Bradford House.
Bradford House offers multifamily, subsidized housing for low-income individuals who are elderly or have special needs, according to the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, which oversees management of the building.
The four-floor apartment building has only one of its two elevators working. Other problems on the property, listed in a September HUD inspection report, include inoperable call-for-aid systems for residents to reach help in an emergency and insect or cockroach infestations in some units.
In December, Shore Legal Access, an Easton-based group that provides free and reduced-fee access to legal services, discovered that Millennia filed lawsuits against multiple tenants for failure to pay rent.
Shore Legal Access Executive Director Meredith Girard said there are residents who didn't pay rent because Millennia wasn't providing appropriate property conditions.
Shore Legal Access has been representing the tenants involved in the lawsuits and working with tenants to get apartment conditions improved.
In an April statement to the Star Democrat, Millennia said, "The management team had worked with these residents to address their outstanding balances, but rent had not been paid in more than two years."
Recently, these cases were dismissed in court. But Girard said there are still 13 active rent escrow cases, where tenants pay their rent to a court, rather than to their landlord, until property issues are addressed.
"Now Millennia has to report back to the court each time they get called for a hearing to update the court on what progress they've made," Girard said.
TENANT ASSOCIATION
Frustrated, fed up and worried about their health and safety, a small group of Bradford House residents is taking matters into their own hands.
"At the end of the day, as tenants, we have rights," Johnson said at a meeting in the community room of Bradford House the morning of Feb. 8.
The small group — five residents on Feb. 8, with some more in attendance at a Feb. 22 meeting — has formed a tenant association with some guidance from Shore Legal Access.
Girard said in a late April interview that the association has sent a letter to Millennia and HUD with a list of building issues they would like addressed.
Tenants' concerns range from appliances in apartments not working properly to safety issues, like non-residents getting into the building.
Resident Lesley Stull, who has lived at the Bradford House for about three years, said she has had the same problem since she moved in: she is unable to take a hot bath in her apartment.
Since moving to Bradford House, she has been unable to get more than drips of hot water to come out of the faucet for a bath.
"By the time the tub gets filled up, the hot water's cold," she said. "It comes out (in) a trickle."
Although the shower works better, Stull said the hot water pressure still isn't great.
Stull said she has talked with every Bradford House property manager and maintenance person since moving into the apartment complex. They always tell her the parts are on order, she said.
"I think what happens is we keep going through maintenance men and management that I get lost somewhere," she said.
When the Star Democrat visited some residents' homes in late February, residents pointed out things like possible mold and problems with their stoves.
Resident Delores Diaz showed a hole in the ceiling above her shower, along with water damage in her bathroom. She said nothing has fallen on her ... yet.
"I'm waiting on it," she said.
IN VIOLATION
Sept. 12, the Bradford House property received a HUD inspection score of 30c*, indicating health and safety deficiencies and other problems identified with building systems, the building's exterior and individual apartments. The highest score a building could receive for an inspection is 100a.
The asterisk in the score indicates that health and safety deficiencies with smoke detectors were observed. The "c" in the score indicates that there are one or more exigent or fire safety deficiencies observed. It is the lowest letter that a building can receive on the scoring rubric.
The September report, which broke down what and where deficiencies on the property were, includes points taken off for damaged locks; mold, mildew, water stains or water damage; an inoperable elevator; inoperable call-for-aid systems; leaking faucets and pipes; electrical hazards, such as exposed wires, and more.
In its April statement, Millennia said it has completed more than 200 work orders at Bradford House since the last HUD inspection, and it is confident that will result in an improved score on the next inspection.
A total of 68 health and safety deficiencies were observed during the September HUD inspection. According to the report, if all Bradford House units had been inspected, HUD estimates it would have found 345 health and safety deficiencies on the property.
HUD has not responded to a February Freedom of Information Act request from the Star Democrat for the most recent physical inspection summary report for Bradford House, which may include a more recent report with a new score.
In its statement, Millennia said it has invested more than $300,000 into the maintenance and enhancement of the "severely distressed" property since taking over in 2022. The statement says the property had been neglected by previous management.
Millennia said that since taking over, it has addressed or is in the process of repairing "uninhabitable units," the roof, elevators, generator, nurse call stations and key fob system.
Millennia said it has made investments that include new air conditioning units, new appliances, fire and sprinkler repairs, plumbing repairs, painting and landscaping. It said the management team is conducting daily building inspections and quarterly unit inspections.
Cambridge Assistant City Manager Brandon Hesson said code enforcement is a priority for him and the city. He said the city has taken a collaborative approach in the last year and a half in an effort to get these problems at Bradford House resolved.
Cambridge Code Enforcement is on site at Bradford House at least once a week, Hesson said. He said he speaks with Millennia's attorneys roughly once a month about specific, more serious concerns. He speaks with HUD every two weeks or so about Bradford House.
"These are super unique issues, and they're going to require super unique solutions," he said. "We're not done, but we've gotten to something that appears to be producing results."
Hesson said that every Friday, Millennia gives the city updates on the 40 or 50 things that it has fixed that week.
"I don't want to paint them to be saints," Hesson said about Millennia. "But I do feel there's a lot more effort now than there really ever has been."
FEELING SAFE AT HOME
Along with concerns with the building itself, residents have concerns related to non-residents coming into the building.
In March, resident Tena Cheaton said there was a need for better, more consistent security at Bradford House.
"People come in here acting like they run this place that don't even live here," Cheaton said.
Until a few weeks ago, Bradford House only had a building attendant. Now, they have security, a company called Public Security LLC, which is based in Chester.
Johnson is hopeful this will address the security and safety issues that Bradford House residents have been experiencing.
Between Aug. 1, 2021, and Feb. 21, 2024, the Cambridge Police Department received 1,099 calls for service to Bradford House, according to a calls for service report requested by the Star Democrat.
Of the 1,099 calls, 93 were for trespassing, 57 were for thefts, 43 were for assaults and 19 were for drug complaints. The top three categories of calls for service were non-criminal miscellaneous reports, welfare checks and trespassing reports.
Police Chief Justin Todd said Cambridge Police considers Bradford House a high-crime area. He said that last year alone, the number of calls for service to Bradford House averaged more than two calls per day.
"Which creates a problem for the community and the neighborhoods (and) businesses that surround the Bradford House," he said.
Todd said apartment management should be responsible for what happens on their property and should make sure that all safety precautions are taken for tenants. He is hopeful about the new addition of security.
Todd said police have made efforts to reduce crime at Bradford House. He said the department is using community policing to try to build communication and help prevent crime.
The department has assigned two officers to make regular contact with Bradford House management. Todd said these efforts have increased communication, including with tenants.
The list of security concerns voiced by tenants is long.
Cheaton said she has been held at knifepoint, threatened and assaulted on Bradford House property. The instances led Cheaton to move out for about a month to live with her daughter.
"Nothing was being done," she said.
Cheaton isn't the only resident who has security concerns. When there was just a building attendant, resident Dinah Hunt said the attendant would only come for a little while and then leave.
"It's 6 o'clock, I'm looking for him, … but he was nowhere to be (found)," she said.
In a statement, Millennia said the property's night attendant patrols the halls and checks visitors in and out.
Girard from Shore Legal Access said there was a time when the front door had no lock on it, allowing easy access into the building. She said Millennia has fixed that.
"So that is one step in the right direction," she said. "However, there are many other ways for people to get inside the building."
She said people who don't live in the building have easy access and are using the common areas and open areas in the hallways "as a bathroom." Todd mentioned instances of prostitution and people sleeping in the stairwells.
Girard pointed out that in the HUD inspection report, there are multiple units that have doors with damaged hardware or locks. According to the report, this includes entry doors to apartments that don't latch or can't be locked.
In its April statement, Millennia said that "despite repeated damage to the doors by residents and visitors, the building doors are working." It said the company has spent more than $12,000 on door repairs in the last six months.
Millennia said the management team works to provide residents with a safe and secure environment. The statement said the property manager and staff have a relationship with the Cambridge Police, and security camera footage is shared with law enforcement when a crime occurs. It said the property management team sends violations to anyone residing at the property that is the cause of an assault or theft.
MORE THAN MILLENNIA
In December, Millennia was barred by HUD from participating in any new business with HUD for five years.
In a statement to the Star Democrat, Ethan Handelman, HUD deputy assistant secretary for multifamily housing programs, said the action doesn't affect Millennia's existing properties or contracts with HUD, and he said that HUD is "pursuing separate enforcement actions and will take further action as appropriate and necessary."
Handelman said the department expects Millennia to continue to perform any needed repairs or maintenance at its properties, and HUD will continue to monitor Millennia properties. He did not say why the debarment had been issued.
According to a February Vice article, which details the dangerous conditions that Millennia tenants have faced, Bradford House is not the only Millennia-managed apartment where tenants have had concerns. The article mentions incidents in Mississippi, Arkansas, Georgia and other states.
In statements to the Star Democrat, Millennia said that in January 2023, the company decided to sell the majority of its affordable multifamily housing properties. This will likely include Bradford House, it said.
"The Millennia Companies is thankful for its decades of partnership with HUD and looks forward to facilitating a smooth transition in partnership with HUD and the future buyer," Millennia said. "While The Millennia Companies is in the process of addressing all issues raised by HUD, the company will satisfy all obligations and issues with the completion of the sale."
According to its website, Millennia owns and operates more than 280 apartment developments in 26 states.
Girard has concerns about what this news will mean for Bradford House and its residents. She said it's unclear to her how much Millennia will invest in Bradford House and whether they will fix the problems.
"It really creates a lot of uncertainty for the tenants and for the community about what's going to happen to this building," she said.
MAKING CHANGE HAPPEN
Johnson said that Bradford House residents just want to live in a clean environment where management does what it's supposed to.
"(We) need real management," she said.
In February, Stull said the formation of the tenant association made her more hopeful that Bradford House will change for the better, but she said it's hard for her to look on the bright side of things.
"If something gets done, it'll be great," she said.
Multiple residents, including Stull, Cheaton and Johnson are considering moving.
And although Johnson is looking to move out of Bradford House, she doesn't see the move closing that chapter in her life.
"Even when I do move, I'm still coming back and helping them," she said about her neighbors. "I am not going to leave them hanging. I will come back every day."
Johnson has been instrumental in getting residents together to start a tenant association for Bradford House residents. She sees herself as a leader in the building.
"A lot of people don't like to speak up," she said. "But somebody's got to give them a voice. And you know me, I'm their voice."

title: Diving into National Water Safety Month
author: CAROLINE COUNTY HEALTH DEPARTMENT
content:
Diving into National Water Safety Month

 May 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: CAROLINE COUNTY HEALTH DEPARTMENT | Section: Life 
 
 506
 Words 

 Read News Document

 May is not just about blooming flowers and warmer weather; it's also National Water Safety Month, a crucial time to raise awareness about the importance of water safety, particularly for children.As families gear up for pool parties, beach vacations and lazy days on the river, it's essential for parents to prioritize safety to ensure that every aquatic adventure remains a fun experience.
Supervision is Key
First and foremost, maintaining constant supervision is paramount when children are around water. Whether it's a backyard pool, a nearby river or the ocean, a watchful eye can make all the difference.
Take turns designating a specific adult in your family or group as the assigned water watcher, and ensure they are not distracted by phones or other activities. Being present and attentive can be the most effective preventive measure against potential accidents.
Swim Lessons
Enrolling children in swim lessons early on is an investment in their safety and confidence around water.
Professional instructors can teach essential water skills, instill proper techniques and build a foundation for a lifetime of safe swimming. Caroline County Recreation and Parks, the YMCA and private swim instruction companies in the region offer classes suitable for different age groups, making it convenient for parents to get their kids started on this crucial life skill. Scholarships may also be available to help make lessons affordable for all families.
Know Your Limits
Understanding the swimming abilities of your children is crucial when selecting water environments. Whether it's a calm neighborhood pool or a more dynamic beach setting, choose locations that match the swimming proficiency of your kids.
Inexperienced swimmers may benefit more from controlled environments with lifeguards and clear safety guidelines.
Water Safety Gear
Equip your children with appropriate safety gear. For non-swimmers or those still building their skills, life jackets and floatation devices are essential.
Ensure that the gear fits properly and is Coast Guard-approved. These tools not only provide an added layer of protection but also boost confidence, allowing kids to enjoy the water with a sense of security.
Establish and Enforce Pool Rules
If you have a pool at home or if your children visit family or friends with pools, establish and enforce a set of safety rules.
Make sure your children understand the importance of following these rules, such as no running around the pool, no diving in shallow water and always entering the water feet first. Consistent reinforcement of these guidelines will create a safe and responsible pool environment.
Emergency Preparedness
Lastly, be prepared for emergencies. Ensure that you and your children know basic water rescue skills, CPR and how to call for help in case of an emergency. Quick response time is often crucial in water-related incidents, and having the knowledge and ability to act promptly can be lifesaving.
In conclusion, as we celebrate National Water Safety Month, let's pledge to keep our families safe, happy and splashing responsibly.
By prioritizing supervision, investing in swim lessons, choosing appropriate environments, using safety gear, establishing and enforcing pool rules and being prepared for emergencies, parents can ensure that their kids develop a love for water activities while staying safe in the process.

title: Commissioners approve extended MOU with sheriff's office for Ridgely policing
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Commissioners approve extended MOU with sheriff's office for Ridgely policing

 May 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Life 
 
 655
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Building on a temporary agreement forged in the weeks following the March suspension of Ridgely's entire police force, the Town of Ridgely and the Caroline County Sheriff's Office have agreed to a more permanent plan for ensuring law enforcement coverage in the town.At their May 6 meeting, the Ridgely commissioners approved a memorandum of understanding for fiscal year 2025 that will ensure the sheriff's office provides law enforcement services to Ridgely in the absence of the Ridgely Police Department.
This is a longer term arrangement than originally conceived.
On March 13, the commissioners of Ridgely suspended the entire Ridgely police department with pay, effective immediately, pending an investigation by the Office of the Maryland State Prosecutor. No reason for the investigation has been indicated publicly.
"To guarantee uninterrupted public safety services, the Commissioners initiated a temporary agreement with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office," said Ridgely in a press release. "Now, building upon this temporary arrangement, Ridgely and the Caroline County Sheriff's Office have established a long-term partnership through an updated Memorandum of Understanding (MOU). This MOU will provide the Town of Ridgely with complete law enforcement coverage, by the Caroline County Sheriff's Office, for the fiscal year 2025, with the option to renew service annually. This agreement includes a provision for maintaining 480 hours of coverage per month."
According to the first amendment to agreement for law enforcement services, a document between the town of Ridgely, the Caroline County Commissioners and Caroline County Sheriff Donald L. Baker, the estimated annual cost of this service is $474,971.44.
According to two versions of the town's proposed FY2025 budget, one with the town's police department and the other with the sheriff's office providing policing, posted to the town website Tuesday, the MOU with the sheriff's office cheaper the cost of maintaining a town police force.
"This partnership underscores our shared commitment to safety and community well-being," Baker said in the press release. "By working closely with the Ridgely community, we aim to build trust and ensure seamless law enforcement services to all residents. The updated MOU will take effect July 1, 2024, with the current MOU remaining in effect until then."
This matter was also addressed during the May 7 Caroline County Commissioners meeting.
"At this point in time, I plan on signing it if the County Commissioners sign it, and the (Ridgely) commissioners signed it last night," Baker said about the agreement at that meeting. "Frank Bartz was there. There was a lot of heated discussion, but that is to be expected. I look forward to the continued efforts by the county, the town and the sheriff's office. So I think that only good things are on the horizon."
Many Ridgely residents, like Lakia Harris-Pierce, who went to the meeting, are concerned about what they feel is a lack of transparency. Harris-Pierce said she is still wondering who gave the orders to suspend the police force in the first place.
Commissioner Larry Porter said, "I know there has been a lot of social media discussion about this, but basically this is going to provide 120 hours per week."
Then he asked the sheriff, "Just for clarification, how much coverage was the Ridgely Police Department providing when they were there?"
Baker said originally they were supposed to cover the town 140 hours a week. Vacancies and sickness kept them from reaching that number. The sheriff's office will cover the town as much as the police department had under the new agreement.
"Just so everybody knows, the sheriff's department is constitutionally obligated to handle and provide law enforcement services in Caroline County," Baker said. "Even if we back up the towns of Federalsburg, Greensboro or Denton, who have their own police departments… we are obligated to go in there… I do that in cooperation with the commissioners and your staff."
Baker said he takes the responsibility seriously and that he wants to give the citizens of Ridgely some peace of mind.
The county commissioners' motion unanimously passed to approve the MOU.

title: Bradford House resident wants to feel safe at home after multiple assaults
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Bradford House resident wants to feel safe at home after multiple assaults

 May 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 581
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Tena Cheaton looked forward to moving into the Bradford House Apartments about five years ago.At that time, Cheaton, now 59, was homeless.
She was receiving temporary disability assistance and waiting to be approved for supplemental security income, which is financial assistance for people who have little or no income and resources and have a disability, blindness or are 65 years of age or older.
"So I wanted to come," she said about Bradford House. "I didn't realize it was this bad."
Since moving in, Cheaton — who has PTSD, ADHD, bipolar disorder, fibromyalgia and back problems that include degenerative disc disease and spinal stenosis — said she has been assaulted, threatened and had her belongings stolen on the property.
Cheaton said that about two years ago, she was raped by a man who was staying with another tenant at Bradford House.
Cheaton said it happened in her apartment. She knew the man. He drugged her before raping her, she said.
After a few weeks of "throwing up constantly" and "crying uncontrollably," Cheaton went to rehab to get treatment.
She said it was her therapist that told her she didn't have to face her assaulter in the Bradford House halls everyday, and there were resources that could keep him out of the building.
Although Cheaton said she didn't call the police after she was raped, she did get restraining order against her rapist later on.
But despite the restraining order, Cheaton said she would still see her rapist in the halls at Bradford House.
Under the Violence Against Women Act, a housing provider may evict or terminate the assistance of a perpetrator of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault or stalking, according to the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development's Notice of Occupancy Rights under the Violence Against Women Act.
According to the notice, those who have experienced domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault or stalking must have the option to stay in their subsidized housing and can request an emergency transfer from the housing provider for safety reasons.
In a statement to the Star Democrat, Millennia Housing Management — which manages Bradford House — said the Bradford House property management team sends violations to anyone residing at the property that is the cause of an assault or theft.
Cheaton said she is not the only tenant that has been raped in the building. And this is not the only time Cheaton said she has been put in danger at Bradford House. She said she has also been held at knifepoint, threatened and assaulted on the property.
In one instance, Cheaton remembers taking her dog outside a few hours after midnight.
"I had just shut that door," she said. "And somebody standing way down there at the end of the building was hollering at me."
Cheaton, who said she doesn't leave the door to the building open for anyone, said the person was telling her to leave the door open.
She said the man got in her face and threatened to shoot her. By the time police arrived, he was gone, Cheaton said.
According to a Cambridge Police Department calls for service report requested by the Star Democrat, of the 1,099 calls for service to Bradford House made between Aug. 1, 2021, and Feb. 21, 2024, 18 were for reports of threats.
After being threatened outside the building, Cheaton — who has had experiences with substance abuse — said she moved out of Bradford House for about a month to live with her daughter.
"To stay sober in a building like this is very, very difficult," she said.

title: Grasonville Vol. Fire Department breaks ground on new station
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Grasonville Vol. Fire Department breaks ground on new station

 May 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 420
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GRASONVILLE — An overcast day did nothing to diminish future possibilities and endeavors as Grasonville Volunteer Fire Department celebrated the groundbreaking of its new firehouse May 10.Grasonville's first firehouse was chartered in 1960 and welcomed new additions in 1970 to suit department expansions, President Matt Coursey said.
"Now here we stand together on the same date exactly 54 years later, once again about to break ground on the new firehouse that will further our ability to keep up with modern standards and needs of our rapidly growing department," he said.
Fundraising efforts have been underway for over 10 years, he noted, and the department's building committee has spent countless hours discussing and designing the perfect facility to continuously serve the community.
The state-of-the-art facility will include all necessary accommodations for volunteers including bunk rooms, a kitchen and a housing bay for the department's apparatus.
Fire Chief Jason Anthony expressed immense gratitude to the community, whose staunch support and donations helped bring the project to fruition.
Over 50 years operating out of the same firehouse has left the facility "busting at the seams," according to Anthony, with increases in department membership, larger fire vehicles and updated equipment.
"Where we're at today is a proud moment for our fire department," he said.
The Grasonville all volunteer department currently operates out of three buildings and the new facility will be able to seamlessly transfer operations to one location and set future members up for success, Anthony said.
The project cost is estimated at $5.6 million and construction is estimated to take one year.
Future plans include eventually housing a Queen Anne's County medic unit in the old emergency medical services (EMS) building, Anthony said.
Queen Anne's County Commissioner Phil Dumenil recognized the tremendous efforts and dedications of volunteer departments who ensure community protection without the need for paid career service departments.
"I shudder to think the costs to make that work," he said.
Bob Breeding General Contractors has felt right at home taking on the design, build and contract work for community fire department facilities, according to Manager Andrew Breeding.
"Being a family owned and operated company, I believe this makes us a well suited match for a volunteer fire department whose members are like a big family," he said.
A moment of silence recognized the passing of Tom Davis, of DMS and Associates who completed site work for the project.
The department will continue operations from the building behind the old firehouse while the new one is constructed. Grasonville Volunteer Fire Department is located at 4128 Main Street and more information can be found at: https://gvfd2.com.

title: Police Unity Tour peddles through Denton
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Police Unity Tour peddles through Denton

 May 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 491
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — On May 11, a river of blue-shirted cyclists flowed down Market Street.All of these police officers on bicycles stopped at the Chesapeake Culinary Center for lunch on their Police Unity Tour, which starts in Portsmouth, Virginia, and ends in Washington, D.C.
The Police Unity Tour is a bicycle ride that raises awareness about officers who have died in the line of duty. The event raises money for the National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial. Their motto is "We ride for those who died."
Anyone on any level of law enforcement can make the ride. Although Denton is a nice spot in the middle of their ride, there were no law enforcement officers from Caroline County in the ride.
"The Denton Fire Chief and Town Manager have all been great to us, opening doors. The vo-tech kids cooked lunch for us. The Culinary Center fed us," said Marlboro, New Jersey, Police Department Lt. Nicholas Szymanski.
"In 16 years, we have ridden through Denton every year. We had 650 on bicycles and another 150 or so on support. We started in Lewes, Delaware, and stopped just short of the bridge in Kent Island," Szymanski said.
These men and women have lots of visible support, not just from massive American flags hoisted between two fire truck ladders, but mini flag waving children who offer high fives along the way.
"We have chapter trucks and trailers that bring Gatorade, waters, snacks. We have a full mechanic's truck, ambulances and motor units. Believe it or not, we had the commissioner of Highway Patrol in California ride with us this year. We had about 50 motorcycles in our group alone. They will stop intersections for us. Once we start pedaling we don't stop," Szymanski said.
Their efforts have raised a lot of money over the years.
"Our chapter had 440 riders, and we raised over $400,000. We raised over $2 million overall. It is for fallen police officers. Our responsibility it to make sure that the names of the former police officers aren't forgotten," Szymanski said.
All the money goes to the National Law Enforcement Museum and the National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial.
"All the names of the fallen officers are enshrined on (the memorial). There are 25,000 names on there at least. We did an expansion last year for more stones to have room for more names. We add five or 10 names to that wall every year," Szymanski said.
The names are important. But supporting the families who have lost loved ones is essential, he said.
"The most important of it — the reason we do this is we bring survivors along with us. That is somebody's family member that was killed in the line of duty. We have their wives, their kids, their family members, fathers, mothers ride with us. We had 50 survivors ride with us this year," he said.
What started with 18 riders in 1997 has grown exponentially. Since then, the Unity Tour has raised $35 million.
To learn more, go to policeunitytourchapterten.com

title: Federalsburg man arrested after fleeing police
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Federalsburg man arrested after fleeing police

 May 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 267
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A Federalsburg man who was wanted by Cambridge Police for attempted murder and assault was arrested Wednesday after fleeing Talbot County Sheriff's deputies.Adrian Jerrod Jenkins, 29, was charged with possession of a controlled substance, intent to distribute heroin/fentanyl, fleeing and eluding, driving without a license and other traffic violations, according to a news release from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office.
The release said Jenkins was driving east on Ocean Gateway in the Trappe area when deputies attempted to stop him for moving violations. Police said deputies also determined Jenkins' vehicle registration was suspended.
According to the news release, Jenkins accelerated in an attempt to elude deputies. He traveled into Dorchester County, where the Talbot deputies were joined in the pursuit by Dorchester County Sheriff's Office deputies.
In Cambridge, Jenkins lost control of his vehicle, hitting a retaining wall and disabling his vehicle on Academy Street near Cedar Street, police said.
Police said upon taking Jenkins into custody, they discovered through a records check that he was wanted for attempted murder and assault stemming from charges in September of 2023. At the time of those charges, Jenkins was on probation for a second degree assault conviction in 2022.
Jenkins was taken to the Talbot County Central Booking Center. Police said he was held pending further court action.

 EASTON — A Cambridge man pled guilty Monday to first-degree murder for the Sept. 30 shooting death of 23-year-old Antonio Smith.Smith died from a gunshot wound to the head following an incident in the parking lot of Sidetracked Saloon in Easton.
Kevron Chase, 35, was charged with first- and second-degree murder, first- and second-degree assault, reckless endangerment, using a firearm in a felony crime and illegal possession of a regulated firearm. On Monday, he pled guilty to the count of first-degree murder.
At the plea hearing Monday, Talbot County State's Attorney Joseph Coale said that on the night of the shooting, Chase arrived at the Easton bar around 12 a.m. with friends, and Smith arrived around 1 a.m.
Coale said that Smith, who did not have a weapon, approached Chase outside the bar, and Chase pointed a handgun at Smith's face.
Coale said this led to a fist fight between the two. He said that during the fist fight, Chadnee Harris, 33, of Hurlock — who faces charges of acting as an accessory after the fact of first- and second-degree murder and acting as an accessory after a felony for the same incident — was in possession of the handgun.
Coale said Chase then took the handgun back from Harris and fired a shot into the air before pistol-whipping Smith several times. At around 1:52 a.m., Chase walked toward Smith in the parking lot and fired a shot, striking Smith in the left side of the head, Coale said.
Coale said Chase then left the scene and drove to Cambridge, where he disposed of the handgun in the Choptank River.
Chase's attorney Kisha Petticolas, who is with the Talbot County Public Defender's Office, said Chase did not know Smith would be at the bar and believed Smith didn't know Chase would be at the bar. She said that Smith was aggressive in his initial approach to Chase, and the two had a history. Petticolas said Chase had a reason to be fearful of Smith.
According to charging documents, in interviews with Cambridge police, Chase told officers that the physical fight began over Smith trying to rob him several months before.
Petticolas also said Chase heard Smith say "Give me the gun."
Coale said the State's Attorney's Office would be sticking to its facts and objected to the additions Petticolas mentioned.
Judge Charles C. Deeley, Jr. said he was satisfied with what was said and found Chase guilty of first-degree murder. He did not hand down a sentence.
Deeley said the reason he did not want to hand down a sentence at the hearing was because he wanted to see a pre-sentence investigation report first. Deeley, who had not presided on the case until the plea hearing, said it would be best for him to have more information before handing down a sentence.
A sentencing hearing has yet to be scheduled. The state is recommending that Chase be served a life sentence with 55 years in prison followed by 5 years of probation, with the remainder of the life sentence suspended.
Harris' trial is set to begin Friday.

title: Midwest bracing for more severe weather
author: Staff Writer
content:
Midwest bracing for more severe weather

 May 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: National 
 
 457
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OKLAHOMA CITY — Forecasters are warning of another day of heightened risk of dangerous tornadoes in the Midwest on Saturday and telling people in south Texas they may experience triple-digit temperatures — and that's with four weeks to go before summer starts.The weather service in Oklahoma compared the day to "a gasoline-soaked brush pile." Forecasters aren't certain storms will form, but any that do could explode with large hail, dangerous winds and tornadoes.
"There's a small chance most of the matches are duds and we only see a few storms today. Still, that's not a match I would want to play with. It only takes one storm to be impactful," the National Weather Service in Norman, Oklahoma, wrote on Facebook.
Excessive heat, especially for May, is the danger in south Texas, where the heat index is forecast to approach near 120 degrees F (49 degrees C) during the weekend. The region is on the north end of a heat dome that stretches from Mexico to South America, National Weather Service meteorologist Zack Taylor said.
Sunday looks like the hottest day with record-setting highs for late May forecast for Austin, Brownsville, Dallas and San Antonio, Taylor said.
The temperature was approaching 90 degrees F (32 degrees) and the heat index was 104 F (40 C) in Brownsville on the U.S./Mexico border by midmorning Saturday, according to the National Weather Service.
Red Flag fire warnings are also in place in west Texas, all of New Mexico and parts of Oklahoma, Arizona and Colorado, where very low humidity of below 10%, wind gusts of up to 60 mph (97 kph) combine with the hot temperatures.
"We've got very dry air, warm temperatures and strong winds creating a high fire danger over a wide area ... that can lead to rapidly spreading or uncontrollable fires," Taylor said.
Meanwhile, several inches of snow fell Friday into early Saturday in Rolla, North Dakota, about 10 miles (16 kilometers) from the Canadian border.
April and May have been a busy month for tornadoes, especially in the Midwest. Climate change is heightening the severity of storms around the world.
April had the country's second-highest number of tornadoes on record. And in 2024, the U.S. is already 25% ahead of the average number of twisters, according to the Storm Prediction Center in Norman, Oklahoma.
Iowa has been the hardest hit so far this week. A deadly twister devastated Greenfield. And other storms brought flooding and wind damage elsewhere in the state.
The storm system causing the severe weather is expected to move east as the Memorial Day weekend continues, bringing rain that could delay the Indianapolis 500 auto race Sunday in Indiana and more severe storms in Illinois, Indiana, Missouri and Kentucky.
The risk of severe weather moves into North Carolina and Virginia on Monday, forecasters said.

title: Three graduate from Caroline County's Problem Solving Court
author: Tom McCall
content:
Three graduate from Caroline County's Problem Solving Court

 May 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News

 DENTON — In a celebratory event at the Circuit Court for Caroline County, Judge Heather Price presided over the May 10 graduation of three remarkable women.Through a yearlong Problem Solving Court program, they have taken a giant step forward to step out of the cycle of substance use disorder and incarceration.
"Being the problem solving court judge is sometimes a very difficult job, but it is also one of the most gratifying parts of the job. You will hear some success stories today," Price said.
The back row of the courtroom was packed with people supporting the graduates — Nichole Meredith, Samantha Mitchell and Carole Rawding. There were tearful testimonies to the power of this program. Love ones were showed the before and after pictures that marked the women's journey from the beginning of the program to the end.
Problem Solving Coordinator Michelle Bethke spoke to the journey these women have taken and she presented certificates and flowers.
Each graduate had a presenter. Meredith had lawyer Dana Boston, Mitchell had Whitely, and Rawding had Bethke.
There were lots of local dignitaries present, including Caroline County Commissioner Larry Porter, Sheriff Don Baker, Police Chief Geroge Bacorn and State's Attorney Sloan Franklin. Even Roger McKnight, MTU program administrator, was there.
From state to county to town, there was community supporting these women to break the cycle of addiction and incarceration.
"It is an achievement and we are sending our graduates back out into the world to do good things," Price said.
Price noted the rigor of the program. Collectively the three graduates had submitted 382 drug tests. They completed 313 treatments of either substance abuse disorder or mental health treatment. They had to complete 146.25 hours of community service.
Bethke went up to the podium and addressed the crowded court room.
"The Caroline County Problem Solving Court employs science-based best practices to provide a pathway to sobriety for participants with diagnosed substance use disorders utilizing a combination of therapy, counseling, mentoring, encouragement and discipline when necessary," Bethke said.
The program received a $200,000 grant from the Maryland Office of Problem Solving Courts through a sub grant of the Bureau of Justice Assistance, which helped provide the program's staffing.
A graduate from 2022's program, and keynote speaker at the May 10 graduation, is Whiteley.
"I am a recovering addict and alumni from the Problem Solving Court. The definition of recovery is the process of change for which individuals improve their health and wellness, live a self-directed life and strive," she said. "The mindset and thinking pattern I once had, I needed to give up in order to change. Today I am a strong worthy loving and lovable woman, mother and friend."
The next speaker was Meredith.
"My addiction had taken everything that I ever loved away from me. I lost custody of my kids. I lost the trust and respect of my family. When I looked into the mirror, I didn't even recognize the person staring back at me," Meredith said. "This program has saved my life. I have full custody of my kids now. My family and friends can depend on me."
The next to speak was Mitchell.
"Drug court has given me the resources I need when I need people," Mitchell said.
The final graduate, Rawding, was introduced by Bethke. Rawding was described as quiet and determined.
"I am just glad I accepted this program," Rawding said.

title: Community turns out 4th annual First Responders Celebration in Easton

Community turns out 4th annual First Responders Celebration in Easton

 Words

 EASTON — On Monday afternoon, community members and local and state leaders gathered under an American flag suspended between two fire trucks for the fourth annual First Responders Celebration in downtown Easton.People from the Eastern Shore held signs thanking the first responders for their work in the community.
Attendees gathered to listen to Edward Forte, a member of the Easton Volunteer Fire Department, express gratitude for the opportunity to serve for over 45 years.
"I'm proud to be a member of the first responders of this community," Forte said. "I did some research before today, and there's been over 81 first responders killed in the line of duty throughout the country … It's important to know that we all pray for each other as we go about doing our regular jobs and as we go about doing our volunteer jobs."
Forte introduced Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) to the crowd. Mautz thanked everyone for showing their support to the first responders in their area and congratulated local first responders for the work they did during the weekend, including an incident that happened Saturday night when a boat crashed, resulting in the injury of several people.
"This is a day to remember, reflect and celebrate our first responders," Mautz said. "You all are here in attendance. I want to salute you on behalf of your state delegation … You are on call 24/7. For us, you have served us. You should be saluted and remembered every day, and it's an honor to be able to do that today."
The keynote speaker, U.S. Sen. Ben Cardin (D-MD), began his speech by sharing his love for the region and the joy he experiences coming to the Eastern Shore.
Cardin said that as chair of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, he has been involved with what is going on around the world and the fight for the "preservation of democracy and democratic values." Though the fight abroad is important, everything starts with "protecting the rule of law," and that starts with public safety, he said.
"I've been there on Sept. 11 and saw what happened, as being in the capital when planes were in the air," Cardin said. "I saw what happened on Jan. 6, and our Capitol police officers keeping us safe. I know how important our first responders are through all circumstances. They literally put their life on the line by wearing the uniform. And we can never say thank you enough."
Cardin said people have to do more than show gratitude through words. He told the crowd that the federal delegation is "laser-focused" on getting first responders the help they need through firefighter assistance and Staffing for Adequate Fire and Emergency Response and burn assistant grants.
But most importantly, Cardin said, it is essential for members of the public to support first responders and the work they do every day.
"We're here today to express, collectively, this community's support for what you do every day," Cardin said. "It's not easy. We know what you have to go through today. Not only on getting the support you need through the budget process but the support you need through the community. And we tell you, we are with you every step of the way, doing everything we can to make sure you are kept safe so you can keep us safe."

Officers dispatched an ambulance crew, which drove Caparella to Upper Chesapeake Aberdeen for treatment to her wounded hand, police reported.
Caparella is charged with second-degree burglary, fourth-degree storehouse burglary and malicious destruction of property valued at less than $1,000, according to Cecil County District Court records.

'Why can’t they just let people rest in peace?': Dozens of headstones vandalized at Maryland cemetery

 A police investigation is continuing after a vandal or vandals damaged and displaced dozens of headstones at the North East Cemetery earlier this month.According to North East Police Department Chief Stephen Yates, approximately 57 headstones were pushed over June 6 and 7. Most of the headstones were tipped over; however, several were damaged, Yates said. Additionally, some of the commemorative vases placed alongside the headstones were crushed.
"Some people just don't have any respect for things," Yates remarked.
Deidre Taylor came from Charlestown to find the headstones of her siblings tipped over.
"I feel for the families who have lost more today," Taylor said. "I hope they figure out who did this."
Nicholas Grove was angry as he worked with other family members to repair the damage done to stones in their family plot.
"Why can't they just let people rest in peace?" Grove said as he worked to clean the top of the foundation and the bottom of the headstone on one gravesite in preparation for setting it aright. "This is disrespecting everybody."
Like so many others, Karen Haines saw a post of Facebook about the vandalism and came to North East Cemetery to see if her parent's gravestones had been included in the attack. It was.
"I was expecting it to be worse," Haines said. "I was expecting it to be in pieces."
Law enforcement officials reported that they are investigating a number of different leads. To avoid compromising the ongoing investigation, police officials declined to elaborate.
When bystanders asked what would happen if the vandals turn out to be minors, Yates explained that the ages of the vandals would determine the next steps.
Family members spent Friday afternoon cleaning up some of their loved ones' damaged and tipped-over headstones. Yates said the cemetery association has learned its insurance will cover the cost to reset and repair all the headstones.
Michael Kline Jr, whose father, Michael Kline Sr. is among the graves that were vandalized, is offering a reward for information leading to a conviction of the guilty.
"I'm offering a $1,000 cash reward," Kline said Friday. "But I do have a lot of people reaching out to contribute to it."
The investigation is ongoing and anyone with knowledge of the incident is encouraged to reach out to NEPD at 410-287-5996.

title: 'He snapped': Maryland teacher sentenced to probation for assaulting doorbell pranksters
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
'He snapped': Maryland teacher sentenced to probation for assaulting doorbell pranksters

 June 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 1555
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A Rising Sun High School teacher who has served as an educator for 30 years received a suspended six-month sentence and was placed on 15 months of supervised probation Wednesday, after pleading guilty to assaulting a 13-year-old boy after the child and a friend pranked him at his residence.The defendant, Dylan M. Aiman, 54, of Rising Sun, pleaded guilty to second-degree assault, a misdemeanor that is punishable by up to 10 years in prison. In exchange, prosecutors dismissed related charges of reckless endangerment and false imprisonment.
Cecil County District Court Administrative Judge Bonnie G. Schneider rejected a defense request to grant Aiman probation-before-judgement, commonly known as a PBJ — a verdict in which the presiding judge finds the defendant guilty and then sets aside the conviction, meaning the conviction will not appear on that person's record.
A PBJ reportedly would have been more favorable for Aiman when the Cecil County Public Schools administration decides on his future employment.
Assistant State's Attorney Joseph Verratti told the judge that he would not object to Aiman receiving a PBJ.
Aiman's defense lawyer, Thomas C. Morrow of Towson, told the judge that Aiman is on administrative leave, a status that school officials assigned Aiman shortly after a Rising Sun Police Department officer filed criminal charges against him in the wake of the early-May incident.
Joseph Buckley, who is the CCPS associate superintendent for administrative services, told the Cecil Whig on Thursday, "We are aware of the legal matter that's facing one of our employees and we're going to follow all of our human resources processes to access the situation to address the matter. We'll be working with the employee to address the matter. Other than that, at this point, we really have no further comment."
Buckley noted that CCPS officials are not at liberty to release specific information concerning personnel matters.
From the bench, Schneider opined Wednesday that a PBJ verdict would not be appropriate because, according to information provided by the prosecution, Aiman was convicted of failure to obey a peace order in 2012, some 12 years ago. (Aiman reportedly had been granted a PBJ in that 2012 case, which stemmed from a dispute with a neighbor, and he violated the peace order when he entered his neighbor's yard to retrieve as Nerf lawn dart that his son had shot onto that property.)
Electing to still accept the plea deal, knowing that the judge would not grant him a PBJ, Aiman pleaded guilty to second-degree assault. Then, after Verratti read aloud the statement of facts, Schneider found Aiman guilty of that offense and imposed a suspended six-month sentence on him. (Verratti had recommended a suspended one-year sentence, one year of supervised probation, an anger management class and no contact with the victims in the proffered plea agreement.)
In addition, the judge ordered Aiman to serve 15 months of supervised probation. Schneider acknowledged that Aiman already had successfully completed an anger management class since the incident occurred. The judge, however, ordered Aiman to take another anger management course if his probation officer deems that it is necessary.
The judge also ordered Aiman to have no contact with the two victims, one of whom turned 14 about three weeks after the incident.
Moments before sentencing, Aiman stood at the defense table, reflected on the incident and told the judge, "I clearly way overreacted."
His words echoed ones uttered moments earlier by Morrow, who reported that Aiman has an unblemished employment record during his 30 years as an educator, the last 24 of which in Cecil County, and that he is a RSHS biology teacher, one who teaches predominantly honors classes, in addition to that subject at other levels.
Morrow advocated for an outcome in the criminal case that might result in the "salvaging of his (Aiman's) career."
THE INCIDENT
Aiman chased the two boys in the early evening of May 4, which was a Saturday, after they rang the doorbell at his residence in the 200 block of Turtleneck Court and ran away — a prank known as "ding dong ditch."
After catching the teens across the street from his home, Aiman forced them back to his front porch, where he made the boys wait for police officers to respond after calling authorities and making a harassment complaint, according to court records.
RSPD Pfc. Cunningham and Patrolman Moore responded to the scene at 7:32 p.m., and Aiman told them that he "gripped one up," referring to one of the teens. Aiman maintained that he gave chase after the second time that the ding-dong-ditch prank had been pulled at his residence that evening.
In the courtroom Wednesday, the prosecutor reported that Aiman grabbed one of the boys by his sweatshirt, lifted him up by the garment and kneed him in the ribs. Verratti also reported that Aiman handled the situation in "an aggressive manner," which included him yelling at the boys.
Cunningham informed Aiman that "he could not put his hands on juveniles and that it does classify as an assault," according to court records.
"(Aiman) did not seem to understand, asking what he was supposed to do — let them run away. (Aiman) continually stated that he just held the kids on his front porch until the police arrived," court records show.
Aiman did not know the boys, who live in his neighborhood, according to the defense.
Investigators filed charges of second-degree assault, reckless endangerment and false imprisonment against Aiman on May 5, a day after the incident, and served him the criminal summons on May 6, court records show. He was released on personal recognizance.
'HE SNAPPED'
Morrow maintained that the incident was an aberration.
He reported that Aiman served as a soccer coach for RSHS boys and girls teams and as a coach for Cecil County Department of Parks and Recreation youth soccer teams, in addition to his 30-year career as a teacher, and that he received no official complaints.
The defense lawyer also told the judge that Aiman and his family have been the target of harassment in the Rising Sun community by unknown people for an unspecified long time, with encroachments including people hurling eggs at the Aiman house — which required professional cleaning — and cars and placing "anonymous threats in his mailbox.".
Aiman reported those incidents to police "multiple times" in the past, but nothing was done, Morrow said. Officers told Aiman that it would be difficult for law enforcement to take action unless he was able to identify the culprit or culprits, he added.
(Speculating on why Aiman was harassed, Morrow told the judge that Aiman is "a good teacher" who teaches biology at a high level, which can be difficult and frustrating for students. Aside from the two boys who admitted to playing the May 4 ding-dong-ditch prank at Aiman's home, however, no one has been identified as a perpetrator of the previous purported pranks and harassment directed at him and his family.)
Aiman caught the teens and held them on his porch until officers arrived because he wanted parents and authorities involved, according to Morrow.
"It was not his intent to injure anyone," Morrow said, stressing that Aiman told one of the boys, "I want you to call your father right now," after escorting the teens to his porch.
"His only intent was to get some kind of parental involvement to end this trend of harassment," Morrow said.
The defense lawyer also emphasized that Aiman is "facing potential dismissal and the loss of his teaching certificate" after 30 years as an educator.
Aiman's wife spoke on his behalf, telling the judge that her husband's action on May 4 was uncharacteristic. She blamed his response on the frustration and weariness of enduring pranks and various types of harassment over the years. She and Aiman have been married for 24 years.
She opined that a family's home should feel like "a safe place," one that provides "peace, a respite," before maintaining that the prolonged harassment had eroded her family's sense of tranquility and that the ding-dong-ditch prank on May 4 pushed her husband to his limit.
"He snapped. He had enough," Aiman's wife said.
She commented, "He's a great man, a loving father and a great husband . . . He's remorseful and sick about it (the incident)."
Aiman, who has six children, apologized to the two victims, their families, his own family, the school system and county parks and recreation moments before sentencing.
"I let all of them down, including myself," Aiman said. "I worked with kids to give them a positive experience in the classroom and on the soccer field."
He also alluded to the question hanging over his career in education, remarking, "Teaching is very important to me."
A LEVEL OF LEADERSHIP
The father of the boy whom Aiman picked up and kneed in the ribs told the judge that he was surprised when he learned that Aiman was a teacher.
"He's trained to deal with kids, to show a level of leadership. He should be someone to look up to," the father said. "It's concerning to me that this man is employed by the school."
The mother of the other boy also addressed the judge. She acknowledged that, although Aiman did not aggressively touch her son to the level that he did to her son's friend, the interaction with Aiman negatively impacted her son. She contended that Aiman yelled threateningly.
According to the woman, her son was afraid to walked into a store by himself one day after the incident. "I'm concerned how quickly he went into anger," she said of Aiman. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Two plead guilty in Eastern Shore Hospital Center shooting and escape
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Two plead guilty in Eastern Shore Hospital Center shooting and escape

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Crime 
 
 585
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Two men have pleaded guilty to charges related to an August 2023 escape from the Eastern Shore Hospital Center.Darrin Jeter, 20, of Rockville, was sentenced to 10 years in prison and five years of supervised probation for first-degree escape. With eight years of his prison sentence suspended, Jeter will have to serve two years in prison and will get credit for 310 days already served.
Israel Labastida Jr., 19, of Glen Burnie, pleaded guilty on Friday to one count of first-degree assault, use of a firearm during a felony or violent crime and first-degree conspiracy to escape. Maryland Circuit Court Judge Karen Dean granted Labastida's request to defer his sentencing approximately 90 days so that his family could be present.
At Labastida's hearing, Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard said the state is recommending Labastida be handed a sentence of a five-year mandatory minimum without parole, followed by five years of probation. Leonard said the state also recommends Labastida be required to stay away from the Eastern Shore Hospital Center and the facility's staff.
Charges against Jeter and Labastida stem from Jeter's August 2023 escape from the Eastern Shore Hospital Center, a psychiatric facility located on Woods Road in Cambridge. At that time, Jeter, who has schizophrenia, had been committed to the hospital center.
At both the Thursday hearing for Jeter and the Friday hearing for Labastida, Leonard said that Labastida approached the facility on Aug. 1 and shot into a window several times. She said Labastida and Jeter kicked out the broken window so that Jeter could exit the building, and the two fled the area in a black vehicle.
Jeter was located by the Montgomery County Sheriff's Office the following day and has remained in custody since.
During Jeter's plea hearing, Leonard said that through an investigation, evidence of an escape plan between Jeter and Labastida was discovered. She said that if the case had gone to trial, the state would have presented evidence that proves Jeter knew where to go during the escape.
At Labastida's plea hearing, Leonard said Labastida was identified as a suspect through investigation, and she said Bay Bridge records show Labastida's car crossing the bridge to and from the Eastern Shore before and after the Aug. 1 incident.
Leonard said that through a search warrant, texts between Labastida and Jeter's girlfriend were discovered. Leonard said that in the text chain, Jeter's girlfriend told Labastida that Jeter had been apprehended, and Labastida replied that she should tell Jeter to keep quiet about him helping Jeter escape.
Leonard said a handgun was found in Labastida's bedroom. She said that ballistics testing found the spent shell casings discovered at the hospital center consistent with the handgun found in Labastida's room.
Jeter, who's sentence was handed down by Dorchester County Circuit Court Judge William Jones on Thursday, was ordered to seek substance abuse treatment, mental health treatment with medication compliance and not make contact with Labastida.
Before handing down the sentence, Jones called the set of facts presented during the hearing "very troubling." He said that the people working in the hospital center that day should not have had to experience that.
Jeter's attorney Archibald McFadden said Jeter has a detailed track record of mental health struggles. He said Jeter has had those struggles since childhood.
McFadden also said he has spoken with Jeter's father regularly since taking on the case, and Jeter has a supportive family behind him. McFadden said that if Jeter takes the steps to manage his mental health struggles now, it will benefit him as he gets older.

title: Beloved school crossing guard retires after 54 years
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Beloved school crossing guard retires after 54 years

 June 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 491
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — For 54 years, when school let out, Charles Jenkins worked his magic, directing traffic and ensuring Easton Middle School students walked home safely.Tuesday morning was unique, though, as the longtime crossing guard was honored for his last day on the job, waving to hundreds of cars, trucks and buses at the intersection of S. Washington Street and Peachblossom Road.
"I'm gonna miss every bit of it because I've been doing it all my life," Jenkins, who is best known by his nickname 'Nut,' said. "Just like starting driving your first time, you want to keep right on driving. That's what I felt about this.
"I've enjoyed every bit of it, working with the community and working with my fine officers and everything. …(I) give them respect, and they give me respect."
Jenkins, 81, has 54 years of service at schools in Easton, along with over 20 years in the St. Michaels community on the weekends. He's been manning the intersection for decades, managing the chaotic, busy scene of buses departing, students walking home and parents picking up their children.
"Wait 'til I tell them to go, don't go on your own," Jenkins said of his longtime message to the students. "Wait until I turn around to tell you to go, but they're great for that. They really do (listen)."
Josepha Price and Carla Beavers, who each have children that just wrapped up sixth grade at EMS, led an effort to honor Jenkins Tuesday morning. Price and Beavers worked with the school's Family Teacher Organization to have students and parents drop off cards.
They energized a large part of the Easton community prior to Tuesday morning with a Facebook post, which garnered hundreds of likes, and a wealth of appreciation for what Jenkins has done for pedestrian safety in Easton.
"He's tough on us parents that drive, but so soft and enthusiastic to our children," Price wrote. "You know wherever he is, the kids will be safe, and I can't think of any greater purpose than protecting children."
As Easton Middle's early dismissal on its last day commenced, Price and others held up "Honk for Mr. Jenkins" signs in front of the Idlewild Park fountain, down the street from the school. Some students walked over to embrace Jenkins and say goodbye.
Once dismissal finished, EMS administrators, teachers and staff all walked down to the intersection to greet Jenkins, who was accompanied by one of his two daughters.
"They all respect me and everything with my work, and I respect all of them by being here," Jenkins said.
In 2022, he was presented a Governor's Citation by former Gov. Larry Hogan for his dedication to keeping the community safe.
Jenkins' plans moving forward are to spend time with his daughters and "take it easy and relax."
"I just wish I was 30 years younger," Jenkins said.
When asked if he would do it all over again for another 50-plus years, the beloved crossing guard had no hesitation.
"If I could, I really would," Jenkins said.

Plea hearing is scheduled for Rider case

 EASTON — Fred "Trey" Rider III is planning to enter a plea deal in August rather than standing trial for charges related to a fire at his home on Peach Orchard Road in Easton.At a virtual status hearing Tuesday, Judge Thomas G. Ross scheduled a plea hearing for Aug. 19, the first day of when Rider's trial was supposed to begin, and a sentencing hearing for October.
Rider is accused of setting his house on fire in November 2022.
Through investigation, officials identified the fire as an act of human intervention with an open flame, classifying the cause of fire as incendiary. According to court documents, Rider's reckless conduct in igniting the house on fire "clearly" put more than 45 firefighters who responded in danger as they suppressed the fire.
At the status hearing Tuesday, Talbot County Assistant State's Attorney Jennifer Wilson said Rider plans to plead guilty to first-degree arson and five counts of reckless endangerment. She said the state plans to enter nolle prosequi for Rider's remaining nine charges, meaning the state will not prosecute for those charges.
Rider's attorney Christine DuFour, who took over from attorney Stephanie Shipley in April, said Rider's divorce proceedings with Kari Rider are happening parallel to this case. She said it would be helpful to know the outcome of the divorce before Rider is handed a sentence because the divorce will have an affect on the sentencing.
The sentencing was scheduled for Oct. 4, a little over a week after the final hearing in Rider's divorce process.
Wilson said the state is not opposed to Rider being handed suspended consecutive sentences for the reckless endangerment counts. DuFour said the state could seek restitution in the plea agreement, but that has not been determined.
Rider was supposed to stand trial March 4, but at a status hearing that morning, Ross said Rider had been voluntarily admitted to Johns Hopkins Hospital and issued a bench warrant for Rider's failure to appear in court that morning. After getting discharged, Rider was granted a request to be transferred to an alcohol and drug rehab facility for 60 days, with the condition that he return to the Talbot County Detention Center upon completing the program.
On May 14, the detention center was ordered to release Rider on a previously posted $20,000 unsecured bond. Rider was released on conditions including that he surrender his passport, he reside in a sober living home in Pasadena, he attend Alcoholics Anonymous and Narcotics Anonymous meetings and he enroll in mental health services.
This report has been updated from an earlier version to clarify the state's opinion on Rider potentially receiving suspended consecutive sentences.

title: Man charged with murder in fatal shooting
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Man charged with murder in fatal shooting

 June 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 724
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Investigators have filed murder charges against a man who allegedly shot a visitor at close range outside his residence near Elkton earlier this week during an incident that was caught on security camera video, according to Cecil County District Court records.The suspect — Donald Raymond Snyder Jr., 41 — reportedly surrendered himself to the Maryland State Police late Thursday night at the agency's North East Barrack, in accordance with arrangements that had been made amid the investigation.
Snyder is accused of gunning down Christopher Cimorose, 55, of Elkton, at approximately 9:20 p.m. on Monday in the driveway of Snyder's residence in the unit block of Locust Point Road, south of Elkton.
MSP troopers and other first responders rushed to that Locust Point Road residence at 9:24 p.m. Monday, after Snyder called and told a 911 dispatcher, "Someone just got shot," at that address, police reported.
"As the dispatcher was collecting the information on the call for service, she asked Snyder directly if he shot the gun. Snyder replied, 'Yeah'," according to the charging document.
At the scene, troopers spoke to Snyder and his 46-year-old girlfriend, Michelle McCarthy, before driving them to the North East Barrack, where MSP Homicide Unit investigators interviewed them, police said. Investigators secured Snyder's weapon, which had been placed in the bed of a pickup truck on the premises before first responders arrived, police added.
Paramedics pronounced Cimorose dead at the scene, police reported.
During the on-scene investigation, MSP detectives confiscated external security cameras on Snyder's property, after obtaining a warrant to do so, court records show.
Investigators note in court documents that "a few of the cameras" faced the driveway "where the intentional killing of Cimorose took place," and that they produced a video showing the fatal shooting and the events leading up to it.
Investigators had sent the confiscated DVR security system to MSP's Digital Forensic Lab on Wednesday, and technicians there extricated a 19-minute-long, motion-activated video clip of what occurred outside Snyder's residence on Monday night, court records show.
The video first shows Snyder and McCarthy exit the Locust Point Road residence and then get into McCarthy's vehicle in the driveway at approximately 9 p.m. Monday, with McCarthy sliding into the driver's seat and Snyder getting into the seat directly behind her, police reported.
About two minutes later, the video shows Cimorose pulling into that driveway in a red Nissan Versa, according to court records, which indicate that Cimorose was there to pick up McCarthy. The document does not provide a reason why Cimorose was there to pick up McCarthy.
The video then shows McCarthy exit her vehicle and walk to the front passenger's seat of Cimorose's Nissan and Snyder walk directly to the open window of the Nissan's driver's side door, police reported.
"Snyder almost immediately punches Cimorose in the head/face area, as he was still in the vehicle. As a response to being punched, Cimorose's vehicle lunged forward, dragging Snyder for a few feet," according to the charging document.
Before the Nissan came to a stop, Snyder armed himself, based on the footage, police reported.
"Snynder removes 9mm handgun from his waistband and points it at Cimorose. Cimorose places his vehicle in park, opens his door (and) attempts to get out of his vehicle — at which time Snyder fired three (3) times, striking Cimorose in the neck and chest area. Cimorose is observed falling to the ground next to his vehicle. Lying next to him was wooden table leg," court records allege.
During his police interview at the MSP barrack later that night, Snyder maintained that Cimorose was the aggressor, court records show.
"Snyder stated 'As far as I can see, the man grabbed a pipe and came at me.' Snyder also stated, 'I never wanted to do this'," according to the charging document.
MSP investigators consulted with the Cecil County State's Attorney's Office before filing criminal charges against Snyder on Thursday, court records indicate.
Snyder is charged with second-degree murder, a felony that is punishable by up to 40 years in prison if convicted, and five other offenses, including first-degree assault, use of a firearm in the commission of a felony or a crime of violence and reckless endangerment, court records show.
He remained in the Cecil County Detention Center on no bond Friday, after his bail review hearing earlier that day, according to court records, which show that Cecil County District Court Administrative Judge Bonnie G. Schneider presided over that proceeding.
