title: 5-year-old dies after bounce castle swept away at Blue Crabs game
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content:
5-year-old dies after bounce castle swept away at Blue Crabs game

 August 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 501
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A 5-year-old child died after a bounce castle was swept away by a wind gust at the Aug. 2 Southern Maryland Blue Crabs game.It was revealed through online fundraising and memorial posts that the 5-year-old was Declan Hicks of La Plata.
"That day family, friends, and the world lost a dinosaur lover, ninja turtle fan, and crazy sock wearing (with boots!) 5-year-old, Declan Hicks," Tiffany Goudie, the organizer of a GoFundMe for Hicks' family, wrote on the page.
"Hicks was a part of the Blessed Lambs Preschool family for 3 years. He was a very special little boy who brought light and laughter to everyone who had the pleasure of knowing him," Gouldie said. "To know him was to love him. He was a great friend, and a fan favorite in his 4-year-old classroom, not just with other children but with his teachers."
Hicks was a member of the La Plata Blue Knights Football and Cheerleading Organization as a flag football player.
In a Facebook post by the organization, the Blue Knights said that they will be dedicating their upcoming season to Hicks, all flag football players and cheerleaders will wear a patch and all tackle football players will have his number on their helmets.
At 9:21 p.m. Aug. 2, Charles County 911 Public Safety Communications received a call from the Regency Furniture Stadium reporting that a moon bounce house became airborne due to a wind gust, while children were inside it.
At the time, the Southern Maryland Blue Crabs baseball team was playing a game, and the moon bounce was carried approximately 15 to 20 feet in the air, causing children to fall before it landed on the playing field, a release from Charles County government said.
Charles County EMS personnel, who were stationed at the stadium for the game, along with trainers from the baseball team and several volunteer first responders, swiftly began patient care within minutes of the incident.
One pediatric patient sustained life-threatening injuries and was transported by Maryland State Police Trooper 2 to Children's Hospital. This patient, the 5-year-old boy from La Plata, died at the hospital.
A second pediatric patient who sustained non-life-threatening injuries was also flown out by MSP Trooper 7.
"We extend our deepest empathy to the children and their families during this difficult time," Commission President Reuben B. Collins II (D) said. "We thank our EMS team and the Maryland State Police for their swift actions to ensure the children received immediate care."
Courtney Knichel, general manager of the Southern Maryland Blue Crabs said that "our entire organization shares our condolences with the family mourning the loss of a child, and concern for the child who was injured. Our thoughts and prayers are with them all."
The Southern Maryland Blue Crabs canceled Saturday's baseball game and all baseball activities for Aug. 3 and are offering counseling and support to families, players and fans who attended the game.
A spokesperson from the Charles County Sheriff's Office said that the agency is working with investigators from Maryland Occupational Safety and Health, who will lead the investigation.

title: Greensboro adds security measures, hears resident feedback after water system 'sabotage'
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Greensboro adds security measures, hears resident feedback after water system 'sabotage'

 August 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 549
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO — Town employees discussed an apparent "sabotage" of Greensboro's water system and heard feedback from residents during a Thursday evening Town Council meeting.On July 29, the town announced that the its water and wastewater contract operator, Susquehanna Operational Services, conducted tests throughout town, finding higher than normal chlorine levels. It came after a bevy of complaints from concerned residents, who said the water had a chlorine-like taste and smell the weekend prior.
The town concluded that "one of the chlorine regulators had been tampered with" in the tower wells. In a press release, it was deemed "deliberate sabotage," and the town stated the Caroline County Sheriff's Office would conduct an investigation.
Brandon Cunningham, the town's public works supervisor, provided an update Thursday on security measures put in place in days since. Cunningham said "the locks have all been changed to all the well houses."
Keys were given to members of Susquehanna Operational Services, and himself and the town manager in case of emergency, he said.
He also said he's been in contact with SafeHouse, a security system company, to potentially procure security cameras and keypads. Cunningham said SafeHouse security measures, including adding cameras, would cost $15,865.54.
Councilmember Joe Noon said he'd "like a couple more bids" for the cameras and security additions. Carly Landolfi, assistant to the town attorney, told councilmembers they could vote on a "contingent" motion to purchase the SafeHouse services, depending on whether she finds the town must legally seek out other bids or not.
Mayor David Spencer said he's visited the wells and vouched for security services to be adopted as soon as possible.
"I really don't want to push this off," Spencer said. Councilmember Pete Breila made a motion to pass the "contingent" motion, which was seconded by Councilmember Bob Harrison.
PUBLIC COMMENTMultiple residents expressed concerns about the water quality and the town's response to councilmembers Thursday.
"The word sabotage, that's a pretty extensive word," resident Chris Mason said. "It means a lot, and it puts fear in the community."
Mason continued, questioning why the investigation is being conducted by Caroline County Sheriff's Office and not the Greensboro Police Department. He added that he wished the town had passed out water to residents during the days in which the chlorine-like taste and smell was apparent.
"Who has access to sabotage?" resident Melissa Knight asked. "Where'd that information come from? We're not getting any forthcoming information."
Knight said that "the entire bedroom (smelled) like chlorine" after flushing the toilet in her house last weekend. She also asked about the process of testing the chlorine levels.
George Smith, president of Susquehanna Operational Services, said his team tested multiple locations when notified by the town of the complaints. Smith and a Susquehanna employee confirmed there were readings of 2.2, 0.6 and 0.54 milligrams per liter. The Environmental Protection Agency's standard is that anything above the 4.0 milligram per liter mark is not healthy to drink and could pose long-term health effects such as eye irritation and stomach problems.
Smith declined to comment on the investigation since it's active. Spencer also declined.
"There's a lot that we'd all like to say," Spencer said. "But since there is an investigation ongoing, when that is concluded, then we will try to give you as much information as we possibly can."
The Caroline County Sheriff's Office declined to comment on the investigation for this article.

title: Ridgely residents call for police department to be reinstated
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Ridgely residents call for police department to be reinstated

 August 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 665
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RIDGELY — Following tense public comment at Monday's Ridgely Town Meeting, residents are calling for the Ridgely Police Department and its officers to be reinstated after nearly five months of suspension.The Commissioners of Ridgely suspended the department in March, with pay, pending an investigation by the Maryland Office of the State Prosecutor. At Monday's meeting, residents raised that the department and its officers had been exonerated by investigators surfaced.
Multiple people asked for the department to be reinstated. Resident James Romph questioned the commissioners and town employees on the investigation.
"What is the update on the Ridgely Police Department investigation?" Romph asked.
"Sir, I'd love to answer that but I was told to keep my mouth shut," David Crist, the town's director of public works, responded.
"I'm going to answer it for you, for the public," Romph said. "The entire police department has been exonerated. The state has concluded their investigation and found no fault with the police department or the police chief, criminally or administratively. They're exonerated."
As of Tuesday, town employees and the Office of the State Prosecutor did not immediately respond to requests regarding the report and whether or not it cleared the department and its officers.
Romph claimed the commissioners had "known for over two weeks and didn't share that with you," speaking to the standing-room-only crowd, which included members of the police department.
"No we have not, we have not been notified," Commissioner John Hurley said. Crist backed the commissioners up, saying they hadn't been notified but confirming that he had been. Romph questioned why Crist did not inform the commissioners or the public.
"From my counsel, I was told this is a personnel matter, you cannot speak," Crist said. "I'm not a lawyer, I don't know law. But if the town attorney tells me to zip it, I'm zipping it."
Since the initial suspension, the town has not provided clear reasoning for the investigation. Nor has the Office of the State Prosecutor.
The town came to a temporary memorandum of understanding with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office, agreeing that the Sheriff's Office and Maryland State Police would split duties to cover the suspended department.
In May, the town agreed to a new memorandum of understanding with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office, this one providing a "long-term partnership" for fiscal year 2025. It included "a provision for maintaining 480 hours of coverage per month," per a town release, and took effect on July 1.
Caroline County Chief Deputy Rodney Helmer told The Star Democrat on Tuesday that the updated MOU is still in effect. As of Tuesday, the county had not heard from the town requesting to cease the MOU. Such a request would require 30 days of notice, Helmer said.
Residents have brought concerns about the county's law enforcement coverage compared to what town police provided. Resident and business owner Holly Justice says it hasn't been the same.
"When you deal with a big giant, you lose a lot of those small-town things," Justice said in an interview. "The county, they have a lot of area to cover, and although we have officers that they did dedicate to this territory, it's just not the same."
Justice created a petition Tuesday, asking the town to reinstate the officers. As of Tuesday evening, it had over 30 signatures.
"People's lives were jeopardized with this," Justice said. " … These people have families. My heart goes out to them. But I also understand the town's side, being told by their counsel that they can not speak about this matter.
"Instead of joining in with the brigade and yelling and fussing, I said, 'What's a better way to come at this? What's a better way to be heard and be seen?'"
Resident Lakia Harris-Pierce said she believes residents should be informed on the investigation's results. "They need to make the investigation public, we have the right to know," she said.
Town commissioners are meeting in closed session Wednesday afternoon to discuss personnel matters, according to an agenda posted to the town's website.
Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado and Tom McCall contributed reporting to this story.

title: Man sentenced to life without parole for 2023 murder of Jasmine Hicks
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content:
Man sentenced to life without parole for 2023 murder of Jasmine Hicks

 August 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 579
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On Aug. 6, Deanthony Lamont Warrick, 35, was sentenced to life without parole for the April 2023 murder of Jasmine Hicks.Hicks was stabbed to death in the overnight hours of April 12, 2023 after an argument with Warrick. She was 29 at the time.
A video captured by a security camera system on a nearby house was presented during the trial.
The video depicted Hicks and Warrick leaving a red Chrysler vehicle in the 2300 block of Woodberry Drive in Bryans Road, when Warrick realized that PCP, a handgun and an assault rifle were missing from the vehicle, according to testimony.
Warrick argued with Hicks and got progressively louder until Warrick grabbed a knife and repeatedly stabbed Hicks. Police said lacerations were found on her head, neck, hands and upper arms.
Hicks could be heard on tape, from across the street, saying, "You've already killed me. I'm already dead."
Warrick tried to move Hicks, who was still alive at the time, into his car. He gave up and fled the scene.
Hicks' family attended en masse for the sentencing, with Assistant State's Attorney Laura Caspar presenting the case to give Warrick life without parole.
Caspar told Judge William R. Greer that the State's Attorney's Office does not seek this sentence in every case, but that the murder of Jasmine Hicks was "vile, malicious and vengeful."
Warrick claimed at one point that Hicks had a gun and that the killing was in self-defense, but the footage from the camera that caught the murder showed otherwise.
"Where's my s—," Warrick could be heard screaming on the footage, looking for PCP and a firearm that Hicks' brother took in fear that he would use the firearm on his sister after he had pointed the firearm at a vehicle Hicks was in.
"There was no fear there," Caspar said. "There was no gun and he knew it."
After the argument escalated, Warrick stabbed Hicks a number of times before saying, "Don't make me kill you."
Hicks replied, "You already did."
Caspar could only speculate the horror that Hicks had to endure after Warrick left the scene of the murder, where Hicks was alive for another hour and a half.
Members of Hicks' family came forward to ask that Greer impose the maximum sentence.
Arthur Lancaster, Hicks' uncle, told the judge that Hicks was the type of person that would "brighten your day" and that she was a loving mother to her three children.
"Today, your honor, we are looking for closure," Lancaster said. "Deanthony Warrick is an atrocious, cruel, heinous, cold-blooded murderer."
Lancaster called Warrick a "wild animal" before saying, "Wild animals need to be caged."
Mary Lawson — Hicks' mother — fought tears to say, "She went too soon."
Lawson recalled how Hicks' children came home from school and were looking for their mother, but she had to tell them that she would not be there.
"I'll be there every time," Lawson said.
Andre Mahasa, Warrick's attorney, said that while he and Warrick respected the jury's verdict, they still believed that there was no premeditation in the murder and that it should have been second-degree murder at most.
Warrick had nothing to say to the judge after being informed of his right to speak.
During the sentencing, Greer dismissed Warrick's claim that Hicks had a firearm, saying that at some point during the stabbing, he had to realize that there was no gun.
Greer said that Warrick's actions after the attack showed a lack of empathy.
"Jasmine Hicks died alone in the night on the cold ground," Greer said before imposing a life sentence on Warrick.

The goal is to prevent crime and have people know the officers and emergency services personnel who serve their area.
Megan Coxon, a sergeant with the Easton Police Department, has been a primary force in organizing the event.
"We are here for First Night Out, which is a nationwide event. It happens the first Tuesday in August. I probably know half the folks here just because we interact on a daily anyway," Coxon said. "It is like a mini reunion. We get to hang out for a night, and of course you get to meet new people. If I don't know you, I will come talk to you and if I have seen you before, we will reconnect."
She said she got a lot of help from Jill Garvey, an EPD management assistant, and Lorraine Gould, director of Easton Parks and Recreation.
Coxon pointed out the law enforcement representatives in attendance.
"We have at least ten from EPD. We have sheriff's office, fire marshall's office, Natural Resources Police, Talbot Sheriff's office and MSP. There are about 40 people," she said.
Over a smoking hot grill with about 50 burgers were members of the Easton Volunteer Fire Department.
"We are cooking some good burgers. We got some good hot dogs. We got a decent crowd of people, it is its a good time," Aiden Lowery, a firefighter and EMT said.
Mayor Megan Cook was also present, immersed in community.
"Talking to people? That is the best part of my job," Cook said. "The sense of community is what is important tonight. I think to see the police department as partners and to get them visible in the community so our neighbors know that they are a resource and they are there to help."
John Grothe of the state's fire marshal office had a full kevlar and ballistic shield bomb squad suit and special helmet on display. He is a bomb tech and said the suit weighs 100 pounds.
"In the event that there is a device or suspicious package, we try to stay as remote as possible. We try to utilize our bomb robot, but every once in a while, we have to put on the suit and go downrange in person. Night Out is a great opportunity to meet people and have them come up and touch the equipment. We get to explain what we do. It puts a face to the agency," Grothe said.
There were over 100 community members wandering around, getting food, visiting with friends and getting information from the community service booths.
Jessica Carter, who was sharing an shaved ice with her daughter, said the National Night Out event gives her family an opportunity to see what resources are available to them.
"We come every year. The resources. Giving back to the community. Some people may not know what resources are available to them. So it is good. I like the health department and Chesapeake Voyagers," Carter said.
Garvey said she has been working on this event for over a month. She had two massive sheet cakes from Cordova Bakery in her air conditioned vehicle.
"It falls into place. I have been planning these for 18 years. It is a free fun family event. The pool is open. Come out and enjoy. There is free food. It is a good community event," she said.

title: State investigators continue investigation into fatal Easton police chase
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
State investigators continue investigation into fatal Easton police chase

 August 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 544
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Independent Investigations Division of the Maryland Office of the Attorney General is continuing its investigation into a police chase that ended in a fatality last month.In an interview with The Star Democrat, Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble said his department "preliminarily" determined the county's deputies "complied" with state law and county policies on vehicle pursuits. But that determination "won't finalize" until the state investigation is complete, he said.
The state's preliminary investigation into the incident revealed that just after 7 p.m. on July 22, deputies from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, in marked police cruisers, encountered a car in the area of westbound Route 50 and Dutchmans Lane, where they attempted to initiate a traffic stop.
According to the preliminary investigation, the front seat passenger, identified as 18-year old Yemaya Wilson, and the driver were transported to a local hospital for treatment of serious injuries. Wilson was later pronounced dead at the hospital.
The driver of the car, an unidentified juvenile male, did not stop and continued to drive on Route 50. The deputies pursued the vehicle for several minutes, with officers from the Easton Police Department assisting, before it crashed into a tree in the 8300 block of Black Dog Alley.
The two rear passengers, an unidentified juvenile male and adult woman, were transported to an area hospital for treatment of serious injuries.
Gamble said after the crash, police learned the vehicle had been stolen from Montgomery County.
The involved officers were equipped with body-worn cameras.
The attorney general's office identified the officers involved in the pursuit: Talbot County deputies Brittanie DiMichele, William Barnett and Owen Joseph, and Easton Police Department officer Nicholas Lange.
The Independent Investigations Division is continuing its investigation with assistance from the Maryland State Police Crash Team.
Both the Talbot County Sheriff's Office and Easton Police Department have standards for vehicle pursuits in their department policies, many of which are identical.
Written in both policies are factors to consider when initiating a police pursuit. These include the seriousness of the alleged crime, public safety, officers' familiarity with the area, weather or traffic patterns, if the suspect has been identified and if other people are in the vehicle that's being pursued.
Both departments' policies state that a pursuit should be halted when "present risks of continuing the pursuit reasonably appear to outweigh the risks resulting from the suspect's escape."
An administrative review by the Talbot County Sheriff's Office is underway, Gamble said. That review will not be completed until the state's investigation is complete. The three county deputies are still working, Gamble added.
In a statement to The Star Democrat, Attorney General Anthony Brown vouched for the creation state standards of police pursuits, which currently do not exist.
"I would like (to) see statewide standards for police-involved vehicle pursuits, but the rules should consider different population densities and take geography into account," Brown said in the statement. "The goal should be to make our communities safer for all, reduce fatalities and help law enforcement do their jobs effectively."
When asked about the potential of statewide standards, Gamble said "one size does not fit all," emphasizing that pursuits in populated areas like Baltimore City are different to pursuits in rural areas like Talbot County.
Gamble expressed concerns of such legislative efforts to create what he calls "one size fits all" statewide police policies.

 CHESTER — Strengthening neighborhood spirit, a warm evening of collaboration brings a festival of resources and organizations for a community night out block party to the United Methodist Church in Chester Aug. 2.The annual community block party is a multi-organization collaborative event brought forth music, food vendors, resources and giveaways.
Blending everything in the county in one central hub: the warm evening of collaboration provided an opportunity for citizens, law enforcement, faith-based organizations, county agencies, civic organizations, neighborhood organizations, and businesses to come together and address prevention issues.
Sponsored by CSAFE, the Collaborative Supervision and Focused Enforcement Group, and in collaboration with the organizations including the Queen Anne's County Department of Health Alcohol and Drug Abuse Prevention Services, Citizens Against Smoking Tobacco Coalition, the Office of the Sheriff and the Wellness Coalition, the annual community-building campaign promotes police-community partnerships to make neighborhoods safer.
Thankful to be part of the diverse landscape that makes up Queen Anne's County, Dorine Fassett has been organizing community events to bring resources to surrounding neighbors for years.
"I love to see people come out and support each other," Fassett said.
Community festivals are excellent ways for neighbors to learn more about the resources and organizations surrounding them in a casual, fun environment, she said.
Alongside local vendors, raffles and activities for all ages, other participating organizations included the Queen Anne's County Sheriff's Department, the County Health Department, and the Maryland Army National Guard.
National Night Out is a nationwide event that brings law enforcement and the community together and is traditionally held on the first Tuesday in August.  RISING SUN — Two men are facing criminal charges after a fight in which fishing equipment was used as weapons — including a gaff hook that one of the combatants allegedly used to stab the other in the leg, sending him to the hospital in an ambulance, according to the Cecil County Sheriff's Office.The incident occurred at approximately 7:45 p.m. on Tuesday at a residence in the 200 block of Smith Road. near Rising Sun, police said. CCSO deputies rushed to that address after someone called 911 from that location and then hung up the phone, police added.
Investigators learned that two tenants — William Winford Abbott, 59, and Mark Alvin Vincent, 58, both of whom reside at 241 Smith Road — had gotten into a property dispute, police reported.
Abbott allegedly struck Vincent's back and side with a fishing pole, according to Lt. Michael Zack, a CCSO spokesman. Then Vincent allegedly hit Abbott in his right leg with a fishing gaff hook, puncturing Abbott's leg, Zack reported.
An ambulance crew drove Abbott to Christiana Hospital in Delaware, where he was treated for his non-life-threatening puncture wound to his leg, police said.
Arrested at the scene, Vincent is charged with first-degree assault, second-degree assault and reckless endangerment, court records show. First-degree assault is a felony that is punishable by up to 25 years in prison if convicted while second-degree assault and reckless endangerment are misdemeanors that carry maximum sentences of 10 years and five years respectively.
Vincent remained in the Cecil County Detention Center in lieu of $5,000 bond on Thursday, one day after a bail review hearing in which his no-bond status was reduced to that sum, according to court records, which indicate that Cecil County District Court Administrative Judge Bonnie G. Schneider presided over that proceeding.
Abbott, meanwhile, is charged with second-degree assault and reckless endangerment for his alleged role in the incident, court records show. Abbott was not arrested but, rather, was served a criminal summons, court records indicate.

title: Debby's remnants bring flooding to the Shore

Debby's remnants bring flooding to the Shore

 Flooding was prevalent as the remnants of Hurricane Debby hit the Eastern Shore Friday morning, with communities bracing for unusually high tides later that day."We've gotten a report on email from Emergency Management. It's been minor flooding so far," said Rescue Fire Company Chief Adam Pritchett Friday afternoon. "I believe the high tides are expected to be tonight of concern for Cambridge. But as of right now, it's been minor flooding so far."
The Town of Oxford warned residents that higher-than-expected tides could cause further flooding in the area Friday evening.
"Please be aware that the NOAA prediction for this evening's high tide has changed significantly and is now anticipated to be 4.5 feet, which could produce major flooding," the town said in an email to residents Friday afternoon. "By comparison, this morning's high tide that resulted in flooding throughout the town registered as a 3.9-foot tide at the Cambridge marker. With a 4.5-foot tide, the Causeway area will be impassable for a period of time."
Debby was downgraded to a tropical depression late Thursday afternoon, and was a post-tropical cyclone on Friday, the National Hurricane Center said. It made landfall early Monday on the Gulf Coast of Florida as a category 1 hurricane. Then, Debby made a second landfall early Thursday in South Carolina as a tropical storm.
Pritchett said his department was ready to help with any impacts from Friday evening's tides.
"We pretty much stay at a ready pace for things like this because it's becoming more normal all the time now with each storm that passes on," he said. "So we're kind of always ready for events like this. Have our equipment ready, checked out and so forth."

content:
22-year-old sentenced for week-long crime spree

 An Anne Arundel County man was sentenced to 44 years in prison for multiple crimes committed in St. Mary's two years ago.State's Attorney Jaymi Sterling this week announced that Tyler Ray Marini Sater, 22, of Stoney Beach was sentenced to 59 years in prison, with 44 years of active incarceration, for multiple criminal convictions stemming from his week-long, one-man crime spree in late 2022.
On Dec. 13, 2022, Sater committed a robbery by knifepoint at the Cloud Smoke Shop in California, according to a release from the state's attorney's office.
Six days later, he committed an additional series of crimes at the Wildewood Shopping Center.
As a result, he was convicted of robbery, attempted armed carjacking, unlawful taking of a motor vehicle, attempted harm of a law enforcement animal, and rogue and vagabond.
While pending trial, Sater fled to Charles County. He was subsequently charged and convicted of second-degree escape.
"While the defendant was on supervised probation in several other counties for disturbingly similar crimes, he fled to our county and initiated a one-man crime spree. His deliberate actions victimized multiple community members, each suffering from the impact of his criminal conduct," Sterling (R) said in the release. "This sentence serves as a critical step toward safeguarding the public and ensuring that this Defendant can no longer target the citizens in our community."
During his arrest in 2022, Sater had been shot by Sgt. Timothy Wesner, a 10-year veteran of the agency, who fired his weapon, striking the suspect twice.
St. Mary's deputies responded to a Wawa gas station in California in regard to a vehicle theft on Dec. 19, 2022, according to a sheriff's office press release at the time.
Deputies located the stolen vehicle minutes later at a hotel in the 23400 block of Three Notch Road and the suspect fled on foot toward the Wildewood shopping center. Deputies pursued the Sater, who allegedly was armed with a knife, and attempted less lethal means by using a Taser on him multiple times. They also used a sheriff's office canine, the press release states.
Sater attempted to carjack an occupied vehicle at a restaurant, but the victim fled. Sater continued to flee through the shopping center and entered a separate vehicle which was running, but he was then shot by the deputy who fired three rounds, according to the release.
Sater was transported by helicopter to an area trauma center, the release states. No injuries to deputies were reported.
Judge Michael Stamm presided over the case. Senior Assistant State's Attorney Alena Mosier prosecuted the case.
Detective Warren Forinash, Detective Daniel Sidorowicz and Detective Taylore Nauman of the St. Mary's County Sheriff's Office were the lead investigators.

title: Investigation into Ridgely Police closed, 'sufficient evidence' of allegations not found
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Investigation into Ridgely Police closed, 'sufficient evidence' of allegations not found

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 712
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RIDGELY — An investigation by the Maryland Office of the State Prosecutor into Ridgely Police Department Chief Jeff Eckrich is closed, according to a report obtained from the state prosecutor's office Tuesday.The report, dated July 25, states an investigation was opened due to "suspected" perjury and misconduct in office. It states the investigation found no "sufficient evidence of criminal activity warranting further investigation or prosecution."
Eckrich, along with the entire Ridgely Police Department, was suspended in March by the Commissioners of Ridgely and has not been reinstated.
"Chief Eckrich is gratified that an independent investigation conducted by the Office of the State Prosecutor culminated in repudiation of the allegations of misconduct and his full exoneration," read a statement from Bruce Marcus, an attorney representing Eckrich. "He is grateful to that Office for their work in clearing his good name."
The investigation began in February following claims that Eckrich "knowingly withheld a disclosure (referred to as the Brady list) related to a former out-of-state police officer from an application to the MD Police and Correctional Training Commission," the investigation report states.
The report notes that on March 11, the town held a closed session meeting, during which these allegations were presented. Specific allegations claimed that Eckrich falsified documents, such as payroll documents and firearms and field training requirements.
Allegations against the chief also included that he "sold a vehicle owned by the town under value and without permission, was under the influence of medications while on duty, and had poor management," according to the state's report.
On March 12, the Caroline County Sheriff's Office obtained a search warrant for the police department in relation to the "alleged misconduct."
That same day, the report adds, was when commissioners suspended the entire police department and its officers. That decision came "without guidance" from the state prosecutor, according to the report.
Investigators conducted interviews with both town and police department employees, along with obtaining documents and revenue reports related to the police department.
The town has not made clear whether the police department will be reinstated. Ridgely is currently operating under an agreement with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office for law enforcement coverage.
At a closed-session meeting in April, town commissioners laid off the dismissed officers and support staff. This took effect July 1 with the beginning of the new fiscal year.
In May, the town agreed to a new memorandum of understanding with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office, providing a "long-term partnership" for fiscal year 2025. It included "a provision for maintaining 480 hours of coverage per month," per a town release.
PUBLIC OUTCRYA heated public comment section at an Aug. 5 town meeting brought Ridgely under scrutiny for not making an announcement about the state's completed investigation.
Town commissioners said during the meeting they were not notified of the report, though David Crist, director of public works, said he was. Crist said he "was told this is a personnel matter," adding that he couldn't provide further details based on guidance from legal counsel.
At that meeting, some residents asked for the police department to be reinstated. In the following days, a petition to reinstate the officers gained traction. It had nearly 100 signatures as of Tuesday.
"I absolutely think that they should be brought back, rightfully so," resident Holly Justice, who began the online petition, said in an interview. "They were not guilty of what they were accused of. So everything taken from them should be given back to them and more."
Justice added that she understands the town's position. "I think they were very hasty in the way that they moved about removing our police officers," she said, " ... so I think moving forward, people are just a little more cautious with the decisions that they are making."
In a Town of Ridgely statement released on Aug. 8, the town said it is aware of the Office of the State Prosecutor's report.
"The Commissioners wish to remind the public that there are limitations on the information that it can publicly share regarding confidential personnel matters," the statement reads. "Additionally, the investigation was initiated and conducted by the OSP, not the Town, and the OSP provides very little information regarding its investigations. Thus, there is limited information that the Town can publicly disclose."
The town said "a more detailed statement" will be provided at the town's next meeting on Sept. 9.

title: 'It was all smiles': Cambridge National Night Out brings more than 800 to county pool
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
'It was all smiles': Cambridge National Night Out brings more than 800 to county pool

 August 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 582
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — This year's National Night Out event in Cambridge brought more people, more hotdogs and more smiles."Like many other years, it was another successful year," Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd said. "We had tons of kids and a lot of people and businesses and community leaders that came out and all took part. It was all smiles."
Between 800 and 900 people showed up to the Dorchester County Pool on Aug. 6 for National Night Out on, compared to around 600 people last year, Cambridge Police Captain Antoine Patton said.
Patton said all of the feedback he received about the evening was positive. He said multiple children came up to him to thank him and tell him they had a great time.
Todd said all of the positive feedback is why the police department continues to hold the event at the pool year after year.
"I think there's just something about being at the county pool and the kids being able to have the opportunity to swim for a couple hours, not worry about any prices or charges and just enjoy time with their friends and family," he said.
Attendees were able to talk with a variety of vendors, from the Dorchester County Health Department to the Department of Juvenile Services to the Boys and Girls Club. The different vendors offered pamphlets and information about the resources they have available to residents.
Similar to the number of attendees, Patton said there were more vendors at this year's event than in years past. Todd said that number has increased every year.
"And it's good because you get those necessary resources and information that people may not otherwise see or get," Todd said. "It actually gets handed to them. And they can talk to one another and start forming those bonds."
Along with swimming in the pool, listening to the music played by DJ Doc Lane and eating hotdogs courtesy of the police department, a handful of lucky attendees won prizes that had been donated by Paul Davis Restoration. Prizes ranged from a TV, to a Minnie Mouse kitchen set, to a gas grill, to baskets filled with household goods.
"The lady who won a TV actually cried," Patton said.
Not only did attendees get served the 700 hotdogs the police station cooked up, but MidShore Meals til Monday — a nonprofit that provides food for food-insecure children and families in Dorchester County — handed out bags of food, Patton said.
Todd said National Night Out represents what Cambridge police have been trying to do for the last two years: community-oriented policing.
"It's building relationships between the police and the community," he said. "But also (building) other relationships such as (with) Juvenile Services, the health department, the Dorchester County school system. ... Us all working together to build a stronger community for tomorrow."
According to National Night Out's website, the event was first held in 1984. It aims to promote partnerships between the police and community nationwide, as well as make neighborhoods safer. Patton said the event was created with the intention of having a night without crime in every community.
"And what it does is it brings community together and it gives them a live interaction with law enforcement officers to let the community know that we're working together and we support them just like they support us," he said about the event.
Patton thanked Dorchester County Recreation and Parks for allowing Cambridge police to hold the event at the county pool.
"It was a great event and we look forward to doing it again," he said.

 EASTON — A Cambridge man was handed a life sentence on Friday for the death of of 23-year-old Antonio Smith, who died from a gunshot wound to the head following an incident in the parking lot of Sidetracked Saloon in Easton.According to a news release from the Talbot County State's Attorney's Office, all but 45 years of Kevron Chase's life sentence will be suspended. His incarceration will be followed by five years of probation.
In May, Chase, 35, pleaded guilty to first-degree murder for Smith's death.
According to the news release, Easton Police officers responded to Sidetracked Saloon around 2 a.m. on Sept. 30, 2023. Upon arrival, officers located Smith, with a gunshot wound to the head, surrounded by a crowd of people in the parking lot. Smith was later pronounced dead at the hospital, the news release says.
Smith was born and raised in St. Michaels and was a 2018 graduate of St. Michaels Middle High School, the news release says.
According to previous Star Democrat reporting, in charging documents, police said the bar's security camera footage the night of the shooting showed Chase and Chadnee Harris, 33, of Cambridge, standing between two cars near the entrance of the bar and Smith approaching the two.
According to the documents, Chase pulled a handgun from his waistband area and pointed it at Smith. Chase put the handgun back toward his waistband area and then appeared to hand the gun to Harris, police said.
After a fight broke out, Harris reportedly walked toward the men. A crowd that had gathered quickly dispersed. According to the charging documents, Smith appeared to duck behind a car and Chase walked toward Smith, pointing a handgun at him. The officer who reviewed the footage wrote in charging documents that they saw a muzzle flash from the gun and Smith collapse in between two cars.
At Chase's plea hearing on May 20, Talbot County State's Attorney Joseph Coale said Chase then left the scene and drove to Cambridge, where he disposed of the handgun in the Choptank River.
Chase and Harris were later found during a traffic stop on Race Street in Cambridge. They were both detained by police.
On May 22, Harris was handed a three-year sentence, with all but 236 days suspended, after pleading guilty to altering physical evidence in the incident.

 ANNAPOLIS — On Wednesday, former City of Cambridge Planning and Zoning Director John Steven Kaii-Ziegler pleaded guilty to two counts stemming from a fatal hit-and-run that occurred in Annapolis in January 2023.Kaii-Ziegler pleaded guilty to charges of leaving the scene of an accident involving death and causing injury as the result of operating a vehicle.
On Jan. 12, Kaii-Ziegler, 64, of Annapolis, was indicted in Anne Arundel County in connection to the hit-and-run that occurred on Hilltop Lane in Annapolis. He resigned from his position in Cambridge on Jan. 16. Two days later, Kaii-Ziegler turned himself in to the Annapolis Police Department.

 EASTON — Charges made against a Preston woman for the assault of a toddler were made inactive in the Talbot County District Court at a hearing on Tuesday.In June, Linda Perry, 77, was charged with neglect of a minor, second-degree assault and reckless endangerment for a May 2 incident at Best Buddies Learning Center, a child care facility in Easton.
At a hearing on Tuesday, District Court Judge Karen Ketterman placed Perry's case on the stet docket, making her charges inactive on the conditions that Perry have no contact with the child or the child's family, not provide child care to any non-family member, and complete a mental health evaluation and follow through with any treatment recommendations that come out of that evaluation.

According to court documents, on May 2 Perry was seen putting a 2-year-old boy on a changing table, spanking him on his bare butt and then dropping him to the floor.

According to the document, in the video Perry is seen picking up the crying toddler and walking him over to a changing table. When Perry puts the boy on the changing table, he cries even louder, the document says.
In the video, Perry can be heard telling the boy, "You better not kick me, young man," and "Stop," as she changes his diaper. According to the document, Perry then lifts both of the toddler's legs and audibly smacks him on the butt, causing other teachers in the room to take notice.

In an interview, the parents of the child told Hanson the child might have autism, and they were meeting with doctors to make that determination, the document says.

title: New training center will provide cross-training, easier commute for first responders
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
New training center will provide cross-training, easier commute for first responders

 August 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 731
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — First responders are excited about the benefits a new Emergency Services Training Campus will bring to Talbot County.Construction of a 7,200-square-foot campus at 9095 Mistletoe Drive in Easton is nearing, according to Easton Volunteer Fire Department Chief Sonny Jones. Once completed, the training campus will be run by the Easton Volunteer Fire Department.
The department will coordinate training with the University of Maryland Fire and Rescue Institue, which provides training statewide for firefighters and EMS technicians, including advanced cardiac life support, medical training and emergency vehicle operation training.
Jones and Brian LeCates, director of the Talbot County Department of Emergency Services, are looking forward to cross-training with public safety partners, including town and county police.
"They're great to work with, but it would be awesome to train with them before the emergency happens," Jones said. "I've always said, the first time I meet one of my public safety partners, I don't want it to be at the scene of an emergency. I want to interact with them beforehand so we have a smooth, unified response to an emergency."
"This will ultimately improve the way we are able to respond to our day-to-day emergencies and our large-scale emergencies because we'll be able to train with our partners," LeCates said.
A drive to Centreville, the location of the closest training facility of this type, is difficult for Talbot County firefighters who may live an hour or more away to schedule, Jones said. With a shorter commute, he expects them to take more training.
"Having this facility here, the University of Maryland and their adjunct instructors can host classes right at this facility," Jones said. "So that someone in Tilghman, instead of having to drive 60 miles, may only have to drive 20 or 25 miles."
At an Aug. 5 Easton Town Council meeting, Jones said the construction contract has been awarded to Willow Construction. The goal is to break ground this September or October on the classroom portion of the building. The fire chief hopes to see the entire project completed before the end of 2025.
"We have, what we feel is an attainable goal that probably … fall to winter of next year … you may see the majority if not all of this campus done," Jones said.
Ward 2 Easton Town Council Member and fire department volunteer Don Abbatiello emphasized that the project is "not being built with town money," but instead through fundraising. He commended the "hard work" from those involved in fundraising efforts.
The Friends of the Easton Volunteer Fire Department, a nonprofit fundraising arm of the department, has around $2 million left to raise. President Brett Whitehead said all donations through the end of September are being matched by the A. James and Alice B. Clark Foundation.
A key feature of the facility will be a burn building, which Jones said will be made out of "steel with special materials inside that are heat- and flame-resistant" and allow for repeated burning that will help firefighters train in real-life scenarios.
Jones said he used to train in "acquired structures" that were a "one-time deal" for firefighter training, such as farm houses that were meant to be burned down. The burn building is designed for repeated training.
LeCates also said the larger training center will help his department experience "more real-world scenarios." "Now we can bring in wrecked cars … and put simulated patients in them or some of our rescue mannequins in there," he said.
LeCates added that prospective employees may take notice of the facility, a trend that the fire department hopes to see as well. While Jones said his priority is to "make it easier" on current volunteer firefighters, he acknowledges the high costs and packed work schedules that make it difficult for younger, prospective volunteers to commit to training at facilities in Centreville or Princess Anne.
"Now it's harder to get the younger generation," Jones said of the department's recruiting efforts. "We don't have as many that want to volunteer, and the ones we do are awesome, they're absolutely awesome. They come in, they take all the required training, and they're participating just as well as anybody else."
" … We just don't have as much of an infill of younger people as we used to have."
A previous version of this story incorrectly stated which entity is responsible for managing the training campus. The Easton Volunteer Fire Department will be responsible for the management and operation of the facility.

title: Violence is everywhere, so are those fighting it
author: RIVERA SUN
content:
Violence is everywhere, so are those fighting it

 August 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: RIVERA SUN | Section: Columns 
 
 688
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I'm tired of the violence. Aren't you?Some days, it seems relentless. A mass shooting at a school. Another youth killed by gun violence. A family on the street after fleeing an abusive partner. A genocide halfway around the world. Brutal wars displacing millions.
When will the violence stop?
The answer is: When we take action to stop it, together.
It's not impossible. Communities across the country and around the world are showing us how. Violence may be everywhere, but so are the people trying to stop it. And many of them have powerful antidotes to the violence we face.
During the Campaign Nonviolence Action Days, Sept 21-Oct 2, tens of thousands of people will show everyone that another world is possible.
What does a nonviolent world look like? It's not all roses. Conflict happens — but we have better ways to respond without resorting to violence. Many of these strategies will be on display during the upcoming Action Days: Neighborhood safety patrols to prevent gun violence. Unarmed peace teams de-escalating tension in hot conflict zones worldwide. Anti-bullying programs aimed at preventing the next school shooter. Centers that help mothers and families get back on their feet after leaving abusive situations. Protests pushing banks to divest from weapons.
More than 4,438 actions and events are planned across the United States and around the world to "build a culture of peace and active nonviolence, free from war, poverty, racism, and environmental destruction."
An 11-year-old movement, Campaign Nonviolence aims to end violence in its many forms. This includes direct or physical violence (fights, bullying, war, gun violence) and it also includes systemic violence (houselessness, hunger, mass incarceration and the climate crisis). Going even further, the effort seeks to transform cultural violence as well, the beliefs, attitudes and values that lead to harm and destruction, such as militarism, racism, sexism, xenophobia and homophobia.
Instead, Campaign Nonviolence rallies hundreds of groups and organizations who use nonviolent action and promote nonviolent solutions. Sandy Hook Promise trains thousands of schoolchildren in how to counter social isolation — a factor in mass shootings — with Start With Hello Week. The Nobel Prize-winning International Campaign Against Nuclear Weapons coordinates hundreds of actions to move money out of nukes. The Global Silent Minute synchronizes thousands of people for a moment of prayerful silence for peace on the International Day of Peace, Sept 21. Nonviolent Peaceforce and Cure Violence use de-escalation techniques in conflict zones worldwide to prevent attacks.
Local community groups take powerful action in their neighborhoods. Nonviolent Opelika, Alabama, (part of the nationwide Nonviolent Cities Project) offers trainings and talks on their neighborhood patrols to prevent gun violence. Groups in Honolulu reaffirm their Zone of Peace and Nonviolence in a low-income public housing complex. An elementary school in Little Rock, Arkansas, holds a peace march with all the children. In Detroit, Meta Peace Team trains an entire high school in de-escalation skills.
There are street theater protests at military bases and teach-ins on nonviolent history, such as M.K. Gandhi or Cesar Chavez and the United Farm Workers. There are peace art contests and concerts in public parks. There are marches for ceasefires in Gaza and Ukraine. There are actions to stop environmental destruction and the climate crisis.
Campaign Nonviolence is gearing up for its largest-ever Action Days stretching between the International Day of Peace Sept 21 to the International Day of Nonviolence on Oct 2. In 2023, more than 5,000 actions were held. With weeks to go, there are already 4,438 actions planned for 2024, and hundreds more expected to be added. The campaign calls for a range of nonviolent actions to be used during the 12 days, including labor strike solidarity, divestment from fossil fuels and weapons, racial healing circles, nonviolence teach-ins, peace demonstrations, and violence de-escalation trainings.
When the violence of our world weighs on your heart, connect to the people working to change it. They bring practical solutions and real-life experience. They persist in showing that something else is possible. They invite you to be part of the solution.
Rivera Sun has written numerous books. She is the editor of Nonviolence News, program coordinator for Campaign Nonviolence, and a nationwide trainer in strategy for nonviolent campaigns.

title: Church Hill boy injured when gunpowder explodes
author: ERIC SYLVIA Special to the Kent County News

 CHURCH HILL — Just before midnight on Aug.15, a loud explosion rocked the small Eastern Shore community of Church Hill. After hearing the blast and receiving a 911 call, paramedics from the Church Hill Volunteer Fire Company responded to the home of Amanda Unkart at Laysan Teal Court where a boy was critically injured as a result of the blast.Paramedics arrived to find the boy suffering with injuries to his left hand and eyes. Anthony Sturgill, a close family friend, had tied a piece of a sheet around the boy's arm as a tourniquet while they waited for help to arrive.
Sturgill reported that paramedics were on scene less than 7 minutes after the 911 call. After the initial assessment of the boy's condition, the team worked to prepare him for transport via Maryland State Police helicopter to Johns Hopkins trauma center.
The boy was stabilized by the paramedics onboard the flight and continued to be treated after arriving at the hospital, where he was rushed into surgery.
He is currently in stable condition with non-life threatening injuries, Sturgill said.
The Maryland State Fire Marshal's Office worked with the Queen Anne's County Sheriff's Office and the Maryland State Patrol to preserve the scene and determine the cause of the explosion.
What officials know at this point is that two boys were experimenting with black powder, marbles and a section of electrical conduit, trying to construct a device capable of shooting the marbles at a target set up in the backyard.
As the one boy who was injured held the device, the second boy lit the powder with a lighter. The resulting blast was heard miles away.
Both of the youths involved in the incident have grown up around firearms in the rural neighborhood and are well acquainted with firearms safety measures, Sturgill said. Family members are still trying to understand what led them to attempt such a dangerous stunt. While there are firearms kept in the home which are typically under lock and key, there were no firearms involved in this incident.

title: Rider pleads guilty to first-degree arson, reckless endangerment for house fire
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Rider pleads guilty to first-degree arson, reckless endangerment for house fire

 August 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Crime 
 
 762
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Fred "Trey" Rider III pleaded guilty to first-degree arson and five counts of reckless endangerment at a hearing on Monday for starting a fire at his home in Easton in November 2022.Rider had also been charged with second-degree arson, first-degree malicious burning, two counts of arson threat, two counts of malicious destruction of property, obstruction of emergency assistance and two additional counts of reckless endangerment. As part of a plea deal, the state will not prosecute Rider for those remaining nine charges.
Rider's plea comes five months after he was supposed to stand trial, but failed to appear in court that morning.
At the hearing, Judge Thomas G. Ross said Rider could receive up to 30 years in prison and $50,000 in fines for first-degree arson. He could receive up to 25 years in prison and $25,000 in fines for the five counts of reckless endangerment.
Rider told Ross the state had put pressure on him to plead guilty, but he was making the decision freely. Rider said he was pleading guilty to the six charges because he is guilty and he believes it is in his best interest.
On Nov. 24, 2022, just after 8 p.m., 45 firefighters responded to a fire in Rider's two-story, single-family home at 27930 Peach Orchard Road in Easton.
At the hearing on Monday, Talbot County Deputy State's Attorney Joyce Jones said that on that night, Rider had been angry with his wife for taking their sons to see relatives for Thanksgiving, and he began threatening her.
According to court documents, Rider reportedly blamed his wife for all of his troubles and stated he was going to burn the house down.
That night, according to charging documents, the two driveways to Rider's home were blocked with vehicles: Rider's truck and a golf cart. Jones said Rider did this before intentionally setting fire to his family's home. Several people on the scene were able to push the golf cart out of the way so fire engines could begin suppression efforts, according to the charging documents.
It took the responding firefighters over 30 minutes to control the fire with a tanker task force.
A person connected to Rider told officials Rider had clearly indicated to him that he was attempting suicide and wanted to be left alone, according to charging documents. Rider also reportedly told the person that he lit the house on fire.
Jones said Rider hid within sight of the house after setting fire to it and watched it burn down. She said Rider let firefighters search for him in the house rather than tell them he wasn't inside it. She said some firefighter gear had to be decommissioned because it had been burned so badly.
That night, Rider was located a short distance away from his home and transported to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Easton for emergency care. Rider's attorney Christine DuFour said Rider was under the influence of alcohol during the incident and had slit his wrists.
Through investigation, officials identified the fire as an act of human intervention with an open flame, classifying the cause of the fire as incendiary. According to court documents, Rider's reckless conduct in igniting the house on fire "clearly" put the firefighters who responded in danger.
The day after the fire, Rider's wife filed a petition for a protective order against him, citing verbal threats of abuse, mental abuse and property destruction from Rider in the months leading up to the fire.
A sentencing hearing for Rider is set for Oct. 4, following Rider's ongoing divorce proceedings.
At a June status hearing for the case, DuFour said it would be helpful to know the outcome of the divorce before Rider is handed a sentence because the divorce will have an affect on the sentencing.
Rider was supposed to stand trial March 4, but at a status hearing that morning, Ross said Rider had been voluntarily admitted to Johns Hopkins Hospital and issued a bench warrant for Rider's failure to appear in court that morning. After getting discharged, Rider was granted a request to be transferred to an alcohol and drug rehab facility for 60 days, with the condition that he return to the Talbot County Detention Center upon completing the program.
On May 14, the detention center was ordered to release Rider on a previously posted $20,000 unsecured bond. Rider was released on conditions including that he surrender his passport, he reside in a sober living home in Pasadena, he attend Alcoholics Anonymous and Narcotics Anonymous meetings and he enroll in mental health services.
Rider will remain at the sober living facility until his sentencing, DuFour said on Monday.

 CAMBRIDGE — The Dorchester County State's Attorney's Office will not prosecute a Cambridge man for charges relating to an August 2023 shooting at Maces Lane and Bayly Road.Shallamar Robinson, 47, was arrested last August for attempted first- and second-degree murder, firearm use in a felony violent crime, first- and second-degree assault, reckless endangerment, reckless endangerment from a car, handgun on person, handgun in vehicle, loaded handgun on person and loaded handgun in vehicle.
The State's Attorney's Office will not prosecute Robinson for any of these 11 charges. Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard said the state made this decision because it felt there was insufficient evidence to prove that Robinson is guilty of the charges beyond a reasonable doubt.
According to previous Star Democrat reporting, police said officers met with a victim at the Cambridge Police Department on Aug. 16 in reference to a shooting. The victim told police that as they came to the intersection, there was another vehicle there. As the victim passed by, the subject in the other vehicle fired multiple shots at the victim, who was not struck, police said.
Robinson was identified as the shooter by the victim, police said. When officers responded to Maces Lane and Bayly Road, where the shooting was alleged to have occurred, they located multiple rounds of spent .45 caliber ammunition as well as a live round of ammunition, police said.
Robinson was arrested two days later at the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Cambridge.
Robinson's attorney Brad MacFee said Robinson was "extremely relieved" and "beyond excited" when he learned the state would not be prosecuting the case. MacFee said Robinson had been dealing with this "nightmare" situation for about a year and had been concerned about potentially having to be away from his children.
MacFee said Leonard made the right decision. He said there would be credibility issues associated with the alleged victim and that, at the end of the day, there was not enough evidence to convict Robinson.

 The Maryland State Highway Administration has sent out an invitation for contractors to bid on a clean-up contract for a homeless camp located at Crain Highway and Mattawoman Beantown Road north of Waldorf in Charles County."Contractor shall provide all labor and expertise for surveying, documenting, clean-up, collecting, removal, and disposal services involving homeless encampment abatement actions on MDOT SHA property located in Charles County under an 'as needed' agreement basis," the contract's summary reads.
The contract provides for the dismantling, clean-up and disposal of temporary housing structures, including tents, mattresses and blankets.
Further, clean-up and disposal of trash and debris, like overfill from dumpsters, cardboard and tires is also listed. Disposal of biohazardous waste, including human bodily fluids and waste and drug paraphernalia is also covered in the contract.
"The site must be restored to a condition without obvious evidence of previous human habitation," the contract states.
A spokesperson for Charles County government said that due to the area in question being along two state roads, the encampment is largely a state situation.
The issue itself may not be new, according to Corae Young, the chief operating officer of Lifestyles of Maryland, which assists people who are homeless in Charles County.
She told Southern Maryland News that there was another camp in the area roughly a year ago that Lifestyles had helped the State Highway Administration in delivering notices to clear out.
"I believe what occurred is people moved close by," Young said.
A site visit was conducted the morning of Aug. 21, where a reporter with Southern Maryland News was in attendance.
While there was an ample amount of debris and trash strewn about the wooded site, there were also multiple lived-in tents in the encampment.
One individual who is homeless emerged from his tent to see contractors walking around.
Bikes, shopping carts, bags, mattresses, cardboard, propane tanks and bottles littered the area. To get the area to the "condition without obvious evidence of previous human habitation" specified in the contract will likely be an uphill battle.
In light of there still being inhabitants in the camp, Southern Maryland News reached out to the State Highway Administration at the conclusion of the site tour.
"SHA works in partnership with local agencies, including support and outreach services and law enforcement, to assist those residing on state rights-of-way. Connecting them with agencies that can provide relocation assistance, housing or other support services has proven to be a successful approach," Daniel Allman of the agency's communications office said in an email.
State workers inform those residing on state rights-of-way that they are on state property before cleaning an area, he said, adding that there is a 30- to 60-day timeframe for them to relocate. Despite the contract seeking bids, Allman said, "At this time, there is no work scheduled for this location."
Bids on the contract are due Aug. 28. The contract sets no exact start date for the work, and relocation efforts were uncertain as of this week.

title: A community of motorcycle enthusiasts advocate for each other
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
A community of motorcycle enthusiasts advocate for each other

 August 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 678
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Thursday evening, a man with a long beard lead a group of motorcycle enthusiasts in a meeting of the American Bikers Against Totalitarian Enactments. Ken Eaton, executive director for ABATE, has devoted his life to the open road, freedom of choice, and his bike.This group is part of a national organization dedicated to "Freedom of the Road and Responsible Motorcycle Legislation," according to the ABATE website.
Eaton said he has been riding a motorcycle for decades.
"For me, it's kind of a release and a sense of freedom," Eaton said. "There's a lot of things that may or may not go on during the day in people's jobs or lives. Sometimes you get on a motorcycle and you can just leave that behind and enjoy the sounds and the sights on the road and relax."
The organization is pushing for changes to already existing Maryland law around fatal accidents, advocating that drivers who cause a death should face mandatory court appearances rather than just paying a fine.
"Happened to our director in 2006 right here in Easton," Eaton said. "He got hit by a driver that ran a stop sign and killed him, and they didn't have to appear in court. Paid a fine for running a stop sign and never had to show up. That very same person that died in that accident was the person who got me involved in ABATE."
According to Eaton, ABATE members are all pushed to be politically active at the local, state and national level for these very reasons.
Eaton said ABATE has a long history of legislation, such as opposing excessive noise bills that target motorcycles.
"One of the bills that has come up in the last several years, and we've been able to defeat is an excessive noise bill," Eaton said. "It seems like it probably has a good intention ... (But) there are a lot of motorcycles out there that are pretty loud."
Hilton Thomas, a member of ABATE, said he has been a member for three years and has been riding a motorcycle for over 50 years. For Hilton, the work that ABATE does for the safety of riders is what he admires the most about the organization.
"They do a lot of things for motorcyclists," Thomas said. "We have a lot of issues that we try to solve. When people cut grass, they throw grass on the road. We try to get that against the law. It's hazardous to motorcycles."
For other members, it is ABATE's focus on community that drew them in.
Tammy Lenske said it is the community building that she loves about the organization. Lenske began riding less than five years ago. Her boyfriend is an avid rider, and she said she would ride with him on his bike, but now she has her own bike and rides beside him.
Lenske said she loves the community work that ABATE does, including toy drives during Christmas, fundraisers and a memorial ride, which she is the lead planner for. The memorial ride gathers motorcyclists to honor passed members by stopping at several cemeteries and putting flowers and flags down on their graves.
"We help each other out," Lenske said. "If there's someone in our group with a problem. We're all there. We have this one guy in our group who had a massive stroke, and he used to ride all the time, and he had a big American flag, and his bike's all decked out in American flags, and he can't ride right now, but we're behind him, and we go visit him."
For Eaton, ABATE had made riding a motorcycle less of a hobby and a more central part of his life. It is important to him that the safety of motorcyclists is not forgotten.
"We want people to look for motorcycles but the other side of that is I also want motorcyclists to be aware of their surroundings and be ready before they jump on the bike and hit the road," Eaton said. "... Cars need to watch out for us, but we also need to be prepared and to watch out for them."

 EASTON — An effort to honor past and present veterans, firefighters and police officers gained momentum at the Easton Town Council on Monday evening.Joan Harris-Brooks, speaking on behalf of Blake-Blackston American Legion Post 77, asked the council to partner with the group in creating a banner program so that families of Talbot County veterans, firefighters and officers can honor their loved ones.
Harris-Brooks said the banners would be placed on Ward 4 roads such as Glenwood Avenue, Port Street and West Street. Her father, John Harris Jr., and her uncle were members of Post 77, which operates on Glenwood Avenue.
With members of Post 77 in attendance, council members expressed nothing but support for the project.
"I think that this is a great endeavor," Ward 4 Council Member the Rev. Elmer Davis said. "(It's important) that we don't lose the memory of those persons who fought for our country. I believe it's our responsibility to help out with this project. Secondly, it doesn't cost the town a dime."
The Hometown Heroes Banner program began in 2006 in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania. Today, Mid-Shore towns including Federalsburg, Hurlock and Preston showcase banners honoring past and present veterans.
Harris-Brooks said the banners would cost $200 each. There will be no ask of the council to provide any money for the project.
She asked that the town office hold blank applications for interested families, in addition to applications being advertised on social media and at Post 77.
"It will instill a sense of pride and unity in Easton and for our country," Harris-Brooks told the council. "It is our goal that you grant us approval. And we believe that if you grant us an approval, this will make a landmark for you as our councilmen."
Council members unanimously approved the request. Prior to voting, the council expressed hopes that the banner project could extend to the entire town.
Harris-Brooks said that Post 77 will accept donations from the community that can help families who cannot afford the cost of a banner. She added that Post 77 will work with American Legion Talbot Post 70, Easton Utilities and the town as the project comes to life.

title: 'Generational trauma': Man sentenced to life in prison for 1979 murder
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content:
'Generational trauma': Man sentenced to life in prison for 1979 murder

 August 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 756
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Andre Taylor was sentenced last week to life in prison for a murder he committed 45 years ago.Taylor, 63, was convicted of the first-degree murder of Vickie Lynn Belk by a Charles County jury on July 18. Circuit Court Judge H. James West handed down the sentence on Aug. 23.
On Aug. 28, 1979, Belk's then-boyfriend reported her missing to the Prince George's County Police Department after last seeing her on Aug. 27 at their shared place of work in Washington, D.C.
Belk had not returned to her apartment in Suitland, a release from the Charles County State Attorney's Office said.
On Aug. 29, 1979, a local teenager called 911 after noticing a body on the ground in a wooded location in the area of Metropolitan Church Road and Route 227 in Bryans Road.
Officers with the Charles County Sheriff's Office responded to the location and discovered the body of a woman with a gunshot wound to the right side of her head and undressed from the waist down, the release said.
Belk was identified the following day as the woman. The Office of the Chief Medical Examiner in Baltimore ruled her cause of death to be from the gunshot wound, the release said.
Investigators recovered, processed and maintained evidence during the initial investigation. However, the case went cold.
In the following years, several detectives worked on the case. In more recent years, Detective Sgt. John Elliott of the Charles County Sheriff's Office's Criminal Investigations Division continued the investigation and worked with various agencies to pursue leads.
As forensic technology advanced, the evidence of the murder continued to be re-examined. In 2022, the Charles sheriff's office's Forensic Science Section re-evaluated the evidence and submitted Belk's clothing for testing with newer technology. A profile was developed and entered into the Combined DNA Index System, a national DNA database.
On Nov. 1, 2022, Noelle Gehrman, the deputy director of the county sheriff's office's Forensic Science Section, was notified of a DNA match between the profiles developed from the evidence and Taylor, the release said.
While investigating Taylor's background, detectives learned that he was arrested for violent crimes that occurred in Washington, D.C. It was also discovered that Taylor lived at a residence in Bryans Road around the time of the murder.
The address was less than four miles from where Belk's body was discovered. Taylor also had connections to the area of Washington, D.C., where it is believed that Belk was abducted.
Detectives began trying to locate Taylor, but he had no known address since 2019. In collaboration with the U.S. Homeland Security Investigations, D.C. Metropolitan Police Department and the U.S. Secret Service Baltimore Field Office, detectives of the Charles sheriff's office were able to locate Taylor in Washington, D.C., where he resided.
On June 22, 2023, Taylor was arrested by the Charles County Sheriff's Office, the U.S. Marshals Service, Capital Area Regional Fugitive Task Force and members of the Metropolitan Police Department.
In an interview with detectives, Taylor admitted to actions that amounted to the rape of Belk, but he denied having any part in her murder, the release said.
At the time of the murder, Belk was 28 years old, and Taylor was 18 years old. There is no evidence that indicates that Belk and Taylor knew each other before the incident, according to the release.
During sentencing, Assistant State's Attorney John Stackhouse told the judge that the incident caused "generational trauma because it went on for 45 years. [Belk's] son grew up without a mother. Her parents had to bury their daughter. Her parents had to lay on their deathbed not knowing who killed their daughter. Her grandchildren never got a chance to meet their grandmother. Yet all throughout this case, I've never seen a family with so much grit, determination and grace."
Stackhouse added, "When you victimize someone like this and then murder them, it really doesn't get more horrific than that."
Echoing the word of Belk's son, he asked the judge to "use the power you have to get justice, and justice in this case is life [in prison]."
Before sentencing Taylor to life in prison, West said that Belk "had a presence or spirit that has endured in ways that I've honestly never seen before," furthering that the "victim leaves a tremendous legacy, and the family carries on a tremendous legacy."
The judge also stated that "the crime is a horrific loss of a life — the violence was extreme. The amount of fear and terror that preceded the violence doesn't exist in most cases. [The incident was] so heinous, I can't think of a lesser sentence that would be appropriate."
