title: Justice Department sues companies for bridge collapse
author: CAIT KELLEY and CALEY FOX SHANNON Capital News Service
content:
Justice Department sues companies for bridge collapse

 September 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: CAIT KELLEY and CALEY FOX SHANNON Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 416
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — The Department of Justice filed a lawsuit Wednesday against the owner and the operator of the ship that collided with the Francis Scott Key Bridge in March, asking for more than $100 million to recoup the cost of extensive cleanup efforts to reopen the Fort McHenry Channel.The Justice Department asserted that the companies' conduct in sending the container ship Dali down the Patapsco River was "outrageous, grossly negligent, willful, wanton, and reckless."
The suit claimed that "the Dali got underway with known unseaworthy conditions in confined waters where a ship of its magnitude had every opportunity to cause catastrophic damage and loss of life, which in fact happened."
The defendants in the civil suit, filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland, are the Singapore-based corporations Grace Ocean Private Limited, which owned the Dali, and Synergy Marine Private Limited, the Dali's operator.
Representatives for the companies did not respond to requests for comment.
The bridge collapse resulted in the death of six road workers and impeded operations in the Port of Baltimore until the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and U.S. Navy Supervisor of Salvage and Diving completed the cleanup in June.
"The Justice Department is committed to ensuring accountability for those responsible for the destruction of the Francis Scott Key Bridge, which resulted in the tragic deaths of six people and disrupted our country's transportation and defense infrastructure," Attorney General Merrick Garland said in a statement.
This suit from the DOJ is a response to Grace Ocean and Synergy's petition to the court in April "for exoneration from or limitation of liability" for damages resulting from the collision. In that claim, the companies asked that their liability be limited to $43.67 million for the damage to the ship and its cargo.
In the 53-page filing Wednesday, the Justice Department detailed a litany of mechanical and electrical flaws in the Dali that led to collision with the bridge. The suit alleges that Grace Ocean and Synergy were aware of these issues and that Dali's crew mishandled the ship's approach to the bridge after two power outages occurred in the early hours of March 26.
"This was an entirely avoidable catastrophe, resulting from a series of eminently foreseeable errors made by the owner and operator of the Dali," Principal Deputy Assistant Attorney General Brian Boynton said in a statement.
On Tuesday, families of the victims of the bridge collapse announced at a press conference they will be filing their own legal claim to hold the owner of the Dali liable.

title: Scammers look to lure voters to get information
author: MORGAN LEASON Capital News Service
content:
Scammers look to lure voters to get information

 September 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MORGAN LEASON Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 549
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Scammers posing as election workers are trying to mislead Maryland voters with fraudulent text messages, prompting concerns at the State Board of Elections.The scammers are telling voters they're not registered to vote in November and then urging them to click a false link to remedy that, according to Jared DeMarinis, the board's state administrator of elections.
"They're capitalizing on the hypertension involving this election," DeMarinis said in an interview with Capital News Service. "The text message is urgent, and they're playing on a fear that an individual is not registered to vote when they really are."
He said he worries that texting scams of this nature could have a sweeping impact on the election, especially if they mislead voters about whether they're registered and eligible to vote.
"The impact of this is to create a new narrative and foster disinformation about voter roles," DeMarinis said.
Similar incidents of text scams have been reported in Illinois, Georgia and Pennsylvania already this year. In Peoria County, for example, text scammers also meant to deceive voters into registering to vote by mail through a false link.
Ensuring the integrity of elections and maintaining public trust are critical issues for Maryland election officials and the nation, especially as the 2024 election nears and texting scams become more prevalent.
As the state elections administrator, DeMarinis is tasked with administering and conducting elections and creating consistent policy and application of the laws in Maryland.
The Maryland board was already working to recruit election judges, track mail-in ballots and secure the local elections. Now, they must also battle continuous threats to undermine public trust in elections.
According to the board, the text scam informs recipients that public records show they are not registered at their address. The matter is "URGENT," the text says. The text then invites the recipient to click a fake link to register before the deadline.
The board's website lists the valid sources for voter registration, polling locations, mail-in ballot status and ways to vote. The board is also reminding voters that trusted information will come from a .gov web address.
DeMarinis told CNS he is determined to combat the spread of disinformation by being proactive on social media. He also encouraged people to contact him or the state board to verify information.
"You don't wait until things hit critical mass," he said, "you combat this information and correct the record immediately."
The board created a portal on its website where people can report instances of scamming and disinformation. DeMarinis said he plans to work with social media platforms to help correct false information.
He said that if scam efforts rise to the level of voter disenfranchisement or suppression, the board will work with law enforcement to ensure that Marylanders are "free to vote, without any sort of undue influence."
As the general election approaches with only 48 days left and early voting starting on Sept. 23, the threat of these scammers remains high. The public must remain vigilant and in the meantime, the board will continue its efforts to combat scams and safeguard the integrity of the election, he said.
"These scams are a direct threat to the legitimacy of the electoral process, because, at best, they're just trying to steal identities," DeMarinis said. "But at worst, they're there to kind of sow distrust in an election administration and undermine confidence in the system."

title: Motorists encouraged to watch for deer as breeding season approaches
author: Tom McCall
content:
Motorists encouraged to watch for deer as breeding season approaches

 September 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 505
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — As deer breeding season nears, motorists are encouraged to keep their eyes peeled for white tails on the road.Local auto repair businesses say they are busier fixing collisions this time of year. Hitting a deer can cause thousands of dollars worth of damage, bending front fenders, crumpling hoods and cracking front windshields.
"It is about 20% to 30% more this time of year," said TJ Jefferson of Grants Automotive in Easton. "I get more calls early in the morning, 'Can you come get my car? I just struck a deer or a deer just struck me.'"
With increased volume during deer season, he says they just get it done with the available manpower that they have.
According to data from State Farm, "U.S. drivers had an estimated 1.8 million animal collision insurance claims in the U.S. between July 2022 and June 2023."
About 1.5 million deer-car accidents happen every year. More than $1 billion in annual insured losses are due to damages caused by deer-car accidents. According to State Farm, Maryland drivers have a one-in-116-vehicle likelihood risk for animal collisions. The highest risk state for deer-car collisions is West Virginia at one in 37 vehicles.
Deer breeding season begins in October and runs through mid-December. During these months, bucks become more active, seeking out female deer. The females move around more to avoid the bucks. All this motion means more deer are on the roads.
Deer are most active between the hours of 5 and 8 a.m. and again from 5 to 8 p.m., which are also hours that many drivers are on the road commuting to or from work.
Trooper Ian Rola of the Easton Barracks of the Maryland State Police said, "The incidents that rise this time of year are car accidents. (Deer) are in rut and are running all over and crossing the roadway. It is usually up this time of year — in the November time frame."
Rola and fellow law enforcement officers work to help keep roadways clear of hazards during these peak months.
"It is between law enforcement and SHA. We try to keep the roads clear. We rely on the public. If you see a carcass, give us a call, and we will come out. If it is a mess, we call SHA (State Highway Administration) to help," Rola said.
Rola emphasized the importance of drivers slowing down and wearing seat belts, especially as deer breeding season approaches.
"You have got to imagine, you hit a dear, you slam on the brakes and you are going forward at the same time. The seat belt will stop that forward momentum. This saves a lot of injuries from deer accidents," he said.
Representatives from the State Highway Administration encouraged drivers to avoid making sudden turns or movements to avoid hitting deer.
"Making sudden, sharp turns is dangerous as it could place the driver in the path of oncoming traffic or cause your vehicle to strike a fixed object such as a tree or utility pole," wrote Charlie Gischlar of the Maryland Department of Transportation State Highway Administration in an email.

 U.S. Customs and Border Protection officers at the Port of Wilmington seized a shipment of counterfeit designer handbags bound for Newark, authorities said.CPB officers initially inspected the shipment on Sept. 4 after it arrived via express air cargo from China. The shipment, which was heading to an address in Newark, consisted of 26 handbags bearing luxury brand names, such as Chanel, Goyard, Gucci, Hermes, Loewe and Louis Vuitton.
Officers suspected that the handbags may be counterfeit and detained the shipment to verify the authenticity of the handbags' trademarks. CBP's trade experts verified that the handbags were counterfeit and subject to seizure pursuant to the agency's statutory and regulatory authorities.
Had the handbags been genuine, they would have been worth more than $150,000.
The international trade in counterfeit consumer goods is illegal, CBP spokesman Steve Sapp said.

Counterfeiters often manufacture consumer goods using substandard materials and parts that either break prematurely or that could hurt consumers. Counterfeit consumer goods may also be sourced or manufactured in facilities that employ forced labor.
"Unscrupulous vendors that peddle counterfeit consumer goods continue to place their profits over your health and safety. Customs and Border Protection urges you to protect your families by purchasing authentic consumer products from reputable retailers," said Erik Kelling, CBP's port director for the Port of Wilmington.
The most recent incidents came two weeks after CBP officers in Wilmington seized 277 counterfeit Lululemon Everywhere Belt Bags, valued at nearly $13,000 had they been authentic.

 CHESTERTOWN — Every first and third Wednesday, the Kent County Sheriff's Office K-9 unit, cooperating with law enforcement in Talbot, Dorchester and Caroline counties, train their dogs.On Wednesday, Sept. 18, they trained at Geno's Automotive in Kent County. After that, the K-9 units were invited to the Kent County Middle School to receive something special.
In a gesture of police support, the Kent Puppy Pals 4-H Dog Club donated a Line of fire Defense Street Fighter vest to Addy, a German Shepherd, handled by Dfc. Craig Lewis of the Dorchester County Sheriff's Office.
Going through Kent County Sheriff's Office Sgt. Scott Lockerman's organization, the Maryland Police K9 Foundation, the Puppy Pals donated a check for $300 in June.
Club Leader of Puppy Pals Kim Montooth explained each year they do a service project. Last year, for instance, they raised money for the Humane Society. This year was exciting for the kids and something different, Montooth said.
Molly's Place also donated $1,000 in a vest for Waylon, a K-9 black lab handled by Pfc. Nick Lang of the Easton Police Department.
In front of about 20 people, the dogs modeled the vests, which are lightweight enough yet specially designed to protect their vital organs.
Then the Puppy Pals kids and their families gathered around to pet the dogs.
After the children met with the dogs and 4-H mom Karri Bryant had a playful tug of war with Addy, they were invited into the school where they witnessed a live demonstration of how Addy sniffs out controlled substances.
Controlled substances were stashed in two classrooms. Led by Lewis, sniffing desks and drawers, Addy alerted to the controlled substance in both rooms in about 30 seconds.
Trainer Mark Carr of Tidewater Strategic Services said the dog doesn't go right to the spot because of the nature of scent itself. The K-9 moves around the perimeter of the room, getting the entire scent. Once she gets a complete picture, she can hone in.
President of the club Trenton Montooth was impressed. At 14 years of age, he has decided he wants to be a K-9 officer.
Lockerman thanked the Puppy Pals and Molly's Place, expressing the importance of their giving by showing the positive impact K-9 dogs make.

 An 80-year-old man retrieved a gun when his adult son attempted to break into his Conowingo residence on Tuesday, Sept. 24 and then fatally shot him, according to Maryland State Police.As of Thursday, criminal charges had not been filed against the alleged shooter.
Investigators identified Joe Berry Jr., 53, of Conowingo, as the victim. Police said the father is cooperating with investigators.

 CAMBRIDGE — Following an incident at Génesis Food Market on Washington Street, the establishment's owner has been arrested for assault.Alex Perez, 38, of St. Michaels, was arrested for first- and second-degree assault and reckless endangerment.
According to a news release from the Cambridge Police Department, officers received a report that someone was shoplifting at the store Perez owns. When the officers arrived, they found one man sitting down and two men standing next to him. Police said one of the men standing was holding a hammer and the man sitting was bleeding from his hand.

According to the petition — which had 356 signatures as of Monday afternoon — Perez was arrested for defending his business. It calls on law enforcement and courts to review Perez's case, drop the charges and re-examine the law when it comes to small businesses defending themselves.
Perez's niece Cindy Chun said in an interview with the Star Democrat that the charges should be dropped because there were no cameras, so it is one person's word against another, and the news release doesn't share Perez's side.
Chun said Perez — who also owns three businesses in Easton and one in St. Michaels — is a loving father and husband and a great boss.

 EASTON — The Talbot County Department of Social Services hosted a child safety presentation Monday evening at the Talbot County Free Library to educate adults and children ages 3 to 12 on best practices to avoid child abuse.Paris Quillet, special projects coordinator for the department, presented the "Empower Me!" presentation, based on resources from the Jacob Wetterling Resource Center, a program that works to prevent child sexual abuse.
The county receives around 400 reports of child sexual abuse, physical abuse or neglect each year, she said.
"We want to talk about safety for our bodies the same way that we talk about fire drills and active shooter safety and bike safety," Quillet said.
Quillet emphasized to parents that the program avoids "stranger danger" terminology since over 90% of child sexual abuse nationwide is perpetrated by someone who the child knows. Instead, the program keys on the behavior aspect.
"We really want to make sure that we're giving these clear (messages) to children to focus on the behavior and how somebody makes us feel or what they're asking us to do, as opposed to the relationship," Quillet said.
In the children's portion of the program, children were encouraged to identify five trusted adults. Quillet encouraged parents and guardians to "be comfortable that (they) might not be the person that (children) come to for everything."
Having trusted adults in different spaces is important not just for young children but also teenagers, Quillet noted. With the dangers of technology and the internet, she said the 12- to 17-year-old age range is "more vulnerable than ever."
"We see a lot of things locally that revolve around technology and often used as a grooming practice," she said.
At the end of the hourlong presentation, Quillet said parents should stay involved in their children's activities and choose caregivers carefully.
"There should never be a time where I'm not allowed to have access to my children or I'm not allowed to watch them," she said. "… Screen all your caregivers carefully. Ask for references, definitely do unannounced visits."

title: Eastern Shore residents assist survivors of Hurricane Helene
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado

Eastern Shore residents assist survivors of Hurricane Helene

 October 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 CAMBRIDGE — In an effort to do their part, a group of Eastern Shore residents have come together to send a truck of donated urgent relief supplies for areas affected by Hurricane Helene.Members of the Eastern Shore Hurricane Relief Committee have been in the works with Hurricane Helene Airlift Relief, an organization based at the Statesville Regional Airport in North Carolina using private small planes and helicopters to land donations past multiple bridge and road collapses.
Helene, a monstrous category 4 hurricane, has devastated communities across six states, including North Carolina, where over 56 deaths have been reported thus far.
Mike Detmer, an organizer for the donation drive, said supplies have been donated by Eastern Shore locals through drop off stations they established in Hurlock and Cambridge.
Detmer said they encouraged people to donate only items listed by the Hurricane Helene Airlift Relief. Those items include, but are not limited to, diapers, baby formula, non-perishable food, feminine care products, hand sanitizer, and toothbrushes and toothpaste.
Detmer said he is surprised by the vast amount of support the initiative has received from the Eastern Shore.
"In the face of such a terrible disaster, it's been really encouraging to see the volume of response, and I'm thankful for it, and I hope to be able to work with all of our neighbors here to send it to people who need help," Detmer said.
Lindsay Wheatley, an organizer for the donation drive, said on Monday she and Detmer were casually talking about the devastation in North Carolina and felt the urge to find ways they could help.
Wheatley said they contacted Eddie James, an owner of Koski Trucking in Dorchester County, and the company generously donated a truck and driver to take desperately needed items to the Statesville staging area. According to Wheatley, James, who previously has worked in disaster relief, was eager to do his part.
Wheatley said through social media they were able to quickly gather community resources together.
Additionally, Wheatley said her husband and one of the owners of Koski Trucking will be heading down to North Carolina in their private vehicles with chainsaws, materials and tools to try to help out in anyway they can.
"At the end of the day, community, family, that's really all that you have," Wheatley said. "And in times of need, you just hope that others show up and help, and that's what we're trying to do."

author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com

Nonprofit hosts meeting to discuss concerns at apartment complex outside Ridgely

 HILLSBORO — Residents and community members gathered at Allen AME Church on Saturday to speak about safety concerns at an apartment complex just outside of Ridgely.Residents of the Dayspring Apartments, located off of School Street close to the Ridgely town line, have voiced worries from since early this year. Those worries intensified after a non-fatal shooting outside of the apartment complex in August.
Bridge Maryland Inc., a nonprofit organization based in Baltimore County, organized a public meeting Saturday to facilitate discussion of housing justice, water equity and safety in the area of the complex. More than 50 people were in attendance.
Trina Ewell, a resident of the Dayspring Apartments for five years, outlined her concerns, ranging from safety, to management, to mold found in bedrooms and bathrooms.
"I feel outraged that nothing has been done," Ewell said, "that all families that live back here in the neighborhood are ignored, and we have been ignored for long."
Ewell said property management has been largely unresponsive to tenants. Attempts by The Star Democrat to reach the property manager or the management company, East Coast Property Management, were unsuccessful.
Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker attended the meeting, emphasizing his commitment to work with property management and the local neighborhood association that Bridge Maryland is assisting.
"I met with the management group about a year ago and was promised that a lot of these things would be fixed," Baker said on Saturday. "And we're still waiting on it now. But to my knowledge, the county commissioners have been working, and they have gotten the cameras up and running. They are working on the lighting. They are working on the shrubbery and the other things that affect our job in law enforcement."
As Baker described efforts to improve safety in the area, he was met with applause from the crowd.
"It has to be a working relationship," Baker said. "It has to be law enforcement and the management group to make sure that citizens are safe in that community. And I am absolutely, 100% behind helping and making that community a much better and safer place."
County police responded to a shooting on Aug. 10 outside of the complex in which one man was injured. Residents such as Ewell have expressed lasting effects from the shooting.
"My son's bedroom faces the street," Ewell said. "He could feel the vibration of the gunshots in which brought on (a) panic attack for my son that night. … It has brought ongoing panic attacks for him."
Sandra Pitts lives on School Street, near the apartment complex. She has worked with Bridge Maryland in recent months and spoke at Saturday's meeting, noting flooding concerns on School Street.
Pitts says those who live in Dayspring are often afraid to speak up, a role she doesn't mind taking. She said the work of Bridge Maryland has been critical in advancing efforts of the local residents.
"I think they're doing a good job and I think things have really grown," Pitts said in an interview.
As president of Bridge Maryland and pastor of Allen AME Church, the Rev. Angelique Mason spoke during Saturday's meeting. She thanked attendees and explained that Bridge Maryland's water equity team assembled environmental leaders to focus "on the failing waste system that sits on Daysprings."
"This is what community looks like," Mason said. "This is what real power looks like."

title: Maryland spends millions to settle lawsuits every year, officials don't like it
author: SOFIA APPOLONIO Capital News Service
content:
Maryland spends millions to settle lawsuits every year, officials don't like it

 October 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SOFIA APPOLONIO Capital News Service | Section: News 
 
 322
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The state of Maryland is spending millions of dollars to settle lawsuits every year, and top elected officials aren't happy about it.At a meeting of the Board of Public Works on Wednesday, two officials questioned why the state was being asked to approve yet another payout – this one having to do with strip searches by public safety employees.
Although the board approved the $50,000 settlement request, Comptroller Brooke Lierman and Treasurer Dereck E. Davis questioned the prison agency's decision to settle instead of heading to trial.
"If somebody has been wronged, we should be paying that person and the employees should be retrained or released, but we can't have strip searches that were done properly cost the state $50,000 each," Lierman said.
The request stems from a lawsuit alleging misconduct by employees during a strip search, but the Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services did not detail the case at the public meeting.
Joseph Sedtal, the agency's deputy secretary of administration, told the board that the employees involved in the suit followed proper procedures regarding strip searches.
But, Sedtal said, it's difficult to go to trial and prove this because, due to privacy concerns, there are no cameras allowed in the strip search room.
Often, he said a case is the defendant's word against that of the facility.
Even though the board voted to approve the settlement, Lierman asked that the agency come back with more information.
She asked for follow-up on how many such cases are filed, how often the state fully litigates them and how many result in complete dismissals.
State Treasurer Dereck E. Davis questioned the logic, asking whether juries would be more inclined to believe the defendants over the correctional officers if the officers proceeded with proper protocol.
"I would like to think settlements are more of a rarity as opposed to a regularity," Davis said. "It bothers me because this is money, public dollars that I know could be put to good use."

title: Trey Rider sentenced to 15 months at detention center for house fire
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Trey Rider sentenced to 15 months at detention center for house fire

 October 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 590

 EASTON — Fred "Trey" Rider III has been ordered to turn himself into the Talbot County Detention Center on Monday morning to serve 15 months for reckless endangerment. His charges stem from a fire he started at his home in November 2022.At a sentencing hearing Friday, Judge Thomas G. Ross also handed Rider a 20-year sentence for first-degree arson with all but the time he's already served suspended. Rider was given five years of probation with conditions that include attending Alcoholics Anonymous and Narcotics Anonymous meetings and completing an abuser intervention program.
In August, Rider pleaded guilty to first-degree arson and five counts of reckless endangerment for a fire started at his home in Easton on Nov. 24, 2022. He faced up to 30 years in prison and $50,000 in fines for first-degree arson and up to 25 years in prison and $25,000 in fines for the five counts of reckless endangerment.
Rider had also been charged with second-degree arson, first-degree malicious burning, two counts of arson threat, two counts of malicious destruction of property, obstruction of emergency assistance and two additional counts of reckless endangerment. As part of a plea deal, the state did not prosecute Rider for those nine additional charges.
Forty-five firefighters responded to the fire in Rider's two-story, single-family home at 27930 Peach Orchard Road in Easton. Through investigation, officials classified the fire as incendiary.
According to court documents, Rider's reckless conduct in igniting the house on fire "clearly" put the firefighters who responded in danger.
At Rider's plea hearing, Talbot County Deputy State's Attorney Joyce Jones said Rider blocked his two driveways with vehicles before setting fire to the house.
That night, Rider was located a short distance from his home and transported to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Easton for emergency care. Rider's attorney Christine DuFour said at the plea hearing that Rider was under the influence of alcohol during the incident and had slit his wrists.
At the sentencing hearing Friday, Jones asked that Rider's sentencing include incarceration. She said the fire was a planned event, citing threatening texts he sent his wife, Kari Rider, who is currently in the midst of a divorce from Trey Rider.
At the sentencing, Kari Rider said the night of the fire has caused her and their two sons lasting emotional and psychological effects. She said she and Trey Rider had been in a "horribly abusive relationship" and he had been destroying her things for years.
A restitution hearing, which Kari Rider asked for Friday, is set to be scheduled after the divorce proceedings.
DuFour, Trey Rider's attorney, said that over the past seven months, Trey Rider has put in hard work at a recovery center and a sober living home. She said that while he has a ways to go, Rider's goal is to become a sponsor for others struggling with addiction. DuFour said Rider also hopes to participate in reunification therapy with his sons.
A variety of people gave statements on Rider's character during the sentencing, including friends, family and counselors.
Rider said he was ashamed of his conduct, which has "caused immense harm and pain" in the lives of his wife and children. Before apologizing to his family, he said he has "fallen very far" and has reached out to get as much support as possible so he can continue down a road of recovery.
Before handing down the sentence, Ross called Rider's actions the night of the fire "calculated," "planned" and "self-serving." He said Rider has been given opportunities that most people don't get, including getting to begin rehab before being sentenced.

author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Ridgely police vehicles, equipment were sold, transferred this summer

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News

 RIDGELY — The town of Ridgely has sold seven vehicles and three firearms once belonging to the Ridgely Police Department since the police department was disbanded, according to records obtained by the Star Democrat.The vehicles and firearms were sold to the the Caroline County sheriff and other Eastern Shore municipalities.
Residents in Ridgely have been without the service of the Ridgely Police Department since a state investigation into the town's police chief was opened in March. Ridgely's commissioners suspended Eckrich and the entire department on March 12.
The town entered into a short-term agreement with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office to provide police coverage in place of the suspended officers. When the Ridgely officers were officially laid off at the start of the fiscal year on July 1, the town entered into a new memorandum of understanding with the county sheriff's office for fiscal year 2025.
Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker says he is committed to ensuring his office provides Ridgely residents with adequate police coverage.
"We have had positive feedback from a large number of residents who are happy with the service," Baker said. "I am absolutely here for the citizens of the Town of Ridgely and the citizens of Caroline County."
A July report said state investigators found no "sufficient evidence of criminal activity" looking into "suspected" perjury and misconduct by Ridgely Police Chief Jeff Eckrich.
Transaction records from Ridgely show the town began to sell and transfer vehicles and equipment in the weeks before the release of the investigation's report and before officers were officially laid off.
In June, the town transferred three pistols and three radios to the Caroline County Sheriff's Office with no charge associated.
Three police vehicles — two 2022 Ford Interceptors and one 2020 Ford Interceptor — were sold to the Sheriff's Office for $1 apiece on June 18, transaction records show.
On July 12, the town sold a 2023 Chevy Tahoe to the Town of Denton for just over $44,000. On July 27, Ridgely sold three vehicles to the City of Salisbury — a 2014 stripped K-9 Ford Interceptor for $1,000, a 2015 Ford Interceptor for $4,000 and a 2017 Ford Interceptor for $8,000.
Ridgely Town Commissioners did not respond to questions from the Star Democrat regarding the vehicle and equipment sales. Commissioners have maintained that a statement provided at a Sept. 9 town meeting, which did not address the vehicles and equipment, will be the town's final statement regarding the police department.
COUNTY COVERAGEBaker said the vehicles and equipment acquired by the county are being used by the deputies providing coverage to the town. The vehicles and equipment those deputies previously had will go back to the Sheriff's Office inventory to be used by county officers.
The current memorandum of understanding between the town and county outlines that the Sheriff's Office provides 480 hours of coverage per month.
Baker said the end goal is to have three full-time deputies providing coverage in Ridgely. At this time, there are only two full-time deputies, with a third in the police academy.
Sgt. Keith Collison, a former Ridgely officer, is overseeing daily operations in the town. The second full-time deputy is Cpl. Tracy Ferguson, who has more than seven years of law enforcement experience.
When the deputies stationed in Ridgely are not working, the Sheriff's Office and Maryland State Police are supplementing that temporary gap with patrol checks, Baker said.
Baker added that at one point during the current agreement, there were two officers training in the academy that were planned to be stationed in Ridgely. During that time, the county brought an "experienced" officer to serve as the second full-time deputy and assumed the cost of one of those officers in training at the academy.
By February or early March, Baker says he plans to transfer a third full-time deputy to Ridgely, which he says will "more than fulfill the agreement set out in the MOU."
The Ridgely Police Department office within the town hall building is serving as a substation for the Sheriff's Office deputies, Baker said. It is "up and functional" with fiber optics, computer systems and phone lines.

author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com

Dorchester County unveils restructuring plan for emergency services, corrections

 CAMBRIDGE — Dorchester County is moving forward with a plan to restructure parts of its 911 Center, Emergency Medical Services Division and Department of Corrections in an effort to improve recruitment and retention.At a Dorchester County Council meeting Tuesday, County Manager Jerry Jones said there are 35 vacancies in these three departments.
"We have had difficulty being competitive with surrounding counties," Jones said. "That attrition has created a number of public safety-related issues (within) the county."
Jones said half the positions in the 911 Center are currently vacant, which makes it more difficult to get calls out to first responders efficiently.
The restructuring plan will essentially create career ladders within each of the three departments to create opportunity for employees.
"You're not going into one position and stuck there forever," Jones said about the plan in an interview with the Star Democrat, later adding, "It's just giving more of a career ladder for our employees, which is more attractive to them."
During the meeting, Jones said that in the EMS division, the plan is to create four supervisor positions to oversee EMTs and paramedics. He said the plan also includes having two levels of EMT and paramedic positions. Currently, EMS Chief Debbie Wheedleton is overseeing everything without help, he said.
"So we're putting some structural pieces in there that make us more efficient and, at the same time, improve opportunities for retention and recruitment," Jones said.
Along with restructuring the three departments, the plan addresses a "substantial pay disparity" for directors.
Jones said the county looked at pay in surrounding counties and determined equitable salaries for Dorchester County employees. The county believes this will stop employees from taking jobs in other counties.
Jones warned that pay isn't the only concern when it comes to reasons why employees leave the county for other jobs. He said retirement systems in neighboring counties are another factor. Jones said they are looking into this.
"But we've got to be competitive in salary as well," he said, later adding, "And these proposals that you have before you make those salaries competitive."
In an interview, Jones said the plan is not expected to increase county budget expenses. He said filling positions will mean less spending in overtime pay.
Before the council took a vote, Council member Ricky Travers commended 911 Center, EMS and Department of Corrections staff for working short-staffed. He said that while overtime puts extra money in an employee's pocket, it also takes them away from home and, for these employees, puts them in stressful situations.
"I want each and every employee to know that we understand this, and we're very sorry you've had to deal with this, but we are truly working on this," he said.
Travers also commended Jones for finding the resources to make this plan possible in a county where money has been a concern. He said the county is still looking at retirement options, but it's much costlier.
Council Vice President Mike Detmer said county employees aren't paid what the council wishes they could be paid.
"We're working here on this side, and we appreciate the efforts of our staff to help magnify what we're trying to do as a council," he said.
At the end of the meeting, Department of Corrections Director Don Satterfield said he applauded these efforts and acknowledged there is still more work to be done.
"I would be remiss if I did not share with you my deep gratitude for the county manager and for the HR Department," he said. "They have been a dream in getting us from where we were to where we thought we needed to be and beyond."

title: ‘Ticking time bombs’: Lithium-ion batteries blamed for Hurricane Helene fires, continued danger
author: Mike Sunnucks APG Newspapers
content:
‘Ticking time bombs’: Lithium-ion batteries blamed for Hurricane Helene fires, continued danger

 October 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks APG Newspapers | Section: State News 
 
 875
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Hurricane Helene's cataclysmic path brought historic storm surges, record rainfall and destructive flooding from Florida to the Carolinas and Appalachia.But all the storm's wind and rain were accompanied by a surge of fires across multiple states that officials said appear to be caused by overheating and sometimes exploding lithium-ion batteries in electric cars, golf carts, electric bikes and scooters as well as other devices.
Lithium-ion batteries can catch fire if they are exposed to salt or freshwater, said Chad Hawkins, assistant chief deputy with the Oregon State Fire Marshal's Office.
"It doesn't matter. It shorts them out," Hawkins said of the batteries, noting that it takes "copious amounts" of water to put out lithium battery fires.
"It takes a lot of water to extinguish them," he said.
Florida State Fire Marshal Jimmy Patronis on Tuesday said there have been 16 fires during and after Hurricane Helene attributed to lithium-ion batteries used in Tesla and other electric vehicles, golf carts and other vehicles and devices.
Florida officials are investigating more structure and vehicle fires to see if more in storm-impacted areas were caused by electric batteries.
Patronis is worried that more lithium batteries could catch fire or explode after being exposed to floodwaters from the hurricane.
He urged owners to remove, properly dispose of or have towed away electric vehicle golf carts and other devices that have been exposed to floodwaters after record storm surges deluged communities and neighborhoods along Florida's west coast.
Patronis, who serves as Florida's CFO, said the hurricane's flooding can make "EV's a dangerous fire threat" and called storm surge-exposed lithium-ion batteries "ticking time bombs."
He stressed that electric batteries should not be put in the trash and to move EVs outdoors and roll down their windows and open doors to allow potentially flammable gas to escape.
Other hurricane fires may have been caused by downed power lines and flooded electrical systems.
North Carolina Fire Marshal Brian Taylor encourages residents and businesses to stay away from downed power lines and to unplug appliances to safeguard against power surges.
Fire and public safety officials in states hit by Helene are also encouraging residents and businesses to have electrical systems inspected before rebooting power after the storm and its outages.
The fires added to emergency workloads of fire and other public safety departments already responding to water rescues from historic storm surges and dangerous flooding.
"We responded to over 1,100 calls for service from the start of the storm until 4 p.m. yesterday," said John Klinefelter, division chief for Clearwater Fire Rescue in Florida on Wednesday. The popular tourist destination saw record storm surge from Helene, which was a Category 4 hurricane when it stormed ashore in Florida.
Klinefelter said his department responded to 37 structure fires with at least two involved lithium batteries with more incidents being reviewed for their causes.
"This information is based on the person who called 911 because we could not send fire inspectors out. One of the structure fires was an electric bicycle store located on the beach," he said.
Other communities in Florida and other states hit by the hurricane also saw fire during and after the storm.
St. Petersburg Fire Rescue responded to 47 vehicle fires and 7 structure fires from Sept. 26 to 28 on top of 86 water rescues and 1,744 emergency 911 calls, said spokeswoman Ashlie Handy.
She had some tips for avoiding electric fires — including those involving lithium batteries and electrical systems.
"When a storm is on its way, we encourage residents to prepare their homes by unplugging appliances from electrical outlets and moving them to a higher location. We recommend moving electric vehicles and other lithium-ion battery-powered devices away from areas that may see storm surge associated with the storm. We see most of our structure fires after the storm has passed. That is because when salt water comes in contact with exposed electrical systems, it becomes a fire hazard. The best thing someone can do to avoid an electrical fire is to turn off the main circuit breaker to their home," she said.
North of Tampa, Hernando County Fire Rescue responded to 7 structure fires, 4 of which involved lithium batteries, said Nick Brandt, communications manager for the agency.
"Tips for future storms would be to remove lithium batteries from flood prone locations and if batteries are submerged in salt water, move them to a location at least 50 feet away from any structures or vehicles to prevent further damage in the event they fail and cause a fire," Brandt said.
Handy and Hawkins also said lithium batteries should be moved away from potential flooding and unplugged from charging sources.
That might be possible with some golf carts and other devices but not with Teslas and other electric vehicles, Hawkins said.
He said overcharging lithium batteries in all types of devices — large and small — can cause them to catch fire.
"They can overcharge. They can overheat, they can pressurize and can explode," Hawkins said.
Hawkins also said consumers should make sure they are buying legitimately tested batteries and charges, warning that some overseas products can be faulty and cause fires.
He also said not to charge electric batteries in extreme cold (under 32 degrees Fahrenheit) or extreme heat (above 105 degrees Fahrenheit), not to just let devices always charge over long periods of time and to be at home when recharging vehicles or devices.

title: Vote 'yes' on Question A — support public safety
author: PETE LESHER
content:
Vote 'yes' on Question A — support public safety

 October 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: PETE LESHER | Section: Columns 
 
 478
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Four years ago, Talbot County voters overwhelmingly approved a temporary increase in the property tax revenue cap by an "extra penny." Our public safety operations were facing a recruitment and retention crisis because of low pay and inferior benefits compared to surrounding jurisdictions.Talbot County has made enormous progress with the "extra penny" on the property tax since 2022. Sheriff's deputies' pay is competitive and sheriff's deputies now are on the state-sponsored LEOPS retirement program, allowing them to retire after 25 years. These benefits, in conjunction with solid leadership, means the Sheriff's Office can fill open positions. Deputies now retire from the department – a once-rare circumstance – rather than leaving to work in other jurisdictions.
Likewise, our Emergency Services compensation has increased.
Pay for paramedics, emergency medical technicians and 911 dispatchers is more competitive than in 2020 — though we need to monitor this against surrounding counties, and paramedics are now eligible for the LEOPS retirement program, a popular benefit. The county has stepped its sixth advanced life aupport ambulance crew to a seven-day, round-the-clock unit, helping us keep response times within the critical 8-minute standard.
The county is planning a new ambulance station near the Chapel District Elementary School, which will help reduce response times in the northeast corner of Talbot County, where we have struggled to meet the 8-minute standard.
Our County Detention Center has faced staffing shortages, forcing mandatory overtime to operate the facility safely. The County has responded by boosting correctional officer salaries and budgeted to convert their retirement plan to the more robust state-sponsored CORS program.
The state of Maryland mandates what we spend on our court system and the minimum that we must spend on public schools. While the state allows the county to exceed its property tax cap to fund schools, there is no state mandate to fund the sheriff's department or ambulance services or road repairs. And so these critical county services may suffer if the property tax cap restricts revenues and forces cuts.
All of the funds raised by the "extra penny" on the property tax since 2022 — and more — has gone to boosting public safety. The "extra penny" runs out in 2026. The Talbot County Council unanimously authorized a ballot question to renew the "extra penny" for seven more years, out of concern public safety costs will continue to rise faster than the 2% property tax cap.
Voting for Question A allows the County Council the option to levy the "extra penny" for seven more years — through fiscal year 2033. Even with this "extra penny," over the last four years or for the next seven years, Talbot County maintains the lowest property tax rate in the state of Maryland.
If you support public safety and emergency services, vote for Question A. Do it for your family's safety. Do it for your neighbors. Do it for your own good. Vote for Question A.

Community collaboration packs trailer for hurricane relief

 299

 QUEEN ANNE'S — Sending relief and goodwill down south, Justin Davis of First Light First Responders and countless volunteers and local organizations have been hard at work collecting donations to provide relief to victims of Hurricane Helene.First Light is currently collecting from numerous businesses serving as donation drop-off sites and has multiple organizations working together across the Eastern Shore to get the items down south to where they are crucially needed, according to Davis.
"The amount of help from the community has been amazing and is great to see. Everyone has been more than willing to donate, and helpful," Davis said.
One thousand donated canned goods were received from Cambridge, he said.
Right now donations are focused on essential needs of first aid, food, bug spray, toiletries, diapers, wipes, cleaning supplies, according to Davis.
The hurricane relief is expected to be an ongoing effort for some time, he said, and donations will soon be switching over to seeking winter gear of blankets, sleeping bags and thermal wear.
Participating counties include Anne Arundel, Caroline, Kent, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico, Worcester and parts of Delaware.
Queen Anne's County drop-off locations include Britt's Barber Shop, Bella Rose, Mamma Mia Italian Bistro & Bar, Kent Island Methodist Church, Custom Canvas Coverings Inc., Parks Tire & Auto Service, Inc., Ten Eyck Brewing Company, Queenstown Collision Center, Duty's Service Center, and The Edge Training Academy.
The list of donation drop off sites continues to grow as of press time. Davis urged would be helpers to check the updated lists of donation items and current drop-off locations at the First Light For First Responders Facebook page. Those who would like to make monetary donations to aid the relief effort can do so care of the Kent Island Lions Club, he said.
More information about First Light for First Responders can be found at flffr.org.

author: STEVEN JACOBS JR. Capital News Service

Moore cancels back debt for thousands of parolees

 ANNAPOLIS — Gov. Wes Moore is canceling outstanding debts owed to the state by those on parole and probation, calling it the "equitable and just" thing to do.The action will forgive the debt for more than 6,700 people who owe supervision fees as part of their parole or release arrangement with the Department of Public Safety and Correctional services.
"Marylanders who serve their time deserve a second chance without bearing the financial burden of recurring administrative fees," Moore said in a release. "This action will create paths to work, wages and wealth for Marylanders; grow our economy; and build a state that is more equitable and just."
The decision forgives more than $13 million in debt. It applies only to current parolees on active supervision, not to those whose debts are already in collection proceedings.
Individuals under court-ordered supervision — whether through parole, probation or release — pay monthly fees to the state. The rate ranges from $40 to $50 a month depending on the date the supervision began.
"The decision to waive parole and drug testing fees aligns with Gov. Moore's vision for a more supportive reintegration process," said Carolyn Scruggs, secretary of the correctional agency. "This decision eases financial burden, promotes successful reintegration and will ultimately help reduce recidivism among returning citizens."

title: Hurricane Milton tests Tampa Bay’s Indian blessing, ‘Bay of the Holy Spirit’ legends; Storm projected to hit near Sarasota
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS Belgrade News
content:
Hurricane Milton tests Tampa Bay’s Indian blessing, ‘Bay of the Holy Spirit’ legends; Storm projected to hit near Sarasota

 October 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS Belgrade News | Section: News 
 
 632
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Anyone who grew up in or has lived in the Tampa-St. Petersburg area for a number of years likely knows about the Indian blessing that protects Tampa Bay from hurricanes.The blessing stems from the ancient Tocobaga Native American tribe which protects Tampa Bay against hurricanes. The indigenous tribe lived in the bay area with sacred sites in Safety Harbor in Pinellas County overlooking Old Tampa Bay.
On top of the indigenous tribe's blessing, Spanish explorer Hernando de Soto (during his search for the Fountain of Youth) encountered the Tocobaga in Safety Harbor in 1539 on Pentecost Sunday and named what is now Tampa Bay — Bahia Espiritu Santo (tBay of the Holy Spirit).
The Indian blessing and de Soto's Christian name for the bay have protected the Tampa area from hurricanes, according to local legends.
Tampa has not been hit directly by hurricane since 1921. There have been numerous contemporary examples of hurricane projected to hit Tampa Bay and then turning and deviating north or south — including Hurricane Ian.
Hurricane Milton is putting the spiritual legends to test. The hurricane is slated to hit Florida early Thursday with Tampa Bay potentially facing historic and catastrophic storm surges, 100 miles per hour winds and heavy rain.
The Category 4 storm has winds of 155 miles per hour and is expected to make landfall in Florida early Thursday morning.
But some of the latest updates from the National Hurricane Center and storm path models have Milton making landfall south of Tampa Bay potentially in Sarasota or south of Sarasota.
If those expectations hold true, that would bring the worst of the storm to the south of the Tampa area.
Tampa Bay could avoid biblical storm surge flooding is the storm lands to the south.
Still, Tampa and Pinellas County are in the wider path cone of the storm and are almost certain to see high winds, power outages, possible tornadoes, thunderstorms and downpours from Milton.
But it might dodge a more catastrophic storm surge bullet.
Tampa. St. Petersburg and Pinellas barrier islands did see major damage from Hurricane Helene as is barreled north.
The Indian blessing legend is not lost on Tampa Bay locals.
"I kind of believe it," said Kristen Hendry, who lives in Brandon near Tampa.
"I've seen weird things happen with other hurricanes. Storms will turn."
Hendry is not alone.
There are plenty of local references to the blessings against hurricanes on social media, breakfast diners and dog parks as local residents brace for Milton's impacts.
Still, having faith in the spiritual, if not keeping local residents from bracing from Hurricane Milton's impacts.
"We're definitely getting ready," she said.
Others are also bringing their faith and spiritual beliefs as Milton approaches from the western Gulf of Mexico with a potential historic hit on Florida.
Fathers Athanasios Haros and Pappa Fanis of the St. Nichols Greek Orthodox Cathedral in Tarpon Springs went to the shores of the Gulf of Mexico on Monday to bless the body of water in advance of Hurricane Milton and ask for spiritual intercessions and protections.
In a Facebook video, Haros said they were on the Gulf of Mexico shores to bless the waters and ask for blessing and protections.
Tocobaga indigenous tribe inhabited had burial mounds in the Tampa area specifically Safety Harbor, which sits on the northern end of Old Tampa Bay in Pinellas County.
Tocobaga encountered the Spanish in the 1500 and 1600s, had their populations decreased by diseases brought by Europeans, conflicts with other tribes and eventually emigrated to Cuba with the Spanish when Florida came under British rule from 1763 to 1783 before returning to Spanish control.
Tampa is home to one of the largest ports in the U.S. and U.S. Central Command at MacDill Air Force Base. Central Command runs U.S. military operations in the Middle East and Holy land including those involving the current war between Israel and Iranian proxies Hamas and Hezbollah.

title: Bus driver likely to face charges after abandoning students at the wrong stop
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
Bus driver likely to face charges after abandoning students at the wrong stop

 October 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 733
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A bus driver for Newark Charter School in Delaware is expected to face charges after 10 elementary school students were abandoned at the wrong bus stop.The incident happened Tuesday afternoon as Bus #28 was driving the students home for the day. School officials called police at approximately 4:15 p.m. to report the incident, according to Sgt. Joseph Conover, a spokesman for the Newark Police Department.
The driver made the students — ranging from kindergarten to fifth grade — get off the bus at a stop in Robscott Manor, which is not their normal stop, Conover said.
A parent waiting for her child at that stop realized that extra students exited the bus and called the school and police to report the incident.
School officials and officers from the Newark and New Castle County police departments all rushed to Robscott Manor, where they found the students safe.
"The cooperative efforts between Newark Charter School, the Newark Police Department and its law enforcement partners ensured the safe reunification of all of the students with their guardians," Conover said.
State troopers tracked down the bus and confirmed that there were no more students aboard.
Conover said Newark's school resource officers are still interviewing students and families but he expects the driver to be arrested and charged with multiple offenses.
Police are still trying to figure out exactly why the students were told to get out in Robscott Manor. The neighborhood is on the bus route, but some of those students live a significant distance away from where they were dropped off, Conover said.
The mother of one of the affected students told the Newark Post she was waiting for her child to come home and was tracking the bus via an app that parents have access to. She began to get concerned when the bus was late and she saw on the GPS tracking app that the bus was going in the wrong direction.
She then got a call from the parent who witnessed the kids get kicked off the bus, and she went to Robscott to pick up her child.
She started to piece together what happened by talking to her son.
"He said they were at a stop, and the bus driver said 'Everybody get off the bus. Get your stuff and get off,'" recounted the mother, who asked not to be identified out of concern for her child's safety.
Some of the children were confused and scared and refused to get off, she added. At the next stop on the same street, the driver again told them it's the last stop and they had to get off, and the remaining students eventually complied.
She said she told her son she was proud of him for helping his younger classmates.
"It's just a crazy thing, but I do feel like the kids really stuck together and they kind of took care of each other," she said. "I think that made a lot of the parents feel better."
She also praised school officials for reacting quickly to ensure the students were safe.
The mother said she has decided to let her child continue to ride the bus, but she will be more alert about knowing who is driving her child.
"You don't really think about who is it that's driving the bus," she said. "You don't really see them a whole lot. You just kind of let your kid get on, and there they are."
The incident has taught her to be more vigilant about talking to her child about what happens during bus rides.
"A big takeaway with all the parents is just to kind of watch out a little bit more and try to notice if things do seem strange and having your kid be able to tell you if things seem off," she said.
The driver, whose name has not yet been made public, is an employee of Advanced Student Transportation, the bus company Newark Charter has contracted with since the school opened 23 years ago.
"Yesterday's incident was unfortunate and we are tremendously disappointed that it occurred," Head of School Sam Golder wrote in a letter to parents. "The bus driver will no longer be driving for Newark Charter School."
Golder assured parents the school is fully cooperating with the police investigation.
"Student safety is, and will continue to be, our number one priority at Newark Charter School," he said. "I personally have three children of my own and I would not have tolerated yesterday's behavior, had my children been riding this bus."

title: Police: Man, 63, took inappropriate photos of girls at volleyball games
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Police: Man, 63, took inappropriate photos of girls at volleyball games

 October 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 840
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESAPEAKE CITY — A 63-year-old man is charged with disturbing school operation and disorderly conduct after he allegedly took numerous inappropriate photos and videos of girls playing volleyball matches inside the Bohemia Manor High School gymnasium, according to Cecil County District Court records.Investigators identified the suspect as Michael Cornell Griffin of Townsend, Del.
Maryland State Police Master Trooper Jason Proctor conducted an on-scene investigation during the incident, which occurred shortly before 8 p.m. on Thursday, and he was able to view the photographic content of the suspect's cell phone after Griffin had given verbal consent to do so, police reported.
"I reviewed the photo album and observed that it contained several photographs and videos of the junior varsity teams and varsity teams from both schools: Bohemia Manor High School and Perryville High School . . . The photographs observed in the photo album were of the buttock areas of the juvenile aged female players," Proctor summarized in his written statement of probable cause.
The investigator noted, "The uniform shorts that are worn by all the volleyball players are tight in nature; however, the photographs that were taken were zoomed in by Griffin revealing inappropriate detail, as certain curvature of the female players body parts could be clearly observed."
Court records indicate that the investigation leading to the two criminal charges against Griffin started after spectators noticed the suspect acting suspiciously in the bleachers during the volleyball game, police said. The initial complainant was a 41-year-old woman, court records show. (It is not clear if Griffin had direct ties to the volleyball competition, such as a relative who was one of the players.)
The complainants had seen the suspect "deliberately zoom in on the players' buttock areas" while he was taking digital photos with his cell phone, court records allege.
Griffin's alleged actions caused nearby parents and other spectators to ask him why he was taking pictures, creating a scene that diverted some of the spectators' attention away from the volleyball game, according to the charging document.
"This was actively causing disturbance within the stands," court records allege.
After spectators complained and pointed to the suspect, the trooper escorted Griffin from the gymnasium into the lobby, police said. Bohemia Manor Middle School Assistant Principal Stacy Rahnama was in the lobby and was present during the on-scene investigation, police added.
Proctor informed Griffin that he had been accused of taking inappropriate photos of female volleyball players, court records show. Griffin denied taking pictures of the players and started opening and closing the photo album on his phone, according to court records.
"It appeared as if he was trying to hide the photographs. Griffin appeared to be extremely nervous while speaking with me. I observed his right hand and fingers shake multiple times as he was scrolling through his phone," Proctor outlined in court records.
At that point, the trooper asked Griffin if he would be willing to show him the photos that he had taken and Griffin gave verbal consent, court records show. During that viewing of the photographic content of Griffin's cell phone, Proctor and Rahnama saw numerous inappropriate photos and videos of the female volleyball players, court records allege.
"While reviewing the photo albums, the initial complainant entered the lobby and made inquiries as to whether or not her daughter's photograph was on his phone and was making comments that she wanted the photographs deleted," according to the charging document.
Proctor then escorted Griffin out of the building and into the breezeway, where — with the suspect's consent — he and Rahnama deleted all of the questionable pictures and videos found in the phone's photo library and then from the phone's trash bin file, court records show.
"While this was taking place, a group of patrons had gathered in the lobby and were actively observing my interactions with Griffin. Another patron had to tell that group of people to remain inside and not to interfere, as they were making threats to assault Griffin due to his actions," according to the charging document, which indicates that the group obeyed and returned to the gymnasium.
After the deletion of the photos and videos, Rahnama requested that Griffin leave the school property, police said. The trooper then escorted Griffin to his 2014 Chrysler 200 that was parked in the school lot and ordered him to leave the premises, which Griffin did, police added.
At the end of his written statement of probable cause, Proctor summarized, "Griffin's direct actions of being visible while he was taking inappropriate and offensive photographs (by way of zooming in) caused direct disturbance within the stands of the sporting event which is also disruption of school activities."
Griffin was not arrested but, instead, was charged through a criminal summons that was issued on Monday, court records show. Griffin is charged with disturbing school operation, a misdemeanor that carries a maximum six-month penalty and a $2,500 fine if convicted; and disorderly conduct, which is punishable by up to 60 days in jail and a $500 fine if convicted, according to court records.
Griffin is scheduled to appear for a preliminary inquiry on Nov. 25, court records show.

title: Thousands of troops, hundreds of out-of-state police in Florida after Hurricane Milton
author: Mike Sunnucks APG Newspapers
content:
Thousands of troops, hundreds of out-of-state police in Florida after Hurricane Milton

 October 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks APG Newspapers | Section: National 
 
 658
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Thousands of National Guard troops are being deployed and the Pentagon is also sending military personnel to Florida after Hurricane Milton slammed into the gulf coast and swept through much of the state causing significant damage from extreme winds, relentless rains and hundred-year floods.Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis has activated more than 6,500 National Guard troops and another 200 soldiers from the Florida State Guard (a state defense force that has been in place since World War II) to help with emergency and public safety responses to the hurricane.
DeSantis and state officials said the Milton response includes Blackhawk helicopters and drones.
Pentagon spokesman Maj. Gen. Pat Ryder said Thursday there are another 3,000 National Guard troops from 19 other states are also at the ready to help with search and rescue, relief and security efforts after the storm.
Ryder said the response includes 26 helicopters and more than 500 high-water vehicles are part of the response.
The Pentagon is also sending U.S. military assets to Florida as part of the Federal Emergency Management Agency's response to Milton — which knocked power to more than 3 million Florida households and resulted in wind damage and widespread flooding in southwest Florida, the Tampa Bay area, Orlando and other parts of the state.
FEMA has already been in the state after Hurricane Helene cause substantial storm surge damage along Florida's west coast.
"The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers has approximately 250 people supporting the response with temporary roof support, debris control, flood control, waterway clearance and more," Ryder said during a press briefing Thursday.
"U.S. Northern Command and U.S. Army North have also have active duty forces and capabilities postured and ready to support FEMA when requested, to include up to 60 high water vehicles from Fort Stewart, Georgia, up to 100 U.S. Marines from Camp Lejeune, North Carolina to provide support for urban search and rescue, search and rescue helicopters plus light and medium rotary wing airlift aircraft from the 3rd Infantry Division, as well as command and control support capabilities."
Those two military commands focus on domestic security.
Ryder said U.S. military bases in Florida and nearby southern states will serve as staging areas for Hurricane Milton responses. Tampa is home to MacDill Air Force Base and the U.S. Central Command (which runs U.S. military operations in the Middle East including the current Holy Land war zone involving Israel, Iran and its proxies Hamas and Hezbollah). Officials at Central Command have not responded to questions about the impact of Milton on operations and whether any commanders or assets were moved ahead of the Category 3 storm. Ryder also did not provide details when asked about the hurricane's impact on the Tampa-baed command Thursday.
Florida police agencies restricted access to beach areas after the storm surge damage of Hurricane Helene for safety and security reasons — in part, because of their concerns about looting and criminal activity. The Helene response has included National Guard troops patrolling beach areas.
They will likely do the same for areas after Milton which brought widespread flooding and wind damage to southwest Florida and Tampa Bay. Deployed troops will also be part of search and rescue and cleanup efforts in response to Milton, according to state officials.
While the Florida governor has promised as quick as possible access to their homes for Floridians who evacuated before Milton's arrival, some local officials are less keen on that approach.
A number of local police and fire departments pulled back on responses during Milton which brought intense winds and hours-long torrential rains Wednesday night and early Thursday morning.
DeSantis said 500 out-of-state police are coming to Florida to add to state law enforcement responses to Milton.
Local sheriffs, in particular, along with DeSantis and state officials have promised aggressive response to any post-hurricane looting or burglaries of wealthy homes or businesses impacted by Milton or Helene.
"We are going to come down hard on you," said DeSantis at a press briefing Wednesday before Milton's treacherous arrival. "We need to maintain law and order."

 At the Worton Dollar General on Sunday, Oct. 6, a fire broke out due to what the Maryland Fire Marshal reported as an unspecified failure of a refrigerator unit.The Fire Marshal report further states, the fire at 10838 Worton Road was deemed accidental and caused an estimated loss of $100,000 in structure and $400,000 in contents. The primary responding company was Chestertown Volunteer Fire Department that later issued their press release.

They continued into the parking lot deploying a single 1-3/4 fire attack hose, entering the building. Officials knew which way to go from the deputy's instructions, and faced with heavy smoke, were able to do a quick "knock down."

With no fire, their efforts turned to clearing the building of smoke, taking more than 45 minutes.
Conducting an Origin and Cause investigation, a representative from the Maryland State's Fire Marshal's Office strongly believed the cause to be electrical. As a result Delmarva Power arrived on-site, however service was left on after determining it was safe.
Additionally, a representative from the Kent County Health Department arrived due to the the amount of food in the store. Their decision was to condemn and dispose of all food material.

 Mid-Shore community members and organizations have headed south in recent days to provide crucial assistance to communities impacted by Hurricane Helene and Hurricane Milton.Helene hit land as a Category 4 hurricane on Sept. 26, making its way through the Southeast and devastating communities. More than 200 deaths have been confirmed in six states.
Milton tore through Florida late Wednesday night, leaving millions without power and causing at least five confirmed deaths as of Thursday afternoon. It made landfall as a Category 3 hurricane.
Easton Town Council President Frank Gunsallus, who is active with Disaster Aid USA, a nonprofit that delivers disaster relief worldwide, has made two trips to North Carolina to assist Hurricane Helene victims.
This past weekend, Gunsallus drove down and delivered 20 cases of water, food, medicine, first aid supplies, diapers, hygiene products and more to Skyland United Methodist Church in Asheville, North Carolina.
He spent the weekend delivering aid and driving in Asheville and surrounding areas in western North Carolina. On Sunday, he drove through Swannanoa, North Carolina, among other ravaged towns.
"The devastation that I witnessed is moving," Gunsallus said at Monday's Easton Town Council meeting. "It doesn't really matter how well you think you have your life planned out. Sometimes the Earth just has plans of its own, and everything you know and love can just be gone. There are still people stranded, (who) cannot get out of their properties."
Gunsallus and Barc Upchurch, members of the Easton Rotary Club, drove down on Tuesday to the small community of Green Mountain, North Carolina. They took a generator to the Double Island Fire Department on behalf of the Rotary Club.
There, they also delivered an off-road, all-terrain vehicle to the local fire department, which was needed for search and rescue efforts. Gunsallus said the ATV was donated by Dave Wilson, president of Preston Automotive Group and Preston Powersports.
Gunsallus described the sights of devastation during his two trips, from houses and buildings destroyed to trees blocking roads and railroad tracks broken.
"I can't not do anything. … I've got to do something," Gunsallus said in an interview.
Donations to Disaster Aid USA can be made by visiting disasteraidusa.org or mailing a check. Checks can be mailed to: Disaster Aid USA 700 Port Street #538, Easton, MD 21601.
On Wednesday, 12 lineworkers and additional individuals from Delmarva Power arrived in St. Petersburg, Florida, to assist the electric company Duke Energy amid impacts from Hurricane Milton.

"By the end of this week, Delmarva Power will have close to 50 field crews and additional personnel assisting Florida," Womer wrote.
Delmarva Power crews just wrapped up providing aid in Georgia following last month's Hurricane Helene. Womer said those crews and personnel departed Sept. 26, finished their work on Wednesday and will be heading home.

title: Turner gets life sentence for shootout with Calvert cops
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
Turner gets life sentence for shootout with Calvert cops

 October 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 617
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A 23-year-old Prince George's County man who was convicted in June of attempting to kill a Calvert County deputy sheriff during an incident in December 2022 was given a life sentence Friday by a circuit court judge.In imposing Brandon Alexander Turner's sentence on 16 counts related to a high speed pursuit and shootout with deputies in a Huntingtown neighborhood, Judge Andrew Rappaport suspended all but 40 years of the life sentence for attempting to shoot and kill Deputy James Flynt.
Two counts of first-degree assault netted the defendant an additional 50 years with all but 18 year suspended, combined with 15 years with all but five years suspended for firearm possession with a crime of violence conviction. Those sentences will run consecutively, along with a three-year sentence for fleeing and eluding. Several other counts will run concurrently with the other charges.
Combined, Turner's sentence is for over 60 years and due to the violent nature of the crimes he must serve at least half of that time behind bars before becoming eligible for parole.
Calvert County State's Attorney Robert H. Harvey Jr. (R) called the sentence "fair and appropriate, given the magnitude of the crime."
During Friday's sentencing hearing, Flynt addressed the court, reading a prepared statement.
"Mr. Turner is a coward," Flynt said, adding that his fellow deputies responding to the shooting scene in the Walnut Creek subdivision saved his life with their quick actions.
"This would have been a murder trial," Flynt said, adding that the leg injuries he sustained in the shooting still hamper his ability today.
"My life is changed forever," Flynt said. "I've fought like hell to get back to full duty."
Noting that he has undergone about 10 surgeries due to his wounds, Flynt told the court he will be on medication for the rest of his life.
"I will never be able to run like I used to," Flynt said. The deputy asked Rappaport to impose the maximum sentence on Turner.
The other two deputies involved in the shootout also told the court their lives were changed by the incident.
Deputy Tyler Bowen also read a statement, calling the incident a "traumatic, stressful event."
In a letter read into the record during the hearing, Deputy Anthony Aranda stated the incident has impacted his career and personal life.
"The sole focus must be on public safety," Harvey said of the sentence, adding that Turner's "conduct was reprehensible. He has shown no remorse. He blames everyone else. He has been a disciplinary problem since his incarceration."
The defendant's attorney, Michelle Harewood, said her client suffers from a bipolar disorder for which he was not taking his medication.
Harewood asked that Turner be sent to Patuxent Institute in Jessup so that his behavioral health issues can be addressed.
"If he had kept on his medication we wouldn't be here today," Shelton Turner, the defendant's father, told the court. The elder Turner added that his family and church "prayed earnestly" for Flynt after the shooting incident.
"I hope you will find it in your heart to forgive me," Brandon Turner said in a written statement he read to the court prior to sentencing.
The Dec. 17, 2022, incident began in the Dunkirk area when the vehicle Turner and his wife were in was pulled over on the side of Route 4. Deputies had stopped and were about to search the vehicle when Turner fled. He led the deputies on a high-speed chase on Route 4 and several times fired a weapon out the driver's side window.
Flynt, operating a patrol vehicle, disabled Turner's Kia with a precision immobilization technique. That's when the defendant reportedly began shooting at the deputies, who returned fire.
"You could have stopped at any time but you chose not to," Rappaport told the defendant before the sentence was imposed.

title: Caroline commissioners talk new regional detention center

Caroline commissioners talk new regional detention center
