 DENTON — On Oct. 15 the Caroline County Commissioners discussed a plan to build a new regional detention center in Queen Anne's county.The financial burden would be split between Caroline, Queen Anne's and Kent counties, but it is still unclear how that would be managed or what would happen to the detention center on 101 Gay Street in Denton, commissioners said at the meeting.
The new facility is being designed to hold 338 beds for men and women. The current Denton jail holds 130 inmates.
The warden of the Caroline County Detention Center, Charles Scott, said there are mental health needs among the inmates that could be better managed with a designated space, which could be incorporated into the design of the new facility.
"There should be a wing just for mental health. Juveniles and mental health are just piling up in the jail," Scott said.
He said there is plenty of land in Queen Anne's County to build this new detention center. The new facility will be located in Church Hill on the site of the Eastern Pre-Release Unit.
Commission President Travis Breeding cited the economies of scale and how the new detention center could serve the needs of the counties for less money.
The commissioners discussed who would be the authority on this tri-county project. Right now, one county commissioner and one county administrator oversee the jail in Denton. The commissioners said they wanted more clarity on how that would work in a tri-county context.
The commissioners also discussed the employment possibilities for current Caroline County Detention Center employees. Employment decisions would factor in tenure and managing workers who have fulfilled this amount of time as they work in a new county.
Scott said it is hard to find correctional officers, so everyone's job should be safe.
County Administrator Katheleen Freeman said the new facility will offer better services at lower costs, but the devil is in the details.

Queen Anne's County High School gets school security grant

 CENTREVILLE — Queen Anne's County High School has recently been awarded $70,000 to pursue the hiring of the district's first School Security Employee (SSE), according to Joe Saboury, coordinator of school safety and security.As of August, the district received funding from the Maryland Center for School Safety School Resource Officer (SRO) Adequate Coverage Grant under the 2018 Maryland Safe to Learn Act, Saboury said.
This funding allows school districts to hire an employee to serve as a supplement to the SRO already in place, he said. Resource officers already serving the school district fall under the direction and budget of the county sheriff's office.
The statewide grant funding assists in supplementing law enforcement coverage for public schools with $10 to 15 million in FY26 and $20 million in FY27 and each year thereafter, he said.
As school security is considered a top state priority, a minimum three years of funding following this year is secured, according to Saboury.
"So really that's putting additional eyes and ears in our schools, which is a wonderful thing," he said.
As a member of the district, the SSE works more closely with school leaders on safety measures, often outside law enforcement scopes, and are more closely involved with student behavior, support and providing intervention to mitigate and prevent harm, he said.
As district employees, QACPS has the flexibility to utilize SSEs for after school sporting events or field trips Saboury said.
"It's a great resource that the school district has never had before," he said.
SSEs are held to the same standards and certification programs through the Maryland for School Safety Model training as SROs.
Training, uniforms, equipment and overtime are all budgeted into the grant with no cost the district, he said.
With the potential for increased funding down the road, Saboury was hopeful to be able to build the program and continually create a safe learning environment for students.

title: Dorchester County may need to add to detention center
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Dorchester County may need to add to detention center

 October 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 681
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The Dorchester County detention center is struggling to keep up with increases in the number of juveniles incarcerated and may ask for money to build a new wing to house the young offenders.During a Tuesday County Council meeting, council members decided to prioritize the topic for the upcoming Maryland General Assembly legislative session.
During a final discussion on priorities for the legislative session, Councilmember Mike Detmer, talked about what he described as his "juvenile crime concern."
In his comments, Detmer said juvenile crime in Dorchester County has been on the rise and the crimes being committed are more than simply jaywalking.
"It's absolutely insane that we have so many people that have had direct and directly affected by this, multiple people in this room directly affected by juvenile crime," Detmer said. "And it's unbelievable that in 2024 that we can be in a place of all the resources and all the talent we have that are wearing badges, that we can be in a place where we're held hostage by ostensibly well intentioned laws."
Detmer pleaded with council to put emphasis on juvenile crime for the Maryland General Assembly legislative session. He reminded the council of stories he shared on juvenile crime during previous meetings including children as young as 10 with guns and speeding cars on U.S. Route 50 and state Route 16 by underage drivers.
"There are kids that are still kids on paper," Detmer said. "(But) they're not acting like children."
Council President George Pfeffer, said the topic is on the list and there's no priority on the list created. Pfeffer described the topics on the list as "equally important to us" and said they will emphasize the importance of those topics once there is a legislator in front of them.
The list will be discussed with the local contingent of state delegates and senators.
Later on in the meeting Councilmember Ricky Travers, added that he agreed with Detmer and said he had issue with the way the juvenile justice system functions and said the system is "setting up a whole group of young kids for failure."
During public comment, detention center Warden Don Satterfield shared that over the last two months the detention center has had seven juveniles waiting for adult status.
Satterfield said because the state of Maryland has passed laws stating that juveniles must be housed separately by "vision and audio," those regulations have created a difficult barrier with the increase of juveniles being sent to adult detention centers.
Satterfield shared that the current detention center is almost 34 years old and is not designed to accommodate increased numbers of juveniles.
"Unfortunately, I'm going to be coming before you to add a wing (to the center)," Satterfield said. "That's where we are with this. We are already in violation of the law because of the audio part, and every other facility in the states is pretty much the same way. But this is where we are with the juvenile situation, and I don't see it concluding. And they are, quite frankly, they're a holy terror."
After hearing comment from Satterfield, Pfeffers suggested in addition to the rise in juvenile crime, that they discuss the restrictions placed on detention centers could possibly force the county to build another wing to the detention facility.
The council unanimously agreed to add the topics to the county's legislative priorities.
Dorchester is not the only county facing questions of outdated detention centers. Earlier this week, Caroline County commissioners discussed plans to join with Queen Anne's and Kent counties to build a new center, in part to deal with the increase in juvenile inmates.
In a March article in The Star Democrat, Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd talked about the growing challenge of juvenile crime in Dorchester County's largest city.
"Through investigation and statistical analysis, we have determined that the overwhelming suspect profiles for these crimes are male juveniles under the age of 16," according to a Cambridge police report. "But we have detained suspects as young as 11 for stealing vehicles in Cambridge."
According to the report, there is one 12-year-old who has been arrested for vehicle theft 11 times in the past three years.

title: Eastern Shore fire companies aid areas affected by Hurricane Helene
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:

 OXFORD — Fire companies throughout the Eastern Shore have stepped up to assist with disaster areas affected by Hurricane Helene. Together they have donated fire and EMS equipment to first responders in need.When Hurricane Helene occurred, some of the members of the Oxford and Tilghman Fire Company felt the need to assist in any way possible. After watching several YouTube and Facebook videos circulating online showing the conditions in the affected areas, members of the fire company came up with the idea to assist first responders in Tennessee by donating some of their equipment.
Graham Norbury, chief of the Oxford Fire Company, said regardless of location, fire departments seek to help each other and anyone else in need.
"We do a lot of mutual aid to other departments in the area and elsewhere," Norbury said. "The Brotherhood of the Fire Services is pretty tight. When we see someone in need, then we want to be able to help any way we can."
According to Norbury, most volunteer fire companies replace equipment on a reasonably regular basis. The Oxford Fire Department had several pieces of equipment delivered to them in a short amount of time including a new ambulance and a new fire truck.
Norbury said they put word out through the Maryland State Firefighters Association that they wanted to help by donating equipment. News traveled fast, and Bill Killan, member from a fire department in Tennessee, contacted Norbury and helped coordinate a drop off with a fire department in Butler, Tennessee.
Tim Kearns, president of Oxford Fire Company, was one of the volunteers to deliver essential equipment to support disaster relief efforts. The drive to Tennessee was over 500 miles and was shared among four different drivers.
"It was important because the volunteer system works on mutual aid, so when someone is overwhelmed, we come to help," Kearns said. "And that's what we did, only they're just a little farther away than most."
Kearns said they made two stops to deliver equipment. The first was at an agricultural supply in Bristol, Virginia, which is on the border of Tennessee.
There they offloaded a skid brush unit, which is a pre-assembled piece of equipment that can fit into the back of a pickup truck and turn that pickup truck into a brush truck for fighting land fires and small house fires.
According to Kearns, the brush skid unit was the most valuable piece of equipment they gave because the roads in the area were so badly destroyed that any vehicle would have a difficult time navigating through.
With the brush skid unit the local fire department could use a heavy four-wheel drive pickup truck to help fight fires that occur.
The second stop was a campground called Faith Camp. Kearns said the camp was owned by Darren Clark, a member of the Elk Mills Poga Volunteer Fire Company, who had come from Florida to create the beautiful natural area.
Currently, Clark has been assisting people who have been displaced by the hurricane. Clark has designated his campground as a satellite fire station.
According to Kearns, everyone is trying to do their part, regardless of location. Contributing Maryland fire companies include Oxford, Tilghman, Cordova, Easton, Queen Anne Hillsboro, Suddlersville and Hollywood.
"It took a lot of folks to coordinate and manhandle the transfer of this equipment, from the paperwork, insurances, transfer of titles and tags, to all of the logistics here, there and in between," Kearns said. "Our Chief Engineer Stacy Dulin and Assistant Chief Engineers Mike Greenwak and Tom Bixler assured the equipment was capable of the 500-mile trip. Oxford Ferry loaned the heavy trailer."

 Sheriffs across the state of Maryland are calling for Gov. Wes Moore (D) to "immediately demand the resignation" of Vincent Schiraldi, secretary of the Department of Juvenile Services.The Dorchester, Talbot and Caroline County sheriffs, along with all but five other Maryland sheriffs, voted Monday to have the Maryland Sheriffs' Association send the governor a letter to this effect.
"Since Schiraldi's appointment in 2022, his extreme policies and lack of leadership as the Secretary of the Department of Juvenile Services, have directly made communities less safe in Maryland," the letter reads.
"Consistently in Maryland, juveniles have been charged with serious violent crimes," it later states, "only to be turned right back over to a parent or guardian, and back out on the streets to commit more crimes."
A statement from Moore's office noted that "over the past year," the governor has made a "concerted effort" to hold youth accountable and rehabilitate offenders. The statement highlighted a "26% decline in juvenile homicide arrests and 46% decline in non-fatal shootings of juveniles" statewide.
The statement did not directly respond to the Maryland Sheriffs' Association's request for Moore to call for Schiraldi's resignation.
"The governor is fully committed to working with local elected officials, law enforcement, the judiciary, and community leaders to improve public safety by holding youth accountable and rehabilitating them," it reads.
The Department of Juvenile Services did not immediately respond to a request for comment regarding the sheriffs' letter.
Schiraldi, who was officially appointed to the position by Moore in March 2023, has indicated in other media interviews that he has the governor's support and is planning to "stay in his job."
"Gov. Moore has been extremely supportive," Schiraldi told WBAL-TV on Friday afternoon. "He's gotten us additional funds this year — $17 million to make community safer by expanding programs — and I want those community members who are calling for my resignation to feel safe."
SHERIFFS WEIGH INThe Caroline, Dorchester and Talbot sheriffs said their votes to send the letter to Moore were prompted by negative impacts on local communities during Schiraldi's tenure as Department of Juvenile Services secretary.
Dorchester County Sheriff James Phillips said he "lost all respect" for Schiraldi following an in-person community meeting the secretary attended around a year ago.
"He had the audacity to tell us, … 'The data that I'm receiving doesn't support your claim of increased juvenile crime,'" Phillips recalled. "And our reply to that was, 'Well, obviously the numbers are going to go down because you're not allowing us to charge (them) anymore.'"
Phillips said in Dorchester County, "we're dealing with the same people, the same names, the same age kids."
"The law-abiding citizens are suffering because of their ignorance and stupidity in protecting these criminals," Phillips said. "And that's all they are. They might only be 15 or 16, but they're thugs."
Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble says there's "no accountability," noting that his office was recently involved in a vehicle chase in which a juvenile had an ankle monitor with batteries that hadn't been replaced for two months.
Gamble said the Mid-Shore has "good" juvenile services workers, "but they're being hampered by the secretary." He pointed to Talbot Teen Court, a first-time program for juvenile offenders of misdemeanor crimes, as more successful in rehabilitating youth compared to the state's services.
"They're getting more community service and stuff out of Teen Court than they would ever get out of DJS," Gamble said. "It's just a failed system. And it's being led by what the Sheriffs' Association believes is a bad pick by the governor."
Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker said recent justice reform — particularly Maryland's Child Interrogation Protection Act — has decreased the ability of police to hold juveniles accountable.
That act, enacted in 2022, restricts police from questioning a child without first talking to the parent or guardian's attorney or the Office of the Public Defender. Baker said it's a "shame when parental rights are superseded by the legislature."
Baker, who serves on the state's juvenile justice reform commission, believes the General Assembly has a "role to play" in improving juvenile reform moving forward.
"Juvenile reform needs to be a high priority to help take the steps needed for them to have accountability for when they step into adulthood," Baker said.

 EASTON — The Talbot County Council has enacted a burn ban as a dry spell has rendered the county without rain for weeks.Council members held a special meeting Friday morning to pass the burn ban, which prohibits all "open-air burning." Effective Friday, it will last for 30 days, unless it is extended or terminated.
A county press release defined open-air burning as "burning any material in the open or in a receptacle other than a furnace, … including use of fireworks, sparklers, or sparkling devices."
Brian LeCates, county director of emergency services, said in a memorandum to the county that the request for a burn ban came from volunteer fire chiefs. The county's burn ban committee requested the council enact the 30-day ban.
"Their concern is that we have had abnormally dry conditions with no appreciable precipitation in the weather forecast," LeCates wrote.
LeCates noted that the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration is "currently classifying Talbot County as having abnormally dry conditions."
"Looking at our weather forecast, we do not show any significant precipitation in the near future," he wrote. "The Maryland Department of Natural Resources Forest Service has listed our area as highly susceptible to fire due to these conditions."
Last week, Dorchester and Wicomico counties each enacted burn bans due to drought-like conditions. On Oct. 22, Wicomico County voted to extend its burn ban.
Talbot County most recently enacted a burn ban on July 21, which was placed due to similar dry conditions and a significant heat wave.

An Alford plea allows a person to maintain their innocence while acknowledging the state had enough evidence to obtain a conviction. The other 12 counts will not be prosecuted.
Perez's jury trial, which was scheduled to begin Oct. 28, is now canceled.
The counts that will not be prosecuted included first-degree rape of an 8-year-old child, along with incest, first-degree child abuse, first-degree assault and sexual solicitation of a minor, all allegedly occurring at his residence in Greensboro around March 30.

Perez's sentencing is scheduled for Dec. 13. Judge Sidney S. Campen requested a full pre-sentence investigation into Perez prior to that date.
Attorney Eduardo Gonzalez, who represents Perez, did not immediately respond to request for comment.
Charging documents indicated Perez as the 8-year-old child's parent. Since being charged, he's been held without bond at the Caroline County Detention Center.
Perez faces an addition 19 counts of criminal charges in Wicomico County, including first-degree rape, sexual abuse of a minor and second-degree assault. All 19 of those charges state the offenses occurred between August 2021 and April 2024 in Wicomico County, according to court records.
The Wicomico County charges total a potential 224 years in prison, along with life in prison for the first-degree rape charge.

title: ‘Cutting edge’: Talbot County first responders create mental health peer program
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
‘Cutting edge’: Talbot County first responders create mental health peer program

 October 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 657
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A new peer support program is aiming to break stigmas around mental health and provide direct assistance to first responders across Talbot County.The collaborative program is called Talbot FiRST!, a joint effort between the Talbot County Department of Emergency Services, 911 dispatch center, Talbot County Sheriff's Office, Talbot County Department of Corrections, Easton Police Department and Easton Volunteer Fire Department.
Tina Kintop, EMS division chief for the Department of Emergency Services, says the program is meant to provide mental health services for all first responders in the county.
The peer support team will be made up of a diverse selection of first responders who have been interviewed and trained through a partnership with For All Seasons. When a first responder is in need of help, they can contact a peer member.
Kintop says the program is designed so first responders don't have to "go through the ranks" for mental health assistance.
"The idea is that they can come from the bottom up, meaning that they will know who all the peer (team members) are," Kintop said. " … They will be able to contact who they want to contact."
Kintop and fellow members of Talbot FiRST!'s steering committee — made up of heads from all of the agencies — were applauded by the Talbot County Council on Oct. 22 for the initiative.
County Manager Clay Stamp, a former Talbot County emergency services director, commended the program for being the first of its kind in Maryland.
"The things that we expose our 18-year-old kids to — that become EMTs or dispatchers or police officers — are horrendous," Stamp said on Oct. 22. "We have got to come up with a better way to arm these individuals to deal with these things in a healthy manner and to give them a support system.
"And right here in Talbot County, out of the 23 counties and Baltimore City, they've stepped up, and they're making it happen first."
Former EMS Division Chief Matt Watkins said it's a step very few first responder communities around the country have taken, adding, "Talbot County should be extremely proud of the fact that we're on the cutting edge of this."
Kintop and Watkins have been involved in creating the program for more than a year. A training by former New York City Police Department detective and crisis negotiator Jeff Thompson ignited their enthusiasm for the project.
Kintop called the four-day training "rigorous," yet said all of the first responders who attended were committed to learning from Thompson's life experiences.
"By the time the day was over, you didn't even know you were there for eight hours. It was so engaging, and everybody felt the same way," Kintop said. " … It brought up all the things that maybe I didn't seek help for, that I just kind of sucked it up and handled it on my own."
Kintop says the peer program will be completing a second phase of training soon to expand the peer team, along with doing outreach to first responder agencies. Her hope is that Talbot FiRST! becomes a model up and down the Eastern Shore.
For All Seasons CEO Beth Anne Dorman said funding from the Rural Maryland Council made the nonprofit's clinical training with the Talbot County first responders possible. In fiscal year 2024, the Rural Maryland Council awarded a $30,000 grant to For All Seasons meant to aid the organization in training first responder agencies across the Mid-Shore.
Talbot County Council President Chuck Callahan recalled the stigma around mental health in the first responder community when he first volunteered as a firefighter at 18 years old.
"You kind of feel like you're out there alone sometimes, and you need to talk to somebody," Callahan said at the Oct. 22 meeting. "Sometimes, the stuff that we do feels like it's forgotten.
"As long as we're up here, you guys are never ever going to get forgotten," Callahan said, "because you're our heroes in Talbot County, and we love you guys and you protect us."

 CAMBRIDGE — Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd and Rescue Fire Company Chief Brad Walters both gave updates on their departments at a Cambridge City Council meeting Oct. 28.During the meeting, Walters talked about the fire company's goals and objectives, and Todd talked about the police department's third quarter report, which breaks down data from July through September.
RESCUE FIRE COMPANYThe Rescue Fire Company Chiefs Office has nine goals for 2024 through 2026:
Provide an advanced, cost-effective and dependable fleet of apparatuses.Ensure a healthy and safe workplace.Provide an efficient and well-structured training program.Improve response management.Improve internal and external communications.Provide well-structured and accessible standard operating guidelines and procedures.Improve records management.Provide an efficient system for inventory and supplies.Improve recruitment and retention.
Objectives for the nine goals include developing a health and fitness program for members, developing a standard for response times and staff availability, developing mutual aid agreements with surrounding departments and developing an outreach program for recruitment.
Walters, who attended the council meeting virtually, said the fire company has always had goals and objectives in place.
"Now we're just finally putting them on paper, (putting) them out there," he said to the City Council.
CAMBRIDGE POLICE DEPARTMENTAfter Walters spoke, Todd filled the City Council in on the police department's third quarter report. He said the department has been keeping up with its reporting in an effort to be transparent and keep the public aware of what is happening in Cambridge.
Todd listed some reductions in crime and said he sees these reductions as a sign of progress. He said there is still "a lot of work ahead," but the department will keep working.
According to the report, compared to last year's third quarter, violent crime is down 31%, stolen vehicle reports are down 114%, simple assault complaints are down 16%, aggravated assault complaints are down 62% and ShotSpotter alerts are down 57%.
Todd said he believes the percentage of stolen vehicle reports decreased more than 100% this year because many of the vehicle thefts last year were committed by kids after videos came out showing how a person can easily break into Kias and Hyundais.
Todd said Kia and Hyundai has since fixed this issue. He said the Cambridge Police Department also identified many of those children, and a lot of them were given referrals to the Department of Juvenile Services.
"I believe that's the main reason you see that drop that significant," Todd said.
Todd also mentioned some increases in certain crimes. According to the report, sexual crime is up 122% and vandalism and malicious destruction of property complaints are up 27% compared to last year's third quarter.
Todd said the department will work to address these increases.
"We'll get to the point of figuring out why they are up and who is doing those crimes," he said.
After Todd spoke, multiple commissioners thanked him and his department for their efforts.
Commissioner Jameson Harrington said he was impressed with the results from ShotSpotter, a gunshot detection system. The ShotSpotter data within the report broke down the number of gunshot incidents and rounds fired it has detected, as well as the top locations for gunfire.
"I was very skeptical at first, and I've seen how it's been misused and mis-deployed in other cities, but it seems like it's working well here," Harrington said about the system. "So thank you."

title: Former Easton Police officer to serve 6 months after sexual conduct with teenagers
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Former Easton Police officer to serve 6 months after sexual conduct with teenagers

 November 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Crime 
 
 711
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — During a hearing Friday morning, a former Easton Police officer was sentenced to four years of incarceration with all but six months suspended.In September, Jason Dyott, 38, was found guilty of misconduct in office for engaging in physical sexual conduct with two different teenage girls while on duty.
The former sergeant — who resigned from the police department Thursday — will also have to serve three years of supervised probation upon his release. Judge C. Carey Deeley Jr., who handed down the sentence, said conditions of probation include completing treatment and not having any contact with the victims.
During the hearing Friday, Deeley said Dyott had leveraged his position of trust as a police officer in order to cause young women to "come under his spell."
"It was heinous conduct," Deeley said.
On Sept. 10, Deeley found Dyott guilty on two counts of misconduct in office. The charges stem from allegations that Dyott used his departmental cell phone to communicate in a sexual manner with several teenagers and students at local high schools. Dyott met up with the students while on duty.
During the September trial, Senior Assistant State Prosecutor Mary Setzer said in the fall of 2022, Dyott engaged in physical acts with the two teenage girls in separate instances.
Deputy State Prosecutor Sarah David said at the trial that in the two incidents, Dyott acted in his official capacity. Not only was he on duty, she said, but he was presenting himself to the public and to the teenage girls as an officer.
At the hearing Friday, Dyott apologized to the court, the victims, the Town of Easton and his family. He said he was going through a separation at the time of the incidents and he "wasn't in (his) right mind." He said he should not have used his position of power and said what he did was morally and ethically wrong.
Dyott said he has sought treatment and hopes to continue it. According to Dyott's defense attorney, Shaun Owens, Dyott has been undergoing sex offender treatment.
Dyott's wife, Amber Dyott, said her husband has owned up to his mistakes and grown and learned from them. She said her husband has faced public punishment and asked that the court consider her family, including Jason Dyott's kids, while determining the sentence.
The defense requested Dyott be sentenced to three years of supervised probation with no incarceration. The Office of the State Prosecutor asked that Dyott be sentenced to four years of incarceration with all but six months suspended.
Although one of the victims who testified in the trial wrote a statement for the sentencing, it was not read aloud during the hearing.
Until Thursday, Dyott — who was named the Easton Police Department's officer of the year in 2014 — had been suspended with pay by the department. He was put on suspension in the beginning stages of the investigation in 2023.
In an interview with the Star Democrat, Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey said the department sent a letter to Dyott that if he did not resign, he would be terminated following his sentencing. Lowrey said Dyott resigned from the department Thursday.
Lowrey said Dyott had been served with charges by the Talbot County Administrative Charging Committee and they held off on pursuing a trial in an effort to protect the victims. Lowrey said an additional trial with the Administrative Charging Committee would mean the victims would have to testify twice. He said he didn't want to do that to them and that is why it took as long as it did for the department to separate from Dyott.
Lowrey said he agreed with the court's decision. In a news release he said the department is happy it can continue to serve the community "without the weight of Mr. Dyott's immoral actions on our shoulders."
"Being a police officer is more than a job, it is an acceptance of a duty to uphold the laws of our country and a duty to the safety of the members of our community," Lowrey said. "It is also the acceptance of a duty to your fellow law enforcement officers. It is disappointing and maddening to our community, our officers and to me that Mr. Dyott chose to violate these duties and serve his own gratifications at the expense of young people in our community."

title: Polling places taking security measures on election day
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Polling places taking security measures on election day

 November 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 691
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Voters may notice police presence on Election Day.Talbot County Election Director Tammy Stafford said her office has been working with local law enforcement and emergency services to prepare for Nov. 5. Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble outlined in an interview the security measures the Sheriff's Office has been requested to provide.
Gamble says his deputies and town police departments in Talbot County will be performing patrol checks in parking lots on Election Day. With schools closed, school resource officers will provide assistance, allowing for a "quicker response time should there be an issue," he said.
Local police will also be following election judges from polling places to the elections office as ballots are escorted, the sheriff said.
Despite the added measures, Gamble said he has been in communications with the State Board of Elections ahead of Tuesday's election, and "(There are) no known issues in Maryland, there are no known threats in Maryland."
Election officials in neighboring counties say there haven't been any incidents to threaten security.
Dorchester County Election Director Gwendolyn Dales said she has not experienced any incidents, adding that there are no current plans to have a police presence when ballots are escorted.
The Dorchester County Sheriff's Office and Cambridge Police Department will be performing security checks at polling locations, Dales said.
"They'll be going from polling place to polling place (at) various times," Dales said, "meandering through the parking lots and making sure everything's safe and secure."
Caroline County Election Director Allison Murphy said her office has "security measures in place" to ensure voters have a safe voting experience.
"We're following guidance from the state," Murphy said, "and we have plans in place to ensure voters' ballots are secure."
Murphy said the county will be "diligent in making sure" that every ballot is counted.
The topic of election security generated a back-and-forth last month between Gamble and Attorney General Anthony Brown. On Oct. 1, Gamble wrote in a letter to the local board of elections that his office will conduct security checks of polling locations "to ensure we have a safe and fair election."
Brown said in an Oct. 7 letter that sheriff's offices across the state play a limited role in election security.
"I understand that local law enforcement agencies do provide assistance to local boards of elections in some jurisdictions, including deploying personnel to provide security and transporting election materials," Brown wrote. "But importantly, this is done at the request and under the direction of the local Board of Elections itself."
Gamble wrote a letter in response to Brown on Oct. 15, saying he understood chief election judges "have authority at the polling places." He expanded on his original letter, noting that the Talbot County Board of Elections requested additional police presence.
BALLOT DROP BOXESEarlier this week, ballot boxes were set on fire in Oregon and Washington, leading to security concerns across the nation.
Election officials in Washington said hundreds of ballots were damaged Monday in a fire set with an incendiary device, according to The Associated Press. That incident is connected to another ballot box fire in Oregon, according to local police.
Every county in Maryland has drop boxes for voters to place their completed mail-in ballots. There are three in Caroline County, and two in both Dorchester and Talbot counties.
In an emailed statement to the Star Democrat, Maryland State Board of Elections Administrator Jared DeMarinis said "Marylanders can feel safe and confident in using the drop box."
"This is always something I'm concerned about," DeMarinis wrote. "This is a crime against democracy. We have taken steps to mitigate any potential problems if it occurs in Maryland. This situation was a scenario in our tabletop exercises prior to the election."
DeMarinis said drop box locations are under "24/7 video surveillance" and that local election boards are "modifying pick up schedules to increase coverage." The state board is in contact with state and federal law enforcement for added protections, DeMarinis said.
Dales, the Dorchester election director, said what she's seeing nationally this week is "very concerning."
"We just want citizens and voters to feel safe and secure in any situation," Dales said. "But I think the safest thing and most secure thing to do is to come into a polling place and vote your ballot."

 EASTON — A chimney fire was extinguished Sunday night at the Tidewater Inn before any significant damage was caused the the structure, according to Easton Volunteer Fire Department Chief Sonny Jones.According to bystanders at the scene, smoke and embers could be seen from the historic hotel's roof at around 7 p.m. Jones said around 45 firefighters from the Easton, Oxford, Trappe and Cordova departments worked to extinguish the blaze "within 15 to 20 minutes of arrival."
"When we arrived, we determined that the fire was actually coming from the chimney for the hotel, so it was a chimney fire," Jones said. "And there was no extension to the roof decking or any of the surrounding structure to the chimney. The fire was contained to the inside of the chimney."
Jones added that there was "minimal damage" and that the hotel's roof and its contents were left unharmed. No injuries were reported.
Don Reedy, director of operations at the Tidewater Inn, said the hotel's chimney is being inspected and there will not be any fires in the lobby fireplace in the meantime.
Reedy said Sunday's fire will not affect the Tidewater Inn's hosting of the Waterfowl Festival opening ceremonies this Thursday evening.
"We're back to business this morning," Reedy said. " … The floors and the guest rooms all seem fine."
Jones said he's glad the fire departments prevented any major damage to the historic inn the week of Waterfowl. He added that chimney fires are something to watch out for
"This time of year, chimney fires are common," Jones said. "A lot of times, chimney fires can be started from burning wood that is green (and) may not be completely seasoned. It's a buildup of basically creosote in the chimney.
" … We encourage people to regularly maintain chimneys, have them professionally cleaned (in order to) avoid these types of fires."

 EASTON — Easton residents reported incidents of sign vandalism in the days leading up to the 2024 general election.Sandra Chappell said on Monday her two yard signs supporting Vice President Kamala Harris and Angela Alsobrooks were taken from her yard and disposed of away from her property.
Chappell said the incident left her surprised and concerned over political vandalism.
"It's just not right," Chappell said. "You can have different opinions, but you should also respect the fact that others do too, and it doesn't mean that the other side from wherever a person is bad, it just means that they differ with you and their opinions, because that should be a part of life."

title: Support for Veterans Court gains momentum
author: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com
content:
Support for Veterans Court gains momentum

 November 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 746
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A lobbying effort that could create at least one military veterans treatment court on the Mid-Shore continues to gain momentum.The charge is being led by Josh Marks, a Carroll County resident who wrote to the Kent County News and Bay Times Record Observer this summer stating he is part of a group hoping to establish the court across the Mid- and Upper Shore. His initiative was broached in Carroll County in 2022.
"The proposed veterans treatment court would provide treatment for those veterans suffering from post traumatic stress disorder and traumatic brain injury, accountability and mentoring to former military service members, while helping those veterans to reintegrate into society and connect those veterans who are involved with the justice system with the benefits they have earned," Marks said.
In noting the success his efforts had in his home county, Marks stated it was helped by "written letters of support" from several entities, including veterans groups, the Maryland Bar Association, the American Red Cross and United Way.
"There are currently four veterans courts in Maryland — Baltimore city, Anne Arundel, Prince George's and Dorchester," Marks said.
The court in Dorchester County serves the Lower Eastern Shore region.
Across the U.S., there are just over 600 veteran-focused court programs.
On the Mid- and Upper Shore, Marks continues to gain support.
In August, Marks received letters of support from Maryland Sens. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico), Steve Hershey (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) and Jason Gallion (R-Cecil, Harford) and Del. Christopher Adams (R-Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico).
Adams wrote, "treatment courts provide a second chance to individuals suffering trauma and illness as a result of their service, while providing ongoing peer support to these Marylanders."
Hershey agreed suggesting, a Veterans Court could also access local resources where a veteran does not qualify for VA benefits. "Veterans suffering from mental health issues and substance abuse would be able to enter programs to assist in recovery and be given a pathway to reintegrate into the community," Hershey wrote in his letter of support.
Mautz too lent his support for "a Veteran's Treatment Court in Kent County, Maryland that would support my District 37 constituents in Caroline and Talbot Counties."
In Kent County, Marks was pleased to hear from Maryland District Court Judge John E. Nunn, who asked the District 3 Criminal Intake Commissioners to do a study of veteran defendants by county.
This is a major first step to gauge case volume, Marks said, and he believes once the data is gathered there will be ample volume to establish a regional court. venue. In Marks' Southern Maryland initiative (District 4), he said, Maryland District Court Judge Kristy Holt Chesser asked for a year of data.
"I believe we have shown consensus with four of the five counties encompassing District 3 for a Veterans Treatment Court," Marks said in an August correspondence to the paper.
Marks has also established contact with Eric Johnson of VAMSA (Veteran and Military Support Alliance) in Queen Anne's County and although working independently of each other, Marks said they are sharing resources to promote this venue. "If in fact this venue becomes a reality, it would be my hope that the VAMSA center could be the Docket Coordinator," Marks said.
During Marks' work in Southern Maryland in 2022, then Calvert County Interim State's Attorney Robert Harvey said he supports "expanding legal resources available to veterans through our court system."
Harvey stated he has spoken to judges from both the local circuit and district courts as well as the public defenders' office about the issue and stated the courts have had problems identifying veterans entering the system. Harvey said there is a move to get changes in the application process at the state level. He also plans to observe the workings of the veterans court in Anne Arundel.
"We'll see how it's done in another county," said Harvey.
Calvert Commissioner President Earl F. "Buddy Hance stated he has received a request for support of starting the veterans treatment court in Calvert and has forwarded the initiative to the veterans affairs commission.
When asked this fall about the possibility of a District 3 court on the Shore, Queen Anne's County State's Attorney Lance Richardson said he would be in favor of such a court. "I see many veterans with mental health and substance abuse issues," he said. "I'm in favor of more options for treatment services. These veterans deserve the assistance as a reward for their service."
Establishing the court would require local funding or grant funding from the state.
Marty Madden at Southern Maryland News contributed to this article.

title: Brushfire underscores state's burn ban as drought persists
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content:
Brushfire underscores state's burn ban as drought persists

 November 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 541
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Despite some much-needed rain overnight Sunday into early Monday, a burn ban remains in effect for all of Maryland.Last week on Nov. 6 around 2:30 p.m., Waldorf Company 3 was dispatched to the area of Slater Lane, off Poplar Hill Road, to investigate the report of smoke. Upon arrival, it was determined this was a large area brush fire and additional resources were requested, according to a release from the Waldorf Volunteer Fire Department.
All available brush trucks from all stations in Charles County were requested, as well as units from St. Mary's, Calvert and Prince George's counties.
Roughly four to five acres of land were involved. A number of units remained on scene throughout the night, the release said.
The brush fire was indicative of the larger problem at hand — a drought that brought some of the driest weather that the region has seen within 130 years.
The statewide burning ban implemented by the Maryland Department of Natural Resources Nov. 1 remains in effect, the state agency said in a Nov. 12 update.
"While most of the state experienced varying amounts of rain earlier this week, fuel and drought conditions continue to be well above normal seasonal highs," a release from the Maryland Department of Natural Resources said. "These conditions coupled with low humidity and gusty winds expected in the next several days will once again raise fire danger across the state."
A return to normal seasonal patterns with cooler temperatures and frequent showers will be needed to lift the burn ban, the department said.
"We do not make these determinations lightly and understand this may require some people to adjust their plans," Department of Natural Resources Secretary Josh Kurtz said. "However, a ban of this magnitude is necessary to protect the lives and property of Maryland residents and visitors, as well as the state's natural resources."
Since Oct. 1, Maryland Department of Natural Resources units and partner agencies have responded to 50 wildland fires in the state that burned an estimated 117.8 acres of land.
As of Nov. 12, five of those fires are contained and actively staffed, 15 are contained and monitored by patrol, and 30 are out.
According to the National Integrated Drought Information System, a program under the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, 3.1 million residents of Maryland are in areas of drought.
That is roughly half the population of the state, according to census data.
According to the National Integrated Drought Information System, each county in the tri-county had a top five driest October within the past 130 years.
Throughout October, Charles County had 2.6 less inches of rain than normal, Calvert County had 2.83 inches less, and St. Mary's County had 2.9 inches less.
That marked St. Mary's County's second driest October in the past 130 years.
Since 1988, the state of Maryland has enacted full statutory bans in 1988, 1995, 1999 and 2006 and less stringent regulatory bans four times in 1991, 1998, 2001 and 2002. Historically, restrictions have remained in place from one to eight weeks.
Other states in the mid-Atlantic region are experiencing wildfires, according to DNR. One such blaze near the border of New York and New Jersey has burned roughly 3,500 acres as of Nov. 12, underscoring the importance of Maryland's burn ban.
More rain was predicted in the region overnight Thursday into Friday.

title: CASA is grateful for its volunteers this holiday season

 At CASA of the Mid-Shore, we are committed to advocating for children under the protection of the Talbot, Dorchester, Queen Anne's and Kent circuit courts due to abuse, neglect or abandonment. Our nonprofit organization's mission is to ensure that every child has the right to thrive in a safe and permanent home.CASA (Court Appointed Special Advocate) volunteers play a vital role in this mission. "Speaking up for children is our guiding principle," said Robin Davenport, CASA's executive director. "It reinforces our belief that a brighter future is possible for every child we serve... National studies confirm the value of CASA — findings show that children are more hopeful when a CASA is in their lives.
CASA volunteers come from all walks of life, have varied experiences and professions, and are at least 21 years of age. After completing the application and screening process, individuals participate in pre-service training before being sworn in as officers of the court. title: Cambridge parents plead guilty, sentenced for neglect of a minor
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Cambridge parents plead guilty, sentenced for neglect of a minor

 November 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Crime 
 
 699
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Two Cambridge parents pleaded guilty to neglect of a minor Monday following the death of their 14-year-old daughter.David and Mandy Insley were each handed a sentence of five years of incarceration with all but 271 days of the incarceration suspended. Both have 271 days of credit for time served leading up to their plea hearing Monday.
Judge Karen Dean also sentenced David and Mandy Insley to five years of supervised probation. Conditions of probation include that they cannot bring pets into their home and that they both continue mental health treatment.
The parents were originally each charged with first-degree child abuse resulting in death, but the state entered into nolle prosequi on those counts, meaning the state will not prosecute for those charges.
As a part of a plea deal, Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard recommended no more than an 18 month active sentence. She said no sentence is more difficult to go through than what David and Mandy Insley have to live with for the rest of their lives.
Leonard said that on June 26, 2023, police and emergency medical services responded to the Insley home in response to a 14-year-old girl suffering from a cardiac arrest. Paige Insley was found unresponsive in her bed and pronounced dead on the scene.
Leonard said the teen had been diagnosed at birth with a developmental disability that caused her to suffer from seizures. She said Mandy Insley indicated to police that she had forgotten to give her daughter medication for her seizures the night before but gave them to her in the morning.
An autopsy report found that Paige Insley most likely died of a seizure that was due to an underlying condition, Leonard said.
Leonard also spoke about the condition of the Insley home. She said police noted the house was dirty and cluttered. There was animal feces on the ground. Leonard said mice and mice excrement were found throughout the house.
Leonard said there were no findings of abuse to the child as a result of the conditions of the home, but she said there were findings that Paige Insley was neglected by parents who were responsible for her wellness, safety and living conditions.
Cambridge Code Enforcement and Dorchester County Animal Control were called to the house following Paige Insley's death, and, according to a news release from the Cambridge Police Department, Cambridge Code Enforcement condemned the house.
Both David and Mandy Insley spoke during the hearing Monday. Mandy Insley said she has been attending weekly appointments with a therapist and has started taking medication. David asked the judge that she allow him to rebuild with his wife. He said that leading up to Paige's death, the tapestry of his life had begun to unravel and they weren't able to get help with the house.
"We just want a chance to try and function again," he said through tears. "She was my best friend."
Mandy Insley's attorney Archibald McFadden said there was no causal link between the conditions of the house and Paige's death. He said the COVID-19 pandemic affected everyone, and the Inselys are one of example of that. The pandemic, he said, resulted in David Insley losing his job as a reporter at the Star Democrat. He said mental health issues exacerbated by isolation resulted in the family's poor living conditions.
McFadden said both David and Mandy Insley have gotten treatment and cleaned up their house.
David Insley's attorney Michelle Moodispaw from the Office of the Public Defender said David Insley has struggled with mental health challenges for most of his life and the pandemic and its effects led to a steep decline of mental health. She said letters submitted into evidence show who David Insley is as a father, particularly with Paige.
Leonard said she didn't think there was a lack of love or care of Paige from David and Mandy Insley, adding, "I can't explain what was going on in that home."
Before handing down the sentence, Judge Karen Dean said she was sorry for the Insleys' loss and called the situation "horrible." Dean said it was clear that neglect based on the state of the household and the death of the teen were two separate things. She said the death brought the neglect to light.

title: Emergency officials offer safety tips for frying turkey
author: Tom McCall
content:
Emergency officials offer safety tips for frying turkey

 November 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 656
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — There are a few ways to cook a turkey. Deep frying has become a popular, though sometimes treacherous, way to get the job done.Many people like the crispy results deep frying can provide, including Easton Volunteer Fire Department Assistant Chief JR Dobson.
"I love deep fried turkey. It is like eating fried chicken. It is always moist in the middle. It tastes pretty good, especially if you season it right," Dobson said.
But when frying a turkey, especially for the first time, Dobson and other emergency officials warn it's important to research proper safety protocols.
"I think they can be dangerous if you don't do your research first," Dobson said. "You don't want to overfill that pot with grease and then the grease comes out of the pot and gets in the flame. We recommend that people who have never done it before, do your research."
Grease fires can happen quickly and are difficult to extinguish, as water cannot be used to put them out.
According to the National Fire Protection Association, Thanksgiving Day is the peak day for fires caused by cooking. About 1,000 home fires occur on that day nationwide.
On top of keeping an eye out for splashing grease, those frying turkeys are encouraged to ensure cooking oil doesn't get too hot, fryers are used in outdoor settings away from any structures and turkeys are fully thawed before being dropped in the oil.
"Make sure your turkey is thawed out. Make sure not deep frying a turkey inside of your house or inside a shed. Make sure you are outside away from any structure. If there was an event, make sure you are far enough away not to catch your building on fire," Dobson said.
Though it's not his favorite way to cook the bird, Jordon Lloyd, the chef at the Robert Morris Inn, offered some tips for frying turkey.
"You have a nice big pot. You want to keep it self-contained like out in a yard. You have kind of a jet propulsion burner is what you need, like what you would steam crabs with. It has a basket inside that you can lift up out of it. It takes about 45 minutes. You don't want the oil to be ripping hot like at 400 degrees. 325 is good. Fry it kind of slow and low," Lloyd said.
"You can't put stuffing in. It just falls out. Maybe I am not doing it right. Everyone seems to like it, but it just tastes weird to me," Lloyd said.
He offered his favorite way to cook a turkey.
"The best way is to brine it. The classic brine is one gallon of water, one cup of salt, half a cup of sugar. That is your brine. You boil that, and then chill it, and then you let your turkey soak in that," Lloyd said. "... A 12 pound turkey, you leave it overnight for 24 hours. Then I roast in an oven, no basting necessary. The brine is absorbed in the meat, keeps it nice and tender. The sugar you put in the brine activates that gorgeous brown turkey crust. Say 375 for three hours."
Those looking to give frying a turkey a try can find everything they need at local hardware stores.
"I sell it all. I have the pot, I have the burner, I have the oil, gloves. We have peanut oil. We sell propane and injectors if you want to put your own seasoning into them. Most of the people that buy know what they are doing and have done it before. But there are some that don't," said Mason of Easton Hardware, who did not share his last name.
"The bucket of oil pretty much explains it. So many minutes per pound and at such and such a temperature, and you roll on. It is easier than sitting in an oven. Just don't let there be any moisture on the bird before you put it in there. Happy Thanksgiving," Mason said.

title: Jury convicts Maryland man of involuntary manslaughter in crossbow killing of girlfriend
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Jury convicts Maryland man of involuntary manslaughter in crossbow killing of girlfriend

 November 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 1643
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A man who fatally shot his live-in girlfriend with a crossbow inside their Conowingo residence is facing up to 15 years in prison after a Cecil County Circuit Court jury convicted him of two lesser charges at the conclusion of three-day-long murder trial.Jurors deliberated for approximately four hours on Friday, Nov. 22, before finding the defendant — Jeffrey Allen Lander, 41 — guilty of involuntary manslaughter and reckless endangerment, which carry maximum sentences of 10 years and five years respectively.
Involuntary manslaughter applies when the defendant unintentionally kills someone while acting with gross negligence, meaning the defendant should have known the risk of his or her actions. Other elements also can apply under the statute.
The jury, however, acquitted Lander of second-degree murder, first-degree assault and second-degree assault. All of those criminal offenses involve an intentional act, to varied degrees. Second-degree murder is punishable by up to 40 years in prison. First-degree assault and second-degree assault carry maximum sentences of 25 years and 10 years respectively.
Lander's sentencing is set for Jan. 28.
ACCIDENTAL OR INTENTIONALProsecutors maintained that Lander intentionally shot 45-year-old Judy Elizabeth Gee in the back with a crossbow arrow inside the couple's residence in the 700 block of Bell Manor Road at approximately 4:40 p.m. on Jan. 14. An ambulance crew transported Gee to Lancaster General Hospital in Lancaster, Pa., where she died on an operating table at 7:13 p.m., about two and half hours later.
The defense, however, contended that Lander accidentally shot Gee with the arrow when he tripped seconds after removing his loaded crossbow from a wall rack in the living room while she was seated on a nearby couch, possibly leaning toward an end table to retrieve something.
Aside from Gee, Lander was the only person present when the fatal shooting occurred — and he provided the narrative of the incident to investigators.
Assistant State's Attorney Robert Sentman asserted in his opening statement and closing arguments that Lander intentionally shot Gee because, during an argument moments earlier, Gee had informed Lander that she was ending their two-year relationship and that she was leaving him.
"The safety must be manually moved into the unlocked position," Sentman emphasized during his opening statement, telling jurors that a deliberate action must occur before that crossbow owned by Lander can be fired.
Cecil County Sheriff's Office detectives made that same contention on the witness stand and during a recorded police interview with Lander. Those investigators insisted that Lander shot Gee in the "heat of the moment" amid the argument and that he immediately experienced regret and emotional aguish, prompting him to call 911.
Assistant Public Defender Jason Ricke, however, categorized the deadly shooting this way when addressing the jury in his opening statement: "It was a tragic accident — nothing more. It is not a murder. It is not a crime."
Lander elected not to testify in his own defense.
But his version of the fatal shooting and the events leading up to it were documented by video gleaned from agency-issued cameras worn by deputies at the shooting scene and by a recording of investigators interviewing Lander at CCSO headquarters on the night of the incident.
Lander's explanation of how the fatal shooting occurred also was recorded on March 14 by detectives during a third-party call — an investigative technique in which police monitor a phone call made to an unwitting suspect by someone the suspect knows.
During that monitored phone call, Lander continued to maintain that the shooting was an accident. Lander, however, denied that he and Gee had been arguing before the shooting — contrasting the information he had given investigators two months earlier on the late afternoon and night of the incident.
Those recordings were played in the courtroom for the jury during the trial.
The defense maintained that Lander never wavered from his explanation — that it was an accidental shooting — but the state contended that he changed minor and even some significant details of his account.
Police arrested and charged Lander on June 28, six months after the incident, after an investigation that included consulting with a crossbow expert.
LANDER'S ACCOUNTLander told investigators that he slept most of the day on Jan. 14 and awoke at about 4 p.m. to an immediate argument with Gee, who was accusing him of "stealing her stuff."
"She was kicking me in the knee. It was a rude awakening. I woke up angry," Lander told investigators in one of the recordings.
During the dispute, Gee reminded Lander that she was making her own money now and that she was going to leave him.
"She was making a move," Lander said, before telling investigators, "I told her, 'Get your (expletive) and go'."
Lander maintained that Gee's stated decision to leave did not bother him, telling investigators, "I'd rather her leave and be happy than stay and be miserable."
Amid that argument or directly after it, Lander decided to go deer hunting, wanting to make use of approximately one hour of remaining daylight.
Along those lines, Lander told investigators that he typically would leave the house and take walks in the woods to decompress after confrontations with Gee who, according to Lander, had falsely accused him of cheating on her and of committing other transgressions in the past.
Lander told police that, during deer hunting season, he always kept his crossbow loaded and drawn while stored on a wall mount. "It's cocked and loaded and ready to go," Lander told investigators.
In addition, Lander told investigators that he believed the safety on the crossbow was engaged when he pulled the weapon off the wall and turned to maneuver it through a doorway. That is when a pet cat — one of "12 to 20" inside that house — cut into his path.
"I turned to get through the door and the damn cat tripped me up and the thing (crossbow) went off," Lander outlined.
Lander insisted to investigators, "I did not touch the safety at all. I did not touch the trigger."
He later theorized to investigators that the cocking rope might have gotten snagged on an object in that cluttered house and caused the crossbow to discharge. Lander also remained adamant that he thought the crossbow's safety was engaged.
"I can't describe what happened," Lander said, telling investigators that he could explain what caused the crossbow to shoot. "It's (expletive) up."
He told police that he immediately called 911, after realizing that the arrow had struck Gee, and then followed the instructions that an emergency dispatcher gave him over the phone while waiting for first responders to arrive.
Trial testimony indicated that the arrow entered Gee's chest through the side of her upper back and severed her spinal cord, causing instantaneous paralysis, and it lodged inside of her body, with the tip protruding out the front side of her lower chest. The arrow entered Gee's body at a five-degree downward angle.
A recording of Lander's 911 call was played for jurors. Lander told the dispatcher that he had accidentally shot Gee. Lander cried and uttered exclamations, sounding frantic at times as he urged Gee to remain awake.
Early on at the scene, Gee was conscious but not alert, to the point she did not know her name when asked. Experiencing heavy internal bleeding, Gee's condition declined rapidly.
SUSPECT TIMINGCCSO investigators expressed disbelief that Lander's shooting of Gee was an accident — considering that she had kicked him awake less than one hour before it happened and then accused him of stealing her stuff during an argument in which Gee informed Lander that she was leaving him, ending their two-year-long relationship.
"We look at the totality of things," one of the CCSO detectives told Lander in recorded police interview, before opining, "I don't think you're a bad guy. I think you made a mistake in the heat of the moment . . . Because of everything that went on, you snapped."
Investigators also suggested that, short of that scenario, Lander pointed the crossbow at Gee to scare her and that it discharged.
Lander told investigators that he didn't believe Gee actually was going to leave him. It was Lander's opinion that Gee made that remark only to make him angry and that her effort failed.
During that interview, investigators advised Lander that if he admitted to intentionally shooting Gee, it could mitigate his consequences. They also reminded Lander that Gee could give police an account that might incriminate him. Later in the interview, investigators informed Lander that Gee had died from her wound, causing him to sob. Investigators admittedly withheld news of Gee's death from Lander for a brief period during that interview, as an investigative tactic.
While investigators tried to convince Lander to change his version and admit to intentionally shooting Gee, Lander commented, "I'm not going to lie about. Lying is not in my (expletive) character . . . My story is not going to change. I did not mean for this to happen. It was not on my agenda."
INCONGRUENT BEHAVIOROn Friday morning, during his closing argument, Ricke listed several things that Lander did and said after the fatal shooting that would be inconsistent with someone who intentionally killed his girlfriend.
The list included an emotional Lander calling 911 to report the shooting; positioning himself so close to Gee while urging her to stay awake that Gee's breathing could be heard on the recording of that 911 call; requesting that he be allowed to go to the hospital with Gee; asking investigators for medical updates on Gee during his police interview and breaking down in tears after investigators informed him of Gee's death.
Addressing one other item on that list, Ricke emphasized that investigators likely would have never known that Lander and Gee had been engaged in argument before the fatal shooting — but for Lander volunteering that information at the outset.
"Why did he tell about the argument at all if he is this mastermind? Because he was being honest," Ricke asked and answered rhetorically during his closing argument, before stressing to jurors that Lander was telling the whole truth.

title: Emergency Medical Services hq named after public servant
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Emergency Medical Services hq named after public servant

 November 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 445
 Words

 CHESTERTOWN — On Tuesday afternoon, Nov. 19, ground was broken for the future site of the Robert B. Rust Jr. Kent County Emergency Medical Services headquarters at 104 Vickers Drive. The site was dedicated to the public servant for his vision almost 30 years ago.Rust, as well as Director of Emergency Services Pete Landon, Chief of Emergency Services Logan Quinn, Kent County Commission President Ron Fithian, Commissioners John Price and Albert Nickerson and County Administrator Shelley Heller tossed out the first shovelfuls of dirt as community members applauded.
Rust reflected on the past, his son, Danny, at his side. Rust said he would have never imagined this building being named after him when he first proposed an idea for a 24-7 Advanced Life System (ALS) to then, Sheriff John Price.
Fithian pointed out that in 1994, Rust approached the County with an idea to pay EMT's to assist with the volunteers.
At the time, the County only had one paramedic, part time, and that was deputy John Longest, Fithian said.
Price added, "It was Mr. Rust who started the conversation and the reason the program has grown to this degree."
Rust was director of emergency services management in Kent from Oct. 24, 1983 to April 12, 2005, a county employee, a dedicated volunteer and Chief of Kent and Queen Anne's Rescue Squad for 11 consecutive years.
According to Director of Public Works Dan Mattson, they can expect the building project to be finished late spring of next year and will begin moving dirt shortly.
Heller noted how fast the project has moved since it was introduced at the commissioners meeting in early September.
"It has defied the laws of government," she said, crediting the Department of Public Works and the Department of Emergency Services on an effective collaborative effort.
Quinn noted the importance of the site. He said the property is not just a headquarters, but a second home for his crew. Quinn expressed gratitude for all the repairs the County made to preserve the current headquarters in Lynch, but stated it was clear they could not stay in that place longterm.
The new site will enable them to expand their programs, Quinn remarked. A place where ideas will be posed and where they can grow as a community.
Landon told the audience consisting of policemen, EMT's, county employees and concerned citizens, that this is not as much of a groundbreaking ceremony as it is a gathering, of past, present and future.
The new building will be designed and constructed by Industrial Engineering Incorporated and will roughly cost $628,000.
Quinn honored Rust as well as those who followed him.
"They were trailblazers of the past, and with this building, myself and others can be trailblazers of the future."

title: 11-year-old killed in hit-and-run remembered in Elkton
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
11-year-old killed in hit-and-run remembered in Elkton

 December 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: State News 
 
 1038
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ELKTON — Mesiah Lafayette produced a big barrel of cheese puffs recently after the dismissal bell rang at Cherry Hill Middle School and happily shared them with every fellow student who approached him.His display of generosity — one of Mesiah's many endearing qualities — is the last memory that most will have of him.
Mesiah, 11, was killed at approximately 8:30 p.m. on Nov.16, when a motorist struck him as he attempted to pedal his bicycle across Elkton Road from Belle Hill Road and then allegedly drove away. Police arrested the suspect on three days later, after tracking him down in Wilmington, Del., and charged him with involuntary manslaughter and numerous other offenses.
Gauging by the turnouts for two candlelight vigils that were held for Mesiah last week near the intersection where he lost his life, it's quite clear that the smiling boy who loved football, dancing, cool hairstyles, jokes, island music, Skittles and most assuredly his family and friends was adored in his community.
After moving with his family from New Jersey to Elkton in November 2023, Mesiah finished the remaining eight months of his fifth-grade year at Kenmore Elementary School, before starting sixth-grade at Cherry Hill Middle School in September.
Mesiah was here for only a little while, one year, but he made a beautiful, lasting impression on many in that short time.
"He was a kind, loving and gentle child. He spread joy through the school," one Kenmore Elementary School teacher commented Monday night during the first vigil.
An administrator at that school recalled, "He had a bright smile. He hugged people. And he always showed students and teachers affection and gave them attention."
From a much more profound standpoint, Mesiah was here on this earth for only a short time and, yet, he still positively impacted a vast number of people.
"Mesiah was only here 11 years, but he touched a lot of lives — more than most people do in 50 years," emphasized The Rev. Moneira Hawkins of Spirit Life Ministries International in Wilmington, Del. on Tuesday night after praying aloud during the second vigil.
Speaking to the group of children, parents, teachers and others in attendance, Hawkins soothingly said, "His spirit is still alive. He touched every one of you."
One night earlier, some Kenmore Elementary School and Cherry Hill Middle School teachers, administrators and other staff members attended the first vigil and huddled with approximately 20 students.
They shared their fond memories of Mesiah.
"He was a wonderful big brother to his sister. He walked her to her classroom every day," one Kenmore Elementary School administrator said, recalling how fifth-grade Mesiah looked out for his third-grade sibling last school year.
A teacher volunteered, "I remember how friendly and outgoing he was."
The teachers, administrators and staff members spoke words of comfort.
"It's OK to feel sad. It's OK to cry. Take a moment," one of the teachers softly told the students, for whom it was likely that this was the first time most of those children have experienced the death of a peer.
After the circle disbanded, Joanne Carradin, a Cherry Hill Middle School counselor, told the Cecil Whig that crisis intervention counselors were at that school Monday morning to help students deal with their grief.
"They were very busy all morning. They had a lot of questions," Carradin said, adding that some students were sent home.
On Tuesday evening, Mesiah's surviving family members attended the second vigil — and somberness seemed even stronger than it did one night earlier. As supporters standing in a large semi-circle watched silently, Mesiah's relatives gathered in front of a makeshift memorial for Mesiah.
More than 25 candles flickered there. Poster boards covered with decorations and photos of Mesiah smiling and laughing with family members were displayed. Flower bouquets, a football and a bag of McDonald's food were lying there, too. Some helium balloons hovered slightly above the memorial.
The boy's relatives hugged, stood, crouched, sat and cried while gazing at the memorial for several moments amid the hush. Mesiah's stepfather made a couple of comments to the reverently quiet onlookers, expressing the family's gratitude for the show of support and love.
Mesiah's surviving family members include his mom, dad, stepdad, younger sister, 8; older brother, 15; and older sisters, ages 16 and 20.
Attendees of the two vigils fondly remembered Mesiah, who played wide receiver on a boys league football team. Mesiah rooted for the Philadelphia Eagles, probably because he and his family lived in Philly at one point. Without hesitation, one of his school buddies answered, "Professional NFL player," when asked what Mesiah wanted to be when he grew up.
Mesiah had flair.
"I remember his fancy hairstyles," one of the teachers shared during Monday night's vigil. Another teacher referred to them as "adorable hairstyles."
As it turns out, Mesiah's 16-year-old sister was the person responsible for keeping his hairstyles sharp and different. "I do his hair. I do it in different ways about once a month. He likes braids, straight backs — I guess you'd call them cornrows," his sister said Tuesday night, still speaking of Mesiah in the present tense.
Mesiah had a special spot in his heart for island music, which includes reggae, calypso and other genres. His favorite song was "I Am A Bajan," a festive recording by an artist known as Rupee.
He loved to dance — unabashedly. His stepdad smiled when he recalled the times he saw Mesiah dancing with his mom in the kitchen.
Mesiah's stepdad and dad, both of whom write and record music, agree that Mesiah had a gift for composition. His stepdad recalled how Mesiah, after hearing one of his beats, sat down and wrote lyrics. Mesiah titled the song, "I Wish I Had You," a tribute to his twin sister who died before birth. Mesiah then seamlessly rapped that fresh new song to the beat.
"He's a natural. He has a way with words," his stepdad marveled, before shifting into past-tense and declaring, "That kid was special."
Mesiah had a winning, charismatic personality and the football, the hairstyles, the dancing, the music and all of the other things that he loved were just some of the countless manifestations of it.
"He was a bright light. When he walked into a room, he lit it up," his dad summarized while walking away from the memorial site at the conclusion of Tuesday night's vigil.

St. Michaels Shop with a Cop event brings holiday gifts a few weeks early

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News
