 EASTON — In a winding line at register 10, St. Michaels' youngest residents snacked on popcorn and waited for their new toys, clothes, beauty supplies and other goods to be scanned through and wrapped up.During the St. Michaels Police Department's Shop with a Cop event Monday evening at the Target in Easton, 44 kids were able to each pick out $100 worth of anything they wanted.
As children scanned the aisles for the coolest toys and cutest pajamas, St. Michaels Police Chief Jeffrey Oswald and Officer Kristian Bailey ambled the store, checking in on families and making sure things ran smoothly. Before shopping was in full swing, Oswald said he and Bailey would help out a little bit in the shopping process, but would try to stay out of the way.
"And let them have a little bit of fun," he said.
On Thursday, the children's picks will be presented to them during a party in front of the police station, complete with Santa, hot cocoa, a DJ and the entire police department crew.
Oswald said these events "create a great excuse to come together."
"It's not all about gifts," he said. "It's about bonding with the police officers. Getting to know them by their name instead of just police, solely. You know, we're individuals and we care. So that's why we do it."
Tiffany Sweeney, the department's administrative assistant, said the St. Michaels community really invests in the program to get gifts to kids in town. This year, 44 children registered.
"It's a good amount of kids for our small town," Sweeney said.
Jimmy Grimley, 4, came to the Target Monday evening with hopes of finding the "better t-rex ever." By the time he got to the register, Grimley had multiple dinosaur toys in his cart.
Sisters Summer and Sophia Smith filled their carts with books, makeup, clothes and skin care products. The 12- and 14-year olds, respectively, participated in Shop with a Cop last year. Sophia said they decided to participate again because it's fun.
Heather Beecher, the mother of 11-year-old Sophia Showacre, called the event "a blessing."
"I'm thankful," she said next to her daughter's cart, which was filled with an Owala water bottle, press-on nails and other goodies.
At the end of the checkout line, volunteer Glenn Glasgow donned a Santa hat as he put colorful gift bags into carts so that the gifts could be picked up and taken to the police station for Thursday's party. This being his second year volunteering, Glasgow said it was nice to participate. He called it a "great, feel-good experience."

title: Mid-Shore organization pioneers a 'hub' of resources for victims of domestic violence
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Mid-Shore organization pioneers a 'hub' of resources for victims of domestic violence

 December 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 557
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — For more than four decades, the Mid-Shore Council on Family Violence has been at the forefront of advocating for victims on the Mid-Shore. With a new program, the organization is now planning to assist far beyond.The nonprofit for victims of domestic violence has taken steps to advance resource access for clients using the Geographic Information System program, a mapping dashboard providing a free one-stop shop for essential resources for victims.
Jeanne Yeager, executive director for Mid-Shore Council on Family Violence, said rural clients face various barriers to receiving care. During the pandemic the barriers to care were more apparent and Mid-Shore Council sought to find alternative solutions to helping their clients.
This initiative, she said, revolutionizes the way domestic violence victims access vital resources.
"I was really mindful of coming out of COVID, because everything we did at Mid-Shore was very one-on-one, personalized — our case management, our meetings, our support groups, everything — and we would say, 'Oh, well, we'll do an online group sometime.' Well, 'that sometime' became tomorrow," Yeager said. "So it normalized using technology, and I think there's no turning back."
The barriers faced by victims in rural communities include limited employment opportunities, spotty cell service, transportation, lack of affordable housing, and social and geographic isolation.
The GIS program operates with a holistic Chesapeake Crisis-to-Self-Sufficiency model, providing comprehensive services and case management from crisis through transition to self-sufficiency.
According to Yeager, the program initially focused on mapping out housing resources in five counties in Maryland. The data team began working with case managers and staff to compile a list of resources that clients frequently inquire about, such as childcare and pet care.
From there it continued to expand.
Kazeem Anifowoshe, GIS senior data analyst, said the project went from the initial five counties to nine counties, and the team decided to create a website as a "hub" for the project. Now, this hub is used by 25 agencies and has expanded resources to include nearby pro bono and legal services across Maryland through a partnership with the Access to Justice organization.
"When people kind of think of victim services, there's kind of like a formula that a lot of people have been doing for 20 to 40 plus years at their organization that works for them," Anifowoshe said. "But again, we're just trying to make things easier the best way we know how, by mapping things."
According to Yeager, the GIS program has been earning notable recognition, such as the prestigious Domestic Shelters Purple Ribbon Award.
The organization's GIS Hub integrates data from various sources, including popular rental property platforms/affordable housing, childcare resources, medical facilities, grocery stores, law enforcement agencies, court houses and local social service organizations.
Pamela Caudill Jordan, program evaluator for the GIS Hub, said she hopes to encourage other organizations to adopt a comprehensive model where the focus is not just on crisis intervention but on helping survivors achieve long-term stability and self-sufficiency. For Caudill Jordan, having access to tools such as the GIS Hub can make the work of advocates for victims easier and more efficient.
According to Yeager and Anifowoshe, the goal is to get the GIS Hub more widely adopted and used by other organizations, going beyond Maryland and, hopefully, one day nationwide.
"We know what victims need," Yeager said. "We ought to work with victims, and we're making this available. Let's see where we're going with it."

title: Glen Burnie man sentenced for role in Eastern Shore Hospital Center escape
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Glen Burnie man sentenced for role in Eastern Shore Hospital Center escape

 December 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Crime 
 
 633
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A Glen Burnie man will serve 12 years for helping a patient escape the Eastern Shore Hospital Center in August 2023.Israel Labastida Jr., 20, was sentenced Friday to 25 years, with all but eight years suspended, for first-degree assault, followed by 10 years, with all but five years suspended, for use of a firearm during a felony or violent crime. Labastida was also sentenced to five years for first-degree conspiracy to escape, with all of those years suspended.
Labastida will get credit for one year of time served.
He will serve five years of supervised probation following his release from prison. Conditions of probation include that he must receive a mental health evaluation and seek treatment, receive a substance abuse and alcohol evaluation and seek related treatment, abstain from alcohol and illegal drugs, stay away from the Eastern Shore Hospital Center, and not contact Darrin Jeter, 20, who was also involved in the incident.
Before Dean handed down the sentence, Leonard recommended Labastida be sentenced to five years without parole followed by five years of probation. Dean said she was "taken aback" by the state's "lenient" sentencing recommendation.
She said that although she feels for Labastida's family and the pain they have been going through, she also feels for the people that were at the psychiatric facility on the day of the escape.
In June, Labastida pleaded guilty to the three charges. The charges stem from Jeter's escape from the psychiatric facility located on Woods Road in Cambridge last year. At that time, Jeter, who has schizophrenia, had been committed to the hospital center.
At the June plea hearings for both Labastida and Jeter, Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard said Labastida approached the facility on Aug. 1, 2023 and shot into a window several times. She said Labastida and Jeter kicked out the broken window so Jeter could exit the building. The two fled the area in a black vehicle.
Jeter was located by the Montgomery County Sheriff's Office the following day. Leonard said Labastida was identified as a suspect through investigation. Evidence of an escape plan between the two was discovered through investigation, Leonard said at Jeter's hearing.
Jeter was sentenced to 10 years in prison for first-degree escape with eight of those years suspended.
During Labastida's sentencing hearing Friday, defense attorney Marvin Ochoa said Labastida is sorry for his actions and is ashamed and embarrassed. He said when Labastida was in middle school, he withdrew from his family and started hanging out with the "wrong" crew, making bad decisions.
Ochoa said that when Labastida helped with the escape, his brain wasn't fully developed and didn't realize the consequences of his actions, including the "pain and suffering" it would cause his family.
Before showing the certificates Labastida was awarded for classes he took in jail, Ochoa said Labastida has "a lot to give to this world" and he just needs guidance and support.
Labastida told Judge Karen Dean that there was no reason for him to do what he did on Aug. 1 2023, but there is also no reason for his life to be "stunted." He said he believes he can be a productive member of society.
Labastida's family also spoke at the hearing Friday, sharing the toll this incident has taken on their family. His mother Patricia Sanchez said her son "has learned a lesson." She said that she never imagined she would see one of her children standing in front of a judge like this.
"We should (have been) getting ready to go to a graduation or something else," Sanchez said, "not to this."
Labastida's older brother, Nicholas Sanchez, said that Labastida is a hard worker and that with the right guidance, he can become a productive member of society.
The victim of Labastida's assault charge was not present at the hearing and did not wish to make an impact statement.

title: Jury acquits man of all charges in fatal shooting
author: Carl Hamilton and Lilly Howard cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Jury acquits man of all charges in fatal shooting

 December 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton and Lilly Howard cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 978
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Donald Raymond Snyder Jr. pulled a 9mm handgun from his waistband in the driveway of his Elkton-area residence at approximately 9:20 p.m. on June 17 and, from close range, he fired two shots into the upper torso of his friend, Christopher Cimorose, who was in the driver's seat of a red Nissan Versa.Snyder, 41, and his defense lawyers maintained during the two-day-long trial this week that he shot Cimorose — killing him — in self-defense because Cimorose, 55, had threatened, "I'm going to kill you, (expletive)," while a "metal pipe" was resting on his lap.
The prosecution, however, contended that Snyder gunned down Cimorose "in cold blood" because Snyder's 41-year-old girlfriend, Michelle McCarthy, was ending their relationship and that Cimorose — her former boyfriend — had come to Snyder's residence to pick her up at McCarthy's request.
On Thursday morning, the jury acquitted Snyder of first-degree murder, second-degree murder, voluntary manslaughter and the eight related charges after about four hours of deliberations.
As the forelady announced the not guilty verdicts, Snyder lowered his head and appeared emotional while standing beside his Timonium-based lawyer, Joshua Insley, at the defense table. Then they embraced for several seconds. Bruce Saller, who wasn't present, served as Insley's co-counsel at trial.
Snyder, who reiterated his self-defense account on the witness stand, was released from the Cecil County Detention Center on Thursday after his acquittal, court records indicate. Snyder had been incarcerated on no bond since his June 20 arrest.
Maryland State Police investigators elected not to charge Snyder after interviewing him in the hours after the shooting because they lacked probable cause and they let him go home.
But on June 20, after viewing security-camera footage of the incident in the drivefway of Snyder's Locust Point Road residence, south of Elkton, and re-interviewing the sole eyewitness, McCarthy, detectives charged him with murder and other offenses.
The pertinent part of that video was played for jurors.
"Thirteen seconds, in real time, you are going to see the intentional, premeditated killing of Mr. Cimorose," Cecil County State's Attorney James Dellmyer told jurors Wednesday during his closing argument. "This is evidence of first-degree murder. Chris (Cimorose) didn't stand a chance. That gun was on him before he got out of the car."
The footage starts with Snyder "briskly walking up" to the driver's side door and punching Cimorose in the face, according to Dellmyer, who prosecuted the case with Deputy State's Attorney Patricia Fitzgerald. State evidence included a photo of Snyder's right hand, which showed bruising on his knuckles, and a picture of an abrasion on Cimorose's forehead.
After the car lurches forward a few feet, Snyder pulls the handgun as he walks forward to the driver's side door, gets into a shooting stance and rapidly fires three shots at Cimorose, including one errant round, Dellmyer reviewed.
A person cannot be the aggressor and then claim self-defense, Dellmyer said. The video doesn't show Cimorose swinging the object or advancing, nor does it show Snyder retreating because of a perceived threat, he added.
"You cannot start a fistfight and then shoot someone to death," Dellmyer stressed, before asking, "Is it reasonable to use deadly force?"
McCarthy testified that Snyder hurled her cell phone, cracking the front, during a heated argument between the two shortly earlier that day and then alleged that Snyder, in anger, had broken five other cell phones of hers that year.
McCarthy told Snyder that she was leaving him during that dispute.
"I said, 'That's it. I'm done with you . . . I packed all my stuff in the car," McCarthy said.
But McCarthy could not legally drive her packed car because it lacked valid license plates — so she called Cimorose for a ride.
McCarthy testified that she was in the front passenger's seat of Cimorose's car when Snyder wordlessly sucker-punched Cimorose in the face and swiftly fired three shots. "I saw the punch. I saw everything," she said.
Insley, however, maintained that McCarthy wasn't a credible witness.
The defense lawyer proffered that the footage shows McCarthy outside Cimorose's car during the incident. Seconds earlier, McCarthy and Snyder had been inside her vehicle waiting for Cimorose to arrive.
Insley also reminded jurors that McCarthy admittedly never mentioned Snyder throwing a punch during her first interview with investigators. "I was covering a little bit for my boyfriend," McCarthy confessed on the witness stand.
Guilt prompted McCarthy to contact police on June 19 and set up a second interview, in which she told investigators that Snyder punched Cimorose without provocation before the shooting, she testified. McCarthy testified that she and Cimorose were no longer romantically involved.
When Insley asked McCarthy if she had asked the prosecution to dismiss two drug cases against her in exchange for her cooperation, she combatively responded, "Drugs has nothing to to do with this case."
Also during Insley's cross-examination, McCarthy confirmed that Cimorose was on probation in a criminal case for strangling her.
Insley reminded the jury during his closing argument Thursday that the autopsy report showed that Cimorose had methadone, cocaine and fentanyl and other drugs in his system at the time of his death.
"Ever smoke crack before," Ingsley rhetorically asked the jury, before remarking, "I heard it makes you pretty wacky."
The defense also took exception to the state's interpretation of what the shadowy footage showed. The state contended that Snyder lunged forward and punched Cimorose, but Insley insisted that a thrown punch is not visible in the video.
As for the object Cimorose purportedly possessed, Insley accused investigators of "sugar-coating" by using words like stick, pole and a table leg to describe it, so it wouldn't be associated with a weapon. Insley referred to the object as a club. It looked like a wooden cane with a section of metal where the handle should have been.
Snyder called 911; identified himself as the shooter; told the dispatcher he acted in self-defense and turned himself in after learning about the charges against him — all actions of an innocent man, according to Insley.

title: CEO shooting suspect is a Maryland native from Towson
author: TIM PRUDENTE The Baltimore Banner
content:
CEO shooting suspect is a Maryland native from Towson

 December 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TIM PRUDENTE The Baltimore Banner | Section: State News 
 
 1100
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Authorities are questioning a 26-year-old man from Towson in the killing of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson, law enforcement officials said.New York police identified the man as Luigi Nicholas Mangione, who they said was born and raised in Maryland, with ties to San Francisco. He lived in Honolulu, Hawaii, until recently.
Mangione, a high school valedictorian from the Gilman School in Baltimore, earned undergraduate and graduate degrees in computer science in 2020 from the University of Pennsylvania, a spokesman told The Associated Press on Monday.
He had learned to code in high school and helped start a club at Penn for people interested in gaming and game design, according to a 2018 story in Penn Today, a campus publication.
His posts suggest that he belonged to the fraternity Phi Kappa Psi. They also show him taking part in a 2019 program at Stanford University, and in photos with family and friends in Hawaii, San Diego, Puerto Rico, the New Jersey shore and other destinations.
He is a scion of a prominent Baltimore-area family whose interests reach from development to politics and civic life.
In his valedictory speech at Gilman School, he praised the school for instilling in him the "incredible courage to explore the unknown and try new things," according to an excerpt from his speech on the school website. That same year, Mangione was featured in a Baltimore Fishbowl article spotlighting local valedictorians, where he outlined his ambition to study artificial intelligence.
The headmaster of Gilman School issued a statement Monday, calling the revelation "deeply distressing."
"We recently became aware that the person arrested in connection with the killing of the United Healthcare CEO is a Gilman alumnus, Luigi Mangione, Class of 2016," Henry P.A. Smyth said. "This is deeply distressing news on top of an already awful situation. Our hearts go out to everyone affected."
Mangione had writings that appeared to be critical of the health insurance industry, a law enforcement official told the Associated Press.
He had a gun thought to be similar to the one used in the killing, the official said. Along with the gun, police found a silencer and fake IDs, according to the official.
Police apprehended Mangione after receiving a tip that he had been spotted at a McDonald's near Altoona, Pennsylvania, about 233 miles west of New York City, said the official, who was not authorized to discuss details of the investigation and spoke to the AP on condition of anonymity.
His late grandfather, Nicholas Mangione Sr., was a self-made real estate developer who owned country clubs, nursing homes and a radio station. And his grandmother Mary, who died in 2023 from Parkinson's disease, was described in an obituary as a hospital benefactor and a music patron.
They purchased Turf Valley Country Club in 1978, establishing it as a golf course resort and residential community, and later Hayfields Country Club in 1986.
Family businesses also include the Lorien Health Services nursing homes and radio station WCBM-AM. Mary Mangione was a supporter of the Catholic Archdiocese of Baltimore, Greater Baltimore Medical Center, the old Baltimore Opera Company and the Walters Art Museum, eventually becoming a Walters trustee. Del. Nino Mangione, a Baltimore County Republican, is a cousin, his office confirmed to WBAL.
Thompson, 50, was killed last Wednesday in what police said was a "brazen, targeted" attack as he walked alone to the Hilton from a nearby hotel, where UnitedHealthcare's parent company, UnitedHealth Group, was holding its annual investor conference, police said.
The shooter appeared to be "lying in wait for several minutes" before approaching the executive from behind and opening fire, NYPD Commissioner Jessica Tisch said. He used a 9 mm pistol that police said resembled the guns farmers use to put down animals without causing a loud noise.
In the days since the shooting, police turned to the public for help by releasing a collection of photos and video — including footage of the attack, as well as images of the suspect at a Starbucks beforehand.
Photos taken in the lobby of a hostel on Manhattan's Upper West Side showed the suspect grinning after removing his mask, police said.
Ammunition found near Thompson's body bore the words "delay," "deny" and "depose," mimicking a phrase used by insurance industry critics.
Monday's development came as dogs and divers returned to New York's Central Park while the dragnet for Thompson's killer stretched into a sixth day.
Investigators have been combing the park since the Wednesday shooting and have been searching at least one of its ponds for three days, looking for evidence that may have been thrown into it.
On Friday, police found a backpack in the park that they say the killer discarded as he fled from the crime scene to an uptown bus station, where they believe he left the city on a bus.
On Monday, K-9 units sniffed leaf-covered planters between walking paths in Central Park near where police found the shooter's backpack. Farther along the path that police believe the suspect took through the park after the shooting, scuba divers geared up and began searching a pond for the third straight day.
Retracing the gunman's steps using surveillance video, investigators say the shooter fled into Central Park on a bicycle, emerged from park without his backpack and then ditched the bicycle.
He then walked a couple blocks and got into a taxi, arriving at at the George Washington Bridge Bus Station, which is near the northern tip of Manhattan and offers commuter service to New Jersey and Greyhound routes to Philadelphia, Boston and Washington, D.C., NYPD Chief of Detectives Joseph Kenny said.
The FBI announced late Friday that it was offering a $50,000 reward for information leading to an arrest and conviction, adding to a reward of up to $10,000 that the NYPD has offered. Police say they believe the suspect acted alone.
Late Saturday, police released two additional photos of the suspect that appeared to be from a camera mounted inside a taxi. The first shows him outside the vehicle and the second shows him looking through the partition between the back seat and the front of the cab. In both, his face is partially obscured by a blue mask.
Through the park search, the NYPD has taken steps to minimize disruption to visitors, leading to an odd juxtaposition of joggers, tourists and an active crime scene.
On Monday, a small section of the park was cordoned off with blue and white police tape, giving divers an area to change and enter the water.
At one point, a group of about 30 French-speaking tourists followed a guide down a path, but they couldn't go any farther because of the police tape. Before turning back, many of them whipped out their phones to snap photos of the diver crew.

title: Family fights Dunkirk cemetery's plan to move plot
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
Family fights Dunkirk cemetery's plan to move plot

 December 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 508
 Words 

 Read News Document

 According to her daughter, it was in 1989 that Gloria Moseley purchased two plots at Dunkirk's Southern Memorial Gardens. It was supposed to be a modest resting place in a quiet rural setting.Laura Dodgson, Moseley's daughter who now lives in North Carolina, said her sister died in 1994 and her brother died four years later. Urns containing their ashes were buried side-by-side on the site.
Gloria Moseley died in 2002 and eight years later her husband, Robert, passed. Both were laid to rest at the family gravesite.
Southern Memorial Gardens has had different owners since 1989, when the Moseleys purchased the plots.
Now the cemetery owners say mistakes have been made. Their solution has brought distress to the family.
In a letter to Southern Maryland News, Dodgson said she received a phone call from cemetery officials back in September.
"They stated that my family had been buried in the wrong plot and that they would have to be dug up and moved," Dodgson wrote.
During a phone conversation with Dodgson after the letter was received, Southern Maryland News learned cemetery officials, via mail, told her to sign papers for moving the family members to another location.
"I don't want them moved," Dodgson said.
When Southern Maryland News contacted the cemetery about the situation, the employee answering the phone provided contact information for the business's attorney, Kevin Vitelli.
"It happens at every cemetery," Vitelli said of the Moseley family's situation. "Mistakes were made in 1989. We're just trying to make it right."
Vitelli, whose law practice is based in Pennsylvania, said the relocation of the family's plot would be done at no additional cost.
The local cemetery has a well-documented history of problems.
Nearly 20 years ago, fraudulent activity on the part of former owner, Larry Deffenbaugh, came to light after a Maryland State Police investigation. Deffenbaugh was later convicted of defrauding over 500 people out of funeral and memorial items.
He had entered an Alford plea, which is not an admission of guilt, but an acknowledgment that prosecutors have evidence to support a charge, received a 15-year suspended sentence and ordered to pay restitution to the victims.
Deffenbaugh's story then gets more convoluted, as he was summoned back to court for a violation of probation hearing but failed to appear. Apparently not wishing to go to prison, Deffenbaugh reportedly fell off a fishing boat. He was, however, recaptured in 2010 and sent to prison.
Dodgson said her late sister's daughter, Pam, filed court papers to have her mother's urn removed from the cemetery and given over to her. Dodgson and another family member confirmed that the urn was flooded with water.
Dodgson said she fears the disturbance of the plot could result in the collapse of the vaults where her parents' coffins are laid.
The family has been in contact with attorneys for a possible breech of contract and gross negligence lawsuit.
"There were some mistakes made by prior owners," Vitelli said of the Southern Memorial Gardens situation. "We have to correct those mistakes."
The attorney added that while aggrieved plot owners have been urged to file suit, "nobody has filed any action against the cemetery."

 EASTON — On Saturday evening, Bridget O'Brien, 2024 Miss Maryland, opened the dance floor at Easton Elks Lodge by singing the "Star Spangled Banner." Couples, of all ages, gathered on the dance floor under USO military-themed decorations for a benefit in honor of disabled veterans.In an effort to provide continued care for disabled veterans at Pleasant Day Adult Day Care in Cambridge, the Easton Elks 1622 Veterans Affairs Committee hosted a USO event in an effort to raise funds for disabled veterans. Over a hundred people attended the event that included dancing, food, a silent auction and a raffle.
Michael Feehley, chair of the 1622 Veterans Affairs Committee and a lead planner for the event, said the committee believes in doing what they can to provide for those veterans in need and this event was a way to raise funds for veterans that are often overlooked.
"We believe in taking care of veterans, the veterans that use services at Pleasant Day, whether it's just for two meals, whether it's for medications, whether it's to meet with medical people, whether it's transportation to their medical appointments, they're only funded for two days a week through (Veteran Affairs), we feel it's necessary to fund those guys for five days," Feehley said.
Throughout the event, veterans were honored by attendees and volunteers but also by potential new recruits. Feehley said Easton High School's Navy Junior Reserve Officers' Training Corps members assisted in functions such as drawing tickets, helping people to their seats and any assistance needed including putting away chairs at the end of the evening.
Tom Carlson, Vietnam veteran and member of the Easton Elks 1622 Veterans Affairs Committee, said the event provided him the opportunity to be around more veterans and talk about their experiences between enjoying the music and dancing.
Carlson said he was surprised by the enjoyment of the guests when it came to the music being played. Guests of a variety of ages were in attendance that evening singing along to songs of Carlson's youth and flooding the dance floor.
"It wasn't just people in their 60s and 70s and 80s. There were a lot of people in their 20s and 30s, and they had a great time too," Carlson said. "It's amazing that some of these youngsters really knew the music. They know our songs that we grew up with."
Feehley said he was proud of the ability to organize an event to honor veterans in the area, and he advises anyone who comes across a veteran to take the time to honor them even in the smallest ways.
"When you see that Army hat or the Coast Guard bumper sticker on the back of a car, or anything that says, 'Hey, I was in the service,' say, 'Thank you for your service.'"
"Because that veteran, the person who wears that hat, or the person who drives that car, they gave an awful lot of themselves," Feehley said. "They took time away from their families, away from home, in some but not all cases, they put themselves in danger, so you and I can do what we do today, and who are we not to give back to those people."

 CAMBRIDGE — On Saturday afternoon, police sirens rang as dozens of children were escorted by Cambridge police to Walmart for the annual Shop with a Cop event.The children were met with warm welcomes from police officers before they raced inside for this holiday tradition.
Shop with a Cop provides the opportunity for underprivileged children in the community to spend quality time with local police officers and purchase Christmas presents.
Sergeant Antoine Patton from the Cambridge Police Department, said this event began in 2015 in an effort to help families throughout the area during the holiday season.
"We realized that in today's economy that everyone doesn't have the funds, and we as a police department here, wanted to make sure that we could help as many families as possible," Patton said. "We wanted to see as many smiling kids on Christmas as we possibly could."
Through a live raffle system, families and loved ones of local children apply to have the children participate. Each drawing is broadcast on Facebook Live.
After names are picked, Patton calls the families to let them know their child has won. Then, a small group leaves the station to pick the children up from their homes and take them to Walmart.
Each child then gets to spend $100 on "anything of their choosing." This year 30 children were chosen during the raffle.
According to Patton, this is the first year that all funds for the event were entirely made available through donations. Patton said several organizations, including Paul Davis Restoration of Delmarva, The Lions Club, the Friendship Methodist Church of Aireys, and private donations provided funds for gifts.
On Saturday, the children were split into small groups and assigned a police officer, who guided them through the toy aisles. With the help of the officers, children choose toys from Nerf guns to pink tea sets.
Lydia Travers, a parent of a Shop with a Cop winner, said her mother sent her son Zyonn's name into the Shop with a Cop raffle and they were lucky enough to be chosen.
According to Travers, this event allows the community to come together and help each other.
Patton said the children aren't the only ones benefitting from Shop with a Cop. Police officers have shared positive experiences with the children outside of the event.
"It helps us out tremendously, because the children get to see us doing something fun and positive," Patton said. "And these children don't forget. I have children that we took maybe three or four years ago, and they still remember me, say, 'Hey Mom, that's the guy took us Christmas shopping.'"

title: Ground broken for state-of-the-art first responder training facility in Easton
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Ground broken for state-of-the-art first responder training facility in Easton

 EASTON — First responders, along with local and state officials, broke ground Monday on a state-of-the-art emergency services training facility in Easton.The A. James Clark Emergency Services Training Campus is being constructed on Mistletoe Drive. The 7,200-square-foot facility is intended to allow for cross-training between emergency responders and reduce long commutes for first responders in training.
Brett Whitehead, president of the Friends of Easton Volunteer Fire Department, co-led the fundraising campaign for the facility with his partner, Ed Forte. Whitehead said on Monday that the campus will be in a world of its own as far as allowing firefighters, police officers, EMS workers and others to train together.
"There's no place that I know of … in the Mid-Shore where three of the legs, if you will, of emergency services can practice together," Whitehead said.
The closest training facilities are in Princess Anne and Centreville, Whitehead noted. Whitehead believes the Easton facility can be the premier cross-training facility in the region.
"We want to be the Taj Mahal," he said. "We want to be the mecca of education for all emergency services as it relates to what we do."
The campus will have a public safety building and an educational building with classrooms, as well as a 1,500-square-foot concrete pad for car fire and extrication training. Hostage rescues, ladder climbs and traffic safety situations are other ways in which the facilities will be used.
Leaders from across public safety agencies attended Monday's groundbreaking, including Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble, Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey and Talbot County Director of Emergency Services Brian LeCates.
LeCates said the facility will be a "more professional setting" for collaborating and training to take place. That setting could end up saving lives, he said.
"We all know that every second counts," LeCates said. "In real emergencies, lives are at stake, and the difference between success and failure often comes to how we train before the disaster occurs."
"At least 90% of the calls that we go on involve all three groups," Whitehead said. " … It allows us to all hone our skills together. And that's the magic of what we're trying to get done. Hopefully in 12 months, we'll have this facility built."
FUNDRAISINGThus far, around $4 million of the $5 million goal has been raised for the A. James Clark Emergency Services Training Campus.
As the name indicates, the A. James & Alice B. Clark Foundation and its Board Chair Courtney Clark Pastrick were fundamental in that fundraising success. Last September, the foundation gave $1 million to the fundraising efforts for the training campus. In total, the foundation has contributed $1.9 million to the project.
"I don't think I've ever encountered someone as professional and, as my wife reminds me, gracious, as Courtney Clark Pastrick," Whitehead said.
Clark Pastrick said she knew the project was a "perfect fit," something her late father, A. James Clark, would be immensely proud of. She thanked all the community members and sponsors who donated to the project in tandem with the foundation.
Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said the state House and Senate chambers each contributed $150,000 to the project, a charge led by Jeannie Haddaway-Riccio, a former Republican legislator and Department of Natural Resources secretary.
Former Easton Mayor Bob Willey attended the groundbreaking event, adorned with his fellow firefighters in Easton Volunteer Fire Department gear. Mautz, Whitehead and Mayor Megan Cook each thanked Willey for having the original vision to bring a project like this to life.

"And it is no surprise to me that our very own 62-year veteran of the Easton Volunteer Fire Department, Mayor Willey, was the one who sparked this idea. Mayor Willey, we owe you an incredible debt of gratitude," he said.

title: Gallatin County Sheriff's Office welcomes public to tour new building at Four Corners
author: Laurenz Busch Chronicle Staff Writer

Gallatin County Sheriff's Office welcomes public to tour new building at Four Corners

 December 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Laurenz Busch Chronicle Staff Writer | Section: News

 Words

 Sheriff Dan Springer hosted a public tour of the new Gallatin County Sheriff's Office building in Four Corners on Wednesday, formally ushering in the next step in modernizing county law enforcement.Having moved in over the summer, the 25,000-square-foot building offers expanded office and training space and a more strategic location to respond to calls for service.
The building, off Laura Louise Lane near Jackrabbit Lane, has three shooting ranges, space for patrol units, detectives, and the Missouri River Drug Task Force. It is a welcomed development that has been in the works since 2020.
Springer said the location is ideal as most of his office's calls for service are within a nine-mile radius. It also prevents deputies from having to navigate traffic along 19th Avenue and Huffine Lane, as was the case with the old location at the Gallatin County Detention Center.
"Seventy percent of our calls occurring within that radius is pretty significant," Springer said. "Getting our calls from here has been excellent and puts us right to where we need to be."
On Wednesday, Springer welcomed the public in the main conference room as fireplaces crackled on dual TVs, and cookies and coffee were provided. He then gave a tour of the facility, which the county purchased for $5.4 million in 2020. Springer described it as relatively affordable, considering the building's sheer size and the site's 6.48 acres.
"There wasn't enough money to build a facility, which had been the plan to build our Sheriff's Office up by the jail," Springer said. "Since we couldn't do that, there wasn't that kind of money available, so we ended up remodeling this to make it more fiscally responsible."
Newly appointed county auditor Jill Therrien was along for the tour, and county CFO Justine Swanson was seen later.
The first stop was in the hallway past the main entrance waiting area, where a dedication to deputies lost in the line of service hung from the wall. Over some 160 years, the Gallatin County Sheriff's Office has lost five deputies, the most recent being Jake Allmendinger in 2019 due to an accident with his patrol vehicle.
In May, a stretch of Bridger Canyon Road, near where Allmendinger's accident occurred, was dedicated to the deputy.
Before that, two deputies were killed in 1917 as they went to look for a suspect who had allegedly shot a farmer, a Sheriff's Office chaplain told the tour group.
Beyond desk space, such as in the large gold and blue room where county detectives are based, the facility offers the three shooting ranges, one of 100 yards.
Springer said the ranges can handle up to a .50-caliber rifle, although the Chronicle was not provided a demonstration.
"We do most of our training here, this is by far the most active bay," Springer said while showing the 25-yard range. "You can do movements and cover and all that type of stuff but the only thing I would do differently is try and figure out a way to get a car down here (to train with)."
The facility was previously a private gun range, Springer said, hence the three ranges, and although it provides deputies with shooting practice, more space is needed for comprehensive training.
"We train a lot in shooting, but when you look at the big picture, it's (mostly) traffic stops and domestic responses," Springer said. "(Ranges were) the bonus to the facility. The primary objective when we purchased this was the fact that it's 6.48 acres, in the middle of Four Corners, which is where we're growing and where our primary routes are."
Beyond the building's gold and black exterior, a new search and rescue building remains under construction across the street. Springer also keeps his eyes on a future training facility, as a county law enforcement and emergency response campus slowly emerges.

title: Caroline County meeting sheds light on possible police accountability 'overreach'
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Caroline County meeting sheds light on possible police accountability 'overreach'

 December 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 756
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Law enforcement officials from multiple counties gathered at the Caroline County Commissioners meeting Tuesday, bringing concerns about an incident involving a Caroline County sheriff's deputy and its implications for police accountability committee practices throughout the state.The officials represented the state's Police Accountability Board, a state agency that oversees administrative charging committees, county organizations intended to provide oversight for police practices.
The charging committees were formed as a result of the Maryland Police Accountability Act of 2021. According to maryland.gov, the committees' job is to "... (review) the findings of each law enforcement agency's investigation of police misconduct complaints forwarded by the agency to the Committee. From information related to the investigation, the Committee makes determinations and recommendations."
"We have a lot of law enforcement representation in the room," Commission President Travis Breeding stated at the beginning of the discussion. "I think this will be a great opportunity to discuss the role of the ACC (Administrative Charging Committee) and the PAB (Police Accountability Board)."
The discussion stemmed from an incident that called into question the county committee's investigation practices.
A Caroline County sheriff's deputy, who was not named, was investigated by the committee about a harassment complaint. Charge committee members invited the deputy to meet with the committee regarding the complaint, a move considered by some sheriff's departments to be "not proper protocol" or an "overreach."
"I understand that," said John Bartlett, a member of the Caroline County Administrative Charging Committee who was involved in the event in question. "I've been called in for incidents happening when I was on the job. That's why I walked to his cruiser, identified myself, asked him if he had talked to a lawyer or if he wanted a lawyer, and he was comfortable with coming in (to meet with the committee) without a lawyer."
A date for the incident was not specified. Charging committee members told The Star Democrat they could not further elaborate on the matter.
Sheriff Donald Barker of the Caroline County Sheriff's Office was very confused as to why his officer was called into the meeting, saying Tuesday that to his knowledge the harassment charge had already been exonerated at the time of the incident.
"But the problem I have is my deputy also told me that John told him that he was not," Baker said. "They'd already exonerated him of harassment. So he's already exonerated the entire complaint. What are you going to ask?"
Police Accountability Board members in attendance voiced that it was unusual for a county charging committee member to approach an officer in this manner.
"I think that the only concern that I've had is it's the first time I've seen an ACC ask an individual to come in and testify," James DeWess, Sheriff of Carrol County, said. "I think if somebody's got to meet a deputy out in the parking lot and ask them if they need an attorney, then they shouldn't be inviting them in. I think that's an extension of an overreach of what they should be doing, and that's really the only thing that concerns me."
The Police Accountability Board and the charging committee members agreed Tuesday that the state legislation establishing the oversight committees needs some work in order to clarify protocols for incidents like this going forward.
Caroline County Attorney Stewart Barroll drafted an agreement that will be sent out to the Police Accountability Board and the charge committee at a later date.
Reading from the draft, Barroll said. "Subpoenas may be issued by the ACC or by the chairman acting on behalf of the ACC. The ACC may not request or compel a police officer to appear before the ACC unless it has first requested the information it seeks from the LEA (law enforcement agency), and if still not satisfied, served written questions upon the officer, together with a notice signed by the chair or presiding officer stating that the ACC is in need of the officer's answers to make its determination of whether an officer is to be administratively charged, a copy of the notice and the questions shall be delivered by the chair or the presiding officer or ACC staff to the head of a law enforcement agency that employs the police officer, who shall deliver same to the officer and notify the ACC of the date of service within 15 days after service, the officer shall provide to the ACC and written the answers and a signed statement that the answers are true to the best of the officers, knowledge, information and belief."
The Caroline County Sheriff's Office could not be reached for comment.

title: No small feat
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
No small feat

 December 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 784
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Being a court appointed special advocate isn't your average volunteer gig."This is not something you just sign up for Saturday and show up if you can," CASA of the Mid-Shore Volunteer Coordinator Jane Crawford said.
As Mid-Shore court appointed special advocates, or CASAs, volunteers in Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties are assigned to be advocates for children who are considered to be at significant risk in their current homes and have been placed under court protection. According to the nonprofit, reasons a child might be under court protection include abuse, neglect and abandonment.
Those advocates are tasked with identifying a child's needs and advocating for the necessary services so their needs can be met. CASAs share their recommendations with the judge assigned to that child's case.
CASA of the Mid-Shore Executive Director Robin Davenport said the work that the organization's volunteers do is "heroic."
"In a nutshell, we're saying, 'Be a sponge,'" she said about a CASA's role. "Just go around and soak up every bit of information you can about the child. Wring the sponge out. Figure out what is important for us to be paying attention to and bringing to the court's attention."
Though it can be considered rewarding, the volunteer gig — open to residents who are at least 21 years old — is a commitment.
Following a lengthy application process and in-depth interview, those interested in volunteering with CASA of the Mid-Shore must complete eight training sessions. Once those trainings are complete and the volunteers have been sworn into the courthouses as officers of the court, they are assigned to a case.
Generally, CASAs are assigned to one case at a time. The length of a case can vary. And although the children are from one of the four counties served by CASA of the Mid-Shore, a lot of the time they are living in placements outside the four counties, Davenport said.
Crawford said the decision to become a CASA volunteer isn't always an easy one to make.
"Once people learn about the program and what's required, sometimes they need to think about it too because of that commitment," she said.
Janet Healy, a Talbot County resident, has been a CASA volunteer since 2008. After a career as an educator, Healy wanted to find a volunteer opportunity where she could work with kids in a less "intensive" way, she said.
"And it just seemed like the right fit," she said about volunteering with CASA of the Mid-Shore.
For Healy, one of the most rewarding aspects of the job is building relationships.
"(Building relationships) with kids, with foster parents, with social workers," she said, later adding, "It's hard when things don't work out the way you think they should, but it's also, on the other hand, very rewarding."
Healy said one adoptive mother still sends her photos of the sibling group that she was a CASA for about four years ago.
"That's very rewarding to get some of that feedback," she said. "To see how well some of these kids are doing."
But there are challenging aspects of the job, too. Davenport said it's important for CASAs to take things slow and be consistent when building relationships with the children. She said they tell volunteers not to take things personally.
A child might be dealing with trauma, she said, "and so there are a lot of things that we have to just keep track of and measure things in very small victories."
Healy said making recommendations to judges is a big responsibility. She said taking on the role of a CASA means becoming invested and emotionally involved.
"Because you do get very invested in these kids, but you know it really is temporary," she said. "You have to keep that in the back of your mind all the time."
BECOMING TOUCHSTONESCASA of the Mid-Shore is celebrating 35 years of service in 2025. Davenport has been there since the beginning. She has seen the organization grow not only in staff, but in the number of counties it serves.
"It was a very tiny, tiny organization," she said about the nonprofit's start. "We, at that point, were only Talbot County."
On May 17, the nonprofit will host a special fundraiser called "Voices of Hope." The celebration is, in part, to celebrate CASA of the Mid-Shore's successful 35 years and kick off its next 35.
Davenport said that over the years, she's seen CASAs become "incredible touchstones" for the children they advocate for.
"The CASA volunteers end up kind of being the one consistent adult in these children's lives," she said. "Foster care is not a short turnaround usually. So it's been really exciting for us to see that the CASAs themselves are not only helping the judge, but they're actually really giving messages to the children that stick with them for years."

title: Cambridge man found guilty of child abuse, assault
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Cambridge man found guilty of child abuse, assault

 December 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Crime 
 
 519
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A Cambridge man has been found guilty of first-degree assault and first-degree child abuse relating to an incident with his infant.Marcus Peak, 28, was arrested in April 2023 after his five-week-old child was seriously injured with a traumatic brain injury. He was charged with attempted first- and second-degree murder, first- and second-degree assault, first- and second-degree child abuse, neglect of a minor and reckless endangerment.
The state later decided it would not prosecute for the murder charges. Peak was found guilty by Dorchester County Circuit Court Judge William Jones of the other six counts.
The charges against Peak stem from an incident on April 21, 2023, when Cambridge Police officers responded to assist Dorchester County Emergency Medical Services with an infant who was unconscious and not breathing. EMS treated the infant and transported her to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Cambridge. The baby was then transported to Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore.
According to police, Peak told detectives he had just fed the baby a bottle and placed her in a bassinet for a nap. He said the baby was asleep. He said that when he returned to check on the her later, he noticed the baby's head was tilted to the side with fluid coming from her nose and mouth. He said the baby's eyes were partially opened.
At that time, Peak denied any traumatic event that could have caused injury to the baby.
Detectives were told Peak had lied and did not inform them that the baby had fallen to the floor striking her head. Peak allegedly then picked the baby up and shook the baby to wake it, according to a report from the Cambridge Police Department.
During the trial, Jones heard a variety of testimony, including testimony from doctors and the child's mother.
The mother, Paris Keene, testified that she had left the house that day to pick up their older child from daycare. She said Peak had stayed with the their five-week-old. She said that when she came back, Peak told her the infant had choked on her spit up.
When Keene took the baby from Peak, she realized that the baby's eyes were rolling back, and Peak called 911.
Dr. Eric Klotz, an emergency medicine physician who treated the child that day, said her injuries were consistent with a high mechanism of injury. He said it was one of the more severe head injuries he's seen in his career.
Dr. Joseph Scheller, a pediatric neurologist who was asked by Peak's defense to testify, said it is possible the child's injuries were caused by an accidental fall. He said that while it is rare, short falls can sometimes cause serious injury.
"I am thankful for the judge's consideration," Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard told the Star Democrat. "He gave a very well thought out explanation citing case law and it was obvious that he took significant time to consider the evidence put forth by the state, including expert testimony and other evidence."
Leonard said that a "long form" pre-sentence investigation will be conducted, which may take multiple months. As of Friday afternoon, no sentencing date for Peak was scheduled.

title: Maryland police officer retires at 40 years of service
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Maryland police officer retires at 40 years of service

 January 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 694
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Dennis Wood fought back tears Thursday morning during his retirement ceremony in front of the North East Police Department station. His emotion was understandable, considering that Wood was saying goodbye to his beloved career after spending nearly a half-century serving as a law enforcement officer."Forty-six years, all I ever wanted to do was serve the people of Cecil County and the people of North East, and I think I did that to the best of my ability," Wood summarized during his brief speech to a crowd of family, friends and law enforcement officers representing various police agencies.
Moments earlier, Wood and his wife, Lou, trailed a bagpipe player as they walked out the front door of the NEPD station on Cecil Avenue and made their way between two rows of saluting police officers in the parking lot.
Then Wood slid into the driver's seat of a patrol vehicle, raised a radio transmitter to his mouth and uttered, "I'm off duty — and retired."
After the new retiree stepped out of the vehicle and said a few words to the ceremony attendees, Cecil County Executive Adam Streight presented a proclamation to Wood on behalf of himself and the Cecil County Council.
Streight certainly can appreciate the emotions evoked by Wood's retirement day. Less than two months earlier, Streight made that same ceremonial walk and intoned a similar sign-off over the police radio waves when he retired from the Cecil County Sheriff's Office, after serving 25 years with that agency.
In his case, Streight retired so he could assume his elected position as county executive — but even so, walking away from law enforcement work was bittersweet for him.
"There is no other job like police work. It is who you are," Streight emphasized shortly after his own retirement ceremony.
Wood expressed similar sentiments when asked why he became a police officer. It was more of a calling than a career choice, according to Wood, who could not point to a particular person or a specific event that led him on this path. It was like the career chose him, not the other way around.
"Ever since I was a kid, I wanted to be a police officer. That's all I ever wanted to be. I wanted to be able to help people," explained Wood, his eyes still moist moments after the ceremony.
Marking the end of his second excursion into Cecil County law enforcement, Wood retired Thursday from the North East Police Department at the rank of corporal after serving as a patrol officer with that agency for 25 years.
In addition, Wood served as the department's firearms instructor for several years. Wood also served on many homeowner associations as the North East Police Department liaison.
"You could count on Cpl. Wood to take extra shifts and to do whatever needed to be done. He also was great as a community liaison for the department, working with the homeowners associations," NEPD Chief Stephen Yates said.
Wood joined the North East Police Department in June 1999 — one month after leaving the Cecil County Sheriff's Office, where he had served in various capacities for slightly more than 20 years.
Hired by the late Sheriff John F. "Jack" DeWitt, Wood started his CCSO career in 1979 as a correctional officer at the old jail on North Street in Elkton. After about three years, Wood transferred to the law enforcement side of CCSO and attended the Anne Arundel Police Academy.
Wood served as a patrol deputy and as a detective while with the CCSO. During his time with the agency, Wood also helped form the county's first dive team. In addition, Wood ran the Sheriff's Office Explorer Post Program for four years.
He left the CCSO in May 1999 to take an officer position with the North East Police Department and started in June 1999, one month later.
During the retirement ceremony on Thursday, a dispatcher read Wood's career summary aloud over the police radio. In conclusion, the dispatcher read, "We thank Cpl. Wood's wife, Lou, and his family for sharing him with us for 46 years. Cpl. Wood, thank you for all you have done to make Cecil County a better place . . . Enjoy your camping trips and cutting firewood."

 As a result of multiple vehicle break-ins and thefts that occurred on Dec. 30 in the La Trappe Heights community in Trappe Maryland, the Talbot County Sheriff's department made three arrests last week.On Dec. 30, deputies responded to a report of an attempted vehicle break-in on the 3800 block of Seymour Drive in Trappe, according to a release from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office. At around 5 p.m., deputies were dispatched to Harrison Circle in Trappe for suspicious activity. A resident of the area noticed the three male suspects dressed in black clothing and wearing masks looking into vehicles, police said.
After observation, the suspects fled on foot into a residence on the 3900 block of Main Street and attempted to barricade themselves inside, according to the sheriff's office. Deputies surrounded the residence and made contact with the suspects after a short time, police said.
The suspects were identified as 18 year-old Nihjay T. Greene of Trappe, 18 year-old Aamad A. Turner of Trappe and a juvenile 16 year-old male, who was not named by the sheriff's office.
Police said Greene attempted to resist arrest and assaulted a deputy as he was being detained. No one was injured during the arrests.
Greene has been charged with second degree assault on a police officer, resisting arrest, obstructing and hindering, fourth degree burglary, rogue and vagabond, theft of less than $100 and malicious destruction of property.
Turner has been charged with obstructing and hindering, fourth degree burglary, rogue and vagabond, theft less than $100 and malicious destruction of property less than $1,000.
The 16-year-old juvenile was charged with the same offenses as Turner and referred to the Maryland Department of Juvenile Services, where he was released to a guardian, the sheriff's office said.
Members of the Talbot County Sheriff's Office Criminal Investigations Division arranged and proceeded a search and seizure warrant of the residence the suspects attempted to barricade, which was signed by a judge. During the search deputies found evidence connecting the three suspects to the vehicle break-ins in La Trappe Heights, as well as vehicle break-ins that occurred in Easton early in 2024.
Greene and Turner were transferred to the Talbot County Central Booking Facility for processing and their first appearance before a District Court Commissioner. They are being held without bond at Talbot County Detention Center. Both suspects were released on unsecured bail after bail reviews before a district court judge.

title: Jones, outgoing Easton fire chief, reflects on third term

Jones, outgoing Easton fire chief, reflects on third term

 January 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 547
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Wrapping up his third stint as Easton Volunteer Fire Department's fire chief, Sonny Jones is proud of the group of men and women that he has led for the past two years."I have a love of the fire service in general. I love the job that the volunteer firefighters do," Jones said. "I enjoy knowing that when someone needs help … we respond and try to make what could be their worst day a better day by trying to solve their problems or make things better."
Jones has served as chief of the volunteer department from 2013-2014, 2019-2020, and most recently, 2023-2024. It's typically a "gentleman's agreement" within the firehouse that chiefs serve two-year terms non-consecutively.
At its December meeting, the fire department elected current Assistant Chief JR Dobson as its incoming chief for 2025.
It'll be Dobson's first stint as fire chief, something Jones remembers being excited for when he assumed the role in 2013.
"I'm excited for him to be able to experience that as well," Jones said. "I'm confident that he'll do a good job."
Jones began in fire service when he was 16, joining the Kent Island Volunteer Fire Department in 1988. He says he isn't going anywhere. He'll still be responding to calls as a volunteer and helping the department carry out its mission to serve Easton residents.
For more than 23 years, Jones has been an active member of the Easton Volunteer Fire Department, including in roles such as fire officer and assistant chief before he was first elected chief.
"Each time I've been chief, it's had its unique challenges, whether it be major incidents or natural disasters," Jones said. "There's been some really positive moments in the acquisition of new firefighting apparatus."
In the past year, firefighters responded to a fatal plane crash in the Tred Avon River in July, along with multiple significant fires. The fire department and its fundraising arm was also integral in the groundbreaking of the A. James Clark Emergency Services Training Campus in December.
During the pandemic, firefighters didn't socialize in-person at the firehouse as much as usual due to safety guidelines. But in the years since, Jones is happy that aspect has returned, especially since he views the membership as family.
"They're your brothers and sisters as much as your own brothers and sisters or wives or husbands would be," Jones said. "They're people that you see almost every day. You put your life in their hands, they put their life in yours, and you work together to do some very exciting yet dangerous work."
Since Easton Volunteer Fire Department's start in 1808, Jones is only one of three members to serve three separate times as chief. C.R. Chance has the department record at four terms.
As he exits a historic third term, Jones is thankful for the fire department's strong membership, and he looks forward to those assuming leadership roles in 2025.
"I can step away from the position not having any regrets whatsoever and nothing but pride in the job that the members have done over the years," he said. "Pride in the upcoming leadership, knowing that they'll continue to do good work to support not only the department but the public in general. And just knowing that I was part of a small group of history within the Town of Easton."

title: Counties and towns prepare for snow on the Mid-Shore this weekend
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Counties and towns prepare for snow on the Mid-Shore this weekend

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 531
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — With snow in the forecast this Sunday and Monday, Mid-Shore towns and counties are making plans and readying their snow plows."Every storm is different and unique," Easton Town Engineer Rick Van Emburgh said. "But we feel that we're prepared and ready for the storm."
On Friday, the Talbot County Department of Emergency Services had a meeting with local towns to coordinate in preparation for the winter weather.
According to the National Weather Service forecast as of Friday afternoon, snow is likely to fall in Easton from Sunday night into Monday. The weather organization is expecting a "major winter storm" will bring snow and ice across the country, "from the Central Plains to the Mid-Atlantic" this weekend.
Sunday night, there is a 90% chance of precipitation in Easton with snow expected mainly after 1 a.m., according to the National Weather Service. On Monday, there is a 90% chance of precipitation in Easton with snow expected before 1 p.m. and then rain and snow likely. Monday night, there is a 50% chance of precipitation.
Talbot County Public Schools Communications Director Debbie Gardner said the district is monitoring the forecast to determine if closures will be necessary.
Dorchester County Emergency Management Division Director Jimmy Windsor said Dorchester County has warned all its departments of the predicted weather, including its Highway Division. He said the county's Highway Division is preparing its inclement weather plans.
Van Emburgh said on Friday that Easton was putting plows on the fronts of trucks and loading salt into the trucks that spread salt.
"And we have equipment that we're placing around town that we'll use to address alleys and some of the tighter spots that we plow," he said.
Windsor said it is important that residents make sure they take the usual winter preparedness precautions, such as making sure vehicles have gas in them. He said that residents who live in areas that are prone to power outages should make sure they have blankets and warm clothing in the event of an outage.
"And a supply of fresh water in case the power goes out and you're on well water and therefore you rely on the power for your water source," he said.
Van Emburgh said it's helpful if residents do not park their cars on main streets.
"When people park on the streets, we have to plow around the cars and sometimes that can — depending on how much snow we get — that can get tricky and then we plow the cars in," he said.
Van Emburgh also talked about the importance of not plowing snow from the sidewalks into the street.
"Because we then plow it back onto the sidewalk," he said, laughing. "It's just a battle. (Residents) plow it onto the street. We plow it back onto the sidewalk. And they get mad at us."
Van Emburgh said residents should plow snow off their sidewalks by starting in the center of the street and working toward a house or building so that the snow is plowed into a yard.
"Some properties don't have yards," he said. "But if you plow it out in the street, it's just going to get pushed back onto the sidewalk. So we ask that everything moves away from the center of the street."

title: Three robbers target Brinks armored vehicle driver
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com

Three robbers target Brinks armored vehicle driver

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 421
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Three men remained on the loose Thursday after they assaulted a female Brinks employee in broad daylight near an ATM machine in Elkton during a failed attempt to steal money from her parked armored vehicle, according to police.One of the assailants was armed with a pistol that likens an assault rifle, reported Lt. Ronald Odom, an Elkton Police Department detective who also serves as an agency spokesman. Odom also reported that one of the suspects pepper-sprayed the victim.
The attempted armed robbery occurred shortly after 1 p.m. on Wednesday in the Walmart Supercenter parking lot in the 1000 block of East Pulaski Highway (Route 40), police said. At the time, the employee was in a section of the parking lot that is closest to the Chick-Fil-A while servicing an ATM machine, police added.
An ambulance crew transported the woman from the scene to ChristianaCare Union Hospital in Elkton, where she was treated for minor injuries and then discharged, police reported.
Based on the preliminary investigation, detectives believe that the culprits approached the employee in that parking lot and tried to force her to open a compartment in the armored vehicle where the money is stored, according to Odom.
At some point during the attempted robbery, one of the suspects pepper-sprayed the woman, who was unable to oblige her assailants' demand to unlock the compartment, Odom reported.
"She was not able to open the locked section because, for security reasons, there are procedures in place. It's not as easy as unlocking your car," Odom explained.
Odom described the three assailants only as black men and noted that one of them brandished "an AK mini Draco style pistol that looks like an assault rifle."
He further reported that the culprits fled from the scene in a dark-colored sport utility vehicle that is similar to a Dodge Durango or a Chevrolet Tahoe — with tinted windows and a white license plate — and that the getaway vehicle was last seen heading east on Route 40 into Delaware.
Investigators believe that the assailants were concerned that law enforcement officers might be rushing to the scene, which prompted them to abandon their efforts to break into the armored vehicle and flee instead, police reported.
EPD investigators watched video that they gleaned from security cameras in the area where the attempted armed robbery occurred, Odom said. They also interviewed witnesses, Odom added, declining to elaborate because of the ongoing investigation.
After receiving notification about the attempted robbery resulting in an injured employee, Brink sent representatives to the scene and they removed the armored vehicle, police reported.

 EASTON — Snow blanketed the Eastern Shore Monday, with reports from the National Weather Service reporting more than 11 inches of snow in Talbot County, one of the heaviest snowfalls in recent memory.Along with the heavy snow came emergency declarations from Easton, Federalsburg, Dorchester County and Gov. Wes Moore (D) for the state of Maryland, among others.
The snow storm began Sunday night and continued through early Tuesday morning. Weather reports are predicting more snow may come Friday and Saturday.
The National Weather Service has reported inch counts throughout the day for several Eastern Shore counties, with several areas reporting snowfall at or near a foot.
12 inches of snow were reported in Preston at 2:53 p.m. Monday, with more snowfall to come that evening.
A reading taken in Easton the following morning also showed a foot of snow had fallen, and a 6:15 a.m. reading Tuesday in East New Market showed 10.5 inches of snowfall.
Megan Cook, mayor of Easton, said county and town departments and residents did a great job with addressing the snow storm.
"Our Public Works department did an excellent job clearing the roads during the snow emergency," Cook said Tuesday afternoon. "They worked tirelessly during the last 40 hours, starting at midnight Sunday night, plowing roads, parking lots and parks for residents. And during this time, they also managed to pick up both Monday and Tuesday's trash routes."
Additionally, Cook said she is grateful for the residents who heeded the snow emergency declaration and stayed off the roads so it could be properly be cleared in a safe manner. The Easton Volunteer Fire Department and the Easton Police Department worked hard on responding to all the calls made during the snow storm.
Glenn Steckman, city manager for Cambridge, said he is happy with the amount of cooperation the residents and town staff had when trying to navigate the snow storm.
"I think the city did very well," Steckman said. "We haven't had a — from what everybody has told me — a major snow in Cambridge in about four years. The city staff started meeting on Friday to discuss how they were going to approach addressing the storm. And we just did what we needed to do, which was get out and plow our streets, and salt them and make travel as easy as possible."
According to Steckman, Cambridge staff tried to work quickly and efficiently with the changes in weather. Steckman said there was a point where staff spent 20 hours battling the snow.
"I want to acknowledge our staff in the Public Works who are the ones who put the effort in in moving the snow," Steckman said. "That was a long day for anybody, and I think they need a pat on the back for the work they did."
In a press release from Talbot County, Brian LeCates, director of the Talbot County Department of Emergency Services, said his department had been working hard to keep the county safe from the drastic changes in weather.
"Our first priority is keeping residents safe," LeCates said. "We urge everyone to stay off the roads, especially as drifting snow and strong winds will create dangerous driving conditions overnight."
Talbot County Sheriff's Office made a post on Facebook Monday morning showing heavy snow on MD 331 coming out of Caroline County and recommended for residents to "Please stay home and stay safe."
In a press release from the county, Clay Stamp, manager for Talbot County, expressed his gratitude for the dedication of Talbot County employees during the storm response.
"I want to personally thank our Roads & Facilities Department and Emergency Services staff for their incredible efforts during this winter storm," Stamp said. "Their hard work and commitment to keeping our community safe and operational, often in challenging conditions, exemplify the very best of public service."
While crews worked to keep roadways safe and return operations to normal as soon as possible, Eastern Shore communities saw multiple businesses, government offices and schools close for the inclement weather.
The town of St. Michaels announced its town offices would be closed due to the weather Monday, as did the town of Easton and other municipalities in the area, many of which also remained closed on Tuesday. By Wednesday, many offices were expected to return to normal operations.
St. Michaels announced trash collection would resume its usual schedule with collection on Wednesday, but Denton delayed trash pick up for Thursday due to the weather.
Talbot County, Caroline County and Dorchester County Public Schools announced closures on Monday due to the weather and were not expected to reopen to students until Thursday.
Saints Peter & Paul School announced virtual learning days for its students on Tuesday and Wednesday.
Chesapeake Community College, Salisbury University and University of Maryland Eastern Shore announced closures due to the weather for Monday and Tuesday.

title: Gasser plans to take Federalsburg police in the right direction
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Gasser plans to take Federalsburg police in the right direction
