 FEDERALSBURG — Joseph Gasser has taken his new role of chief of police in stride, setting goals to help further the Federalsburg Police Department amid turnover and a third-party investigation.On Wednesday, Gasser was publicly named chief of police in a Facebook post made by the town government. Gasser has been interim chief of police since October, when an unspecified incident caused the town to have a third party investigate the department.
Gasser comes into this position with a military background, and he has been serving the Town of Federalsburg for almost 30 years. He believes his strong background and experience will help him serve as chief.
"The jobs that I have had throughout both my military and my police career have pointed me in this direction," Gasser said. "As not somebody simply to have a standard to take over, but someone that has the ability and the knowledge to build from."
On Oct. 14 the Town of Federalsburg made a facebook post about an unspecified incident causing the town to have a third party investigate the department.
"The Town of Federalsburg received a complaint about an incident involving the Federalsburg Police Department that occurred on October 9, 2024. We are engaging an independent third party to investigate this incident," the post said.
When asked whether turnover in the Federalsburg Police Department was related to the October incident, Mayor Kim Abner referred the Star Democrat to the Facebook post.
Gasser confirmed the October incident was a consideration in his appointment. "But that's as far as I'll go with it," he said.
In the post announcing Gasser promotion, the town stated former Chief Michael McDermott, who had served in law enforcement for more than 40 years, resigned effective Jan. 5.
"The Mayor and Council, on behalf of the Town of Federalsburg, extend our appreciation to Chief McDermott for his years of service to the Town and wish him all the best in his future endeavors," the town said in the Facebook post.
In McDermott's years as chief, the department saw a significant reduction in crime rates, the post said. Gasser wants to continue McDermott's work.
"We've had a good several years here with the former chief, and I want to expound upon that and make it even better for the future," Gasser said.
Some of Gasser's goals and plans will be executed within three years, the new chief said. He plans to shape the department better for the future.
"We have several new officers with less than a year in the field," Gasser stated. "They are the future of this department. My primary goal is to prepare this department three years down the line, five years down the line, for those individuals to take over this department and to run it effectively and in service of the community."
In addition to continuing the work that has been done, Gasser plans for some reorganization as well.
"There's certainly some internal reorganization to the department that needs to be done," Gasser said. "That's going to be a transitional point, both with me coming in as Chief, even though I've been here forever. It's also going to be a task to better serve the officers themselves, like some officers have things they like to do more than others, I want to get them headed in that direction."

title: YMCA back to normal operations after Saturday fires
author: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com
content:
YMCA back to normal operations after Saturday fires

 January 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 559
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Peter Hyman was in his gym clothes and already on his way to the YMCA on Peachblossom Road around noon on Saturday when he learned there had been a fire at the Y.When he arrived moments later, Hyman, who is president of the YMCA's board, said he saw members of the community and Y staff gathering, many visibly upset by the event.
"The staff was upset. It was an upsetting moment, and I just did what I could to help both in terms of the emotions of the folks as well as the physical reality of the situation," he said Sunday morning.
The fire, which involved a second-floor closet at the Y, was one of two that the Easton Volunteer Fire Department and other departments responded to at the YMCA Saturday, according to Easton Fire Chief JR Dobson.
At around 5:30 p.m., firefighters were once again called to the Y, where an HVAC unit was on fire on the building's roof.
Neither fire resulted in any extensive damage to the building, according to YMCA of the Chesapeake CEO Robbie Gill.
Dobson said the first fire was extinguished by the Y's sprinkler system before firefighters arrived at the scene. The second fire was quickly extinguished by firefighters using a fire extinguisher after gas feeding the HVAC unit was shut off, the fire chief said.
The fires closed the Y for the remainder of Saturday, but regular operations resumed Sunday morning with all facilities but the racquetball courts open for use. The racquetball courts were largely undamaged, Gill said, but due to their proximity to the first fire, a sprinkler had gone off over them, meaning they had to be closed Sunday while staff worked to dry the area.
"We were fortunate there wasn't a substantial amount of damage to the building," Gill said. "And now we're working with local authorities to provide any information we can to help them investigate."
While the second fire's cause was ruled by the Office of the State Fire Marshal to have been a mechanical failure with the HVAC unit, Dobson said, the cause of the first fire is still under investigation.
Gill said the first fire is not believed to have been caused by any mechanical or similar failure.
Though the fires did not cause extensive damage to the facilities, Hyman said the events were particularly upsetting for Y staff and regulars because of the role the YMCA plays in the Easton community.
"We're lucky," he said. "Our YMCA is not just a place to work out and exercise. It really is a community. It's a very wonderful group of people… I've been a member of the Y for years, and it really is a community across cultures, all kinds of folks. And it's a really special place."
Dobson said multiple departments, including the Easton, Oxford and Trappe volunteer fire departments and Talbot County Emergency Services, responded to the events Saturday. These departments worked with staff and others on the scene to evacuate the building and secure the area.
Gill said although Saturday was "a little bit of a traumatic day," the coordinated community response to the fires served as a reminder of the importance of the YMCA.
"The Y has been around for 168 years, so it's an institution in the community that serves one in three people, and it's wonderful to see so many people care for it at that level," Gill said.

title: 'Believers don’t give up hope': Delaware church vows to rebuild after second vehicle strike in six months
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
'Believers don’t give up hope': Delaware church vows to rebuild after second vehicle strike in six months

 January 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 719
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The driver of a stolen car fleeing police smashed through the front of St. John AM Church early Jan. 13 marking the second time in six months that a vehicle has caused significant damage to the historic church.The latest incident happened at approximately 4:30 a.m. An Infiniti Q50 jumped the curb, knocked over a barrier intended to protect the church, destroyed a chain-link fence and crashed through the front of the building, which is located at the corner of New London Road and Cleveland Avenue.
Lt. Greg D'Elia, a spokesman for the Newark Police Department, said officers were called to a car dealership on Cleveland Avenue for a report of suspicious people. While investigating, they saw a car pulling out of the dealership, and the officers attempted to pull over the vehicle. The vehicle fled, and the officers did not pursue it but discovered minutes later that the car had crashed into the church.
Two occupants of the vehicle were taken to Christiana Hospital for treatment. Both are 24-year-old men, and one was listed in critical condition, according to paramedics.
Charges are pending, D'Elia said, adding that the car had been reported stolen from Pennsylvania.
St. John AM Church was damaged in a similar incident Aug. 9, when a car topping speeds of 90 mph crashed into the church. That driver, who had stolen the car from a Cleveland Avenue dealership, managed to get out of the car before police arrived and was finally arrested in December.
The church's sanctuary has remained condemned since the August crash, and the church has been holding weekly services in the fellowship hall, which is located in an undamaged rear portion of the building.
Pastor Blaine Hackett said the church had just finished negotiating with its insurance company about repairing the damage from the August incident. Monday's crash happened just hours before he was scheduled to sign a contract with the construction company.
Now, Hackett and his congregation have even further damage to contend with. While the first crash mostly damaged the entry vestibule, the latest crash appeared to be more severe. The car did heavy damage to the corner of the main church building, and large cracks could be seen in the surrounding brick walls.
Though Monday's crash is a setback, the congregation remains undeterred, Hackett said.
"Believers don't give up hope," he said. "God is still in the fixing business, and he's going to fix this. He's going to restore it all back to where it needs to be. We're encouraged. This is just a delay, not a denial, of what God is doing in our ministry."
After two crashes, many have wondered why this keeps happening to the small, tight-knit congregation.
"I believe because the gospel is going forth here and that we're really sharing the good news of Jesus Christ, the enemy is not happy," Hackett said. "But the gates of hell will not prevail."
The first Black church in Newark, St. John first opened in a log cabin in 1848. The log cabin burned down in 1866, and the following year, the current church building was constructed at the same site. Since its inception, St. John has been a cornerstone of Newark's historically Black community.
Due to its location, the church has unfortunately been the victim of several crashes recently. Cars build up speed coming down a hill on Cleveland Avenue and either lose control or fail to navigate a slight curve past the church.
While Monday's crash and the one in August did the most damage, the church was also struck a few years ago. The damage in that case was just exterior, but it prompted the church to install barriers in the front yard to try to stop cars from hitting the building. The church suffered another vehicle strike this past November, but the car was stopped by the barriers and did not impact the main building.
Hackett said he is talking with the construction company about reinforcing the concrete barriers and adding additional barriers to better protect the church.
He is also planning to start a GoFundMe page to raise money for repairing the damage. Those interested in helping can also mail or drop off donations to St. John AM Church, 77 New London Road, Newark DE, 19711.
"We're resilient people, we have always been," Hackett said. "We believe in the power of God and how he restores those that love."

title: YMCA fire on Saturday intentionally set, fire marshal says

YMCA fire on Saturday intentionally set, fire marshal says

 January 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 457
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A fire at the YMCA on Peachblossom Road on Saturday was intentionally set, according to the Office of the State Fire Marshal.At around 12:30 p.m., Easton firefighters responded to a fire on the second floor, which took just under an hour to control, per the fire marshal. No injuries were reported.
A preliminary investigation ruled the cause as "incendiary." The fire marshal stated that "subject(s) ignited a small pile of party supplies located on the second floor rear storage hallway."
Normal operations at the Y resumed Sunday.
YMCA of the Chesapeake CEO Robbie Gill said, "it's disheartening to know that that can happen."
"The Y's been in this community 168 years," Gill said Monday. "It serves one in three people. It's kind of a third place where people go. It's a place where everyone is welcome."
The blaze around 12:30 p.m. was the first of two fires at the Y on Saturday. Around 5:30 p.m., firefighters were once again called to the Y, where an HVAC unit was on fire on the building's roof.
The cause of the HVAC fire was deemed to be a mechanical failure. The fire marshal ruled that second blaze as accidental and said it was unrelated to the incident earlier that day.
Both fires caused a combined $50,000 in estimated damages, according to the fire marshal's reports.
Gill said he's grateful the Easton Volunteer Fire Department responded so promptly and that there weren't extensive damages to the Y. Saturday's first fire was extinguished by the Y's sprinkler system before firefighters arrived at the scene.
Peter Hyman, president of the YMCA's board, was on his way to the Y around noon on Saturday when he learned of the first fire. He noticed community members and Y staff gathering.
"The staff was upset. It was an upsetting moment, and I just did what I could to help both in terms of the emotions of the folks as well as the physical reality of the situation," Hyman said Sunday morning.
"When something like this happens, it's offensive on a multiplicity of levels," Hyman added.
Gill said the Y is going to take a look at its procedures and protocols moving forward, as well as continuing to work with law enforcement in its investigation.
The fire marshal's office is asking anyone with information regarding the intentionally set fire to contact its Upper Eastern Regional Office at 410-819-3500.
Gill said the fact that someone tried to "impact the sanctity" of the Y as a community center is "always scary at the time and also sad."
"But if there's one thing about Talbot County and our community, it is a tight group of people," Gill said. "... Something like this isn't going to deter us from continuing to make a positive impact."
Star Democrat editor Wendy Weitzel contributed to this report.

title: Regional detention facility agreement needs work, Caroline commissioners say
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Regional detention facility agreement needs work, Caroline commissioners say

 January 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 508
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Tuesday at the Caroline County Commissioners meeting, officials spent an hour and 10 minutes discussing the draft agreement for the potential regional detention center in Queen Anne's County.Caroline County skepticism about the agreement could halt the joint effort on the new 388-bed facility that would house all Caroline, Queen Anne's and Kent county prisoners.
The commissioners' concerns largely dealt with who would manage and staff the new facility, as well as how authority over the facility would be divided among the three participating counties.
"All the employees would be Queen Anne's county employees," Caroline County Commission President Travis Breeding said. "The Warden, and all the way through the chain of command would be Queen Anne's workers, and honestly, I'm really struggling with the investment."
The potential detention center would be located at the former Eastern Pre-Release Unit site at 700 Flat Iron Square Road near Church Hill.
The center aims to address the growing need for modern and efficient detention facilities in the region, where counties are struggling to finance renovations or replacements of their aging detention facilities.
Last year, Caroline County sent a letter expressing interest in participating in the project. But Tuesday, the commissioners made it clear that they were not quite ready to sign on.
Caroline County Commissioners proposed a regional authority to manage the detention center, which is not mentioned in the drafter agreement.
"The item that we are still trying to hammer out is the agreement, we were under the impression that we were going to form a regional authority to manage the detention center," County Administrator Katheleen Freeman said.
The majority of the authority over the center will be in Queen Anne's County hands, according to the draft. All decisions and disagreement must go through Queen Anne's County Commissioners, and if they may have a disagreement it will be mediated.
The Caroline County commissioners also expressed concerns about the autonomy and authority of the the new facility's warden. According to the draft agreement, "The Board shall appoint a Warden to operate the Facility with the consent of the County Commissioners of Queen Anne's County."
The draft agreement also states that "The Warden's contract shall not be terminated without the Board's consent"
The commissioners voiced that they believed under the draft that Queens Anne's county could decide after a certain amount of time to remove Caroline or Kent county from agreement, regardless of the amount of money that was put up. To remove one or both of the other counties from the agreement, according to the draft, Queen Anne's County must give the other county a two-year notice to take all their prisoners and house them somewhere else.
The commissioners said they understood Queen Anne's County's decision to conduct the draft agreement this way, but they requested further negotiation and discussion to establish a partnering jurisdiction.
"It was never really any discussion by the prospective members that we would form an authority or develop this regional detention center via agreement with our partner jurisdiction," Freeman said.
Caroline County believes that the draft agreement can work, but before they sign on, changes must be made.

title: Easton man pleads guilty to possessing child pornography

Easton man pleads guilty to possessing child pornography

 EASTON — An Easton man pleaded guilty to four counts of possession of child pornography during a plea hearing on Thursday in the Talbot County Circuit Court.In June, Travis Schwaninger, 43, was arrested on eight counts of possessing child pornography following the execution of a search warrant where detectives from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office found evidence of child pornography on Schwaninger's electronic devices.
Before his arrest, the Easton Police Department Criminal Investigations Unit had received several tips about Schwaninger from the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children.
On Thursday, Maryland Circuit Court Judge Theresa Adams suspended all of the five-year sentences for each of the four counts Schwaninger pleaded guilty to. This means he will serve no jail time.
Adams said Schwaninger will have to serve five years of supervised probation, register as a Tier I sex offender and submit to supervision, meaning that he will have to comply with a sex offender management program.
The state agreed not to prosecute the remaining four charges Schwaninger faced.
Before handing down Schwaninger's sentence, Adams said that by obtaining and possessing the videos, Schwaninger was participating in the child pornography industry.
"The most important thing we can all do is protect children," she said.
During the plea hearing, Talbot County State's Attorney Joseph Coale gave descriptions of the four videos that Schwaninger pleaded guilty to having. He said the children in the videos were real children, not created by artificial intelligence.
Coale said that although Schwaninger had not manufactured the videos, his "participation in that market allows the market to flourish."
Schwaninger's attorney Thomas Maronick Jr. said his client "looked at some pictures he should not have" and didn't distribute them. Maronick said Schwaninger has since met with a counselor experienced in treating sex offenders. Maronick said the counselor did not feel that Schwaninger had a problem that requires "lengthy" therapy.
This was "a crime of curiosity," Maronick said, later adding that Schwaninger didn't realize the industry he was supporting.
Schwaninger told Adams that he came across the videos on social media toward the end of 2023.
"It was like watching a train wreck," he said about the videos. "I know better."
Schwaninger said the videos were on an old phone and didn't realize they were on the phone he was using at the time of his arrest. He said he thought he had deleted the videos.

Prosecutors: 80-year-old man who fatally shot son won't be charged

 January 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 307
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ELKTON — Prosecutors have elected not to file criminal charges against an 80-year-old man who fatally shot his adult son in September during an incident on the family's Conowingo property, concluding that the patriarch had acted in self-defense, according to The Office of the Cecil County State's Attorney.The father fatally shot his son — Joe Berry Jr., 53, of Conowingo — at approximately 2 p.m. on Sept. 24 on a residential property in the 200 block of Mt. Zoar Road while the son was attempting to break into his parents' home, police reported at the time.
During the incident leading up to the fatal shooting, the patriarch's 78-year-old wife suffered injuries, police said. An ambulance crew drove the woman to Upper Chesapeake Medical Center in Bel Air, where she was treated for unspecified injuries that were not caused by gunfire, police added.
"Following a thorough review of the evidence, Maryland State Police investigators determined that the decedent was shot while attempting to break into the home after an earlier physical and verbal altercation with the resident elderly couple. After a review of the current statute, case law, and all information gathered by the Maryland State Police, the Office of the State's Attorney has elected to not proceed with criminal charges. In these circumstances, the suspect was protecting himself and his wife and was acting in self-defense," an SAO spokeswoman explained.
The father was cooperative throughout the investigation, police reported.
MSP troopers assigned to the agency's North East Barrack rushed to scene shortly before 2 p.m. on Sept. 24 in response to a reported shooting, police said.
Firefighters responded to that Mt. Zoar Road property, too, and extinguished a blaze at an adjacent home, police added.
After completing their concurrent investigation, detectives with the Maryland Office of the State Fire Marshal ruled "undetermined" for the cause of that blaze, the SAO spokeswoman reported.

title: Easton's new fire chief has plans for equipment, recruitment
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton's new fire chief has plans for equipment, recruitment

 January 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 626
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — J.R. Dobson grew up around the fire house, always knowing he wanted to be a firefighter.In his teenage years, Dobson joined the Trappe Volunteer Fire Company as a junior cadet, and by 16 he began riding the fire trucks. He fondly recalls the "everybody knew everybody" aspect of the tight-knit community.
Dobson eventually moved to Easton, beginning his journey with the Easton Volunteer Fire Department in 2003. Over time, he's served in a number of roles, including most recently, assistant chief.
Now he's taking on the department's top role for the first time. Dobson was elected the department's chief in December.
With a wife and two daughters, timing was everything for Dobson when considering the commitment to assume a role as demanding as Easton fire chief. The timing is right, he said, and he's looking forward to leading and making a difference.
"There's a lot of tradition here," Dobson said. "It's certainly the biggest department in the county. It's got probably the most going on out of all the departments in the county. I think just being here, seeing how this department operates versus a small department. It's a business. And we're all here for free, none of us get paid."
Dobson officially began as chief this month. Sonny Jones just wrapped up his third two-year term leading the department.
Dobson, who volunteers at the fire department as all the firefighters do, is a patrol and operations commander at the Talbot County Sheriff's Office. He believes his experience leading around 35 deputies across multiple divisions will translate to his duties in the fire house.
"I think that I bring a lot of management skills, leadership skills," Dobson said. "Just from my experience there, I think it helps you here."
Thus far, Dobson says the support he's received has been "overwhelming."
Past fire chiefs have reached out, and he hopes to pick up one thing from each of them to set himself up for success. For instance, Jones' ability as an incident commander is something Dobson admires.
"If there were ever a bad day anybody was having, he's who you would want there," Dobson said of Jones. "Just the way he kind of rolls through an incident scene. He's been there and done that kind of thing."
Similarly, Jones — who is remaining involved with the department — spoke highly of Dobson.
"I've known J.R. the entire time that I've been a member of the Easton fire department," Jones said. "J.R. is a first-rate guy. He's a terrific leader. He has many, many qualities which will bode well for him as the chief of the department."
Some of the ongoing projects the new fire chief has his eye on include purchasing a utility vehicle to use for Rails to Trails and woods fires, buying a new engine and updating box alarm assignments. He also wants to implement some new standard operating procedures.
Dobson said he hopes to nail down a handful of tasks for the year and keep circling back to see what progress is being made. At the top of his list is recruitment and retention of volunteers.
"I think it all starts with recruiting. I think it all starts with retention," Dobson said. "Those are things that we've done well in the past, although the last year or so we haven't gotten as many members as we would like. And sometimes we'll get members in and they don't realize the commitment."
While acknowledging the town's consistent support of the department over the years, Dobson believes Easton Fire can do better in attracting more volunteers amid struggles statewide and nationwide to fill volunteer fire departments.
"We got to get people in here," Dobson said. "We've got to get these trucks out. And I think that the way the town's growing, if we don't grow with it, then we're failing ourselves."

title: OFFICERS WANTED: Mid-Shore law enforcement grapples with recruitment, retention
author: Konner Metz
content:
OFFICERS WANTED: Mid-Shore law enforcement grapples with recruitment, retention

 January 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 1400
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In his 48 years with the department, Dorchester County Sheriff James Phillips says the current landscape of law enforcement recruiting is the "absolute worst" he's ever seen.His department historically had applications on file at all times, but in recent years, the number of applicants has severely dwindled.
Phillips said while he loves his career, he understands why many are hesitant to become police officers.
"If it were me today, and I was starting over again, I'd probably go and try to be a paid firefighter somewhere," Phillips said, "because their schedules are better, they make good money and they're not under the scrutinization that we are."
For Phillips, increased state oversight on police officer conduct and a social shift in how the career is viewed by the general public have both negatively impacted the recruitment and retention of officers on the Eastern Shore.
Other sheriffs and police chiefs have cited those same state oversight actions, along with growing competition between agencies and a decline in quality applicants as reasons why smaller departments are struggling to staff at 100%.
Easton Police Department Deputy Chief Greg Wright says "police officers that were once held on the pedestal as being heroes are now villains."
"I think that all the negative talk that's broadcasted across the nation does affect these small agencies," Wright said. "There's larger agencies that we've talked to that talk about their struggles, because they're a thousand short of officers. But when you scale that down to a 48-man agency, 10 is a quarter of your agency."
STATE ACTIONSMaryland's Police Accountability Act of 2021 ushered in a new era of police reform, requiring counties to have police accountability boards and repealing the Law Enforcement Officers' Bill of Rights. It came the year after George Floyd's murder by a Minneapolis police officer and calls for reform to prevent police brutality.
Wright believes the enacted reform has positive aspects, but he worries that officers feel the waning trust from the public.
"You feel like you can't be trusted," he said. "They don't trust us to do the job."
In Easton, the police department has 43 of 48 slots full. Wright says the town has always been supportive of its police, and in his 37 years in Easton, he's never felt that community support evaporate.
Wright and Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble each mentioned local support is critical to the success of small departments. The Talbot County Sheriff's Office is at 47 of 48 slots, and Gamble says some of that is due to "lateral" transfers — officers choosing Talbot over other nearby departments.
However, multiple sheriffs and chiefs on the Eastern Shore separately raised concerns about the Maryland attorney general's Independent Investigations Division, which investigates all police-involved deaths such as high-speed chases.
Since its inception in 2021, the division has investigated 65 police-related deaths, according to data on its website. A fatal vehicle pursuit in Easton last July — which involved both county deputies and Easton officers — is still under investigation.
Wright says there's no doubt that it's in the back of officers' minds when conducting chases and "could delay their response." Phillips said it not only affects how many applicants Dorchester receives, but also how long current law enforcement employees remain.
"I've had several officers that could've worked longer, but as soon as they got their time then were able to retire, they retired just to get away from it," Phillips said.
Cambridge-Dorchester Fraternal Order of Police Lodge 27 President Thomas Hurley believes the state's actions are hurting recruitment and retention.
"You have to get them in the door, you have to keep them, and when they get old like me, you have to get rid of them," Hurley said. "The only thing that's working right now is retirement."
Hurley — a retired Cambridge officer of 30 years — said he sees officers leaving "all the time now" and that some "feel like they can't be cops."
"Absolutely it affects their job performance," Gamble said of the investigations. "Proactive policing in Maryland is dying. Proactive policing is traffic enforcement, it's DWI enforcement, it's drug enforcement. It's dying. People don't want to go into those units in some of these larger departments."
"Cops are going to shut down," Gamble later said. "They're going to do what they do in the metro areas. They answer the 911 calls and no more."
Last month, Attorney General Anthony Brown announced the indictment of two Anne Arundel County police officers in connection to a fatal 2023 chase. It was the division's first time charging an officer since the state passed a bill in 2023 giving the attorney general prosecutorial power in the investigations instead of local state's attorneys.
The attorney general's office declined a request for comment. In 2023, Brown voiced his support for that bill, noting that the Independent Investigations Division has "a team of experienced criminal prosecutors and investigators" and the measure to ensure independence and transparency "would fall in line with police accountability in many other states."
"The public should have confidence that prosecution decisions are made in an impartial manner, by people who do not work together or rely on each other professionally or personally," Brown wrote in a letter addressed to Maryland House Judiciary Committee Chair Luke Clippinger.
{h3 style="text-align: center "}PATH FORWARD{/h3}
While legislative decisions have drawn worries that police recruiting may only become more difficult, law enforcement leaders are also aware of challenges such as applicant quality, salaries and tight competition.
In Caroline County, Sheriff Donnie Baker noted that agencies in Delaware create serious competition in terms of hiring.
Sgt. Timothy Maloney of the Milford Police Department, around 20 miles from the Maryland border, said his department sees a "consistent" one to two Maryland officers apply during each hiring cycle.
The Caroline County Sheriff's Office has 46 of 48 positions staffed. Baker said many officers are working overtime to provide coverage in the towns of Ridgely and Greensboro.
Ridgely has been without a police department since it was suspended by the town last March, while Greensboro is down to Chief Lenox Trams as its lone officer.
Cambridge Police Department Chief Justin Todd said the hiring process remains "strict," and that many applicants fail background checks or the police academy.
Todd, though, has seen improvement in the last few years. Currently, 36 of 40 positions are filled in Cambridge, compared to 29 in the summer of 2022, despite the department's $56,000 starting salary for officers in the academy being slightly below Dorchester County ($57,458) and other agencies.
"The competition per agency is so strong," Todd said. "You have different agencies that make more money, say, than us. So it's a challenge for us to recruit the good officers."
This year, the Cambridge chief says the goal is to increase recruitment at job fairs, colleges and universities. He already feels the City of Cambridge and its council has been supportive of the police department's efforts.
"We know there's qualified applicants and great people out there that want to be officers," Todd said. "I think that we just need to promote ourselves better."
Maryland State Police leaders are similarly focusing on recruitment. Lt. Col. Scott Keyser, chief of MSP's Support Services Bureau, said the department is "incredibly aggressive," noting it went to 558 events and contacted more than 19,000 applicants last year.
MSP is authorized to have 1,564 troopers and there are currently 155 vacancies, Keyser said. He said the department's unique task is recruiting amid what is a "rigorous" and "daunting" hiring process.
"We're casting a wide net, just as far as we can go to get anybody that might be pursuing a career in law enforcement," Keyser said. "We want to bring them to the Maryland State Police."
In Easton, Wright said it's difficult to compete with MSP, though the town focuses on an appealing pension plan and other perks to recruit. State troopers start at a $68,000 salary upon training graduation, which is around $5,000 to $10,000 more than many departments on the Mid-Shore.
In terms of a path forward for recruiting, Wright sees it as a "reset button." Since George Floyd's death, Wright believes all officers have been viewed in "the same light," which has affected both public perception and desire to become an officer.
"We have to gain the trust, and we probably have to start young again," Wright said. "As they grow up, let them see that we're not the monsters that the news or the parents or society's making us look to be."
"We have no choice. We have to regain our fanbase," he continued. "And make people interested and excited about doing the job."

Cambridge parents to serve probation for child neglect charges

 January 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Crime

 CAMBRIDGE — Two Cambridge parents will serve two years of supervised probation after being arrested and charged for leaving their two young children unattended in a car in the Cambridge Walmart parking lot in late July.This past summer, Salvelia Josefina Lucas, 41, and Salvador Dejesus Delcid-Aguilar, 49, were each charged with two counts of neglect of a minor, two counts of confining and leaving a child unattended and two counts of reckless endangerment.
According to a news release from the Cambridge Police Department, on July 31, officers located a 4-year-old child and a 1-year-old child alone in a vehicle that wasn't running and had a partially-open window. Police said the temperature at that time was 88 degrees Fahrenheit but felt like 100 degrees Fahrenheit and the children were sweating "profusely."
Police said both children vomited from heat exposure before getting transported to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Cambridge for further evaluation.
According to Maryland court records, Lucas and Delcid-Aguilar were each placed on probation before judgement during a pre-trial conference on Jan. 13. This means the court has deferred any entry of conviction or finding of guilt and placed the defendants on probation.
The supervised probation will last two years and includes standard conditions, according to court documents.

title: Major explosion rocks Kent Island industrial facility, multiple injuries reported
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Major explosion rocks Kent Island industrial facility, multiple injuries reported

 January 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: News 
 
 296
 Words 

 Read News Document

 This story was updated at 5:24 p.m.STEVENSVILLE — Emergency crews contained a fire following an explosion at a commercial building on Kent Island Tuesday afternoon. Multiple injuries were reported and hazardous materials were involved.
The incident occurred shortly before 2 p.m. at 339 Log Canoe Circle in Stevensville. First responders arrived to find significant damage and active fire at the facility.
The cause of the explosion has not been identified by officials.
According to emergency dispatch communications, the explosion reportedly originated in the building's extraction room. Multiple witnesses reported hearing the blast, with emergency services receiving numerous 911 calls from the area.
The 3,350-square-foot commercial facility formerly housed operations for Munters, a Swedish-owned international company that manufactures climate control solutions. However, employees on site gave contact information for PharmaCann, which, according to its website, is "one of the country's largest vertically integrated cannabis companies, providing safe, reliable, top-quality cannabis products."
Employees for PharmaCann said they could not comment further due to the "sensitive nature of their business."
Kent Island Volunteer Fire Department Chief Buddy Thomas advised additional support from Anne Arundel and Dorchester counties' hazmat teams was requested due to the presence of hazardous materials.
Local volunteer fire departments from Kent Island, Grasovnille, Romancoke, Goodwill, United Communities and Queenstown responded, along with units from Queen Anne's County Department of Emergency Services and the Naval District Fire Department in Annapolis.
Sprinklers contained the fire, and crews were able to further extinguish with the fire with no involvement of nearby businesses, an official on the scene told reporters.
Officials said the site was no longer a hazmat concern by late afternoon. At least two were transported to area hospitals with minor injuries. The Office of the State Fire Marshal is conducting an investigation.
This is a developing story. Updates will be provided as more information becomes available.

title: 'A cautionary tale': Problems with hydrants, water during L.A. fires brings infrastructure, preparedness to forefront
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media
content:
'A cautionary tale': Problems with hydrants, water during L.A. fires brings infrastructure, preparedness to forefront

 January 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media | Section: News 
 
 1200
 Words 

 Read News Document

 There are an estimated 9 million fire hydrants in the U.S.Some hydrants ran dry and failed to operate during the recent raging wildfires that decimated Malibu, Pacific Palisades and other parts of Los Angeles because of water pressure and water supplies problems.
California Gov. Gavin Newsom — who has faced significant criticism along with Los Angeles Mayor Karen Bass over the fires — has ordered investigations into what went wrong with the fires, including the issues with hydrants losing pressure and not working.
Jeff Wenninger, CEO of Law Enforcement Consultants LLC (a public safety advisory firm) and a former Los Angeles Police Department lieutenant, says other communities should take heed of the Southern California fires.
"The Los Angeles wildfires are a cautionary tale for every community, showing that preparedness is non-negotiable," Wenninger said. "One key lesson is the importance of maintaining critical infrastructure. Fire hydrants, reservoirs, and water systems must be inspected and repaired regularly."
He pointed to tree trimming in the Los Angeles urban forest and a local reservoir that was empty at the time of the fires earlier this month.
Wenninger said Los Angeles has the largest tree count in the country, with 700,000 trees and 6,500 miles of tree-lined streets.
"But tree trimming happens on a 15-year cycle—far too long in fire-prone areas. Nearby communities trim every 2–5 years, significantly reducing their risk. This is a clear area where improvement is both possible and necessary," he said.
"Then, there's the failure of the Santa Ynez Reservoir, which sat empty for over a year due to a torn cover awaiting repair. Fixing it would've cost $130,000—a fraction of the damages caused by the fires," he said.
Wenninger said a regular inspection and maintenance regime as well as smart technologies that can detect water and firefighting infrastructure problems should be looked at in California and across the country.
Mitch Francis, a Beverly Hills-based real estate developer and author who delves into policy matters, said communities need to look at and potentially up their current funding and resource levels for water reserves, firefighting equipments and forest and brush management.
"Building methodologies and codes must be restructured to move away from building with flammable materials. Building wood-frame structures is tantamount to building with gasoline. We have to build with more nonflammable materials such as concrete and steel," Francis said.
He also said there could be reimagined volunteer fire departments in local neighborhoods to help battle blazes
"We have to reinstate and proliferate the old idea of volunteer fire departments, but on an extremely local level of small communities, down to even just a few blocks. Small enclaves of homeowners can own their own water/hose truck and be trained in maintaining and using it," Francis said.
Year-round vigilance
Fire departments and local governments across the country are also watching and looking to learn lessons from the California fires, which continue to spark in the Los Angeles and San Diego area.
In Sarasota County on Florida's west coast, county officials said the California fires reinforce the need for year-round mitigation and clearings for fire-prone areas, year-around monitoring and maintenance of water infrastructure and shows the need for brushfire training and mutual aid emergency planning with other jurisdictions.
Sarasota County, which has a population of more than 469,000 people, operates 7,800 fire hydrants in unincorporated areas and 1,400 miles of water mains.
"All potable water supply mains, back-flow preventers, and fire hydrants are approved, inspected, and maintained by the Sarasota County Public Utilities Department," the county said in a statement
The Florida county abides by National Fire Protection Association standards that calls for fire hydrants to be inspected annually and after each use.
'Prevention and preparation'
Takami Clark, spokesperson for the city of Bozeman in Montana, said her city is also watching the California fires unfold.
"We recognize that wildfire is a major concern and our best strategies to deal with this growing problem are prevention and preparation," Clark said.
The Montana city of more than 57,300 people has roughly 3,100 fire hydrants and 350 miles of water mains that are supplied by four water tanks with 16 million gallons of storage.
The city's water and sewer division maintains the hydrants and mains.
Bozeman officials said they conduct leak detection surveys and inspections, including to make sure they are working in the wintertime.
"We try to accomplish one-third of our hydrants each year for this task. We also flow about a one-fourth of our fire hydrants each year and flow test random spots of another 5% of our system each year," Clark said.
Clark said Bozeman has not had any problems with its hydrants, noting that the city only utilizes two pump stations to get water to higher elevations.
Actionable lessons
Rebekah Thurston, public information officer for the Wilmington Fire Department in North Carolina said the agency "directly inspected 6,294 fire hydrants" in 2024 and any repairs are done promptly.
"This includes both public hydrants owned by the Cape Fear Public Utility Authority (CFPUA) and private hydrants," she said. The North Carolina city has a population of close 122,700 people.
"Our hydrant management software uses GPS for precise location tracking, records hydrant details, captures maintenance needs, and includes a comprehensive inspection checklist," Thurston said, adding that inspections are conducted throughout the year.
She said WFD conducts post-incident reviews of major national and international disasters and weather events.
"These reviews are essential for enhancing safety, fostering continuous improvement, and identifying actionable lessons to improve future responses," she said.
'You're vulnerable'
Michael Coffey, a partner with New York-based law firm Coffey Modica LLP (who previously served as fire commissioner and on the city council in Norwalk, Connecticut), said local governments need to look if they are doing enough emergency preparedness for wildfires and other natural disasters and make sure water systems and other infrastructure are in working conditions.
"This is an epic failure of a lot of different agencies," Coffey said, of the California wildfires.
Coffey said working fire hydrants are tied to insurance premiums for nearby. He said water infrastructure isn't always high on government spending lists, but municipalities and counties need to take fresh and regular looks at those needs.
"Infrastructure is not sexy. People don't get jazzed up about it," Coffey said.
He said communities also need to look at building codes (including materials used for housing and commercial buildings), zoning, current and future challenges with water rights and insurance quandaries with fire seasons getting longer and more destructive hurricanes and other storms due to weather changes.
Eric Brown, founder and CEO of Orlando-based Imperio Consulting and former U.S. Army Green Beret, puts fighting fires in military terms.
"There's a tenet I've carried with me from my time in Special Forces: You're only as strong as your supply lines. In the context of firefighting, that means your water infrastructure must be rock-solid," Brown said.
He said the lessons of Los Angeles should be "to shore up" water delivery systems and infrastructure and be on the watch for aging hydrants and pipes and insufficient or fluctuating water pressure.
He said local governments need to collaborate more closely with utilities and treat water infrastructure as a "critical asset."
"When the fires raged, every second counted. Without robust water pressure and well-maintained hydrants, firefighters are effectively sent into battle with half their ammunition. Communities and fire departments across the country should take note: If your infrastructure can't handle peak demand at a moment's notice, you're vulnerable," Brown said.

title: Fire at substation causing power outages in Caroline County
author: Staff Writer
content:
Fire at substation causing power outages in Caroline County

 January 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Local News 
 
 365
 Words 

 Read News Document

 UPDATE 2 P.M. — Choptank Electric announced power had been restored to all its customers in the area at in a Facebook post at 1:45 p.m.UPDATE 11 A.M. — Caroline County Publics Schools reported via Facebook that Colonel Richardson Middle and Colonel Richardson High School are both without power. The power outage is affecting the school's phones.
Due to the power outages in the area, the schools will stay open. Student drivers are being released, and if parents want to pick their children up they can.
The school is safe, heated and will provide lunch for students that are staying.
High school finals have been canceled for the day.
ORGINAL REPORT —
DENTON — A reported commercial vehicle fire near a Delmarva Power substation on Camp Road in Denton is causing power outages in the area.
Demarva Power is reporting it does not expect power to be restored to the area until later Thursday afternoon, according to the utility company's website.
Choptank Electric, which uses the substation, is reporting around 2,400 customers are without power in Caroline County.
"We currently have 2,400 members in Caroline County without power due to a fire in another utility's substation," Choptank Electric wrote in a Facebook post Thursday morning. "Our crew is working to reroute and restore power as quickly as possible."
Choptank Electric encouraged those who did not lose power to conserve electricity as much as possible while restoration efforts are underway.
"Due to the cold temperatures and high load this morning, we encourage members to only use essential appliances and electricity to make restoration faster," the Facebook post said.
Greensboro Elementary School is currently without power, district officials confirmed, though they were unsure it was related to the substation fire. Firefighters are at the scene of the fire at this time and are reporting the blaze is contained. No injuries have been reported.

title: State could improve juvenile justice system
author: STEPHEN RIDEOUT
content:
State could improve juvenile justice system

 January 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEPHEN RIDEOUT | Section: Columns 
 
 759
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The first juvenile court was founded in 1899 in Chicago. Since then, the states have passed laws that created their own juvenile court systems. These are broad systems that function differently within each state. That impacts similar cases in different ways.So, in one state a child of a certain age automatically can be treated as an adult depending on the crime charged while in another state that same child would go through a hearing in the juvenile court to determine probable cause and if a judicial officer felt the case should remain in juvenile court or go to adult court for trial and treatment as an adult.
After I retired from the bench in 2004, I began consulting in states to help them improve how their systems worked for children and families with a focus on local collaboration efforts among courts, child welfare agencies, lawyers and service agencies to help improve outcomes.
From my experience as a judge in Virginia and my consulting work around the country, some states have confusing and sometimes counterproductive laws for the treatment of juveniles tried for delinquent offenses or crimes. Maryland is one of them.
To that end, what follows is an explanation of just one way that Maryland could improve its juvenile justice system. It is not, however, intended to say that the proposed legislation that the General Assembly is considering is the right answer. It is meant to offer an alternative that might work better for everyone.
In Virginia, where I was a juvenile and domestic relations district court judge, the decision for treating a youth as an adult was left to the juvenile court judge after he or she made a determination of probable cause that the child committed the offense, reviewed a report prepared by the juvenile justice agency on the child's background and court history and heard other evidence that the parties wanted to present.
The judge then decided if the evidence supported the removal of the case to adult court or not. No matter what the decision was, either the commonwealth attorney or the defense attorney could appeal that decision to the Circuit Court for a new hearing by a different judge.
The Virginia process worked well and efficiently, and those cases that were removed to Circuit Court were done with a more complete understanding of what happened and who may have done what. It also allowed the juvenile court judge to detain the youth in a juvenile detention facility where services were available rather than in an adult jail, where he or she should have been held separate from the adult population.
The concern that I have about the Maryland process is that the state's attorney can have limited information about the crime and alleged perpetrator and his or her background. The decision can be made based on public outrage that may not be founded on facts but rather, nowadays, on social media.
I recall cases that I heard that would have met the Maryland standard for trial as an adult that did not, in my opinion, warrant removal to Circuit Court. One involved a youth with no prior court involvement who was handed a gun while riding in a car with four other youth, one of whom was his cousin, who was sitting in the front seat of the car. The defendant was holding the gun when it discharged accidentally and killed his cousin.
In Maryland, given his age, from my understanding of Maryland law, it would have gone to Circuit Court for trial as an adult; and he would have been held in jail rather than a juvenile detention facility.
Another case involved what would have been a school yard fistfight. The commonwealth attorney sought to remove that case involving several youths to Circuit Court. While there was probable cause for the removal of most of them, there was no probable cause as to one and the cause of death was a blow to the back of deceased youth's head when his head hit on some steps after he was hit one time with a fist.
Some of the youth had prior records with the court and so their cases went to Circuit Court for trial as adults while I kept some in juvenile court and found no probable cause as to one youth. Appeals were allowed for all those cases for new determinations by our Circuit Court.
Despite opposition by state's attorneys to a change in the law, I would urge the members of the General Assembly to work to improve the current law by supporting reasonable changes such as the process in Virginia.

title: Will state lawmakers regulate police drones?
author: PAUL KIEFER Capital News Service
content:
Will state lawmakers regulate police drones?

 January 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: PAUL KIEFER Capital News Service | Section: News 
 
 1052
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — On an afternoon in mid-January, a Montgomery County police drone tracked a shoplifting suspect as he made his way from a Wheaton CVS to the entrance of a nearby Metro station, where a patrol unit intercepted and arrested him.Police flight records show that the drone, piloted by officers at a command center in Rockville, then returned to its station on a nearby rooftop to await the next 911 call.
The drone is one of four operated by the Montgomery County Department of Police. The year-old drone response program is the first of its kind in Maryland, with drones stationed in Gaithersburg, Silver Spring and Wheaton. The drones have responded to nearly 2,000 calls since the program's launch, often reaching the scene before police officers get there.
"We hear the emergency as you're describing it, and we can just send the drone," said Commander Jason Cokinos, who leads the department's drone program. "We're cheating time."
Reactions to the program are mixed, with some observers enthusiastic about the flexibility it provides and others concerned about the technology's privacy implications. This year, Maryland lawmakers are considering regulating the use of drones for police responses before a more widespread adoption of the technology occurs.
Some Maryland lawmakers worry that current state law doesn't offer clear guidance on how or when law enforcement can use drones as the first or only responders to emergency calls.
The police are operating in a legal gray area, said Del. Robin Grammer Jr., a Republican representing Baltimore County and a member of Maryland's House Judiciary Committee.
"Now, it's reactive enforcement," Grammer said. "You can come back to this moment in time in a year, two years from now, and some jurisdiction's going to be sending out drones proactively. That's not the world I want to live in."
Montgomery County police say they reached out to community members and civil liberties groups to develop rules for their use of drones and the storage of aerial surveillance footage before implementing their program in November 2023.
But it wasn't until this month that the Maryland General Assembly began weighing whether to set state-level rules for more expansive drone programs. House lawmakers summoned police and a spokesperson for the American Civil Liberties Union to Annapolis last Wednesday to review Montgomery County's program.
In that meeting, Cokinos emphasized that his department has taken a narrow approach to aerial surveillance.
"We want to have the least amount of visual intrusion (on) anybody on the ground level that we can," Cokinos told lawmakers.
Police only dispatch the drones in response to emergency calls involving "safety issues," Cokinos said, and they do not send drones to calls without a suspect present. Those can range from assaults in progress to children playing hockey on potentially thin ice, according to the department's flight records.
Pilots do not point the drones' cameras downward nor begin recording until they reach the scene, he added, and the drones do not record audio or use facial recognition technology. Members of the public can view details of drone responses within 24 hours of a deployment.
Cokinos said that the drone's live feeds have helped officers avoid at least one confrontation with an armed suspect. He argued that the use of the drone helped to de-escalate a response that "very well could have resulted in an officer-involved shooting."
While the drones aren't a replacement for police officers, Cokinos said, the department has responded to nearly 300 emergency calls with drones alone since November 2023. If there's no need for a police officer, he said, they don't dispatch one.
More widespread adoption of the technology by law enforcement agencies appears to be just over the horizon.
As the prices of drones fall, other law enforcement agencies across the state will likely be able to launch their own programs for far less than the roughly $773,000 the Montgomery County Department of Police spent last year. The FAA could offer a less costly waiver to fly surveillance drones over large areas, potentially enabling smaller departments to launch their own programs. The Prince George's County Police Department is currently considering whether to launch its own first responder drone program.
But civil libertarians say Maryland lawmakers should get ahead of that trend.
Jay Stanley, a senior policy analyst with the ACLU's Speech, Privacy and Technology Project, warned lawmakers against allowing the use of surveillance drones to proliferate without guardrails.
Law enforcement agencies have used drones in less sophisticated ways for years, Stanley said, but so-called "Drone as First Responder" programs raise a much larger range of privacy and transparency concerns for civil liberties groups.
"When there's a brand new technology that's controversial … government agencies tend to be on their best behavior," Stanley said. But as the technology becomes more ubiquitous and scrutiny subsides, he added, "We could see it expand to routine patrols to cover an entire city."
Stanley also underscored that other law enforcement agencies may not adopt Montgomery County's transparency mechanisms and privacy protections.
"[As] this technology spreads to other counties in Maryland, and perhaps someday all counties in Maryland, are they all going to have these same protections?" he asked.
Even Montgomery County's program, he added, may still evolve in ways lawmakers do not anticipate.
Grammer, the Republican lawmaker, shares Stanley's concerns.
"These marginal benefits — I don't think they outweigh the costs of, frankly, living in a society where the state's surveilling you 24/7 in 10 different ways," Grammer said.
After the Baltimore Police Department launched a controversial aerial surveillance program to capture images of nearly the entire city in 2019, Grammer introduced legislation to require law enforcement to obtain warrants before using aerial surveillance to gather evidence in criminal investigations. Despite reintroducing the bill each year, Grammar hasn't managed to pass it.
Grammer told Capital News Service he approached fellow lawmakers for signatures on the latest iteration of his bill ahead of last Wednesday's hearing.
"I'm talking with people in the committee on both sides of the aisle that are uneasy about how we didn't take this unmanned aerial surveillance (and) put guardrails there," he told CNS.
Though the General Assembly has yet to act on the subject, Stanley says Maryland may actually be ahead of other state legislatures by taking an interest in the Montgomery County program.
"I'm not aware of any other state legislatures that have begun to really think through the questions that the DFR programs bring forth," he said.
So far, legislation has yet to materialize in Maryland's General Assembly.

In an email to The Star Democrat, the district said the arrest did not take place at the school.
School and police officials say rumors of a parent being detained while dropping off a child at the elementary school are false.
Representatives of the Easton Police Department added that the arrest was made due to outstanding warrants for an individual in town and not as a result of any directive from the new presidential administration. As of Monday, the Talbot school district had not communicated with families regarding the rumors, though counseling and mental health support for students, families and staff has been made available. TCPS' Director of Communications Debbie Gardner said in an email that the district has reviewed its existing protocols around "actions or inquiries by law enforcement."
Last week, State Superintendent Carey Wright sent a letter to Maryland superintendents outlining the practices school employees should take if immigration authorities enter schools.
"If federal immigration officials or law enforcement enter a school building seeking access to students (for interviews and/or questioning), school personnel should contact the local superintendent immediately for guidance," Wright wrote on Jan. 23.
"School personnel should not argue or debate with immigration enforcement officials but should direct them to the local superintendent or designated administrator for further action," the letter read.
Wright's letter comes as Donald Trump's immigration initiatives have brought sweeping policy changes since the inauguration last Monday.
A directive last week from the Trump administration reversed a policy that established places such as schools, churches and shelters as "protected areas." That policy discouraged immigration enforcement agents from conducting arrests in those areas.
"Criminals will no longer be able to hide in America's schools and churches to avoid arrest," Department of Homeland Security spokesperson Benjamine Huffman stated. "The Trump Administration will not tie the hands of our brave law enforcement, and instead trusts them to use common sense."
In her letter, Wright said that if immigration officials request student records, local schools should consult with their attorneys.
"Personnel should immediately notify the student's parent or guardian if an immigration official or law enforcement officer requests or gains access to a student for immigration-enforcement purposes," Wright stated, "unless such access was following a judicial warrant or subpoena that restricts the disclosure of the information to the parent or guardian."
In a statement, Talbot County Public Schools said that superintendents across the state had a meeting with Wright, as well as the Maryland ICE director. The district is following guidance from the Maryland Department of Education on immigration enforcement actions.
Regarding the Easton arrest, a spokesperson for Enforcement and Removal Operations' Baltimore field office did not provide specific information on the arrest or if other arrests in the area have occurred in the past week. Enforcement and Removal Operations is a directorate of ICE.

title: Kent ham radio club tests emergency communications skills
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Kent ham radio club tests emergency communications skills

 January 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 557
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WORTON — As wildfire recovery begins in southern California and a lengthy reconstruction effort continues after Hurricane Helene devastated the Appalachian area, emergency preparation is getting attention.In Kent, that conversation and training is happening among amateur radio operators prepared for potential disasters on the Eastern Shore.
Starting at 3 p.m. Saturday, over 24 hours, the Kent Amateur Radio Society club set up satellite and radio equipment in the Kent County High School parking lot. Using emergency power from generators and solar panels, they communicated with 145 stations — 18 were amateur radio satellites.
With a refurbished school bus and a camper, they operated from five stations, classified as mobile, including the emergency trailer EMCOMM 1, which contained equipment from the school's ham radio classes taught by WKHS station manager Chris Singleton, a KARS member for 30 years.
EMCOMM 1 serves as backup when regular emergency dispatch fails.
This was part of the American Radio Relay League's Winter Field Day training exercise. Radio operators set up field operations in remote locations "with the aim to improve their preparedness for disasters, enhancing their operational abilities in adverse conditions."
For KARS members, ham radio is a lifelong passion, but disaster preparation remains the priority.
KARS President Chris Cote cited Hurricane Irma in September 2017, when 7.5 million homes lost electricity. Ham radio could become the only communication mode in such situations.
Inside Cote's bus, three stations operate off a 12-volt battery charging from a solar array — two radio with VHF/UHF capabilities and one satellite communications. They reached operators nationwide without external power all weekend.
The event reached young people when Singleton's KCHS broadcasting students operated the ham radio. Junior, Jordana Capp, in her second year of broadcasting, contacted Washington state over a Russian satellite connection.
Junior, Aidan Maxey, also in his second broadcasting year, made contact with New York. He plans to pursue media studies at Syracuse, impressed with ther program.
Senior, Alayna Brown, featured on Radio World's Jan. 1 cover, contacted Tennessee. Brown, already certified by the Society of Broadcast Engineers, was recently accepted to Belmont in Nashville, where she plans to work with multitrack recording systems, live stage and master tapes.
All three students became interested in ham radio certification after attending the ARRL School Round up on Oct. 21. Brown had communicated with Russia during that event.
Singleton celebrated his students' interest in this vital skill. He had worked for 15 years to engage youth in ham radio, noting that combining broadcasting skills, live audio, music production and SBE certification opens many career paths.
"They are amazed," Singleton said. "They don't get many opportunities to work with this very specialized equipment. It is a rare opportunity."
KARS members continue generating youth interest in ham radio by teaching them radio operating skills and attending the Winter Field Day Contest. They anticipate the ARRL School Club Roundup Contest Feb. 10-14 as well.
On Sunday, as Cote's drone photographed their stations, KARS member Bobby Kelley helped newest member Alberto Larotonda dismantle his homemade antenna built from a ski pole, copper pipes and a drywall mud bucket.
"My little setup just shows anybody can do this with enough imagination," said Larotonda, who joined two months ago.
Cote said while no one wants to think disasters like those in California or North Carolina will strike locally, testing equipment in harsh conditions benefits the county; ensuring first responders that it is battle-tested.
For more information about KARS, visit k3ars.org/kars/.

title: Hoarding turned deadly: Mother takes plea deal in Christmas Day 2023 fire that killed her daughter
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Hoarding turned deadly: Mother takes plea deal in Christmas Day 2023 fire that killed her daughter

 January 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 1125
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The mother of a 10-year-old girl who was killed in a townhouse fire near Elkton on Christmas Day 2023 is facing up to 10 years in prison, after accepting a plea deal in a criminal case in which prosecutors maintain that overloaded electrical outlets, hoarding conditions and a lack of smoke detectors contributed to the youngster's death.The defendant — Theresa Ann Moats, 41 — entered an Alford plea to involuntary manslaughter, the most serious charge in the case, on Jan. 24 during a Cecil County Circuit Court hearing.
In an Alford plea, the defendant maintains his or her innocence but, at the same time, he or she does not dispute the incriminating evidence possessed by the state.
Prosecutors agreed to drop 11 related charges against Moats, including reckless endangerment and neglect of a child, as part of the plea agreement reached by Assistant State's Attorney Gavin Patashnick and Moats' lawyers, Assistant Public Defenders Denise Winston and Emily Gillis.
Cecil County Circuit Court Judge William W. Davis Jr. accepted Moats' Alford plea and then, after Patashnick read aloud the prosecution's statement of facts, the judge found her guilty of involuntary manslaughter.
Also part of the plea deal, Davis will wait four months before sentencing Moats, who will remain on house arrest until then on an unsecured $50,000 bond posted in late May after she had spent approximately six weeks in jail on no bond.
Moats' daughter — Kyleigh Nicole Treadway — perished in the swift-moving, two-alarm blaze that started accidentally inside 317 Willow Dr. in the Winding Brook neighborhood, northeast of Elkton, shortly before 7:30 a.m. on Dec. 25, 2023.
Kyleigh, who had been sleeping in a second-floor bedroom, was trapped inside that burning townhouse after her mother, her grandmother, her two older brothers and her mother's boyfriend — Kevin Neal Summerfield, now 41 — had escaped.
As firefighters battled the blaze, Moats alerted Capt. William Ryan of Singerly Volunteer Fire Company that "her baby was right inside the front door." Firefighters tried to rescue Kyleigh, but the "magnitude and intensity of the fire" prevented them from entering the house. Kyleigh's body later was found near the front door.
Including Kyleigh's five surviving family members, the blaze displaced 17 residents in the three adjacent townhouses damaged by the fire.
In March, a Cecil County grand jury handed up indictments against Moats and Summerfield, charging them with involuntary manslaughter and numerous other offenses.
Summerfield's jury trial is set to start and Feb. 3 and is expected to last five days. Before taking the plea deal, Moats had been scheduled to tried along with Summerfield.
During her plea hearing on Friday, Moats stood behind the defense table and wiped tears from her eyes with tissue paper as Patashnick read aloud the prosecution's statement of fact.
The prosecutor reported that an "overload situation" existed in the dwelling's electrical system because multiple extension cords inside an 8'-by-8' first-floor addition at the rear of house had been connected to each other to bypass non-functioning outlets and to reach operational power sources. Court records show that cords were plugged into a power strip.
Along those lines, Patashnick noted that a freezer and refrigerator were plugged into electrical outlets that weren't designed to handle the power demand of such heavy-duty appliances.
One of the power cords drawing electricity from inside of the townhouse snaked out of the dwelling and was connected to a backyard grill, according to the prosecutor, who also reported that some cords ran behind appliances.
Exacerbating the overload situation, strewn clothing, trash and other combustible debris — including a coating of animal feces left by numerous pet dogs and cats — covered the electrical cords in the back room, according to the prosecutor.
Court records show that Moats admitted that as many as 35 pets — mostly dogs and cats — were kept inside the dwelling at one time.
The prosecutor told the judge that "an extensive amount of hoarding conditions" existed inside the 1,100-square-foot, two-story townhouse. He explained that boxes of clothing, bags of trash and other miscellaneous items cluttered the dwelling.
In addition to making it difficult to walk out of the townhouse or anywhere inside of the dwelling, the hoarding conditions worsened an already existing fire hazard created by the improper use of electrical cords and outlets.
The trash, pet feces, clothing and other combustible items "increased the magnitude and intensity of the fire" caused by the electrical overload, according to Patashnick.
Also a factor, the townhouse lacked smoke detectors.
The prosecutor reported that autopsy results indicated that Kyleigh had 0.3 grams of an antidepressant that aids sleep in her system and that her death was attributed to smoke inhalation and burns over 90 percent of her body.
Patashnick summarized that the involuntary manslaughter charge against Moats hinges on her neglect of the townhouse and of Kyleigh.
Court records indicate that two Cecil County Department of Animal Services officers went to 317 Willow Dr. on Dec. 20, 2023 — five days before the fatal fire there — and impounded 14 dogs and four cats that showed signs of neglect and abuse after receiving a complaint.
Officers heard "excessive barking" when they knocked on the door and, once inside the dwelling, they "detected the smell of animal urine and feces" and noticed that a vast majority of the floor was covered in caked animal waste, court records show.
After impounding the 18 animals, officers, "planned to make a report to Child Protective Services, as the children in the home were subjected to poor living conditions," according to court records.
Administrators at Cecil Manor Elementary School in Elk Mills, where Kyleigh was a fourth-grader, also noticed signs of possible neglect and made referrals to the Cecil County Department of Social Services after Kyleigh moved with her family from Delaware and started attending that school, court records show.
Those school officials reported to investigators that Kyleigh's hair and clothes emanated the smell of animal waste and that fellow students avoided the girl because of the pungent odor, according to court records.
The school nurse routinely washed Kyleigh's clothes and washed and brushed the girl's unkempt hair, investigators said. Staff members replaced Kyleigh's backpack twice because cats at her residence urinated and vomited on top of her previous backpacks, investigators added.
"Kyleigh's hygiene issues were described as 'terrible' and they needed to be addressed 3-4 times per day. Kyleigh stated to teachers that she had a 'ton' of pets and that she loved them," court records show.
School staff attempted to contact Moats by email and by phone, but there was "absolutely no involvement to address concern brought forth by the school," according to court records.
Court records also indicate that, in the wake of townhouse fire, Moats told investigators that "this all could have been preventable," and that she "felt bad and felt it was her fault."
In addition, according to those court records, Moats told investigators that she missed Kyleigh.
