title: Leaving a timeless mark: Remembering lives lost with roadside memorials
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
Leaving a timeless mark: Remembering lives lost with roadside memorials

 February 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 1814
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As one drives along Route 210 through Bryans Road in the area of Livingston Road a metal cross can be seen by anyone with an observant eye. It helps to know it's there if you are looking for it, but if you approach it on foot via sidewalk you can better observe its simplicity.The name "Tiffani" in big capital letters using a decorative font is in the middle of the cross, at the top is a red flower and at the bottom is the insignia for the Bryans Road Volunteer Fire Department and Rescue Squad.
According to Deborah Carrington-Smith, the cross commemorates the life of her daughter, Tiffani Carrington, who was killed near the Indian Head Highway intersection on Dec. 21, 1996.
"She was 19 years old," Carrington-Smith told Southern Maryland News. "Her car, a 1987 Nissan 300ZX, was broadsided by a Charles County sheriff's officer."
The deputy driving the sheriff's office patrol car was responding to a call. Tiffani Carrington, according to information posted by the U.S. National Emergency Medical Service Memorial Service, had logged a lot of volunteer hours with the Bryans Road company.
At the time she was killed, Tiffani Carrington was pursuing a career as a Maryland State Police trooper paramedic.
"This is who Tiffani was to our family," her mother said. "She was a child full of spunk, a teenager wise beyond her years and an EMT with aspirations of becoming a flight paramedic. She was a cheerleader, a softball player, a coach and a mentor to other youth. She was the apple of her father's eye and a bit bossy with her younger brothers. She had so much love to give and was never stingy with her affection."
In 1998, the national EMS memorial service honored Tiffani Carrington, declaring her death was in the line of duty.
Carrington-Smith is quoted in the organization's citation saying that her daughter took the career path toward becoming a paramedic "after she saw a lady collapse from a seizure."
Tiffani Carrington, her mother said, was frustrated that she didn't have the expertise to aid the stricken woman. That led to her career path decision.
Carrington-Smith said that over six months after the tragic death, her daughter posthumously earned her flight paramedic wings.
"She spoke her mind unabashedly, valuing authenticity, honesty and courage," Carrington-Smith said of Tiffani. "Material things were not important to her and she judged people by how they treated others."
Marking the spot of a memorialFor those wishing to have a marking to remember a loved one lost in a road tragedy, the rules in Maryland can be ambiguous.
"State Highway Administration does not track memorials that are placed along state highways in memory of crash victims," SHA spokesman Daniel Allman told Southern Maryland News. "However, state law prohibits the unauthorized placement of anything along state highways that are not approved, highway safety-related signs or devices. The placement of roadside memorials could pose safety and maintenance concerns for motorists, pedestrians and highway workers."
A website called "Roadside Tribute" notes in Maryland, the state highway administration "must comply with the law and has an obligation to motorists to keep roads safe, which includes removing distractions and illegal items from state right-of-way. When doing so, crews keep any intact roadside memorials at the nearest shop to be reclaimed within two weeks. If the owners of the memorials are known, SHA tries to contact them."
Those rules don't stop people from placing memorials, though, as evidenced by the many memorials large and small along the region's roadways.
The state website further noted that there are other options in Maryland that can be used to pay tribute to a loved one lost in a road tragedy. Those options include the Adopt-a-Highway program and Partnership Plantings. In some cases, plantings along the highway are done in honor of someone and can be noted with a sign.
Remembered with flowersNearly 18 years after Tiffani Carrington's death, Charles County lost another volunteer responder in a road crash. Autumn Jenkins was 20 years old when her life was claimed in a collision that occurred April 28, 2015, on Route 424 in the area of Tim's Place in Nanjemoy.
Katelyn Shannon remembered her cousin Autumn Jenkins as a consummate volunteer, someone whose passion was to help people and animals. She had worked at the Charles County Humane Society as a technician and was also a manager at a Waldorf swimming pool.
According to a July 2016 Maryland Independent article on the sentencing of the other driver, an Indian Head man in his early 20s, police investigating the crash said the Chevrolet Silverado the at-fault driver was operating crossed the center line and crashed into the Kia Soul that Jenkins was driving.
Crews desperately worked to free her from the wreckage, but Jenkins was pronounced dead at the scene. The driver of the truck, court testimony stated, registered a 0.14 blood alcohol level. He was sentenced to 10 years with all but three years suspended.
Shannon said the memorial to her cousin "sits in front of a telephone pole. We have a stone that was engraved with a drawing of a dog and the fire shield. We also have her helmet shield up and we actively put flowers and solar lights. We actively attend DUI checkpoints conducted by the La Plata Police Department in memory of her."
The Maryland Independent story on the sentencing mentioned that when the defendant's mother made her plea for clemency to the judge, she mentioned that her son went back to the crash site on the anniversary of Jenkins' death and left flowers.
Memories of a 'bright and positive person'Jonna Jones of Lusby remembers her friend, Lauren Pitt, as someone who loved people and life.
"Her enthusiasm for people made me feel like I could do anything," Jones said. "Such a bright, positive person. We lost a bright light when she passed."
Pitt, who lived in St. Mary's County's Hollywood, was 27 when she was killed Sept. 3, 2015, while riding as a passenger on a motorcycle. The operator of the Harley Davidson, Conrado "Chico" Fabricante Jr., 55, of Broomes Island, also died in the crash at the Route 2/4 and Rousby Hall Road intersection in Lusby.
"This year it will be 10 years, that's hard to believe," Jones said.
Fabricante, the father of three, had worked at Calvert Cliffs Nuclear Power Plant for over 30 years. His obituary posted by Rausch Funeral Home said he was an avid motorcyclist and a member of Hells Angels, "who were his second family."
At the time of her death, Pitt was employed at Calvert Orthopedic of Southern Maryland as a radiology technician and part-time by MedStar St. Mary's Hospital.
According to her obituary, Pitt was a 2006 graduate of Leonardtown High, where she played clarinet in the school jazz band. Jones recalled Pitt was in the process of learning to play the mandolin in 2015.
The markers memorializing Pitt and Fabricante — two wooden crosses with their first names — are placed in front of the guardrail on southbound Route 2/4 near the Rousby Hall Road intersection.
Several months after the collision occurred, the Calvert County Sheriff's Office announced that the incident was nobody's fault and no blame would be placed nor charges filed.
Jones said she has never stopped to visit the roadside memorial but has visited Pitt's gravesite in Leonardtown.
"I have done things in her honor," Jones said.
One of the events Jones dedicated to her friend's memory was a half-marathon she trained for and ran in 2016.
"It helped me keep going," Jones said of the 13-mile dash and the inspiration of her late friend. "I finished it with a smile on my face."
'Unknown reasons'It was on a Monday morning, the first day of October 2018, that 24-year-old David Joseph Johnson of Ridge lost his life when his small sedan traveling south of Lexington Park went off Route 235, up a steep embankment, struck a tree and flipped over on its roof.
The Leonardtown High grad was employed as a welder at the time of his passing.
A release from the St. Mary's County Sheriff's Office stated that Johnson's vehicle went out of control "for unknown reasons," before it went off the road and subsequently crashed.
"There's only one person that knows, and that person can't tell us," then-Captain Steve Hall, the county's current sheriff, told The Enterprise the day after the fatality. "There's never any logical explanation."
An array of flowers surrounding a cross with the name "Joseph" in capital letters marks the location of the fatality on Three Notch Road just north of a local bus and car repair shop.
'A gifted swimmer'He was born in a Siberian city in July 1998 and eight months later was adopted by David and Kandia Spain, who brought him to their home in Huntingtown. Zachary David Igor "Zack" Spain attended Plum Point Elementary, Plum Point Middle and Huntingtown High, graduating in 2016.
While he played soccer during his elementary and middle school years, Zack Spain's true passion was swimming, which he did competitively starting at age 5.
"He was a gifted swimmer and swam club team, summer league and for his high school," Kandia Spain told Southern Maryland News. "He was a kind and caring brother, son and friend."
His plan was to study political science with the goal of working for an environmental protection group.
On Thanksgiving Day 2020 — Nov. 26 — Zack Spain was operating a vehicle on Wilson Road in Prince Frederick. He was the lone occupant of the car. According to the Calvert sheriff's office, the vehicle left the road and crashed into two utility poles. Zack Spain was declared dead at the scene. He was 22.
"I keep flowers all year round attached to the utility pole," Kandia Spain told Southern Maryland News.
Remembering 'Lil Bro'It's hard to spot, but somewhere in a sparsely wooded area near the Route 5 and Chingville Road intersection of St. Mary's County a small white cross that had been staked into the earth lays on the ground. Almost one year ago, a horrific, single-vehicle crash occurred there, injuring three — the adult female driver and two small children — and killing a male juvenile who had recently celebrated his 8th birthday.
Brysen McKinley Carter had been a football player for the Pax River Raiders team.
According to the St. Mary's sheriff's office, the three juvenile occupants, including Brysen, "were found to not be correctly restrained."
Brysen was taken to MedStar St. Mary's Hospital and was later pronounced dead.
The crash occurred on March 16, 2024, and more than seven months later the driver, Ashley Nicole Nolan, now 28, of Lexington Park, was served an 18-count indictment, which includes four felony charges for negligent manslaughter and homicide with a motor vehicle while impaired, according to court records. A circuit court jury trial is currently scheduled for early April.
A GoFundMe page in Brysen Carter's honor raised over $19,000 before organizers stopped accepting donations. The Pax River Raiders contributed $500 to the fund.
On a tribute page posted by Briscoe-Tonic Funeral Home, one of Brysen's friends wrote, "I miss you every day, Lil Bro." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Former councilmember Engle leads way in creating Easton's new highway safety plan
author: Konner Metz
content:
Former councilmember Engle leads way in creating Easton's new highway safety plan

 February 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 611
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Ron Engle has a robust resume of public service.The former National Highway Traffic Safety Administration senior manager and Virginia police officer developed an extensive portfolio in traffic policy and management over more than three decades.
Following retirement, Engle remained busy, serving on many local boards in Talbot County and winning a seat on the Easton Town Council in 2015.
So when Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey asked Engle in 2023 if he would give the town a hand in creating a Strategic Highway Safety Plan, it was a no-brainer.
"The chief grabbed me and said, 'I need help getting grants,'" Engle recalled. "And he said, 'And I know you know how to do it.'"
Though he lost his council seat two years ago, Engle has spearheaded the creation of a traffic safety plan for Easton during the last year.
Approved by the Town Council earlier this month, Easton's new Strategic Highway Safety Plan is expected to bring significant funding opportunities to the town for its transportation and safety efforts, town officials say.
It is 72 pages in length, detailing strategies and action plans for Easton to address vehicular, bicycle and pedestrian safety issues as the town grows. Not every city or town in the state has adopted a strategic plan aligning with the state's vision, Engle noted.
"My gut feeling is that with so few of these programs, we can do pretty well," he said.
The plan goes hand-in-hand with Maryland's Vision Zero law that was established in 2019, which aims to eliminate all vehicle-related deaths by 2030. Traditional approaches to highway safety assume crashes and injuries are inevitable, but Vision Zero lays out that traffic systems can accommodate for human error.
"What I mainly focused on was speeding, distracted driving, impaired driving, bicycling and pedestrians," Engle said, as well as sections dedicated to Route 50 safety and mature drivers, given Talbot County's older population.
In order to lay the groundwork, town leaders worked with Washington College's Geographic Information Systems Program to compile accident data dating back to 2018, culminating in the release of an interactive traffic dashboard.
While Easton doesn't have traffic fatalities often, the numbers depict problem areas in town where the most crashes occurred from 2018-2023, such as Dover Road and Aurora Street.
Engle said the data, combined with sleek and easy-to-read graphic designs and charts made by the town's communications specialist, Greg Mueller, helped the strategic plan come to life.
"It wasn't until I got the data," Engle said. "I would have never thought Dover Street had the most crashes. It just wouldn't occur to me."
Town Engineer Rick Van Emburgh, one of the plan's main contributors, said it all boils down to making Easton safer. Clear deadlines for goals and improvements will keep the town's progress timely, he said.
"It will hold us accountable," Van Emburgh said.
Lowrey says the Strategic Highway Safety Plan is just one step in Easton's efforts to better safety for residents using all modes of transportation.
"It's an important first step, but it's part of a bigger process that the mayor's undertaking to help us address Easton as it is right now and how it will be in the future," Lowrey said.
Engle, who says he's "fascinated" by public service, has been inspired not just by his traffic safety background, but by local organizations and residents, too.
It's part of the reason he's continued to dedicate hours upon hours of his time to creating a better and safer Easton.
"It's a big bite for the town, because there's a lot of things in here they need to (do that) they may not have the money or may not have the resources (for)," Engle said of the highway safety plan. "But everything in here is something we should do."

 CAMBRIDGE — A Cambridge man has been sentenced to incarceration after being found guilty of charges that stem from an incident with his infant in April 2023.On Feb. 21, Marcus Peak, 28, was sentenced to 28 years of incarceration, with all but 15 of those years suspended, in the Dorchester County Circuit Court. Peak was also sentenced to serve five years of probation with the condition that he not have any unsupervised contact with minors.
In December, Dorchester County Circuit Court Judge William Jones found Peak guilty of of first- and second-degree assault, first- and second-degree child abuse, neglect of a minor and reckless endangerment.
The charges against Peak stem from an incident on April 21, 2023, when Cambridge Police officers responded to assist Dorchester County Emergency Medical Services with an infant who was unconscious and not breathing. EMS treated the infant and transported her to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Cambridge. The baby was then transported to Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore.
According to police, Peak told detectives he had just fed his daughter a bottle and placed her in a bassinet for a nap. He said the baby was asleep.
Peak said that when he returned to check on her later, he noticed the baby's head was tilted to the side with fluid coming from her nose and mouth. He said the baby's eyes were partially opened.
At that time, Peak denied any traumatic event that could have caused injury to his daughter.
Detectives were told Peak had lied and did not inform them the baby had fallen to the floor, striking her head. Peak allegedly then picked the baby up and shook her to wake her up, according to a report from the Cambridge Police Department.
During the trial in December, Dr. Eric Klotz, an emergency medicine physician who treated the child that day, said the child's injuries were consistent with a high mechanism of injury. He said it was one of the more severe head injuries he's seen in his career.
Dr. Joseph Scheller, a pediatric neurologist who was asked by Peak's defense to testify, said it is possible the child's injuries were caused by an accidental fall. He said short falls can sometimes cause serious injury.
According to Maryland court documents, Dorchester County Assistant Public Defender Michelle Moodispaw filed a notice to appeal the case on Tuesday.

title: Common sense degrees needed
author: Staff Writer
content:
Common sense degrees needed

 March 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 391
 Words 

 Read News Document

 This past weekend, I was enjoying my morning tea when I got a curious phone call. The gentleman knew me by my nickname, and I quickly became a good listener. Trying to place the voice it took me a few minutes to realize who it was a long-time multigenerational family friend. Let's call him Mike. I would later reflect on what an honor it was for me.For the better part of an hour, he regaled me with stories of yesteryear (none, surprisingly, set in the famed bygone watering hole of that name), featuring my father, grandfather and great-grandfather. My eyes swelled as he began to bring the good old days back to life, first in black and white, then in color. Some stories I had had a taste of, but most were new to me. What gentlemen they were.
I share that story to preface this one. While enjoying the company of "The Thursday Brotherhood" the topic of today's social climate came up. All of our comments were true and valid in their own way; I can only imagine that each generation feels the same, that in any moment in history, there are good times and not-so-good times.
The conversation brought back memories of my great-grandfather Walter Wood; he was the chief of police for then little old Easton. He called it "my town," and used his platform to serve with understanding as only he could. One quality of old Walter I heard about more than a few times was his sensible approach to life. My dad called it his C.S. (common sense) degree.
As it goes, he would leave home after supper, head to the firehouse, and open the door to the locals who needed shelter for the night. Today, we call them homeless. He would lock the door and call it a night. In the morning, the routine played out in reverse. What a novel solution.
Today, we share the same challenges as our predecessors, updated for the 21st century. How we approach them and resolve them is up to us, let's call it perspective. Sometimes what is old is what's new again. Having a bit more compassion and understanding for our neighbors can't be all wrong. Just maybe if we all use our C.S. degrees a bit more, we can all wake up and go to sleep with a smile.
ROO WOOD
Wittman

 Delaware court documents released Tuesday shed new light on how a Kirk Middle School teacher allegedly spent months grooming one of his students by sending her sexual messages and fantasies through an online chat application.Ultimately, the inappropriate behavior expanded to school grounds, where David DiFilippo would spend time alone with the 13-year-old girl in his classroom, making sexual comments to her and, on one occasion, touching her legs, court records allege.
DiFilippo's actions "are clearly and reasonably indicative of an adult grooming and enticing a minor for the purpose of sexual contact and/or a sexual experience," Detective Marc Conway, of the Delaware State Police, wrote in court documents, adding that DiFilippo was trying to build up trust with the girl to "ultimately entice and arouse her sexually."
DiFilippo's alleged behavior took place between September 2023 and February 2024, when DiFilippo was 43 and 44 years old.
During that six-month period, DiFilippo and the girl chatted nearly every day over Discord, a messaging app. The messages were "flirtatious and sexual in nature," and DiFilippo suggested sexual acts with the girl, made comments about her body and clothing and referred to her as "babe" and "baby," court records show.
He sent her several stories detailing explicit sexual fantasies involving her engaging in sexual intercourse, masturbation and oral sex. He would then ask the girl "if the writings were good enough that she could picture them in her mind and if reading them made her feel a certain way," court documents allege.
One story involved a teacher and a student having sexual relations on a school bus during a field trip, and DiFilippo then told the girl he was planing a field trip and asked if she would like to sit with him on the bus, court records indicate.
DiFilippo would delete the messages after the girl read them, but she kept screenshots of the messages on her phone.
DiFilippo's behavior eventually extended into in-person encounters, and he would allow the girl to skip class to hang out with him alone in his classroom during his planning period when he did not have a class to teach. Other times, she would stay in his classroom after class ended and the other students left.
On one occasion, DiFilippo told the girl he liked her "milky white thighs" and said seeing them made him feel "like an animal ready to attack his prey," court documents allege. Another time, he suggested they go into a closet to kiss, but the girl refused. On a different day, the girl brought DiFilippo an assortment of snack food and asked him which he liked best, to which he replied he liked "the snack in the dress," presumably referring to her.
Court records describe one incident in which DiFilippo's behavior turned physical. The girl was sitting on a counter near his desk, and DiFilippo allegedly knelt down and rubbed her legs. The girl told him to stop, which he did.
It's not clear why DiFilippo's behavior ended in February 2024. Court records indicate that the girl told her therapist about it in August 2024, sparking a police investigation.
The girl provided police with screenshots of DiFilippo's Discord messages, and detectives later subpoenaed Discord for a transcript of the messages sent from his account. Investigators interviewed the girl with help from the Child Advocacy Center in Wilmington.
DiFilippo turned himself in to police in February after the months-long investigation.
He was charged with sexual solicitation of a child, enticement for purposes of sexual conduct, dangerous crime against a minor, promoting sexual solicitation of a child, providing obscenity material to a child, sexual abuse of a child by a person of trust and offensive touching. He was released after posting $65,500 secured bond.
Police asked anyone with information or who may be a victim to contact Conway at 302-365-8411.
According to a brief biography posted on Kirk's website, DiFilippo taught in the gifted and talented program and has been a teacher for approximately 15 years. He wrote that his favorite part of the job is "forming strong bonds and relationships with my students."
A spokesperson for the Christina School District did not respond to a request for comment.

title: A jury of their peers: Talbot County Teen Court gives youth offenders, volunteers room to learn
author: Konner Metz
content:
A jury of their peers: Talbot County Teen Court gives youth offenders, volunteers room to learn

 March 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 936
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Inside the Bradley Meeting Room of the Talbot County Courthouse, high schoolers bring court into session.It's not mock trial, but instead, a program called Talbot Teen Court. First-time youth misdemeanor offenders of crimes such as second-degree assault or possession of cannabis stand before a jury of their peers awaiting a disposition.
Teen Court is a restorative justice pathway for youth offenders as much as it is a volunteer opportunity for students interested in the judicial process, organizers say.
"Kids can get a really bad rap these days. The kids that we have are amazing," Teen Court Coordinator Kelley Callaghan said. "They are passionate about it, they are prepared, they are super into it."
Around once every month, student volunteers handle three cases, agreeing on sanctions for the offender such as community service or conflict management. Students assume the roles of attorneys, bailiffs, clerks, jurors and judges, all taking an oath of confidentiality.
The program is an alternative to going to the Department of Juvenile Services for youth offenders ages 13 through 17. Offenders, called "respondents," must admit involvement in the crime and follow through with their sanctions.
Callaghan says the aspect of guilt or innocence isn't the program's focus, but rather affording respondents a chance for a "clean slate."
"By the time they come to us, this is kind of a pivotal moment for a lot of them," Callaghan said. "You could go this way or you could go this way. We're going to give you every resource possibly to help you get back on track."
Teen Court volunteer Allegra West, a senior at Chesapeake Christian School, believes the program helps youth offenders feel like they're being heard.
"At this level, I think that everybody deserves some forgiveness," West said. "And it's harder for us when we hear things from adults, because we maybe feel like they don't necessarily appeal to us or understand our struggles and our problems."
'REAL GAME-CHANGER'
Last month, Easton High School senior Skylar Blades sat in the courthouse diligently preparing notes to be the defense attorney for the night's first case. Across from her was Easton High junior Matthew Bravo, the prosecutor.
Blades and Bravo both were respondents in the Teen Court program at one point in time. Now, they're committed volunteers who enjoy learning about law and helping their peers.
Callaghan said respondent-to-volunteer turnarounds illustrate that Teen Court is succeeding. And students like Bravo notice it as well.
"It was a real game-changer because when I was the defendant, it was like, 'This is what it's like to be on the other side,'" Bravo said.
Blades said she knows the nerves that respondents experience, part of the reason she now enjoys talking to respondents and making sure they feel at ease.
For Blades, she sees a future in therapy, a career she thinks her Teen Court experience will help with. Other volunteers like Bravo and Easton High freshman Rhys Campbell want to pursue law, making the program a perfect fit.
"Ever since the seventh grade, I really wanted to be a lawyer," said Campbell, who was the defense attorney for a case later that night. "I bought the textbooks and everything."
Thirteen student volunteers sat in the courthouse room on Feb. 26, catching up with one another despite age and grade differences and being enrolled at different schools.
Teen Court has become a mini-community of its own, as well as a school club at Easton High.
"There are some people that are nervous just because it's their first time being here," Blades said, "but we all try to make each other feel comfortable."
LONG HISTORY
Teen Court has been a pillar of the community since 1999, when then-Spotlight on Schools probation officer Cory Fink organized Talbot County Teen Court's inception and its first hearings.
Fink, now chief operating officer at the Maryland Department of Juvenile Services, stayed involved until 2006. But in the last decade, he's watched Teen Court persist and evolve.
His daughter Caroline Fink, a sophomore at Easton High, began volunteering this school year as a juror and a clerk.
"I like dealing with their punishments because I like that they can understand what they did is wrong," Caroline Fink said. "And it's not serious punishment, but it's enough for them to know that they shouldn't do it again."
"The fact that Talbot County was the first one (on the Eastern Shore) and it's still here — it's weathered the storms of budget, of personnel changes, of oversight and lead agency changes," Cory Fink said.
In 2021, the Talbot County Sheriff's Office took Teen Court under its wing, providing the main chunk of funding needed to save the program after the previous agency closed. Maj. Steve Elliott leads the Sheriff's Office efforts.
As the decades have passed, typical youth crimes have changed. Elliott noted that right now, the busy time for Teen Court is during the school year. Fights and cannabis use are two of the leading referrals.
While the most common offenses have changed over time, Elliott and Fink both say that youth still deserve the same room to learn as kids of years past.
"You can't demonize a kid because he makes one mistake," Elliott said. "And that's kind of what society has gone to."
"Kids are still kids," Fink said. "Kids still make impulsive decisions. Kids don't necessarily think about the consequences of their actions given their brain development."
Callaghan, the program coordinator, said it's impressive seeing the commitment from community and law enforcement partners to divert kids from the juvenile system and make a real difference in their lives.
Elliott says as long as the program is helping someone, it has a place in Talbot County.
"If you change the path of one kid, it's 100% worth it," he said.
This story has been updated.

title: A man of action
author: Staff Writer
content:
A man of action

 March 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 539
 Words 

 Read News Document

 You look at so many things in life that you hope you never see and wonder why no one seems to do anything about it. But then I remember Frank Gunsallus and how one person can truly make a difference. He's a fellow Easton Rotarian and friend, and all of us can learn a lot from him about courage, integrity, action and service to others.Heroes come along rarely, but when Frank Gunsallus and his wife, Iryna, traveled to Ukraine to get her parents out of the country at the beginning of the war there, he became one in short order. Instead of running home, the whole family stayed in Warsaw, Poland, to help Ukrainian refugees in Poland and Ukrainians stuck at home and facing the horrors of a merciless, dreadful war.
Frank secured three ambulances to save lives at the front. He made sure a mental health facility was secured in Warsaw to accommodate refugees who had seen and experienced far too much. Working with Rotary Clubs in Poland and Ukraine and with Disaster Aid USA, he delivered tents, water purification systems, lights, cell phone chargers and much-needed food and supplies to where they were needed most.
He delivered teddy bears made in our own Rotary District to refugee children, and they worked magic. He guided Rotarians from all over the world to refugee camps so they, too, could help.
Last fall, when Hurricane Helene slammed its way through the South, as a Rotary and community leader, Frank could not just sit comfortably at home here in Easton. He wrote:
"In the wake of Hurricane Helene, I felt a deep sense of responsibility to step up and offer help to our fellow countrymen in need during such a challenging time. Perhaps it was the summers I spent in those North Carolina hills as a child, visiting my grandparents, or the deep connection my family has to that land that stirred something within me. Or maybe it was simply the empathy I feel for others in times of crisis. After seeing heartbreaking videos of people suffering on social media, I knew I had to act."
With Rotary's help, he quickly gathered supplies and money and headed to Asheville, North Carolina. He witnessed incredible devastation and not only delivered the supplies where they were needed most, but also pitched in and helped those in need. By doing so, he discovered that many hurricane victims could not be reached because of the severe, unimaginable destruction. Exhausted, but determined, he returned to Easton and procured an ATV that could break into those unreachable areas.
He then went right back to North Carolina with the ATV and delivered it to emergency personnel who could immediately put it to work.
Like the firefighters and police who ran into—and not away from— the World Trade Center on 9/11, Frank Gunsallus ran into the teeth of trouble in Europe and in North Carolina. He is a true hero and public servant and sets a very high standard for the rest of us to follow. Frank will soon be the president of the Rotary Club of Easton and is the very definition of Rotary International's motto of "Service above Self" and its members' proven track record of being "People of Action."
GEORGE A. HATCHER JR.

Man charged with impersonating police officer, falsifying records in Easton PD application

 EASTON — Police arrested a man Wednesday for allegedly impersonating a police officer and falsifying a number of documents in his application to join the Easton Police Department.Richard Browning, 30, of Fairfax, Virginia, was arrested by Easton police after allegedly falsifying military and law enforcement documents and his social security information.
Browning faces 23 total charges, the first 15 of which include perjury, forgery, impersonating a police officer, destroying public records and making false statements to police officers.
Following his arrest March 5, authorities searched Browning's vehicle and found a loaded handgun and a U.S. Marshals Service badge, according to court documents. He was later charged with eight additional counts, including illegal possession of a firearm and loaded handgun in a vehicle, among others.
Court documents state that Browning sent an application to the Easton Police Department Feb. 4. During applicant testing and extensive background investigations that followed, police found discrepancies in Browning's documents and application.
Lt. Milton Orellana, special operations commander for the Easton Police Department, received Browning's initial application and worked the investigation.
"I've been doing background investigations for 21 years, and never seen this before," Orellana told The Star Democrat.
Per court documents, Browning falsified documents claiming he had prior employment with the U.S. Marshals Service and U.S. Capitol Police.
Browning had a warrant out for his arrest in Florida on charges of larceny and grand theft, court records state, as well as criminal history in Texas and Washington, D.C.
During the interview process, Browning was "well-spoken, poised, and respectful" and did not struggle to answer questions, according to court records.
After a lengthy investigation, police brought Browning to the department Wednesday and arrested him. The 30-year-old admitted to the falsified documents and said he was in a "bad place in his life," per court records.
"Browning stated that he got the documents from a guy but would not identify the person," charging documents read. "Browning stated that he didn't want to talk anymore … ."
Police determined that the handgun found in Browning's vehicle was illegally carried. Browning was taken to the Talbot County Detention Center following his arrest. He's being held without bond for the initial 15 charges and held on $10,000 bond for the subsequent eight charges.
Orellana said it was a unique investigation, "especially since (Browning) presented all these documents to a law enforcement agency."
"We do a pretty intense and thorough background investigation," Orellana said. "We're going to catch something if it's fictitious."

title: On NTSB recommendations, FAA closes helicopter route near DC airport weeks after tragedy
author: MENNATALLA IBRAHIM Capital News Service
content:
On NTSB recommendations, FAA closes helicopter route near DC airport weeks after tragedy

 March 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MENNATALLA IBRAHIM Capital News Service | Section: News 
 
 601
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — The National Transportation Safety Board issued urgent safety recommendations Tuesday, warning that helicopter flights near the Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport pose serious safety risks and one helicopter route should be closed during airport operations.Hours later, Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy accepted the recommendations on behalf of the Federal Aviation Administration, promising long-term changes.
"Urgent recommendations require immediate action to prevent similar accidents or incidents when we issue them," NTSB Chair Jennifer Homendy said at an NTSB media briefing Tuesday. "We believe a critical safety issue must be addressed without delay."
The recommendations were released alongside a preliminary investigative report on the Jan. 29 midair collision of an American Airlines jetliner and a military helicopter near Reagan National that killed 67 people.
The NTSB urged the FAA to ban helicopters from a four-mile stretch over the Potomac River when airport runway 15/33 is in use and to designate an alternative route when the area is closed, according to the published recommendations. The American jet was on final approach to runway 15/33 when the collision occurred.
Homendy said that there were warning signs before the January collision, citing data detailing more than 15,000 near-collisions between commercial aircraft and helicopters at Reagan National between October 2021 and December 2024. The majority occurred during plane landings and at night, according to the NTSB's report.
"We're in a situation where we're threading the needle, allowing helicopters to fly down the same airspace as landing aircraft," Duffy said. "And why this information wasn't studied and known before January 29 is an important question."
Following the crash, Duffy restricted helicopter traffic around the airport through the end of March. He said those restrictions will continue in accordance with NTSB recommendations. Duffy said he also spoke with Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth about alternative military flight routes, with exceptions for presidential travel, life-saving operations and law enforcement.
The preliminary report does not identify any probable causes of the collision, as the NTSB is still in "the fact-finding phase" of its investigation, according to Homendy.
"We still have a lot of work to do in this investigation, so the report contains only the facts that we're able to validate and release at this time," Homendy said. "The easiest and quickest part of the investigation is determining what happened. The part that takes longer is the how and why."
Tuesday's NTSB media briefing was the fifth of its kind since the collision.
At a Feb. 14 briefing, Homendy told reporters that investigators believe that the helicopter crew was wearing night vision goggles that would have limited their peripheral vision. She also said that cockpit conversations suggest that the helicopter crew may not have heard key instructions from air traffic controllers and had inaccurate altitude readings in the moments before the crash.
Duffy criticized the air traffic control system as outdated, relying on 25- to 30-year-old technology, including floppy disks and plug-in headphones, at a separate press conference Tuesday. He pledged to propose a plan in the coming weeks that would revolutionize the "antiquated" technology, seeking congressional approval and funding.
"We're at a point where we can do this fast—three and a half to four years for a brand new air traffic control system. Gold plated. Envy of the world," he said. "It will greatly improve our safety…but it's also going to improve the efficiency that we have in American air travel, which I think will mean less delays, less cancellations, and again, better safety."
Despite concerns, Homendy reassured travelers.
"I just flew with my daughter out of DCA…aviation is incredibly safe," she said. "However, there are safety issues and areas where we need to improve to make sure that we are at zero."

title: Lawmakers battle between cracking down and easing up on prison sentences
author: SASHA ALLEN Capital News Service
content:
Lawmakers battle between cracking down and easing up on prison sentences

 March 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SASHA ALLEN Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 745
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Lawmakers are taking a hard look at prison sentences in Maryland this spring, but from two dramatically different points of view.One measure under consideration would help offenders reduce their sentences for demonstrating good behavior. The other would crack down on violent offenders seeking time off their sentences.
Democrat Del. Cheryl Pasteur is sponsoring the Maryland Second Look Act, which would allow offenders showcasing good behavior to petition the courts for time off after serving at least 20 years.
"They have done every single thing possible to be better folks, better than a lot of the folks that I work with here," Pasteur, who represents Baltimore County said, referring to incarcerated people who demonstrate good behavior. "When do we ever have to spend 20 years to be vetted? Never."
But Republican Sen. William Folden is the sponsor for Real Time for Violent Crimes, a bill that would restrict or prohibit violent offenders from receiving diminution credits, or time off due to good behavior. He disagrees with Pasteur.
"If you commit a violent crime and you prey on our communities, and you're that two percenters that are the worst of the worst, then you should get real time and not allow it to be watered down through dim credits and things of that," said Folden, who represents Frederick County.
Hearings for both bills have elicited contentious and emotional testimony, both from families of murder victims and from formerly incarcerated individuals. But after both bills died during last year's legislative session, proponents of each bill are pushing yet again for passage.
Supporters and opponents alike for the Real Time for Real Crimes Act gathered at a Tuesday bill hearing to provide their testimony. Kurt Wolfgang, the executive director of the Maryland Crime Victims Resource Center, said this bill is "long overdue."
"There are so many ways to already diminish a sentence in Maryland," Wolfgang said. "This is just one more hole in the bucket that needs to be plugged up by taking away or diminishing the use of diminution credits to release violent offenders."
Despite his efforts, Folden told CNS that there isn't a "big appetite" for his bill.
Still, there was some opposition to the Maryland Second Look Act in a nearly three-hour long hearing in February, with some detailing emotional stories of their loved ones who are victims of violence.
Theresa Darvish, whose son was murdered in 2021, opposed the bill. She said it is retroactive, and referred to the procedures in the bill as "rampant and ambiguous at best."
"My son will never return to his home," Darvish testified. "No murderer should be given a free ride home."
This is a sentiment was echoed by many including Folden, who said those accused of rape and murder specifically should not get a second look.
But the bill that could allow review of prison sentences over 20 years was also met with large amounts of support from activists and formerly incarcerated individuals.
Anthony Muhummad was just 15 when he was arrested for two homicide charges in Baltimore City. He served over 29 years and was released under the Juvenile Restoration Act, and was one of the first to testify in support of the bill.
"There are dozens of individuals who are still incarcerated throughout the Maryland prison system who have served 20, 30, 40 and yes, sometimes even 50 years of incarceration who are not juveniles, who have demonstrated their maturity and rehabilitation and we believe are worthy of a second opportunity," Muhummad said.
Muhummad detailed his community engagement since his release, including his current employment at the ACLU. He also spoke about the conversation he had with the families of the two victims in his case, both of whom were in favor of rehabilitation.
And Pasteur, who is a former educator in Baltimore City and Baltimore County schools, believes that all deserve the chance for reevaluation after 20 years, especially those who entered the prison system at a young age. Pasteur said two of her "very favorite" former students have been or are currently incarcerated.
"I am really an educator, not a politician," Pasteur said. "Having always been in schools where things are tough for a lot of the students I have seen students get themselves engaged and involved in things that they know they shouldn't have. So they are in my heart."
And ultimately, Pasteur has high hopes for the bill.
"It's about appreciating and recognizing that some folks under the most horrific circumstances have made themselves better," Pasteur said. "Much better than a whole lot of us on any given day."

title: FAA closes helicopter route near D.C. airport
author: MENNATALLA IBRAHIM Capital News Service
content:
FAA closes helicopter route near D.C. airport

 March 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MENNATALLA IBRAHIM Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 676
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The National Transportation Safety Board issued urgent safety recommendations last week, warning that helicopter flights near the Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport pose serious safety risks and one helicopter route should be closed during airport operations.Hours later, Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy accepted the recommendations on behalf of the Federal Aviation Administration, promising long-term changes.
"Urgent recommendations require immediate action to prevent similar accidents or incidents when we issue them," NTSB Chair Jennifer Homendy said at an NTSB media briefing on March 11. "We believe a critical safety issue must be addressed without delay."
The recommendations were released alongside a preliminary investigative report on the Jan. 29 midair collision of an American Airlines jetliner and a military helicopter near Reagan National that killed 67 people.
Nine men from Southern Maryland died in the collision: Jonathan D. Boyd, 40, of Welcome; Tom Clagett, 43, of Newburg; Andrew Eaves, 39, of Great Mills; Alexander "Alex" Huffman, 34, of Mechanicsville; Steven "Stevie" Johnson, 45, of Welcome; Charles "Charlie" McDaniel, 44, of Port Republic; Jesse Pitcher, 30, of Lusby; Robert Prewitt, 44, of Calvert County; and Michael "Mikey" Stovall, 40, of Accokeek.
The NTSB urged the FAA to ban helicopters from a four-mile stretch over the Potomac River when airport runway 15/33 is in use and to designate an alternative route when the area is closed, according to the published recommendations. The American jet was on final approach to runway 15/33 when the collision occurred and everyone on board died.
Homendy said that there were warning signs before the January collision, citing data detailing more than 15,000 near-collisions between commercial aircraft and helicopters at Reagan National between October 2021 and December 2024. The majority occurred during plane landings and at night, according to the NTSB's report.
"We're in a situation where we're threading the needle, allowing helicopters to fly down the same airspace as landing aircraft," Duffy said. "And why this information wasn't studied and known before Jan. 29 is an important question."
Following the crash, Duffy restricted helicopter traffic around the airport through the end of March. He said those restrictions will continue in accordance with NTSB recommendations.
Duffy said he also spoke with Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth about alternative military flight routes, with exceptions for presidential travel, life-saving operations and law enforcement.
The preliminary report does not identify any probable causes of the collision, as the NTSB is still in "the fact-finding phase" of its investigation, according to Homendy.
"We still have a lot of work to do in this investigation, so the report contains only the facts that we're able to validate and release at this time," Homendy said. "The easiest and quickest part of the investigation is determining what happened. The part that takes longer is the how and why."
Tuesday's NTSB media briefing was the fifth of its kind since the collision.
At a Feb. 14 briefing, Homendy told reporters that investigators believe that the helicopter crew was wearing night vision goggles that would have limited their peripheral vision. She also said that cockpit conversations suggest that the helicopter crew may not have heard key instructions from air traffic controllers and had inaccurate altitude readings in the moments before the crash.
Duffy criticized the air traffic control system as outdated, relying on 25- to 30-year-old technology, including floppy disks and plug-in headphones, at a separate press conference on March 11. He pledged to propose a plan in the coming weeks that would revolutionize the "antiquated" technology, seeking congressional approval and funding.
"We're at a point where we can do this fast — three and a half to four years for a brand new air traffic control system. Gold plated. Envy of the world," he said. "It will greatly improve our safety … but it's also going to improve the efficiency that we have in American air travel, which I think will mean less delays, less cancellations, and again, better safety."
Despite concerns, Homendy reassured travelers.
"I just flew with my daughter out of DCA … aviation is incredibly safe," she said. "However, there are safety issues and areas where we need to improve to make sure that we are at zero."

Cambridge man pleads guilty to assault, carrying handgun in shooting

 March 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 305
 Words

 CAMBRIDGE — A Cambridge man has pleaded guilty to two charges related to a shooting that took place at the Corner Market Exxon in Cambridge in July.Dykir Qualick Lee, 23, pleaded guilty during a hearing March 10 to first-degree assault and carrying a loaded handgun.
Dorchester County Circuit Court Judge William Jones handed down a sentence of 25 years for the first-degree assault charge and a consecutive sentence of three years for carrying a loaded handgun. All but 18 months of Lee's 25-year sentence were suspended. His entire three-year sentence was suspended.
After incarceration, Lee will have to serve five years of supervised probation.
Lee had previously been charged with 18 other charges related to the July incident, including attempted first- and second-degree murder. The state has entered nolle prosequi for those charges, meaning the state will not prosecute for them.
Lee's charges stem from a July 11 shooting. According to a news release from the Cambridge Police Department, officers responded to the Corner Market Exxon on Maryland Route 16 and Stone Boundary Road for a report of shots fired that day.
Police said that as officers were on their way to the scene, Cambridge Police learned a vehicle had left the area of the reported shooting and two victims had arrived at the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Cambridge. Police said both victims, a 19-year-old from Cambridge and a 20-year-old from Cambridge, were treated for non-life-threatening gunshot wounds.
Police said evidence was found at the scene of the shooting and at the hospital, where the vehicle — reportedly damaged in the shooting — was located. Through investigation by the police department's Criminal Investigations Division, Lee was identified as a suspect in the shooting.
With assistance from the U.S. Marshals Fugitive Task Force, the Cambridge Police Department located Lee at a home in Cambridge in August and arrested him.

title: Ridgely commissioners, residents weigh in on potential of reinstating police department
author: Konner Metz
content:
Ridgely commissioners, residents weigh in on potential of reinstating police department

 March 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 769
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RIDGELY — Over a year after suspending the now-defunct Ridgely Police Department, town commissioners say reestablishing the force will cost the town nearly double its projected payment to the county sheriff for police coverage.At a workshop Wednesday, Commissioner Brad Sears told residents that restoring the department would cost an estimated $852,000. Ridgely currently receives dedicated coverage from the Caroline County Sheriff's Office based on a memorandum of understanding. Renewing that MOU for fiscal year 2026 would cost $493,000, per estimates.
A number of residents questioned the Town Council's openness to consider reinstating the department. Concerns raised stem back to the town's controversial decision to suspend and subsequently lay off the department last year amid a criminal investigation into the police chief that came up empty.
Residents were only permitted to testify in front of the commissioners Wednesday if they had signed up around a day in advance.
Heather Amador said the workshop felt like the town was "checking a box."
"I feel solid that your minds are made up," Amador told commissioners. "Some of you openly expressed that at the last town meeting. It feels pretty certain that my words and efforts will be for nothing."
"We're not going to make any decisions tonight," Sears said. "We're not really going to take questions, because we want to focus on what you, the public, have to say. And we want to take some time to properly consider what you have to say."
The commissioners suspended former Police Chief Jeff Eckrich and the entire department March 12, 2024, amid a state criminal investigation into Eckrich due to "suspected" perjury and misconduct in office.
On July 25, 2024, an investigation report by the Office of the State Prosecutor found no "sufficient evidence of criminal activity warranting further investigation or prosecution."
But by that time, the Ridgely officers had already been laid off with the start of the new fiscal year July 1. The town began selling and transferring its police vehicles and equipment in the weeks before the state prosecutor's report was released.
Since then, Ridgely has maintained a contract with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office to have assigned officers covering the town. Last week, the Sheriff's Office announced a third officer was assigned to the Ridgely patrol group.
At Wednesday's meeting, Sears explained why Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker and Chief Deputy Rodney Helmer weren't in attendance.
"They wanted to attend, but they were advised by their attorney not to attend because there is potential litigation outstanding," Sears said. Lt. George Paugh attended in their place.
While two residents submitted written testimony in support of maintaining Caroline County Sheriff's Office coverage, residents who spoke at the meeting largely asked for two other options: reinstating the town's force or ending the Sheriff's Office contract and operating like towns such as Goldsboro and Preston, which receive general county and state police patrol.
"Since the sheriff has taken over, we've had no community policing like before," said Christine Eckrich, wife of the former Ridgely chief. "And a lot of the hours have not been covered. So now my question is, what are we paying for? Why are we double paying for the Sheriff's Office to come to Ridgely."
Resident Anna Mansfield questioned if the budget estimates for a reestablished town force and the county coverage are comparable.
"Was the Ridgely Police Department afforded the ability to reduce their hours to meet the amount of hours expected for the desired budget?" Mansfield asked commissioners.
Sears, who assumed his seat in July 2024 after the department's suspension earlier that year, prepared the cost estimates by reviewing past police budgets, meeting with a consultant and comparing projections to other local departments.
He said it's key to have "rationale and cost effective reasons" when considering creating a police department.
Resident Jennifer Nesselroad stood up to express her displeasure.
"We had a police department, and we don't need to start a new one because you illegally took ours away," she said, leaving the room.
President John Buckle said in an opening statement that "the commissioners will listen carefully to what everyone has to say." Commissioner John Hurley provided no comment at the workshop.
As the meeting closed, Sears emphasized that reinstating the police department would require infrastructure and safety improvements to the department's office within the town hall building.
"But the police department existed how many years without those features," resident Robin Martin said.
"Things have changed a lot over the last five to 10 years," Sears responded. "The racial incidents, the general degradation of respect for authority, COVID and so on has changed our cultural landscape. Violence is on the upswing."
"It's very difficult to be a police officer," he later added. "It's very difficult to attract and retain police officers."

title: Students complete inaugural Talbot County Sheriff's Office police academy
author: Konner Metz
content:
Students complete inaugural Talbot County Sheriff's Office police academy

 March 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 481
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Students in grades 10 through 12 graduated from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office inaugural citizens police academy Tuesday night.In a 10-week course that met every Tuesday, officers provided students an inside look at the law enforcement field, teaching topics such as crisis response, bleeding emergencies and traffic stops.
Saints Peter & Paul sophomore Carson Tyree said the academy changed his perspective of police work.
"What stood out is how these guys work. It's not all fun and games," Tyree said. " … When they go into a situation, there's a lot of thinking behind it because they can't violate procedure. If they violate procedure, they can't be a police officer."
Junior Canin Parks said he took the academy to learn more about law enforcement since he is considering entering the field. His favorite week was the virtual reality simulator, during which students were posed with the virtual task of helping people in distress.
Jules Stepp, a Saints Peter & Paul junior, most enjoyed learning about Talbot County's crisis response unit, or SWAT team. Students were shown the inside of a SWAT van and learned about the materials and techniques used in situations that call for crisis response.
"It was like we were there with them," Stepp said. "We got to live vicariously through them."
Stepp said she recommends the academy to anyone interested. The academy made it clear the extreme level of detail that policing requires, she said.
"I was surprised how much detail went into every little thing, and how one little thing can cause a problem so they had to backtrack and think about what the consequences could be," she said. "And how they have to go through so many processes to get grants, peace orders, protective orders and all that type of stuff."
Following Tuesday's 10th and final class, Maj. Steve Elliott thanked the students and called them a "great group" for the first ever citizens police academy. Lt. J.R Dobson said it was a fun 10 weeks.
"I think from day one — when (Sheriff Joe Gamble) was giving you guys a lesson on when the first sheriff of Talbot County was — until now, I've seen you all loosen up," Dobson said.
Gamble thanked Lori Stepp, the grants administrator for the Sheriff's Office, for procuring a grant to make the police academy possible.
The Talbot County Sheriff's Office is now fielding applications for its second citizens police academy. This round is open to county residents 18 and older. Classes are held every Tuesday for 10 weeks beginning April 8. Applications are open until March 31.

 QUEENSTOWN — Troy Michael Sellman, 37, of Queenstown, has been added to the Queen Anne's County Animal Abuse Registry after pleading guilty to animal abuse charges, according to Queen Anne's County State's Attorney Lance Richardson.Sellman entered a guilty plea in Queen Anne's County District Court on Nov. 24, 2024, for failing to provide proper shelter for a Cane Corso dog, violating Maryland Criminal Law Article 10-604, Richardson said. Richardson said Sellman received a suspended jail sentence and supervised probation, as he was already incarcerated on unrelated charges. His probation conditions prohibit him from owning or possessing animals and require a mental health evaluation.

title: Firefighters extinguish large barn blaze in Easton
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Firefighters extinguish large barn blaze in Easton

 March 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 373
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Dozens of firefighters from agencies throughout the Mid-Shore extinguished a large barn fire on Chapel Road Wednesday, a blaze which was caused by a controlled burn and took more than five hours to put out, according to officials.No injuries were reported, fire officials said, though the main barn structure was mostly destroyed.
The Easton Volunteer Fire Department was called at 10:33 a.m. Wednesday and arrived on the scene at 10:37 a.m., according to Captain Justin Jones. Most of the barn was engulfed in flames at that time, he said.
"On arrival, it was probably 75% involved," Jones said. "And with the wind conditions, spot fires were popping up all around the property. And with all the fuel load around the structure, I went ahead and hit the second (alarm) to get the manpower and equipment that I needed."
Jones said 76 personnel were on scene. It took around 200,000 gallons of water and hours of work for firefighters to handle the blaze, which was fully extinguished by 3:50 p.m.
Wood and mulch piles around the barn led to spot fires that presented a further challenge for fire crews. Excavators were brought to the scene to help pull apart the piles.
"The main challenge was getting all the piles of debris around the structure broken apart, soaked down anyway we could, and keeping all the fire in check," Jones said.
Officials say the barn and surrounding area is used by Economy Tree Service, a company based in Queenstown. Jones said personnel on the scene confirmed the fire began as a controlled burn by the tree service. It then spread, partly due to significant wind gusts and dry conditions.
Jones said he wasn't aware of any animal injuries. A cat that exited the barn structure during the fire was saved, he added.
The property is located at the 9000 block of Chapel Road, east of U.S. Route 50. It's at the site of the former Murdoch Gardens florist business and farm, according to officials.
Jones thanked the many fire departments from across the Mid-Shore that provided crucial assistance Wednesday.
"We couldn't do it without all the mutual aid from Caroline, Dorchester, the other stations in Talbot County and also Queen Anne's County," Jones said.
This report has been updated to include additional information.

He was taken into custody and transported to a local medical facility for a mental health evaluation. Criminal charges are pending, Chestertown Police Chief Ron Dixon, lead agency on the incident, said.
Flatland Road remained closed throughout the day, with motorists advised to avoid the area. Authorities used the Everbridge alert system to notify nearby residents of the ongoing situation.
While initial police statements suggested no immediate public risk, neighbors expressed concerns about the incident's severity. The precise circumstances leading to the standoff remain under investigation.

title: Kent County weighs ICE cooperation amid liability concerns
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Kent County weighs ICE cooperation amid liability concerns

 March 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 626
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Will Kent County police cooperate with U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement when and if they call? More specifically, will they participate in the 287(g) program, which allows local law enforcement agencies to collaborate with ICE to detain immigrants?Kent County Sheriff Dennis Hickman acknowledges this is a complicated issue, based on recommendations from the Maryland State's Attorney's Office.
A 2018 guidance memorandum states that law enforcement agencies can cooperate, but are not required to do so and could be liable in certain situations.
"As the elected sheriff, I don't want to potentially cause additional liability to me or our county government, but we don't want the same problems that we have seen in other counties," Hickman said in an interview with the Kent County News.
Hickman is referring to the releasing of dangerous criminals back into the community. By refusing to cooperate with ICE, local lawmakers could release a person charged with a minor offense while the federal government has information about a more serious crime.
Although Hickman is aware of liability issues, his first priority is protecting the public.
The issue is politically charged across Maryland and the country. Democratic lawmakers are advocating for eliminating the federal program altogether. On March 17, during the Maryland General Assembly crossover session, Delegate Nicole Williams, D-Prince George's County, advanced a bill that appeared closer to passage.
"We should not be doing the federal government's job for them," Williams told her colleagues during a floor debate.
In the state Senate, Sen. Will Smith, D-Montgomery County, has proposed a "protected spaces" bill that would require guidelines for how ICE carries out actions in sensitive locations like churches and schools.
Several Maryland jurisdictions already have policies limiting cooperation with ICE.
Howard County's Liberty Act prohibits county employees from asking residents about their immigration status and bans discrimination based on citizenship status.
Similarly, in Prince George's County, legislation has been enacted to ban local agencies from cooperating with immigration enforcement.
Despite opposition, sheriffs from Garrett, Allegany and Washington counties agreed to assist ICE, joining Frederick County, which has been assisting for several years.
Hickman acknowledged that this level of cooperation is not feasible in Kent County, not because they oppose the policy, but because it requires additional training and duties without federal compensation.
Most likely, Kent will not enter into a 287(g) agreement but will cooperate while trying to avoid liability and maintain public safety.
On its website, ICE expressed gratitude for the three counties' cooperation in the Secure Communities Program, which helps "identify criminal aliens in state prisons and local jails by running their fingerprints against federal immigration databases when they are locked in the system."
This information-sharing program now includes 21 counties, including Kent.
Matt Elliston, Maryland ICE director, warned that cooperating with the state may put local law enforcement in liability issues, but not cooperating could also create consequences.
In Frederick and Howard counties, Elliston is calling on the U.S. Department of Justice to take action against them for refusing ICE detainers and releasing criminals without notifying ICE.
For Hickman, a balanced approach is best and, most importantly, safest. "Some counties refuse to cooperate with the federal government, resulting in releasing potentially dangerous people back into the community," he said. "Failing to have some measure of cooperation is not in the best interest of our community."
Currently, the county has not been asked to assist ICE beyond notifying the agency before a state release. The Kent County Sheriff's Department has not been asked to hold anyone past their state-release date.
"If ICE has a detainer on someone, we will let them know when they are done with local charges and they are welcome to meet them at the back gate to pick them up," Hickman clarified.
Since the mid-March, there have been no ICE seizures, but one individual completed their local sentence and was then received by ICE.

title: Talbot County Police Accountability Board reports decrease in misconduct complaints
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot County Police Accountability Board reports decrease in misconduct complaints

 April 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 416
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot County's Police Accountability Board investigated just six resident complaints of police misconduct in 2024, down from 15 complaints in 2023.Mitch Ettinger, chairman of the board, reported these statistics to the Talbot County Council Tuesday. He said the decrease in complaints is "a testament to the fantastic law enforcement agencies" in the county.
Complaints have ticked up since January. In the first quarter of 2025, the charging committee has received seven complaints of police misconduct, Ettinger noted. An explanation for the uptick was not provided at the meeting.
Of the six complaints last year, four were dismissed and two resulted in administrative charges against an officer.
According to the board's 2024 report, the decrease is due, in part, to a resident moving out of the county who submitted many complaints in 2023.
With fewer complaints to investigate, PAB members became interested in how they might otherwise serve the county, Ettinger said.
Tuesday, Ettinger noted all police misconduct complaints in the last two years have been made directly to law enforcement agencies and subsequently referred to the charging committee. Ettinger said residents may not be aware that complaints can be made directly to the accountability board as well.
He asked council members for feedback on whether the board is meeting expectations and on potentially expanding the role of the PAB.
"Our mandate is narrow by statute," Ettinger said, "but we have seen in other jurisdictions, PABs go well beyond that mandate at the direction of their council, including to review policies of law enforcement agencies."
"The PAB feels that its role is not all that substantive," he added.
Police accountability boards were mandated statewide by Maryland's Police Accountability Act of 2021. PABs, made up of everyday residents, are responsible for meeting with law enforcement agencies, fielding complaints of police misconduct, reviewing use of force reports and submitting annual reports to county officials.
All counties have an administrative charging committee that sits under the PAB. Those committees determine if an officer will be administratively charged and, if so, what discipline they receive.
County Council Vice President Pete Lesher said he hopes for the county to "look at other models and see what might be working in other jurisdictions."
Council member Keasha Haythe said it is important for the county to consider both looking at other jurisdictions and increasing resident awareness of the PAB complaint process.
Meanwhile, council member Dave Stepp said he is comfortable with the board's responsibilities remaining the same.
"I see no reason to expand the scope or functionality other than what's required by law," Stepp said.

title: Point-in-time count shows Mid-Shore homelessness is up
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Point-in-time count shows Mid-Shore homelessness is up

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 565

 EASTON — A point-in-time count conducted in January showed a 50% rise in people experiencing homelessness on the Mid-Shore since last year, according to results released earlier this month.The count is an annual survey that measures homelessness across the U.S. This year, Mid Shore Behavioral Health's Continuum of Care team contributed by gathering data from individuals in encampments, shelters and temporary housing in Talbot, Kent, Dorchester, Caroline and Queen Anne's counties.
In addition to the 50% rise, the Mid-Shore saw a 400% rise in total unsheltered homelessness since 2024, according to the results of the count. Unsheltered homelessness involves a person living in a place not meant for habitation.
But Ashley Kessinger, continuum of care program manager, says these numbers might not accurately represent changes in homelessness on the Mid-Shore.
The number may be so high, she said, because of the difficulty of reaching people in the past due to the Shore's rural nature.
"That 400% increase, I think it has to do with the efforts that went into reaching more people (this year)," Kessinger said. "We live in a rural community, and it's different from the cities, where a lot of times people experiencing homelessness may be right on the sidewalk and in front of your stores."
According to the count, The total number of people experiencing homelessness on the Mid-Shore sits at 195, with 179 people in sheltered locations and 16 in unsheltered locations.
According to Jimmy Morris, continuum of care housing outreach specialist at Mid-Shore Behavioral Health, the count is important due to the rise of unsheltered individuals on the Shore.
"There's people that lost their homes because of medical conditions or job layoff, drug, alcohol, addiction or mental health," Morris said to the Star Democrat in January. "We are overwhelmed in these five counties."
While many issues can cause homelessness, Kessinger cites lack of affordable housing as one of the main factors.
"Housing is definitely a huge barrier that we have seen," Kessinger said. "We have funding that can place people in housing like security deposits, first month's rent and depending on the program, they can help with some additional months.
"But it has been really hard to find housing that can fit within the HUD fair market rent that we have to abide by."
Another factor Kessinger cites is transportation in Mid-Shore communities.
"Transportation may not be something that people think about right off the bat, but it's a huge need for the people that we work with," Kessinger said. "This rural community, it makes it very hard to go from one county to another. It's hard because it's so spread out, you need a vehicle, and vehicles are expensive."
Kessigner hopes that Continuum of Care can help improve homelessness in the area. Aid from the Department of Housing and Community Development with affordable housing for people experiencing homelessness will help as well, she said.
"So I know the DHCD has a really great initiative with creating more permanent housing," Kessinger said. "We have a permanent housing program, and they are basically expanding that in the state of Maryland.
"I know the governor's had a hand in that as well. I think that is a really great is a step in the right direction as far as helping to resolve a lot of the homelessness that we see on the shore. I think the emergency shelters are vital. They're very important, but what everyone needs is a safe home that they can actually afford."

 CAMBRIDGE — Some in lunge positions and some clutching the police tape marking the starting line, around 200 children waited eagerly as Capt. Antoine Patton counted down the seconds to the start of the annual Cambridge Police Department Easter Egg Hunt.When he got to one, children aged 2 to 12 leapt forward with excitement and began to search for the 5,000 eggs spread across Gerry Boyle Park Saturday. Many children inspected the park closely for golden eggs, which, when found, could be taken to the prize table and traded for an Easter basket full of toys and candy.
After 6-year-old Johana Green found her golden egg, she received an Easter basket almost half as tall as her. The basket was complete with candy, a dart board, foam darts, a spinner, a slingshot and more.
Green said she was excited to open the basket and was looking forward to trying out the slingshot.
And Green was not the only kid to walk away from the hunt with a haul to bring home. Many children left with baskets filled to the brim with eggs.
Patton said the police department began spreading out thousands of eggs across the park at 8 a.m. so all the children there would be able to put eggs in their baskets.
The department started putting on the egg hunt about 10 years ago when the county stopped hosting it, Patton said.
"We actually started 10 years ago with about 100 eggs and maybe 25 kids on Pine Street," he said. "And it got so large that we ended up coming here. So we went from 100 eggs to now 5,000 eggs and a lot of people."
Patton said he was excited for the event because it gives kids the opportunity to participate in an Easter egg hunt and helps the police department build a relationship with the community.
Along with the hunt, children could take pictures with the Easter Bunny, paint eggs with The Garden Church and get food and drink from the Salvation Army. For the adults, a sack race was held immediately after the egg hunt.
"It is a beautiful day," Patton said as warm breezes glided through the air. "I don't think we could ask for a better day."
After learning about the event in the newspaper, Cambridge resident Chuck Pinkston brought his two sons, Corey, 8, and Carter, 6. Like many of the other older kids at the hunt, Corey and Carter were determined to find a golden egg.
Pinkston said even though he told his sons to stay together, Corey ran out to find a golden egg with his younger brother chasing behind him. Later in the hunt, Corey helped Carter fill his basket with eggs.
April and Levi Jarman, who brought their 4- and 1-year-old children to the hunt, said even though there were a lot of people, there were a lot of eggs.
"I'm just glad that they put this on for the community," April Jarman said. "It was nice to get everybody out. I've seen some old coworkers, so that was nice. Just nice to get out with the family, do something."
