title: CASA of the Mid-Shore celebrates its volunteers
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
CASA of the Mid-Shore celebrates its volunteers

 April 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 400

 EASTON — Over appetizers, drinks and good conversation, CASA of the Mid-Shore thanked its volunteers Thursday with a special event at the Avalon Theatre in downtown Easton."The people who bring our mission to life are our CASA volunteers," Executive Director Robin Davenport said.
CASA of the Mid-Shore assigns volunteer court appointed special advocates in Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties to advocate for children who are considered to be at significant risk in their current homes and have been placed under court protection.
Advocates are tasked with identifying a child's needs and advocating for necessary services so those needs can be met.
During the celebration Thursday, Davenport shared a story of the impact volunteers can have on the children they advocate for. She said a retired volunteer, Sally, was at the doctor's office recently when she discovered her nurse was a child whose case she was appointed to a decade ago.
Davenport said Sally had never known if she had made a difference in the child's life. At the doctor's office that day, the now-nurse told Sally she got through high school and college because of what Sally said to her.
"And so we're here tonight because everyone in this room talks the talk and walks the walk," Davenport said. "And that is really important to us, but certainly to the future of the kids who we're working with."
Volunteer Geoff Searle said he got involved with CASA of the Mid-Shore in 2022 after retiring. He said social workers often have large caseloads, and CASA volunteers are able to focus solely on one child.
Larry Neviaser, who became a volunteer this year, said one of the things that drew him to the organization is its focus on finding the best outcome for every child.
"We don't represent anybody else except the child," he said.
Neviaser said he feels supported by CASA of the Mid-Shore's staff.
"They recognize the value of the volunteers, and (that) it really makes the organization," he said.
Along with being thanked and served up food and drink, CASA volunteers heard a presentation from author and speaker Frank Kros about making positive impacts on children that can last generations.
Weaving in stories about his own childhood, Kros talked about the mindset of children who have been through abuse and gave tips on how to encourage children.
"It's incredible what we can do when someone genuinely believes in us and provides us the support that we need," he said.

 A man charged with murdering his girlfriend is back in Charles County after being returned from U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement custody.The state's attorney for Charles County advised that on Friday, April 25, a grand jury returned an indictment for Keycy Robinson Alexi Barrera-Rosa, 24, of Waldorf for the murder of Lesbia Mileth Ramirez Guerra.
The indictment charges Barrera-Rosa with first-degree murder, second-degree murder and making a false report, a release from the state's attorney's office said.
On April 2, Barrera-Rosa contacted the Charles County Sheriff's Office to report that his girlfriend, Guerra, was missing from their Waldorf residence. During the investigation, detectives reviewed video surveillance showing the victim entering their residence on March 31 but never exiting, the release said.
Witnesses reported that during the early morning hours of April 1 Barrera-Rosa and Guerra were allegedly in a violent argument.
During the afternoon of April 1, video surveillance allegedly captured Barrera-Rosa grabbing a large plastic bin from a shed in his backyard and carrying it to the back of the house, the state's attorney's office said.
Barrera-Rosa then drove his truck to the back of the house.
Cellular tower data records indicate that Barrera-Rosa traveled to Prince George's County to meet with his uncle, Rolvin Eduardo Barerra-Barerra, at a construction worksite, according to the release.
Further cellular records indicate that Barrera-Rosa and his uncle traveled to a secluded, densely wooded intersection in the area of Cedarville State Park.
Barerra-Barerra was interviewed by detectives and reported that on April 1 his nephew told him that he had killed his girlfriend by strangulation and asked for help with hiding the body, the release said.
He further stated that when Barrera-Rosa allegedly traveled to his work site in Prince George's County, the woman was already deceased and in a plastic bin in the back of Barrera-Rosa's vehicle.
The uncle, Barerra-Barerra, allegedly told detectives that he and Barrera-Rosa disposed of the Guerra's body by burying her in a wooded area near Cedarville State Park, the release said.
On April 18, Charles sheriff's officers located Guerra's body in a plastic bin buried at a location described by Barerra-Barerra and in proximity to where phone records indicated Barrera-Rosa and his uncle parked their vehicles on April 1.
On April 5, Barrera-Rosa was arrested and detained by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement for unrelated charges.
On April 22, he was transported by ICE agents and turned over to the Charles County Sheriff's Office. He is being held without bond at the Charles County Detention Center.
Barerra-Barerra has been charged as an accessory after the fact to murder in Prince George's County and is also being held without bond in that jurisdiction.

 EASTON — At their April 17 meeting, Greensboro Town Council members approved police K-9 Mosley to start immediately."It feels quite amazing," Police Chief Lenox Trams said to The Star Democrat Friday. "She's has a very good career, and my vision was to have a police K-9 at the Greensboro Police Department to assists with the K-9 scans with the county and just be the resource. So it feels amazing to actually have it all approved."
Mosley is the K-9 of new Greensboro Police Department Sgt. Jeff Adams. Mosley has been with Adams since 2017.
Mosley has been experienced cancer, but Adams says she is still able to work as a K-9.
"She's done everything," Adams told The Star Democrat when he was hired in February. "She's already certified in tracking and narcotics. Now we took off the tracking because she lost her leg to cancer in Halloween of 2023. She went through chemo, radiation, and she's she's still working. She's did awesome with the training. She nailed it."
Mosley was retired after Adams left Federalsburg Police Department because Adams wanted to make sure he was able to keep Mosley.
The council members asked multiple questions about the lack of K-9s on the Mid-Shore. The concern the council members had deals with Mosley being called into other towns in Caroline County or other jurisdictions in the Mid-Shore.
"I understand the shortage of the dogs in the county, and I understand they're a great resource," said Pete Brelia, town council member. "But this is the Greensboro Police Department, and it serves the citizens of Greensboro, and I don't want to hire a dog and have Jeff and his dog called all over the state and the county to do the duty or the job of the dog at our expense.
"We're paying him his overtime, we're going to take care of the dog, assume all his responsibilities, and the officer is not going to be in town, which is where we're hiring him to be, so that's my issue with the dog."
While the concerns where heard by Trams, he assured the council members that he can set a mile radius on where Mosley and Adams could go.
"As the police chief, I have the authority to give a time frame or a mile radius of Adams and the police K-9 to respond," Trams said.
The council members also discussed whether to bring the K-9 on before this fiscal budget year ends or in July, when the new fiscal year begins. The cost for the K-9 is $2,000 for this fiscal year.
After discussion, the council members voted 3-1 in favor of hiring Mosley immediately. Brelia voted against hiring the dog.
"I would like to go ahead and make a motion to hire the dog for two months until the July budget for $2,000," Joe Moon, council member, said. "We have a drug problem, I don't think it makes a difference from now until July. After hearing the public I just like to make that motion."

title: Ridgley commissioners vote to continue MOU with Caroline County Sheriff's Office
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com

Ridgley commissioners vote to continue MOU with Caroline County Sheriff's Office

 RIDGELY — The Ridgely commissioners voted to continue the town's memorandum of understanding with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office at their monthly meeting Monday.Commissioner Brad Sears voted in favor of the MOU, but he said he plans to continue negotiation with the Sheriff's Office over details of the agreement.
"I think at this point we're to a point where we would entertain a motion to give the town authorization to meet with the county to negotiate any changes to the MOU and go from there," Sears said.
Ridgely has maintained a contract with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office to have assigned officers covering the town since last year. In March of 2024, the town suspended the entirety of its police department amid a state investigation.
On July 25, 2024, an investigation report by the Office of the State Prosecutor found no "sufficient evidence of criminal activity warranting further investigation or prosecution." By that time, the Ridgely officers had already been laid off.
Monday's decision came after a discussion at last month's commissioners meeting about three potential options to continue policing for the town.
"I know last month we talked about three options, one completely going back to the sheriff's department regular patrol pattern," Sears said. "Second was to attempt to re-establish an original police force, and even that price was conservatively estimated at $852,000 for the first year if we could find the police officer."
The third option was to continue the MOU with the county.
The cost for the services of the Caroline County Sheriff's Office would be $493,415 on the fiscal year 2026 budget.
The Sheriff advocated for his office to continue its agreement with the town.
"The sheriff's office is providing what is going to be a high quality of law enforcement in the town," Caroline County Sheriff Donald Baker said in an interview. "The town going with the MOU with the sheriff's office, they get everything the sheriff's office has to provide as far as criminal investigations handled by a investigator or detective, as well as the sheriff's office is a member of the Caroline County Drug Task Force and we have two deputies assigned to that."
Multiple questions were brought up by town residents regarding where the $493,415 would go. Baker clarified to residents and commissioners how the funds would be broken down.
"There was some confusion that this money is dumped right into the Sheriff's Office budget. That's not true," Baker said. "The county is billing the town based upon the usage. So, if we don't use something or there's money left over, the county does not bill it and it goes back to the town or the town keeps it and it's never filled."
The vote to continue the MOU was unanimous. Commissioner John Hurley was absent from the meeting.

 EASTON — Construction on the A. James Clark Emergency Services Training Campus is well underway — and project leaders even had the chance to show Gov. Wes Moore around the construction site last week.Brett Whitehead, president of Friends of the Easton Volunteer Fire Department, has spearheaded fundraising efforts for the state-of-the-art training campus, which will be used by firefighters, police officers and EMS workers when it opens.
Whitehead said construction teams have made "unbelievable progress."
The 7,200-square-foot campus is located on Mistletoe Drive. Once complete, Easton Volunteer Fire Department Assistant Chief Daryl Caldwell said it will include a 4,200-square-foot classroom building, a burn building for search-and-rescue and active shooter simulations, and two pads for car fire and extrication training.
The burn building won't be damaged, project leaders say, since it's going to be a metal building with concrete floors and stairs. It will have movable walls to provide a variety of room configurations during trainings.
Caldwell said the training campus will keep on-duty first responders centrally located. The campus also will reduce long travel times that local first responders often incur when going to Salisbury or the western shore for necessary training.
Ground was broken in December on the project. As of Monday, significant work had been done to both the classroom and burn buildings. Whitehead said the goal of opening by the end of the year still remains.
"If weather holds up, permits get approved," he said.
Whitehead said more than $4 million has been raised, which leaves less than $1 million remaining of the project's $5 million fundraising goal.
As the name indicates, the A. James & Alice B. Clark Foundation was fundamental in fundraising efforts. Last September, the foundation donated $1 million to the training campus. Overall, the foundation has contributed $1.9 million to the project.
The project also has received $300,000 in state grant funding.
On April 29, Moore toured the training campus as part of a private visit in Easton.
Caldwell said Moore was "very attentive" and asked many questions. Caldwell, Whitehead and other members of the department, along with town leaders, were present for the governor's visit.
"Governor Moore's visit to the A. James Clark Emergency Services Training Campus site in Easton highlights his continued commitment to public safety, and ensuring Maryland is providing our law enforcement and first responder personnel with the best resources available," Moore's office said in a statement. "The governor is proud to work alongside so many local electeds and community leaders in supporting this project."
Whitehead believes the Easton training campus will be a model for future first responder training facilities where personnel can train separately or together.
"This is the only one of its kind in the Mid-Shore period," Whitehead said. "Where you have real-time training opportunities. You have all first responders training together. No other site does that in the Mid-Shore."

title: Be responsible on the water
author: Staff Writer
content:
Be responsible on the water

 May 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 453
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Summer is a great time to enjoy local waters. Whether you're a boater, angler or water sports enthusiast on the Eastern Shore, please remember to be responsible around the water. May 17-23 is National Safe Boating Week. The Safe Boating Campaign, led by the National Safe Boating Council, offers these tips for practicing social distancing and safety while boating:Wear a life jacket. No matter what activity you have planned on the water, always remember to wear a life jacket every time you are on the water. Accidents on the water can happen much too fast to reach and put on a stowed life jacket.Make sure your life jacket is U.S. Coast Guard approved, appropriate for your water activity and fits properly. A life jacket that is too large or too small can cause different situational problems.Know state boating laws. Rules and laws can differ from state to state and violations can result in ticketing, fines or jail time.Take a boating safety course.Learn valuable tips that can help save your life in unexpected situations.Make sure your boat is prepared. There are many items that need to be checked and rechecked on any boat. Schedule a vessel safety check with your local U.S. Coast Guard Auxiliary or U.S. Power Squadrons before you hit the water. Every vessel safety check is conducted at no charge.Always file a float plan. File a float plan before you leave shore with someone you trust that includes details about the trip, boat, persons, towing or trailer vehicle, communication equipment, and emergency contacts.Check the weather, including the water temperature. Know the latest marine weather forecast prior to going out, and keep a regular check for changing conditions.Don't drink while you boat. Where the primary cause was known, alcohol was listed as a leading factor in boating-related deaths.Beware of carbon monoxide poisoning. Gasoline-powered engines on boats, including onboard generators, produce carbon monoxide (CO), a colorless and odorless gas that can poison or kill someone who breathes too much of it. Be sure to install and maintain a working CO detector, never block exhaust outlets, and always dock, beach or anchor at least 20 feet away from the nearest boat that is running a generator or engine.Keep in touch. Communication devices can be the most important piece of emergency equipment on board a vessel, especially in case of emergency. Be sure to have and know how to use at least two communication devices that work when wet, such as satellite phones, emergency position indicating radio beacons, VHF radios and personal locator beacons.
By following these tips, you can enjoy your boat, the water, sunshine and fresh air responsibly. For additional boating resources and tips, please visit SafeBoatingCampaign.com.

 EASTON — On Friday, police charged an Easton woman for allegedly placing swastika stickers on political signs and town property ahead of Easton's recent election.Jennifer Cristaudo, 53, has been charged with 20 counts of using a hate symbol, three counts of malicious destruction of property and one count of defacing property in a race/religion crime. All counts are misdemeanors.
According to charging documents, Cristaudo allegedly placed six swastika stickers on political signs and 16 stickers with red lines through swastikas on town property, such as light poles and stop signs.
The six stickers placed on Gunsallus signs were all in "high-minority areas," according to charging documents prepared by Detective Cory Schuch.
"The placement of a hate symbol, such as a swastika on campaign signs in these areas is a clear indication that Cristaudo's motivation was to intimidate minority voters in the Town of Easton to not vote for Frank Gunsallus," charging documents stated.
Police say the placement of the stickers began in late March and continued through early May. The election was held May 6.
According to the Easton Police Department, on March 26, officers located three swastika stickers on Gunsallus signs. They reviewed surveillance video, which showed a woman driving a blue Subaru as the person placing the hate symbols.
On April 1, police discovered another defaced sign. April 28, officers found two more Gunsallus signs defaced near the Easton Amish Market.
Per charging documents, police later found 16 swastika stickers with red lines throughout town, with 10 reported on April 1 and 2, and six reported between April 30 and May 6.
According to court documents, a town official told police removing the stickers causes "permanent damage" to the signs, "rendering them unusable." The town's public works department estimated $21,000 in replacement costs.
In addition to video footage linking Cristaudo to the stickers, court documents state police found a "large roll of matching swastika stickers" in Cristaudo's residence.
Matching clothing and more stickers were found in her car, police said in charging documents.
During the campaign, Gunsallus and his then-opponent Don Abbatiello both spoke out against sign vandalism. Gunsallus told The Star Democrat in March that "these types of things shouldn't happen during a campaign."
"This act of hate has escalated the situation into a deeply troubling reality that demands our collective attention," Gunsallus wrote in a letter sent to The Star Democrat, local police and various local officials in March.
Rabbi Fred Scherlinder Dobb, interim rabbi for Temple B'Nai Israel and Satell Center for Jewish Life on the Eastern Shore, said he was "disappointed" but not "shocked" by the use of hate symbols.
"I would say Easton and Talbot County are mostly a wonderful refuge from some of that national division," he said. "But sadly, and maybe inevitably, pieces of that creep in."
Dobb said the placement of hate symbols is "utterly unacceptable" no matter the intent. "Full-on continental devastation and genocide — which is the ultimate Nazi legacy — needs to be reserved for issues far greater than Town Council," Dobb said.
Lt. Milton Orellana, special operations commander for the Easton Police Department, said Monday that the department had also received a report of a Ku Klux Klan hood being placed on a Gunsallus sign during the campaign. Police were not sure who was behind that incident.
Orellana said police are actively investigating both incidents. A preliminary hearing for Cristaudo is set for June 20.
Gunsallus declined to further comment on the situation, citing the ongoing investigation.

According to police reports, Queen Anne's County deputies responded to a residence on Auckland Way in Chester at approximately 8:26 p.m. on May 17, 2024, for reports of a cardiac arrest. Upon arrival, deputies found the elder Meyer deceased under "suspicious circumstances."

title: Anton Black's cause of death should be ruled homicide, audit finds
author: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com
content:
Anton Black's cause of death should be ruled homicide, audit finds

 May 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 674
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In 2018, the state medical examiner ruled that Anton Black's death at the hands of police in Greensboro was an accident. An audit report released by the state attorney general's office Thursday says the cause of death should have been ruled a homicide.The recommendation, one of dozens, comes after a four-year review of cases from between 2003 and 2019, during which time former Medical Examiner Dr. David Fowler was in office. The audit ultimately evaluated 87 cases, reclassifying the cause of death from accidental, unknown or natural to homicide in 36 of them.
"The audit also validated concerns that bias may have affected death investigations in Maryland," Attorney General Anthony Brown said in a letter to Marylanders included with the report. "Addressing those concerns benefits everyone in our system of justice — including the vast majority of law enforcement professionals who perform their duties with integrity and deserve clear, consistent standards."
The audit, led by Towson University psychology professor Jeff Kukucka, began in 2021 after Fowler's testimony in the trial of Minneapolis Police Officer Derek Chauvin sparked outcry. Chauvin, who was convicted of murder for the 2020 death of George Floyd, knelt on Floyd's neck for up to nine minutes during an arrest.
During his testimony, Fowler, who was called as an expert witness, said Floyd's death could be attributed to causes other than police restraint, including "excited delirium," a term used to describe agitation and aggression related to mental health or substance abuse that has been disavowed by leading medical authorities. Over 450 medical experts co-signed a letter to former Maryland Attorney General Brian Frosh and others condemning Fowler's testimony.
"This audit marks the beginning of a long conversation — one that must be handled with honesty, delicacy, resolve, and deep consideration," Gov. Wes Moore said in a letter included in the Thursday report. Moore went on to highlight reforms in the medical examiner's office that have been underway for several years.
The 2023 settlement of a case brought by the Coalition for Justice for Anton Black and Black's family demanded changes including a policy addressing how medical examiners handle deaths in custody, including those involving law enforcement restraint, according to the ACLU of Maryland.
The policy incorporates and models guidelines from the National Association of Medical Examiners for determining how such deaths are investigated and how examiners determine causation.
On Sept. 15, 2018, Black, 19, and a 12-year-old family friend were walking around Greensboro when Black began pulling and dragging the child, who called out for help, garnering attention from onlookers that led to a 911 call.
A chase that ensued ended outside Black's home, where Greensboro Police Officer Thomas Webster IV, off-duty Ridgely Police Chief Gary Manos, Centreville Police Officer Dennis Lannon and a civilian pinned Black against a wooden handicap ramp for six minutes while handcuffing and shackling him.
Black, who had severe bipolar depression, stopped breathing and became unresponsive after being handcuffed and shackled. He was taken to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center in Easton, where he was pronounced dead that evening.
Fowler ruled Black's cause of death was a sudden cardiac event. A later examination by a Johns Hopkins University cardiologist determined asphyxiation was the cause. No one was charged in the incident.
For those who have advocated for change in the way in-custody deaths are handled by the state since Black's death, the report released Thursday marked a potential turning point.
"This 70-page independent report vindicates what family members and communities — mostly Black and Brown Marylanders — have been saying for decades: the truth. That the entire system has been complicit in making police-involved deaths seem inevitable," said ACLU of Maryland senior staff attorney Sonia Kumar, who led the team that litigated the 2023 settlement, in a statement Friday.
An executive order issued by Moore Thursday called for the attorney general and the state's attorney's office to examine whether any cases should be reopened for investigation as a result of the report's findings. The executive order also established a task force to examine the handling of in-custody deaths.
Star Democrat reporter Lily Tierney contributed to this report.

title: Mother gets six years for Christmas Day fire that killed daughter, 10
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Mother gets six years for Christmas Day fire that killed daughter, 10

 May 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 1001
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The mother of a 10-year-old girl who was killed in a townhouse fire near Elkton on Christmas Day 2023 has received a six-year prison term for involuntary manslaughter — an offense relating to overloaded electrical outlets, hoarding conditions and a lack of smoke detectors that contributed to the youngster's death.Cecil County Circuit Court Judge William W. Davis Jr. imposed a maximum 10-year sentence on the defendant — Theresa Ann Moats, 41 — during a May 12 courtroom proceeding and then suspended four years of the penalty.
"It was totally preventable. I'm not doubting that you love your daughter, but the care wasn't there," Davis told Moats after remarking, "This is the exact definition of a difficult case. You have the tragic loss of a young person and there his zero intention for this to happen. It's the nature of the charge."
Moats' daughter — Kyleigh Nicole Treadway — perished in the swift-moving, two-alarm blaze that started accidentally inside 317 Willow Dr. in the Winding Brook neighborhood, northeast of Elkton, shortly before 7:30 a.m. on Dec. 25, 2023.
Kyleigh, who had been sleeping in a second-floor bedroom, was trapped inside that burning townhouse after her mother, her grandmother, her two older brothers and her mother's boyfriend — Kevin Neal Summerfield, now 42 — had escaped.
Investigators reported that as many as 35 pets, mostly dogs and cats, lived inside the townhouse with the family and that the floor was coated in animal feces, saturated with urine and covered with trash, clothing and other combustibles.
Those unsanitary conditions and the hoarding situation made walking passage difficult. Those extreme conditions also exacerbated the overloaded electrical outlets marked by long runs of extension cords powering everything, including heavy-duty appliances like the refrigerator and freezer.
The investigation also revealed that Kyleigh's hair and clothing emanated the smell of animal waste every morning she arrived at Cecil Manor Elementary School in Elk Mills, where she was a fourth-grader, and that fellow students avoided her because of the pungent unpleasant odor.
In addition, the investigation revealed that the school nurse routinely washed Kyleigh's clothes and washed and brushed the girl's unkempt hair and that attempts to interact with Moats about the situation were futile.
The evidence of neglect prompted school officials to make referrals to the Cecil County Department of Social Services, after Kyleigh moved with her family from Delaware and started attending that school, court records show.
"It was the saddest fact pattern I've ever read," Davis commented from the bench Monday before sentencing Moats. "Her existence seemed to be miserable and her demise was miserable. It does make me want to cry."
Moats will serve her six-year term in a Maryland Department of Corrections prison. She was taken into custody inside the courtroom directly after sentencing. The judge gave Moats credit for 424 days that she already served, initially as a pre-trial jail inmate and later on house arrest on a $50,000 unsecured bond.
She tearfully addressed the judge moments before sentencing.
"Living without my daughter has been like a mental prison. I miss her. I can't hug her. I can't play games with her. Life is dull. She was the shining star of the family. Kyleigh was everything to me . . . I can't look at her picture. I wish she was here," Moats said.
In addition to the six-year prison term, Davis ordered Moats to serve five years of supervised probation once released. The judge ordered her to submit to any mental health treatment and counseling deemed necessary.
Assistant State's Attorney Gavin Patashnick sought the full 10 years of incarceration for Moats, whom he accused of minimizing her gross negligence. The judge agreed with Patashnick's assessment of Moats' mindset.
"The defendant flatly refuses to accept any responsibility . . . The house was in shambles . . . Kyleigh didn't have any friends. No one would touch her. Her only friends were teachers. This child was essentially forgotten," Pataschnick told the judge.
The prosecutor remarked that Kyleigh "died horribly" because of the squalid dwelling conditions that caused the blaze and then fueled it. The state medical examiner attributed Kyleigh's death to smoke inhalation and burns over 90 percent of her body.
"She did not die peacefully. She had soot in her mouth, smoke in her lungs. She burned. She was breathing in gases," Patashnick outlined.
As for his recommendation of the maximum 10-year sentence, Patashnick told the judge, "I'm here to stand up for this girl."
Moats' lawyer, Assistant Public Defender Emily Gillis, recommended that the judge sentence her client to time served, approximately 16 months. Gillis categorized the townhouse fire that killed Kyleigh as a "tragic accident" and reported that Moats has been suffering — and will continue to suffer — from the loss of her daughter.
"She lives with that. Parents aren't suppose to bury their children," Gillis told Davis.
Court records indicate that two Cecil County Department of Animal Services officers went to 317 Willow Dr. on Dec. 20, 2023 — five days before the fatal fire there — and impounded 14 dogs and four cats that showed signs of neglect and abuse after receiving a complaint.
After impounding the 18 animals, officers, "planned to make a report to Child Protective Services, as the children in the home were subjected to poor living conditions," according to court records.
At Monday's sentencing, Gillis questioned why Social Services did not remove Kyleigh and her minor sibling from the dwelling at that point and arrange for foster care or a similar program.
"There was no shelter plan, no safety plan . . . The Department of Social Services failed. They (social services) would have had Kyleigh with them if they had done their job properly," Gillis asserted.
In January, as part of a plea deal, Moats entered an Alford plea to involuntary manslaughter, the most serious charge in the case. In an Alford plea, the defendant maintains his or her innocence but, at the same time, he or she does not dispute the incriminating evidence possessed by the state.
Prosecutors, in return, agreed to drop 11 related charges against Moats, including reckless endangerment and neglect of a child.

title: ICE detains 2 longtime Caroline County residents in Preston
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
ICE detains 2 longtime Caroline County residents in Preston

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 495
 Words

 PRESTON — Longtime Caroline County residents Olga Velazquez and Frutalco Ramírez were detained by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement on Saturday, May 10, in Preston.According to a GoFundMe started by their daughter, Lili Ramirez, the couple are agricultural workers who have been in the United States for more than 20 years with no criminal record.
The Department of Homeland Security's field office in Salisbury did not respond to an email asking for details about the incident and was not able to answer questions about the incident on the phone Tuesday. When a reporter called on Monday, the Caroline County Sheriff's Office was not aware of the incident.
Valezquez and Ramirez worked for multiple farms in the Preston and Hurlock area. When farm owners learned they were taken by immigration agents, they were devastated.
"We were devastated," said Bret Colbourne, owner of Triangle Acres Farm. "Very good, hard-working people, honest, never in trouble."
"It was devastating to all of us. We cannot believe it, for our whole community around it," Bret's wife, Myra Colbourne, said.
Ramirez, who also worked part time for TJ Farms in Preston, was described as "a nice fellow" by the farm's owner Timmy Jester.
"Well, he's a real nice guy, and he worked several different farms around here," Jester said. "But when we needed him, he would help us, and he certainly didn't cause any trouble or anything. He was a nice fellow."
The Colbourne family had developed a relationship with the couple and described their relationship as really good friends. They even described Lili Ramirez as their granddaughter.
"They're very good friends of ours, and their daughter, she's going to school to be a nurse," Bret said. "Been helping me for 10 or 12 years probably, longer."
While the $10,000 goal was surpassed on the GoFundMe, the $10,000 was just enough to retain a lawyer. According to the Colbourne family, the price of a bond is unknown.
"We don't know yet, and that's the disturbing part," Bret Colbourne said.
Though immigration enforcement has seen increased attention since President Donald Trump took office earlier this year, Matthew Peters, director at Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center, said immigration enforcement on the Eastern Shore has been at a steady rate since 2012.
"So since we've been working in this role with the immigrant community since 2012, we've always seen immigration enforcement, it's always been here," Peters said. "Now the degree and the number varies from month to month, season to season, year to year."
While farmers in Caroline County hope for the couple's return, they expect heavy declines in production due to the couple's absence.
"I'm getting older, and he's been helping me out part time all along. There's no help around anymore. You can't hardly find anyone working on a farm anymore," Jester said. "We're probably just going to close the produce, and we're just going to buy from wholesalers and resell it instead of growing it ourselves because it's just too much hard work. Nobody wants to do any hard work, and he would always come."

Florestal, a Federalsburg resident, posted $5,000 unsecured bond following a bail review Thursday, according to court records. A preliminary hearing is scheduled for June 16.
The juvenile is being held without bond at the Caroline County Detention Center, police said.
The woman, 20, sustained life-threatening injuries but is now in stable condition, police said.
According to the Sheriff's Office, police in Seaford, Delaware responded to a local hospital where the woman was dropped off with multiple stab wounds. Per investigators, Florestal and the 16-year-old "transported the victim to the hospital before fleeing the scene."
The Caroline County Sheriff's Office, at the request of the Federalsburg Police Department, is actively investigating the incident. Anyone with information is asked to contact 410-479-2515 or info@carolinesheriff.net.

title: Local K-9 units work to overcome retirements from cannabis law
author: Konner Metz
content:
Local K-9 units work to overcome retirements from cannabis law

 May 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 917
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — In just a handful of months, K-9 Knox is making an impact at the Easton Police Department.The nearly 2-year-old black lab completed training in January. In 2025's first quarter alone, she was deployed 17 times, making six drug arrests alongside her handler, Pfc. Mark Schinault.
"She has that drive for her reward, her toy after she does a good scan," Schinault said. "That means the world to her, so she's very driven to work."
Knox is part of Easton's new guard of K-9s. Last year, three dogs trained in marijuana detection were forced into early retirement due to the legalization of recreational cannabis use legalization in Maryland, which took effect July 2023.
Easton is not the only agency looking to rebuild its K-9 team in the wake of the legislation. Across the state, law enforcement agencies are working to fund and fill their K-9 units, which serve crucial roles not only in deterring crime, but also in connecting with the community.
Police officers largely agree that dogs trained to sniff marijuana can't be used to detect drug offenses any longer, nor does the dogs' expertise hold up in court.
"I really didn't want to go down the road because I didn't want to be challenged in the courtroom," Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble said.
Knox joined K-9 Waylon in Easton, and soon two other young dogs not imprinted on marijuana will fill out the town's K-9 unit. Lt. Tim Larrimore said it has been a "complete rebuild" for the unit since the law passed.
Trained dogs can sometimes cost around $14,000, Larrimore said. Younger, untrained pups are significantly less, though they require major time commitments for training and certification.
Across the state, the work of K-9 dogs — depending on their training — often includes drug sniffing, tracking of suspects or missing subjects, and explosives detection. Knox is certified in drug detection and on her way to certification in tracking.
Schinault and Knox completed more than 60 hours of one-on-one training before she was certified in drug detection. Easton opted to go with untrained dogs to save costs and build rapport between K-9s and officers.
While Maryland K-9s are no longer sniffing for marijuana, Larrimore says their work is more important than ever in combating drug offenses.
"This odor of marijuana was enough before 2023 to give us probable cause to search. Now that's out," Larrimore said. "So now you need the ability to smell something that the human nose isn't necessarily good at detecting. It's the dog that gets you there."
PLAYING CATCH UP
Kent County Sgt. Scott Lockerman has a passion for not just his K-9 partner, Khari, but for all police dogs across the state. He is president of the Maryland Police K9 Foundation, a nonprofit that helps police agencies buy, train and protect their four-legged workers. The foundation paid for one of Easton's new dogs.
Lockerman said that after the legalization of cannabis, there was roughly a 60-40 split of agencies that could quickly get their K-9 units back on track versus those that were more affected by unexpected retirements. But he said progress is being made across all departments.
"Most of the agencies were able to replenish the dogs," Lockerman said.
At the Dorchester County Sheriff's Office, one K-9 retired early after the cannabis law was passed, while multiple dogs retired shortly before. The agency worked ahead to bring in replacement dogs not trained to detect marijuana so the state legislation didn't present too many challenges.
"We saw it coming," Sheriff James Phillips said. "It was on the horizon."
Six K-9s currently work for the Dorchester Sheriff's Office. Three can assist in patrols and narcotic detection, two work in narcotics only, and one bloodhound specializes in tracking. Phillips said the office has adequate funding to fill its seventh and final spot for a K-9 trained in detecting explosives.
Funding often comes from grants, local donations, organizations such as the K9 Foundation and county councils. Phillips said it's "mind-boggling" how generous people have been in donating dogs to the Sheriff's Office.
In addition to purchasing the dogs, agencies pay for safety equipment (like bulletproof vests) and health payments. Departments are also on the hook for vet costs incurred by retired dogs, per state law. For a retired K-9, departments could pay up to as much as $2,500 a year, capped at $10,000 per dog.
Larrimore, the Easton lieutenant, says that hasn't yet presented a major funding challenge, though it could down the road.
"It hasn't hit us yet," he said. "These dogs are just retired last year. They're young, they're healthy."
COMMUNITY IMPACT
When the highly-skilled dogs aren't working a case, they're often out in the community showing more of their friendly side.
In Dorchester County, Sgt. Steve Twilley says the K-9 unit bridges the gap between the Sheriff's Office and the community. The dogs especially help police build trust with kids.
"Next thing you know, that kid's come to you for help instead of lashing out or doing something at school," Twilley said.
Schinault and Knox attended a recent Coffee with a Cop event this spring. Schinault said they're very involved with community policing efforts.
Phillips and Twilley say the same is true in Dorchester County. Whatever dollar amount is spent on police dogs, Phillips says, comes back to the Sheriff's Office "10 times over because of the relationships that we build with the kids and the people."
"I think an agency that's trying to do today's police work and doesn't have the K-9 ability out there, I don't think they're a full police agency," Phillips said. "I think it completes the police agency by having the K-9s."

 EASTON — Cpl. Joseph Schinault still remembers the first time his K-9 partner Murph tracked down a suspect.The Belgian malinois and German shepherd mix located a residence in the Doverbrook Apartments an unarmed robbery suspect ran to with stolen items. It was the dog's first tracking mission and far from his last.
Starting in 2018, Murph served as an integral part of vehicle searches and the Easton Police Department's crisis response unit.

"It is truly an honor to work with them," Schinault said of the skilled dogs.
Murph, 7, still lives with Schinault and his family. He's become the "best of friends" with Schinault's son, who is just six months younger than Murph.
Schinault said it took a while for Murph to adapt to staying home instead of jumping in the police car when it started. "He lives to have a purpose," Schinault said.
Schinault's younger brother and fellow Easton police officer, Mark, is the handler of one of Easton's new K-9s, Knox. Joseph Schinault says it's amazing what K-9s can do, emphasizing the importance of police dogs in solving crime.
"Who's to say we (would've) ever solved that?" he said of Murph's first tracking.
For the Easton police officer, having a partner like Murph was a source of daily motivation.
"There's not a day that you bring a K-9 to work that they don't want to work," Schinault said.

title: Man gets five years for Thanksgiving Day stabbing of stepson
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Man gets five years for Thanksgiving Day stabbing of stepson

 May 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 548
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A man who stabbed his adult stepson following Thanksgiving dinner in November 2023 at a residence near Elkton received a five-year prison term on Thursday, according to Cecil County Circuit Court records.Cecil County Circuit Court Judge Cameron A. Brown imposed a maximum 10-year sentence on the defendant — Ernest Anthony Vuocolo, 64 — for second-degree assault and then suspended all but four years of the penalty, court records show.
In addition, Brown imposed a consecutive one-year sentence on Vuocolo for carrying a dangerous weapon with intent to injure.
The judge also imposed a concurrent four-year sentence on Vuocolo for reckless endangerment.
Brown ordered Vuocolo to serve three years of supervised probation after completing his five-year term in a Maryland Department of Corrections prison.
A jury convicted Vuocolo of those three charges in March after a two-day-long trial. The jury, however, acquitted Vuocolo of the criminal case's most serious charge, first-degree assault, a felony offense that carries a maximum 25-year sentence.
Assistant State's Attorney Gavin Patashnick prosecuted Vuocolo, who was represented by Elkton-based defense lawyers Tina Harris Schlecker and C. Thomas Brown, and Brown presided over the trial.
The defense maintained that Vuocolo acted in self-defense and that he was at a disadvantage during the confrontation with his stepson because Vuocolo has a history of medical issues, including suffering multiple heart attacks, and that he is 20 years older than his stepson. Vuocolo testified in his own defense.
The incident leading to Vuocolo's convictions and five-year prison term occurred at approximately 10 p.m. on Nov. 23, 2023 at his residence in the unit block of Stirrup Drive after a family Thanksgiving dinner, police reported.
Vuocolo assaulted his 41-year-old stepson when the stepson confronted Vuocolo regarding "sexual comments" that Vuocolo purportedly had made about his stepson's wife, according to court records.
An ambulance crew drove the victim to Christiana Hospital in Delaware, where doctors treated him for a stab wound to one side of his chest, court records show.
Cecil County Sheriff's Office deputies rushed to the Stirrup Drive residence at 10:14 p.m. Nov. 23, 2023, after receiving a complaint regarding a "physical domestic involving a knife," police said. Deputies found the victim "bleeding heavily" from his left side, police added.
Family members who witnessed the incident told investigators that Vuocolo assaulted the victim with a knife during an argument, according to court records. At the scene, deputies recovered the knife, which investigators described as being about six inches long with a "thick blade," court records show. (At trial, the term "field clever" was used to describe the knife.)
Because Vuocolo complained of chest pain at the scene, an ambulance crew drove him to ChristianaCare's Union Hospital in Elkton, where doctors treated him before releasing him back into direct custody of police, according to court records.
During an interview conducted by CCSO Det. Joseph Laspina at Christiana Hospital, the victim alleged that Vuocolo had made sexual comments about his wife on Nov. 21, 2023 — two days before the stabbing occurred, according to court records.
The victim told investigators that he confronted Voucolo about those purported comments after Thanksgiving dinner and that he requested an apology from him, court records show. The victim told investigators that, at that point, Vuocolo attacked him with a knife, stabbing him in the side of his chest while holding him in a headlock, according to court records.

title: Police accountability legislation worked on by Caroline County Commissioners
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Police accountability legislation worked on by Caroline County Commissioners

 May 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 470
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — On Tuesday, the Caroline County Commissioners conducted the second reading and public hearing for a legislative bill making changes to legislation defining the county's Police Accountability Board, Administrative Charging Committee and trial boards.The changes come after law enforcement agencies voiced confusion about how far the powers of these boards and committees extend.
"I will tell you in practice that (law enforcement agencies) have to work with the ACC. This has to be a partnership. This should not be a combative relationship," Executive Director of Police Training and Standards Commission Wayne Silver said.
The committees and boards were formed as a result of the Maryland Police Accountability Act of 2021, which aimed to create a system for evaluating and investigation complaints against law enforcement agencies.
The county implemented the accountability board, charging committee and trial boards when required by the state. But the exact duties and appearances of these boards are still being fine-tuned through the county's legislative processes.
Silver talked with the county commissioners about the trends seen in other counties and about how these counties implemented the boards and committees.
One of the questions presented by the commissioners asked about the subpoena power of the charging committee. Silver gave insight on how subpoena power should be implemented.
"To my knowledge, Caroline County is the only county to ever subpoena an officer," Silver said. "The ACC does not have subpoena authority... Our position on this, ladies and gentlemen, is that it is the law enforcement agency that would issue the subpoena if it was necessary."
In December, law enforcement officials from multiple counties gathered at a Caroline County Commissioners meeting, bringing concerns about an incident involving a Caroline County sheriff's deputy and its implications for police accountability practices throughout the state.
The deputy, who was not named, was investigated by the administrative charging committee about a harassment complaint. Committee members invited the deputy to meet with the committee regarding the complaint, a move considered by some sheriff's departments to be "not proper protocol" or an "overreach."
After a 40-minute conversation with Silver on Tuesday, the commissioners opened the public comment period for the legislative bill.
While no one spoke during the public comment period, the county received multiple letters from the Police Accountability Board and Administrative Charging Committee and a letter from Denton Chief of Police George Bacorn on behalf of other chiefs in Caroline County.
After discussion, some of the important changes made within the legislative bill establishing the roles and powers of the boards include:
Clarifying definitions and language and correcting grammar errors.Adjusting requirements of board members, including removing the three-year residency requirement and allowing members to attend meetings virtually. The commissioners will also appoint an alternate member of the Police Accountability Board.Removing subpoena language from the legislation. The ACC recommended paragraph removal on subpoena responsibilities, but commissioners decided to the remove "subpoenas" sentence from the paragraph.

 CAMBRIDGE — Friday, residents of the Altair Apartments were given a notice that strict parking and gate access measures would be in place beginning at 4 p.m.Altair management chained and bolted the fencing at the complex, preventing residents from entering or leaving and causing concern among residents and emergency officials.
"The concern was that there was not an emergency exit or an evacuation route for the residents," said Cambridge Commissioner Shay Lewis-Sisco, who represents the ward where Altair is located.

Though this year's event was cancelled, police maintained a heavy presence in the area for the next few days. Todd said the increased presence was due to social media rumblings of a large crowd for the "Freaknik" event. He said the department wanted to ensure the safety of residents and visitors.
"You know, our main goal and our presence, which we always try to keep our presence in all of our higher crime areas or where we've experienced major crimes to keep our residents safe and that's our number one goal and our number one priority," Todd said.

title: Talbot, Queen Anne's counties included on Trump's list of 'sanctuary jurisdictions'
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot, Queen Anne's counties included on Trump's list of 'sanctuary jurisdictions'

 May 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 636
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Talbot and Queen Anne's counties have been listed as "sanctuary jurisdictions" by the Trump administration, a label disputed by officials from both counties.President Donald Trump issued an executive order last month instructing DHS Secretary Kristi Noem to track the jurisdictions the administration considers to be defying the president's immigration crackdown efforts.
On Thursday, the Department of Homeland Security published a list of more than 500 jurisdictions across the country, stating that those jurisdictions are "defying federal immigration law."
Queen Anne's and Talbot officials challenged the claim Friday. In a statement, Queen Anne's County called the sanctuary designation "wholly inaccurate."
"Queen Anne's County has never adopted or endorsed sanctuary policies, nor have we enacted any ordinances or resolutions that would shield individuals in violation of federal immigration law," the statement read.
Talbot County said it received no communication from the federal government that it wasn't complying with federal immigration laws in advance of the list being published.
"We have, and will continue to, follow all applicable federal laws and have not taken any deliberate actions to obstruct their enforcement," a statement from a Talbot County spokesperson read.
"We welcome further information and guidance from the federal government so we can address any pertinent issues," the statement added.
The DHS website states that jurisdictions were designated "sanctuary" based on the following factors: "compliance with federal law enforcement, information restrictions, and legal protections for illegal aliens."
Noem said in a DHS press release about the list of jurisdictions that the department is "exposing these sanctuary politicians who harbor criminal illegal aliens and defy federal law."
"These sanctuary city politicians are endangering Americans and our law enforcement in order to protect violent criminal illegal aliens," Noem said.
As part of Trump's effort to label "sanctuary jurisdictions," federal agencies are directed to identify federal grants and contracts for potential "suspension or termination, as appropriate," per the president's executive order.
Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble said in an interview Friday he's concerned for the status of a federal grant that goes to the Talbot County Sheriff's Office. This year, the agency received $40,000 to increase patrol efforts in Trappe, a town without its own police department.
The grant — which is administered annually — has led to a number of arrests and reduced crime, Gamble said.
"We hope that we can reapply and renew that grant," he said.
Talbot County's inclusion on the list was a "total shock" to Gamble, who says his office has always complied with immigration agents. "They haven't asked us to do anything," he said. "We haven't said no to anything."
Gamble said he's spoken with the former and current Maryland ICE directors, both of whom indicated they are unsure of why Talbot County is listed.
Queen Anne's County Sheriff Gary Hofmann expressed similar sentiments. He said Friday he's not aware of any actions by his office or the county government that could lead to the sanctuary designation.
"This is continued misinformation that's been perpetuated now," Hofmann said. "I've heard this for a couple years, so it's of no surprise."
Under Trump, Immigration and Customs Enforcement, or ICE, has ramped up agreements with local law enforcement agencies, referred to as 287(g) agreements, to carry out immigration crackdown efforts. ICE has signed nearly 700 of these agreements nationwide and seven in Maryland.
Neither Talbot County nor Queen Anne's County are currently engaged in 287(g) agreements. Hofmann and Gamble said since the sheriff's offices aren't in charge of the counties' jails, they can't enter into jail enforcement agreements with ICE like other Maryland counties have.
Hofmann noted the Queen Anne's sheriff's office was eligible for ICE's Secure Communities program, a separate and now defunct effort where local agencies submitted fingerprints of those arrested to the federal government. Fingerprints were cross-checked with immigration databases.
Hofmann added that since it ended, his office "hasn't changed on how we deal with criminals," emphasizing a "zero tolerance" approach.
The Associated Press contributed to this report.

 QUEENSTOWN — Route 213 (Centerville Road) John Brown Road and Lloyds Meadow Lane has reopened following an ongoing fatal shooting investigation.At approximately 1:15 a.m. on June 1, deputies from the Queen Anne's County Office of the Sheriff responded to reports of gunfire in the 1500 block of Centreville Road. Prior to law enforcement arrival, a large party had been held at a residence in the area.
According to a statement released by the sheriff's office, witnesses reported that upon hearing gunshots, attendees fled the scene. Deputies located three individuals suffering from gunshot wounds. One victim was pronounced deceased, and the other two victims were transported to area hospitals, where they remain hospitalized.
Mid-day Sunday, police confirmed Christopher Parsley, 19, of Centreville is the deceased victim. Police said they would not release the names of the other two gunshot victims at this point in the investigation.
Through witness interviews, investigators believe the suspect or suspects were present at the party before the shooting occurred.
Dispatch reports indicated that at 1:19 a.m., emergency medical teams, including units from Talbot and Caroline counties and two Maryland State Police helicopters, were dispatched to the scene. At 1:35 a.m., EMS personnel advised a Mass Casualty Incident response. By 2:06 a.m., the incident was placed under control, with EMS and fire units clearing the scene shortly afterward.
Sheriff Gary Hofmann expressed his condolences: "Our thoughts and prayers are with the family of the victim whose life was tragically taken, as well as with those who were injured. This kind of violence has no place in our community. We are working diligently to identify and apprehend those responsible. I encourage anyone with information to come forward, your help could make all the difference in delivering justice for these families."
There is no suspect in custody at this time, Public Information Officer Kaitlyn Briselli said.

title: Trial begins for Cambridge man charged in fatal shooting last October
author: Konner Metz
content:
Trial begins for Cambridge man charged in fatal shooting last October

 June 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Crime 
 
 491
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Testimony began Monday afternoon in the jury trial for a Cambridge man charged in the shooting death of a 26-year-old man last year.Jo'Mir Norman, 18, is charged with first- and second-degree murder, among other offenses, in the fatal shooting of Virgil Simms on Oct. 20, 2024.
On Monday, the jury heard opening statements from Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard, the lead prosecutor, and defense attorney Margaret Fox, as well as testimony from witnesses.
Norman sat at the right of Fox dressed in an all-gray suit. He faces nine total charges, three of which are felony charges — the first- and second-degree murder counts and a count of first-degree assault.
Leonard recounted the "senseless killing" in which she said Norman and another shooter acted together to murder Simms on Pine Street, firing many rounds at Simms before fleeing the scene. She said no matter who landed the fatal shot, they are both responsible for the crime.
"One doesn't get exonerated because they had better or worse aim," she said.
Leonard told jurors to expect lots of video evidence and expert testimony about how surveillance cameras work. Prosecutors are also expected to bring forward "distinctive clothing" worn by Norman on the day of the murder as evidence.
Fox argued the state will present no forensic evidence nor an eyewitness placing Norman at the scene.
"The state's case is not resting upon direct evidence. ... It's completely circumstantial," Fox said. "This case comes down to what you can see with your eyes," the defense attorney added.
Leonard and Fox's arguments to the jury both acknowledged a hiccup in the early days of the murder investigation — the misidentification of the other main suspect. Initially, police charged then-15-year-old Brian Wongus Jr. in connection to the murder.
Maryland State Police announced the arrests of Norman and Wongus in an Oct. 28 press release. But Wongus was misidentified by police, the attorneys said.
An MSP spokesperson said Tuesday that "in consultation with the Office of the State's Attorney in Dorchester County," charges against Wongus were dropped in late October or early November.
In the courtroom Monday, Fox looked to poke a hole in the state's case, telling the jury that prosecutors are depending upon "the same video evidence that led to the misidentification of somebody."
Leonard said "police readily and quickly" discovered the misidentification. Surveillance cameras linking Norman to the crime stand true, she said.
"All of the evidence always pointed at Jo'Mir Norman," Leonard said.
Prosecutors brought three witnesses to the stand Monday afternoon: a police officer and EMT who responded to the shooting, as well as Simms' mother Yolanda Hernandez.
Hernandez provided a brief but emotional testimony as prosecutors asked her about her son.
Hernandez said she and Simms had grown closer since he had two young children. She said he liked to cook, grill and joke around. "He was a decent guy," Hernandez said.
Jurors are expected to hear from a number of expert witnesses in the coming days. The trial is scheduled to run through Thursday.

title: Transcript reveals final words from Dali crew before Key Bridge collapse
author: LIV BARRY obarry@chespub.com
content:
Transcript reveals final words from Dali crew before Key Bridge collapse

 June 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LIV BARRY obarry@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 887
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Just five minutes prior to the collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge on March 26, 2024, crewmen aboard the Dali ship were conducting business as usual.At 1:06 a.m., the ship's pilot communicated to one of the Dali's tugboats: "I like my chances if you want to take off."
"Alright — all done here. (Have) safe trip," the tugboat Bridget McAllister responded.
Less than 20 minutes later, around 1:25 a.m., the Dali's command center was sent into chaos as the vessel lost power.
A transcript released by the National Transportation Safety Board in April, which was first reported by The Baltimore Banner on Monday, notes the first 25 minutes of the Dali's voyage as unremarkable.
However, the initial power outage, signified in the transcript by a sound "similar to Automatic Power Change Over Circuit" and multiple blaring alarms that continued throughout the collision, threw the crew into a state of alarm.
What followed the power outage is a series of internal and external communications between Dali crew members, the Dali's tugboats, the Maryland Transportation Authority Command Center. To better lay out the events leading to the collision, The Dundalk Eagle has organized the communications between calls for external help, attempts to lower the anchor and attempts to use bow thrusters.
CALLS FOR HELP
Immediately upon losing power, the pilot asked the second officer and helmsman if they had steering, to which both responded yes.
As the crew attempted to maneuver the ship away from the Key Bridge, the pilot communicated to the second officer and helmsman again at 1:25:24 p.m.
"(Just) let me know if you can't steer," the pilot said.
Seconds after the pilot's command, another sound similar to an automatic power change is noted in the transcript. The pilot then communicated with the AMP Pilot Command Center.
"@[AMP Pilot Dispatcher] have them shut down the Bay Bridge. I just lost steering — not the Bay Bridge — the, uh ... Key Bridge," the pilot said.
At 1:26:10 a.m., the helmsman reported that they were "swinging to starboard." Soon after, the pilot can be heard asking for a "mac boat," referring to the Dali's two tugboats, the Bridget McAllister and Eric McAllister.
"Calling the Mac boats — anybody out there?" the pilot asked at 1:26:38 a.m. Just seven seconds later, the Eric McAllister responded.
"Hey Eric [IMO 9707413] it's the Dali — I need ya over here quick. I've uh just lost power (heading to the Key Bridge)," the pilot said.
Simultaneously, as the pilot called the Eric McAllister, the pilot's command center contacted the MDTA.
"No there's a vessel — I'm calling for the pilot. There's a ship heading toward the Key Bridge. He lost steering. We need to stop all traffic on the Key Bridge," the pilot's command center said to the MDTA Command Center at 1:26:57 a.m.
As the captain attempted to lower the anchors, the training pilot made a call over very high frequency (VHF) radio to alert other ships at 1:27:25 a.m.
"Security call. Security call. Container ship Dali has lost power. Approaching the Key Bridge — I repeat — the container ship Dali has lost all power approaching the Key Bridge — Dali," the training pilot said.
This was the final external warning call.
ATTEMPTS TO LOWER ANCHOR
After the pilot's command center asked to close traffic on the bridge, the captain can be heard asking the forward crewman to let go of the port anchor.
"Sir I cannot * * *," the forward said. According to the NTSB, the rest of the forward's response could not be made out over shouting on the ship's bridge, marking the obscuring with asterisks.
The captain again called for the anchor to be lowered at 1:27:14 a.m., shouting, "Fast, fast let go port anchor."
As the pilot attempted to use the bow thrusters, the captain continued to command the forward to lower the anchor, imploring the crewman until he received another response at 1:27:55 a.m.
"I tried to open the break. Break is not able to open up," the forward said.
At 1:28:42, the frontman told the captain that he opened the break.
"Let go. Let go," the captain said in response.
After not receiving a response, the captain checked back in with the forward at 1:29 a.m. exactly before delivering what would be the final words before the crash is marked on the transcript: "Let go, yes."
LAST-RESORT ATTEMPTS
The pilot made one final attempt to prevent the ship from colliding with the Key Bridge.
At 1:27:42, the pilot asked the crew if the ship had bow thrusters. According to The Baltimore Banner, the device helps guide ships laterally while docking.
After the crew confirmed to the pilot that the ship had bow thrusters, the second officer delivered devastating news: "No. It's not working."
"Not working #," the pilot said, with an expletive marked by a pound sign in the transcript. These would be the pilot's final words before the collision, which is estimated by the transcript to have occurred at 1:29:06 a.m.
What followed was a story that Dundalk knows well: six construction workers dead and a span that connected Baltimore left twisted in spirals of steel.
As the collision is still under investigation, around 12 Dali crewmen remain in Baltimore. This June marks a year since the crew was allowed to leave the ship, as cleanup efforts, expired visas and maritime law complicated their departure.
To read the full transcript, including the events before and after the Dali lost power, visit the docket at ntsb.gov/investigations/Pages/DCA24MM031.aspx

title: Cambridge police get a raise. City council member says it's not enough
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Cambridge police get a raise. City council member says it's not enough

 June 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Local News 
 
 349
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Cambridge has raised police salaries by 3% along with a $3,000 add-on in the fiscal year 2026 budget. But that's not enough, according to City Council Member Brett Summers."I don't feel like that's quite enough given what some of our neighboring jurisdictions are paying and the fact that we are losing officers to these jurisdictions," Summers said during a City Council meeting May 19.
According to Police Chief Justin Todd, the Cambridge Police Department currently has 36 officers with the possibility of two more joining upon their successful completion of the police academy. "Back in 2022, we were down to 29 officers, so we've done a lot of work," Todd said.
Todd said the department has struggled with officer retention for quite some time. Summers affirmed this, saying officers of all ranks are leaving to join departments in neighboring areas that offer higher wages, better benefits or less crime.
In 2024, Cambridge was ranked the third most dangerous city in Maryland, with Baltimore following fourth. The city also had the third highest rate of rape cases in 2022, averaging nearly one a month according to a study done by RoadSnacks, which analyzed FBI crime data to determine the ranks. The study examined violent and property crime per capita for every place in Maryland with over 5,000 residents.
"We don't want to be at the top of that list," Summers said.
Todd compiled numbers of police incomes from neighboring law enforcement agencies and presented them to Summers, who came up with a proposal for the commission.
Summers proposed raising the salary add-on based on officer rank. Privates would receive $3,000, corporals would receive $6,000, sergeants would receive $8,000 and lieutenants and Todd would receive $10,000.
Down the line, Summers plans on looking into a 10-year step pay scale, which will increase officers' salaries a certain amount yearly.
"We want to be competitive," Summers said.
"I think it would be a big benefit not only for the department, but for the city as a whole," Todd said.
The City Council is continuing to discuss the fiscal year 2026 budget and hopes to sign it in later in June.

 CENTREVILLE — In a Wednesday interview, Queen Anne's County Sheriff Gary Hofmann emphasized that the homicide investigation into the shooting death of 19-year-old Christopher Parsley remains the department's primary focus.Parsley was shot and killed on Sunday, June 1, near a residence on Centreville Road while attending a bonfire with friends.
"We're dealing with a homicide here, and that's going to take precedence," Hofmann said. He noted that many attendees at the party have not come forward, and some individuals may be hesitant to share information out of fear of legal consequences related to underage drinking or drug use. "Let us be clear: We are not seeking to prosecute anyone for those actions," he said.
Hofmann encouraged the public to provide any information, stressing that failing to do so could hinder the investigation. "This shouldn't happen here," Hofmann stressed, "We're not going tolerate this happening here."
Having information that could aid in the investigation and withholding it, is definitely not helpful to the family of individual that you were friends with, Hofmann reiterated. It is hope that the person/s involved in this incident will soon be held accountable.
The Sheriff also warned that social media platforms like Instagram and Snapchat have exacerbated the problem, with parties being posted online drawing unwanted attention.
In addition to the ongoing investigation, Metro Crime Stoppers of Maryland is offering a cash reward for information leading to the arrest of the person or persons responsible for Parsley's death. All tips submitted through Metro Crime Stoppers are anonymous and eligible for a reward. Anyone with information is encouraged to call 1-866-7LOCKUP or submit an anonymous tip online at www.metrocrimestoppers.org.
"Christopher wasn't just a 'good kid' — he was the best," said friends of the family. "He was the kind of young man who would drop everything to help a friend, offer a smile to a stranger, and light up every room he walked into." A GoFundMe page has been created to help with funeral expenses, help support his family during this tragic time, and to pay off his truck loan, a symbol of something Christopher was proud of.

title: Human remains found on farm during Cherrywood Solar construction
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Human remains found on farm during Cherrywood Solar construction

 June 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News

 Words

 GREENSBORO — On May 20, while Cherrywood Solar workers were at Ronald Spearing Farm, human remains were found."They found that while they were conducting grading activities at the Spearing Farm on Bridgetown Road, and they immediately stopped work, secured the area and went to their plan," said Crystal Dadds, Caroline County director of planning and codes.
"Cherrywood has a plan when anytime they come across what's called an 'unanticipated discovery,' they made all the proper notifications contacting Public Service Commission, the Maryland Historical Trust, the sheriff's office, the state's attorney, the planning and code, the health officer, roped off the area, covered the area with tarps to protect it because we did have bad weather."
Cherrywood then brought in Search, an organization that has an archeological team to do a preliminary assessment of the area where they presumed remains were found.
The Search team then made a determination that there were human remains at the site. Five burial plots were discovered.
Cherrywood Solar brought the team back to do an ground-penetrating radar to see if there were any more potential burial sights. Once the final report from that test comes back, the Burial Sites Preservation Board in Caroline County will review that data and make a recommendation of what area needs to be protected.
Cherrywood Solar, produced by NextEra Energy Resources LLC, is a 145-megawatt project in Caroline County.
NextEra Energy Resources sent a press release to the Star Democrat Wednesday stating, "We are cooperating with Caroline County and other pertinent agencies on the investigation. Once we receive clearance from the relevant authorities, we will resume construction activities."
All parties involved believe that there was no foul play involved. They are believed to be human remains of family members from previous property owners.
"Given the fact that the house on this farm is a late 1800s house, most likely it was a family burial plot that could date back that far," Dadds said.

 A Newark park will be closed for the foreseeable future after a recent inspection found "significant safety concerns and hazardous conditions," city officials said.One of the city's lesser-known parks, Coleman Park is located near the Maryland border, bounded by Valley Road and the Country Hills and Briarcreek neighborhoods. The main entrance is in Country Hills.
The 8.5-acre park contains walking trails but otherwise is preserved in its natural state.
The inspection found that the tree canopy near the entrance to the park consists of many black locust trees that are structurally compromised by fungal decay and pose a significant risk of falling.
The walking paths are eroded and surrounded by dense thickets of greenbrier, multiflora rose and poison ivy.
"These thorny species have overgrown the area and become entangled with large woody debris from fallen trees and limbs," City Manager Tom Coleman wrote in a memo to city council. "Significant land clearing and tree removal must be completed before we can reopen the park."
The city does not have funding for such work in the 2025 budget, according to Coleman, who did not provide any indication as to when the park might reopen.
The city's five-year capital improvement plan includes plans for broader improvements to Coleman Park, such as building a turf/meadow area, planting new trees and possibly paving the trails. However that $50,000 in funding, which is dependent on a state grant, is not budgeted until 2027.
Coleman Park was created in 1993 when Newark purchased the land for $180,000 and annexed it into the city. It is named for the family that previously owned the property.
