title: Cambridge man found not guilty of murder in shooting last year
author: Konner Metz
content:
Cambridge man found not guilty of murder in shooting last year

 June 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 775
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — After just over an hour of jury deliberation Thursday afternoon, a Cambridge man was acquitted of charges in connection to the fatal shooting of 26-year-old Virgil Simms last year.Jo'Mir Norman, 18, was found not guilty on all counts, including first-degree murder, assault charges, and firearm and handgun charges. Family and friends of Norman embraced outside the court room. Norman's father, Joseph Norman, said his son was wrongly accused and said it was relieving to hear the not guilty verdict.
During the trial, Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard relied on video evidence to piece together Norman's whereabouts and the clothes she said he wore the day of the murder.
On Oct. 20, 2024, Cambridge Police Department officers responded to the area of Pine Street just after 7 p.m. for reports of a shooting. Investigators determined 19 rounds were fired by two different shooters. Simms was pronounced dead on the scene, sustaining a gunshot wound to the chest.
On Thursday, jurors rewatched videos that had been closely examined during the four-day trial. Leonard argued camera evidence showed Norman and the other shooter flee from the scene and enter a house on Camelia Street, where clothes allegedly worn by Norman the day of the murder were found by investigators.
But defense attorney Molly Fox told jurors that prosectors relied too heavily on circumstantial evidence and had glaring holes in their arguments, such as the fact that surveillance video meant to bolster clothing and vehicle evidence jumped from a 1 p.m. convenience store video to a 6 p.m. video an hour before the shooting.
Fox called the state's case against Norman "a circus" like she's never seen before.
"There was a lot they didn't even try and present," Fox said in an interview after the verdict was announced. "It just seemed like it was thrown together last second."
Fox cited a lack of direct witness testimony, missing videos and issues during the discovery process leading up to the trial as reasons why "the evidence did not point toward my client."
Prosecutors encountered some specific challenges during witness testimony.
On Monday, an EMT who responded to the scene testified that she saw Simms with a gunshot wound to the head, though it was established during trial that he sustained a chest wound. And during the trial, a state's witness who allegedly dropped off the two shooters the day of the murder did not confirm that Norman was one of the men she drove that day. Leonard called that witness "young" and dealing with a "very packed court room."
"Don't be fooled by the shaved head here today," Leonard noted to jurors, referencing Norman's buzz cut Thursday compared to longer hair he had when arrested.
Fox also reminded jurors of a key mistake in the early days of the murder investigation: Maryland State Police wrongly arrested then-15-year-old Brian Wongus Jr. at the same time they charged Norman in October.
Attorneys on both sides acknowledged police misidentified Wongus as one of the shooters. An MSP spokesperson said Tuesday that charges against Wongus were dropped in late October or early November.
Leonard said the evidence investigators used when wrongly charging Wongus was "very different" from the evidence presented against Norman at the trial. She said jurors received "no testimony at any time that Jo'Mir Norman was misidentified."
Fox said while video evidence can be useful, it can also lead to wrong identifications.
"You have nothing more than what they had when Brian Wongus was arrested," Fox told the jury.
The lead-up to Thursday's verdict and the reaction afterward was emotional but civil on both sides, with family of both Simms and Norman attending. When the trial began Monday, Simms' mother Yolanda Hernandez took the witness stand.
Hernandez provided a brief but emotional testimony as prosecutors asked her about her son.
Hernandez said she and Simms had grown closer since he had two young children. She said he liked to cook, grill and joke around. "He was a decent guy," Hernandez said.
Leonard told The Star Democrat after the verdict that she respects the jury but was "disappointed" in the outcome. She declined to comment further, citing an active case against the man police arrested after misidentifying Wongus, 19-year-old Jahmere Bryan.
Bryan, from Cambridge, faces the following charges in connection to the Simms shooting: first- and second-degree murder, first- and second-degree assault, use of a firearm while committing a felony, and three other firearm and handgun charges.
A May 19 hearing for Bryan in the Dorchester County Circuit Court was postponed. A jury trial is scheduled for next month, but Leonard said Thursday that trial is expected to be pushed back due to a change of Bryan's defense attorney.

title: Man pleads guilty to 2021 murder of Trappe woman

Man pleads guilty to 2021 murder of Trappe woman

 A man has pleaded guilty to the murder of a Trappe woman that took place on Christmas Eve in 2021.Mauricio Ibarra Juarez, 33, entered an Alford plea on May 23 for a first-degree murder charge in connection to the killing of Marta Merina over three years ago.
Judge Philip Cronan handed down a life sentence with all but 75 years suspended.
"I am confident that Mr. Juarez will spend the rest of his life in prison for this heinous crime," said Talbot County State's Attorney Joseph Coale in a press release.
An Alford plea allows a person to maintain their innocence while acknowledging the state had enough evidence to obtain a conviction. Five other counts levied against Juarez — including second-degree murder and first-degree assault charges — will not be prosecuted.
The morning of the murder, police responded to Howell Point Road in Trappe for a reported shooting. Merina, 33, was found outside her home and pronounced dead on the scene.
A few days later, following an investigation, Maryland State Police issued a warrant for Juarez in connection to the murder.
Per the recent state's attorney's office press release, investigators traced a phone found at the scene to Juarez. They also worked with police in Virginia — where Juarez lived at the time — to match a vehicle driven by Juarez to what was found on nearby security footage the night of the murder, according to court documents.
Juarez was located by Mexican authorities for an unrelated crime in Oaxaca, Mexico in 2022. The U.S. Department of Justice's Office of International Affairs worked with Mexican prosecutors to request Juarez's provisional arrest. Extradition was granted later that year, but was deferred pending completion of Juarez's sentence in Mexico.
Last October, Juarez was extradited to Maryland. His 75-year sentence will credit back to February 2023. Juarez is being held without bond.

title: Kayak group offers law enforcement, firefighters, vets a chance to relax
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
Kayak group offers law enforcement, firefighters, vets a chance to relax

 June 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 734
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Sure, dropping his fishing rod overboard while his son Shane fought to land a chain pickerel during the Heroes on the Water event Saturday at St. Mary's River State Park could have been an embarrassing moment, but Thornton Jackson was just planning ahead.Kayaks can be very temperamental when it comes to balance, so the Waldorf resident was just jettisoning weight in anticipation of the weight of the fish being added to the tandem kayak. Or that one excuse, anyways.
"I did do that," he said happily — and somewhat relieved — when it was suggested to him.
The event was held to allow first responders, law enforcement, firefighters and military veterans a chance to relax and and take a few casts if they so desired.
"It's not serious fishing. We're just out to have a good time, relaxing time on the water," said Maryland Chapter Coordinator Chris Vassallo, who spent 21 years as a senior chief in the U.S. Navy on submarines and recently retired following a career with the Office of Naval Intelligence. "You're maneuvering the kayak, you're using your fishing tackle to try and outsmart [the fish] and it takes your mind off everything else. It shuts that noise off and gives your brain some peace and for me that's what this is all about."
Thornton Jackson spent 13 years as a Yeoman in the U.S. Navy and was deployed "multiple times" and even missed the birth of Shane, "but it was also nice getting back and meeting him at the pier."
And Thornton Jackson certainly appreciated the father-son bonding time.
"It's definitely nice to get away from everything and just being out here spending time with him and just be a dad," said Jackson, who has worked in naval intelligence for the past two years. "Right now I'm here for a bit, but with deployments you never know when they're going to pop up. Just getting some time out on a Saturday and putting the work away to focus on him is great."
"It was fun to spend time with him," said 8-year-old Shane, who reeled in several fish. "I miss him a lot [when he's gone]."
Vassallo found out about the organization while listening to a podcast and attended an event in Montgomery County.
"That was something that I wanted, something that I wanted to establish here in Southern Maryland," he said. "To me this is what it's all about; having the camaraderie and being out on the water and enjoying the time on the water."
He co-coordinated two events and coordinated previous events this year in Laytonsville and Salisbury. The next event will be held July 26 at Mallows Bay in Charles County.
One of the volunteers at the event was Wayne Stinchcomb, a retired U.S. Army chaplain.
"Some of these guys are going through trials and tribulations for what they're going through. They're going through counseling. But when you do something like this it gets them back into real life," he said. "[They think] I can do this, I can be around my guys and I don't have to worry about something or what somebody might think because we're all going through it or been through it. One guy was here just to float in the sun. He didn't even take his pole out. He said the whole idea was to be and relax. If you've been in combat or anything you've been around, and you're around like-minded folks, there's an ease in that."
Mark Anderson of Kent Island drove about two hours to volunteer for the event.
"I didn't serve but I've shot [guns and rifles] competitively with a lot of people who are veterans," said Anderson, who is works in information technology and captured the event with his drone. "I just got to know a lot of them and really appreciate what they do for this country and the sacrifices they've made."
"I just love the military and fishing so that's how I figured I could at least give back," said Nathan Miller, who drove down from Westminster to assist at the event. "My friend brought me out once [to a Heroes on the Water event] and I've been hooked ever since. If there's an event and I know about it ahead of time, I'll figure out a way to help. It's good to see [them relax]. It's worth the drive."
For more information on how to participate or to volunteer at the Mallows Bay event on July 26, email maryland@heroesonthewater.org.

title: Video of presumed ICE arrest sparks confusion, fear in Cambridge
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Video of presumed ICE arrest sparks confusion, fear in Cambridge

 June 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 705
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Immigrant communities are living in fear after arrests of immigrants have taken a new shape under the Trump administration.A Facebook video of unmarked vehicles with federal agents in bulletproof vests and ski masks arresting four men on Maryland Avenue off Route 50 in Cambridge has been circulating throughout the community.
"You know, it's definitely something we knew was coming, but we didn't know it was gonna be handled this way," said Julie Martinez, who recorded and uploaded the video to Facebook.
Residents and commenters of the video believe these agents to be Immigration and Customs Enforcement officials. The Department of Homeland Security has not responded to The Star Democrat's request for details about the incident.
Since President Donald Trump's inauguration, ICE raids have looked different. Washington, D.C., immigration attorney of over 25 years Matthew Famiglietti said the legal gray area has grown significantly due to rapid policy changes such as getting rid of safe spaces like churches, courts, hospitals and schools.
"Talking about what's legal and what's not legal, that's changed quite a bit since Trump," Famiglietti said.
Trump campaigned on stepping up immigration enforcement, promising to deliver the largest mass deportation in American history. ICE arrests have increased by 25% since he took office, according to the most recent ICE detention data.
To make this possible Trump signed five immigration-based executive orders on his first day, instated enforcement and structural changes within federal agencies like Customs and Border Control and ICE, conducted mass arrests including in safe spaces, and enacted travel bans from 12 countries, according to the White House's website.
Famiglietti said ICE agents and the Department of Homeland Security are under no legal obligation to let local law enforcement agencies know of their actions.
Cambridge police Capt. Antoine Patton and Dorchester County Sheriff Jimmy Phillips both said they were not aware of the arrests made on June 4.
The Cambridge Maryland Police Department's official Facebook made a post regarding the arrests saying, "We have received several phone calls and inquiries regarding photos passed through social media showing subjects being detained/arrested within the city limits by law enforcement. The law enforcement in the pictures is not anyone associated with the Cambridge Police Department, and we have no knowledge of the incident(s) that took place."
Martinez said around 7:15 a.m. June 4, four unmarked cars surrounded a work truck and began making what she called "unclear" announcements through a speaker while arresting the four individuals on Maryland Avenue.
"As you can see in the video, they didn't even give them time at all to even explain or say why you're getting pulled over," Martinez said. "It was very quick, so when I saw it, my first thing was 'oh my gosh, there's no way this is happening.'"
Famiglietti said ICE agents do not have to show their faces or ride in marked cars, but they have to wear some sort of identifying detail. Martinez said the agents' bulletproof vests said "Police," but that was the only identifying mark.
Martinez said she immediately pulled out her phone and began recording. She said she's always recording because "you never know what could happen, especially right now."
The video quickly caught traction, with 554 shares, 176 reactions and 135 comments on Facebook. The post made its way to the family members of the detained individuals, who, according to Martinez, were not aware of the arrests before the video.
Out of the 135 comments on Martinez's post, multiple alluded to further ICE actions around Cambridge. However, those actions were not verified.
Famiglietti said concerned residents and those looking for family members who may be detained should call their senators and representatives for information.
"That's the No. 1 thing," he said.
On June 14, demonstrations will be held across the nation on what protesters are calling "No King Day" in response to the administration's immigration policies and the actions of ICE agents. Protests are planned in Easton and Cambridge on that day, according to posts made on social media.
Martinez said the immigrant community has to be especially careful right now.
"Drive at the speed limit. Do everything you're supposed to be doing," she said. "You know we contribute to this country a lot, and unfortunately, we can't stay home. We can't do much but to keep going forward, but definitely stay more on the low."

North East mom, boyfriend charged in murder of toddler

 Author/Byline: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com | Section: News

 Words

 NORTH EAST — Maryland State Police have charged Darrian Lynelle Randle of North East with first and second degree murder in the death of her 3-year-old daughter, Nola Dinkins.Her boyfriend, Cedrick Antoine Britten, 44, from North East, is charged as an accessory. He's being held in the Cecil County Detention Center on a $75,000 bond.
Dinkins body — described in charging documents released Thursday as "consistent with an emaciated child and were completely wrapped in saran (sic) wrap" — was found in the unit block of Dune Drive in North East inside a blue suitcase.
Randle and Dinkins were living in Britten's home when the alleged crime took place, according to police. The pair shared a room in the home on Elk Nest Road
Charging documents indicate Randle beat the child 15-20 times Monday with a belt. When the child fell to the ground, she noticed the child was no longer breathing.
"Randle stated that Britten attempted CPR ... but eventually realized (Nola Dinkins) was deceased," the documents filed in Cecil County District Court of Maryland read.
Becoming upset, Randle told police that the body was placed in Britten's vehicle — a BMW — and the couple drove around for awhile.
"Randle stated that once they returned to the residence she placed (the body) in a dark blue suitcase belonging to Britten," the court documents read. The suitcase was placed on the third step of the basement stairs overnight. She checked on the suitcase one time, then asked Britten to take it from the house.
Britten told investigators he took the suitcase away, later sending Randle a photo of a park.
On Tuesday, Randle told New Castle County Police the child had been kidnapped from her vehicle at gunpoint; a story later determined to be false. While searching for Dinkins, police questioned Britten, who was described as having "little to no reaction" to word that the child had been reported missing.
At the home, investigators noticed a distinct odor of bleach. Blue nitrile gloves were found during a search; one pair in a downstairs trash can and another pair in the room that Randle and Dinkins shared.
Investigators searched Perryville Community Park in response to the photo of a park, but ultimately located Dinkins' body — still in the suitcase — on a vacant lot near Britten's home.
Randle, being held by New Castle County Police on a $1 million bond for a charge of filing a false police report, is now facing numerous charged in Maryland including first- and second-degree murder, first- and second-degree assault, reckless endangerment, child abuse resulting in death, neglect, failure to report a child death and unauthorized disposal of a body.
Britten is charged with eight counts including accessory after the fact to first- and second-degree murder, neglect of a minor, unauthorized disposal of a body, and failure to report a child's death.
The body has been taken to the Office of the Medical Examiner for an autopsy and positive identification.
Police officials have yet to say when Randle will be extradited from Delaware to Maryland.

title: Attorney general visits Easton to honor first responders at annual celebration

Attorney general visits Easton to honor first responders at annual celebration

 EASTON — First responders across different Talbot County agencies were honored Thursday in Easton by local residents, business leaders and Maryland Attorney General Anthony Brown.Bluepoint Hospitality Group hosted the fifth annual First Responders Celebration, closing down North Washington Street temporarily on Thursday afternoon to pay thanks to the county's police officers, firefighters, EMTs and other first responders.
"These people put their lives on the line so that we can live in a civil and safe community," said Bluepoint Hospitality owner Paul Prager.
The event was headlined by Maryland Attorney General Anthony Brown, who called the Talbot County first responders — paid or volunteers — "heroes."
"When others run away from danger, you run toward it," Brown said. "From volunteers who respond to dangerous house fires in the middle of the night, to police officers who take drugs, and guns and bad people off our streets, to emergency medical service personnel who rush people to the hospital for life-saving care, our first responders are the backbone of public safety and the cornerstone of our communities."
During the brief ceremonies, Ed Forte, vice president of the Friends of Easton Volunteer Fire Department, revealed a new rendering of an in-construction training campus to Easton Fire Chief J.R. Dobson.
The A. James Clark Emergency Services Training Campus, located on Mistletoe Drive, will be 7,200 square feet and provide state-of-the-art training opportunities for all first responders.
As the rendering showed, a building on the training campus will be named after Paul Prager and his wife, Joanne. The Pragers donated $500,000 to the project.
Forte said Thursday that $4.5 million has been raised in the last two-and-a-half years, nearly all of the project's $5 million goal. Project leaders hope for the campus to open by the end of this year.
"(It's) taken many, many years; many, many people; many hours; many ideas," Forte said. " … Raising the money was the hardest thing."
After the event, Brown said in an interview he's impressed with the coordination between the different first responder agencies in Talbot County.
"Often people think small, rural community on the Eastern Shore, 'how busy does it get?'" Brown said. "But clearly the numbers show that they're busy. It's important to stand ready. The facility that is going to be built is going to help them do that."
When asked afterward if the First Responders Celebration is becoming a tradition, Prager had no hesitation.
"It's gotta be, absolutely," Prager said. "These people do thankless jobs. And there's not a whole lot you can do to enable them to make their lives better. So I think if you at least just say thank you, that goes a long way."

Knocking on people's doors at night is bad idea

 June 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GLENN MOLLETTE | Section: Columns 
 
 552
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The recent murder of Minnesota state Rep. Melissa Hortman and her husband, Mark, has dropped jaws across the country. The couple was gunned down in their home by someone masquerading as a police officer. Obviously, he was able to fool them long enough to kill them. Moments before and only five miles away he had visited the home of Minnesota state Sen. John Hoffman and his wife, Yvette, shooting them multiple times, most likely thinking he was leaving them for dead.At this writing they are expected to survive.
Such an intrusion scares people because criminals copy the acts of other criminals. How do we know if a legitimate policer officer is knocking on our door whether it's the middle of the night or the middle of the day?
Two officers should make the visit and announce themselves as police loud and clear. They should clearly state the reason for the visit before entering a home. Flashlights or outside lighting should be on to help with visibility and identification. Uniforms should be visible with badges and IDs. The knock pattern should be a firm knock or doorbell press then they should announce themselves as police again. There should be a 30-second to one-minute wait for a response from the resident before knocking or ringing the doorbell again. For a search warrant, the warrant should be shown before entry. Your local sheriff or city chief of police may have a different protocol, and it needs to be made known.
Unfortunately, this still doesn't keep a criminal from copying the protocol to achieve their criminal endeavor.
I believe 99 percent of Americans are good law-abiding people. However, no one wants to be caught off guard by a criminal invasion. Rep. Hortman would not have wanted to mistakenly shoot a real policer officer who might have been doing his job to protect her. Sadly, the man was there to kill her and her husband. He succeeded. This is why door knocking after dusk is a bad idea unless you have a pre-arranged appointment, and everyone knows who everyone is and the reason for the visit.
When I was 12 years old, I was home alone while my parents were at church. About 8 o'clock it was pitch black with darkness and a man started knocking on our front door. He then went to the back door and started knocking. He then came back to the front door and continued pounding the door. I was terrified. I didn't know who it could be. I loaded our 12-gauge shotgun and aimed it at the front door in fear he would soon be coming through.
Like a fool, I opened the door but knew the outer storm door was locked. I had the shot gun close by. The man asked if my dad was home to which I replied, "No. he's gone to church." The man then inquired if my father still had hogs for sale to which I replied, "Yes, but you'll need to speak to him about that." The man said he would come back later.
To this day I don't know who that man was, but I'm glad I didn't shoot him. It's too bad Rep. Hortman or Sen. Hoffman didn't shoot the man knocking on their door in the middle of the night.
Knocking on doors at night is a bad idea.

No injuries were reported.Around 1:20 p.m. Saturday, the St. Michaels Fire Department responded to a fire at a six-unit town house complex on Martingham Circle. Assistant Chief Phil Jones said a second alarm was requested. Agencies from Talbot, Caroline, Dorchester and Queen Anne's counties assisted, with at least 70 people on the scene.

All firefighters were required to receive a medical check on their vitals, Jones said. Crews went through over 20 cases of bottled waters.
Jones emphasized that the firefighters on scene were all volunteers. He expressed appreciation for the responding units from surrounding counties, as the additional manpower was necessary for such a hot day. Jones said there was good cooperation with the homeowners and between fire agencies.

title: Demolition of remaining Key Bridge structures beginning around July 7
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@chespub.com
content:
Demolition of remaining Key Bridge structures beginning around July 7

 June 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 457
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Demolition of the remaining Key Bridge structures will begin on or about July 7, the Maryland Transportation Authority announced on June 26.The work is expected to take several months to complete and will involve the use of heavy machinery to dismantle what is left of the bridge.
The process will begin with the removal of the bridge deck over the river, followed by demolition of sections over Hawkins Point and then Sollers Point, the Maryland Transportation Authority said in a release.
This phase of work focuses on removing portions of the existing structure that interfere with the alignment of the new bridge.
No controlled detonations will occur.
The general demolition sequence will include the removal of deck, barriers and parapets over the river from both Hawkins Point and Sollers Point, followed by the removal of deck, barriers, parapets, girders and piers on the landside approaches, down to just below ground level.
Finally, the original north and south abutments will be removed.
Nearby communities should expect to see active tug and barge operations on the river, with heavy equipment and trucks visible on the existing bridge structure.
Barges will serve as protective shielding during demolition and must be avoided by waterway users. Machinery used may include excavators, concrete saws, vacuums, cranes and trucks.
An on-site concrete crusher will recycle materials for haul roads and staging areas, reducing truck trips and cost.
Typical large construction project noise is expected from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m.
Equipment is being installed in nearby communities to capture baseline noise and vibration data before the start of demolition and upcoming construction activities.
Buoys will mark a safety zone, no entry area around active work areas.
Notices will be issued to designate speed restrictions and safety zones to ensure the safe passage of vessels near the construction area.
The Maryland Transportation Authority said that it will continue to provide updates and advance notice of any work that may affect nearby communities, roads or waterways.
Based on months of field investigations and engineering analysis, the bridge alignment is slightly east or downriver of the original structure, remaining entirely within the Maryland Transportation Authority's existing right-of-way. To proceed with construction, the Maryland Transportation Authority is requesting modifications to permits that have been issued by the Maryland Board of Public Works, Maryland Department of the Environment, U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and the U.S. Coast Guard in support of the Key Bridge Rebuild, according to the release.
The permit modification requests will reflect updates to the bridge pier foundation design, pier protection elements, and trestle configuration. They also include a decrease in authorized impacts to tidal waters and some additional impacts to non-tidal wetlands and waterways.
A reevaluation of the project's categorical exclusion will also be submitted to the Federal Highway Administration.
No significant increase in environmental impacts is expected, the release said.

Stone, 46, of Aberdeen — fatally shot Christopher Blaine Thomas, 46, in his chest and Thomas' cohabiting girlfriend, Ashley Dove Brown, five times on July 1, 2023 inside the bedroom of an abandoned house in the 100 block of Bethel Church Road.

Perry is facing three life sentences and a significant humber of additional years after a jury convicted him of two counts of first-degree murder and 31 related charges on May 1 at the conclusion of a four-day-long trial, after deliberating about 90 minutes.
"I hope you both rot in Hades and that God . . . not . . . have . . . mercy . . . on . . . your . . . souls," Jerry Brown, the father of Ashley Brown, remarked Monday during his victim impact statement while standing at a courtroom podium a few feet away from Stone, seated at the defense table in a jail uniform.
Brown purposely left pregnant pauses between the last few words of his comment for emphasis. Brown told the judge that he still cries frequently over the senseless taking of his daughter's life. "They murdered a big part of me," he said.
Moments earlier, his 64-year-old wife, Bonnie Brown, who discovered the bodies of her daughter and Thomas, commented, "I have a life sentence of PTSD, and they have shown no remorse," during her victim-impact statement in the courtroom. (The Browns have been married for 38 years.)
Thomas' surviving family members also read victim-impact statements with similar sentiments aloud in the courtroom, including his mother and son, who listed his high school graduation and his senior walk off the football field as some of the milestones that his murdered father missed. Thomas' daughter submitted a written victim-impact statement to the judge and appeared on courtroom screen via Zoom.
Assistant State's Attorney Scott Lewis described the murders of Brown and Thomas as a "very senseless crime" while making his sentence recommendation. Lewis also told the judge that he is still taken aback by the "brutality of it," noting that bullets lethally damaged the hearts of both victims and that the fatal gunshot for Brown was fired while she was prone on the floor, already wounded.
"What compassion was shown? Where is the sense of humanity?" Lewis asked rhetorically.
Cecil County Circuit Court Judge William W. Davis Jr. imposed sentences on Stone that matched Lewis' recommendation.
Davis imposed a life sentence on Stone for first-degree murder relating to Brown; a consecutive life sentence for first-degree murder relating to Thomas; and a consecutive life sentence for conspiracy to commit first-degree murder.
In addition, the judge imposed a consecutive 25-year sentence on Stone for home invasion and then suspended 15 years of the penalty, leaving Stone with an additional 10 years of incarceration.
Davis also imposed two consecutive 20-year sentences on Stone for armed robbery and use of a handgun in the commission of a felony or a crime of violence, before suspending 10 years of each of those penalties. The judge noted that the use-of-a-handgun conviction carries a mandatory five-year sentence.
On April 4, at the conclusion of a four-day-long trial, a jury deliberated approximately five hours before convicting Stone of all 45 charges against him. The majority of those convictions merged into other convictions during Monday's sentencing.
Stone maintained his innocence at sentencing and, through his defense lawyer, Michael J. Halter, he indicated that he planned to file an appeal.
Prefacing that Stone does not lack "sympathy and empathy," Halter told the judge, "He had nothing to do with this crime. He has been adamant since Day One that he did not participate in these crimes."
Halter noted that Stone's convicted co-defendant, Perry, had "a grudge with Thomas over a drug sale" and that Stone had had no interactions with Thomas.
The defense lawyer stressed that, on the morning of the double murder, Stone unwittingly accompanied Perry and one other man in a convoy from their Aberdeen residence to the abandoned house where Brown and Thomas were living.
(Brown and Thomas were recovering drug addicts, and they had been squatting in that abandoned house with boarded-up windows and no electricity for approximately eight months, according to trial testimony, which indicated that Thomas sometimes borrowed a generator to power the place.)
"He (Stone) was with them, but he did not know what they were going to do. He was at the wrong place at the wrong time with the wrong people," Halter assertively summarized.
Halter asked the judge to run the sentences concurrently, opining that, otherwise, Stone would have "no possibility to see the light of day."
Stone stood at the defense table and maintained his innocence during his allocution, telling the judge, "The events that happened, I had no part in it. No life should be (taken)."
From the bench, Davis reminded Stone that the jury had spoken.
The judge reviewed that the evidence that Cecil County Sheriff's Office detectives, deputies and crime-scene technicians collected included Stone's registered handgun — one of firearms used in the double murder — and that it had Stone's DNA on it. (Investigators recovered the stolen cell phones belonging to Brown and Thomas inside Perry's bedroom, in the same Aberdeen house were Stone was living.) Incriminating text messages also were gathered.
Collected evidence also included distinctive masks matching those described by an eyewitness who saw an unmasked Perry accompanied by masked men on that Bethel Church Road property on the morning of July 1, 2023. Moments after that group arrived on a motorcycle and in a car, the eyewitness heard someone kick in the front door of the abandoned house, a scream and then a gunshot, which prompted him to run into the wood in fear.
In addition, the judge reviewed that CCSO investigators had tracked down several videos gleaned from security-cameras between Aberdeen and North East and that those videos showed Stone traveling in that caravan to that Bethel Church Road property on the morning of the double murder and directly after it occurred.
"It's hard not to listen to the jury and to what the (surviving) family (members) said," Davis told Stone from the bench.

Police are actively investigating the incident.
In the hours since, many residents from Greensboro and Caroline County have made donations in honor of the children as well as planned for a funeral fundraiser next weekend.
A MealTrain link shared on Facebook on Monday raised over $5,000 in donations for the family as of Tuesday afternoon. The MealTrain also facilitates a calendar for neighbors to provide meals to the family.
"We are completely overwhelmed with the love, support, and kindness that has surrounded us during the most unimaginable time of our lives. Losing our babies has broken our hearts in ways we never thought possible — but we have felt every prayer, hug, message, and meal that's been shared with us," said Michael Puckett, the father of the two boys, on behalf of the Puckett family in a statement to the Star Democrat on Tuesday.
Greensboro resident Victor Reynolds is spearheading a funeral fundraiser, tentatively slated for July 13 at 1 p.m. at the Greater Impact church in Greensboro. He says it will be a chance for the community to help the family financially.
"Nobody expects to have to afford that," Reynolds said.
Reynolds owns a food truck, Bayside Hotdogs, which will offer meals with all proceeds going to the family, he said. Other food vendors are expected to attend as well as local businesses, some of which will host fundraising raffles.

"Being parents ourselves, this story really kind of hit close to home," Thomas said. " ... It honestly just broke my heart, and it had been weighing on me heavily for the last day or two."
While the Puckett family hasn't been able to respond to all the messages they have received from the community, they appreciate the support.

title: Officials emphasize firework safety ahead of July 4
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com

Officials emphasize firework safety ahead of July 4

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 275
 Words

 EASTON — Fourth of July is right around the corner, and many residents and towns will began setting off fireworks to celebrate.Fireworks come with risks from starting fires to injuries of an individual, safety officials say. Residents are advised to follow certain protocols to keep celebrations safe.
Master Deputy State Fire Marshal Oliver Alkire recommends residents to go to public fireworks shows. For those who are dead-set on setting fireworks off themselves, Alkire doesn't recommend going over state lines to purchase fireworks.
"If you are going to be using any fireworks, just to keep in mind that you should only be purchasing and using fireworks that you are buying within your county or your area," he said. "... Anything that you can purchase at a roadside stand, I can assure you, has been inspected, or anywhere in any retail stores."
The most important thing Alkire emphasizes is only adults should handle fireworks.
"If you're going to light fireworks, only allow the adults to light the fireworks, only light one firework at a time, and also keep all children and pets away from fireworks," he said.
For those handling fireworks at home, Easton Volunteer Fire Department Chief J.R. Dobson recommends to have a water hose nearby and ready in case of a fire.
For fireworks that light and don't work, Alkire recommends putting the fireworks in a bucket of water for 24 hours, then disposing of them properly.
The state fire marshal's office recommend not putting fireworks anywhere on the body. In 2023, there were two deaths in Maryland resulting from people holding fireworks to their chest or head.
In the event of an emergency, people are advised to call 911 for assistance.

 DENTON — A poultry property outside Denton was the site of a fire Wednesday morning, marking the second consecutive day crews battled a blaze at the property's chicken houses.The two fires occurred at two different chicken houses located southwest of Denton on the 8600 block of Tuckahoe Road. Terry Tribbett's family owns the chicken houses. She said the first fire was at Tuckahoe River Farm Poultry LLC and the second at L&B Farms LLC.
The Denton Volunteer Fire Company, along with other agencies, responded to both incidents. Denton Fire Chief Doug Higgs said both were second-alarm fires, each taking around three hours to control.

In a statement Wednesday, Tribbett expressed deep appreciation for the volunteer firefighters.
"It doesn't matter if it's day or night, rain or shine, hot or cold, they are called and they come," Tribbett wrote. "We certainly appreciate all their efforts and dedication."
After Tuesday's fire, which began around 3:20 a.m., one firefighter received heat exhaustion treatment at a local hospital. No other injuries were reported. Higgs said no injuries occurred as a result of Wednesday's blaze.
On Tuesday, the Office of the State Fire Marshal released an investigation report on the first fire, estimating $525,000 in damages.
The fire marshal said the first fire's cause was still under investigation. On Wednesday, Higgs said both fires were likely due to electrical issues, though he noted that's not yet official.
"I think it's just unlucky," Higgs said. "Chicken houses are dirty because of the feathers and dust."
Tribbett said the family is thankful for all of the community members who have reached out with prayers and support in the last two days.

"We will be ready" for Friday, Shaw said. "It's just a minor setback."

 TRAPPE — The Trappe Volunteer Fire Company is raising funds to build an up-to-date firehouse. Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md. 1st) wants to secure federal funding to help.The Trappe Volunteer Firehouse was completed in 1951 and has not been updated since. "We probably have the oldest one in the county," Assistant Secretary Treasurer of the Trappe Volunteer Fire Company Cheryl Lewis said.
Lewis said a new firehouse is necessary because the current building is no longer suitable for the modern equipment.
Because Trappe has a volunteer fire company, like many towns on the Eastern Shore, projects like this rely heavily on government and local support, Lewis said.
"We've been in the process of trying to get assistance," Lewis said. "In the last budget year, the federal budget that was just approved, we had successfully worked with Andy Harris's office to be included in the budget. But with the cuts that were done early on this year, it was removed."
Harris said the appropriations bill to provide funding for the project failed due to negotiations in Congress leading to a continued delay, but she said the project has been reapplied for in the current year's legislation.
"We hope the appropriations process has a better outcome, but then that's not up to us because it involves the minority party as well," he said in an interview with the Star Democrat.
In order to qualify for federal grants, the company must match 25% of the projected project cost of $6 million. The company set a goal of $1,500,000 and set aside $450,000 to begin the efforts.
Fundraising efforts include The Trappe Volunteer Fire Company's upcoming annual fair, held on July 31 through Aug. 2 at the firehouse. The event begins at 6 p.m. and ends at 10 p.m. each day and will include fire truck rides, hay rides, food, games and prizes, and live entertainment, according to the fire company's Facebook page. Saturday's event will open with a parade.
Harris said the outcome of federal funding depends on the successful bipartisan negotiations in Congress to pass this version of the appropriations bill.
"In the end, this is going to depend on the minority party. And you know, if they're not willing to negotiate in good faith, that could end up being a problem," Harris said. "The people in Trappe have to know that their member of Congress was working hard to get that money to the fire company."

title: Ham it up: Queen Anne’s Amateur Radio Club has a 'Field Day'
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Ham it up: Queen Anne’s Amateur Radio Club has a 'Field Day'

 July 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 647
 Words 

 Read News Document

 QUEEN ANNE — Showcasing amateur radios are a versatile means of communication, adaptable and reliable in a pinch, the Queen Anne's Amateur Radio Club welcomed the public to its temporary transmitting stations as it hosted its annual Field Day at Tuckahoe State Park June 28 and 29.In addition to inviting everyone to check out amateur or "ham" radios and communication capabilities, the annual field day provides a great opportunity for members to practice skills and equipment closely to real emergency situations, Club President Corey Ruth said.
Easily the biggest annual ham radio event of the year, across North America, Field Day brings in the participation of 40,000 skilled "hams," to publicly demonstrate amateur radio's science and services, particularly for emergency situations, Ruth said.
Many members of Club are also part of Queen Anne's County Radio Amateur Civil Emergency Service that support the Queen Anne's County Department of Emergency Services and provide communications for first responders and emergency personnel in disaster situations, he said.
"It's a great opportunity to practice our technical skills in a simulated emergency environment and have fun doing it. We also love getting to introduce new people to the hobby at such a high-profile event," Ruth said.
With what is essentially the equivalent of a single lightbulb and no permanent infrastructure, ham radio operators can talk to people around the world.
"It's definitely important to have that as a backup and maintain that knowledge of how to use it, " Ruth said.
The public event helps serve as validation to the numerous ham radio volunteers who spend countless hours providing emergency communications, public service work and other benefits throughout the community and region, Ruth said.
This year's event was also notable as the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration predicted a more active hurricane season than normal and saw the first named storm of the season already, he said.
While incredibly important and useful, smartphone technology is often taken for granted and relies on a multi billion dollar infrastructure that, whether storms or computer glitches, doesn't take a lot to knock down, he said.
Radios are more than just an old fashioned means of communication, according to Ruth, with new technologies and capabilities always being added that can function on older equipment.
"It doesn't always have to be the latest and greatest equipment," he said.
The club recently introduced a program called WinLink Global Radio Email that, by connecting to pathways, essentially allows emails to be sent through ham radio, he said.
The area in Tuckahoe the field day event operated in was essentially a cell phone dead zone and a highlight of the event is showcasing to visiting groups including Scouts how the radios can connect with other operators across the country.
"Their eyes light up," Ruth said.
The Radio Club is a nonprofit organization dedicated to the promotion of amateur radio and service to the community and provides communications support to other local non-profit groups during public events.
Further supporting emergency preparedness education, the group also recently donated handheld Family Radio Service radios and tabletop weather radios to Homeland Security classes at Kent Island High School and Queen Anne's County High School, as well as sponsoring an Enrichment, Extension and Intervention class at Stevensville Middle School.
These classes are part of a broader initiative offering the Community Emergency Response Team program to students, in partnership with Queen Anne's County Department of Emergency Services.
The donated radios will be used to help provide hand-on experience for students to become familiar with radio communications, a vital component of public safety and emergency response training, Ruth said.
Donations were made possible through a grant by the Amateur Radio Relay League Foundation to promote knowledge and interest in ham radio among youths.
Happy to welcome anyone curious about ham radios, the Queen Anne's Amateur Radio Club meets monthly and regularly provides demonstrations at community events including all weeklong at the upcoming Queen Anne's County Fair.
More information can be found by contacting qso@qaarc.org or visiting qaarc.org.

Second teen charged with murder in Cambridge shooting

 CAMBRIDGE — An 18-year-old has been arrested on murder charges in connection to a fatal shooting in Cambridge last month, the second teen charged in the incident.Nisiah Fletcher of Cambridge was arrested Sunday by police. He's charged with 13 counts, including first- and second-degree murder, first- and second-degree assault, and other firearm and armed robbery charges.
Police identified Fletcher as an alleged participant in the June 8 shooting that killed 23-year-old Alyson Elien, of Seaford, Delaware. Just after 8:30 p.m. that night. Officers responded to the 900 bock of Camelia Street and found Elien lying outside of a vehicle in a driveway with a gunshot wound to his head. He was transported to the hospital and pronounced dead.
Video surveillance was used to identify Fletcher, as well the other suspect already charged with first-degree murder, according to court documents.
Jakai Wilson, 15, was arrested two days after the shooting. Wilson, who's being charged as an adult, is facing similar counts of murder, assault and firearm crimes.
Charging documents for Fletcher indicate that investigators used multiple city cameras to link Fletcher, Wilson and three unnamed "co-conspirators" in the lead up to the shooting.
Police allege that an unnamed person approached Elien's vehicle at 903 Camelia St. That person appeared "to either look into the vehicle to verify the victim's presence or potentially make contact," police wrote.
The person returned to where Fletcher, Wilson and others were, police say. Wilson approached the driver's side of the vehicle, followed by Fletcher and the three others, court documents state.
Charging documents allege Wilson opened the driver's side door and shot Elien in the head with a handgun. Elien fell to the ground and Wilson, Fletcher and the others fled, police said.
Investigators found a handgun on the scene and allege it was left by Wilson — court documents state that "Wilson was observed dropping an object from his possession onto the ground" after the shooting.
A co-conspirator returned to where Elien was lying and potentially removed an object from his body, detectives alleged.
Police wrote in charging documents that "there is probable cause to believe" Fletcher, Wilson and the three unnamed people "formed a plan" to rob and shoot Elien.
Fletcher is being held at the Dorchester County Department of Corrections on no bond. A bond hearing is slated for July 16 and a preliminary hearing Aug. 5.
The Cambridge Police Department said in a press release last month that Wilson was being held without bond. Court scheduling information for Wilson, 15, was unavailable on Maryland's court records database.

 FEDERALSBURG — At the July 7 town meeting, Federalsburg Mayor Kim Abner announced Police Chief Joseph Gasser resigned from his position on June 25."The mayor and council would like to announce the resignation of Chief Gasser from the Federalsburg Police Department effective June 25," Abner said. "We want to thank Chief Gasser for his service to the town and wish him well on his future endeavors."
Within the announcement, Abner said that the Caroline County Sheriff's Office would take over leadership of the Federalsburg Police Department to give the mayor and council time to figure out police department leadership.
"I was contacted by the mayor and council and asked to take over day-to-day operations and management oversight of the department," Sheriff Donald Baker said to the Star Democrat in an interview Tuesday. The mayor also announced a public forum meeting for July 21 at 6 p.m. at the Federalsburg Town Hall to discuss their options moving forward with the police department, public safety and policing.
While the sheriff's office and the town of Federalsburg are in the early stages of conversation, Baker believes all options are on the table for the Federalsburg Police Department, including an memorandum of understanding with the sheriff's office that could discontinue the police department.
"I believe that everything is on the table to include signing an MOU somewhat like Ridgley's, directly with the sheriff's office of the county," Baker said. "Again, everything is on the table. and we are really early in this stage, but we absolutely could absorb any officers that were left."
Gasser was appointed to police chief position in January. He came into the position with a military background, and he had been serving the Town of Federalsburg for almost 30 years.
Ridgley has maintained a contract with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office to have assigned officers covering the town since last year. In March 2024, the town suspended its police department amid a state investigation.

title: Natural Resources Police use thermal imaging to rescue lost kayaker in Talbot County

Natural Resources Police use thermal imaging to rescue lost kayaker in Talbot County

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 344
 Words 

 Read News Document

 BROAD CREEK — Police and firefighters teamed to locate a lost juvenile kayaker last weekend in Talbot County.On July 4 around 10 p.m., Maryland Natural Resources Police were informed of a lost kayaker in the Broad Creek area, which is on the west side of the county south of St. Michaels. Officials said he was on the water for "several hours" and around three miles from home.
Using thermal imaging cameras, a Natural Resource Police aviation unit quickly found the lost person — in around five minutes, according to Sgt. John Buchanan, chief pilot for NRP. Buchanan was in the aircraft with tactical flight officer Christian Helwig.
Buchanan said the kayaker left out of Grace Creek.
"I think it got dark on him, and he didn't know where he was," Buchanan said.
Once located, police used a spotlight to direct a rescue boat from the Tilghman Island Volunteer Fire Company toward the juvenile.
A video posted to Facebook by Natural Resource Police shows the aircraft hone in on the kayaker and direct the fire boat to retrieve the juvenile.
Buchanan said such a rescue isn't too common, but it become somewhat prominent during boating season.
"(The) Chesapeake Bay and the tributaries are very large," Buchanan said. "When you start thinking about the different rivers and creeks and stuff off the Chesapeake Bay, we go out on different search missions like that probably a few times a month."
The pilot emphasized Helwig's expertise is crucial to such rescues. Helwig handles the thermal imaging camera, which can expose subjects in dark conditions, as well as a mapping system to pull up addresses and latitudes and longitudes.
"He's gotten really good with it, he's worked really hard at it," Buchanan said. "He's made us as a team very successful going out and doing these search missions."
Buchanan advises those going out on the water, especially alone, to be prepared with a charged cell phone and other equipment in case of emergency.
"Have a life jacket if you're out at night," he said. "Obviously have some kind of flashlight. And know the area, that's probably the biggest thing."

 TRAPPE — As storms traveled through Maryland Tuesday, a church outside of Trappe caught fire after being struck by lightning, according to fire officials.Around 7:45 p.m. Tuesday, firefighters responded to the Faith Chapel United Methodist Church for a blaze caused by lightning. No injuries occurred, according to the Office of the State Fire Marshal.
The church, located east of Trappe in the village of Bruceville, suffered $25,000 in damages, the fire marshal reported.
The Rev. Gary Moore said the damage is "very, very significant" for the small church, which dates to the 1880s.
"I was there last night," Moore said in an interview Wednesday. "Assessing the building will be a difficult decision as we move into the future."
The Trappe Volunteer Fire Company was assisted by local fire departments in extinguishing the fire. It took around 20 minutes to control, the fire marshal's report stated.
Moore thanked fire crews for their quick response.
"It's what makes living in Talbot County a joy," he said.
Sunday morning services at the Bruceville church will be moved to Trappe United Methodist Church on Maple Avenue, Moore said.
OTHER DAMAGES
Elsewhere in Talbot County, around nine trees fell due to the storm, according to Talbot County Emergency Services Director Brian LeCates. There were also downed wires, some flooding and minor car accidents, he added.
"We had a total of 24 incidents that were storm-related," LeCates said. "Most of them are trees down with wires and then just flooding on streets down in Oxford and here in Easton."
Commerce Drive in Easton was temporarily closed due to flooding Tuesday night, according to the town's Facebook. It reopened shortly after closing.
The St. Michaels town office will be closed Thursday due to repairs to an electric pole lost in the storm, the town announced Wednesday. Repairs won't cause any other outages, the town said.
Jimmy Windsor, Dorchester County's emergency management planner, said there were no reports of major flooding or significant storm damages. He said there was tree damage in northern parts of the county, but no serious incidents.
In Caroline County, a few trees were downed but mostly cleared out of roadways by mid-Wednesday morning.
An Easton Utilities spokesperson said two customers experienced power outages Tuesday night. Easton Utilities President and CEO John Horner cited the organization's efforts to provide reliability.
"Every upgrade we make strengthens our system, reduces outages, and ensures we're prepared to meet growing demands," Horner wrote in a statement.

 A man accused of disposing of the body of his girlfriend's 3-year-old daughter after the mother allegedly beat the girl to death and falsely claimed she was kidnapped near Newark, Delaware is facing new, more serious charges after a Maryland grand jury handed up an 11-count indictment against him July 3.The defendant — Cedrick Antoine Britten, 44 — is now charged with felony first-degree child abuse resulting in a death of a child under 13 years old and a mirroring conspiracy count, both of which are punishable by up to life in prison if convicted.
Other new charges against Britten include first-degree child abuse resulting in severe injury and an additional conspiracy count relating to that felony offense. Each of those charges carries a maximum 25-year sentence.
Under the original charges filed last month against Britten, the most serious of the eight counts he faced — accessory after the fact relating to first-degree murder — is punishable by up to 10 years in prison.
The indictment retains some of the original charges against Britten, including burying/disposing a body in unauthorized place, neglect of a minor and failure to report a child's death, court records show.
After the additional charges, Britten is being held in the Cecil County Detention Center on no bond.
Britten's co-defendant — his girlfriend, Darrian Lynnelle Randle, 31 — remains in a Delaware jail in lieu of $1 million bond.
She is awaiting extradition to Cecil County, Randle is accused of fatally beating her 3-year-old daughter, Nola Dinkins, inside their shared bedroom at Britten's residence in the 300 block of Elk Nest Road in North East, Md., during the daytime hours on June 9.
She also told investigators that, after picking up Nola, she called for Britten, who also was inside the residence, according to court records. Britten attempted CPR on Nola, but eventually realized that the girl was dead.
Randle told police that she and Britten placed Nola's body in his black 2019 BMW X3 and that they then drove around for a while, before returning to their Elk Nest Road residence.
Then, according to the documented account that Randle gave police, she and Britten placed the girl's body in a dark blue suitcase that belonged to Britten and placed the luggage on the third step of the basement stairs, where it remained overnight. Randle told police that she asked Britten to take the girl's body "somewhere," court records show.
Randle then drove to Delaware and called police to falsely report Nola had been kidnapped at gunpoint on Gender Road.
Randle's abduction complaint triggered an Amber Alert but after further investigation, Randle admitted that she had killed Nola, according to court records.

A social media release from the department reported that a deputy chief was first on the scene and reported fire showing from the eaves.
After learning there was a dog trapped inside, Fire Chief John Otis Darling donned protective gear and a self-contained breathing apparatus before entering the home. He quickly located the dog, named Lainey, and brought her to safety.

The Office of the Maryland State Fire Marshal determined the preliminary cause of the fire to be natural — a lightning strike. Estimated damages were $200,000 to the structure and $60,000 to contents.

 CENTREVILLE — The woman responsible for a 20-plus vehicle crash on the Bay Bridge has been sentenced in Queen Anne's County Circuit Court.On July 8, Gwendolyn Persina, 49, of Chester, was sentenced to three years of jail time with all but 315 days suspended, which is the time Persina has served in jail from the time of her arrest.
According to the Office of the State's Attorney, Persina was sentenced for causing a life-threatening injury to another while operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol. This was the most serious charge that Persina was charged with and the maximum penalty for the offense is three years in jail and a $5,000 fine.
Persina was also sentenced to five years of supervised probation, ordered to have a mental health evaluation and complete any recommended treatment, to abstain from alcohol and drugs, to get an alcohol evaluation and complete any recommended treatment.
Persina pleaded guilty by way of an Alford guilty plea, by not admitting guilt but by acknowledging that the state had sufficient evidence that she could be found guilty of the charge.
The case was prosecuted by Lance G. Richardson, state's attorney for Queen Anne's County, assisted by Carolynn Grammas, assistant state's attorney from Anne Arundel County, appointed as a special prosecutor for the case.
The state said the sentence fell within the recommended sentence range as calculated by the Maryland Sentencing Guidelines, which recommended a sentence ranging from six months to three years of active incarceration.
Persina's conviction was based on a Jan. 27, 2024, incident when at approximately 7:46 a.m. she was operating a Honda Civic passenger vehicle at a high rate of speed in heavy fog traveling westbound on the Bay Bridge on the Queen Anne's County portion of the Chesapeake Bay Bridge. Persina rear-ended another vehicle, which disabled her vehicle in the travel portion of the bridge, resulting in a 23-vehicle chain reaction collision.
The collision resulted in a victim having his arm severed from his body. The man's arm was unable to be reattached. Persina suffered serious injuries in the collision and was transported to the hospital.
Through the course of their investigation, police determined at the time of the collision, Persina's blood alcohol content was between 0.24 and 0.27 — three times greater than the legal limit.
Although the accident occurred on Jan. 27, 2024, Persina wasn't criminally charged until August 2024. The state reported the delay in formally charging Persina was due to the incredible amount of vehicle data that had to be reviewed for the more than 20 vehicles involved.
According to State's Attorney Lance Richardson's chief of staff, Rob Penny, medical records had to be obtained and then the large volume of records had to be reviewed.
Additionally, a large volume of other evidence, and information from witnesses, had to be reviewed and analyzed. All of this investigative information took months to be collected and examined, Penny said.
Once Persina was formally charged, she was arrested and held without bail. Her attorneys ultimately filed a notice of incompetency to stand trial due to her inability to assist in her defense or an inability to understand the nature of the proceedings.
Experts from both the state and the defense examined Persina. After many delays, the state doctor from the Maryland Department of Health deemed Persina competent to stand trial on July 2.
The Office of the Public Defender represented Persina.

title: Talbot County Sheriff's Office to place cameras in patrol cars
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot County Sheriff's Office to place cameras in patrol cars

 July 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 465
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Sheriff's Office is planning to add cameras to its patrol vehicles, a move that Sheriff Joe Gamble said will increase transparency with the public.Earlier this month, Talbot County council members approved the purchase of 30 in-car cameras for $415,000, spread across a five-year period. Body-worn cameras have their limits, Gamble said, only showing the steering wheel during situations like police chases.
The sheriff said the in-car cameras have two main benefits.
"One, it's another level of transparency with the public," Gamble said. "And the other is evidence gathering."
But Gamble noted that a state investigation into a fatal police-involved chase last year factored into the decision.
"It definitely played a role in it," he said.
In July 2024, Talbot County deputies and an Easton police officer engaged in a pursuit of a vehicle on U.S. Route 50 in Easton after the driver failed to pull over for a traffic stop. Police reached speeds over 100 mph, and the chase ended with the vehicle crashing into a tree on Black Dog Alley. An 18-year-old passenger died.
The Independent Investigations Division of the Maryland Attorney General's Office reviewed the incident, as it does for all fatal police-involved chases statewide. Body-worn camera footage was eventually released in September. It wasn't until January when state investigators determined they wouldn't seek charges against any of the involved officers.
At the time, Gamble said it shouldn't have taken that long for the state to complete its investigation and clear his deputies. Now, the in-car cameras will better show the actions taken by vehicles being pursued by police, he argues.
"You couldn't see the egregious disregard for public safety by the driver in that car," Gamble said in an interview this week, referencing the limited view of the chase provided by body-worn cameras.
"It protects our deputies in the sense that, this is what they did," he added. "And if there's allegations they did something else, it's on footage."
Other sheriffs on the Eastern Shore concur with the effectiveness of the cameras.
Queen Anne's Sheriff Gary Hofmann said most patrol vehicles have had the in-car cameras for a few years. Complaints are down, and it's increased trust with the community, Hofmann says.
"It's been extremely beneficial for us to avoid any type of complaints or allegations," he said.
Dorchester Sheriff James Phillips said he would love for his agency to buy them, although cost is a problem — the in-car cameras are more expensive than body-worn ones.
In Caroline County, the vehicle cameras were purchased under a former sheriff, current Sheriff Donnie Baker noted. They are key in providing a better perspective for traffic stops and other incident, he said.
"I think that they make a good cop better," Baker said, "and they limit false reports."
Gamble said the Talbot County Sheriff's Office hopes to install all 30 in-car cameras by 2026.

title: 18-year-old charged with murder in Cambridge shooting
author: Konner Metz

18-year-old charged with murder in Cambridge shooting

 July 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Crime 
 
 457

 CAMBRIDGE — A Cambridge teen has been arrested on murder charges in connection to a fatal shooting last month.Damarion Sampson, 18, was arrested Wednesday by police on 12 counts, including first- and second-degree murder, first- and second-degree assault and other firearm charges.
Police identified Sampson as the alleged shooter in the killing of 45-year-old Steven Lee Dennis on the night of June 25. Court records show that police used an eyewitness account from an off-duty officer, a recovered handgun at Sampson's residence and surveillance cameras to identify the 18-year-old as their suspect.
Just after 8:30 p.m. the night of the shooting, police responded to Hudson Road (state Route 343) and the Westside Bypass. Officers found Dennis lying in the roadway with a gunshot wound to his chest, police say.
An off-duty Dorchester County Sheriff's deputy and a civilian attempted CPR, as did responding officers. EMS, though, declared Dennis dead at the scene.
The sheriff's deputy provided Cambridge police an account of the shooting. He saw Dennis running down Westside Bypass approaching a silver Nissan, according to court records. The deputy then heard a gunshot and saw the Nissan drive past him and turn onto Hudson Road, charging documents state.
As the car drove by, the deputy "observed a black male driver leaning out the (window) holding a handgun," court records state.
A second witness told police that Dennis followed the Nissan and went up to the car's window, and "'then they popped,'" the witness said.
Following an anonymous tip, Cambridge detectives began to look into Sampson. Police had already been investigating Sampson in connection to an armed robbery. Detectives visited the teen's residence two days after the shooting and saw a silver Nissan, according to court records, and matched witness descriptions of the tags to what they saw.
Later that day, investigators searched Sampson's home, finding a handgun matching the casing found on the scene, charging documents say. A family member of Sampson's told detectives that the 18-year-old was driving the silver Nissan since graduating in May, according to court documents.
Police said in charging documents that "several different cameras" show the routes allegedly taken by Sampson toward the site of the shooting.
Sampson was arrested for murder Wednesday at the Dorchester County Detention Center — he was being held there since June 27 on unrelated charges in connection to an armed robbery of three teens in Cambridge on May 24.
Sampson faces 32 counts in connection to the armed robbery, court documents show. Charges include armed robbery, first- and second-degree assault, and other firearm and theft counts. Police say they are still searching for a second suspect in the May robbery.
The 18-year-old is being held without bond on both the murder and armed robbery cases. A preliminary hearing for both cases is scheduled for July 24.

title: God’s watchful eye misses nothing
author: Staff Writer
content:
God’s watchful eye misses nothing

 July 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 377
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Two pudgy toddler hands rose above the murky river, small and still. My heart leapt into my throat, and I shouted my husband's name. He had already turned and was sprinting through the shallows toward our youngest daughter.Our family of five had gone to a little stretch of sandy beach in Cambridge, Maryland. We watched our girls playing at the water's edge, our toddler splashing nearby. But in what seemed like an instant, she had wandered out too far and was now completely submerged, with only her tiny hands reaching up for help.
That near-tragedy rattled us deeply. We considered ourselves good parents, careful and attentive, but in one unguarded moment, everything could have changed forever.
This memory has been on my mind again after hearing of two recent tragedies: the loss of two toddler brothers who drowned in Greensboro, Maryland, and the young girls swept away by flash flooding at Camp Mystic in Texas.
The grief of those families is unimaginable, and my heart aches for them.
I find myself asking the same questions they surely ask: Where was God? Did He see? Did He hear their cries?
I don't know why some are rescued and others are not. But I do know this: God did not turn His face away.
Even when Jesus hung on the cross, suffering unimaginably, God saw. Many assume He turned His back when Jesus cried out, "My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?" (Matthew 27:46). I once believed that too. But as Bible teacher Rich Schmidt explains, Jesus was quoting Psalm 22 — a psalm that begins in agony but ends in hope: "For he has not despised or scorned the suffering of the afflicted one; he has not hidden his face from him but has listened to his cry for help" (Psalm 22:24).
Jesus was not alone on the cross. And those children were not alone in the water.
God's watchful eye misses nothing:
"The eyes of the Lord are in every place, keeping watch on the evil and the good." (Proverbs 15:3)
"The Lord is close to the brokenhearted and saves those who are crushed in spirit." (Psalm 34:18)
My prayer is that the grieving families somehow feel His gaze upon them now — not with answers, but with presence.
Because He sees.
Even here. Even now.
TRACY HARPER
Preston

content:
Police ID remains of toddler in murder case

 544
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The human remains located in a vacant lot in North East last month have been positively identified as those of 3-year-old Nola Dinkins, whose mother stands accused of murdering the toddler and whose other caregiver, the woman's live-in boyfriend, also is facing criminal charges relating to the girl's death, according to the Maryland State Police.MSP officials reported July 11 that investigators confirmed that the body found on June 11 is, indeed, that of Nola, doing so in the in the wake of an autopsy performed by the Maryland Office of the Chief Medical Examiner in Baltimore.
The update is tantamount to a formality because the victim's mother — Darrian Lynnelle Randle, 31 — admitted that she beat Nola to death inside their shared bedroom at her boyfriend's residence in the 300 block of Elk Nest Road during the daytime hours on June 9 and then made arrangements to get rid of the girl's body, court records allege.
Randle told investigators that she struck Nola 15 to 20 times with a belt all over her body, causing the girl to collapse to the floor and stop breathing — a confession given after she had falsely reported that her daughter had been kidnapped during an attempted carjacking in Delaware, to explain the girl's absence, triggering an Amber Alert, according to charging documents.
In addition, Randle told detectives that she asked her boyfriend — Cedrick Antoine Britten, 44 — to get rid of Nola's body, which they had placed inside a dark blue suitcase, police said. She also told investigators that Britten later sent her a photograph of a park, after driving away from residence with the suitcase inside his car, police added.
Charging documents further allege that, during an interview at MSP's North East Barrack on June 11, Britten "produced a map of where he believed that Randle may have disposed of" Nola's body, a statement that appears to allege that Randle got rid of the body.
Based on that map, investigators found human remains "consistent with an emaciated child" inside a suitcase found in a vacant lot in the unit block of Dune Drive near North East, close to Britten's residence, court records show.
Randle remained in a New Castle (Del.) County jail in lieu of $1 million bond on Monday, after her arrest there last month. She is awaiting extradition to Cecil County, where she will be served court papers charging her with several offenses, including first-degree murder, burying/disposing a body in an unauthorized place and neglect of a minor, according to the Cecil County State's Attorney's Office.
Britten remained in the Cecil County Detention Center on no bond Monday, after a Cecil County grand jury handed up an 11-count indictment against him on July 2. Included in those charges against Britten are felony first-degree child abuse resulting in a death of a child under 13 years old and a mirroring conspiracy count, both of which are punishable by up to life in prison if convicted.
Britten also is charged with first-degree child abuse resulting in severe injury and an additional conspiracy count relating to that felony offense — each of which carries a maximum 25-year sentence if convicted — and accessory after the fact relating to first-degree murder, which is punishable by up to 10 years in prison if convicted.

Jones, who lives in the 200 block of Hollingsworth Manor, which is one block away from where the incident occurred.
The investigation leading to Jones' arrest and the charges against him started at approximately 10:50 a.m. on Sunday, when Elkton Police Department officers rushed to a residence in the 300 block of Hollingsworth Manor after receiving a dispatch regarding a knife-related incident in progress, police reported.

One of the women who lives at that residence told investigators that she awoke to find Jones, whom she does not know, and that she then "raised her voice" at him, police said. At that point, Jones allegedly pulled a knife and demanded that she apologize to him, police added.
The woman's sister told investigators that Jones — uninvited — entered the residence through a back door and demanded that she drive him to New Castle, Del., according to the charging document. She also told investigators that this marked the third time that day that Jones had entered the residence, court records allege.
A man described in court papers as a "witness" told investigators that he was awakened by the sound of one of the female residents arguing with Jones who, according to the witness' account, was "waving a blade" at that woman, police reported.
That man told investigators that he told Jones to lower his voice and to calm down, police said. He also told investigators that Jones "swung the knife back and forth," which is what he was doing when officers arrived at the residence, prompting Jones to retreat into the back bedroom, police added.
