title: Feral cat colonies spark calls for action
author: Aamaly Hossain somdnewsintern@chespub.com
content:
Feral cat colonies spark calls for action

 July 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Aamaly Hossain somdnewsintern@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 533
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In wooded lots behind strip malls, under abandoned sheds or near residential dumpsters, small feline eyes glint through the dark.These are unseen inhabitants of Charles County's feral cat colonies, which can grow as large as 30 cats or more, according to Animal Control Officer Hannah Neel.
The quiet spread of these colonies prompted renewed discussion at a recent county commissioners' meeting, where animal control officials recounted a 2022 incident at Berry Elementary School.
"A school resource officer called in a bomb threat after seeing a duct-tape cooler at the woodline," Neel said. "The children were moved to the far side of the school, buses were rerouted. … And an explosive technician was called out."
The suspicious object turned out to be a homemade cat shelter. Though harmless, the scare triggered a lockdown, rattled parents and tied up emergency resources.
"This is an example, when you don't have the owner's permission and individuals try to run a cat colony without really having that open communication with the property owner," Neel said.
She noted schools, government land and private properties are off-limits for colonies without the explicit permission and oversight.
While the county lacks a formal trap-neuter-return, or TNR, program, animal control collaborates with the Humane Society and Rescue Angels to implement humane alternatives.
One such initiative is the Barn Cat Program, which relocates semi-feral or feral cats to places where they serve as natural pest control — farms, barns or wineries — in exchange for shelter, food and vaccinations.
Patricia "Pat" Parrish, president of Help For Pets and a former veterinary technician, later told commissioners that TNR is the only proven way to reduce cat overpopulation.
"Trap and kill does not work," she said, arguing that taxpayer money is wasted when nonprofits, like hers, are ready to assist.
Parrish shared a personal story from her first volunteer case with the Humane Society a decade ago in Nanjemoy, where a woman was overwhelmed by a colony of 30 cats.
"I said, 'Well how about if I come out and trap all these cats for ya, get them all spayed and neutered and vaccinated and bring them back? Then, could you keep them?'" Parrish said. "She started crying. She said, 'I love my cats. ... They give me a reason to get up in the morning.'"
Parrish helped eventually reduce that colony from 30 cats to three.
"That's what I've done for hundreds of colonies all over Charles County," she said.
Parrish said her group has spent over $200,000 in the past decade to reduce feral cat populations and wants to partner with animal control on a formal TNR program.
At the care center, Neel said cats with a tip of one ear cut off — an indicator that they have been neutered — are logged and local TNR groups are notified.
Animal control handles a wide range of responsibilities, including managing nuisance reports, responding to livestock issues and preventing rabies.
Neel emphasized the importance of staying current on vaccinations, calling it essential.
Animal control Lt. Katy Rosche noted a recent milestone — over 560 animals (between dogs, cats and ferrets) were vaccinated during two clinics held between May and early June.
Meanwhile, Parrish holds firm to her belief: "If we can get on board with this [TNR], we can make a big difference."

Pull over! – The complex realities of traffic stops

 July 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 1336
 Words 

 Read News Document

 "To protect and to serve." It's a motto first used by the Los Angeles Police Department over 60 years ago that has been embraced by law enforcement agencies all over the world. Simple words, but in the real world the goal has often seemed problematic.A nationwide study shows police patrol officers all over America pull over more than 50,000 drivers on a typical day, more than 20 million a year.
In Calvert County alone, as the halfway point of 2025 is reached, sheriff's deputies have made over 10,050 traffic stops.
"There's no such thing as a routine traffic stop," Capt. Nathan Funchion, patrol bureau commander for the Calvert County Sheriff's Office, told Southern Maryland News during a recent telephone interview.
Debora Harris, president of Calvert's NAACP chapter, noted that over the years the local organization has frequently fielded calls from citizens, in particular African Americans, who have sensed they were being profiled by county law enforcement when driving. She said those number of calls have dwindled somewhat.
"We don't get complaints, not lately," Harris told Southern Maryland News.
Harris said it was Calvert's NAACP chapter that engaged the American Civil Liberties Union of Maryland in researching questionable encounters among local deputies and African Americans. While traffic stops are part of the study, a major focus is what the state union calls "invasive police searches," which occurred from 2020 through 2024.
The state union's request for documentation reached a stalemate when sheriff's officials insisted on remittance of a $12,000 in exchange for the requested records. The ACLU challenged the hefty charge, citing the Maryland Public Information Act, and prevailed in both circuit and appellate courts.
Southern Maryland News made calls and sent emails to the state ACLU seeking an update on their study, plus basic information on how citizens should, within their rights, interact with law enforcement. No response was received.
When things go wrongLast December, a Prince George's County man with ties to Calvert County reached out to Southern Maryland News to share his story of a bad encounter with a Calvert County deputy.
On Dec. 18 William Jacks, 41, of Clinton was traveling with his wife, Kimberly, in Prince Frederick. The couple was traveling in their 2013 Ford Edge and Kimberly was driving.
Around 9:30 a.m., the vehicle was pulled over in the area of Prince Frederick Boulevard and Chapline Place. The officer conducting the stop is identified in court documents as Deputy Gavin Shuart of the Calvert County Sheriff's Office.
In his lengthy statement recalling the incident, Jacks said he put his passenger side window down "about 3½ inches. Once the officer walked up on the passenger side, his first words were 'wind your window all the way down.'"
Jacks said he refused the deputy's order, telling him, "You can see me, you can see inside my car, you can hear me, I can hear you and if I need to pass you something or if I need to receive something from you we are able to."
Jacks claimed in his statement that the deputy threatened to break the window if it wasn't rolled all the way down. When, according to Jacks, the deputy "proceeded to reach his arm in from his forearm up to the mid-bicep through my window" a cup of hot coffee in the vehicle's middle console spilled out on the two men, who were in a struggle for the vehicle's door handle. After the deputy managed to gain entry into the vehicle, Jacks said he demanded to speak with the officer's supervisor, which he eventually did, followed by the filing of a complaint with Calvert's Police Accountability Board.
According to the board's complaint tracker, the complaint filed Dec. 19 alleging "abuse of authority" was investigated, with the probe being completed Feb. 13. The final result was no administrative charges for the deputy.
Kimberly Jacks, identified in court documents as Kimberly Pilkerton, 44, was cited for displaying an expired registration plate, driving a vehicle on a highway without current registration plates, failure to maintain and to provide on request required security, and knowingly driving an uninsured vehicle.
All of the traffic citations were placed on the district court stet docket after a February hearing presided over by Judge Robyn Riddle.
In a followup phone call last week, Jacks expressed doubts that the board investigators reviewed Shuart's body camera footage when weighing the merits of the complaint.
In his statement provided to Southern Maryland News, Jacks said, "I truly feel that this officer had broken entry into by vehicle" and "assaulted me fighting over a door handle."
In another matter, Harris shared with Southern Maryland News that the local NAACP chapter "received a complaint last year by an elderly woman" who claimed Calvert police pulled her over and "charged her with drunk driving, and took her license."
Harris said subsequent sobriety tests showed "she was not driving under the influence." However, the woman, according to Harris, has not been able to get her license back.
Recommendations made
Funchion told Southern Maryland News, "in this county in particular, most interactions are positive."
The Calvert sheriff's office captain's advice for motorists is if they see a flashing light behind you "turn on your turn signal to indicate you are going to pull over. Keeping hands in sight is highly recommended. It's highly recommended" that you "roll your window down."
Funchion said the officer will identify themselves and let you know they are wearing an activated body camera.
"Be polite and courteous, provide documents," Funchion said, adding that if the vehicle's registration is in the glove box, "let the officer know you want to retrieve it."
The captain said the information provided will be run through a computer the deputy has in his or her patrol vehicle.
A citation or a warning will be provided to the motorist, who then "may pull back onto the road."
Occasionally, law enforcement officers also issue repair orders to motorists, who may not be aware that a brake light or tag light is out. Calvert's sheriff's office, said Funchoin, on average only issues 50 to 60 repair orders annually to motorists.
The national NAACP advises motorists on their website that they "have the right not to consent to a search of your vehicle. If the police state they have probable cause, they may begin to search your car without your consent. Do not interfere but clearly state your lack of consent. If you are given a ticket, sign it. You can always fight the case in court later."
The latter advice is also recommended by the American Civil Liberties Union, which states on its national website that anyone stopped by the police has a right to ask, "'Am I being detained or am I free to go.' If you wish to remain silent, you should say, 'I don't want to talk to you without a lawyer.'"
The union also advised, "You have the right to refuse to consent to a search of yourself, your car or your home, with certain exceptions."
Driving forward
Overall, in 2024 the Calvert County Sheriff's Office received a total of 33 complaints, with five resulting in administrative charges, which mostly resulted in letters of reprimand and one with suspension and loss of leave.
So far in 2025, 10 complaints are currently under investigation by the county's Police Accountability Board and four have been completed, resulting in a letter of reprimand given to an officer.
Harris said the local NAACP chapter does receive complaints about the way the two panels — police accountability board and administrative charging committee — do business.
"It's very limited to what can happen," Harris said. "Police are really governing themselves."
As to the low number of complaints resulting in punitive action, Funchion said he believes the body cameras each deputy is equipped with are making a difference.
"We felt like we were disliked and getting a bad rap," Funchion said. "The perception has changed."
Funchion acknowledged the county has seen "an uptick" in "roadside interactions," which he said is part of a strategy implemented due to the county's higher number of road fatalities in 2024.
The captain explained motorists who see police interactions tend to drive slower, so the increased traffic stops, due to their visibility "slows traffic."

title: Tilghman Island Volunteer Fire Department marks 100 years with parade Saturday
author: Konner Metz
content:
Tilghman Island Volunteer Fire Department marks 100 years with parade Saturday

 July 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 619
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TILGHMAN ISLAND — It began in 1925 as a wagon with tanks, and now, the Tilghman Island Volunteer Fire Department is celebrating its centennial.Serving residents in the waterfront village, the fire department has persisted through many ups and downs, president Jesse Gottleib said.
"So many small companies don't see 100 years because of not only funding, but more so because of lack of participation, lack of volunteers for the department," he said.
Such challenges are true in Tilghman Island — there are around 30 volunteers, 12 of them firefighters, the president noted. And while money is always a challenge, Gottleib said the department is extremely active in hosting community fundraisers.
The key cog in the fire department's survival and success has been community support, said Gottleib and his mother Linda, the department's secretary.
"We would've never thought it," he said of reaching the 100-year mark. "And I think the reason is because people in this side of St. Michaels down, they realize that we're gonna be there when they need it."
To celebrate the milestone, Tilghman Island firefighters are hosting a parade on Saturday. It begins at 10 a.m. with a fair atmosphere, including food, live music and games. At 11:30 a.m., kids will hop in fire gear to compete in a junior firefighters competition, spraying hoses at targets.
"It might help them to say, 'I wanna join,'" Linda Gottleib said.
The parade begins near the Knapps Narrows Bridge at 1 p.m. A friendly firefighters' competition will follow, and later that evening, the department plans to host a private ceremony to honor some key life members.
On Wednesday at the fire house, the Gottleibs pointed out some of the unsung heroes of the fire department. Dewayne Stewart, a line officer for 36 years, and Billy Lednum, a line officer for 31 years, have been integral to the company's success.
"You'll see a hurt in the fire department when those two are gone," Jesse Gottleib said.
The Tilghman Island Volunteer Fire Department doesn't go on a ton of calls — sometimes two to 10 per month, Gottleib said. But the department often provides mutual aid or helps with water rescues. Most recently, the Tilghman fire boat assisted state searchers with a rescue in Broad Creek on July 4.
In addition to the fire boat, the fire station houses multiple fire trucks and a Talbot County ambulance. Last year, the station donated a fire engine to a Tennessee fire department dealing with damages from Hurricane Helene.
Jesse Gottleib, 43, is the youngest sitting president and has been a member since he turned 16 in 1997. His mother joined in 1999 and has served a number of roles, including secretary, president and board member.
In recent days, they've been scouring through old newspaper clips and photos to create collages for Saturday's festivities. Some photos show the fire station in its three different buildings, the current one built in 2005.
It's a family affair for Jesse Gottleib, as it is for many of the volunteers. He recalled once ditching a baseball game — while actively manning left field — just to watch the fire trucks pull out of the station when he was about 9 years old.
"First game that we had down here at Tilghman school, the fire siren went off," he said. "And (my mom) and my dad were standing there and were like, 'Is he leaving?' And I ran across the field to go to the fence."
Saturday will be a chance to reflect on some of those fun memories, interact with the community and honor longtime volunteer firefighters and administrators. Gottleib said the dedication of volunteers has been remarkable.
"Their time is appreciated here," Gottleib said. "I feel like they play a key role into getting us to where we are now at 100 years."

title: Texas tragedy has shown worst of American society
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Texas tragedy has shown worst of American society

 July 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 782
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The recent flash flood tragedy in central Texas resulted in seeing the best and the worst of American society.The best has been an outpouring of sympathy, caring and support for the flood victims, their families and the survivors. There have been countless reports of selfless rescue and recovery efforts by first responders and volunteers, some from well beyond the immediate flooded area.
The worst has been numerous messages on social media and other media platforms — e.g., a newspaper editorial cartoon — that were vile, hateful and some of which were vulgar.
Many of them chose to blame Trump supporters or policy decisions of the Trump administration for this tragedy.
Far too many did not include expressions of sadness or sympathy for the deaths of innocent children and adults or compassion for the lifelong impact on all the flooding survivors.
The level of vitriol in these messages is so offensive, I will not repeat any of them in this column.
The only thing they have in common is they are devoid of any sense of decency and civility.
Somewhat surprising has been dismay and even outrage expressed from unexpected sources over these vile messages.
Nina Turner is a former national co-chair for the Bernie Sanders 2020 presidential campaign.
She recently said, "It takes a serious lack of humanity to see children to be in a politicized discussion and respond something like lines of "that's what they [voters in Texas] voted for."
Turner's closing one word comment says it all — "Shameful."
John Favreau and Tommy Vietor are co-hosts on the left of center, Pod Save America.
Both worked for Barack Obama prior to and during his presidential administration.
Both have condemned social media posts that blame local Texans and the Trump administration for all who died as a result of the recent floods.
Favreau said: "I think the really gross stuff was, I saw some people be, like, 'Well, Texas, you voted for Trump, and this is what you get.'"
Favreau has challenged suggestions that staffing levels at the National Weather Service in Texas had anything to do with the tragedy. Favreau has said, "It seems like the National Weather Service, like I said, did send out a timely warning, it just didn't get to people. And that's, you know, not the Trump administration saying that; independent meteorologists and experts have all said this."
Vietor has said that while questions about the effect of weather services cuts could be "an important question going forward, I could have done without the, like, instant, you know, leap to blame name-your-political-opponent for this tragedy on Twitter."
The "blame your political opponent" campaign on this tragedy is already well underway.
Shortly after news broke on the flooding, Sen. Chuck Schumer demanded the Commerce Department's inspector general investigate vacancies at National Weather Service offices and whether the purported vacancies resulted in a higher death toll in in Texas.
Schumer has suggested that proposed but yet-to-be-implemented Trump budget cuts resulted in unfilled weather service positions in Texas were to blame. Sen. Chris Dodd has said likewise.
Schumer proclaimed: "The American people deserve answers."
Yes, we do, but not from you two or anyone who wants to advance a political agenda from this tragedy.
We deserve answers only if the following investigative guidelines are agreed to, in advance of, and are strictly adhered to during every phase of any investigation. At a minimum, the investigation must focus less on assigning blame for what happened or did not happen with regard to timely and effective flash flood alerts.
The laser like focus must be on what can be done going forward to help ensure it never happens again.
Differing opinions must be welcome and considered provided they follow the timeless observation of former U.S. Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who once said, "Everyone is entitled to their own opinions, but not their own facts."
One new previously unreported fact comes from a recent Washington Post article headline — "Camp Mystic's leader got a 'life threatening' flood alert. They evacuated an hour later."
We also need to accept that we never have and never will live in a risk-free world.
We can only anticipate risks and take prudent steps to try to avoid them or deal with them if and when necessary. Accidents can never be totally avoided despite plans and best intentions.
Going forward, we desperately need a renewed universal commitment that when tragedies strike, to make sure social media posts and other public reactions reflect common decency and respect for each and every person impacted in any way by that tragedy.
This is especially vital in dealing with those who hold different political party affiliations or different views on a wide range of public policy issues.
We must do so if we have any hope of reversing the steadily declining levels of decency and civility in our society.

title: Lightning-strike fire destroys buildings, causes $200k in damage
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Lightning-strike fire destroys buildings, causes $200k in damage

 July 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 226
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Investigators are blaming a lightning strike for sparking a blaze that destroyed three outbuildings and damaged another on a Conowingo residential property, leaving an estimated $200,000 in losses, according to the Maryland Office of the State Fire Marshal.The owners called 911 at 10:56 p.m. on Wednesday (July 16) after discovering that two barns, one shed and a garage in the 100 block of McCauley Road were ablaze amid a severe thunderstorm, prompting area volunteer fire companies to respond, fire officials said. The Water Witch Volunteer Fire Company of Port Deposit served as the on-scene command unit, fire officials added.
An MOSFM spokesperson outlined, "The owners heard the strike and later discovered their buildings on fire."
Approximately 30 volunteer firefighters battled the blaze for about 20 minutes before bringing it under control, fire officials reported.
"The barns and shed were a complete loss, while the garage sustained heavy to moderate damage. Their home sustained radiant heat damage; however, they were not displaced," the spokesperson said, adding that no one was injured and that the fire cause a total of $200,000 in damage to the four outbuildings and their contents.
During their on-scene investigation, MOSFM detectives determined that the blaze started inside one of the outbuildings, fire officials said. Investigators concluded that a lightning strike triggered the fire and then listed "natural" as the cause of the blaze, fire officials added.

Police investigating fatal two-vehicle crash in Queen Anne's County

 CHURCH HILL — Maryland State Police are investigating a fatal two-vehicle crash that occurred Tuesday morning on southbound U.S. Route 301 at Price Station Road in Queen Anne's County.Mickie Mowbray, 58, of Greensboro, was pronounced dead at the scene. Mowbray was the driver and sole occupant of a Kia passenger vehicle.
Two occupants of a Mazda — a 22-year-old male driver and a 20-year-old female passenger — were flown by Maryland State Police Aviation Command to the R Adams Cowley Shock Trauma Center in Baltimore for treatment of their injuries. Police listed their condition as critical.
The crash occurred around 9:10 a.m. when the southbound Mazda struck the driver's side of the Kia as it attempted to cross Route 301, causing the Kia to overturn. Police said speed may have been a factor.
One person was ejected and two others were trapped in vehicles, requiring extrication. Emergency responders included multiple medical helicopters and personnel from Queen Anne's County Fire Department, the sheriff's office and the Maryland Department of Transportation State Highway Administration.
Southbound lanes were closed for approximately three hours, with traffic reopening around 12:40 p.m.
The Maryland State Police Crash Team is leading the investigation. Their findings will be submitted to the Queen Anne's County State's Attorney's Office for a charging decision.
The investigation is ongoing.

title: Easton minister detained by ICE
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Easton minister detained by ICE

 July 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Local News 
 
 507
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A beloved Easton minister was detained by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents, taken to Salisbury and is now at the Baltimore ICE detention center where he is awaiting his next transfer, according to his daughter.Honduran born Daniel Fuentes Espinal has lived in the United States since 2001 and has served as the minister of Iglesia del Nazareno Jesús Te Ama since 2015. According to his daughter, Clarissa Fuentes Diaz, Espinal was arrested by ICE agents early Monday morning after stopping by Lowe's to pick up material for a job site.
"He didn't see anything suspicious. He put the material in the car, but then when he went to McDonald's to get something for breakfast, he saw a car behind him that looked kind of weird," Cordero said.
ICE agents followed Espinal to the Easton pool, ultimately arresting him on Route 322. He was taken to the Salisbury holding center. "He preached to them all the way to Salisbury," Diaz said.
From 8 a.m. to 12:30 p.m., Espinal's family had no clue of his whereabouts. "We were about to do a report on a missing person because we didn't find out until almost 12:30," Diaz said.
Diaz said Espinal had no criminal record.
Since President Donald Trump took office in January, immigration arrests have doubled in the state of Maryland. More than 600 immigrants arrested during this time had no former criminal charges, according to the Deportation Data Project.
Espinal has three children and a large extended family that he cares for, Diaz said. Tred Avon Strategies principal Len Foxwell referred to him as a pillar of the community.
Earlier this month, Espinal spoke at Foxwell's son Darren's funeral. Diaz said Darren and her brother were best friends and his death has been hard on Espinal and the family.
Diaz said she has received over 10 character letters on her father's behalf since his arrest yesterday morning, including one from Foxwell.
"It wasn't until I got to know him, however, that I saw how he honors and embodies the values of Christ in every aspect of his life," Foxwell wrote in a letter to ICE.
Espinal's family has tried obtaining citizenship legally for years, but due to backlogs and expenses, Espinal remained undocumented, Diaz said.
"He's contributing to this country, and we're just trying to do it the right way," Diaz said. "You know, unfortunately, with everything going on, everyone's a criminal apparently, but we're just hoping for the best and just to get him out of there."
Diaz said each phone call Espinal makes from the detention center costs $50 for a 20-minute call and bond amounts for release currently range from $10,000 to $15,000.
"I've heard stories that people say, 'But why didn't you do it the legal way? Why aren't you doing it the legal way?' It's not easy," Diaz said. "You know, if you're not in that person's shoes, you shouldn't be judging, and you shouldn't be criticizing."
Espinal's family is relying on their faith and are hopeful that he will return home.
ICE could not be reached via phone to comment on this incident.

 Fire trucks and other emergency vehicles took a victorious ride down Tilghman Road on Saturday as the Tilghman Island Volunteer Fire Company marked its 100th anniversary.Locals and visitors of all ages lined the street in front of the fire station to watch the parade. Along with Talbot County vehicles, the colorful display featured fire trucks from Sudlersville, Federalsburg and several other Maryland towns.
The event was more than just a tribute to the fire company; it was a celebration of community.
"It really gets everybody out," volunteer firefighter Charles Lomax of Tilghman said. "People that don't get along, people that don't necessarily agree with each other, all come out and support one cause."
Lomax started volunteering with the fire company when he was 16, following in the footsteps of his father, who had been with the fire company for over 20 years. He said the fire company has always been a meaningful part of his life and the community. The parade, he added, is a way for the town to honor the work of generations of volunteers.
"I've only been in it six years, eight years, something like that," Lomax said. "But seeing some of these older members and how much it means to them, it's awesome."
The celebration attracted not only the local community, but visitors from beyond Tilghman.
Matthew Tucker from northeastern Pennsylvania watched the parade with his family, including his brother, a volunteer firefighter in Oxford.
"I think it's important to celebrate anything that helps protect and serve the community. It's all volunteer, and that's wonderful," Tucker said. "A parade like this symbolizes generations of families coming out and supporting community, local health and the people that are providing service to us as volunteers."
Tucker's mother, Christine, added to his remarks: "It's a thankless job, and it can really be dangerous."
The day ended with a fireman's contest, in which volunteer firefighters from different locations demonstrated their skills in a simulated emergency, followed by a parade trophy ceremony.
The celebration emphasized the importance of such service in a small town, like Tilghman, where the fire company is a lifeline to its residents.
After 100 years of service to Tilghman Island, the celebration honored the legacy and dedication of generations of residents who have volunteered their time to protect their community.
Richard Childers, a former Tilghman firefighter who lives in Preston, returned to Tilghman to attend the celebration with his 9-year-old son, Noah. Inside the firehouse, Richard and Noah examined a large display of photos, including several generations of volunteers and fire trucks, along with newspaper clippings about the fire company's history dating back over 70 years.
"It's just an accomplishment to have a volunteer department that long — that has stayed volunteer for 100 years," Childers said.

 CHURCH HILL — For the second time in three days, a deadly crash has occurred at the intersection of U.S. Route 301 and Price Station Road (MD 405), a corridor long plagued by collisions.The most recent crash happened around 12:26 p.m. Thursday, July 24, and involved two vehicles. Initial reports indicate one person was able to extricate themselves, while two others were pronounced dead at the scene.
According to Maryland State Police, the driver and the passenger of a Toyota Camry, identified as Valerie Haines, 63, and Patricia Mead, 86, of Ridgley, were pronounced deceased on the scene by Queen Anne's emergency medical services personnel. The driver of a utility truck, a 39-year-old male, was reported uninjured in the crash. The preliminary investigation indicates the utility truck was traveling south when it struck the Toyota, which was attempting to cross U.S. Route 301.
On Tuesday morning, July 22, another two-vehicle crash at the same intersection claimed the life of Mickie Mowbray, 58, of Greensboro, who was driving a Kia. Police said a southbound Mazda struck the Kia as it attempted to cross Route 301, causing it to overturn. The 22-year-old male driver and 20-year-old female passenger in the Mazda were flown to R Adams Cowley Shock Trauma Center in Baltimore in critical condition.
In that crash, one person was ejected and two others required extrication. Emergency crews from the Maryland State Police, Queen Anne's County Fire and EMS, and the Maryland Department of Transportation responded. Southbound lanes were closed for roughly three hours.
According to the Maryland State Highway Administration, the intersection has a troubling safety record. Between January 2019 and December 2023, 76 crashes were reported at the site — 62 of them involving the southbound lanes. Most were attributed to driver inattention or failure to yield.
Despite several mitigation efforts — including pavement realignment, rumble strips, and enhanced signage — crashes have continued. In July 2024, the SHA closed the MD 405 median crossover at US 301 to all traffic movements, citing ongoing safety concerns. The closure was since lifted and reopened to crossing.
Highway officials were not immediately available for comment.
The Maryland State Police Crash Team is leading both investigations. Findings will be submitted to the Queen Anne's County State's Attorney's Office for review.

title: Easton man receives 18 years for sex assault of daughter, other crimes
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton man receives 18 years for sex assault of daughter, other crimes

 July 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Crime 
 
 660
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — An Easton man received an 18-year sentence on Thursday for third-degree sex offense against his then-3-year-old daughter, among other offenses.Kevin Manning, 34, appeared in court to hear his fate after entering a guilty plea for the felony sex offense and nine other counts, including witness intimidation, electronic communication harassment and violation of a protective order. Those nine counts were levied for actions he took against his daughter's mother after the Sept. 2024 assault of the daughter.
Talbot County Circuit Court Judge Phil Cronan handed down the 18-year sentence — a term exceeding the recommended five- to 13-year range — for what he called a "vicious and heinous" crime.
Before Cronan delivered the sentence, Deputy State's Attorney Chelsea Endzel asked the court for a 30-year sentence.
Endzel cited Manning's past sex assault convictions: a fourth-degree sex offense in Anne Arundel County in 2016 and second-degree rape in Talbot County in 2022 stemming from a 2009 incident involving Manning and an underage female living with him at the time.
The rape conviction was dismissed in 2023 after it was determined that the judge who postponed Manning's trial date was not designated to do so.
Endzel argued for the extended sentence, in part, due to Manning's "repeated harassment" of the child's mother, Emily Hiester, beginning last September. Endzel wrote in a memo to the court that Manning contacted Hiester nearly 200 times through emails and phone calls, violating a protective order.
Endzel read a written impact statement from Hiester, in which the mother said she couldn't bear to be in a courtroom with Manning. Hiester wrote that she has secluded herself from others and that she "can see the pain" in her daughter's eyes.
"I can't see others the same when someone I thought I knew I could trust did something so horrible," a portion of the statement read.
Hiester asked for Manning's sentence to be "as much time as the court will allow."
Endzel also argued that an open District Court case in which Manning is accused of assaulting an inmate at the Talbot County Detention Center factors into the danger he poses to society. The alleged assault occurred May 24.
"The question is not whether he will reoffend, but when," Endzel said.
Manning's defense attorney, Holly Brownley of the public defender's office, asked Cronan to deliver a sentence within the pre-sentence recommendations.
Manning "had some serious traumas in his young life," such as the murder of his mother and being exposed to drug and substance abuse, Brownley said.
The 34-year-old defendant, in an orange suit, handcuffs and wide black glasses, spoke for a few minutes at the hearing Thursday. He said he wants to go to a maximum-security prison, Patuxent Institution in Jessup, to receive treatment.
Manning acknowledged his daughter was the victim and said what occurred was an accident. He disagreed with Endzel's claims that he has shown no remorse.
"To ostracize me from society, I don't believe's appropriate," Manning said, noting that since 2019, he doesn't feel he's been a "trouble or menace" to society.
Cronan disagreed with that assessment.
The judge said Manning's behavior has escalated the last 15 years. The dismissed rape conviction is "certainly something ... in this court's mind," Cronan said. He added that the sex offense conviction and a related burglary crime from 2016 as well as the pending assault case from two months ago played a role.
"That doesn't sound to me that you haven't been any trouble," Cronan told Manning. "Quite the opposite."
The judge said the facts of the case were clear: Manning assaulted his daughter and "manipulated the mother of your child" to try to get her to lie in court for him.
Cronan said the daughter "should have the comfort" to be with her father without such a thing happening.
In addition to the 18 years, Manning is ordered to be on probation for five years after his release, make no contact with Hiester or the daughter and not visit their residences, schools, places of employment or daycares. He will register as a Tier III sex offender.

title: Second fatal crash in three days prompts re-closure of Price Station Road crossover on U.S. 301
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Second fatal crash in three days prompts re-closure of Price Station Road crossover on U.S. 301

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Local News 
 
 565
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHURCH HILL — Following two fatal crashes in three days, state transportation officials have ordered the closure of the MD 405 (Price Station Road) median crossover at U.S. Route 301 in Queen Anne's County.The Maryland Department of Transportation State Highway Administration announced Friday, July 25, that the crossover will be closed beginning Saturday, July 26. Emergency vehicle access will be maintained, and alternate crossovers are available at MD 19 (Roberts Station Road), two miles north, and Hayden Clark Road, 1.7 miles south.
"This is a safety-focused decision," said State Highway Administrator Will Pines. "This closure is necessary to save lives and make the corridor safer for the tens of thousands of travelers and residents who use it every day."
The announcement follows two deadly collisions at the intersection this week, resulting in three fatalities.
On Thursday, July 24, a two-vehicle crash occurred around noon, leaving two people dead at the scene.
Just two days earlier, another woman was killed when her vehicle was struck by a southbound car as she attempted to cross Route 301. The impact caused her car to overturn. The other vehicle's two occupants — a 22-year-old man and a 20-year-old woman — were flown to R Adams Cowley Shock Trauma Center in Baltimore in critical condition.
The State Highway Administration had previously closed the crossover in July 2024 due to a high number of crashes. Between January 2019 and December 2023, there were 76 reported crashes at the site — 62 of them in the southbound lanes, most attributed to driver inattention or failure to yield. Despite safety upgrades such as restriping, rumble strips, additional signage, and channelizing devices, collisions have continued at an alarming rate.
Troopers from the Centreville Barrack of the Maryland State Police, Queen Anne's County Sheriff Gary Hofmann, and first responders from the Church Hill Volunteer Fire Company have all voiced strong support for the closure.
The Church Hill Volunteer Fire Company confirmed Friday that it had been notified of the closure and has coordinated with SHA to ensure continued emergency access to communities east of Route 301, including Price and Bridgetown Estates.
"As we did in July of 2024, the department leadership reached out to SHA to ensure emergency access would be available to Fire, EMS, and Police units responding to emergency calls on the east side of Route 301," the fire company said in a statement. "We have been assured by SHA leadership that they intend to use the same process as before and that emergency access will be available.
"While this will create a slight delay in response times, we appreciate the willingness of SHA to work with us to keep those delays as short as possible while long-term solutions for the crossover are worked. The leadership of the Church Hill Volunteer Fire Company is committed to providing the most timely and efficient emergency response possible and will continue to monitor the situation and be a partner with SHA for a permanent solution."
Sen. Steve Hershey (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) also voiced support for the re-closure, stating, "Given the dangerous track record at this intersection — and now two fatal accidents in just three days — it is clear that further action is urgently needed. While I understand the temporary inconvenience to motorists, public safety must come first."
The Maryland State Police Crash Team is leading both crash investigations. Findings will be submitted to the Queen Anne's County State's Attorney's Office for review.

author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com

Police: Suspects caught with Molotov cocktail in truck linked to recent homicide

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 964
 Words

 Two men and a woman remained jailed July 30 after officers stopped their pickup truck — which allegedly was "involved in a recent homicide" — on an Elkton neighborhood street and confiscated a Molotov cocktail created with a liquor bottle and gasoline, according to Cecil County District Court records.As of July 30, additional information regarding the vehicle's alleged connection to a recent homicide was unavailable.
Investigators identified the suspects as Timothy Michael Dickerson, 18, of Newark, Del.; Bobbie Sue Perkins, 28, of Elkton; and Xavier Armani Santana, 20, of Philadelphia, Pa.
The investigation leading the arrests of Dickerson, Perkins and Santana and the charges against them started at approximately 12:20 a.m. on Saturday, when a patrolling Elkton Police Department officer stopped a green Ford pickup truck driven by Perkins after she allegedly failed to obey a stop sign while making a left turn from Road A in Hollingsworth Manor onto Landing Lane, police reported.
When describing Hollingsworth Manor and the nearby outskirts that he had been patrolling at the time of the traffic stop, EPD Ofc. A. McGonigle wrote in the charging document, "I have personally made dozens of arrests in reference to violent crimes and narcotics in this area. Additionally, this area has recently been inundated with violent crime, including a homicide and shooting."
Along those lines, shortly before midnight on July 18 — some eight days earlier — a 14-year-old boy was stabbed to death while he and "five or six" companions purportedly were attacking a one-armed man in his 30s on the street of Road C in Hollingsworth Manor, according to an EPD spokesman and Cecil Whig archives.
The spokesman, who also serves as an EPD detective, reported that the disabled man stabbed the teen in the neck with a knife amid the attack and that the teen and his companions of varying ages were armed with "knives, sticks or clubs."
In addition, the spokesman commented, "It looks like a pretty strong case of self-defense, which would make this a justifiable homicide," and then qualified that the case would be reviewed by the Cecil County State's Attorney's Office.
As of Tuesday, no arrests had been made in the homicide, nor in the alleged group assault that occurred moments before the fatal stabbing.
Outlining the traffic stop that led to the confiscation of the Molotov cocktail early Saturday morning, McGonigle reported that Dickerson was Perkins' right-seat passenger and that Santana was her middle-seat passenger.
"I know Santana and Dickerson to be violent offenders through previous incidents with both of them. Additionally, dispatch advised the vehicle had been involved in the recent homicide," the officer wrote in court records, noting, "As I spoke to both Dickerson and Santana, whom I have a rapport with; I noticed they were acting in an unusual manner. Typically, both Dickerson and Santana are very talkative and often joke with me. However, they were unusually quiet and could not maintain eye contact."
The officer dispatched a K9 Unit handler and his specially-trained scent dog from a different police agency to the traffic-stop scene and the canine made a "positive alert" during a sniff-scan of truck's exterior, court records show. The officer explained in court records that he summoned the K9 Unit "due to the high crime area, the time of night and the observed behavior."
During the probable-cause search of the truck, investigators seized a glass E&J liquor bottle that was filled approximately three-quarters with gasoline and was covered by a blue paper rag soaked in gas, after finding it on the vehicle's floorboard, court records allege.
Investigators also confiscated a Bic-style lighter, after finding it "shoved inside the seat cushion, in close proximity to the glass bottle full of gasoline," according to the charging document.
The three suspects agreed to speak with the officer, police reported.
Perkins told the officer that Dickerson and Santana had been with her at her Elkton residence on Mackall Street, before she drove to the Wawa near Hollingsworth Manor — where she filled the liquor bottle with gasoline that she planned to pour into the fuel tank of the dirt bike on Mackall Street, police said. But Perkins then told McGonigle that the dirt bike wasn't on Mackall Street, police added.
Court records allege that Dickerson and Santana told McGonigle that the dirt bike was located on Mallard Court, which is part of a neighborhood that is directly adjacent to Hollingsworth Manor. But according to the officer, "All three subjects were traveling from the opposite direction from Mallard Court when stopped."
"When asked about about the incendiary device, Santana advised the rag was being used to stop the gasoline from spilling. However, the cap from the glass E&J bottle was located in the bed of the truck, conveniently located on the rear wheel well. Dickerson advised he filled the bottle with gasoline," according to the charging document.
The officer noticed that Santana was wearing a key chain designed to attach a Bic-style lighter and that the lighter was missing, police reported. McGonigle also noticed that the front of Santana's pants was "soaked in a liquid," police said. Santana attributed the soaked front of his pants to rain, although, according to the officer, there hadn't been any precipitation since about 10:45 p.m. on Friday, about 90 minutes earlier, police added.
Investigators reported the Dickerson was in possession of a blue torch-style lighter and that no cigarettes or other "smoke-able objects" were located during the search.
Arrested at the traffic-stop scene, Dickerson, Perkins and Santana are each charged with possession of a destructive device, which is a felony that is punishable by up to 25 years in prison and a $250,000 fine if convicted, court records show.
All three remained in the Cecil County Detention Center on no bond Tuesday, one day after their bail review hearings in front of Cecil County District Court Administrative Judge Clara E. Campbell, according to court records.

 CHURCH HILL — Following two fatal crashes in three days, state transportation officials ordered the closure of the MD 405 (Price Station Road) median crossover at U.S. Route 301 in Queen Anne's County beginning July 26.According to State Highway Administration spokesperson Charlie Gischlar, the closure is temporary but will remain in effect until a permanent safety improvement is designed and constructed. In the meantime, SHA is evaluating additional safety measures for the US 301/MD 405 intersection.
The action follows two deadly collisions at the site last week, resulting in three fatalities.
On Thursday, July 24, a two-vehicle crash occurred around noon, leaving two people dead at the scene.
Just two days earlier, on Tuesday morning, July 22, another woman was killed when her vehicle was struck by a southbound car as she attempted to cross Route 301. The impact caused her vehicle to overturn. The other vehicle's two occupants — a 22-year-old man and a 20-year-old woman — were flown to R Adams Cowley Shock Trauma Center in Baltimore in critical condition.
The State Highway Administration had previously closed the same crossover in 2024. That closure remained in effect for nearly two months and was lifted after SHA implemented sight distance improvements at the intersection, including reconfiguring the westbound MD 405 approach to slightly turn vehicles to the right and trimming roadside trees.
Between January 2019 and December 2023, there were 76 reported crashes at the crossover, 62 of which occurred in the southbound lanes. Most were attributed to driver inattention or failure to yield.
According to Gischlar, SHA staff remain in direct communication with local emergency responders. The current median closure configuration was originally recommended by the Church Hill Volunteer Fire Department and has been effective in maintaining emergency access.
Some residents have expressed concerns about redirecting traffic to the MD 19 crossover and the safety risks associated with increased turning movements or U-turns there. SHA acknowledged those challenges.
"There are challenges with at-grade crossings along a major highway, especially as we observe traffic volumes, speed and distracted driving behaviors continue to increase," Gischlar said. "Crossings such as MD 19 and Hayden Clark Road are well-marked with flashers to alert drivers to potential cross traffic."
Additional long-term improvements are under evaluation.
"SHA is committed to improving safety for motorists along this corridor," Gischlar said. "We are evaluating larger safety improvements; however, our immediate focus is addressing the safety concerns with near-term projects that improve safety conditions and assist motorists in making good driving decisions."

title: Seconds count: The Country School hosts active shooter training for law enforcement, EMS
author: Konner Metz
content:
Seconds count: The Country School hosts active shooter training for law enforcement, EMS

 July 31, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 591
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — With schools starting back up next month, police and first responders gathered at The Country School in Easton on Thursday to partake in active shooter training.Four separate drills took place Thursday. Officers entered the school to take down a mock shooter. They joined with paramedics and EMTs to locate mock students in classrooms, assess their injuries and evacuate them from the building in a safe manner.
Responders often communicated with one another on how to follow the proper incident command tactics, at times acknowledging the improvements they could make to their decisions during the drill. Caroline County Cpl. Kenny Tull said the drills will help improve all aspects of emergency response if a school shooting occurs on the Mid-Shore.
"It's a learning experience for everyone," Tull said.
In previous years, active shooter training took place at schools in Talbot and Caroline counties.
Recently, the drills have included a team of both law enforcement and EMS personnel called the Rescue Task Force. Once a hallway or area is cleared, officers will protect unarmed EMTs and paramedics in "warm zones," where danger may still exist even if the main threat is eliminated.
That practice is life-saving in a real situation, Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble said.
"Before, (EMS personnel) didn't go in until the building got cleared, which caused more deaths," he said. "The quicker we can get treatment for people, the quicker we can get paramedics in there with us, the more people that hopefully will survive."
Still, the top priority is eliminating the shooter or main threat.
"The initial driving force is stop the killing, because the statistics will show you that an assailant can kill more people than you can treat," Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey said.
"Their driving force is stop the dying," Lowrey said of EMTs and paramedics. "You toggle between those two driving forces."
Gamble said first responders have taken FEMA-required incident command training, which serves as a common baseline for members of different agencies.
"A lot of this stuff spawned out of 9/11, getting fire, police, paramedics everybody on the same page. Square up communications," Gamble said.
Having so many agencies on hand Thursday was an opportunity for first responders to acclimate with one another and become more comfortable working together during an emergency response, agency leaders said.
Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker emphasized that local agencies already share a solid rapport.
"You'd be surprised how much there is interaction between counties and agencies," Baker said.
Plus, the geography of Mid-Shore counties sometimes means Caroline County police may be first on the scene to a Talbot County emergency, or vice versa.
"For something that happens at Preston Elementary, Talbot County will be the first ones there," Talbot County Maj. Steve Elliott said. "If something happens at Chapel Elementary, Caroline County will be the first ones there."
Tina Kintop, EMS division chief for the Talbot County Department of Emergency Services, said it's most important for EMTs and paramedics to be disciplined and properly trained to participate in the rescue task force with police.
On Thursday, the drills didn't stop when the mock shooter went down. First responders secured students, assessed the severity of their injuries and evacuated them from the building. The job doesn't end there, Kintop said.
Police and EMS focus on locating a site for reunification of families. Gamble said different schools already have plans in place for reunification spots, some of which have been used for fire drills or bomb threats in the past.
By practicing these processes Thursday, agencies worked to create a streamlined plan they hope they will never have to use.
"It's all about organization and accountability," Kintop said.

Based on information gathered during the preliminary investigation, the teen suffered a stab wound to his neck during the incident on Road C in Hollingsworth Manor shortly before midnight Friday, according to Lt. Ronald Odom, an EPD detective and spokesman.
A driver and an unspecified number of passengers accompanied the boy to ChristianaCare's Union Hospital in Elkton in a private vehicle, after he had gone to a nearby house seeking help in the wake of suffering his stab wound, and they dropped him off at that medical center, Odom reported.

The teen was pronounced dead at that hospital, after emergency room doctors tried to revive him, Odom reported.
"He suffered the stab wound during a group assault on a single person — a man in his early 30s who is physically disabled. About five or six people of varying ages, including the teen, were in the group that was assaulting him," Odom outlined.
The man is missing his left arm from the elbow down, Odom confirmed Tuesday.
"A person who is not physically disabled would have had a hard time in that situation; this guy is physically disabled," Odom said.

"It looks like a pretty strong case of self-defense, which would make this a justifiable homicide. We also have reports that the people in that group had armed themselves with knives and sticks or clubs," Odom commented. "We are still investigating to determine a motive for the group attack."
The overall investigation is continuing, according to Odom.
Odom reported that investigators will consult with Cecil County State's Attorney James Dellmyer to determine what, if any, charges should be filed against the disabled man and also what, if any, charges should be filed against the people in the group that was attacking him

title: 'People are really motivated to take action': Rallies continue for pastor
author: Lily Tierney
content:
'People are really motivated to take action': Rallies continue for pastor

 August 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Local News 
 
 731
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Friday, The Talbot County Democratic Forum hosted a rally for Pastor Daniel Fuentes Espinal, who was detained by U.S. Customs and Immigration on July 21. This is the third rally held for Espinal since his arrest.Around 100 people showed up on the corner of Route 50 and Dover Street to support Espinal, including Talbot County Council Vice President Pete Lesher and Dan Schwartz, one of three Democratic candidates running for Maryland's first congressional district, which includes Easton.
Espinal was arrested on Monday, July 21, when ICE agents followed him from Lowe's to McDonald's, ultimately being arrested on Route 322 near the Easton pool.
He was initially taken to holding facility in Salisbury, then transferred to a temporary ICE facility in Baltimore, where he remained until July 24. He is now in Louisiana, where he is awaiting his hearing.
Espinal has been in the country since 2001 and has been pastor of Iglesia del Nazareno Jesús Te Ama since 2015. He has no criminal record, paid his taxes and was in the process of seeking legal status, according to his daughter Clarissa Fuentes Diaz.
ICE said in a statement to The Star Democrat that Espinal overstayed a six-month visa by 24 years. Espinal's arrest comes amid a push by the President Donald Trump and his administration to step up immigration enforcement.
Community members expressed "outrage" not only about Espinal's arrest, but by what they say is a lack of due process following.
Jim Bruce, a member of the Talbot County Democratic Forum communications committee, said the Trump administration's actions violate fundamental legal principles established as far back as the Magna Carta.
"How Pastor Espinal could wind up in Louisiana without any kind of hearing is it strikes me that there should have been due process afforded him," Bruce said.
Espinal has not had a hearing, and there is not currently one scheduled, according to Diaz.
A June poll from Pew Research Center found approval of the Trump administration's approach to immigration was largely split along party lines, with 78% of Republicans approving of the approach and 81% of Democrats disapproving.
But multiple Easton community members, like Espinal's close friend Len Foxwell, suggested his arrest by ICE has become a bipartisan issue.
"People from both parties can share their dissatisfaction with what's happening in the case of Pastor Fuentes Espinal and with the immigration system that is fundamentally broken in this country," said Foxwell, former chief of staff for Democratic Maryland Comptroller Peter Franchot.
These sentiments were echoed by Lesher, a Democrat, who said he believes that both parties are supporting Espinal because people have a sense of fairness.
"For somebody who was trying to work with the system, who is trying to do the right thing, who is paying taxes, who is raising a family, who was working and contributing to our community in so many ways. It just leads me to ask, why?" Lesher said.
Member of the Talbot County Democrat Forum Board of Directors Rick Hughes said it crosses party lines because it feels deeply personal to the community.
"The six degrees of separation make it so that it doesn't feels personal, and once you can make it personal, or it becomes personal, people are really motivated to take action," Hughes said.
Espinal's arrest has spurred protest outside of Easton.
A rally was held on Monday in Baltimore, where over 300 protesters marched from McKeldin Square to the Fallon Courthouse, the site of the temporary ICE detention center where Espinal was held before being transferred to Louisiana.
Democratic elected officials spoke once they reached the ICE facility, raising concerns about the transparency of the facility.
Earlier in the day, Maryland public officials, including U.S. Sens. Angela Alsobrooks (D-Md.) and Chris Van Hollen (D-Md.), were denied a tour of the temporary detention center in Baltimore and held a sit in.
"These are elected members of the U.S. Congress and they are entitled to have full unrestrained access to any government facility that they wish," Foxwell said. "But this is an administration that doesn't respect due process of the rule of law. And frankly, it is a terrible substandard subhuman facility," he said.
Foxwell said that while Espinal was in the Baltimore facility, he had no bed, shower or place to brush his teeth, and he did not receive his medication, including a heart medication.
The Talbot County Democratic Forum said it will continue to hold rallies on Friday's from 5:30 to 6:30 p.m. on Route 50 and Dover Street.

content:
Sheriff's Office will absorb Federalsburg Police Department, Town Council says

 August 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 405
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FEDERALSBURG — While an agreement has not yet been signed, Federalsburg officials said the Caroline County Sheriff's Office will absorb the Federalsburg Police Department, taking over policing duties for the town.The Town Council had yet to work out the exact details of a memorandum of understanding with the Sheriff's Office at the town's meeting Monday evening. The council did not vote on the matter, but they indicated they planned to sign an agreement for one year of policing services.
According to council member Brandy James, all Federalsburg Police Department staff will move to the Caroline County Sheriff's Office when the agreement is signed. The Sheriff's Office will use the current Federalsburg Police Department as a substation.
The decision comes as the town tries to tackle $5 million in debt.
James said the police department takes up half of the town's budget. At Federalsburg Public Forum on July 21, council member Ian Furgerson said if the town were to sign an MOU with the Sheriff's Office, it would save the town between $300,000 and $500,000 per year.
Multiple items in the MOU are still being discussed, but the current draft includes five deputies to be assigned to the town. Town Attorney Lyndsey Ryan made it clear to the public the MOU is still a work-in-progress, and the number of officers has not been confirmed.
"I also want to add that while there's been discussions about the number of officers to include in an MOU, there will be an MOU once it's kind of ironed out and reviewed and everything on a Federalsburg agenda, and there will be a public hearing on it," Ryan said.
"The decision has not been made as of now. I think that's the direction that they're going, but there still will be an actual agreement on an agenda for a public comment and a vote."
James said this is the best decision for the town and the officers.
"It actually giving these officers what they so much needed, which is increase in salary," James said. "They get access to le-ops, they get more than what we as a town can provide to them. Police and is very competitive, and Federalsburg is one of the lowest paid agencies. So we felt as we wanted to give this MOU situation a try for a year, and throughout that year we want to have quarterly meetings with the public."
The MOU will have a public hearing at a future Federalsburg Town Council meeting.

title: Sheriff warns of rising scams targeting local businesses, residents
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Sheriff warns of rising scams targeting local businesses, residents

 August 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Headlines 
 
 510
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — The Queen Anne's County Chamber of Commerce welcomed Sheriff Gary Hofmann on July 30 as part of its ongoing seminar series, where he provided an in-depth look at the latest scams affecting businesses and individuals — and the steps they can take to protect themselves.Speaking at the Kent Island Library, Hofmann emphasized the importance of awareness and vigilance in a county he described as "very trusting and generous," where numerous worthwhile charities and nonprofits operate.
"Benefactors should always verify the legitimacy of an organization before donating," he said.
Hofmann outlined how small businesses, which often lack training and robust IT resources, are frequently targeted. Scammers may use stolen credit cards to place large orders, leaving businesses unaware until it is too late. To reduce risk, Hofmann recommended printing invoices and verifying identification when fulfilling pickup orders.
He also warned of phishing emails and fake invoices that can appear legitimate but include malicious links or fraudulent payment requests.
"If you find something out of the ordinary or that looks suspicious, take a breath," Hofmann said. "Scammers often use fear or urgency tactics — like threatening to cut off power — to compel quick action. It's important to slow down."
One common scam involves demands for payment via prepaid gift cards. In other cases, scammers impersonate tech support, offering to fix nonexisting issues in exchange for access to personal data.
Hofmann said data harvesting can occur almost anywhere. Fake job postings often request personal information or payment for background checks. "Check washing" is also on the rise — criminals steal checks from mailboxes and alter them to commit fraud. Hofmann advised residents to walk checks directly into the post office to minimize risk.
"Using secure payment methods and monitoring accounts regularly is key," he said. "Set up alerts for check clearances and large withdrawals, and implement internal controls like requiring two signatures."
When writing checks, Hofmann recommended pressing firmly into the paper to make alterations more difficult. He also urged residents to shred sensitive documents before disposal to avoid "dumpster identity theft."
"We don't think about how much information we're putting out there when we throw things away," he said.
With the rise of contactless payments, Hofmann encouraged people to cover the front of their credit cards at checkout to prevent nearby cameras from capturing card numbers. He also warned about credit card skimmers — devices that mimic real readers and can steal information from magnetic strips using hidden cameras or overlays.
Other scams include:
Overpayment scams, where fraudsters send more than the owed amount and request a refund before the original check bounces.Malicious QR codes that direct users to phishing sites or install malware.Tax scammers impersonating government agencies.Ransomware attacks that encrypt a victim's data until payment is made.
Hofmann stressed that education and prevention are the best tools to stay ahead of increasingly sophisticated criminals. Staff training, multi-factor authentication, and careful scrutiny of digital communications are essential.
"Taking the extra time to assess and validate links is imperative," he said. "Multi-factor authentication might be inconvenient, but it can save you a lot of headaches down the line."
He also encouraged reporting suspicious activity.

title: CPS staff under investigation in Caroline County
author: Lily Tierney
content:
CPS staff under investigation in Caroline County

 August 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Caroline 
 
 746
 Words 

 Read News Document

 An investigation into the work of Caroline County Child Protective Services is long overdue, county Sheriff Donnie Baker said.The internal investigation into CPS staff was prompted by an incident on July 13, where a social worker never arrived to a home where child abuse and neglect was reported, according to Baker.
He said the agency has been "lacking in their responses," including showing up over an hour after being called or not responding to calls of abuse or neglect until law enforcement has already handled the situation.
"There are some issues that the local Caroline County Department of Social Services needs to work out, and we have been working with them for quite some time to work out," Baker said.
The state Department of Human Services is conducting the internal investigation. Maryland State Police are investigating the report of abuse and neglect.
Baker and Caroline County State's Attorney Sloane Franklin met with the secretary of Human Services about a year ago to address long CPS response times.
"We were promised a lot of changes, and unfortunately, those changes have not come to fruition," Baker said.
The Caroline County Department of Social Services, which oversees CPS, did not respond to requests for comment.
Ben Shnider, director of communications for the state Department of Human Services, which oversees the Caroline County department, wrote in an email to the Star Democrat, "The safety and well-being of Maryland's children is our highest priority, and local departments of social services respond to every report of alleged child abuse or neglect."
According to Department of Human Services policy, the Caroline County Child Protective Services response times fall within the guidelines for responding to reports for the examples that Baker cited.
The policy calls for:
Answering calls of physical or sexual abuse within 24 hours.Answering calls for reports of neglect within five calendar days.Answering calls for cases of substance-exposed newborns within 48 hours.
But Baker and Franklin said this policy leaves law enforcement to act as a middle man, but addressing the problem is complicated.
The Caroline County Department of Social Services is a state-run agency over which the county has no control, making it difficult for local agencies and officials to affect change, Franklin said.
"I have no power to enforce changes, I can only make recommendations," Franklin said.
Baker and Franklin said there have been unfulfilled promises of solutions since the problems began during the pandemic but were vague as to what those problems and promises were, saying they wanted to preserve their working relationships with CPS.
Both said they want a better working relationship with Child Protective Services. State law mandates law enforcement agencies working with CPS.
After-hours reports of child neglect or abuse can be handled in a few different ways. In cases involving high or even moderate risks, a Child Protective Services case worker should be automatically dispatched, but if they cannot respond, law enforcement, generally the sheriff's office, will be sent.
Because of the mandated joint investigations, Baker said law enforcement officers have been picking up the slack when the case workers do not arrive, leading to increased frustration by the officers on the scene.
Part of the problem may be vacancies in the state Department of Human Services, where there is a 7% vacancy rate, although Baker said he thinks the root cause stems from procedural and cultural issues that start with upper management.
"I would say that everything starts from upper management and works its way down as far as a cultural issue," he said. "And I think that there are some procedural issues within the agency itself."
Baker spent a majority of his career working in child abuse investigations and said they are near and dear to his heart.
"I know how hard that is, so it's very disheartening to me when we do not have good partners," Baker said.
Shnider, the Department of Human Services communications director, said his agency "is committed to holding ourselves accountable." His email statement said the department will address any systemic issues that are identified through the investigation.
"Any failure to respond to a report of abuse or neglect in a timely manner is unacceptable," Shnider said. "When mistakes are made, we hold ourselves accountable and take action to ensure we do better moving forward."
In the meantime, Baker and Franklin hope the investigation will bring systemic change that will enhance their partnerships and the safety of the children in Caroline County.
"I hope that some accountability and changes will come to better protect the kids," Franklin said.
This report has been updated to clarify that MSP and DHS are conducting separate investigations.

title: Surging ICE arrests raising community concerns
author: Konner Metz
content:
Surging ICE arrests raising community concerns

 August 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: News 
 
 903
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Matthew Peters noticed a stark change at last week's annual National Night Out mixer between residents and police officers from years prior. The immigrant community was largely missing."A lot of our community right now is feeling scared, not wanting to come here," said Peters, executive director of the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center. "If you were here last year and the year before, our community looked different."
Speaking to families at Moton Park in Easton, Peters asked them to keep the local immigrant community in their minds. His appeal comes amid a ramp-up in U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement activity on the Eastern Shore, which has spurred similar calls to action by local governments in Easton and Cambridge.
Feelings of fear and uncertainty have been vocalized early this week by many Eastern Shore residents on social media, who have shared hundreds of posts containing photos, videos and reports of unconfirmed ICE arrests.
"ICE was here today and made some arrests. I mean, it seems like they're here more often than ever," Easton Councilmember the Rev. Elmer Davis said at last week's Town Council meeting.
"It's deeply troubling that such actions have caused young immigrants to fear attending school, worried that their parents might be taken away," Davis said. "No one should live in fear in Easton or in this country, and every person deserves safety and opportunity and a chance to live without the shadow of oppression."
As local officials speak out on residents' concerns, it's still unclear just how many arrests immigration agents are making day-to-day. ICE's Baltimore field office did not respond to a request for comment in time for publication.
Nationwide, immigration arrests have surged since President Donald Trump took office in January. Trump campaigned on stepping up immigration enforcement, promising a mass deportation that targeted criminals.
"Across the country, arrests of criminal illegal immigrants have soared as President Donald Trump makes good on his promise to rid our communities of these threats to public safety," the White House said in a press release on July 22.
According to the press release, ICE arrests in Maryland have jumped 290% since Trump took office. U.S. Customs and Immigration data from June 29 shows a recent shift from focusing mainly on those with criminal records to arresting those without a record. Out of 57,861 people detained by ICE, 41,495 had no criminal convictions.
Members of the Trump administration maintain that targeting criminals remains the administration's priority.
INCREASED ICE ACTIVITY
Cambridge Mayor Lajan Cephas and Cambridge Police Department Chief Justin Todd each issued statements indicating increased ICE activity in city limits.
Cephas said in a statement the city was made aware of last week's activity "after the fact." In an interview, she added that she's contacted Gov. Wes Moore (D), Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md.), and Sen. Angela Alsobrooks (D-Md.). Cephas said they have been in communication and are collecting information on whether constitutional rights may have been violated in interactions with ICE.
"You don't have to be a U.S. citizen to have constitutional rights," Cephas said. "It's for everybody that has stepped foot anywhere in the U.S. territories."
Todd said in an interview last Wednesday that Cambridge police have received phone calls and video footage from residents of the unconfirmed ICE activity. The department wasn't previously aware of the activity, he said.
Easton police have indicated they're aware of ICE activity. But Deputy Chief Greg Wright said the department hasn't been involved in arrests and cannot provide specific details.
Cephas urged residents not to engage with immigration agents. In a statement, she asked residents to send her photos or videos of "perceived inappropriate actions" by immigration agents, details she plans to forward to Congress members.
Elected officials in Easton shared similar thoughts at Monday's meeting. Town Council President Don Abbatiello encouraged residents to reach out to Harris, Alsobrooks and Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-Md.).
FEARS
Fears from the immigrant and Hispanic communities in Easton have gained national attention since the arrest of Honduras-born Daniel Fuentes Espinal, a longtime pastor of Iglesia del Nazareno Jesús Te Ama, on July 21.
ICE confirmed Espinal, who came to Easton in 2001, was arrested for overstaying a six-month visa. He is being detained in Louisiana, his daughter Clarissa Fuentes Diaz said. A hearing for Espinal had not been scheduled as of Tuesday, she said.
Protesters calling for Espinal's return have gathered in Easton the last two Fridays, many of them appealing to Harris, whose congressional district includes the Eastern Shore, to take action.
Harris maintained on Wednesday that his office is in the process of determining what power U.S. Department of Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem holds "in stopping deportations."
"Once we figure out exactly what the secretary can do, (Espinal's) will be one of a number of cases where we will ask the secretary to exert the discretion we think she has," Harris said after an unrelated press conference in Tilghman Island. "But we're going to determine that first before she makes her ask."
At recent protests, residents have expressed fear and anger that the pastor was taken from the community. Now, those sentiments are spreading among residents across the Eastern Shore.
At the National Night Out in Easton on Tuesday, Peters said it's key to continue supporting immigrant communities, especially at events including local officials like police and first responders.
"A lot of people are scared right now," he said. "And I think at events like this, we got to keep these going to show the solidarity we have with our entire community."
Reporter Lily Tierney contributed to this story.
