title: ‘It’s how people should be’: Man credited with rescuing woman, dogs from house fire
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
‘It’s how people should be’: Man credited with rescuing woman, dogs from house fire

 August 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 437
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A Brookside man is being praised for his courage and selflessness after helping a woman and her dogs escape from a house fire last week.Jose Mercado, 34, was leaving his Merry Road house to go to work on the morning of July 28 when he saw a nearby house on fire. He drove the short distance to the burning house and banged on the door to alert the woman inside to the fire.
After assisting her and one of her dogs out of the house, Mercado ran into the burning home in search of the woman's other dog.
"I thought, go to the worst part of the house first, because that's where the dog might be," he said. "So I went upstairs. It was pitch black. I couldn't see in the room, there was so much smoke. I had my shirt over my face."
He could hear the dog barking and finally located it.
"I saw the dog downstairs when I was looking around, and I threw a blanket over him, and I wrapped him up, and I took him outside," he said.
Mercado went back into the house to look for the resident's car keys in an attempt to move the vehicle so it wasn't damaged by the fire, but he was unsuccessful in finding them.
"We are grateful for his courage and selfless act during this situation — and the positive outcome for both the resident and Mr. Mercado," said Lawrence Tan, spokesman for Aetna Hose, Hook and Ladder Company.
Mercado left the scene without seeking recognition, and the fire department only learned of his actions after being notified by another neighbor, Tan said.
Mercado said he was just in the right place at the right time.
"Thankfully, I was there to see," he said. "No one else saw it. It was just wild. It's perfect timing for me."
Mercado said he has young kids and would hope someone else would do the same thing to help them.
"It's how people should be," he said.
While Tan praised Mercado's actions, he made sure to note that the fire department does not encourage witnesses to enter burning buildings.
"Entering a burning structure places an individual into an environment that is immediately dangerous to life and health," he said. "It only takes seconds for someone to become overwhelmed by smoke or heat and lose consciousness — making the situation worse. Persons entering a burning structure without the appropriate training and protective equipment can actually further endanger someone who is trapped, since firefighters would need additional resources and time to find and rescue both the original victim and a well-intentioned bystander that was overcome by smoke, heat and poisonous gases."

title: Police: Armed neighbor thwarts home invasion attempt
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Police: Armed neighbor thwarts home invasion attempt

 August 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 499
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ELKTON — Investigators are crediting a resident in an Elkton neighborhood with thwarting an attempted home invasion at his neighbor's house by detaining the suspect at gunpoint until officers arrived, according to Cecil County District Court records.The incident occurred at approximately 12:15 a.m. on Saturday, Aug, 9. when a suspect identified as Caleb N. Cline, 23, pounded on a door of a residence in the unit block of Upland Court, which is part of the Buckhill Farms community in eastern Elkton, and repeatedly yelled threats to kill the occupant, police reported.
Court records indicate that the victim does not know Cline and, as of Tuesday, information regarding why Cline allegedly targeted that home and the person inside of that dwelling was unavailable. The charging document also alleges that Cline was attempting to break into the home.
During a lull — before the suspect allegedly started pounding on the door again and screaming threats to kill — the resident inside of the dwelling called his "longtime friend and neighbor" and alerted him to the real-time situation, police reported.
The occupant then opened a second-floor window and looked outside to investigate, police said. At that point, he saw Cline, who allegedly said, "Come out here; I want to kill you" after noticing the occupant peeping out the window, police added.
Moments later, the occupant grabbed a baseball bat for protection and went outside after he saw his neighbor walking toward his targeted home, court records show. The occupant heard his neighbor warn the suspect, "Don't move — I have a gun," police reported.
The neighbor told investigators that he instructed his wife to call 911, after he grabbed his gun, and then headed toward the targeted home to confront the suspect, police said. As officers with the Elkton Police Department rushed to the scene, a dispatcher reported that the suspect was being "detained by a neighbor of the victim at gunpoint," police added.
Court records indicate that, according to his account, the neighbor told the suspect, "I have gun, lay down."
"He reported that Cline complied and even put his hands behind his back at one point. He reported that while they were waiting for the police to respond, Cline was saying all kinds of things that did not make sense. He reported that they tried to talk to him and calm him down. (The neighbor) reported that he held his gun behind his back, out of view of the suspect, to help him remain calm," according to the charging document, which indicates that no physical contact was made during the incident.
Officers arrested Cline after they arrived at the scene, police reported.
Cline is facing six criminal charges, including attempted home invasion, attempted fourth-degree burglary of a dwelling, trespassing and disturbing the peace, court records show.
He spent two nights in the Cecil County Detention Center on no bond, before gaining his pre-trial release Monday on an unsecured $5,000 bond after his bail review hearing in front of Cecil County District Court Judge Denise Winston, according to court records.

title: Talbot's advanced life support pioneers reflect on program's 40-year mark
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot's advanced life support pioneers reflect on program's 40-year mark

 August 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 722
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — Pioneers in Talbot County's advanced life support services gathered this week to reminisce on the 40-year anniversary of their revolutionary effort to improve emergency response on the Mid-Shore.Five Easton firefighters began volunteering to man a new advanced life support, or ALS, program on Aug. 13, 1985. They had just one vehicle from the fire department. They sacrificed time at home and kept up constant communication to ensure someone was ready to respond to a cardiac emergency at any given moment.
The "first five," as they're often called, were Wayne Dyott, Kevin Knussman, Marc Stockley, Ray Taylor and the late Gary Jones.
Wednesday afternoon inside the Harrison's Harbour Lights restaurant in St. Michaels, the four men shared laughs and memories of the effort they spearheaded four decades ago to the day.
"It was quite a haul," Stockley recalled. "And unfortunately, in the past five years, I've been able to use this (ALS) system several times. And seeing the changes. It's been interesting to see the advancements. The care level is always there."
They were joined by others integral to the early success and soon-to-come expansion of paramedic services in Talbot County: Margie Callahan, then-nurse coordinator at Easton Memorial Hospital, and Buddy Harrison IV, former County Council president and the first director of Talbot County Advanced Life Support.
They all took time to reflect on Jones' integral role in the effort.
Jones, former director of cardiovascular services at the Easton hospital, died in 2021. Dyott said Jones joined the fire company in the 1980s knowing the ALS program was about to kick off.
"Ultimately, he was a good bridge between hospital staff, them accepting us and bringing the whole program together," Stockley said.
'SKEPTICISM AT FIRST'
Jones and others worked to show people the importance of pre-hospital cardiac care and why countywide ALS services were needed.
A half-decade ago, response times for heart emergencies could sometimes be 20 to 30 minutes. First responders typically reported to the fire station, then traveled to the location of the emergency.
Taylor said it was hard at first for fire companies to even accept EMTs back in the 1970s. The five men, certified as cardiac rescue technicians, aimed to change that.
"We kept hearing the same thing: 'you're not doctors, you don't need to play doctor on the ambulance,'" Taylor said.
Fire department and hospital leaders eventually warmed up to the ALS program, Taylor said. It didn't come without questions from the community, Stockley noted.
"I think there was skepticism at first, but I think it came around eventually when they started seeing positive results," he said.
On Wednesday, Taylor recalled what may have been the first of those positive outcomes. In 1985, he and Dyott rode in the ALS vehicle to the scene of an overturned truck and a man lying down. Taylor successfully defibrillated the man, and that began to turn heads in the right direction.
"It's a good feeling," Taylor recalled.
IMPACT FELT TODAY
Since 1985, the modest five-person, volunteer venture in Easton has transformed to a countywide staple. The Talbot County Department of Emergency Services operates six ALS units and one "chase vehicle" for rapid response. Over 50 paramedics and EMTs staff the units, some full-time and others volunteers.
The hard work of the original five was done with the hope of having a comprehensive system like the one that exists today, Dyott said.
"That's what we started. That was our goal, our ambition," he said.
Tina Kintop, Talbot's EMS division chief, said the division's current success and bandwidth wouldn't be possible without those pioneers. Crews responded to around 6,800 calls last year, she noted.
"We are better prepared and educated more than ever in the life-saving business," Kintop wrote. "Thank you to the visionaries 40 years ago and to those advancing ahead today."
Callahan similarly credits the first five for persevering through the doubts and paramedic funding struggles in 1985 and the years after.
"They were a part of seeing this all come to fruition," she said.
Over the last 40 years, it has always been about saving lives, said Talbot County's original ALS leaders. Knussman said all the vehicle swaps and early morning phone calls were well worth it.
"I think all of us would agree that the people on the street today are better trained, better educated, better equipped and better organized," Knussman said. "That's something that all four of us, and Gary if he were here, that's something to be proud of."

title: Conversation topic: combining police, sheriff
author: STEPHEN RIDEOUT
content:
Conversation topic: combining police, sheriff

 August 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEPHEN RIDEOUT | Section: Columns 
 
 496
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In these challenging times, so much has changed and is being uprooted. Much that was familiar and consistent is now gone. I recall years ago being on an airplane going to give a speech in Alabama when I saw a woman wearing a Dilbert sweatshirt. Above Dilbert was written "Change is Good!" and below Dilbert was written "You go first!"While I thought at the time that what was written spoke to me, much of the change that is happening now is not perceived by many as being good, but it is happening anyway. Those who disagree with the change need to think about how they might make change to confront or address the current change that is happening daily if not in some cases hourly.
Years ago, after I moved to Cambridge, I thought that one change that needed to be considered was how the county, Cambridge, and Hurlock address the challenges of crime in Dorchester County with separate police forces and the sheriff's office. There is, of course, the sheriff, who is elected and two cities with police forces that have police chiefs and staff who are hired by the cities. There are in Maryland and elsewhere in the country, countywide police forces that also work within the cities in those counties. There are also sheriffs in those counties who oversee the safety of the courthouse and the local jail as well as serve court process both civil and criminal.
When I was on city council, I learned that Cambridge alone spent more for its police department than the county did for the sheriff's office. At the same time, the residents of Cambridge and Hurlock are paying county taxes, some of which paid for the sheriff and its staff that do not work full-time in the cities, although they do collaborate with the state and local police on some joint task forces.
Given our current times with less federal and state money coming to the counties and cities and the burden on city taxpayers who also pay county taxes, would it not be a good time for the County Council and the city councils of Cambridge and Hurlock to take a look at the cost of these departments, duplication of staff leadership positions and current areas of need to see if there might be a more efficient and less expensive way to protect all of the residents of Dorchester County than currently exists.
If that study were undertaken by the county manager who has expertise in this area and the city managers with a report back to elected leadership, some "change" that could be "good" could be accomplished. By finding a new and separate way to respond locally to the unexpected and significant changes that are coming to counties and cities because of how federal and state monies are being diverted, some new ways to address the needs of local communities might be found in this area and others.
At the very least is it not worth a conversation?

title: Remembering Sgt. Mowbray: community marks 50 years since officer’s line-of-duty death
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Remembering Sgt. Mowbray: community marks 50 years since officer’s line-of-duty death

 August 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 548
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — The community gathered Aug. 9 to mark the 50th anniversary of Mowbray Park's rededication and honor Maryland State Police Sgt. Wallace J. Mowbray, who was killed in the line of duty in 1975.Mowbray, 39, was shot while performing a routine stop on a suspicious vehicle near a liquor store in Chester shortly before midnight on Aug. 9, 1975. Investigators later found that the van had stolen registration plates and that two of its occupants had outstanding warrants.
Mowbray was flown to a Baltimore hospital, where he died shortly after midnight on Aug. 10. He had served 13 years with the Maryland State Police.
"Everybody that I've had conversations with knew exactly where they were and what they were doing," said Parks and Recreation Director Steve Chandlee, reflecting on the close-knit feel of the county and the impact of Mowbray's death.
County Commissioner Chris Corchiarino said Mowbray was a husband, father and natural-born police officer who, on the night he was killed, was doing what he did best: protecting the community.
"The loss of Mowbray does not erase the good he did, the lives he touched, and the safety he ensured," Corchiarino said. "As we rededicate this memorial, we renew our promise to never forget his sacrifice and character and the enduring impact he left on our community."
Mowbray was also an active member of the community, participating regularly in softball and Little League. Mowbray Park, named in his honor, serves as a safe place for children to play.
Deputy Sgt. Ryan Davidson of the Queen Anne's County Office of the Sheriff said the rededication reaffirmed the community's promise to protect first responders and remember that behind every badge is a human being.
"The park will continue to serve as a place of recreation, reflection on bravery, and a reminder of one who represented the best of the community," Davidson said.
Patrick McLaughlin, now a county commissioner, recalled visiting the park with his children before he knew its namesake. "It just meant so much to me," he said.
Gretchen McKethan, of Kent Island, attended the ceremony on behalf of a grateful community. She graduated in 1975 with Rusty, the youngest Mowbray son. "It was devastating to celebrate our senior year one month and lose your father another," she said. "It's a tearful day and a happy day. Everyone knew and loved Trooper Mowbray."
Nancy Davis recalled that her father, Jack Stowe, worked in the Chester liquor store and heard the gunshots that night. She reflected on how close she could have been to losing her own father if not for Mowbray's courageous actions.
Robin Mowbray, the oldest daughter, said it was inspiring to learn how many lives her father touched. "We had each other," she said, noting the family also received strong support from the Maryland State Police. She authored a book, The Ultimate Sacrifice: The Story of Maryland State Policeman Sgt. Wallace J. Mowbray.
On the park's original opening day in the 1970s, Robin's brother Ryan, then 12, hit the first Little League home run out of the field. "This gives me chills to this day. I bet our dad was smiling up in Heaven that day," she said.
Mowbray Park is located at 629 Romancoke Road in Stevensville. More information about Mowbray's story is available at odmp.org, and details about the park can be found at qac.org.

title: Espinal, Easton pastor arrested by ICE, returns home
author: Konner Metz
content:
Espinal, Easton pastor arrested by ICE, returns home

 August 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 269
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Daniel Fuentes Espinal returned home Friday after nearly a month of being detained by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement.Espinal's daughter, Clarissa Fuentes Diaz, flew to Louisiana last week to bring Espinal home, according to a Facebook post by family friend Len Foxwell on Friday.
"It was an emotional time for me — to see him after almost a month of not seeing him," Diaz told The Baltimore Banner.
Espinal, pastor of Iglesia del Nazareno Jesús Te Ama since 2015, was arrested the morning of July 21. He was on his way to his construction job, his family said. He was taken to ICE's field office in Salisbury and then transferred to Baltimore, where he spent three nights in Baltimore before being transferred to a detention center in Louisiana.
Espinal was granted bond on Tuesday, family told The Baltimore Banner.
His arrest received regional and national attention. In Easton, it stopped services at his congregation and sparked weekly protests against ICE.
Earlier this month, Easton Town Council members called for Espinal to be returned to his family.
Espinal has been in the country since 2001 and has no criminal record, his family has said. Following his arrest, ICE stated that Espinal was arrested for overstaying his six-month visa.
"Daniel Omar Fuentes Espinal is an illegal alien from Honduras who was arrested by ICE on July 21, in Easton, Maryland," the statement said. "Fuentes entered the United States on a 6-month visa and never left in 24 years. It is a federal crime to overstay the authorized period of time granted under a visitors visa."
This story may be updated.
Reporter Lily Tierney contributed to this story.

 EASTON — Police arrested two people last week on firearm charges stemming from an incident at the Days Inn hotel in Easton.Ernest Young Jr., 40, of Federalsburg and Katherine Adkins, 29, of Queen Anne were both arrested on Aug. 12 after an incident that afternoon. Young is charged with first-degree assault, home invasion, reckless endangerment and four firearm charges.

An officer saw Adkins on the second floor and approached her. Adkins told officers "there was no gun" and soon after "doubled down" on that assertion, court records state.
Officers found a gun in the second-floor room, which was allegedly the same one hidden by Adkins and held by Young during the incident on the first floor.
Adkins was released on $25,000 unsecured personal bond on Aug. 14. A preliminary hearing is set for Sept. 2.
Young posted $1,000 cash bond on Aug. 3. His preliminary hearing is set for Sept. 3.

title: Report: Dorchester County K-9 died in hot car
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Report: Dorchester County K-9 died in hot car

 August 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 580
 Words 

 Read News Document

 An investigation into the death of a Dorchester County K-9 revealed the dog died after being left in a hot car.The Dorchester County Sheriff's Office released a statement on June 26 announcing the "untimely" death of 5-year-old K-9 Ender. The statement reported that a full and independent investigation would be handled by the Wicomico County Sheriff's Office.
In an interview Tuesday, Capt. Rich Wiersberg of the Wicomico County Sheriff's Office, who handled the investigation, confirmed that K-9 Ender's death was heat-related due to being left in a car.
The investigation is now in the hands of Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard. Wiersberg said he finished his investigation and handed it over to Leonard on Aug. 11. The state's attorney's office will review the file and decide whether to refer it to another office or keep it.
"We are happy to help Dorchester County Sheriff's Office with the investigation and hope to reach a conclusion soon," Wiersberg said.
The Dorchester County sheriff declined to comment on the open investigation.
The dog's death has left the Throw Away Dog Project, a dog training company that donated Ender to the Dorchester County Sheriff's Office in 2022, with many questions.
"I actually found out from an outside source once Ender passed, which prompted me to call the sheriff's office," founder Carol Skaziak said. "So no phone call from the handler at all, no phone call from the county or the sheriff's office."
The Throw Away Dog Project has placed 70 dogs nationwide, four of them on the Eastern Shore. The organization trains the K-9s, covers the cost of handler training and donates the animals to join the line of duty.
They provide specific instructions on what to do when a K-9 dies.
"As an organization, I said, we have a contract. You signed our contract. And I said, one of the stipulations in the contract is upon the death of the dog, the dog must go to a veterinarian and an autopsy must be done," Skaziak said.
Skaziak said she was told by the Dorchester County Sheriff's Office that Ender's body was taken straight from the handler's house to be cremated.
"You cremated an officer's body without finding out what was wrong because he is an officer of the law," Skaziak said. "No proper ceremony, no honoring this dog that served his county. Why wasn't this done? Why?"
Skaziak said Ender died while his handler was off-duty. She said she was told by the Dorchester County Sheriff's Office that there was a mechanical issue with the vehicle in which the dog was left.
"What I do know is the vehicle was equipped with a Hot-N-Pop system, which is a heat alarm," Skaziak said.
The Hot-N-Pop system is a K-9 heat alarm that is accompanied by an app that notifies the handler of real-time temperature status.
According to Skaziak, if the handler does not respond to a warning or alert, a loud alarm will blare and the windows will automatically be lowered. Skaziak said she was told there was nothing wrong with the heat alarm in the handler's vehicle.
The death of K-9 Ender has prompted Skaziak to advocate for new legislation in his honor. The "K-9 Ender Law" she proposes is state legislation that would mandate working, tested heat alarm systems in all K-9 police vehicles with recorded tests and penalties for non-compliance.
"We're going to hopefully start it in Maryland where every K-9 police car is to have a working heat alarm system that is tested and those tests need to be recorded with their department," Skaziak said.

title: Cambridge Police Department presents second quarter report
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Cambridge Police Department presents second quarter report

 August 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Events 
 
 439
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Capt. Shane Hinson of the Cambridge Police Department presented the department's 2025 second quarter report at the Aug. 11 Cambridge City Council meeting.The report presents a snapshot of police data from April to June of this year, which reveals that overall crime has decreased. But there are still concerns regarding homicides, robberies and juvenile violence, Hinson said.
Hinson said during the meeting that adopting the "policing with a purpose" procedure last year has been effective at catching crime quickly or preventing it before it happens.
Policing with a purpose uses "analytics and statistics to determine which areas of the city need more attention," Hinson said. When officers go into these areas, they are encouraged to interact with the community and stay for a minimum of 15 minutes.
"We're able to look at those numbers and say, 'okay, we need an officer to be here at least 15 minutes every two hours,'" said Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd in an interview. "It allows people to be seen, engaged, and I truly believe that that's what's helping."
Because of this procedure, the total cost of services has increased while the number of calls made to the department remained about the same, per the quarterly report.
Homicides, assaults, larceny and motor vehicle theft all increased from the second quarter in 2024. The homicide rate rose 200%, with two homicides that both led to arrests. One of the homicides was committed by a juvenile.
Assaults slightly increased by 2.1% with one more than last year, larceny offenses increased by 78.5% from 14 to 25 cases in the past year, and motor vehicle thefts increased from 12 to 15 over the same time period.
However, the total number of offenses decreased by 5.5% from 109 in the second quarter of 2024 to 103 in the second quarter of 2025.
Cambridge continues to see stable statistics regarding juvenile delinquency, with 42 juvenile charges in the past three months, some of which are serious and violent crimes like homicide, second degree assault and motor vehicle theft, according to the report.
"These are unprecedented times in our community," said Council President Sputty Chephas on the state of juvenile violence in Cambridge.
The Cambridge teen court deals with minor offenses "like if a kid is vaping at school," said Todd. The teen court program was launched in May, and Todd said it is showing early promises of curbing juvenile offenses.
"They have to go before their peers and be judged by a jury. And then they get found in sentence, whether it be guilty, not guilty, and they get a punishment handed down to them, such as community service hours, such things as that," Todd said.

title: Old mill to be demolished

Old mill to be demolished

 Following lengthy discussion and community considerations, the Centreville Town Council announced intentions to demolish the old mill building at 2647 Centreville Road.Presenting its findings of fact following a recent public hearing, the council on Aug. 7, identified the structure to be a dangerous building that poses a risk to public safety.
Presenting the demolition order, the council stated the property owner has 10 days from the Aug. 7 meeting to demolish the building and in the event of failing to do so, the town may cause the structure to be demolished.
It was also noted, in the first step to acquiring a search warrant for dangerous buildings, the council unanimously approved an ordinance to add a new related town code chapter.
State law requires a town code chapter be in place in order to get an administrative search warrant from a judge.
The town would then have to go to court and get a search warrant before entering the property. The intention is to allow inspectors onto property the town deems pose a public safety risk.
The now more permanent administrative search warrant ordinance is related to the emergency version issued earlier this year.
The ordinance's initial draft received considerable public outcry but no public comment was presented at the hearing.
"So that feels like a good sign," Council President Ashley Kaiser said.
The council has made significant progress in ordinance developments to make it more palatable but public education will be needed before initiating any type of robust enforcement, she said.
"I think it is a step in the right direction and puts us in line with a lot of towns around us," Kaiser said.
In other business, three applications have been received for the two chairs open in the council's upcoming October election.
The Ethics Board will review applications before considerations are brought to the Board of Supervisors of Elections.
Although currently on the ballot for re-election, Council Member Jim Beauchamp noted he intended to withdraw if both other candidates move forward.

title: County buys mask testing system to keep firefighters safe
author: Staff Writer
content:
County buys mask testing system to keep firefighters safe

 August 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Local News 
 
 302
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Volunteer firefighters across Talbot County will soon benefit from new technology designed to keep them safer on the job.At a recent Fire Chiefs Committee meeting, fire chiefs gathered around their brand new AeroFit testing system, a device that delivers precise, OSHA-compliant fit tests for N95 respirators, elastomeric masks and other protective gear. The equipment, fully funded by the county, was purchased to reduce costs for local stations and increase safety for emergency responders.
Until now, fire companies had to pay for individual fit testing services, which added up in cost and required outside scheduling. With the new AeroFit system, once staff are trained, the tool can be used at any station, as well as other local emergency responders, to test firefighter masks, N95 respirators, gas masks and more.
This flexibility means the system will not only help volunteer fire departments but will strengthen readiness across all county emergency responders.
Properly fitted masks are essential for protecting firefighters and other emergency personnel from hazardous smoke, chemicals and airborne particulates. With AeroFit's advanced technology, firefighters will know their equipment is performing as intended before entering dangerous environments.
"Providing our firefighters with the right tools is critical," stated Jimmy Eason, President of the Talbot County Volunteer Fire & Rescue Association "With the county's support, this system ensures that every responder, whether volunteer, law enforcement, or emergency services staff, can be confident their protective equipment will keep them safe."
The purchase of the AeroFit system is part of Talbot County's ongoing investment in the safety of both residents and first responders. Each year, the county provides funding for the seven volunteer fire companies through its annual budget appropriation.  Two teens allegedly attempted to carjack a man at gunpoint at an Elkton carwash — a crime that was captured on video by a business security camera, according to the Elkton Police Department.Investigators identified the suspects as Landon Shane Diebold and Aiden Anthony Meadows, both of whom are 18 and both of whom are Elkton residents who reside at the same address.
The investigation leading to their arrests and the charges against them started at approximately 3 a.m. on Friday, when EPD officers rushed to the Elkton Car Wash in the 500 block of North Bridge Street after receiving a dispatch regarding an attempted armed robbery, police reported.
According to Cecil County District Court records, the victim told investigators that three males dressed in all-black clothing approached him on foot as he was seated in his car a short distance outside Bay 3, where he was cleaning his interior windshield.
The video, which lacks audio, shows one of the masked suspects pulling a handgun out of a tan bag that is on his waist and then pointing the weapon at the victim for a few seconds, before putting the firearm back into the pouch and running away, court records indicate.
Police reported that the victim told investigators that he did not respond to the threat made at gunpoint and that his resistance caused the suspects to flee.
In addition to the all-black clothing, two of the suspects wore ski masks to conceal their facial features, police said. The third — later identified as Meadows — was not wearing a ski mask, and that helped EPD investigators identify him, court records show.
"While walking away from the (victim) and nearer to the camera, the unmasked male with long brown curly hair is clearly identifiable as Aiden Meadows," according to the charging document.
The lead investigator, EPD Detective J. Jollie, notes in his written statement of probable cause that he is familiar with Meadows because of his "prior encounters and interactions" with him during his law enforcement career, court records show.
In that court document, Jollie also reports that he is familiar with Diebold.
"I am familiar with Aiden and his associates because of prior investigations regarding the theft of firearms and the theft of vehicles. One of the associates Aiden is known to commit these types of crimes with in the past is Landon Diebold. Diebold has a thin build and tall frame, similar to that of the perpetrator in the video that retrieves, displays and points the firearm toward (the victim)," court records allege.
In addition, according to the charging document, Diebold's distinctive tattoos, which could be seen on the security-camera footage, helped investigators identify him as a suspect — despite him wearing a ski mask.
"Diebold has tattoos on his hands. I then accessed Diebold's Instagram account . . . and reviewed his profile picture. Within this picture, Diebold's hand tattoos are visible and tattooed on his left hand is red lettering, directly next to a dark arch, which also is close in proximity to a dark round figure," Jollie explains in the written charging document.
EPD officers and detectives worked throughout the better part of Friday to identify, locate and arrest Diebold and Meadows, according to police. During a court-approved search, investigators found and confiscated two guns, police reported.
As of Tuesday, investigators still were trying to identify the third suspect. Anyone with information that might help in this investigation is asked to email EPD Detective Jollie at jjollie@elktonpd.org. EPD officials posted a press release about the alleged attempted carjacking on the agency's Facebook page on Monday morning, along with mugshots of Diebold and Meadows.
Diebold is facing 11 criminal charges, including first-degree assault, armed robbery, use of a handgun in the commission of a felony or a crime of violence, handgun on person and attempted carjacking, according to Cecil County District Court records.
Meadows is facing 10 criminal charges — all of them the same as those filed against Diebold, court records show. Meadows, however, is not charged with handgun on person — the additional charge that Diebold is facing, according to court records.
Both remained in the Cecil County Detention Center on no bond Tuesday, one day after their bail review hearings in front of Cecil County District Court Judge Clara E. Campbell, court records show.

title: Cambridge Police Chief proposes extending juvenile curfew
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Cambridge Police Chief proposes extending juvenile curfew

 August 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 500
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — At the Cambridge City Council meeting on Monday evening, Police Chief Justin Todd proposed extending the city's juvenile curfew, which first went into effect in 2023.The curfew was initially a five-month pilot program. The City Council extended the curfew for an additional year in September 2023 and again in 2024. On Monday, Todd introduced an ordinance that would extend the measure for a for another year.
The new ordinance maintains the same curfew for children under 16, with hours of 10 p.m. to 5 a.m Sunday through Thursday and 11 p.m. to 5 a.m. on Friday and Saturday. It also incorporates the new Cambridge Teen Court.
"I think it's a good way that we'll be able to work even closer with our juveniles and their parents for better outcomes down the road," Todd said.
The teen court program was established in May to identify and recognize early delinquent behavior and to work with first-time misdemeanor offenders and their guardians to develop a strategic plan to keep them out of the juvenile justice system.
Rather than facing a judge, juveniles appear before a court of their peers, where they are given a verdict of guilty or innocent.
The purpose of the curfew is not to hand out violations but to target children in the community who may need help and provide resources, Todd said. Curfew violations allow the authorities to connect with schools and social services to address underlying issues.
The implementation of the curfew has not significantly reduced crime, but Todd said it has helped identify children who may need additional support or resources.
"I can say that I've seen a better investment into the children alone. In other words, when we do have violations, we're able to incorporate that with Corporal Jones (school resource officer) out at the middle school to say, 'You know, is this child having issues at school as well?'" Todd said.
Todd said the new provisions added with the most recent curfew ordinance will help his department do more to connect children to resources.
This ordinance replaces the previously used "local care teams," with the newly founded Cambridge Teen Court so the police department can continue as an agency with keeping track of the behavior of youth instead of requesting that other agencies work to help find solutions.
The second reading of the ordinance will occur at the Sept. 22 city council meeting. Public comment and council discussion will follow the second reading before the council can vote on the measure. If passed, the curfew will go into effect on Oct. 1 and will expire Sept. 30, 2026.
"A lot of what we saw when we put the curfew in effect was that a large population of the juveniles that were out on the streets were obeying their curfew," Todd said. "It was only a small number that was not and that was an immediate indication to me that this alone is worth having into place because it's keeping our kids safe, it's putting them in the house when they need to be."

 A woman allegedly threatened to shoot her husband while brandishing his handgun inside their residence near North East, according to Cecil County District Court records.Investigators identified the suspect as 51-year-old Ammie L. Casula Creese, who is facing seven criminal charges, including first-degree assault, use of a handgun in the commission of a felony or a crime of violence and illegal possession of a regulated firearm, court records show.
First-degree assault is punishable by up to 25 years in prison and use of a handgun in the commission of a felony or a crime of violence carries a maximum 20-year sentence, with a mandatory five-year penalty. Illegal possession of a regulated firearm is punishable by up to 15 years in prison and it, too, carries a mandatory five-year sentence.
Creese remained in the Cecil County Detention Center on no bond Tuesday, one day after her bail review hearing in front of Cecil County District Court Judge Clara E. Campbell, court records show.
The investigation leading to Creese's arrest and the criminal charges against her started at approximately 6:30 p.m. on Saturday, Aug. 23, when Maryland State Police troopers rushed to a residence in the unit block of Cecil Avenue after receiving a dispatch regarding a domestic-related incident involving a firearm, police reported.
"The male caller stated that his wife had his gun and had threatened to shoot him," court records allege.
Police said Creese's 53-year-old husband was outside of the residence when troopers arrived. He told troopers that his wife still was inside the dwelling, on the second floor, and that she still had his firearm, police added.
Providing information about the incident, the husband told investigators that he was using his phone inside the den when he heard a "loud thunk" that came from the staircase, prompting him to investigate, court records show. He then saw a bowie knife and his loaded Smith & Wesson Bodyguard .380 caliber semi-automatic handgun on the landing, near his wife's feet, court records allege.
When he asked Creese why she had his gun, according to the account the suspect's husband gave investigators, she replied, "Who the (expletive) are you talking to?" court records allege.
Creese then picked up the gun and started to walk back up the stairs, according to the charging document, which further alleges, "Ammie had the gun in her hand and stated, 'I'll (expletive) shoot you with it'," before continuing up the stairs.
Her husband tried to find the gun, so he could remove the firearm from the home, but she had hidden it, police reported.
Shortly after arriving, troopers went upstairs, stood outside a closed second-floor door and gave "callouts" for Creese to exit that room, police said. After Creese obliged, a trooper conducted a pat-down search on her and no weapon was found, police added.
Moments later, while searching the room that Creese had occupied, an MSP trooper found the handgun in a closet, on top of a clothing rack, police reported. "The Smith&Wesson was loaded with one round in the chamber and five rounds in the magazine. The safety was on," according to the charging document.
Police arrested Creese at 7:05 p.m., about 35 minutes after arriving at the residence, court records show.
During the follow-up investigation, a trooper contacted the Maryland Gun Center and learned that Creese is prohibited from owning or possession a firearm, court records allege.

title: Trump threatens Key Bridge funds in ongoing feud
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@chespub.com
content:
Trump threatens Key Bridge funds in ongoing feud

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@chespub.com | Section: State News 
 
 571

 Read News Document

 President Donald Trump targeted Maryland Gov. Wes Moore (D) in a Truth Social post on Aug. 24, saying he may reconsider federal dollars for rebuilding the Francis Scott Key Bridge and could "send in the troops" to Baltimore.Over 2,000 National Guard troops are deployed in Washington, D.C., with Trump alluding to other potential deployments around the country, including Baltimore.
On Aug. 21, Moore wrote a letter to Trump, inviting him to Maryland to see the progress on crime that the state has made.
"There is no higher priority for me, as the governor of my state, than the safety of my people. This is an issue of both professional and personal significance. I grew up in and around communities left behind by people in power, who sought to weaponize the pain of their constituents through hollow talking points that never changed the reality on the ground," Moore wrote in the letter.
Moore cited recent crime statistics around the state, saying that he is deeply encouraged by the progress he has seen.
"Homicides in Maryland are down statewide by 20% since my inauguration two and a half years ago. In the first six months of 2025, the Baltimore Police Department continued to see double-digit reductions in gun violence, including a 22% decrease in homicides and a 19% decrease in non-fatal shootings from the year before," Moore wrote. "If there's anything Maryland has proven over the last two years, it's that we can achieve performance without being performative."
At the end of the letter, Moore invited Trump to attend a public safety walk in September on a date of the president's choosing.
"Governor Wes Moore of Maryland has asked, in a rather nasty and provocative tone, that I 'walk the streets of Maryland' with him," Trump wrote in a post on Truth Social on Aug. 24. "I assume he is talking about out-of-control, crime-ridden, Baltimore?"
Trump furthered that he "would much prefer that [Moore] clean up this crime disaster" before he comes to the area for a walk.
"Wes Moore's record on Crime is a very bad one, unless he fudges his figures on crime like many of the other 'Blue States' are doing. But if Wes Moore needs help, like Gavin Newscum [sic] did in [Los Angeles], I will send in the 'troops,' which is being done in nearby D.C., and quickly clean up the crime," Trump wrote.
Trump finished, saying that he gave "Moore a lot of money to fix his demolished bridge."
"I will now have to rethink that decision?" Trump said.
Moore responded to Trump's post on Truth Social, saying, "President Bone Spurs will do anything to get out of walking — even if that means spouting off more lies about the progress we're making on public safety in Maryland."

title: Ex-officers sue Ridgely, sheriff over disbanding force
author: Konner Metz
content:
Ex-officers sue Ridgely, sheriff over disbanding force

 September 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Push 
 
 568
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RIDGELY — Former Ridgely police officers have filed a lawsuit against the town and Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker, claiming the defendants "orchestrated a coup" to disband the now-defunct Ridgely Police Department.The lawsuit was filed Aug. 13 in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland by seven former officers, including former Police Chief Jeff Eckrich, and a civilian employee. Named as defendants are Baker, Chief Deputy Rodney Helmer, current and former town officials and a former Ridgely officer, as well as the State of Maryland and the Town of Ridgely.
The lawsuit includes 13 counts, claiming the defendants violated due process and the 14th Amendment, committed civil conspiracy and committed defamation.
One count claims the Ridgely Town Commissioners at the time — John Hurley, John Buckle and Anthony Casey — wrongfully discharged the police officers. Hurley is an active commissioner; Casey resigned in June 2024 and Buckle lost a reelection bid in April.
Baker declined to comment on the lawsuit when reached Tuesday evening, citing legal advice. Patrick Thomas, an attorney for the Town of Ridgely, wrote in an email that he can't "comment on pending litigation involving" clients.
Eckrich and former police department employees ask for the town to pay economic damages for lost wages and benefits, among other items. Plaintiffs are also seeking the court to demand the town reinstate its department and employees.
In March 2024, Ridgely commissioners suspended Eckrich and the entire department with pay pending an investigation by the state prosecutor. At the time, the town didn't indicate reasons for the investigation.
At a closed session meeting in April, the town laid off the dismissed officers and support staff, a move that took effect July 1, 2024.
Later that July, the Maryland Office of the State Prosecutor released a report in which it investigated Eckrich for "suspected" perjury and misconduct in office. The report found "no sufficient evidence" of the alleged criminal activity, closing its investigation into Eckrich.
Other officers were not investigated in that state prosecutor's report.
In September 2024, Ridgely commissioners stuck by their plans not to reinstate the police department despite heavy criticism from residents at town meetings.
By that time, the town had already sold police vehicles and equipment to nearby agencies, including the Caroline County Sheriff's Office. Those transactions were made in the days leading up to and following July 1, 2024, the effective date the officers were laid off.
The lawsuit alleges that the investigation by the Office of the State Prosecutor was based on allegations made by former Ridgely police officer James Joles, also named as a defendant. Joles, according to the lawsuit, blamed Eckrich for his threatened termination from the Ridgely force in January 2024 that led Joles to resign from the department.
The lawsuit claims Joles met with Baker, the sheriff, "and the two devised a plan that would eliminate the RPD and allow Sheriff's Office to assume responsibility for law enforcement in the Town of Ridgely."
The town has been under contract with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office for police coverage since. Currently, three county officers are dedicated to Ridgely patrol.
This May, the town opted to continue its memorandum of understanding with the Sheriff's Office, agreeing to pay $493,000 for policing services, according to the town's fiscal year 2026 budget.
This story has been updated to clarify the plaintiffs and defendant listed in the lawsuit. As of Sept. 2, this story has been updated to correct John Buckle's title as a former Ridgely commissioner.

title: Former Ridgely officer denies claims made in lawsuit
author: Konner Metz
content:
Former Ridgely officer denies claims made in lawsuit

 September 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 900
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RIDGELY — A former Ridgely police officer is denying claims made in a federal lawsuit that he conspired with town officials and the Caroline County sheriff to disband the town's police department.James Joles resigned as a Ridgely police officer in January 2024, about two months before the now-defunct agency was suspended last year. Joles said in an interview Wednesday that he had "nothing to do" with the town's decision to suspend and later lay off his former colleagues.
Ridgely Police Department officers and employees were laid off by the town effective July 1, 2024, a move that came as the Office of the State Prosecutor actively investigated Police Chief Jeff Eckrich for "suspected" perjury and misconduct stemming from documentation provided by Joles.
Later that July, that investigation found "no sufficient evidence" of criminal activity.
Eckrich, six former officers and a former civilian employee filed a lawsuit on Aug. 13 in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland. They claim, among other allegations, that Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker "orchestrated a coup" — with assistance from Joles and town officials — to disband the police department.
Listed as defendants are Baker, Deputy Chief Rodney Helmer, current Commissioner John Hurley, former Commissioners Anthony Casey and John Buckle, three town employees, Joles, the Town of Ridgely and the State of Maryland.
Baker declined to comment, citing legal advice. An attorney for the Town of Ridgely did not respond to questions, citing the pending litigation. Others could not be reached for comment.
The lawsuit specifically alleges that "sometime prior to February 23, 2024, Joles met with Baker and the two devised a plan that would eliminate the RPD and allow the Sheriff's Office to assume responsibility" for police services in Ridgely.
Joles told The Star Democrat that he and Baker only met once, when they exchanged greetings in December 2023.
"I've met him once at a Christmas party," Joles said. "I might've had maybe a four-word conversation. That's how short it was."
TIME IN RIDGELY
Joles said upon joining the Ridgely Police Department at the rank of corporal in the spring of 2023, he was in charge of reviewing the department's body-worn camera footage and tracking firearms and ammunition. He documented issues in the two areas, he said.
Weapons and firearms were not properly stored and secured, he said. And after reviewing body-worn camera videos, Joles said Eckrich responded to calls with "no police identification, carrying a firearm."
"No badge, and he's responding to calls," Joles said. "It rose concern. And I tried bringing it up to him, and it didn't go anywhere. It kinda just got pushed to the wayside."
In January 2024, after a disagreement about a time-off request, Joles said Eckrich "threatened" to fire him if he didn't resign. Joles said the chief told him he wasn't a "good fit."
The lawsuit filed last month, however, claims Ridgely commissioners voted to fire Joles "without consulting Eckrich." Joles resigned before he was fired.
An attorney for Eckrich and other plaintiffs did not immediately respond Wednesday afternoon to a question about the nature of Joles' potential termination and whether Eckrich was aware of it.
Joles presented his documentation of police misconduct to town officials at a closed session meeting on March 11, 2024, according to the state prosecutor's report.
Joles, who has since left the law enforcement field and lives in Delaware, said town officials asked him to share his documentation of conduct by Eckrich and the police department during an exit interview process following his resignation.
"They asked me some questions, I answered all of them, and they were more concerned about me suing them," Joles said.
The lawsuit against Joles claims he made false allegations that Eckrich "knowingly withheld disclosing that Joles was on a Brady list in Delaware" when he was hired. A Brady list contains records of alleged officer misconduct or complaints.
Plaintiffs claim Joles didn't disclose the Brady list matter during an interview for the Ridgely job. Joles said he did discuss the matter in the interview, according to texts from after his resignation included in court records.
LAWSUIT
The lawsuit levied by Eckrich and his former colleagues includes 13 counts, claiming the defendants violated due process and the 14th Amendment, committed civil conspiracy and committed defamation.
One count claims the Ridgely commissioners wrongfully discharged the police officers and civilian employee.
The commissioners initially suspended Eckrich and the department with pay in March 2024, pending the state prosecutor's investigation. At the time, the town didn't indicate reason for the investigation nor did it clarify that only Eckrich was under investigation.
Eckrich's lawsuit terms the alleged "coup" as a "power grab" by Baker to "expand his office's jurisdiction" by taking over for the defunct Ridgely police.
On April 1, 2024, the town entered into a temporary contract with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office for police coverage. According to documents in the federal lawsuit, Baker emailed town officials three days later with cost estimates "for the Sheriff's Office to assume the Ridgely Police Department" full-time.
At a closed session meeting in April, the town laid off the dismissed officers and support staff, a move that took effect July 1, 2024. Ridgely commissioners have since entered into long-term contracts with the sheriff's office for police coverage, most recently signing one this May.
In the lawsuit, plaintiffs are seeking economic damages for lost wages and benefits, among other items. They're also asking the court to demand Ridgely reinstate its police department and employees.
This story has been updated to correct John Buckle's title as a former Ridgely commissioner.

 BALTIMORE — A federal grand jury returned an indictment against Stephen Nicholas Westcott, 35, of Kennedyville, charging him with sexual exploitation of a child, distribution of child sexual abuse material, possession of child sexual abuse material and illegal possession of an unregistered silencer.Law enforcement arrested Westcott in Manistee County, Michigan, after he fled Maryland to avoid arrest when a warrant was issued in February.
Kelly O. Hayes, U.S. attorney for the District of Maryland, announced the indictment with Special Agent in Charge William J. DelBagno, Federal Bureau of Investigation Baltimore Field Office; Special Agent in Charge Charles Doerrer, Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives; Col. Roland L. Butler, Maryland State Police; James A. Dellmyer, state's attorney for Cecil County; and Bryan DiGregory, state's attorney for Kent County.
According to the 13-count indictment, Westcott produced sexually explicit images of a young child under the age of 5. Westcott also communicated and distributed child sexual abuse materials over various internet platforms including Snapchat, Discord, and Telegram while maintaining a collection of child sexual abuse material on his personal electronic devices.
If convicted, Westcott faces a mandatory minimum sentence of 15 years and a maximum sentence of 30 years in federal prison for each count of Sexual Exploitation of a Child, and a mandatory minimum sentence of five years and a maximum sentence of 20 years for each count of Distribution of Child Pornography. Additionally, Westcott is facing a maximum sentence of 20 years for each count of Possession of Child Pornography and a maximum 10-year sentence for the count of Possession of an Unregistered Silencer.
According to the press release issued Sept. 4, by the U.S. Attorney's Office, actual sentences for federal crimes are typically less than the maximum penalties. A federal district court judge determines sentencing after considering the U.S. Sentencing Guidelines and other statutory factors. An indictment is not a finding of guilt. An individual charged by indictment is presumed innocent until proven guilty at a later criminal proceeding.
This case is also part of Project Safe Childhood, a nationwide initiative launched in May 2006 by the Department of Justice to combat the growing epidemic of child sexual exploitation and abuse. Led by the United States Attorney's Offices and the Criminal Division's Child Exploitation and Obscenity Section, Project Safe Childhood marshals federal, state, and local resources to locate, apprehend, and prosecute individuals who sexually exploit children, and to identify and rescue victims.
U.S. Attorney Hayes commended the FBI, ATF, and MSP for their work in the investigation, and the Manistee County Sheriff's Office and FBI Detroit for their valuable assistance. Hayes also thanked Assistant U.S. Attorney Colleen E. McGuinn who is prosecuting the federal case.

Police fatally shoot Cambridge man Thursday evening

 On Thursday evening, a Cambridge police officer fatally shot a man who the police department said was armed with a knife and threatening advances toward officers.According to a release from the Cambridge Police Department, a Cambridge Police officer assigned to the Patrol Division shot the man multiple times after the man "advanced on officers" with the knife. The man was transported by Maryland State Police Aviation to Tidal Health Peninsula Regional Medical Center in Salisbury, where he later died.
The man, described in the release as a "30-year-old Caucasian male from Cambridge," has not been publicly identified. The police officer who shot the man has also not been publicly identified.
According to the release, shortly after 5 p.m. Thursday, officers responded to the Deep Harbor development around Seaway Lane and Riverview Wharf in reference to a report of a male subject chasing a female subject with a knife.
When officers arrived, they encountered a male subject who was armed with a knife, police said. Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd said three officers were on the scene.
"Officers on scene attempted to deescalate the situation and have the subject drop the knife," the release said. "The subject refused and advanced on officers. Officers gave warnings for the subject to stop as they were attempting to retreat."
Police said the subject continued to engage and approach the officers, leading to one officer shooting the man.
"Officers immediately rendered life saving measures to the subject awaiting EMS arrival," the release said. "After EMS arrived, the subject was transported to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Cambridge prior to being flown by Maryland State Police Aviation to Tidal Health Peninsula Regional Medical Center in Salisbury."
According to Todd, this is Cambridge's first fatal police shooting in approximately 15 years.
The incident is being investigated by the Maryland attorney general's office's Independent Investigations Division, which investigates all officer-involved fatalities in the state. Todd said the officer who discharged their weapon has been placed on paid administrative leave until the investigation is complete.
Todd said press releases and body-worn camera footage will be released to the public as part of the transparency process.
"I think the main thing I want to say is my condolences to the family of the subject that succumbed to his injuries. Unfortunately, it's a sad situation," Todd said. "And speaking with some of the family, I just feel there needs to be thoughts and prayers kept for them as well."

title: Woman charged for graffiti acts at Sts. Peter and Paul Elementary
author: Konner Metz
content:
Woman charged for graffiti acts at Sts. Peter and Paul Elementary

 September 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 719
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A woman is being held at the Talbot County Detention Center after being accused of spray-painting graffiti around town, including at Sts. Peter and Paul Elementary School.Sian Radaskiewicz-King, 32, was arrested Friday by Easton police on charges of malicious destruction of property and use of a hate symbol. She was later charged with defacing religious property and disturbing school operations, among other counts.
According to court documents, King allegedly spray-painted the transgender symbol on dumpsters, the sidewalk and a step outside the Catholic school off of Route 50. Other spray-painted symbols were found on a fence at the Hampton Inn next to the school, per court records.
The symbols were found elsewhere in town, including outside East End Liquors, The Market at Dover Station and other businesses. The transgender symbol, often used to encourage gender inclusivity, is a combination of the male and female signs.
At an unusually crowded bail hearing on Monday afternoon, Talbot County District Court Judge Karen Ketterman ordered King to be held without bond in the Detention Center. A trial is scheduled for Oct. 28.
Many parents and school officials from Sts. Peter and Paul filled the courtroom. School Board Chair Peggy Wilson asked Ketterman to not approve King's release. Wilson cited the Aug. 27 shooting at Annunciation Catholic School in Minneapolis, which killed two children and injured 18 people, as a reason why the school community is concerned for the safety of students.
"Our fear is not the symbol itself, but the possibility of a copycat situation," Wilson said.
King, according to public legal representation, is transgender. She previously attended Sts. Peter and Paul School.
The Minneapolis shooter, Robin Westman, was referred to as transgender by federal officials. Westman's gender identity wasn't clear, according to The Associated Press.
Easton Mayor Megan Cook said in a statement this weekend that the graffiti incidents are "especially painful" given the Minneapolis Catholic school shooting.
"It reminds us of the responsibility we all share to ensure our children's safety and well-being," Cook wrote. "We condemn such acts of intimidation, they have no place in our community."
In a statement Sunday, the Delmarva Pride Center condemned the graffiti acts as a "misuse" of the international transgender symbol.
"We are deeply troubled that an LGBTQIA+ symbol was misused in a way that could be construed as hateful," the statement read. "Symbols such as the Transgender Symbol exist to affirm identity, celebrate diversity, and foster belonging — not to spread fear or division.
"This incident occurs at a time when Transgender people continue to face targeted attacks in society. We call on our neighbors, allies, and community members to stand together, to reject hate in all its forms, and to embrace the values of acceptance, compassion, and love."
On Monday, Easton Police Deputy Chief Greg Wright said the agency will increase patrol this week at Sts. Peter and Paul School and other schools in town. He said police "have no reason to believe that there was any attempt or desire to harm anyone."
BOND DECISION
Bridgette Lane, an assistant at the Talbot County public defender's office, argued in court on Monday that King should be granted release based on the low severity of charges, an otherwise clean criminal record and the Detention Center's recommendation.
Lane said King has "expressed remorse" and understands "she can't be acting out in these ways."
King, who is listed as having a Baltimore address, was recently staying in Easton with her mother, Lane said. If released, the expectation was for King to stay with her mother.
Talbot County State's Attorney Joseph Coale said the graffiti incident is concerning due to the context of the Minneapolis shooting last month, as well as the fact that King's mother's house is close to the school.
"Here we have this clear warning sign," Coale said. " ... We don't know if the defendant is capable of carrying out something worse. But the state doesn't want to find out."
Ketterman said both sides made good points, but she hammered home that there are "no conditions of release" that would ensure the safety of the community. The judge said she's concerned about the location of the graffiti and King's documented mental health diagnoses, which include bipolar disorder and PTSD.
"I don't think the court has another choice," Ketterman said after ruling no bond and ordering the defendant complete a mental health evaluation.
Information from The Associated Press contributed to this report.

title: First responders learn about silo and grain rescues
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
First responders learn about silo and grain rescues

 September 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 564
 Words 

 Read News Document

 KENNEDYVILLE — City firefighters have to deal with issues that rural counties usually do not. For example, there are very few high rises in Kent County.That works both ways though.
City firefighters do not typically have to go into grain or corn silos for rescues. But Kent County firefighters may have to.
And they have the equipment to do it. They are called grain rescue devices and because of a grant, Kennedyville Volunteer Fire Department now has one in addition to the devices already at fire departments in Millington and Rock Hall.
"Kent County, Maryland, is noted for a few things," retired firefighter Larry Slagle said, speaking for the Chestertown Volunteer Fire Company.
"Among those, is our agricultural interests. We have any number of farmers whose primary interest is growing and processing grain products," he said. "And for efficiency, these farmers maintain grain bins, aka silos, on their farms."
Slagle said that occasionally, especially during grain harvest season, personnel may have to enter the silo, perhaps to clear a blockage or discern what the problem may be.
"This is one of the most dangerous things they will ever do," he added.
Slagle's post indicated that that the suction of the grain material as it's being unloaded at the bottom, is as dangerous as the riptide or undertow at the ocean.
"Across the United States and even the entire world, many farm workers have entered this environmen … and lost their lives."
Fire official experts concur with Slagle and Chestertown fire company, saying that about 55 grain bin entrapment events happen around the United States, many in Midwest states. Farmers and workers can get caught in equipment, submerged in grain or experience a medical event while working.
That is why the training with the equipment was instrumental for local firefighters.
On July 21, Slagle reported that fire companies from Chestertown, Galena, Betterton, Chestertown, Millington, Rock Hall and Marydel attended a regional training program, hosted by the Kennedyville Volunteer Fire Company with the topic: "Grain bin emergencies and how to safely mitigate them."
Classes were conducted by members of the National Education Center for Agricultural Safety.
Slagle said, "This training is especially invaluable to us, as sometimes emergency responders are sometimes the victims themselves."
After a period of classroom discussion, the activity transitioned outside to the training trailer.
Through specialized engineering, a grain bin was fashioned, and the "suction" phenomenon duplicated, in a safe manner, he pointed out.
Former member of the Kennedyville firefighter, farmer and owner of Philips Trucking, Josh Philips said that the equipment is a series of 6-8 aluminum panels, interconnected tubes with an auger, a spiral tool used to drill.
During the training, the tube was placed around the mock accident victim and the auger extracted the grain that was simulating suffocating them.
First responders practiced methods like ropes; confined space operations; patient care and packaging.
"At any time during the exercise, should something with the training go sideways, instructors could terminate the process and drain away the grain product," Slagle pointed out.
Everything was conducted safely and first responders left with a sense of confidence in the training, he added.
Kennedyville Assistant Chief Mark Dixon thanked Philips who had nominated Kennedyville for the grant to make the equipment possible.
Slagle said, "In the fire service, we have a mantra. 'It is not acceptable for anyone to be injured, or even die, because of training. It's the purpose of training to prevent that very serious, even tragic outcome … during a real emergency.'"

title: Attorney general identifies man, officer in Cambridge fatal police shooting
author: Lily Tierney

Attorney general identifies man, officer in Cambridge fatal police shooting

 September 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Crime 
 
 213
 Words

 CAMBRIDGE — The Maryland Office of the Attorney General identified an armed man killed by a Cambridge police officer Thursday, as well as the officer involved in the shooting.The deceased was identified Monday as 30-year-old Ryan Garcy of Cambridge. No further information about Garcy was released Monday.
Cpl. Jacob Weber was identified as the officer who shot Garcy. Weber has been with the Cambridge Police Department for six years and is with the patrol division, according to the attorney general's office.
Weber has been placed on paid administrative leave until the investigation is finished, according to Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd.
According to a release from the Cambridge Police Department, Weber shot Garcy multiple times after Garcy allegedly "advanced on officers" with the knife. The attorney general's office said last week that officers unsuccessfully deployed tasers twice before Garcy was shot.
Garcy was transported by Maryland State Police Aviation to Tidal Health Peninsula Regional Medical Center in Salisbury, where he later died.
According to Todd, this is Cambridge's first fatal police shooting in about 15 years.
The incident is being investigated by the Maryland attorney general's office's Independent Investigations Division, which investigates all officer-involved fatalities in the state. Todd said press releases and body-worn camera footage will be released to the public as part of the transparency process.

title: Sheriff: Youth justice laws add to crime
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Sheriff: Youth justice laws add to crime

 September 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Crime 
 
 539
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — In the past week, there have been three juvenile arrests related to violent crimes in the City of Cambridge.Dorchester County Sheriff Jimmy Phillips said this level of violent crime is "not normal" and officers feel their hands are tied by the current juvenile justice laws Phillips said lack accountability.
On the second day of school at Cambridge-South Dorchester High School last week, two students were arrested after assaulting the school safety monitor. Phillips described the scene as a "melee."
Phillips said three sheriff's deputies were spat on and the school safety monitor was taken to the hospital. Two boys, ages 14 and 15, were arrested following the incident.
The 15-year-old boy, Jaheem Mortaz Brown, was released to his step-father's custody. Three days later, the Brown allegedly shot his step-father in the face. The extent of the step-father's injuries has not been disclosed.
In addition, Phillips said Cambridge police received a call this weekend that juveniles around 11 years old were shoplifting from the Wawa on Sunburst Highway.
"They're shoplifting because they know they (the juvenile system) can't do nothing with them," Phillips said.
Phillips said the problem of juvenile crime will continue until the "broken juvenile justice system" is changed.
"The juvenile justice system in the state of Maryland is broken; it's not working," he said. "We're not holding anybody accountable."
The former Secretary of the Department of Juvenile Services, Vincent Schiraldi received intense backlash from Mid-Shore sheriffs, including Phillips. The Maryland Sheriffs Association sent a letter to Gov. Wes Moore calling for Schiraldi's immediate resignation last year. Schiraldi stepped down from the position in June.
"Consistently in Maryland, juveniles have been charged with serious violent crimes," the letter states, "only to be turned right back over to a parent or guardian, and back out on the streets to commit more crimes."
After an in-person community meeting with the secretary around two years ago, Phillips said "He had the audacity to tell us, 'The data that I'm receiving doesn't support your claim of increased juvenile crime,'" Phillips recalled. "And our reply to that was, 'Well, obviously the numbers are going to go down because you're not allowing us to charge (them) anymore.'"
In 2022, the Maryland General Assembly passed a juvenile justice reform bill stressing rehabilitation rather than punishment in addressing juvenile behavioral issues, according to its proponents. The reform took effect in 2024.
In August, the Cambridge Police Department presented its quarterly report, which revealed that overall crime decreased, but there were concerns regarding homicides, robberies and juvenile violence.
Homicides, assaults, larceny and motor vehicle theft all increased from the second quarter in 2024. The homicide rate rose 200%, with two homicides that both led to arrests. One of those homicides was committed by a juvenile.
Phillips said this level of violent crime in Cambridge is not normal.
"I mean, it's not normal anywhere, but I think the biggest contributing factor we had last week is the failure of our juvenile system," he said.
Last school year, students in Dorchester County saw 1,682 long- and short-term suspensions with 1,232 of those suspensions related to violence, according to Dorchester County Public Schools Superintendent Jymil Thompson.
In an attempt to curb suspensions, Dorchester County Public Schools launched a violence prevention initiative course for students, teachers, parents and staff to ensure there is community participation.

title: Juvenile identified in Cambridge shooting
author: Lily Tierney

Juvenile identified in Cambridge shooting

 September 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Crime

 CAMBRIDGE — The juvenile who allegedly shot his step-father in the face on Friday has been identified by Cambridge Police.According to a press release from the Cambridge Police Department, Jaheem Mortaz Brown, 15, of Cambridge was arrested without incident Friday. Police said they were made aware of the shooting by Brown's mother, who drove to the police department and reported that her son had shot her husband in the face.
Brown was arrested the Tuesday before at Cambridge-South Dorchester High School for allegedly assaulting the school safety officer, but he was released the same day to the custody of his step-father according to Dorchester County Sheriff Jimmy Phillips.
{p class="p1"}"He was one of the people involved in this melee at Cambridge-South Dorchester High School last week," Phillips said.
According to the press release from the Cambridge Police Department, a witness, who was sitting in a vehicle on Skinners Court, alleges Brown struck her vehicle before his step-father exited the residence. Brown allegedly brandished a firearm and shot the step-father in the face before fleeing on foot to High Street.
Upon arriving at the scene, officers found Brown exiting the family's residence, where he was arrested. They also found one spent shell casing, but police did not recover the weapon, the press release said.
Police said officers and detectives were flagged down near the Park Lane and Camper Street area, where a man was hunched over and bleeding from his mouth. The 34-year-old man was identified as Brown's step-father.
He suffered a gunshot wound to the right cheek, and Dorchester County EMS transported him to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Cambridge. He was then flown to Shock Trauma by Maryland State Police Aviation. The severity of his injuries has not been disclosed.
Due to current Maryland Juvenile Reform Laws, Brown was not able to be questioned following the incident, police said. The reason for the crime and the whereabouts of the gun are still unknown, they said.
Brown has been turned over to the Dorchester County Department of Corrections without bond and is being tried as an adult. He is facing nine charges: attempted murder in the first and second degree, assault in the first and second degree, reckless endangerment, handgun on person, loaded handgun on person, firearm use in a felony violent crime and the possession of a firearm for a minor.

title: Easton woman pleads guilty to destruction of property for political sign vandalism

Easton woman pleads guilty to destruction of property for political sign vandalism
